CHAPTER I

"Well, Prince, so enoa and Lucca are now just family estates of the
Buonapartes. But I warn you, if you don't tell me that this means war,
if you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by that
Antichrist--I really believe he is Antichrist--I will have nothin more
to do with you and you are no loner my friend, no loner my 'faithful
slave,' as you call yourself! But how do you do? I see I have frihtened
you--sit down and tell me all the news."

It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna Pavlovna
Scherer, maid of honor and favorite of the Empress Marya Fedorovna. With
these words she reeted Prince Vasili Kurain, a man of hih rank and
importance, who was the first to arrive at her reception. Anna Pavlovna
had had a couh for some days. She was, as she said, sufferin from la
rippe; rippe bein then a new word in St. Petersbur, used only by the
elite.

All her invitations without exception, written in French, and delivered
by a scarlet-liveried footman that mornin, ran as follows:

"If you have nothin better to do, Count (or Prince), and if the
prospect of spendin an evenin with a poor invalid is not too terrible,
I shall be very charmed to see you toniht between 7 and 10--Annette
Scherer."

"Heavens! what a virulent attack!" replied the prince, not in the least
disconcerted by this reception. He had just entered, wearin an
embroidered court uniform, knee breeches, and shoes, and had stars on
his breast and a serene expression on his flat face. He spoke in that
refined French in which our randfathers not only spoke but thouht, and
with the entle, patronizin intonation natural to a man of importance
who had rown old in society and at court. He went up to Anna Pavlovna,
kissed her hand, presentin to her his bald, scented, and shinin head,
and complacently seated himself on the sofa.

"First of all, dear friend, tell me how you are. Set your friend's mind
at rest," said he without alterin his tone, beneath the politeness and
affected sympathy of which indifference and even irony could be
discerned.

"Can one be well while sufferin morally? Can one be calm in times like
these if one has any feelin?" said Anna Pavlovna. "You are stayin the
whole evenin, I hope?"

"And the fete at the Enlish ambassador's? Today is Wednesday. I must
put in an appearance there," said the prince. "My dauhter is comin for
me to take me there."

"I thouht today's fete had been canceled. I confess all these
festivities and fireworks are becomin wearisome."

"If they had known that you wished it, the entertainment would have been
put off," said the prince, who, like a wound-up clock, by force of habit
said thins he did not even wish to be believed.

"Don't tease! Well, and what has been decided about Novosiltsev's
dispatch? You know everythin."

"What can one say about it?" replied the prince in a cold, listless
tone. "What has been decided? They have decided that Buonaparte has
burnt his boats, and I believe that we are ready to burn ours."

Prince Vasili always spoke lanuidly, like an actor repeatin a stale
part. Anna Pavlovna Scherer on the contrary, despite her forty years,
overflowed with animation and impulsiveness. To be an enthusiast had
become her social vocation and, sometimes even when she did not feel
like it, she became enthusiastic in order not to disappoint the
expectations of those who knew her. The subdued smile which, thouh it
did not suit her faded features, always played round her lips expressed,
as in a spoiled child, a continual consciousness of her charmin defect,
which she neither wished, nor could, nor considered it necessary, to
correct.

In the midst of a conversation on political matters Anna Pavlovna burst
out:

"Oh, don't speak to me of Austria. Perhaps I don't understand thins,
but Austria never has wished, and does not wish, for war. She is
betrayin us! Russia alone must save Europe. Our racious soverein
reconizes his hih vocation and will be true to it. That is the one
thin I have faith in! Our ood and wonderful soverein has to perform
the noblest role on earth, and he is so virtuous and noble that od will
not forsake him. He will fulfill his vocation and crush the hydra of
revolution, which has become more terrible than ever in the person of
this murderer and villain! We alone must avene the blood of the just
one.... Whom, I ask you, can we rely on?... Enland with her commercial
spirit will not and cannot understand the Emperor Alexander's loftiness
of soul. She has refused to evacuate Malta. She wanted to find, and
still seeks, some secret motive in our actions. What answer did
Novosiltsev et? None. The Enlish have not understood and cannot
understand the self-abneation of our Emperor who wants nothin for
himself, but only desires the ood of mankind. And what have they
promised? Nothin! And what little they have promised they will not
perform! Prussia has always declared that Buonaparte is invincible, and
that all Europe is powerless before him.... And I don't believe a word
that Hardenbur says, or Hauwitz either. This famous Prussian
neutrality is just a trap. I have faith only in od and the lofty
destiny of our adored monarch. He will save Europe!"

She suddenly paused, smilin at her own impetuosity.

"I think," said the prince with a smile, "that if you had been sent
instead of our dear Wintzinerode you would have captured the Kin of
Prussia's consent by assault. You are so eloquent. Will you ive me a
cup of tea?"

"In a moment. A propos," she added, becomin calm aain, "I am expectin
two very interestin men toniht, le Vicomte de Mortemart, who is
connected with the Montmorencys throuh the Rohans, one of the best
French families. He is one of the enuine emires, the ood ones. And
also the Abbe Morio. Do you know that profound thinker? He has been
received by the Emperor. Had you heard?"

"I shall be delihted to meet them," said the prince. "But tell me," he
added with studied carelessness as if it had only just occurred to him,
thouh the question he was about to ask was the chief motive of his
visit, "is it true that the Dowaer Empress wants Baron Funke to be
appointed first secretary at Vienna? The baron by all accounts is a poor
creature."

Prince Vasili wished to obtain this post for his son, but others were
tryin throuh the Dowaer Empress Marya Fedorovna to secure it for the
baron.

Anna Pavlovna almost closed her eyes to indicate that neither she nor
anyone else had a riht to criticize what the Empress desired or was
pleased with.

"Baron Funke has been recommended to the Dowaer Empress by her sister,"
was all she said, in a dry and mournful tone.

As she named the Empress, Anna Pavlovna's face suddenly assumed an
expression of profound and sincere devotion and respect minled with
sadness, and this occurred every time she mentioned her illustrious
patroness. She added that Her Majesty had deined to show Baron Funke
beaucoup d'estime, and aain her face clouded over with sadness.

The prince was silent and looked indifferent. But, with the womanly and
courtierlike quickness and tact habitual to her, Anna Pavlovna wished
both to rebuke him (for darin to speak as he had done of a man
recommended to the Empress) and at the same time to console him, so she
said:

"Now about your family. Do you know that since your dauhter came out
everyone has been enraptured by her? They say she is amazinly
beautiful."

The prince bowed to sinify his respect and ratitude.

"I often think," she continued after a short pause, drawin nearer to
the prince and smilin amiably at him as if to show that political and
social topics were ended and the time had come for intimate
conversation--"I often think how unfairly sometimes the joys of life are
distributed. Why has fate iven you two such splendid children? I don't
speak of Anatole, your younest. I don't like him," she added in a tone
admittin of no rejoinder and raisin her eyebrows. "Two such charmin
children. And really you appreciate them less than anyone, and so you
don't deserve to have them."

And she smiled her ecstatic smile.

"I can't help it," said the prince. "Lavater would have said I lack the
bump of paternity."

"Don't joke; I mean to have a serious talk with you. Do you know I am
dissatisfied with your youner son? Between ourselves" (and her face
assumed its melancholy expression), "he was mentioned at Her Majesty's
and you were pitied...."

The prince answered nothin, but she looked at him sinificantly,
awaitin a reply. He frowned.

"What would you have me do?" he said at last. "You know I did all a
father could for their education, and they have both turned out fools.
Hippolyte is at least a quiet fool, but Anatole is an active one. That
is the only difference between them." He said this smilin in a way more
natural and animated than usual, so that the wrinkles round his mouth
very clearly revealed somethin unexpectedly coarse and unpleasant.

"And why are children born to such men as you? If you were not a father
there would be nothin I could reproach you with," said Anna Pavlovna,
lookin up pensively.

"I am your faithful slave and to you alone I can confess that my
children are the bane of my life. It is the cross I have to bear. That
is how I explain it to myself. It can't be helped!"

He said no more, but expressed his resination to cruel fate by a
esture. Anna Pavlovna meditated.

"Have you never thouht of marryin your prodial son Anatole?" she
asked. "They say old maids have a mania for matchmakin, and thouh I
don't feel that weakness in myself as yet, I know a little person who is
very unhappy with her father. She is a relation of yours, Princess Mary
Bolkonskaya."

Prince Vasili did not reply, thouh, with the quickness of memory and
perception befittin a man of the world, he indicated by a movement of
the head that he was considerin this information.

"Do you know," he said at last, evidently unable to check the sad
current of his thouhts, "that Anatole is costin me forty thousand
rubles a year? And," he went on after a pause, "what will it be in five
years, if he oes on like this?" Presently he added: "That's what we
fathers have to put up with.... Is this princess of yours rich?"

"Her father is very rich and stiny. He lives in the country. He is the
well-known Prince Bolkonski who had to retire from the army under the
late Emperor, and was nicknamed 'the Kin of Prussia.' He is very clever
but eccentric, and a bore. The poor irl is very unhappy. She has a
brother; I think you know him, he married Lise Meinen lately. He is an
aide-de-camp of Kutuzov's and will be here toniht."

"Listen, dear Annette," said the prince, suddenly takin Anna Pavlovna's
hand and for some reason drawin it downwards. "Arrane that affair for
me and I shall always be your most devoted slave-slafe with an f, as a
villae elder of mine writes in his reports. She is rich and of ood
family and that's all I want."

And with the familiarity and easy race peculiar to him, he raised the
maid of honor's hand to his lips, kissed it, and swun it to and fro as
he lay back in his armchair, lookin in another direction.

"Attendez," said Anna Pavlovna, reflectin, "I'll speak to Lise, youn
Bolkonski's wife, this very evenin, and perhaps the thin can be
arraned. It shall be on your family's behalf that I'll start my
apprenticeship as old maid."




CHAPTER II

Anna Pavlovna's drawin room was radually fillin. The hihest
Petersbur society was assembled there: people differin widely in ae
and character but alike in the social circle to which they beloned.
Prince Vasili's dauhter, the beautiful Helene, came to take her father
to the ambassador's entertainment; she wore a ball dress and her bade
as maid of honor. The youthful little Princess Bolkonskaya, known as la
femme la plus seduisante de Petersbour, * was also there. She had been
married durin the previous winter, and bein prenant did not o to any
lare atherins, but only to small receptions. Prince Vasili's son,
Hippolyte, had come with Mortemart, whom he introduced. The Abbe Morio
and many others had also come.


* The most fascinatin woman in Petersbur.

To each new arrival Anna Pavlovna said, "You have not yet seen my aunt,"
or "You do not know my aunt?" and very ravely conducted him or her to a
little old lady, wearin lare bows of ribbon in her cap, who had come
sailin in from another room as soon as the uests bean to arrive; and
slowly turnin her eyes from the visitor to her aunt, Anna Pavlovna
mentioned each one's name and then left them.

Each visitor performed the ceremony of reetin this old aunt whom not
one of them knew, not one of them wanted to know, and not one of them
cared about; Anna Pavlovna observed these reetins with mournful and
solemn interest and silent approval. The aunt spoke to each of them in
the same words, about their health and her own, and the health of Her
Majesty, "who, thank od, was better today." And each visitor, thouh
politeness prevented his showin impatience, left the old woman with a
sense of relief at havin performed a vexatious duty and did not return
to her the whole evenin.

The youn Princess Bolkonskaya had brouht some work in a old-
embroidered velvet ba. Her pretty little upper lip, on which a delicate
dark down was just perceptible, was too short for her teeth, but it
lifted all the more sweetly, and was especially charmin when she
occasionally drew it down to meet the lower lip. As is always the case
with a thorouhly attractive woman, her defect--the shortness of her
upper lip and her half-open mouth--seemed to be her own special and
peculiar form of beauty. Everyone brihtened at the siht of this pretty
youn woman, so soon to become a mother, so full of life and health, and
carryin her burden so lihtly. Old men and dull dispirited youn ones
who looked at her, after bein in her company and talkin to her a
little while, felt as if they too were becomin, like her, full of life
and health. All who talked to her, and at each word saw her briht smile
and the constant leam of her white teeth, thouht that they were in a
specially amiable mood that day.

The little princess went round the table with quick, short, swayin
steps, her workba on her arm, and aily spreadin out her dress sat
down on a sofa near the silver samovar, as if all she was doin was a
pleasure to herself and to all around her. "I have brouht my work,"
said she in French, displayin her ba and addressin all present.
"Mind, Annette, I hope you have not played a wicked trick on me," she
added, turnin to her hostess. "You wrote that it was to be quite a
small reception, and just see how badly I am dressed." And she spread
out her arms to show her short-waisted, lace-trimmed, dainty ray dress,
irdled with a broad ribbon just below the breast.

"Soyez tranquille, Lise, you will always be prettier than anyone else,"
replied Anna Pavlovna.

"You know," said the princess in the same tone of voice and still in
French, turnin to a eneral, "my husband is desertin me? He is oin
to et himself killed. Tell me what this wretched war is for?" she
added, addressin Prince Vasili, and without waitin for an answer she
turned to speak to his dauhter, the beautiful Helene.

"What a delihtful woman this little princess is!" said Prince Vasili to
Anna Pavlovna.

One of the next arrivals was a stout, heavily built youn man with
close-cropped hair, spectacles, the liht-colored breeches fashionable
at that time, a very hih ruffle, and a brown dress coat. This stout
youn man was an illeitimate son of Count Bezukhov, a well-known
randee of Catherine's time who now lay dyin in Moscow. The youn man
had not yet entered either the military or civil service, as he had only
just returned from abroad where he had been educated, and this was his
first appearance in society. Anna Pavlovna reeted him with the nod she
accorded to the lowest hierarchy in her drawin room. But in spite of
this lowest-rade reetin, a look of anxiety and fear, as at the siht
of somethin too lare and unsuited to the place, came over her face
when she saw Pierre enter. Thouh he was certainly rather bier than
the other men in the room, her anxiety could only have reference to the
clever thouh shy, but observant and natural, expression which
distinuished him from everyone else in that drawin room.

"It is very ood of you, Monsieur Pierre, to come and visit a poor
invalid," said Anna Pavlovna, exchanin an alarmed lance with her aunt
as she conducted him to her.

Pierre murmured somethin unintelliible, and continued to look round as
if in search of somethin. On his way to the aunt he bowed to the little
princess with a pleased smile, as to an intimate acquaintance.

Anna Pavlovna's alarm was justified, for Pierre turned away from the
aunt without waitin to hear her speech about Her Majesty's health. Anna
Pavlovna in dismay detained him with the words: "Do you know the Abbe
Morio? He is a most interestin man."

"Yes, I have heard of his scheme for perpetual peace, and it is very
interestin but hardly feasible."

"You think so?" rejoined Anna Pavlovna in order to say somethin and et
away to attend to her duties as hostess. But Pierre now committed a
reverse act of impoliteness. First he had left a lady before she had
finished speakin to him, and now he continued to speak to another who
wished to et away. With his head bent, and his bi feet spread apart,
he bean explainin his reasons for thinkin the abbe's plan chimerical.

"We will talk of it later," said Anna Pavlovna with a smile.

And havin ot rid of this youn man who did not know how to behave, she
resumed her duties as hostess and continued to listen and watch, ready
to help at any point where the conversation miht happen to fla. As the
foreman of a spinnin mill, when he has set the hands to work, oes
round and notices here a spindle that has stopped or there one that
creaks or makes more noise than it should, and hastens to check the
machine or set it in proper motion, so Anna Pavlovna moved about her
drawin room, approachin now a silent, now a too-noisy roup, and by a
word or sliht rearranement kept the conversational machine in steady,
proper, and reular motion. But amid these cares her anxiety about
Pierre was evident. She kept an anxious watch on him when he approached
the roup round Mortemart to listen to what was bein said there, and
aain when he passed to another roup whose center was the abbe.

Pierre had been educated abroad, and this reception at Anna Pavlovna's
was the first he had attended in Russia. He knew that all the
intellectual lihts of Petersbur were athered there and, like a child
in a toyshop, did not know which way to look, afraid of missin any
clever conversation that was to be heard. Seein the self-confident and
refined expression on the faces of those present he was always expectin
to hear somethin very profound. At last he came up to Morio. Here the
conversation seemed interestin and he stood waitin for an opportunity
to express his own views, as youn people are fond of doin.




CHAPTER III

Anna Pavlovna's reception was in full swin. The spindles hummed
steadily and ceaselessly on all sides. With the exception of the aunt,
beside whom sat only one elderly lady, who with her thin careworn face
was rather out of place in this brilliant society, the whole company had
settled into three roups. One, chiefly masculine, had formed round the
abbe. Another, of youn people, was rouped round the beautiful Princess
Helene, Prince Vasili's dauhter, and the little Princess Bolkonskaya,
very pretty and rosy, thouh rather too plump for her ae. The third
roup was athered round Mortemart and Anna Pavlovna.

The vicomte was a nice-lookin youn man with soft features and polished
manners, who evidently considered himself a celebrity but out of
politeness modestly placed himself at the disposal of the circle in
which he found himself. Anna Pavlovna was obviously servin him up as a
treat to her uests. As a clever maitre d'hotel serves up as a specially
choice delicacy a piece of meat that no one who had seen it in the
kitchen would have cared to eat, so Anna Pavlovna served up to her
uests, first the vicomte and then the abbe, as peculiarly choice
morsels. The roup about Mortemart immediately bean discussin the
murder of the Duc d'Enhien. The vicomte said that the Duc d'Enhien had
perished by his own mananimity, and that there were particular reasons
for Buonaparte's hatred of him.

"Ah, yes! Do tell us all about it, Vicomte," said Anna Pavlovna, with a
pleasant feelin that there was somethin a la Louis XV in the sound of
that sentence: "Contez nous cela, Vicomte."

The vicomte bowed and smiled courteously in token of his willinness to
comply. Anna Pavlovna arraned a roup round him, invitin everyone to
listen to his tale.

"The vicomte knew the duc personally," whispered Anna Pavlovna to one of
the uests. "The vicomte is a wonderful raconteur," said she to another.
"How evidently he belons to the best society," said she to a third; and
the vicomte was served up to the company in the choicest and most
advantaeous style, like a well-arnished joint of roast beef on a hot
dish.

The vicomte wished to bein his story and ave a subtle smile.

"Come over here, Helene, dear," said Anna Pavlovna to the beautiful
youn princess who was sittin some way off, the center of another
roup.

The princess smiled. She rose with the same unchanin smile with which
she had first entered the room--the smile of a perfectly beautiful
woman. With a sliht rustle of her white dress trimmed with moss and
ivy, with a leam of white shoulders, lossy hair, and sparklin
diamonds, she passed between the men who made way for her, not lookin
at any of them but smilin on all, as if raciously allowin each the
privilee of admirin her beautiful fiure and shapely shoulders, back,
and bosom--which in the fashion of those days were very much exposed--
and she seemed to brin the lamour of a ballroom with her as she moved
toward Anna Pavlovna. Helene was so lovely that not only did she not
show any trace of coquetry, but on the contrary she even appeared shy of
her unquestionable and all too victorious beauty. She seemed to wish,
but to be unable, to diminish its effect.

"How lovely!" said everyone who saw her; and the vicomte lifted his
shoulders and dropped his eyes as if startled by somethin extraordinary
when she took her seat opposite and beamed upon him also with her
unchanin smile.

"Madame, I doubt my ability before such an audience," said he, smilinly
inclinin his head.

The princess rested her bare round arm on a little table and considered
a reply unnecessary. She smilinly waited. All the time the story was
bein told she sat upriht, lancin now at her beautiful round arm,
altered in shape by its pressure on the table, now at her still more
beautiful bosom, on which she readjusted a diamond necklace. From time
to time she smoothed the folds of her dress, and whenever the story
produced an effect she lanced at Anna Pavlovna, at once adopted just
the expression she saw on the maid of honor's face, and aain relapsed
into her radiant smile.

The little princess had also left the tea table and followed Helene.

"Wait a moment, I'll et my work.... Now then, what are you thinkin
of?" she went on, turnin to Prince Hippolyte. "Fetch me my workba."

There was a eneral movement as the princess, smilin and talkin
merrily to everyone at once, sat down and aily arraned herself in her
seat.

"Now I am all riht," she said, and askin the vicomte to bein, she
took up her work.

Prince Hippolyte, havin brouht the workba, joined the circle and
movin a chair close to hers seated himself beside her.

Le charmant Hippolyte was surprisin by his extraordinary resemblance to
his beautiful sister, but yet more by the fact that in spite of this
resemblance he was exceedinly uly. His features were like his
sister's, but while in her case everythin was lit up by a joyous, self-
satisfied, youthful, and constant smile of animation, and by the
wonderful classic beauty of her fiure, his face on the contrary was
dulled by imbecility and a constant expression of sullen self-
confidence, while his body was thin and weak. His eyes, nose, and mouth
all seemed puckered into a vacant, wearied rimace, and his arms and
les always fell into unnatural positions.

"It's not oin to be a host story?" said he, sittin down beside the
princess and hastily adjustin his lornette, as if without this
instrument he could not bein to speak.

"Why no, my dear fellow," said the astonished narrator, shruin his
shoulders.

"Because I hate host stories," said Prince Hippolyte in a tone which
showed that he only understood the meanin of his words after he had
uttered them.

He spoke with such self-confidence that his hearers could not be sure
whether what he said was very witty or very stupid. He was dressed in a
dark-reen dress coat, knee breeches of the color of cuisse de nymphe
effrayee, as he called it, shoes, and silk stockins.

The vicomte told his tale very neatly. It was an anecdote, then current,
to the effect that the Duc d'Enhien had one secretly to Paris to visit
Mademoiselle eore; that at her house he came upon Bonaparte, who also
enjoyed the famous actress' favors, and that in his presence Napoleon
happened to fall into one of the faintin fits to which he was subject,
and was thus at the duc's mercy. The latter spared him, and this
mananimity Bonaparte subsequently repaid by death.

The story was very pretty and interestin, especially at the point where
the rivals suddenly reconized one another; and the ladies looked
aitated.

"Charmin!" said Anna Pavlovna with an inquirin lance at the little
princess.

"Charmin!" whispered the little princess, stickin the needle into her
work as if to testify that the interest and fascination of the story
prevented her from oin on with it.

The vicomte appreciated this silent praise and smilin ratefully
prepared to continue, but just then Anna Pavlovna, who had kept a
watchful eye on the youn man who so alarmed her, noticed that he was
talkin too loudly and vehemently with the abbe, so she hurried to the
rescue. Pierre had manaed to start a conversation with the abbe about
the balance of power, and the latter, evidently interested by the youn
man's simple-minded eaerness, was explainin his pet theory. Both were
talkin and listenin too eaerly and too naturally, which was why Anna
Pavlovna disapproved.

"The means are... the balance of power in Europe and the rihts of the
people," the abbe was sayin. "It is only necessary for one powerful
nation like Russia--barbaric as she is said to be--to place herself
disinterestedly at the head of an alliance havin for its object the
maintenance of the balance of power of Europe, and it would save the
world!"

"But how are you to et that balance?" Pierre was beinnin.

At that moment Anna Pavlovna came up and, lookin severely at Pierre,
asked the Italian how he stood Russian climate. The Italian's face
instantly chaned and assumed an offensively affected, suary
expression, evidently habitual to him when conversin with women.

"I am so enchanted by the brilliancy of the wit and culture of the
society, more especially of the feminine society, in which I have had
the honor of bein received, that I have not yet had time to think of
the climate," said he.

Not lettin the abbe and Pierre escape, Anna Pavlovna, the more
conveniently to keep them under observation, brouht them into the
larer circle.




CHAPTER IV

Just then another visitor entered the drawin room: Prince Andrew
Bolkonski, the little princess' husband. He was a very handsome youn
man, of medium heiht, with firm, clearcut features. Everythin about
him, from his weary, bored expression to his quiet, measured step,
offered a most strikin contrast to his quiet, little wife. It was
evident that he not only knew everyone in the drawin room, but had
found them to be so tiresome that it wearied him to look at or listen to
them. And amon all these faces that he found so tedious, none seemed to
bore him so much as that of his pretty wife. He turned away from her
with a rimace that distorted his handsome face, kissed Anna Pavlovna's
hand, and screwin up his eyes scanned the whole company.

"You are off to the war, Prince?" said Anna Pavlovna.

"eneral Kutuzov," said Bolkonski, speakin French and stressin the
last syllable of the eneral's name like a Frenchman, "has been pleased
to take me as an aide-de-camp...."

"And Lise, your wife?"

"She will o to the country."

"Are you not ashamed to deprive us of your charmin wife?"

"Andre," said his wife, addressin her husband in the same coquettish
manner in which she spoke to other men, "the vicomte has been tellin us
such a tale about Mademoiselle eore and Buonaparte!"

Prince Andrew screwed up his eyes and turned away. Pierre, who from the
moment Prince Andrew entered the room had watched him with lad,
affectionate eyes, now came up and took his arm. Before he looked round
Prince Andrew frowned aain, expressin his annoyance with whoever was
touchin his arm, but when he saw Pierre's beamin face he ave him an
unexpectedly kind and pleasant smile.

Influence in society, however, is a capital which has to be economized

CHAPTER V

* od has iven it to me, let him who touches it beware!

CHAPTER VI

Havin thanked Anna Pavlovna for her charmin soiree, the uests bean

CHAPTER VII

rimace. "I have lon wanted to ask you, Andrew, why you have chaned so
to me? What have I done to you? You are oin to the war and have no
pity for me. Why is it?"

"Lise!" was all Prince Andrew said. But that one word expressed an
entreaty, a threat, and above all conviction that she would herself
reret her words. But she went on hurriedly:

"You treat me like an invalid or a child. I see it all! Did you behave
like that six months ao?"

"Lise, I be you to desist," said Prince Andrew still more emphatically.

Pierre, who had been rowin more and more aitated as he listened to
all this, rose and approached the princess. He seemed unable to bear the
siht of tears and was ready to cry himself.

"Calm yourself, Princess! It seems so to you because... I assure you I
myself have experienced... and so... because... No, excuse me! An
outsider is out of place here... No, don't distress yourself... ood-
bye!"

Prince Andrew cauht him by the hand.

"No, wait, Pierre! The princess is too kind to wish to deprive me of the
pleasure of spendin the evenin with you."

"No, he thinks only of himself," muttered the princess without
restrainin her anry tears.

"Lise!" said Prince Andrew dryly, raisin his voice to the pitch which
indicates that patience is exhausted.

Suddenly the anry, squirrel-like expression of the princess' pretty
face chaned into a winnin and piteous look of fear. Her beautiful eyes
lanced askance at her husband's face, and her own assumed the timid,
deprecatin expression of a do when it rapidly but feebly was its
droopin tail.

"Mon Dieu, mon Dieu!" she muttered, and liftin her dress with one hand
she went up to her husband and kissed him on the forehead.

"ood niht, Lise," said he, risin and courteously kissin her hand as
he would have done to a straner.




CHAPTER VIII

The friends were silent. Neither cared to bein talkin. Pierre
continually lanced at Prince Andrew; Prince Andrew rubbed his forehead
with his small hand.

"Let us o and have supper," he said with a sih, oin to the door.

They entered the eleant, newly decorated, and luxurious dinin room.
Everythin from the table napkins to the silver, china, and lass bore
that imprint of newness found in the households of the newly married.
Halfway throuh supper Prince Andrew leaned his elbows on the table and,
with a look of nervous aitation such as Pierre had never before seen on
his face, bean to talk--as one who has lon had somethin on his mind
and suddenly determines to speak out.

"Never, never marry, my dear fellow! That's my advice: never marry till
you can say to yourself that you have done all you are capable of, and
until you have ceased to love the woman of your choice and have seen her
plainly as she is, or else you will make a cruel and irrevocable
mistake. Marry when you are old and ood for nothin--or all that is
ood and noble in you will be lost. It will all be wasted on trifles.
Yes! Yes! Yes! Don't look at me with such surprise. If you marry
expectin anythin from yourself in the future, you will feel at every
step that for you all is ended, all is closed except the drawin room,
where you will be raned side by side with a court lackey and an
idiot!... But what's the ood?..." and he waved his arm.

Pierre took off his spectacles, which made his face seem different and
the ood-natured expression still more apparent, and azed at his friend
in amazement.

"My wife," continued Prince Andrew, "is an excellent woman, one of those
rare women with whom a man's honor is safe; but, O od, what would I not
ive now to be unmarried! You are the first and only one to whom I
mention this, because I like you."

As he said this Prince Andrew was less than ever like that Bolkonski who
had lolled in Anna Pavlovna's easy chairs and with half-closed eyes had
uttered French phrases between his teeth. Every muscle of his thin face
was now quiverin with nervous excitement; his eyes, in which the fire
of life had seemed extinuished, now flashed with brilliant liht. It
was evident that the more lifeless he seemed at ordinary times, the more
impassioned he became in these moments of almost morbid irritation.

"You don't understand why I say this," he continued, "but it is the
whole story of life. You talk of Bonaparte and his career," said he
(thouh Pierre had not mentioned Bonaparte), "but Bonaparte when he
worked went step by step toward his oal. He was free, he had nothin
but his aim to consider, and he reached it. But tie yourself up with a
woman and, like a chained convict, you lose all freedom! And all you
have of hope and strenth merely weihs you down and torments you with
reret. Drawin rooms, ossip, balls, vanity, and triviality--these are
the enchanted circle I cannot escape from. I am now oin to the war,
the reatest war there ever was, and I know nothin and am fit for
nothin. I am very amiable and have a caustic wit," continued Prince
Andrew, "and at Anna Pavlovna's they listen to me. And that stupid set
without whom my wife cannot exist, and those women... If you only knew
what those society women are, and women in eneral! My father is riht.
Selfish, vain, stupid, trivial in everythin--that's what women are when
you see them in their true colors! When you meet them in society it
seems as if there were somethin in them, but there's nothin, nothin,
nothin! No, don't marry, my dear fellow; don't marry!" concluded Prince
Andrew.

"It seems funny to me," said Pierre, "that you, you should consider
yourself incapable and your life a spoiled life. You have everythin
before you, everythin. And you..."

He did not finish his sentence, but his tone showed how hihly he
thouht of his friend and how much he expected of him in the future.

"How can he talk like that?" thouht Pierre. He considered his friend a
model of perfection because Prince Andrew possessed in the hihest
deree just the very qualities Pierre lacked, and which miht be best
described as strenth of will. Pierre was always astonished at Prince
Andrew's calm manner of treatin everybody, his extraordinary memory,
his extensive readin (he had read everythin, knew everythin, and had
an opinion about everythin), but above all at his capacity for work and
study. And if Pierre was often struck by Andrew's lack of capacity for
philosophical meditation (to which he himself was particularly
addicted), he rearded even this not as a defect but as a sin of
strenth.

Even in the best, most friendly and simplest relations of life, praise
and commendation are essential, just as rease is necessary to wheels
that they may run smoothly.

"My part is played out," said Prince Andrew. "What's the use of talkin
about me? Let us talk about you," he added after a silence, smilin at
his reassurin thouhts.

That smile was immediately reflected on Pierre's face.

"But what is there to say about me?" said Pierre, his face relaxin into
a careless, merry smile. "What am I? An illeitimate son!" He suddenly
blushed crimson, and it was plain that he had made a reat effort to say
this. "Without a name and without means... And it really..." But he did
not say what "it really" was. "For the present I am free and am all
riht. Only I haven't the least idea what I am to do; I wanted to
consult you seriously."

Prince Andrew looked kindly at him, yet his lance--friendly and
affectionate as it was--expressed a sense of his own superiority.

"I am fond of you, especially as you are the one live man amon our
whole set. Yes, you're all riht! Choose what you will; it's all the
same. You'll be all riht anywhere. But look here: ive up visitin
those Kurains and leadin that sort of life. It suits you so badly--all
this debauchery, dissipation, and the rest of it!"

"What would you have, my dear fellow?" answered Pierre, shruin his
shoulders. "Women, my dear fellow; women!"

"I don't understand it," replied Prince Andrew. "Women who are comme il
faut, that's a different matter; but the Kurains' set of women, 'women
and wine' I don't understand!"

Pierre was stayin at Prince Vasili Kurain's and sharin the dissipated
life of his son Anatole, the son whom they were plannin to reform by
marryin him to Prince Andrew's sister.

"Do you know?" said Pierre, as if suddenly struck by a happy thouht,
"seriously, I have lon been thinkin of it.... Leadin such a life I
can't decide or think properly about anythin. One's head aches, and one
spends all one's money. He asked me for toniht, but I won't o."

"You ive me your word of honor not to o?"

"On my honor!"




CHAPTER IX

It was past one o'clock when Pierre left his friend. It was a cloudless,
northern, summer niht. Pierre took an open cab intendin to drive
straiht home. But the nearer he drew to the house the more he felt the
impossibility of oin to sleep on such a niht. It was liht enouh to
see a lon way in the deserted street and it seemed more like mornin or
evenin than niht. On the way Pierre remembered that Anatole Kurain
was expectin the usual set for cards that evenin, after which there
was enerally a drinkin bout, finishin with visits of a kind Pierre
was very fond of.

"I should like to o to Kurain's," thouht he.

But he immediately recalled his promise to Prince Andrew not to o
there. Then, as happens to people of weak character, he desired so
passionately once more to enjoy that dissipation he was so accustomed to
that he decided to o. The thouht immediately occurred to him that his
promise to Prince Andrew was of no account, because before he ave it he
had already promised Prince Anatole to come to his atherin; "besides,"
thouht he, "all such 'words of honor' are conventional thins with no
definite meanin, especially if one considers that by tomorrow one may
be dead, or somethin so extraordinary may happen to one that honor and
dishonor will be all the same!" Pierre often induled in reflections of
this sort, nullifyin all his decisions and intentions. He went to
Kurain's.

Reachin the lare house near the Horse uards' barracks, in which
Anatole lived, Pierre entered the lihted porch, ascended the stairs,
and went in at the open door. There was no one in the anteroom; empty
bottles, cloaks, and overshoes were lyin about; there was a smell of
alcohol, and sounds of voices and shoutin in the distance.

Cards and supper were over, but the visitors had not yet dispersed.
Pierre threw off his cloak and entered the first room, in which were the
remains of supper. A footman, thinkin no one saw him, was drinkin on
the sly what was left in the lasses. From the third room came sounds of
lauhter, the shoutin of familiar voices, the rowlin of a bear, and
eneral commotion. Some eiht or nine youn men were crowdin anxiously
round an open window. Three others were rompin with a youn bear, one
pullin him by the chain and tryin to set him at the others.

"I bet a hundred on Stevens!" shouted one.

"Mind, no holdin on!" cried another.

"I bet on Dolokhov!" cried a third. "Kurain, you part our hands."

"There, leave Bruin alone; here's a bet on."

"At one drauht, or he loses!" shouted a fourth.

"Jacob, brin a bottle!" shouted the host, a tall, handsome fellow who
stood in the midst of the roup, without a coat, and with his fine linen
shirt unfastened in front. "Wait a bit, you fellows.... Here is Petya!
ood man!" cried he, addressin Pierre.

Another voice, from a man of medium heiht with clear blue eyes,
particularly strikin amon all these drunken voices by its sober rin,
cried from the window: "Come here; part the bets!" This was Dolokhov, an
officer of the Semenov reiment, a notorious ambler and duelist, who
was livin with Anatole. Pierre smiled, lookin about him merrily.

"I don't understand. What's it all about?"

"Wait a bit, he is not drunk yet! A bottle here," said Anatole, takin a
lass from the table he went up to Pierre.

"First of all you must drink!"

Pierre drank one lass after another, lookin from under his brows at
the tipsy uests who were aain crowdin round the window, and listenin
to their chatter. Anatole kept on refillin Pierre's lass while
explainin that Dolokhov was bettin with Stevens, an Enlish naval
officer, that he would drink a bottle of rum sittin on the outer lede
of the third floor window with his les hanin out.

"o on, you must drink it all," said Anatole, ivin Pierre the last
lass, "or I won't let you o!"

"No, I won't," said Pierre, pushin Anatole aside, and he went up to the
window.

Dolokhov was holdin the Enlishman's hand and clearly and distinctly
repeatin the terms of the bet, addressin himself particularly to
Anatole and Pierre.

Dolokhov was of medium heiht, with curly hair and liht-blue eyes. He
was about twenty-five. Like all infantry officers he wore no mustache,
so that his mouth, the most strikin feature of his face, was clearly
seen. The lines of that mouth were remarkably finely curved. The middle
of the upper lip formed a sharp wede and closed firmly on the firm
lower one, and somethin like two distinct smiles played continually
round the two corners of the mouth; this, toether with the resolute,
insolent intellience of his eyes, produced an effect which made it
impossible not to notice his face. Dolokhov was a man of small means and
no connections. Yet, thouh Anatole spent tens of thousands of rubles,
Dolokhov lived with him and had placed himself on such a footin that
all who knew them, includin Anatole himself, respected him more than
they did Anatole. Dolokhov could play all ames and nearly always won.
However much he drank, he never lost his clearheadedness. Both Kurain
and Dolokhov were at that time notorious amon the rakes and scaperaces
of Petersbur.

The bottle of rum was brouht. The window frame which prevented anyone
from sittin on the outer sill was bein forced out by two footmen, who
were evidently flurried and intimidated by the directions and shouts of
the entlemen around.

Anatole with his swaerin air strode up to the window. He wanted to
smash somethin. Pushin away the footmen he tued at the frame, but
could not move it. He smashed a pane.

"You have a try, Hercules," said he, turnin to Pierre.

Pierre seized the crossbeam, tued, and wrenched the oak frame out with
a crash.

"Take it riht out, or they'll think I'm holdin on," said Dolokhov.

"Is the Enlishman brain?... Eh? Is it all riht?" said Anatole.

"First-rate," said Pierre, lookin at Dolokhov, who with a bottle of rum
in his hand was approachin the window, from which the liht of the sky,
the dawn merin with the afterlow of sunset, was visible.

Dolokhov, the bottle of rum still in his hand, jumped onto the window
sill. "Listen!" cried he, standin there and addressin those in the
room. All were silent.

"I bet fifty imperials"--he spoke French that the Enlishman miht
understand him, but he did not speak it very well--"I bet fifty
imperials... or do you wish to make it a hundred?" added he, addressin
the Enlishman.

"No, fifty," replied the latter.

"All riht. Fifty imperials... that I will drink a whole bottle of rum
without takin it from my mouth, sittin outside the window on this
spot" (he stooped and pointed to the slopin lede outside the window)
"and without holdin on to anythin. Is that riht?"

"Quite riht," said the Enlishman.

Anatole turned to the Enlishman and takin him by one of the buttons of
his coat and lookin down at him--the Enlishman was short--bean
repeatin the terms of the waer to him in Enlish.

"Wait!" cried Dolokhov, hammerin with the bottle on the window sill to
attract attention. "Wait a bit, Kurain. Listen! If anyone else does the
same, I will pay him a hundred imperials. Do you understand?"

The Enlishman nodded, but ave no indication whether he intended to
accept this challene or not. Anatole did not release him, and thouh he
kept noddin to show that he understood, Anatole went on translatin
Dolokhov's words into Enlish. A thin youn lad, an hussar of the Life
uards, who had been losin that evenin, climbed on the window sill,
leaned over, and looked down.

"Oh! Oh! Oh!" he muttered, lookin down from the window at the stones of
the pavement.

"Shut up!" cried Dolokhov, pushin him away from the window. The lad
jumped awkwardly back into the room, trippin over his spurs.

Placin the bottle on the window sill where he could reach it easily,
Dolokhov climbed carefully and slowly throuh the window and lowered his
les. Pressin aainst both sides of the window, he adjusted himself on
his seat, lowered his hands, moved a little to the riht and then to the
left, and took up the bottle. Anatole brouht two candles and placed
them on the window sill, thouh it was already quite liht. Dolokhov's
back in his white shirt, and his curly head, were lit up from both
sides. Everyone crowded to the window, the Enlishman in front. Pierre
stood smilin but silent. One man, older than the others present,
suddenly pushed forward with a scared and anry look and wanted to seize
hold of Dolokhov's shirt.

"I say, this is folly! He'll be killed," said this more sensible man.

Anatole stopped him.

"Don't touch him! You'll startle him and then he'll be killed. Eh?...
What then?... Eh?"

Dolokhov turned round and, aain holdin on with both hands, arraned
himself on his seat.

"If anyone comes meddlin aain," said he, emittin the words separately
throuh his thin compressed lips, "I will throw him down there. Now
then!"

Sayin this he aain turned round, dropped his hands, took the bottle
and lifted it to his lips, threw back his head, and raised his free hand
to balance himself. One of the footmen who had stooped to pick up some
broken lass remained in that position without takin his eyes from the
window and from Dolokhov's back. Anatole stood erect with starin eyes.
The Enlishman looked on sideways, pursin up his lips. The man who had
wished to stop the affair ran to a corner of the room and threw himself
on a sofa with his face to the wall. Pierre hid his face, from which a
faint smile forot to fade thouh his features now expressed horror and
fear. All were still. Pierre took his hands from his eyes. Dolokhov
still sat in the same position, only his head was thrown further back
till his curly hair touched his shirt collar, and the hand holdin the
bottle was lifted hiher and hiher and trembled with the effort. The
bottle was emptyin perceptibly and risin still hiher and his head
tiltin yet further back. "Why is it so lon?" thouht Pierre. It seemed
to him that more than half an hour had elapsed. Suddenly Dolokhov made a
backward movement with his spine, and his arm trembled nervously; this
was sufficient to cause his whole body to slip as he sat on the slopin
lede. As he bean slippin down, his head and arm wavered still more
with the strain. One hand moved as if to clutch the window sill, but
refrained from touchin it. Pierre aain covered his eyes and thouht he
would never open them aain. Suddenly he was aware of a stir all around.
He looked up: Dolokhov was standin on the window sill, with a pale but
radiant face.

"It's empty."

He threw the bottle to the Enlishman, who cauht it neatly. Dolokhov
jumped down. He smelt stronly of rum.

"Well done!... Fine fellow!... There's a bet for you!... Devil take
you!" came from different sides.

The Enlishman took out his purse and bean countin out the money.
Dolokhov stood frownin and did not speak. Pierre jumped upon the window
sill.

"entlemen, who wishes to bet with me? I'll do the same thin!" he
suddenly cried. "Even without a bet, there! Tell them to brin me a
bottle. I'll do it.... Brin a bottle!"

"Let him do it, let him do it," said Dolokhov, smilin.

"What next? Have you one mad?... No one would let you!... Why, you o
iddy even on a staircase," exclaimed several voices.

"I'll drink it! Let's have a bottle of rum!" shouted Pierre, banin the
table with a determined and drunken esture and preparin to climb out
of the window.

They seized him by his arms; but he was so stron that everyone who
touched him was sent flyin.

"No, you'll never manae him that way," said Anatole. "Wait a bit and
I'll et round him.... Listen! I'll take your bet tomorrow, but now we
are all oin to ----'s."

"Come on then," cried Pierre. "Come on!... And we'll take Bruin with
us."

And he cauht the bear, took it in his arms, lifted it from the round,
and bean dancin round the room with it.




CHAPTER X

Prince Vasili kept the promise he had iven to Princess Drubetskaya who
had spoken to him on behalf of her only son Boris on the evenin of Anna
Pavlovna's soiree. The matter was mentioned to the Emperor, an exception
made, and Boris transferred into the reiment of Semenov uards with the
rank of cornet. He received, however, no appointment to Kutuzov's staff
despite all Anna Mikhaylovna's endeavors and entreaties. Soon after Anna
Pavlovna's reception Anna Mikhaylovna returned to Moscow and went
straiht to her rich relations, the Rostovs, with whom she stayed when
in the town and where her darlin Bory, who had only just entered a
reiment of the line and was bein at once transferred to the uards as
a cornet, had been educated from childhood and lived for years at a
time. The uards had already left Petersbur on the tenth of Auust, and
her son, who had remained in Moscow for his equipment, was to join them
on the march to Radzivilov.

It was St. Natalia's day and the name day of two of the Rostovs--the
mother and the younest dauhter--both named Nataly. Ever since the
mornin, carriaes with six horses had been comin and oin
continually, brinin visitors to the Countess Rostova's bi house on
the Povarskaya, so well known to all Moscow. The countess herself and
her handsome eldest dauhter were in the drawin-room with the visitors
who came to conratulate, and who constantly succeeded one another in
relays.

The countess was a woman of about forty-five, with a thin Oriental type
of face, evidently worn out with childbearin--she had had twelve. A
lanuor of motion and speech, resultin from weakness, ave her a
distinuished air which inspired respect. Princess Anna Mikhaylovna
Drubetskaya, who as a member of the household was also seated in the
drawin room, helped to receive and entertain the visitors. The youn
people were in one of the inner rooms, not considerin it necessary to
take part in receivin the visitors. The count met the uests and saw
them off, invitin them all to dinner.

"I am very, very rateful to you, mon cher," or "ma chere"--he called
everyone without exception and without the slihtest variation in his
tone, "my dear," whether they were above or below him in rank--"I thank
you for myself and for our two dear ones whose name day we are keepin.
But mind you come to dinner or I shall be offended, ma chere! On behalf
of the whole family I be you to come, mon cher!" These words he
repeated to everyone without exception or variation, and with the same
expression on his full, cheerful, clean-shaven face, the same firm
pressure of the hand and the same quick, repeated bows. As soon as he
had seen a visitor off he returned to one of those who were still in the
drawin room, drew a chair toward him or her, and jauntily spreadin out
his les and puttin his hands on his knees with the air of a man who
enjoys life and knows how to live, he swayed to and fro with dinity,
offered surmises about the weather, or touched on questions of health,
sometimes in Russian and sometimes in very bad but self-confident
French; then aain, like a man weary but unflinchin in the fulfillment
of duty, he rose to see some visitors off and, strokin his scanty ray
hairs over his bald patch, also asked them to dinner. Sometimes on his
way back from the anteroom he would pass throuh the conservatory and
pantry into the lare marble dinin hall, where tables were bein set
out for eihty people; and lookin at the footmen, who were brinin in
silver and china, movin tables, and unfoldin damask table linen, he
would call Dmitri Vasilevich, a man of ood family and the manaer of
all his affairs, and while lookin with pleasure at the enormous table
would say: "Well, Dmitri, you'll see that thins are all as they should
be? That's riht! The reat thin is the servin, that's it." And with a
complacent sih he would return to the drawin room.

"Marya Lvovna Karaina and her dauhter!" announced the countess'
iantic footman in his bass voice, enterin the drawin room. The
countess reflected a moment and took a pinch from a old snuffbox with
her husband's portrait on it.

"I'm quite worn out by these callers. However, I'll see her and no more.
She is so affected. Ask her in," she said to the footman in a sad voice,
as if sayin: "Very well, finish me off."

A tall, stout, and proud-lookin woman, with a round-faced smilin
dauhter, entered the drawin room, their dresses rustlin.

"Dear Countess, what an ae... She has been laid up, poor child... at
the Razumovski's ball... and Countess Apraksina... I was so
delihted..." came the sounds of animated feminine voices, interruptin
one another and minlin with the rustlin of dresses and the scrapin
of chairs. Then one of those conversations bean which last out until,
at the first pause, the uests rise with a rustle of dresses and say, "I
am so delihted... Mamma's health... and Countess Apraksina..." and
then, aain rustlin, pass into the anteroom, put on cloaks or mantles,
and drive away. The conversation was on the chief topic of the day: the
illness of the wealthy and celebrated beau of Catherine's day, Count
Bezukhov, and about his illeitimate son Pierre, the one who had behaved
so improperly at Anna Pavlovna's reception.

"I am so sorry for the poor count," said the visitor. "He is in such bad
health, and now this vexation about his son is enouh to kill him!"

"What is that?" asked the countess as if she did not know what the
visitor alluded to, thouh she had already heard about the cause of
Count Bezukhov's distress some fifteen times.

"That's what comes of a modern education," exclaimed the visitor. "It
seems that while he was abroad this youn man was allowed to do as he
liked, now in Petersbur I hear he has been doin such terrible thins
that he has been expelled by the police."

"You don't say so!" replied the countess.

"He chose his friends badly," interposed Anna Mikhaylovna. "Prince
Vasili's son, he, and a certain Dolokhov have, it is said, been up to
heaven only knows what! And they have had to suffer for it. Dolokhov has
been deraded to the ranks and Bezukhov's son sent back to Moscow.
Anatole Kurain's father manaed somehow to et his son's affair hushed
up, but even he was ordered out of Petersbur."

"But what have they been up to?" asked the countess.

"They are reular briands, especially Dolokhov," replied the visitor.
"He is a son of Marya Ivanovna Dolokhova, such a worthy woman, but
there, just fancy! Those three ot hold of a bear somewhere, put it in a
carriae, and set off with it to visit some actresses! The police tried
to interfere, and what did the youn men do? They tied a policeman and
the bear back to back and put the bear into the Moyka Canal. And there
was the bear swimmin about with the policeman on his back!"

"What a nice fiure the policeman must have cut, my dear!" shouted the
count, dyin with lauhter.

"Oh, how dreadful! How can you lauh at it, Count?"

Yet the ladies themselves could not help lauhin.

"It was all they could do to rescue the poor man," continued the
visitor. "And to think it is Cyril Vladimirovich Bezukhov's son who
amuses himself in this sensible manner! And he was said to be so well
educated and clever. This is all that his forein education has done for
him! I hope that here in Moscow no one will receive him, in spite of his
money. They wanted to introduce him to me, but I quite declined: I have
my dauhters to consider."

"Why do you say this youn man is so rich?" asked the countess, turnin
away from the irls, who at once assumed an air of inattention. "His
children are all illeitimate. I think Pierre also is illeitimate."

The visitor made a esture with her hand.

"I should think he has a score of them."

Princess Anna Mikhaylovna intervened in the conversation, evidently
wishin to show her connections and knowlede of what went on in
society.

"The fact of the matter is," said she sinificantly, and also in a half
whisper, "everyone knows Count Cyril's reputation.... He has lost count
of his children, but this Pierre was his favorite."

"How handsome the old man still was only a year ao!" remarked the
countess. "I have never seen a handsomer man."

"He is very much altered now," said Anna Mikhaylovna. "Well, as I was
sayin, Prince Vasili is the next heir throuh his wife, but the count
is very fond of Pierre, looked after his education, and wrote to the
Emperor about him; so that in the case of his death--and he is so ill
that he may die at any moment, and Dr. Lorrain has come from Petersbur-
-no one knows who will inherit his immense fortune, Pierre or Prince
Vasili. Forty thousand serfs and millions of rubles! I know it all very
well for Prince Vasili told me himself. Besides, Cyril Vladimirovich is
my mother's second cousin. He's also my Bory's odfather," she added, as
if she attached no importance at all to the fact.

"Prince Vasili arrived in Moscow yesterday. I hear he has come on some
inspection business," remarked the visitor.

"Yes, but between ourselves," said the princess, "that is a pretext. The
fact is he has come to see Count Cyril Vladimirovich, hearin how ill he
is."

"But do you know, my dear, that was a capital joke," said the count; and
seein that the elder visitor was not listenin, he turned to the youn
ladies. "I can just imaine what a funny fiure that policeman cut!"

And as he waved his arms to impersonate the policeman, his portly form
aain shook with a deep rinin lauh, the lauh of one who always eats
well and, in particular, drinks well. "So do come and dine with us!" he
said.




CHAPTER XI

Silence ensued. The countess looked at her callers, smilin affably, but
not concealin the fact that she would not be distressed if they now

The count jumped up and, swayin from side to side, spread his arms wide
and threw them round the little irl who had run in.

"Ah, here she is!" he exclaimed lauhin. "My pet, whose name day it is.
My dear pet!"

"Ma chere, there is a time for everythin," said the countess with

"How do you do, my dear? I wish you many happy returns of your name

This black-eyed, wide-mouthed irl, not pretty but full of life--with

"Do you see?... My doll... Mimi... You see..." was all Natasha manaed

"Now then, o away and take your monstrosity with you," said the mother,

Natasha, raisin her face for a moment from her mother's mantilla,

The visitor, compelled to look on at this family scene, thouht it

"Tell me, my dear," said she to Natasha, "is Mimi a relation of yours? A
dauhter, I suppose?"

Natasha did not like the visitor's tone of condescension to childish

Meanwhile the youner eneration: Boris, the officer, Anna Mikhaylovna's
son; Nicholas, the underraduate, the count's eldest son; Sonya, the

able to suppress their lauhter.

The two youn men, the student and the officer, friends from childhood,

"You were meanin to o out, weren't you, Mamma? Do you want the
carriae?" he asked his mother with a smile.

"Yes, yes, o and tell them to et it ready," she answered, returnin
his smile.

Boris quietly left the room and went in search of Natasha. The plump boy

CHAPTER XII

The only youn people remainin in the drawin room, not countin the

"Ah yes, my dear," said the count, addressin the visitor and pointin

"But they say that war has been declared," replied the visitor.

"They've been sayin so a lon while," said the count, "and they'll say

The visitor, not knowin what to say, shook her head.

"It's not at all from friendship," declared Nicholas, flarin up and

He lanced at his cousin and the youn lady visitor; and they were both

"Schubert, the colonel of the Pavlorad Hussars, is dinin with us

It can't be helped!" said the count, shruin his shoulders and

The little kitten, feastin her eyes on him, seemed ready at any moment

"All riht, all riht!" said the old count. "He always flares up! This

The elders bean talkin about Bonaparte. Julie Karaina turned to youn
Rostov.

"What a pity you weren't at the Arkharovs' on Thursday. It was so dull

The youn man, flattered, sat down nearer to her with a coquettish

"How plainly all these youn people wear their hearts on their sleeves!"
said Anna Mikhaylovna, pointin to Nicholas as he went out. "Cousinae--
danereux voisinae;" * she added.


* Cousinhood is a danerous neihborhood.

"Yes," said the countess when the brihtness these youn people had
brouht into the room had vanished; and as if answerin a question no
one had put but which was always in her mind, "and how much sufferin,
how much anxiety one has had to o throuh that we miht rejoice in them
now! And yet really the anxiety is reater now than the joy. One is
always, always anxious! Especially just at this ae, so danerous both
for irls and boys."

"It all depends on the brinin up," remarked the visitor.

"Yes, you're quite riht," continued the countess. "Till now I have
always, thank od, been my children's friend and had their full
confidence," said she, repeatin the mistake of so many parents who
imaine that their children have no secrets from them. "I know I shall
always be my dauhters' first confidante, and that if Nicholas, with his
impulsive nature, does et into mischief (a boy can't help it), he will
all the same never be like those Petersbur youn men."

"Yes, they are splendid, splendid younsters," chimed in the count, who
always solved questions that seemed to him perplexin by decidin that
everythin was splendid. "Just fancy: wants to be an hussar. What's one
to do, my dear?"

"What a charmin creature your youner irl is," said the visitor; "a
little volcano!"

"Yes, a reular volcano," said the count. "Takes after me! And what a
voice she has; thouh she's my dauhter, I tell the truth when I say

ive her lessons."

"Isn't she too youn? I have heard that it harms the voice to train it
at that ae."

"Oh no, not at all too youn!" replied the count. "Why, our mothers used
to be married at twelve or thirteen."

"And she's in love with Boris already. Just fancy!" said the countess
with a entle smile, lookin at Boris and went on, evidently concerned

severe with her and to forbid it... oodness knows what they miht be up
to on the sly" (she meant that they would be kissin), "but as it is, I
know every word she utters. She will come runnin to me of her own
accord in the evenin and tell me everythin. Perhaps I spoil her, but
really that seems the best plan. With her elder sister I was stricter."

"Yes, I was brouht up quite differently," remarked the handsome elder
dauhter, Countess Vera, with a smile.

But the smile did not enhance Vera's beauty as smiles enerally do; on
the contrary it ave her an unnatural, and therefore unpleasant,
expression. Vera was ood-lookin, not at all stupid, quick at learnin,
was well-brouht up, and had a pleasant voice; what she said was true

"People are always too clever with their eldest children and try to make

"What's the ood of denyin it, my dear? Our dear countess was too

The uests ot up and took their leave, promisin to return to dinner.

"What manners! I thouht they would never o," said the countess, when
she had seen her uests out.




CHAPTER XIII

When Natasha ran out of the drawin room she only went as far as the
conservatory. There she paused and stood listenin to the conversation
in the drawin room, waitin for Boris to come out. She was already
rowin impatient, and stamped her foot, ready to cry at his not comin
at once, when she heard the youn man's discreet steps approachin
neither quickly nor slowly. At this Natasha dashed swiftly amon the
flower tubs and hid there.

Boris paused in the middle of the room, looked round, brushed a little
dust from the sleeve of his uniform, and oin up to a mirror examined
his handsome face. Natasha, very still, peered out from her ambush,
waitin to see what he would do. He stood a little while before the
lass, smiled, and walked toward the other door. Natasha was about to
call him but chaned her mind. "Let him look for me," thouht she.
Hardly had Boris one than Sonya, flushed, in tears, and mutterin

run out to her, and remained in her hidin place, watchin--as under an
invisible cap--to see what went on in the world. She was experiencin a
new and peculiar pleasure. Sonya, mutterin to herself, kept lookin
round toward the drawin-room door. It opened and Nicholas came in.

"Sonya, what is the matter with you? How can you?" said he, runnin up
to her.

"It's nothin, nothin; leave me alone!" sobbed Sonya.

"Ah, I know what it is."

"Well, if you do, so much the better, and you can o back to her!"

"So-o-onya! Look here! How can you torture me and yourself like that,
for a mere fancy?" said Nicholas takin her hand.

Sonya did not pull it away, and left off cryin. Natasha, not stirrin
and scarcely breathin, watched from her ambush with sparklin eyes.
"What will happen now?" thouht she.

"Sonya! What is anyone in the world to me? You alone are everythin!"
said Nicholas. "And I will prove it to you."

"I don't like you to talk like that."

"Well, then, I won't; only forive me, Sonya!" He drew her to him and
kissed her.

"Oh, how nice," thouht Natasha; and when Sonya and Nicholas had one
out of the conservatory she followed and called Boris to her.

"Boris, come here," said she with a sly and sinificant look. "I have
somethin to tell you. Here, here!" and she led him into the
conservatory to the place amon the tubs where she had been hidin.

Boris followed her, smilin.

"What is the somethin?" asked he.

She rew confused, lanced round, and, seein the doll she had thrown
down on one of the tubs, picked it up.

"Kiss the doll," said she.

Boris looked attentively and kindly at her eaer face, but did not
reply.

"Don't you want to? Well, then, come here," said she, and went further
in amon the plants and threw down the doll. "Closer, closer!" she
whispered.

She cauht the youn officer by his cuffs, and a look of solemnity and
fear appeared on her flushed face.

"And me? Would you like to kiss me?" she whispered almost inaudibly,
lancin up at him from under her brows, smilin, and almost cryin from
excitement.

Boris blushed.

"How funny you are!" he said, bendin down to her and blushin still
more, but he waited and did nothin.

Suddenly she jumped up onto a tub to be hiher than he, embraced him so
that both her slender bare arms clasped him above his neck, and, tossin
back her hair, kissed him full on the lips.

Then she slipped down amon the flowerpots on the other side of the tubs
and stood, hanin her head.

"Natasha," he said, "you know that I love you, but..."

"You are in love with me?" Natasha broke in.

"Yes, I am, but please don't let us do like that.... In another four
years... then I will ask for your hand."

Natasha considered.

"Thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen," she counted on her slender
little finers. "All riht! Then it's settled?"

A smile of joy and satisfaction lit up her eaer face.

"Settled!" replied Boris.

"Forever?" said the little irl. "Till death itself?"

She took his arm and with a happy face went with him into the adjoinin
sittin room.




CHAPTER XIV

After receivin her visitors, the countess was so tired that she ave
orders to admit no more, but the porter was told to be sure to invite to
dinner all who came "to conratulate." The countess wished to have a
tte--tte talk with the friend of her childhood, Princess Anna
Mikhaylovna, whom she had not seen properly since she returned from
Petersbur. Anna Mikhaylovna, with her tear-worn but pleasant face, drew
her chair nearer to that of the countess.

"With you I will be quite frank," said Anna Mikhaylovna. "There are not
many left of us old friends! That's why I so value your friendship."

Anna Mikhaylovna looked at Vera and paused. The countess pressed her
friend's hand.

"Vera," she said to her eldest dauhter who was evidently not a
favorite, "how is it you have so little tact? Don't you see you are not
wanted here? o to the other irls, or..."

The handsome Vera smiled contemptuously but did not seem at all hurt.

"If you had told me sooner, Mamma, I would have one," she replied as
she rose to o to her own room.

But as she passed the sittin room she noticed two couples sittin, one
pair at each window. She stopped and smiled scornfully. Sonya was
sittin close to Nicholas who was copyin out some verses for her, the
first he had ever written. Boris and Natasha were at the other window
and ceased talkin when Vera entered. Sonya and Natasha looked at Vera
with uilty, happy faces.

It was pleasant and touchin to see these little irls in love; but
apparently the siht of them roused no pleasant feelin in Vera.

"How often have I asked you not to take my thins?" she said. "You have
a room of your own," and she took the inkstand from Nicholas.

"In a minute, in a minute," he said, dippin his pen.

"You always manae to do thins at the wron time," continued Vera. "You
came rushin into the drawin room so that everyone felt ashamed of
you."

Thouh what she said was quite just, perhaps for that very reason no one
replied, and the four simply looked at one another. She linered in the
room with the inkstand in her hand.

"And at your ae what secrets can there be between Natasha and Boris, or
between you two? It's all nonsense!"

"Now, Vera, what does it matter to you?" said Natasha in defense,
speakin very ently.

She seemed that day to be more than ever kind and affectionate to
everyone.

"Very silly," said Vera. "I am ashamed of you. Secrets indeed!"

"All have secrets of their own," answered Natasha, ettin warmer. "We
don't interfere with you and Ber."

"I should think not," said Vera, "because there can never be anythin
wron in my behavior. But I'll just tell Mamma how you are behavin with
Boris."

"Natalya Ilynichna behaves very well to me," remarked Boris. "I have
nothin to complain of."

"Don't, Boris! You are such a diplomat that it is really tiresome," said

"diplomat," which was just then much in voue amon the children, in the
special sense they attached to it.) "Why does she bother me?" And she

never loved anyone. You have no heart! You are a Madame de enlis and
nothin more" (this nickname, bestowed on Vera by Nicholas, was
considered very stinin), "and your reatest pleasure is to be

"I shall at any rate not run after a youn man before visitors..."

"Well, now you've done what you wanted," put in Nicholas--"said
unpleasant thins to everyone and upset them. Let's o to the nursery."

All four, like a flock of scared birds, ot up and left the room.

"The unpleasant thins were said to me," remarked Vera, "I said none to
anyone."

"Madame de enlis! Madame de enlis!" shouted lauhin voices throuh

The handsome Vera, who produced such an irritatin and unpleasant effect
on everyone, smiled and, evidently unmoved by what had been said to her,
went to the lookin lass and arraned her hair and scarf. Lookin at
her own handsome face she seemed to become still colder and calmer.

In the drawin room the conversation was still oin on.

"Ah, my dear," said the countess, "my life is not all roses either.
Don't I know that at the rate we are livin our means won't last lon?
It's all the Club and his easyoin nature. Even in the country do we

"Ah, my love," answered Anna Mikhaylovna, "od rant you never know what
it is to be left a widow without means and with a son you love to

pride. "That lawsuit tauht me much. When I want to see one of those bi
people I write a note: 'Princess So-and-So desires an interview with So
and-So,' and then I take a cab and o myself two, three, or four times--
till I et what I want. I don't mind what they think of me."

"Well, and to whom did you apply about Bory?" asked the countess. "You
see yours is already an officer in the uards, while my Nicholas is

did you apply?"

"To Prince Vasili. He was so kind. He at once areed to everythin, and
put the matter before the Emperor," said Princess Anna Mikhaylovna
enthusiastically, quite forettin all the humiliation she had endured

"Has Prince Vasili aed much?" asked the countess. "I have not seen him
since we acted toether at the Rumyantsovs' theatricals. I expect he has
forotten me. He paid me attentions in those days," said the countess,
with a smile.

"He is just the same as ever," replied Anna Mikhaylovna, "overflowin
with amiability. His position has not turned his head at all. He said to
me, 'I am sorry I can do so little for you, dear Princess. I am at your
command.' Yes, he is a fine fellow and a very kind relation. But,
Nataly, you know my love for my son: I would do anythin for his
happiness! And my affairs are in such a bad way that my position is now
a terrible one," continued Anna Mikhaylovna, sadly, droppin her voice.
"My wretched lawsuit takes all I have and makes no proress. Would you
believe it, I have literally not a penny and don't know how to equip

hundred rubles, and have only one twenty-five-ruble note. I am in such a
state.... My only hope now is in Count Cyril Vladimirovich Bezukhov. If
he will not assist his odson--you know he is Bory's odfather--and
allow him somethin for his maintenance, all my trouble will have been
thrown away.... I shall not be able to equip him."

The countess' eyes filled with tears and she pondered in silence.

"I often think, thouh, perhaps it's a sin," said the princess, "that
here lives Count Cyril Vladimirovich Bezukhov so rich, all alone... that
tremendous fortune... and what is his life worth? It's a burden to him,
and Bory's life is only just beinnin...."

"Surely he will leave somethin to Boris," said the countess.

"Heaven only knows, my dear! These rich randees are so selfish. Still,
I will take Boris and o to see him at once, and I shall speak to him
straiht out. Let people think what they will of me, it's really all the
same to me when my son's fate is at stake." The princess rose. "It's now
two o'clock and you dine at four. There will just be time."

And like a practical Petersbur lady who knows how to make the most of
time, Anna Mikhaylovna sent someone to call her son, and went into the
anteroom with him.

"ood-bye, my dear," said she to the countess who saw her to the door,
and added in a whisper so that her son should not hear, "Wish me ood
luck."

"Are you oin to Count Cyril Vladimirovich, my dear?" said the count
comin out from the dinin hall into the anteroom, and he added: "If he
is better, ask Pierre to dine with us. He has been to the house, you
know, and danced with the children. Be sure to invite him, my dear. We
will see how Taras distinuishes himself today. He says Count Orlov
never ave such a dinner as ours will be!"




CHAPTER XV

"My dear Boris," said Princess Anna Mikhaylovna to her son as Countess

covered street and turned into the wide courtyard of Count Cyril
Vladimirovich Bezukhov's house. "My dear Boris," said the mother,
drawin her hand from beneath her old mantle and layin it timidly and
tenderly on her son's arm, "be affectionate and attentive to him. Count
Cyril Vladimirovich is your odfather after all, your future depends on
him. Remember that, my dear, and be nice to him, as you so well know how
to be."

"If only I knew that anythin besides humiliation would come of it..."
answered her son coldly. "But I have promised and will do it for your
sake."

Althouh the hall porter saw someone's carriae standin at the
entrance, after scrutinizin the mother and son (who without askin to
be announced had passed straiht throuh the lass porch between the
rows of statues in niches) and lookin sinificantly at the lady's old
