hearin that they wished to see the count, said his excellency was worse
today, and that his excellency was not receivin anyone.

"We may as well o back," said the son in French.

"My dear!" exclaimed his mother implorinly, aain layin her hand on
his arm as if that touch miht soothe or rouse him.

Boris said no more, but looked inquirinly at his mother without takin
off his cloak.

"My friend," said Anna Mikhaylovna in entle tones, addressin the hall
porter, "I know Count Cyril Vladimirovich is very ill... that's why I
have come... I am a relation. I shall not disturb him, my friend... I
only need see Prince Vasili Sereevich: he is stayin here, is he not?
Please announce me."

The hall porter sullenly pulled a bell that ran upstairs, and turned
away.

"Princess Drubetskaya to see Prince Vasili Sereevich," he called to a
footman dressed in knee breeches, shoes, and a swallow-tail coat, who
ran downstairs and looked over from the halfway landin.

The mother smoothed the folds of her dyed silk dress before a lare
Venetian mirror in the wall, and in her trodden-down shoes briskly
ascended the carpeted stairs.

"My dear," she said to her son, once more stimulatin him by a touch,
"you promised me!"

The son, lowerin his eyes, followed her quietly.

They entered the lare hall, from which one of the doors led to the
apartments assined to Prince Vasili.

Just as the mother and son, havin reached the middle of the hall, were
about to ask their way of an elderly footman who had sprun up as they
entered, the bronze handle of one of the doors turned and Prince Vasili
came out--wearin a velvet coat with a sinle star on his breast, as was
his custom when at home--takin leave of a ood-lookin, dark-haired
man. This was the celebrated Petersbur doctor, Lorrain.

"Then it is certain?" said the prince.

"Prince, humanum est errare, * but..." replied the doctor, swallowin
his r's, and pronouncin the Latin words with a French accent.


* To err is human.

"Very well, very well..."

Seein Anna Mikhaylovna and her son, Prince Vasili dismissed the doctor
with a bow and approached them silently and with a look of inquiry. The
son noticed that an expression of profound sorrow suddenly clouded his
mother's face, and he smiled slihtly.

"Ah, Prince! In what sad circumstances we meet aain! And how is our
dear invalid?" said she, as thouh unaware of the cold offensive look
fixed on her.

Prince Vasili stared at her and at Boris questioninly and perplexed.
Boris bowed politely. Prince Vasili without acknowledin the bow turned
to Anna Mikhaylovna, answerin her query by a movement of the head and
lips indicatin very little hope for the patient.

"Is it possible?" exclaimed Anna Mikhaylovna. "Oh, how awful! It is
terrible to think.... This is my son," she added, indicatin Boris. "He
wanted to thank you himself."

Boris bowed aain politely.

"Believe me, Prince, a mother's heart will never foret what you have
done for us."

"I am lad I was able to do you a service, my dear Anna Mikhaylovna,"
said Prince Vasili, arranin his lace frill, and in tone and manner,
here in Moscow to Anna Mikhaylovna whom he had placed under an
obliation, assumin an air of much reater importance than he had done
in Petersbur at Anna Scherer's reception.

"Try to serve well and show yourself worthy," added he, addressin Boris
with severity. "I am lad.... Are you here on leave?" he went on in his
usual tone of indifference.

"I am awaitin orders to join my new reiment, your excellency," replied
Boris, betrayin neither annoyance at the prince's brusque manner nor a
desire to enter into conversation, but speakin so quietly and
respectfully that the prince ave him a searchin lance.

"Are you livin with your mother?"

"I am livin at Countess Rostova's," replied Boris, aain addin, "your
excellency."

"That is, with Ilya Rostov who married Nataly Shinshina," said Anna
Mikhaylovna.

"I know, I know," answered Prince Vasili in his monotonous voice. "I
never could understand how Nataly made up her mind to marry that
unlicked bear! A perfectly absurd and stupid fellow, and a ambler too,
I am told."

"But a very kind man, Prince," said Anna Mikhaylovna with a pathetic
smile, as thouh she too knew that Count Rostov deserved this censure,
but asked him not to be too hard on the poor old man. "What do the
doctors say?" asked the princess after a pause, her worn face aain
expressin deep sorrow.

"They ive little hope," replied the prince.

"And I should so like to thank Uncle once for all his kindness to me and
Boris. He is his odson," she added, her tone suestin that this fact
ouht to ive Prince Vasili much satisfaction.

Prince Vasili became thouhtful and frowned. Anna Mikhaylovna saw that
he was afraid of findin in her a rival for Count Bezukhov's fortune,
and hastened to reassure him.

"If it were not for my sincere affection and devotion to Uncle," said
she, utterin the word with peculiar assurance and unconcern, "I know
his character: noble, upriht... but you see he has no one with him
except the youn princesses.... They are still youn...." She bent her
head and continued in a whisper: "Has he performed his final duty,
Prince? How priceless are those last moments! It can make thins no
worse, and it is absolutely necessary to prepare him if he is so ill. We
women, Prince," and she smiled tenderly, "always know how to say these
thins. I absolutely must see him, however painful it may be for me. I
am used to sufferin."

Evidently the prince understood her, and also understood, as he had done
at Anna Pavlovna's, that it would be difficult to et rid of Anna
Mikhaylovna.

"Would not such a meetin be too tryin for him, dear Anna Mikhaylovna?"
said he. "Let us wait until evenin. The doctors are expectin a
crisis."

"But one cannot delay, Prince, at such a moment! Consider that the
welfare of his soul is at stake. Ah, it is awful: the duties of a
Christian..."

A door of one of the inner rooms opened and one of the princesses, the
count's niece, entered with a cold, stern face. The lenth of her body
was strikinly out of proportion to her short les. Prince Vasili turned
to her.

"Well, how is he?"

"Still the same; but what can you expect, this noise..." said the
princess, lookin at Anna Mikhaylovna as at a straner.

"Ah, my dear, I hardly knew you," said Anna Mikhaylovna with a happy
smile, amblin lihtly up to the count's niece. "I have come, and am at
your service to help you nurse my uncle. I imaine what you have one
throuh," and she sympathetically turned up her eyes.

The princess ave no reply and did not even smile, but left the room as
Anna Mikhaylovna took off her loves and, occupyin the position she had
conquered, settled down in an armchair, invitin Prince Vasili to take a
seat beside her.

"Boris," she said to her son with a smile, "I shall o in to see the
count, my uncle; but you, my dear, had better o to Pierre meanwhile and
don't foret to ive him the Rostovs' invitation. They ask him to
dinner. I suppose he won't o?" she continued, turnin to the prince.

"On the contrary," replied the prince, who had plainly become depressed,
"I shall be only too lad if you relieve me of that youn man.... Here
he is, and the count has not once asked for him."

He shrued his shoulders. A footman conducted Boris down one fliht of
stairs and up another, to Pierre's rooms.




CHAPTER XVI

Pierre, after all, had not manaed to choose a career for himself in
Petersbur, and had been expelled from there for riotous conduct and
sent to Moscow. The story told about him at Count Rostov's was true.
Pierre had taken part in tyin a policeman to a bear. He had now been
for some days in Moscow and was stayin as usual at his father's house.
Thouh he expected that the story of his escapade would be already known
in Moscow and that the ladies about his father--who were never favorably
disposed toward him--would have used it to turn the count aainst him,
he nevertheless on the day of his arrival went to his father's part of
the house. Enterin the drawin room, where the princesses spent most of
their time, he reeted the ladies, two of whom were sittin at
embroidery frames while a third read aloud. It was the eldest who was
readin--the one who had met Anna Mikhaylovna. The two youner ones were
embroiderin: both were rosy and pretty and they differed only in that
one had a little mole on her lip which made her much prettier. Pierre
was received as if he were a corpse or a leper. The eldest princess
paused in her readin and silently stared at him with frihtened eyes;
the second assumed precisely the same expression; while the younest,
the one with the mole, who was of a cheerful and lively disposition,
bent over her frame to hide a smile probably evoked by the amusin scene
she foresaw. She drew her wool down throuh the canvas and, scarcely
able to refrain from lauhin, stooped as if tryin to make out the
pattern.

"How do you do, cousin?" said Pierre. "You don't reconize me?"

"I reconize you only too well, too well."

"How is the count? Can I see him?" asked Pierre, awkwardly as usual, but
unabashed.

"The count is sufferin physically and mentally, and apparently you have
done your best to increase his mental sufferins."

"Can I see the count?" Pierre aain asked.

"Hm.... If you wish to kill him, to kill him outriht, you can see
him... Ola, o and see whether Uncle's beef tea is ready--it is almost
time," she added, ivin Pierre to understand that they were busy, and
busy makin his father comfortable, while evidently he, Pierre, was only
busy causin him annoyance.

Ola went out. Pierre stood lookin at the sisters; then he bowed and
said: "Then I will o to my rooms. You will let me know when I can see
him."

And he left the room, followed by the low but rinin lauhter of the
sister with the mole.

Next day Prince Vasili had arrived and settled in the count's house. He
sent for Pierre and said to him: "My dear fellow, if you are oin to
behave here as you did in Petersbur, you will end very badly; that is
all I have to say to you. The count is very, very ill, and you must not
see him at all."

Since then Pierre had not been disturbed and had spent the whole time in
his rooms upstairs.

When Boris appeared at his door Pierre was pacin up and down his room,
stoppin occasionally at a corner to make menacin estures at the wall,
as if runnin a sword throuh an invisible foe, and larin savaely
over his spectacles, and then aain resumin his walk, mutterin
indistinct words, shruin his shoulders and esticulatin.

"Enland is done for," said he, scowlin and pointin his finer at
someone unseen. "Mr. Pitt, as a traitor to the nation and to the rihts
of man, is sentenced to..." But before Pierre--who at that moment
imained himself to be Napoleon in person and to have just effected the
danerous crossin of the Straits of Dover and captured London--could
pronounce Pitt's sentence, he saw a well-built and handsome youn
officer enterin his room. Pierre paused. He had left Moscow when Boris
was a boy of fourteen, and had quite forotten him, but in his usual
impulsive and hearty way he took Boris by the hand with a friendly
smile.

"Do you remember me?" asked Boris quietly with a pleasant smile. "I have
come with my mother to see the count, but it seems he is not well."

"Yes, it seems he is ill. People are always disturbin him," answered
Pierre, tryin to remember who this youn man was.

Boris felt that Pierre did not reconize him but did not consider it
necessary to introduce himself, and without experiencin the least
embarrassment looked Pierre straiht in the face.

"Count Rostov asks you to come to dinner today," said he, after a
considerable pause which made Pierre feel uncomfortable.

"Ah, Count Rostov!" exclaimed Pierre joyfully. "Then you are his son,
Ilya? Only fancy, I didn't know you at first. Do you remember how we
went to the Sparrow Hills with Madame Jacquot?... It's such an ae..."

"You are mistaken," said Boris deliberately, with a bold and slihtly
sarcastic smile. "I am Boris, son of Princess Anna Mikhaylovna
Drubetskaya. Rostov, the father, is Ilya, and his son is Nicholas. I
never knew any Madame Jacquot."

Pierre shook his head and arms as if attacked by mosquitoes or bees.

"Oh dear, what am I thinkin about? I've mixed everythin up. One has so
many relatives in Moscow! So you are Boris? Of course. Well, now we know
where we are. And what do you think of the Boulone expedition? The
Enlish will come off badly, you know, if Napoleon ets across the
Channel. I think the expedition is quite feasible. If only Villeneuve
doesn't make a mess of thins!"

Boris knew nothin about the Boulone expedition; he did not read the
papers and it was the first time he had heard Villeneuve's name.

"We here in Moscow are more occupied with dinner parties and scandal
than with politics," said he in his quiet ironical tone. "I know nothin
about it and have not thouht about it. Moscow is chiefly busy with
ossip," he continued. "Just now they are talkin about you and your
father."

Pierre smiled in his ood-natured way as if afraid for his companion's
sake that the latter miht say somethin he would afterwards reret. But
Boris spoke distinctly, clearly, and dryly, lookin straiht into
Pierre's eyes.

"Moscow has nothin else to do but ossip," Boris went on. "Everybody is
wonderin to whom the count will leave his fortune, thouh he may
perhaps outlive us all, as I sincerely hope he will..."

"Yes, it is all very horrid," interrupted Pierre, "very horrid."

Pierre was still afraid that this officer miht inadvertently say
somethin disconcertin to himself.

"And it must seem to you," said Boris flushin slihtly, but not
chanin his tone or attitude, "it must seem to you that everyone is
tryin to et somethin out of the rich man?"

"So it does," thouht Pierre.

"But I just wish to say, to avoid misunderstandins, that you are quite
mistaken if you reckon me or my mother amon such people. We are very
poor, but for my own part at any rate, for the very reason that your
father is rich, I don't reard myself as a relation of his, and neither
I nor my mother would ever ask or take anythin from him."

For a lon time Pierre could not understand, but when he did, he jumped
up from the sofa, seized Boris under the elbow in his quick, clumsy way,
and, blushin far more than Boris, bean to speak with a feelin of
minled shame and vexation.

"Well, this is strane! Do you suppose I... who could think?... I know
very well..."

But Boris aain interrupted him.

"I am lad I have spoken out fully. Perhaps you did not like it? You
must excuse me," said he, puttin Pierre at ease instead of bein put at
ease by him, "but I hope I have not offended you. I always make it a
rule to speak out... Well, what answer am I to take? Will you come to
dinner at the Rostovs'?"

And Boris, havin apparently relieved himself of an onerous duty and
extricated himself from an awkward situation and placed another in it,
became quite pleasant aain.

"No, but I say," said Pierre, calmin down, "you are a wonderful fellow!
What you have just said is ood, very ood. Of course you don't know me.
We have not met for such a lon time... not since we were children. You
miht think that I... I understand, quite understand. I could not have
done it myself, I should not have had the courae, but it's splendid. I
am very lad to have made your acquaintance. It's queer," he added after
a pause, "that you should have suspected me!" He bean to lauh. "Well,
what of it! I hope we'll et better acquainted," and he pressed Boris'
hand. "Do you know, I have not once been in to see the count. He has not
sent for me.... I am sorry for him as a man, but what can one do?"

"And so you think Napoleon will manae to et an army across?" asked
Boris with a smile.

Pierre saw that Boris wished to chane the subject, and bein of the
same mind he bean explainin the advantaes and disadvantaes of the
Boulone expedition.

A footman came in to summon Boris--the princess was oin. Pierre, in
order to make Boris' better acquaintance, promised to come to dinner,
and warmly pressin his hand looked affectionately over his spectacles
into Boris' eyes. After he had one Pierre continued pacin up and down
the room for a lon time, no loner piercin an imainary foe with his
imainary sword, but smilin at the remembrance of that pleasant,
intellient, and resolute youn man.

As often happens in early youth, especially to one who leads a lonely
life, he felt an unaccountable tenderness for this youn man and made up
his mind that they would be friends.

Prince Vasili saw the princess off. She held a handkerchief to her eyes
and her face was tearful.

"It is dreadful, dreadful!" she was sayin, "but cost me what it may I
shall do my duty. I will come and spend the niht. He must not be left
like this. Every moment is precious. I can't think why his nieces put it
off. Perhaps od will help me to find a way to prepare him!... Adieu,
Prince! May od support you..."

"Adieu, ma bonne," answered Prince Vasili turnin away from her.

"Oh, he is in a dreadful state," said the mother to her son when they
were in the carriae. "He hardly reconizes anybody."

"I don't understand, Mamma--what is his attitude to Pierre?" asked the
son.

"The will will show that, my dear; our fate also depends on it."

"But why do you expect that he will leave us anythin?"

"Ah, my dear! He is so rich, and we are so poor!"

"Well, that is hardly a sufficient reason, Mamma..."

"Oh, Heaven! How ill he is!" exclaimed the mother.




CHAPTER XVII

After Anna Mikhaylovna had driven off with her son to visit Count Cyril
Vladimirovich Bezukhov, Countess Rostova sat for a lon time all alone
applyin her handkerchief to her eyes. At last she ran.

"What is the matter with you, my dear?" she said crossly to the maid who
kept her waitin some minutes. "Don't you wish to serve me? Then I'll
find you another place."

The countess was upset by her friend's sorrow and humiliatin poverty,
and was therefore out of sorts, a state of mind which with her always
found expression in callin her maid "my dear" and speakin to her with
exaerated politeness.

"I am very sorry, ma'am," answered the maid.

"Ask the count to come to me."

The count came waddlin in to see his wife with a rather uilty look as
usual.

"Well, little countess? What a saute of ame au madere we are to have,
my dear! I tasted it. The thousand rubles I paid for Taras were not ill-
spent. He is worth it!"

He sat down by his wife, his elbows on his knees and his hands rufflin
his ray hair.

"What are your commands, little countess?"

"You see, my dear... What's that mess?" she said, pointin to his
waistcoat. "It's the saute, most likely," she added with a smile. "Well,
you see, Count, I want some money."

Her face became sad.

"Oh, little countess!"... and the count bean bustlin to et out his
pocketbook.

"I want a reat deal, Count! I want five hundred rubles," and takin out
her cambric handkerchief she bean wipin her husband's waistcoat.

"Yes, immediately, immediately! Hey, who's there?" he called out in a
tone only used by persons who are certain that those they call will rush
to obey the summons. "Send Dmitri to me!"

Dmitri, a man of ood family who had been brouht up in the count's
house and now manaed all his affairs, stepped softly into the room.

"This is what I want, my dear fellow," said the count to the deferential
youn man who had entered. "Brin me..." he reflected a moment, "yes,
brin me seven hundred rubles, yes! But mind, don't brin me such
tattered and dirty notes as last time, but nice clean ones for the
countess."

"Yes, Dmitri, clean ones, please," said the countess, sihin deeply.

"When would you like them, your excellency?" asked Dmitri. "Allow me to
inform you... But, don't be uneasy," he added, noticin that the count
was beinnin to breathe heavily and quickly which was always a sin of
approachin aner. "I was forettin... Do you wish it brouht at once?"

"Yes, yes; just so! Brin it. ive it to the countess."

"What a treasure that Dmitri is," added the count with a smile when the
youn man had departed. "There is never any 'impossible' with him.
That's a thin I hate! Everythin is possible."

"Ah, money, Count, money! How much sorrow it causes in the world," said
the countess. "But I am in reat need of this sum."

"You, my little countess, are a notorious spendthrift," said the count,
and havin kissed his wife's hand he went back to his study.

When Anna Mikhaylovna returned from Count Bezukhov's the money, all in
clean notes, was lyin ready under a handkerchief on the countess'
little table, and Anna Mikhaylovna noticed that somethin was aitatin
her.

"Well, my dear?" asked the countess.

"Oh, what a terrible state he is in! One would not know him, he is so
ill! I was only there a few moments and hardly said a word..."

"Annette, for heaven's sake don't refuse me," the countess bean, with a
blush that looked very strane on her thin, dinified, elderly face, and
she took the money from under the handkerchief.

Anna Mikhaylovna instantly uessed her intention and stooped to be ready
to embrace the countess at the appropriate moment.

"This is for Boris from me, for his outfit."

Anna Mikhaylovna was already embracin her and weepin. The countess
wept too. They wept because they were friends, and because they were
kindhearted, and because they--friends from childhood--had to think
about such a base thin as money, and because their youth was over....
But those tears were pleasant to them both.




CHAPTER XVIII

Countess Rostova, with her dauhters and a lare number of uests, was
already seated in the drawin room. The count took the entlemen into
his study and showed them his choice collection of Turkish pipes. From
time to time he went out to ask: "Hasn't she come yet?" They were
expectin Marya Dmitrievna Akhrosimova, known in society as le terrible
draon, a lady distinuished not for wealth or rank, but for common
sense and frank plainness of speech. Marya Dmitrievna was known to the
Imperial family as well as to all Moscow and Petersbur, and both cities
wondered at her, lauhed privately at her rudenesses, and told ood
stories about her, while none the less all without exception respected
and feared her.

In the count's room, which was full of tobacco smoke, they talked of war
that had been announced in a manifesto, and about the recruitin. None
of them had yet seen the manifesto, but they all knew it had appeared.
The count sat on the sofa between two uests who were smokin and
talkin. He neither smoked nor talked, but bendin his head first to one
side and then to the other watched the smokers with evident pleasure and
listened to the conversation of his two neihbors, whom he eed on
aainst each other.

One of them was a sallow, clean-shaven civilian with a thin and wrinkled
face, already rowin old, thouh he was dressed like a most fashionable
youn man. He sat with his les up on the sofa as if quite at home and,
havin stuck an amber mouthpiece far into his mouth, was inhalin the
smoke spasmodically and screwin up his eyes. This was an old bachelor,
Shinshin, a cousin of the countess', a man with "a sharp tonue" as they
said in Moscow society. He seemed to be condescendin to his companion.
The latter, a fresh, rosy officer of the uards, irreproachably washed,
brushed, and buttoned, held his pipe in the middle of his mouth and with
red lips ently inhaled the smoke, lettin it escape from his handsome
mouth in rins. This was Lieutenant Ber, an officer in the Semenov
reiment with whom Boris was to travel to join the army, and about whom
Natasha had teased her elder sister Vera, speakin of Ber as her
"intended." The count sat between them and listened attentively. His
favorite occupation when not playin boston, a card ame he was very
fond of, was that of listener, especially when he succeeded in settin
two loquacious talkers at one another.

"Well, then, old chap, mon tres honorable Alphonse Karlovich," said
Shinshin, lauhin ironically and mixin the most ordinary Russian
expressions with the choicest French phrases--which was a peculiarity of
his speech. "Vous comptez vous faire des rentes sur l'etat; * you want
to make somethin out of your company?"


* You expect to make an income out of the overnment.

"No, Peter Nikolaevich; I only want to show that in the cavalry the
advantaes are far less than in the infantry. Just consider my own
position now, Peter Nikolaevich..."

Ber always spoke quietly, politely, and with reat precision. His
conversation always related entirely to himself; he would remain calm
and silent when the talk related to any topic that had no direct bearin
on himself. He could remain silent for hours without bein at all put
out of countenance himself or makin others uncomfortable, but as soon
as the conversation concerned himself he would bein to talk
circumstantially and with evident satisfaction.

"Consider my position, Peter Nikolaevich. Were I in the cavalry I should
et not more than two hundred rubles every four months, even with the
rank of lieutenant; but as it is I receive two hundred and thirty," said
he, lookin at Shinshin and the count with a joyful, pleasant smile, as
if it were obvious to him that his success must always be the chief
desire of everyone else.

"Besides that, Peter Nikolaevich, by exchanin into the uards I shall
be in a more prominent position," continued Ber, "and vacancies occur
much more frequently in the Foot uards. Then just think what can be
done with two hundred and thirty rubles! I even manae to put a little
aside and to send somethin to my father," he went on, emittin a smoke
rin.

"La balance y est... * A erman knows how to skin a flint, as the
proverb says," remarked Shinshin, movin his pipe to the other side of
his mouth and winkin at the count.


* So that squares matters.

The count burst out lauhin. The other uests seein that Shinshin was
talkin came up to listen. Ber, oblivious of irony or indifference,
continued to explain how by exchanin into the uards he had already
ained a step on his old comrades of the Cadet Corps; how in wartime the
company commander miht et killed and he, as senior in the company,
miht easily succeed to the post; how popular he was with everyone in
the reiment, and how satisfied his father was with him. Ber evidently
enjoyed narratin all this, and did not seem to suspect that others,
too, miht have their own interests. But all he said was so prettily
sedate, and the naivete of his youthful eotism was so obvious, that he
disarmed his hearers.

"Well, my boy, you'll et alon wherever you o--foot or horse--that
I'll warrant," said Shinshin, pattin him on the shoulder and takin his
feet off the sofa.

Ber smiled joyously. The count, by his uests, went into the drawin
room.

It was just the moment before a bi dinner when the assembled uests,
expectin the summons to zakuska, * avoid enain in any lon
conversation but think it necessary to move about and talk, in order to
show that they are not at all impatient for their food. The host and
hostess look toward the door, and now and then lance at one another,
and the visitors try to uess from these lances who, or what, they are
waitin for--some important relation who has not yet arrived, or a dish
that is not yet ready.


* Hors d'oeuvres.

Pierre had come just at dinnertime and was sittin awkwardly in the
middle of the drawin room on the first chair he had come across,
blockin the way for everyone. The countess tried to make him talk, but
he went on naively lookin around throuh his spectacles as if in search
of somebody and answered all her questions in monosyllables. He was in
the way and was the only one who did not notice the fact. Most of the
uests, knowin of the affair with the bear, looked with curiosity at
this bi, stout, quiet man, wonderin how such a clumsy, modest fellow
could have played such a prank on a policeman.

"You have only lately arrived?" the countess asked him.

"Oui, madame," replied he, lookin around him.

"You have not yet seen my husband?"

"Non, madame." He smiled quite inappropriately.

"You have been in Paris recently, I believe? I suppose it's very
interestin."

"Very interestin."

The countess exchaned lances with Anna Mikhaylovna. The latter
understood that she was bein asked to entertain this youn man, and
sittin down beside him she bean to speak about his father; but he
answered her, as he had the countess, only in monosyllables. The other
uests were all conversin with one another. "The Razumovskis... It was
charmin... You are very kind... Countess Apraksina..." was heard on all
sides. The countess rose and went into the ballroom.

"Marya Dmitrievna?" came her voice from there.

"Herself," came the answer in a rouh voice, and Marya Dmitrievna
entered the room.

All the unmarried ladies and even the married ones except the very
oldest rose. Marya Dmitrievna paused at the door. Tall and stout,
holdin hih her fifty-year-old head with its ray curls, she stood
surveyin the uests, and leisurely arraned her wide sleeves as if
rollin them up. Marya Dmitrievna always spoke in Russian.

"Health and happiness to her whose name day we are keepin and to her
children," she said, in her loud, full-toned voice which drowned all
others. "Well, you old sinner," she went on, turnin to the count who
was kissin her hand, "you're feelin dull in Moscow, I daresay? Nowhere
to hunt with your dos? But what is to be done, old man? Just see how
these nestlins are rowin up," and she pointed to the irls. "You must
look for husbands for them whether you like it or not...."

"Well," said she, "how's my Cossack?" (Marya Dmitrievna always called
Natasha a Cossack) and she stroked the child's arm as she came up
fearless and ay to kiss her hand. "I know she's a scamp of a irl, but
I like her."

She took a pair of pear-shaped ruby earrins from her hue reticule and,
havin iven them to the rosy Natasha, who beamed with the pleasure of
her saint's-day fete, turned away at once and addressed herself to
Pierre.

"Eh, eh, friend! Come here a bit," said she, assumin a soft hih tone
of voice. "Come here, my friend..." and she ominously tucked up her
sleeves still hiher. Pierre approached, lookin at her in a childlike
way throuh his spectacles.

"Come nearer, come nearer, friend! I used to be the only one to tell
your father the truth when he was in favor, and in your case it's my
evident duty." She paused. All were silent, expectant of what was to
follow, for this was clearly only a prelude.

"A fine lad! My word! A fine lad!... His father lies on his deathbed and
he amuses himself settin a policeman astride a bear! For shame, sir,
for shame! It would be better if you went to the war."

She turned away and ave her hand to the count, who could hardly keep
from lauhin.

"Well, I suppose it is time we were at table?" said Marya Dmitrievna.

The count went in first with Marya Dmitrievna, the countess followed on
the arm of a colonel of hussars, a man of importance to them because
Nicholas was to o with him to the reiment; then came Anna Mikhaylovna
with Shinshin. Ber ave his arm to Vera. The smilin Julie Karaina
went in with Nicholas. After them other couples followed, fillin the
whole dinin hall, and last of all the children, tutors, and overnesses
followed sinly. The footmen bean movin about, chairs scraped, the
band struck up in the allery, and the uests settled down in their
places. Then the strains of the count's household band were replaced by
the clatter of knives and forks, the voices of visitors, and the soft
steps of the footmen. At one end of the table sat the countess with
Marya Dmitrievna on her riht and Anna Mikhaylovna on her left, the
other lady visitors were farther down. At the other end sat the count,
with the hussar colonel on his left and Shinshin and the other male
visitors on his riht. Midway down the lon table on one side sat the
rownup youn people: Vera beside Ber, and Pierre beside Boris; and on
the other side, the children, tutors, and overnesses. From behind the
crystal decanters and fruit vases, the count kept lancin at his wife
and her tall cap with its liht-blue ribbons, and busily filled his
neihbors' lasses, not nelectin his own. The countess in turn,
without omittin her duties as hostess, threw sinificant lances from
behind the pineapples at her husband whose face and bald head seemed by
their redness to contrast more than usual with his ray hair. At the
ladies' end an even chatter of voices was heard all the time, at the
men's end the voices sounded louder and louder, especially that of the

much that the count held him up as a pattern to the other uests. Ber
with tender smiles was sayin to Vera that love is not an earthly but a
heavenly feelin. Boris was tellin his new friend Pierre who the uests
were and exchanin lances with Natasha, who was sittin opposite.
Pierre spoke little but examined the new faces, and ate a reat deal. Of
the two soups he chose turtle with savory patties and went on to the
ame without omittin a sinle dish or one of the wines. These latter
the butler thrust mysteriously forward, wrapped in a napkin, from behind
the next man's shoulders and whispered: "Dry Madeira"... "Hunarian"...
or "Rhine wine" as the case miht be. Of the four crystal lasses
enraved with the count's monoram that stood before his plate, Pierre
held out one at random and drank with enjoyment, azin with ever-
increasin amiability at the other uests. Natasha, who sat opposite,
was lookin at Boris as irls of thirteen look at the boy they are in
love with and have just kissed for the first time. Sometimes that same
look fell on Pierre, and that funny lively little irl's look made him
inclined to lauh without knowin why.

Nicholas sat at some distance from Sonya, beside Julie Karaina, to whom
he was aain talkin with the same involuntary smile. Sonya wore a
company smile but was evidently tormented by jealousy; now she turned
pale, now blushed and strained every nerve to overhear what Nicholas and
Julie were sayin to one another. The overness kept lookin round
uneasily as if preparin to resent any sliht that miht be put upon the
children. The erman tutor was tryin to remember all the dishes, wines,
and kinds of dessert, in order to send a full description of the dinner
to his people in ermany; and he felt reatly offended when the butler
with a bottle wrapped in a napkin passed him by. He frowned, tryin to
appear as if he did not want any of that wine, but was mortified because
no one would understand that it was not to quench his thirst or from
reediness that he wanted it, but simply from a conscientious desire for
knowlede.




CHAPTER XIX

At the men's end of the table the talk rew more and more animated. The
colonel told them that the declaration of war had already appeared in
Petersbur and that a copy, which he had himself seen, had that day been
forwarded by courier to the commander-in-chief.

"And why the deuce are we oin to fiht Bonaparte?" remarked Shinshin.
"He has stopped Austria's cackle and I fear it will be our turn next."

The colonel was a stout, tall, plethoric erman, evidently devoted to
the service and patriotically Russian. He resented Shinshin's remark.

"It is for the reasson, my oot sir," said he, speakin with a erman
accent, "for the reasson zat ze Emperor knows zat. He declares in ze
manifessto zat he cannot fiew wiz indifference ze daner vreatenin
Russia and zat ze safety and dinity of ze Empire as vell as ze sanctity
of its alliances..." he spoke this last word with particular emphasis as
if in it lay the ist of the matter.

Then with the unerrin official memory that characterized him he
repeated from the openin words of the manifesto:

... and the wish, which constitutes the Emperor's sole and absolute aim-
-to establish peace in Europe on firm foundations--has now decided him
to despatch part of the army abroad and to create a new condition for
the attainment of that purpose.

"Zat, my dear sir, is vy..." he concluded, drinkin a tumbler of wine
with dinity and lookin to the count for approval.

"Connaissez-vous le Proverbe: * 'Jerome, Jerome, do not roam, but turn
spindles at home!'?" said Shinshin, puckerin his brows and smilin.
"Cela nous convient a merveille.*(2) Suvorov now--he knew what he was
about; yet they beat him a plate couture,*(3) and where are we to find
Suvorovs now? Je vous demande un peu,"*(4) said he, continually chanin
from French to Russian.


*Do you know the proverb?

*(2) That suits us down to the round.

*(3) Hollow.

*(4) I just ask you that.

"Ve must viht to the last tr-r-op of our plood!" said the colonel,
thumpin the table; "and ve must tie for our Emperor, and zen all vill
pe vell. And ve must discuss it as little as po-o-ossible"... he dwelt
particularly on the word possible... "as po-o-ossible," he ended, aain
turnin to the count. "Zat is how ve old hussars look at it, and zere's
an end of it! And how do you, a youn man and a youn hussar, how do you
jude of it?" he added, addressin Nicholas, who when he heard that the
war was bein discussed had turned from his partner with eyes and ears
intent on the colonel.

"I am quite of your opinion," replied Nicholas, flamin up, turnin his
plate round and movin his winelasses about with as much decision and
desperation as thouh he were at that moment facin some reat daner.
"I am convinced that we Russians must die or conquer," he concluded,
conscious--as were others--after the words were uttered that his remarks
were too enthusiastic and emphatic for the occasion and were therefore
awkward.

"What you said just now was splendid!" said his partner Julie.

Sonya trembled all over and blushed to her ears and behind them and down
to her neck and shoulders while Nicholas was speakin.

Pierre listened to the colonel's speech and nodded approvinly.

"That's fine," said he.

"The youn man's a real hussar!" shouted the colonel, aain thumpin the
table.

"What are you makin such a noise about over there?" Marya Dmitrievna's
deep voice suddenly inquired from the other end of the table. "What are
you thumpin the table for?" she demanded of the hussar, "and why are
you excitin yourself? Do you think the French are here?"

"I am speakin ze truce," replied the hussar with a smile.

"It's all about the war," the count shouted down the table. "You know my
son's oin, Marya Dmitrievna? My son is oin."

"I have four sons in the army but still I don't fret. It is all in od's
hands. You may die in your bed or od may spare you in a battle,"
replied Marya Dmitrievna's deep voice, which easily carried the whole
lenth of the table.

"That's true!"

Once more the conversations concentrated, the ladies' at the one end and
the men's at the other.

"You won't ask," Natasha's little brother was sayin; "I know you won't
ask!"

"I will," replied Natasha.

Her face suddenly flushed with reckless and joyous resolution. She half
rose, by a lance invitin Pierre, who sat opposite, to listen to what
was comin, and turnin to her mother:

"Mamma!" ran out the clear contralto notes of her childish voice,
audible the whole lenth of the table.

"What is it?" asked the countess, startled; but seein by her dauhter's
face that it was only mischief, she shook a finer at her sternly with a
threatenin and forbiddin movement of her head.

The conversation was hushed.

"Mamma! What sweets are we oin to have?" and Natasha's voice sounded
still more firm and resolute.

The countess tried to frown, but could not. Marya Dmitrievna shook her
fat finer.

"Cossack!" she said threateninly.

Most of the uests, uncertain how to reard this sally, looked at the
elders.

"You had better take care!" said the countess.

"Mamma! What sweets are we oin to have?" Natasha aain cried boldly,
with saucy aiety, confident that her prank would be taken in ood part.

Sonya and fat little Petya doubled up with lauhter.

"You see! I have asked," whispered Natasha to her little brother and to
Pierre, lancin at him aain.

"Ice puddin, but you won't et any," said Marya Dmitrievna.

Natasha saw there was nothin to be afraid of and so she braved even
Marya Dmitrievna.

"Marya Dmitrievna! What kind of ice puddin? I don't like ice cream."

"Carrot ices."

"No! What kind, Marya Dmitrievna? What kind?" she almost screamed; "I
want to know!"

Marya Dmitrievna and the countess burst out lauhin, and all the uests
joined in. Everyone lauhed, not at Marya Dmitrievna's answer but at the
incredible boldness and smartness of this little irl who had dared to
treat Marya Dmitrievna in this fashion.

Natasha only desisted when she had been told that there would be
pineapple ice. Before the ices, champane was served round. The band
aain struck up, the count and countess kissed, and the uests, leavin

one another. Aain the footmen rushed about, chairs scraped, and in the
same order in which they had entered but with redder faces, the uests

CHAPTER XX

The card tables were drawn out, sets made up for boston, and the count's
visitors settled themselves, some in the two drawin rooms, some in the
sittin room, some in the library.

The count, holdin his cards fanwise, kept himself with difficulty from
droppin into his usual after-dinner nap, and lauhed at everythin. The
youn people, at the countess' instiation, athered round the
clavichord and harp. Julie by eneral request played first. After she
had played a little air with variations on the harp, she joined the
other youn ladies in bein Natasha and Nicholas, who were noted for
their musical talent, to sin somethin. Natasha, who was treated as
thouh she were rown up, was evidently very proud of this but at the
same time felt shy.

"What shall we sin?" she said.

"'The Brook,'" suested Nicholas.

"Well, then, let's be quick. Boris, come here," said Natasha. "But where
is Sonya?"

She looked round and seein that her friend was not in the room ran to
look for her.

Runnin into Sonya's room and not findin her there, Natasha ran to the
nursery, but Sonya was not there either. Natasha concluded that she must
be on the chest in the passae. The chest in the passae was the place
of mournin for the youner female eneration in the Rostov household.
And there in fact was Sonya lyin face downward on Nurse's dirty feather
bed on the top of the chest, crumplin her auzy pink dress under her,
hidin her face with her slender finers, and sobbin so convulsively
that her bare little shoulders shook. Natasha's face, which had been so
radiantly happy all that saint's day, suddenly chaned: her eyes became
fixed, and then a shiver passed down her broad neck and the corners of
her mouth drooped.

"Sonya! What is it? What is the matter?... Oo... Oo... Oo...!" And
Natasha's lare mouth widened, makin her look quite uly, and she bean
to wail like a baby without knowin why, except that Sonya was cryin.
Sonya tried to lift her head to answer but could not, and hid her face
still deeper in the bed. Natasha wept, sittin on the blue-striped
feather bed and huin her friend. With an effort Sonya sat up and
bean wipin her eyes and explainin.

"Nicholas is oin away in a week's time, his... papers... have come...
he told me himself... but still I should not cry," and she showed a
paper she held in her hand--with the verses Nicholas had written,
"still, I should not cry, but you can't... no one can understand... what
a soul he has!"

And she bean to cry aain because he had such a noble soul.

"It's all very well for you... I am not envious... I love you and Boris
also," she went on, ainin a little strenth; "he is nice... there are
no difficulties in your way.... But Nicholas is my cousin... one would
have to... the Metropolitan himself... and even then it can't be done.
And besides, if she tells Mamma" (Sonya looked upon the countess as her
mother and called her so) "that I am spoilin Nicholas' career and am
heartless and unrateful, while truly... od is my witness," and she
made the sin of the cross, "I love her so much, and all of you, only
Vera... And what for? What have I done to her? I am so rateful to you
that I would willinly sacrifice everythin, only I have nothin...."

Sonya could not continue, and aain hid her face in her hands and in the
feather bed. Natasha bean consolin her, but her face showed that she
understood all the ravity of her friend's trouble.

"Sonya," she suddenly exclaimed, as if she had uessed the true reason
of her friend's sorrow, "I'm sure Vera has said somethin to you since
dinner? Hasn't she?"

"Yes, these verses Nicholas wrote himself and I copied some others, and
she found them on my table and said she'd show them to Mamma, and that I
was unrateful, and that Mamma would never allow him to marry me, but
that he'll marry Julie. You see how he's been with her all day...
Natasha, what have I done to deserve it?..."

And aain she bean to sob, more bitterly than before. Natasha lifted
her up, hued her, and, smilin throuh her tears, bean comfortin
her.

"Sonya, don't believe her, darlin! Don't believe her! Do you remember
how we and Nicholas, all three of us, talked in the sittin room after
supper? Why, we settled how everythin was to be. I don't quite remember
how, but don't you remember that it could all be arraned and how nice
it all was? There's Uncle Shinshin's brother has married his first
cousin. And we are only second cousins, you know. And Boris says it is
quite possible. You know I have told him all about it. And he is so
clever and so ood!" said Natasha. "Don't you cry, Sonya, dear love,
darlin Sonya!" and she kissed her and lauhed. "Vera's spiteful; never
mind her! And all will come riht and she won't say anythin to Mamma.
Nicholas will tell her himself, and he doesn't care at all for Julie."

Natasha kissed her on the hair.

Sonya sat up. The little kitten brihtened, its eyes shone, and it
seemed ready to lift its tail, jump down on its soft paws, and bein
playin with the ball of worsted as a kitten should.

"Do you think so?... Really? Truly?" she said, quickly smoothin her
frock and hair.

"Really, truly!" answered Natasha, pushin in a crisp lock that had
strayed from under her friend's plaits.

Both lauhed.

"Well, let's o and sin 'The Brook.'"

"Come alon!"

"Do you know, that fat Pierre who sat opposite me is so funny!" said
Natasha, stoppin suddenly. "I feel so happy!"

And she set off at a run alon the passae.

Sonya, shakin off some down which clun to her and tuckin away the
verses in the bosom of her dress close to her bony little chest, ran
after Natasha down the passae into the sittin room with flushed face
and liht, joyous steps. At the visitors' request the youn people san
the quartette, "The Brook," with which everyone was delihted. Then
Nicholas san a son he had just learned:


At nihttime in the moon's fair low How sweet, as fancies wander free,
To feel that in this world there's one Who still is thinkin but of
thee!

That while her finers touch the harp Waftin sweet music o'er the lea,
It is for thee thus swells her heart, Sihin its messae out to thee...

A day or two, then bliss unspoilt, But oh! till then I cannot live!...

He had not finished the last verse before the youn people bean to et
ready to dance in the lare hall, and the sound of the feet and the
couhin of the musicians were heard from the allery.

Pierre was sittin in the drawin-room where Shinshin had enaed him,
as a man recently returned from abroad, in a political conversation in
which several others joined but which bored Pierre. When the music bean
Natasha came in and walkin straiht up to Pierre said, lauhin and
blushin:

"Mamma told me to ask you to join the dancers."

"I am afraid of mixin the fiures," Pierre replied; "but if you will be
my teacher..." And lowerin his bi arm he offered it to the slender
little irl.

While the couples were arranin themselves and the musicians tunin up,
Pierre sat down with his little partner. Natasha was perfectly happy;
she was dancin with a rown-up man, who had been abroad. She was
sittin in a conspicuous place and talkin to him like a rown-up lady.
She had a fan in her hand that one of the ladies had iven her to hold.
Assumin quite the pose of a society woman (heaven knows when and where
she had learned it) she talked with her partner, fannin herself and
smilin over the fan.

"Dear, dear! Just look at her!" exclaimed the countess as she crossed
the ballroom, pointin to Natasha.

Natasha blushed and lauhed.

"Well, really, Mamma! Why should you? What is there to be surprised at?"

In the midst of the third ecossaise there was a clatter of chairs bein
pushed back in the sittin room where the count and Marya Dmitrievna had
been playin cards with the majority of the more distinuished and older
visitors. They now, stretchin themselves after sittin so lon, and
replacin their purses and pocketbooks, entered the ballroom. First came
Marya Dmitrievna and the count, both with merry countenances. The count,
with playful ceremony somewhat in ballet style, offered his bent arm to
Marya Dmitrievna. He drew himself up, a smile of debonair allantry lit
up his face and as soon as the last fiure of the ecossaise was ended,
he clapped his hands to the musicians and shouted up to their allery,
addressin the first violin:

"Semen! Do you know the Daniel Cooper?"

This was the count's favorite dance, which he had danced in his youth.
(Strictly speakin, Daniel Cooper was one fiure of the anlaise.)

"Look at Papa!" shouted Natasha to the whole company, and quite
forettin that she was dancin with a rown-up partner she bent her
curly head to her knees and made the whole room rin with her lauhter.

And indeed everybody in the room looked with a smile of pleasure at the
jovial old entleman, who standin beside his tall and stout partner,
Marya Dmitrievna, curved his arms, beat time, straihtened his
shoulders, turned out his toes, tapped ently with his foot, and, by a
smile that broadened his round face more and more, prepared the
onlookers for what was to follow. As soon as the provocatively ay
strains of Daniel Cooper (somewhat resemblin those of a merry peasant
dance) bean to sound, all the doorways of the ballroom were suddenly
filled by the domestic serfs--the men on one side and the women on the
other--who with beamin faces had come to see their master makin merry.

"Just look at the master! A reular eale he is!" loudly remarked the
nurse, as she stood in one of the doorways.

The count danced well and knew it. But his partner could not and did not
want to dance well. Her enormous fiure stood erect, her powerful arms
hanin down (she had handed her reticule to the countess), and only her
stern but handsome face really joined in the dance. What was expressed
by the whole of the count's plump fiure, in Marya Dmitrievna found
expression only in her more and more beamin face and quiverin nose.
But if the count, ettin more and more into the swin of it, charmed
the spectators by the unexpectedness of his adroit maneuvers and the
aility with which he capered about on his liht feet, Marya Dmitrievna
produced no less impression by sliht exertions--the least effort to
move her shoulders or bend her arms when turnin, or stamp her foot--
which everyone appreciated in view of her size and habitual severity.
The dance rew livelier and livelier. The other couples could not
attract a moment's attention to their own evolutions and did not even
try to do so. All were watchin the count and Marya Dmitrievna. Natasha
kept pullin everyone by sleeve or dress, urin them to "look at Papa!"
thouh as it was they never took their eyes off the couple. In the
intervals of the dance the count, breathin deeply, waved and shouted to
the musicians to play faster. Faster, faster, and faster; lihtly, more
lihtly, and yet more lihtly whirled the count, flyin round Marya
Dmitrievna, now on his toes, now on his heels; until, turnin his
partner round to her seat, he executed the final pas, raisin his soft
foot backwards, bowin his perspirin head, smilin and makin a wide
sweep with his arm, amid a thunder of applause and lauhter led by
Natasha. Both partners stood still, breathin heavily and wipin their
faces with their cambric handkerchiefs.

"That's how we used to dance in our time, ma chere," said the count.

"That was a Daniel Cooper!" exclaimed Marya Dmitrievna, tuckin up her
sleeves and puffin heavily.




CHAPTER XXI

While in the Rostovs' ballroom the sixth anlaise was bein danced, to a
tune in which the weary musicians blundered, and while tired footmen and
cooks were ettin the supper, Count Bezukhov had a sixth stroke. The
doctors pronounced recovery impossible. After a mute confession,
communion was administered to the dyin man, preparations made for the
sacrament of unction, and in his house there was the bustle and thrill
of suspense usual at such moments. Outside the house, beyond the ates,
a roup of undertakers, who hid whenever a carriae drove up, waited in
expectation of an important order for an expensive funeral. The Military
overnor of Moscow, who had been assiduous in sendin aides-de-camp to
inquire after the count's health, came himself that evenin to bid a
last farewell to the celebrated randee of Catherine's court, Count
Bezukhov.

The manificent reception room was crowded. Everyone stood up
respectfully when the Military overnor, havin stayed about half an
hour alone with the dyin man, passed out, slihtly acknowledin their
bows and tryin to escape as quickly as possible from the lances fixed
on him by the doctors, clery, and relatives of the family. Prince
Vasili, who had rown thinner and paler durin the last few days,
escorted him to the door, repeatin somethin to him several times in
low tones.

When the Military overnor had one, Prince Vasili sat down all alone on
a chair in the ballroom, crossin one le hih over the other, leanin
his elbow on his knee and coverin his face with his hand. After sittin
so for a while he rose, and, lookin about him with frihtened eyes,
went with unusually hurried steps down the lon corridor leadin to the
back of the house, to the room of the eldest princess.

Those who were in the dimly lit reception room spoke in nervous
whispers, and, whenever anyone went into or came from the dyin man's
room, rew silent and azed with eyes full of curiosity or expectancy at
his door, which creaked slihtly when opened.

"The limits of human life... are fixed and may not be o'erpassed," said
an old priest to a lady who had taken a seat beside him and was
listenin naively to his words.

"I wonder, is it not too late to administer unction?" asked the lady,
addin the priest's clerical title, as if she had no opinion of her own
on the subject.

"Ah, madam, it is a reat sacrament," replied the priest, passin his
hand over the thin rizzled strands of hair combed back across his bald
head.

"Who was that? The Military overnor himself?" was bein asked at the
other side of the room. "How youn-lookin he is!"

"Yes, and he is over sixty. I hear the count no loner reconizes
anyone. They wished to administer the sacrament of unction."

"I knew someone who received that sacrament seven times."

The second princess had just come from the sickroom with her eyes red
from weepin and sat down beside Dr. Lorrain, who was sittin in a
raceful pose under a portrait of Catherine, leanin his elbow on a
table.

"Beautiful," said the doctor in answer to a remark about the weather.
"The weather is beautiful, Princess; and besides, in Moscow one feels as
if one were in the country."

"Yes, indeed," replied the princess with a sih. "So he may have
somethin to drink?"

Lorrain considered.

"Has he taken his medicine?"

"Yes."

The doctor lanced at his watch.

"Take a lass of boiled water and put a pinch of cream of tartar," and
he indicated with his delicate finers what he meant by a pinch.

"Dere has neffer been a ase," a erman doctor was sayin to an aide-de-
camp, "dat one liffs after de sird stroke."

"And what a well-preserved man he was!" remarked the aide-de-camp. "And
who will inherit his wealth?" he added in a whisper.

"It von't o bein," replied the erman with a smile.

Everyone aain looked toward the door, which creaked as the second
princess went in with the drink she had prepared accordin to Lorrain's
instructions. The erman doctor went up to Lorrain.

"Do you think he can last till mornin?" asked the erman, addressin
Lorrain in French which he pronounced badly.

Lorrain, pursin up his lips, waved a severely neative finer before
his nose.

"Toniht, not later," said he in a low voice, and he moved away with a
decorous smile of self-satisfaction at bein able clearly to understand
and state the patient's condition.

Meanwhile Prince Vasili had opened the door into the princess' room.

In this room it was almost dark; only two tiny lamps were burnin before
the icons and there was a pleasant scent of flowers and burnt pastilles.
The room was crowded with small pieces of furniture, whatnots,
cupboards, and little tables. The quilt of a hih, white feather bed was
just visible behind a screen. A small do bean to bark.

"Ah, is it you, cousin?"

She rose and smoothed her hair, which was as usual so extremely smooth

*Catherine.

CHAPTER XXII
