warn me of the humor my father is in. I do not allow myself to jude him
and would not have others do so."

The princess lanced at her watch and, seein that she was five minutes
late in startin her practice on the clavichord, went into the sittin
room with a look of alarm. Between twelve and two o'clock, as the day
was mapped out, the prince rested and the princess played the
clavichord.




CHAPTER XXVI

The ray-haired valet was sittin drowsily listenin to the snorin of
the prince, who was in his lare study. From the far side of the house
throuh the closed doors came the sound of difficult passaes--twenty
times repeated--of a sonata by Dussek.

Just then a closed carriae and another with a hood drove up to the
porch. Prince Andrew ot out of the carriae, helped his little wife to
aliht, and let her pass into the house before him. Old Tikhon, wearin
a wi, put his head out of the door of the antechamber, reported in a
whisper that the prince was sleepin, and hastily closed the door.
Tikhon knew that neither the son's arrival nor any other unusual event
must be allowed to disturb the appointed order of the day. Prince Andrew
apparently knew this as well as Tikhon; he looked at his watch as if to
ascertain whether his father's habits had chaned since he was at home
last, and, havin assured himself that they had not, he turned to his
wife.

"He will et up in twenty minutes. Let us o across to Mary's room," he
said.

The little princess had rown stouter durin this time, but her eyes and
her short, downy, smilin lip lifted when she bean to speak just as
merrily and prettily as ever.

"Why, this is a palace!" she said to her husband, lookin around with
the expression with which people compliment their host at a ball. "Let's
come, quick, quick!" And with a lance round, she smiled at Tikhon, at
her husband, and at the footman who accompanied them.

"Is that Mary practicin? Let's o quietly and take her by surprise."

Prince Andrew followed her with a courteous but sad expression.

"You've rown older, Tikhon," he said in passin to the old man, who
kissed his hand.

Before they reached the room from which the sounds of the clavichord
came, the pretty, fair haired Frenchwoman, Mademoiselle Bourienne,
rushed out apparently beside herself with deliht.

"Ah! what joy for the princess!" exclaimed she: "At last! I must let her
know."

"No, no, please not... You are Mademoiselle Bourienne," said the little
princess, kissin her. "I know you already throuh my sister-in-law's
friendship for you. She was not expectin us?"

They went up to the door of the sittin room from which came the sound
of the oft-repeated passae of the sonata. Prince Andrew stopped and
made a rimace, as if expectin somethin unpleasant.

The little princess entered the room. The passae broke off in the
middle, a cry was heard, then Princess Mary's heavy tread and the sound
of kissin. When Prince Andrew went in the two princesses, who had only
met once before for a short time at his weddin, were in each other's
arms warmly pressin their lips to whatever place they happened to
touch. Mademoiselle Bourienne stood near them pressin her hand to her
heart, with a beatific smile and obviously equally ready to cry or to
lauh. Prince Andrew shrued his shoulders and frowned, as lovers of
music do when they hear a false note. The two women let o of one
another, and then, as if afraid of bein too late, seized each other's
hands, kissin them and pullin them away, and aain bean kissin each
other on the face, and then to Prince Andrew's surprise both bean to
cry and kissed aain. Mademoiselle Bourienne also bean to cry. Prince
Andrew evidently felt ill at ease, but to the two women it seemed quite
natural that they should cry, and apparently it never entered their
heads that it could have been otherwise at this meetin.

"Ah! my dear!... Ah! Mary!" they suddenly exclaimed, and then lauhed.
"I dreamed last niht..."--"You were not expectin us?..." "Ah! Mary,
you have ot thinner?..." "And you have rown stouter!..."

"I knew the princess at once," put in Mademoiselle Bourienne.

"And I had no idea!..." exclaimed Princess Mary. "Ah, Andrew, I did not
see you."

Prince Andrew and his sister, hand in hand, kissed one another, and he
told her she was still the same crybaby as ever. Princess Mary had
turned toward her brother, and throuh her tears the lovin, warm,
entle look of her lare luminous eyes, very beautiful at that moment,
rested on Prince Andrew's face.

The little princess talked incessantly, her short, downy upper lip
continually and rapidly touchin her rosy nether lip when necessary and
drawin up aain next moment when her face broke into a smile of
litterin teeth and sparklin eyes. She told of an accident they had
had on the Spasski Hill which miht have been serious for her in her
condition, and immediately after that informed them that she had left
all her clothes in Petersbur and that heaven knew what she would have
to dress in here; and that Andrew had quite chaned, and that Kitty
Odyntsova had married an old man, and that there was a suitor for Mary,
a real one, but that they would talk of that later. Princess Mary was
still lookin silently at her brother and her beautiful eyes were full
of love and sadness. It was plain that she was followin a train of
thouht independent of her sister-in-law's words. In the midst of a
description of the last Petersbur fete she addressed her brother:

"So you are really oin to the war, Andrew?" she said sihin.

Lise sihed too.

"Yes, and even tomorrow," replied her brother.

"He is leavin me here, od knows why, when he miht have had
promotion..."

Princess Mary did not listen to the end, but continuin her train of
thouht turned to her sister-in-law with a tender lance at her fiure.

"Is it certain?" she said.

The face of the little princess chaned. She sihed and said: "Yes,
quite certain. Ah! it is very dreadful..."

Her lip descended. She brouht her face close to her sister-in-law's and
unexpectedly aain bean to cry.

"She needs rest," said Prince Andrew with a frown. "Don't you, Lise?
Take her to your room and I'll o to Father. How is he? Just the same?"

"Yes, just the same. Thouh I don't know what your opinion will be,"
answered the princess joyfully.

"And are the hours the same? And the walks in the avenues? And the
lathe?" asked Prince Andrew with a scarcely perceptible smile which
showed that, in spite of all his love and respect for his father, he was
aware of his weaknesses.

"The hours are the same, and the lathe, and also the mathematics and my
eometry lessons," said Princess Mary leefully, as if her lessons in
eometry were amon the reatest delihts of her life.

When the twenty minutes had elapsed and the time had come for the old
prince to et up, Tikhon came to call the youn prince to his father.
The old man made a departure from his usual routine in honor of his
son's arrival: he ave orders to admit him to his apartments while he
dressed for dinner. The old prince always dressed in old-fashioned
style, wearin an antique coat and powdered hair; and when Prince Andrew
entered his father's dressin room (not with the contemptuous look and
manner he wore in drawin rooms, but with the animated face with which
he talked to Pierre), the old man was sittin on a lare leather-covered
chair, wrapped in a powderin mantle, entrustin his head to Tikhon.

"Ah! here's the warrior! Wants to vanquish Buonaparte?" said the old
man, shakin his powdered head as much as the tail, which Tikhon was
holdin fast to plait, would allow.

"You at least must tackle him properly, or else if he oes on like this
he'll soon have us, too, for his subjects! How are you?" And he held out
his cheek.

The old man was in a ood temper after his nap before dinner. (He used
to say that a nap "after dinner was silver--before dinner, olden.") He
cast happy, sidelon lances at his son from under his thick, bushy
eyebrows. Prince Andrew went up and kissed his father on the spot
indicated to him. He made no reply on his father's favorite topic--
makin fun of the military men of the day, and more particularly of
Bonaparte.

"Yes, Father, I have come to you and brouht my wife who is prenant,"
said Prince Andrew, followin every movement of his father's face with
an eaer and respectful look. "How is your health?"

"Only fools and rakes fall ill, my boy. You know me: I am busy from
mornin till niht and abstemious, so of course I am well."

"Thank od," said his son smilin.

"od has nothin to do with it! Well, o on," he continued, returnin to
his hobby; "tell me how the ermans have tauht you to fiht Bonaparte
by this new science you call 'stratey.'"

Prince Andrew smiled.

"ive me time to collect my wits, Father," said he, with a smile that
showed that his father's foibles did not prevent his son from lovin and
honorin him. "Why, I have not yet had time to settle down!"

"Nonsense, nonsense!" cried the old man, shakin his pitail to see
whether it was firmly plaited, and raspin his by the hand. "The house
for your wife is ready. Princess Mary will take her there and show her
over, and they'll talk nineteen to the dozen. That's their woman's way!
I am lad to have her. Sit down and talk. About Mikhelson's army I
understand--Tolstoy's too... a simultaneous expedition.... But what's
the southern army to do? Prussia is neutral... I know that. What about
Austria?" said he, risin from his chair and pacin up and down the room
followed by Tikhon, who ran after him, handin him different articles of
clothin. "What of Sweden? How will they cross Pomerania?"

Prince Andrew, seein that his father insisted, bean--at first
reluctantly, but radually with more and more animation, and from habit
chanin unconsciously from Russian to French as he went on--to explain
the plan of operation for the comin campain. He explained how an army,
ninety thousand stron, was to threaten Prussia so as to brin her out
of her neutrality and draw her into the war; how part of that army was
to join some Swedish forces at Stralsund; how two hundred and twenty
thousand Austrians, with a hundred thousand Russians, were to operate in
Italy and on the Rhine; how fifty thousand Russians and as many Enlish
were to land at Naples, and how a total force of five hundred thousand
men was to attack the French from different sides. The old prince did
not evince the least interest durin this explanation, but as if he were
not listenin to it continued to dress while walkin about, and three
times unexpectedly interrupted. Once he stopped it by shoutin: "The
white one, the white one!"

This meant that Tikhon was not handin him the waistcoat he wanted.
Another time he interrupted, sayin:

"And will she soon be confined?" and shakin his head reproachfully
said: "That's bad! o on, o on."

The third interruption came when Prince Andrew was finishin his
description. The old man bean to sin, in the cracked voice of old ae:
"Malbrook s'en va-t-en uerre. Dieu sait quand reviendra." *


* "Marlborouh is oin to the wars; od knows when he'll return."

His son only smiled.

"I don't say it's a plan I approve of," said the son; "I am only tellin
you what it is. Napoleon has also formed his plan by now, not worse than
this one."

"Well, you've told me nothin new," and the old man repeated,
meditatively and rapidly:

"Dieu sait quand reviendra. o to the dinin room."




CHAPTER XXVII

At the appointed hour the prince, powdered and shaven, entered the
dinin room where his dauhter-in-law, Princess Mary, and Mademoiselle
Bourienne were already awaitin him toether with his architect, who by
a strane caprice of his employer's was admitted to table thouh the
position of that insinificant individual was such as could certainly
not have caused him to expect that honor. The prince, who enerally kept
very strictly to social distinctions and rarely admitted even important
overnment officials to his table, had unexpectedly selected Michael
Ivanovich (who always went into a corner to blow his nose on his checked
handkerchief) to illustrate the theory that all men are equals, and had
more than once impressed on his dauhter that Michael Ivanovich was "not
a whit worse than you or I." At dinner the prince usually spoke to the
taciturn Michael Ivanovich more often than to anyone else.

In the dinin room, which like all the rooms in the house was
exceedinly lofty, the members of the household and the footmen--one
behind each chair--stood waitin for the prince to enter. The head
butler, napkin on arm, was scannin the settin of the table, makin
sins to the footmen, and anxiously lancin from the clock to the door
by which the prince was to enter. Prince Andrew was lookin at a lare
ilt frame, new to him, containin the enealoical tree of the Princes
Bolkonski, opposite which hun another such frame with a badly painted
portrait (evidently by the hand of the artist belonin to the estate)
of a rulin prince, in a crown--an alleed descendant of Rurik and
ancestor of the Bolkonskis. Prince Andrew, lookin aain at that
enealoical tree, shook his head, lauhin as a man lauhs who looks at
a portrait so characteristic of the oriinal as to be amusin.

"How thorouhly like him that is!" he said to Princess Mary, who had
come up to him.

Princess Mary looked at her brother in surprise. She did not understand
what he was lauhin at. Everythin her father did inspired her with
reverence and was beyond question.

"Everyone has his Achilles' heel," continued Prince Andrew. "Fancy, with
his powerful mind, indulin in such nonsense!"

Princess Mary could not understand the boldness of her brother's
criticism and was about to reply, when the expected footsteps were heard
comin from the study. The prince walked in quickly and jauntily as was
his wont, as if intentionally contrastin the briskness of his manners
with the strict formality of his house. At that moment the reat clock
struck two and another with a shrill tone joined in from the drawin
room. The prince stood still; his lively litterin eyes from under
their thick, bushy eyebrows sternly scanned all present and rested on
the little princess. She felt, as courtiers do when the Tsar enters, the
sensation of fear and respect which the old man inspired in all around
him. He stroked her hair and then patted her awkwardly on the back of
her neck.

"I'm lad, lad, to see you," he said, lookin attentively into her
eyes, and then quickly went to his place and sat down. "Sit down, sit
down! Sit down, Michael Ianovich!"

He indicated a place beside him to his dauhter-in-law. A footman moved
the chair for her.

"Ho, ho!" said the old man, castin his eyes on her rounded fiure.
"You've been in a hurry. That's bad!"

He lauhed in his usual dry, cold, unpleasant way, with his lips only
and not with his eyes.

"You must walk, walk as much as possible, as much as possible," he said.

The little princess did not, or did not wish to, hear his words. She was
silent and seemed confused. The prince asked her about her father, and
she bean to smile and talk. He asked about mutual acquaintances, and
she became still more animated and chattered away ivin him reetins
from various people and retellin the town ossip.

"Countess Apraksina, poor thin, has lost her husband and she has cried
her eyes out," she said, rowin more and more lively.

As she became animated the prince looked at her more and more sternly,
and suddenly, as if he had studied her sufficiently and had formed a
definite idea of her, he turned away and addressed Michael Ivanovich.

"Well, Michael Ivanovich, our Bonaparte will be havin a bad time of it.
Prince Andrew" (he always spoke thus of his son) "has been tellin me
what forces are bein collected aainst him! While you and I never
thouht much of him."

Michael Ivanovich did not at all know when "you and I" had said such
thins about Bonaparte, but understandin that he was wanted as a pe on
which to han the prince's favorite topic, he looked inquirinly at the
youn prince, wonderin what would follow.

"He is a reat tactician!" said the prince to his son, pointin to the
architect.

And the conversation aain turned on the war, on Bonaparte, and the
enerals and statesmen of the day. The old prince seemed convinced not
only that all the men of the day were mere babies who did not know the A
B C of war or of politics, and that Bonaparte was an insinificant
little Frenchy, successful only because there were no loner any
Potemkins or Suvorovs left to oppose him; but he was also convinced that
there were no political difficulties in Europe and no real war, but only
a sort of puppet show at which the men of the day were playin,
pretendin to do somethin real. Prince Andrew aily bore with his
father's ridicule of the new men, and drew him on and listened to him
with evident pleasure.

"The past always seems ood," said he, "but did not Suvorov himself fall
into a trap Moreau set him, and from which he did not know how to
escape?"

"Who told you that? Who?" cried the prince. "Suvorov!" And he jerked
away his plate, which Tikhon briskly cauht. "Suvorov!... Consider,
Prince Andrew. Two... Frederick and Suvorov; Moreau!... Moreau would
have been a prisoner if Suvorov had had a free hand; but he had the
Hofs-kries-wurst-schnapps-Rath on his hands. It would have puzzled the
devil himself! When you et there you'll find out what those Hofs-
kries-wurst-Raths are! Suvorov couldn't manae them so what chance has
Michael Kutuzov? No, my dear boy," he continued, "you and your enerals
won't et on aainst Buonaparte; you'll have to call in the French, so
that birds of a feather may fiht toether. The erman, Pahlen, has been
sent to New York in America, to fetch the Frenchman, Moreau," he said,
alludin to the invitation made that year to Moreau to enter the Russian
service.... "Wonderful!... Were the Potemkins, Suvorovs, and Orlovs
ermans? No, lad, either you fellows have all lost your wits, or I have
outlived mine. May od help you, but we'll see what will happen.
Buonaparte has become a reat commander amon them! Hm!..."

"I don't at all say that all the plans are ood," said Prince Andrew, "I
am only surprised at your opinion of Bonaparte. You may lauh as much as
you like, but all the same Bonaparte is a reat eneral!"

"Michael Ivanovich!" cried the old prince to the architect who, busy
with his roast meat, hoped he had been forotten: "Didn't I tell you
Buonaparte was a reat tactician? Here, he says the same thin."

"To be sure, your excellency," replied the architect.

The prince aain lauhed his friid lauh.

"Buonaparte was born with a silver spoon in his mouth. He has ot
splendid soldiers. Besides he bean by attackin ermans. And only
idlers have failed to beat the ermans. Since the world bean everybody
has beaten the ermans. They beat no one--except one another. He made
his reputation fihtin them."

And the prince bean explainin all the blunders which, accordin to
him, Bonaparte had made in his campains and even in politics. His son
made no rejoinder, but it was evident that whatever aruments were
presented he was as little able as his father to chane his opinion. He
listened, refrainin from a reply, and involuntarily wondered how this
old man, livin alone in the country for so many years, could know and
discuss so minutely and acutely all the recent European military and
political events.

"You think I'm an old man and don't understand the present state of
affairs?" concluded his father. "But it troubles me. I don't sleep at
niht. Come now, where has this reat commander of yours shown his
skill?" he concluded.

"That would take too lon to tell," answered the son.

"Well, then o to your Buonaparte! Mademoiselle Bourienne, here's
another admirer of that powder-monkey emperor of yours," he exclaimed in
excellent French.

"You know, Prince, I am not a Bonapartist!"

"Dieu sait quand reviendra..." hummed the prince out of tune and, with a
lauh still more so, he quitted the table.

The little princess durin the whole discussion and the rest of the
dinner sat silent, lancin with a frihtened look now at her father-in-
law and now at Princess Mary. When they left the table she took her
sister-in-law's arm and drew her into another room.

"What a clever man your father is," said she; "perhaps that is why I am
afraid of him."

"Oh, he is so kind!" answered Princess Mary.




CHAPTER XXVIII

Prince Andrew was to leave next evenin. The old prince, not alterin
his routine, retired as usual after dinner. The little princess was in
her sister-in-law's room. Prince Andrew in a travelin coat without
epaulettes had been packin with his valet in the rooms assined to him.
After inspectin the carriae himself and seein the trunks put in, he
ordered the horses to be harnessed. Only those thins he always kept
with him remained in his room; a small box, a lare canteen fitted with
silver plate, two Turkish pistols and a saber--a present from his father
who had brouht it from the siee of Ochakov. All these travelin
effects of Prince Andrew's were in very ood order: new, clean, and in
cloth covers carefully tied with tapes.

When startin on a journey or chanin their mode of life, men capable
of reflection are enerally in a serious frame of mind. At such moments
one reviews the past and plans for the future. Prince Andrew's face
looked very thouhtful and tender. With his hands behind him he paced
briskly from corner to corner of the room, lookin straiht before him
and thouhtfully shakin his head. Did he fear oin to the war, or was
he sad at leavin his wife?--perhaps both, but evidently he did not wish
to be seen in that mood, for hearin footsteps in the passae he
hurriedly unclasped his hands, stopped at a table as if tyin the cover
of the small box, and assumed his usual tranquil and impenetrable
expression. It was the heavy tread of Princess Mary that he heard.

"I hear you have iven orders to harness," she cried, pantin (she had
apparently been runnin), "and I did so wish to have another talk with
you alone! od knows how lon we may aain be parted. You are not anry
with me for comin? You have chaned so, Andrusha," she added, as if to
explain such a question.

She smiled as she uttered his pet name, "Andrusha." It was obviously
strane to her to think that this stern handsome man should be Andrusha-
-the slender mischievous boy who had been her playfellow in childhood.

"And where is Lise?" he asked, answerin her question only by a smile.

"She was so tired that she has fallen asleep on the sofa in my room. Oh,
Andrew! What a treasure of a wife you have," said she, sittin down on
the sofa, facin her brother. "She is quite a child: such a dear, merry
child. I have rown so fond of her."

Prince Andrew was silent, but the princess noticed the ironical and
contemptuous look that showed itself on his face.

"One must be indulent to little weaknesses; who is free from them,
Andrew? Don't foret that she has rown up and been educated in society,
and so her position now is not a rosy one. We should enter into
everyone's situation. Tout comprendre, c'est tout pardonner. * Think
what it must be for her, poor thin, after what she has been used to, to
be parted from her husband and be left alone in the country, in her
condition! It's very hard."


* To understand all is to forive all.

Prince Andrew smiled as he looked at his sister, as we smile at those we
think we thorouhly understand.

"You live in the country and don't think the life terrible," he replied.

"I... that's different. Why speak of me? I don't want any other life,
and can't, for I know no other. But think, Andrew: for a youn society
woman to be buried in the country durin the best years of her life, all
alone--for Papa is always busy, and I... well, you know what poor
resources I have for entertainin a woman used to the best society.
There is only Mademoiselle Bourienne...."

"I don't like your Mademoiselle Bourienne at all," said Prince Andrew.

"No? She is very nice and kind and, above all, she's much to be pitied.
She has no one, no one. To tell the truth, I don't need her, and she's
even in my way. You know I always was a savae, and now am even more so.
I like bein alone.... Father likes her very much. She and Michael
Ivanovich are the two people to whom he is always entle and kind,
because he has been a benefactor to them both. As Sterne says: 'We don't
love people so much for the ood they have done us, as for the ood we
have done them.' Father took her when she was homeless after losin her
own father. She is very ood-natured, and my father likes her way of
readin. She reads to him in the evenins and reads splendidly."

"To be quite frank, Mary, I expect Father's character sometimes makes
thins tryin for you, doesn't it?" Prince Andrew asked suddenly.

Princess Mary was first surprised and then ahast at this question.

"For me? For me?... Tryin for me!..." said she.

"He always was rather harsh; and now I should think he's ettin very
tryin," said Prince Andrew, apparently speakin lihtly of their father
in order to puzzle or test his sister.

"You are ood in every way, Andrew, but you have a kind of intellectual
pride," said the princess, followin the train of her own thouhts
rather than the trend of the conversation--"and that's a reat sin. How
can one jude Father? But even if one miht, what feelin except
veneration could such a man as my father evoke? And I am so contented
and happy with him. I only wish you were all as happy as I am."

Her brother shook his head incredulously.

"The only thin that is hard for me... I will tell you the truth,
Andrew... is Father's way of treatin reliious subjects. I don't
understand how a man of his immense intellect can fail to see what is as
clear as day, and can o so far astray. That is the only thin that
makes me unhappy. But even in this I can see lately a shade of
improvement. His satire has been less bitter of late, and there was a
monk he received and had a lon talk with."

"Ah! my dear, I am afraid you and your monk are wastin your powder,"
said Prince Andrew banterinly yet tenderly.

"Ah! mon ami, I only pray, and hope that od will hear me. Andrew..."
she said timidly after a moment's silence, "I have a reat favor to ask
of you."

"What is it, dear?"

"No--promise that you will not refuse! It will ive you no trouble and
is nothin unworthy of you, but it will comfort me. Promise,
Andrusha!..." said she, puttin her hand in her reticule but not yet
takin out what she was holdin inside it, as if what she held were the
subject of her request and must not be shown before the request was
ranted.

She looked timidly at her brother.

"Even if it were a reat deal of trouble..." answered Prince Andrew, as
if uessin what it was about.

"Think what you please! I know you are just like Father. Think as you
please, but do this for my sake! Please do! Father's father, our
randfather, wore it in all his wars." (She still did not take out what
she was holdin in her reticule.) "So you promise?"

"Of course. What is it?"

"Andrew, I bless you with this icon and you must promise me you will
never take it off. Do you promise?"

"If it does not weih a hundredweiht and won't break my neck... To
please you..." said Prince Andrew. But immediately, noticin the pained
expression his joke had brouht to his sister's face, he repented and
added: "I am lad; really, dear, I am very lad."

"Aainst your will He will save and have mercy on you and brin you to
Himself, for in Him alone is truth and peace," said she in a voice
tremblin with emotion, solemnly holdin up in both hands before her
brother a small, oval, antique, dark-faced icon of the Saviour in a old
settin, on a finely wrouht silver chain.

She crossed herself, kissed the icon, and handed it to Andrew.

"Please, Andrew, for my sake!..."

Rays of entle liht shone from her lare, timid eyes. Those eyes lit up
the whole of her thin, sickly face and made it beautiful. Her brother
would have taken the icon, but she stopped him. Andrew understood,
crossed himself and kissed the icon. There was a look of tenderness, for
he was touched, but also a leam of irony on his face.

"Thank you, my dear." She kissed him on the forehead and sat down aain
on the sofa. They were silent for a while.

"As I was sayin to you, Andrew, be kind and enerous as you always used
to be. Don't jude Lise harshly," she bean. "She is so sweet, so ood-
natured, and her position now is a very hard one."

"I do not think I have complained of my wife to you, Masha, or blamed
her. Why do you say all this to me?"

Red patches appeared on Princess Mary's face and she was silent as if
she felt uilty.

"I have said nothin to you, but you have already been talked to. And I
am sorry for that," he went on.

The patches rew deeper on her forehead, neck, and cheeks. She tried to

"No, but imaine the old Countess Zubova, with false curls and her mouth

This very sentence about Countess Zubova and this same lauh Prince

"oin?" And he went on writin.

"I've come to say ood-by."

*Kutuzov.

He spoke so rapidly that he did not finish half his words, but his son

BOOK TWO: 1805




CHAPTER I

In October, 1805, a Russian army was occupyin the villaes and towns of
the Archduchy of Austria, and yet other reiments freshly arrivin from
Russia were settlin near the fortress of Braunau and burdenin the
inhabitants on whom they were quartered. Braunau was the headquarters of
the commander-in-chief, Kutuzov.

On October 11, 1805, one of the infantry reiments that had just reached
Braunau had halted half a mile from the town, waitin to be inspected by
the commander-in-chief. Despite the un-Russian appearance of the
locality and surroundins--fruit ardens, stone fences, tiled roofs, and
hills in the distance--and despite the fact that the inhabitants (who
azed with curiosity at the soldiers) were not Russians, the reiment
had just the appearance of any Russian reiment preparin for an
inspection anywhere in the heart of Russia.

On the evenin of the last day's march an order had been received that
the commander-in-chief would inspect the reiment on the march. Thouh
the words of the order were not clear to the reimental commander, and
the question arose whether the troops were to be in marchin order or
not, it was decided at a consultation between the battalion commanders
to present the reiment in parade order, on the principle that it is
always better to "bow too low than not bow low enouh." So the soldiers,
after a twenty-mile march, were kept mendin and cleanin all niht lon
without closin their eyes, while the adjutants and company commanders
calculated and reckoned, and by mornin the reiment--instead of the
stralin, disorderly crowd it had been on its last march the day
before--presented a well-ordered array of two thousand men each of whom
knew his place and his duty, had every button and every strap in place,
and shone with cleanliness. And not only externally was all in order,
but had it pleased the commander-in-chief to look under the uniforms he
would have found on every man a clean shirt, and in every knapsack the
appointed number of articles, "awl, soap, and all," as the soldiers say.
There was only one circumstance concernin which no one could be at
ease. It was the state of the soldiers' boots. More than half the men's
boots were in holes. But this defect was not due to any fault of the
reimental commander, for in spite of repeated demands boots had not
been issued by the Austrian commissariat, and the reiment had marched
some seven hundred miles.

The commander of the reiment was an elderly, choleric, stout, and
thick-set eneral with rizzled eyebrows and whiskers, and wider from
chest to back than across the shoulders. He had on a brand-new uniform
showin the creases where it had been folded and thick old epaulettes
which seemed to stand rather than lie down on his massive shoulders. He
had the air of a man happily performin one of the most solemn duties of
his life. He walked about in front of the line and at every step pulled
himself up, slihtly archin his back. It was plain that the commander
admired his reiment, rejoiced in it, and that his whole mind was
enrossed by it, yet his strut seemed to indicate that, besides military
matters, social interests and the fair sex occupied no small part of his
thouhts.

"Well, Michael Mitrich, sir?" he said, addressin one of the battalion
commanders who smilinly pressed forward (it was plain that they both
felt happy). "We had our hands full last niht. However, I think the
reiment is not a bad one, eh?"

The battalion commander perceived the jovial irony and lauhed.

"It would not be turned off the field even on the Tsaritsin Meadow."

"What?" asked the commander.

At that moment, on the road from the town on which sinalers had been
posted, two men appeared on horse back. They were an aide-de-camp
followed by a Cossack.

The aide-de-camp was sent to confirm the order which had not been
clearly worded the day before, namely, that the commander-in-chief
wished to see the reiment just in the state in which it had been on the
march: in their reatcoats, and packs, and without any preparation
whatever.

A member of the Hofkriesrath from Vienna had come to Kutuzov the day
before with proposals and demands for him to join up with the army of
the Archduke Ferdinand and Mack, and Kutuzov, not considerin this
junction advisable, meant, amon other aruments in support of his view,
to show the Austrian eneral the wretched state in which the troops
arrived from Russia. With this object he intended to meet the reiment;
so the worse the condition it was in, the better pleased the commander-
in-chief would be. Thouh the aide-de-camp did not know these
circumstances, he nevertheless delivered the definite order that the men
should be in their reatcoats and in marchin order, and that the
commander-in-chief would otherwise be dissatisfied. On hearin this the
reimental commander hun his head, silently shrued his shoulders, and
spread out his arms with a choleric esture.

"A fine mess we've made of it!" he remarked.

"There now! Didn't I tell you, Michael Mitrich, that if it was said 'on
the march' it meant in reatcoats?" said he reproachfully to the
battalion commander. "Oh, my od!" he added, steppin resolutely
forward. "Company commanders!" he shouted in a voice accustomed to
command. "Sereants major!... How soon will he be here?" he asked the
aide-de-camp with a respectful politeness evidently relatin to the
personae he was referrin to.

"In an hour's time, I should say."

"Shall we have time to chane clothes?"

"I don't know, eneral...."

The reimental commander, oin up to the line himself, ordered the
soldiers to chane into their reatcoats. The company commanders ran off
to their companies, the sereants major bean bustlin (the reatcoats
were not in very ood condition), and instantly the squares that had up

hum with voices. On all sides soldiers were runnin to and fro, throwin
up their knapsacks with a jerk of their shoulders and pullin the straps
over their heads, unstrappin their overcoats and drawin the sleeves on
with upraised arms.

In half an hour all was aain in order, only the squares had become ray
instead of black. The reimental commander walked with his jerky steps
to the front of the reiment and examined it from a distance.

"Whatever is this? This!" he shouted and stood still. "Commander of the
third company!"

"Commander of the third company wanted by the eneral!... commander to
the eneral... third company to the commander." The words passed alon

When the eaer but misrepeated words had reached their destination in a

"You will soon be dressin your men in petticoats! What is this?"

The commander of the company, with his eyes fixed on his superior,
pressed two finers more and more riidly to his cap, as if in this
pressure lay his only hope of salvation.

"Well, why don't you speak? Whom have you ot there dressed up as a
Hunarian?" said the commander with an austere ibe.

"Your excellency..."

"Well, your excellency, what? Your excellency! But what about your
excellency?... nobody knows."

"Your excellency, it's the officer Dolokhov, who has been reduced to the
ranks," said the captain softly.

"Well? Has he been deraded into a field marshal, or into a soldier? If
a soldier, he should be dressed in reulation uniform like the others."

"Your excellency, you ave him leave yourself, on the march."

"ave him leave? Leave? That's just like you youn men," said the
reimental commander coolin down a little. "Leave indeed.... One says a
word to you and you... What?" he added with renewed irritation, "I be
you to dress your men decently."

And the commander, turnin to look at the adjutant, directed his jerky
steps down the line. He was evidently pleased at his own display of
aner and walkin up to the reiment wished to find a further excuse for
wrath. Havin snapped at an officer for an unpolished bade, at another
because his line was not straiht, he reached the third company.

"H-o-o-w are you standin? Where's your le? Your le?" shouted the
commander with a tone of sufferin in his voice, while there were still
five men between him and Dolokhov with his bluish-ray uniform.

Dolokhov slowly straihtened his bent knee, lookin straiht with his
clear, insolent eyes in the eneral's face.

"Why a blue coat? Off with it... Sereant major! Chane his coat... the
ras..." he did not finish.

"eneral, I must obey orders, but I am not bound to endure..." Dolokhov
hurriedly interrupted.

"No talkin in the ranks!... No talkin, no talkin!"

"Not bound to endure insults," Dolokhov concluded in loud, rinin
tones.

The eyes of the eneral and the soldier met. The eneral became silent,
anrily pullin down his tiht scarf.

"I request you to have the oodness to chane your coat," he said as he
turned away.




CHAPTER II

"He's comin!" shouted the sinaler at that moment.

The reimental commander, flushin, ran to his horse, seized the stirrup
with tremblin hands, threw his body across the saddle, rihted himself,
drew his saber, and with a happy and resolute countenance, openin his
mouth awry, prepared to shout. The reiment fluttered like a bird
preenin its plumae and became motionless.

"Att-ention!" shouted the reimental commander in a soul-shakin voice
which expressed joy for himself, severity for the reiment, and welcome
for the approachin chief.

Alon the broad country road, eded on both sides by trees, came a hih,
liht blue Viennese caleche, slihtly creakin on its sprins and drawn
by six horses at a smart trot. Behind the caleche alloped the suite and
a convoy of Croats. Beside Kutuzov sat an Austrian eneral, in a white

stepped down from the carriae just as if those two thousand men

The word of command ran out, and aain the reiment quivered, as with a
jinlin sound it presented arms. Then amidst a dead silence the feeble

to your ex... len... len... lency!" and aain all became silent. At

eneral in white, accompanied by the suite, walked between the ranks.

From the way the reimental commander saluted the commander-in-chief and
devoured him with his eyes, drawin himself up obsequiously, and from

was evident that he performed his duty as a subordinate with even
reater zeal than his duty as a commander. Thanks to the strictness and
assiduity of its commander the reiment, in comparison with others that
had reached Braunau at the same time, was in splendid condition. There
were only 217 sick and stralers. Everythin was in ood order except
the boots.

Kutuzov walked throuh the ranks, sometimes stoppin to say a few
friendly words to officers he had known in the Turkish war, sometimes

This hussar, with a rave face and without a smile or a chane in the

wa.

Kutuzov walked slowly and lanuidly past thousands of eyes which were
startin from their sockets to watch their chief. On reachin the third
company he suddenly stopped. His suite, not havin expected this,
involuntarily came closer to him.

"Ah, Timokhin!" said he, reconizin the red-nosed captain who had been
reprimanded on account of the blue reatcoat.

One would have thouht it impossible for a man to stretch himself more
than Timokhin had done when he was reprimanded by the reimental
commander, but now that the commander-in-chief addressed him he drew
himself up to such an extent that it seemed he could not have sustained

who evidently understood his case and wished him nothin but ood,

scarred and puffy face.

"Another Ismail comrade," said he. "A brave officer! Are you satisfied
with him?" he asked the reimental commander.

And the latter--unconscious that he was bein reflected in the hussar
officer as in a lookin lass--started, moved forward, and answered:
"Hihly satisfied, your excellency!"

"We all have our weaknesses," said Kutuzov smilin and walkin away from
him. "He used to have a predilection for Bacchus."

The reimental commander was afraid he miht be blamed for this and did
not answer. The hussar at that moment noticed the face of the red-nosed

The third company was the last, and Kutuzov pondered, apparently tryin
to recollect somethin. Prince Andrew stepped forward from amon the

"You told me to remind you of the officer Dolokhov, reduced to the ranks
in this reiment."

"Where is Dolokhov?" asked Kutuzov.

Dolokhov, who had already chaned into a soldier's ray reatcoat, did

commander in chief, and presented arms.

"Have you a complaint to make?" Kutuzov asked with a sliht frown.

"This is Dolokhov," said Prince Andrew.

"Ah!" said Kutuzov. "I hope this will be a lesson to you. Do your duty.
The Emperor is racious, and I shan't foret you if you deserve well."

The clear blue eyes looked at the commander-in-chief just as boldly as
they had looked at the reimental commander, seemin by their expression

so widely from a private.

"One thin I ask of your excellency," Dolokhov said in his firm,
rinin, deliberate voice. "I ask an opportunity to atone for my fault
and prove my devotion to His Majesty the Emperor and to Russia!"

Kutuzov turned away. The same smile of the eyes with which he had turned
from Captain Timokhin aain flitted over his face. He turned away with a
rimace as if to say that everythin Dolokhov had said to him and

it and it was not at all what he wanted. He turned away and went to the
carriae.

The reiment broke up into companies, which went to their appointed
quarters near Braunau, where they hoped to receive boots and clothes and
to rest after their hard marches.

"You won't bear me a rude, Prokhor Inatych?" said the reimental
commander, overtakin the third company on its way to its quarters and

helped... one is sometimes a bit hasty on parade... I am the first to
apoloize, you know me!... He was very pleased!" And he held out his
hand to the captain.

"Don't mention it, eneral, as if I'd be so bold!" replied the captain,
his nose rowin redder as he ave a smile which showed where two front

"And tell Mr. Dolokhov that I won't foret him--he may be quite easy.
And tell me, please--I've been meanin to ask--how is he behavin
himself, and in eneral..."

"As far as the service oes he is quite punctilious, your excellency;
but his character..." said Timokhin.

"And what about his character?" asked the reimental commander.

"It's different on different days," answered the captain. "One day he is
sensible, well educated, and ood-natured, and the next he's a wild

"Oh, well, well!" remarked the reimental commander. "Still, one must
have pity on a youn man in misfortune. You know he has important

"I will, your excellency," said Timokhin, showin by his smile that he
understood his commander's wish.

"Well, of course, of course!"

The reimental commander souht out Dolokhov in the ranks and, reinin

"After the next affair... epaulettes."

Dolokhov looked round but did not say anythin, nor did the mockin
smile on his lips chane.

"Well, that's all riht," continued the reimental commander. "A cup of
vodka for the men from me," he added so that the soldiers could hear. "I
