overtook the next one.

"Well, he's really a ood fellow, one can serve under him," said
Timokhin to the subaltern beside him.

"In a word, a hearty one..." said the subaltern, lauhin (the
reimental commander was nicknamed Kin of Hearts).

The cheerful mood of their officers after the inspection infected the
soldiers. The company marched on aily. The soldiers' voices could be
heard on every side.

"And they said Kutuzov was blind of one eye?"

"And so he is! Quite blind!"

"No, friend, he is sharper-eyed than you are. Boots and le bands... he
noticed everythin..."

"When he looked at my feet, friend... well, thinks I..."

"And that other one with him, the Austrian, looked as if he were smeared
with chalk--as white as flour! I suppose they polish him up as they do
the uns."

"I say, Fedeshon!... Did he say when the battles are to bein? You were
near him. Everybody said that Buonaparte himself was at Braunau."

"Buonaparte himself!... Just listen to the fool, what he doesn't know!
The Prussians are up in arms now. The Austrians, you see, are puttin
them down. When they've been put down, the war with Buonaparte will
bein. And he says Buonaparte is in Braunau! Shows you're a fool. You'd
better listen more carefully!"

"What devils these quartermasters are! See, the fifth company is turnin
into the villae already... they will have their buckwheat cooked before
we reach our quarters."

"ive me a biscuit, you devil!"

"And did you ive me tobacco yesterday? That's just it, friend! Ah,
well, never mind, here you are."

"They miht call a halt here or we'll have to do another four miles
without eatin."

"Wasn't it fine when those ermans ave us lifts! You just sit still and
are drawn alon."

"And here, friend, the people are quite bearly. There they all seemed
to be Poles--all under the Russian crown--but here they're all reular
ermans."

"Siners to the front" came the captain's order.

And from the different ranks some twenty men ran to the front. A
drummer, their leader, turned round facin the siners, and flourishin
his arm, bean a lon-drawn-out soldiers' son, commencin with the
words: "Mornin dawned, the sun was risin," and concludin: "On then,
brothers, on to lory, led by Father Kamenski." This son had been
composed in the Turkish campain and now bein sun in Austria, the only
chane bein that the words "Father Kamenski" were replaced by "Father
Kutuzov."

Havin jerked out these last words as soldiers do and waved his arms as
if flinin somethin to the round, the drummer--a lean, handsome
soldier of forty--looked sternly at the siners and screwed up his eyes.
Then havin satisfied himself that all eyes were fixed on him, he raised
both arms as if carefully liftin some invisible but precious object
above his head and, holdin it there for some seconds, suddenly flun it
down and bean:

"Oh, my bower, oh, my bower...!"

"Oh, my bower new...!" chimed in twenty voices, and the castanet player,
in spite of the burden of his equipment, rushed out to the front and,
walkin backwards before the company, jerked his shoulders and
flourished his castanets as if threatenin someone. The soldiers,
swinin their arms and keepin time spontaneously, marched with lon
steps. Behind the company the sound of wheels, the creakin of sprins,
and the tramp of horses' hoofs were heard. Kutuzov and his suite were
returnin to the town. The commander-in-chief made a sin that the men
should continue to march at ease, and he and all his suite showed
pleasure at the sound of the sinin and the siht of the dancin
soldier and the ay and smartly marchin men. In the second file from
the riht flank, beside which the carriae passed the company, a blue-
eyed soldier involuntarily attracted notice. It was Dolokhov marchin
with particular race and boldness in time to the son and lookin at
those drivin past as if he pitied all who were not at that moment
marchin with the company. The hussar cornet of Kutuzov's suite who had
mimicked the reimental commander, fell back from the carriae and rode
up to Dolokhov.

Hussar cornet Zherkov had at one time, in Petersbur, beloned to the
wild set led by Dolokhov. Zherkov had met Dolokhov abroad as a private
and had not seen fit to reconize him. But now that Kutuzov had spoken
to the entleman ranker, he addressed him with the cordiality of an old
friend.

"My dear fellow, how are you?" said he throuh the sinin, makin his
horse keep pace with the company.

"How am I?" Dolokhov answered coldly. "I am as you see."

The lively son ave a special flavor to the tone of free and easy
aiety with which Zherkov spoke, and to the intentional coldness of
Dolokhov's reply.

"And how do you et on with the officers?" inquired Zherkov.

"All riht. They are ood fellows. And how have you wriled onto the
staff?"

"I was attached; I'm on duty."

Both were silent.

"She let the hawk fly upward from her wide riht sleeve," went the son,
arousin an involuntary sensation of courae and cheerfulness. Their
conversation would probably have been different but for the effect of
that son.

"Is it true that Austrians have been beaten?" asked Dolokhov.

"The devil only knows! They say so."

"I'm lad," answered Dolokhov briefly and clearly, as the son demanded.

"I say, come round some evenin and we'll have a ame of faro!" said
Zherkov.

"Why, have you too much money?"

"Do come."

"I can't. I've sworn not to. I won't drink and won't play till I et
reinstated."

"Well, that's only till the first enaement."

"We shall see."

They were aain silent.

"Come if you need anythin. One can at least be of use on the staff..."

Dolokhov smiled. "Don't trouble. If I want anythin, I won't be--I'll
take it!"

"Well, never mind; I only..."

"And I only..."

"ood-bye."

"ood health..."


"It's a lon, lon way. To my native land..."

Zherkov touched his horse with the spurs; it pranced excitedly from foot
to foot uncertain with which to start, then settled down, alloped past
the company, and overtook the carriae, still keepin time to the son.




CHAPTER III

On returnin from the review, Kutuzov took the Austrian eneral into his
private room and, callin his adjutant, asked for some papers relatin
to the condition of the troops on their arrival, and the letters that
had come from the Archduke Ferdinand, who was in command of the advanced
army. Prince Andrew Bolkonski came into the room with the required
papers. Kutuzov and the Austrian member of the Hofkriesrath were
sittin at the table on which a plan was spread out.

"Ah!..." said Kutuzov lancin at Bolkonski as if by this exclamation he
was askin the adjutant to wait, and he went on with the conversation in
French.

"All I can say, eneral," said he with a pleasant eleance of expression
and intonation that oblied one to listen to each deliberately spoken
word. It was evident that Kutuzov himself listened with pleasure to his
own voice. "All I can say, eneral, is that if the matter depended on my
personal wishes, the will of His Majesty the Emperor Francis would have
been fulfilled lon ao. I should lon ao have joined the archduke. And
believe me on my honour that to me personally it would be a pleasure to
hand over the supreme command of the army into the hands of a better
informed and more skillful eneral--of whom Austria has so many--and to
lay down all this heavy responsibility. But circumstances are sometimes
too stron for us, eneral."

And Kutuzov smiled in a way that seemed to say, "You are quite at
liberty not to believe me and I don't even care whether you do or not,
but you have no rounds for tellin me so. And that is the whole point."

The Austrian eneral looked dissatisfied, but had no option but to reply
in the same tone.

"On the contrary," he said, in a querulous and anry tone that
contrasted with his flatterin words, "on the contrary, your
excellency's participation in the common action is hihly valued by His
Majesty; but we think the present delay is deprivin the splendid
Russian troops and their commander of the laurels they have been
accustomed to win in their battles," he concluded his evidently
prearraned sentence.

Kutuzov bowed with the same smile.

"But that is my conviction, and judin by the last letter with which
His Hihness the Archduke Ferdinand has honored me, I imaine that the
Austrian troops, under the direction of so skillful a leader as eneral
Mack, have by now already ained a decisive victory and no loner need
our aid," said Kutuzov.

The eneral frowned. Thouh there was no definite news of an Austrian
defeat, there were many circumstances confirmin the unfavorable rumors
that were afloat, and so Kutuzov's suestion of an Austrian victory
sounded much like irony. But Kutuzov went on blandly smilin with the
same expression, which seemed to say that he had a riht to suppose so.
And, in fact, the last letter he had received from Mack's army informed
him of a victory and stated strateically the position of the army was
very favorable.

"ive me that letter," said Kutuzov turnin to Prince Andrew. "Please
have a look at it"--and Kutuzov with an ironical smile about the corners
of his mouth read to the Austrian eneral the followin passae, in
erman, from the Archduke Ferdinand's letter:

We have fully concentrated forces of nearly seventy thousand men with
which to attack and defeat the enemy should he cross the Lech. Also, as
we are masters of Ulm, we cannot be deprived of the advantae of
commandin both sides of the Danube, so that should the enemy not cross
the Lech, we can cross the Danube, throw ourselves on his line of
communications, recross the river lower down, and frustrate his
intention should he try to direct his whole force aainst our faithful
ally. We shall therefore confidently await the moment when the Imperial
Russian army will be fully equipped, and shall then, in conjunction with
it, easily find a way to prepare for the enemy the fate he deserves.

Kutuzov sihed deeply on finishin this pararaph and looked at the
member of the Hofkriesrath mildly and attentively.

"But you know the wise maxim your excellency, advisin one to expect the
worst," said the Austrian eneral, evidently wishin to have done with
jests and to come to business. He involuntarily looked round at the
aide-de-camp.

"Excuse me, eneral," interrupted Kutuzov, also turnin to Prince
Andrew. "Look here, my dear fellow, et from Kozlovski all the reports
from our scouts. Here are two letters from Count Nostitz and here is one
from His Hihness the Archduke Ferdinand and here are these," he said,
handin him several papers, "make a neat memorandum in French out of all
this, showin all the news we have had of the movements of the Austrian
army, and then ive it to his excellency."

Prince Andrew bowed his head in token of havin understood from the
first not only what had been said but also what Kutuzov would have liked
to tell him. He athered up the papers and with a bow to both, stepped
softly over the carpet and went out into the waitin room.

Thouh not much time had passed since Prince Andrew had left Russia, he
had chaned reatly durin that period. In the expression of his face,
in his movements, in his walk, scarcely a trace was left of his former
affected lanuor and indolence. He now looked like a man who has time to
think of the impression he makes on others, but is occupied with
areeable and interestin work. His face expressed more satisfaction
with himself and those around him, his smile and lance were brihter
and more attractive.

Kutuzov, whom he had overtaken in Poland, had received him very kindly,
promised not to foret him, distinuished him above the other adjutants,
and had taken him to Vienna and iven him the more serious commissions.
From Vienna Kutuzov wrote to his old comrade, Prince Andrew's father.

Your son bids fair to become an officer distinuished by his industry,
firmness, and expedition. I consider myself fortunate to have such a
subordinate by me.

On Kutuzov's staff, amon his fellow officers and in the army enerally,
Prince Andrew had, as he had had in Petersbur society, two quite
opposite reputations. Some, a minority, acknowleded him to be different
from themselves and from everyone else, expected reat thins of him,
listened to him, admired, and imitated him, and with them Prince Andrew
was natural and pleasant. Others, the majority, disliked him and
considered him conceited, cold, and disareeable. But amon these people
Prince Andrew knew how to take his stand so that they respected and even
feared him.

Comin out of Kutuzov's room into the waitin room with the papers in
his hand Prince Andrew came up to his comrade, the aide-de-camp on duty,
Kozlovski, who was sittin at the window with a book.

"Well, Prince?" asked Kozlovski.

"I am ordered to write a memorandum explainin why we are not
advancin."

"And why is it?"

Prince Andrew shrued his shoulders.

"Any news from Mack?"

"No."

"If it were true that he has been beaten, news would have come."

"Probably," said Prince Andrew movin toward the outer door.

But at that instant a tall Austrian eneral in a reatcoat, with the
order of Maria Theresa on his neck and a black bandae round his head,
who had evidently just arrived, entered quickly, slammin the door.
Prince Andrew stopped short.

"Commander in Chief Kutuzov?" said the newly arrived eneral speakin
quickly with a harsh erman accent, lookin to both sides and advancin
straiht toward the inner door.

"The commander-in-chief is enaed," said Kozlovski, oin hurriedly up
to the unknown eneral and blockin his way to the door. "Whom shall I
announce?"

The unknown eneral looked disdainfully down at Kozlovski, who was
rather short, as if surprised that anyone should not know him.

"The commander-in-chief is enaed," repeated Kozlovski calmly.

The eneral's face clouded, his lips quivered and trembled. He took out
a notebook, hurriedly scribbled somethin in pencil, tore out the leaf,
ave it to Kozlovski, stepped quickly to the window, and threw himself
into a chair, azin at those in the room as if askin, "Why do they
look at me?" Then he lifted his head, stretched his neck as if he
intended to say somethin, but immediately, with affected indifference,
bean to hum to himself, producin a queer sound which immediately broke
off. The door of the private room opened and Kutuzov appeared in the
doorway. The eneral with the bandaed head bent forward as thouh
runnin away from some daner, and, makin lon, quick strides with his
thin les, went up to Kutuzov.

"Vous voyez le malheureux Mack," he uttered in a broken voice.

Kutuzov's face as he stood in the open doorway remained perfectly
immobile for a few moments. Then wrinkles ran over his face like a wave
and his forehead became smooth aain, he bowed his head respectfully,
closed his eyes, silently let Mack enter his room before him, and closed
the door himself behind him.

The report which had been circulated that the Austrians had been beaten
and that the whole army had surrendered at Ulm proved to be correct.
Within half an hour adjutants had been sent in various directions with
orders which showed that the Russian troops, who had hitherto been
inactive, would also soon have to meet the enemy.

Prince Andrew was one of those rare staff officers whose chief interest
lay in the eneral proress of the war. When he saw Mack and heard the
details of his disaster he understood that half the campain was lost,
understood all the difficulties of the Russian army's position, and
vividly imained what awaited it and the part he would have to play.
Involuntarily he felt a joyful aitation at the thouht of the
humiliation of arroant Austria and that in a week's time he miht,
perhaps, see and take part in the first Russian encounter with the
French since Suvorov met them. He feared that Bonaparte's enius miht
outweih all the courae of the Russian troops, and at the same time
could not admit the idea of his hero bein disraced.

Excited and irritated by these thouhts Prince Andrew went toward his
room to write to his father, to whom he wrote every day. In the corridor
he met Nesvitski, with whom he shared a room, and the wa Zherkov; they
were as usual lauhin.

"Why are you so lum?" asked Nesvitski noticin Prince Andrew's pale
face and litterin eyes.

"There's nothin to be ay about," answered Bolkonski.

Just as Prince Andrew met Nesvitski and Zherkov, there came toward them
from the other end of the corridor, Strauch, an Austrian eneral who on
Kutuzov's staff in chare of the provisionin of the Russian army, and
the member of the Hofkriesrath who had arrived the previous evenin.
There was room enouh in the wide corridor for the enerals to pass the
three officers quite easily, but Zherkov, pushin Nesvitski aside with
his arm, said in a breathless voice,

"They're comin!... they're comin!... Stand aside, make way, please
make way!"

The enerals were passin by, lookin as if they wished to avoid
embarrassin attentions. On the face of the wa Zherkov there suddenly
appeared a stupid smile of lee which he seemed unable to suppress.

"Your excellency," said he in erman, steppin forward and addressin
the Austrian eneral, "I have the honor to conratulate you."

He bowed his head and scraped first with one foot and then with the
other, awkwardly, like a child at a dancin lesson.

The member of the Hofkriesrath looked at him severely but, seein the
seriousness of his stupid smile, could not but ive him a moment's
attention. He screwed up his eyes showin that he was listenin.

"I have the honor to conratulate you. eneral Mack has arrived, quite
well, only a little bruised just here," he added, pointin with a
beamin smile to his head.

The eneral frowned, turned away, and went on.

"ott, wie naiv!" * said he anrily, after he had one a few steps.


* "ood od, what simplicity!"

Nesvitski with a lauh threw his arms round Prince Andrew, but
Bolkonski, turnin still paler, pushed him away with an anry look and
turned to Zherkov. The nervous irritation aroused by the appearance of
Mack, the news of his defeat, and the thouht of what lay before the
Russian army found vent in aner at Zherkov's untimely jest.

"If you, sir, choose to make a buffoon of yourself," he said sharply,
with a sliht tremblin of the lower jaw, "I can't prevent your doin
so; but I warn you that if you dare to play the fool in my presence, I
will teach you to behave yourself."

Nesvitski and Zherkov were so surprised by this outburst that they azed
at Bolkonski silently with wide-open eyes.

"What's the matter? I only conratulated them," said Zherkov.

"I am not jestin with you; please be silent!" cried Bolkonski, and
takin Nesvitski's arm he left Zherkov, who did not know what to say.

"Come, what's the matter, old fellow?" said Nesvitski tryin to soothe
him.

"What's the matter?" exclaimed Prince Andrew standin still in his
excitement. "Don't you understand that either we are officers servin
our Tsar and our country, rejoicin in the successes and rievin at the
misfortunes of our common cause, or we are merely lackeys who care
nothin for their master's business. Quarante mille hommes massacres et
l'armee de nos allies detruite, et vous trouvez la le mot pour rire," *
he said, as if strenthenin his views by this French sentence. "C'est
bien pour un arcon de rien comme cet individu dont vous avez fait un
ami, mais pas pour vous, pas pour vous. *(2) Only a hobbledehoy could
amuse himself in this way," he added in Russian--but pronouncin the
word with a French accent--havin noticed that Zherkov could still hear
him.


* "Forty thousand men massacred and the army of our allies destroyed,
and you find that a cause for jestin!"

* (2) "It is all very well for that ood-for-nothin fellow of whom you
have made a friend, but not for you, not for you."

He waited a moment to see whether the cornet would answer, but he turned
and went out of the corridor.




CHAPTER IV

The Pavlorad Hussars were stationed two miles from Braunau. The
squadron in which Nicholas Rostov served as a cadet was quartered in the
erman villae of Salzeneck. The best quarters in the villae were
assined to cavalry-captain Denisov, the squadron commander, known
throuhout the whole cavalry division as Vaska Denisov. Cadet Rostov,
ever since he had overtaken the reiment in Poland, had lived with the
squadron commander.

On October 11, the day when all was astir at headquarters over the news
of Mack's defeat, the camp life of the officers of this squadron was
proceedin as usual. Denisov, who had been losin at cards all niht,
had not yet come home when Rostov rode back early in the mornin from a
forain expedition. Rostov in his cadet uniform, with a jerk to his
horse, rode up to the porch, swun his le over the saddle with a supple
youthful movement, stood for a moment in the stirrup as if loathe to
part from his horse, and at last spran down and called to his orderly.

"Ah, Bondarenko, dear friend!" said he to the hussar who rushed up
headlon to the horse. "Walk him up and down, my dear fellow," he
continued, with that ay brotherly cordiality which oodhearted youn
people show to everyone when they are happy.

"Yes, your excellency," answered the Ukrainian aily, tossin his head.

"Mind, walk him up and down well!"

Another hussar also rushed toward the horse, but Bondarenko had already
thrown the reins of the snaffle bridle over the horse's head. It was
evident that the cadet was liberal with his tips and that it paid to
serve him. Rostov patted the horse's neck and then his flank, and
linered for a moment.

"Splendid! What a horse he will be!" he thouht with a smile, and
holdin up his saber, his spurs jinlin, he ran up the steps of the
porch. His landlord, who in a waistcoat and a pointed cap, pitchfork in
hand, was clearin manure from the cowhouse, looked out, and his face
immediately brihtened on seein Rostov. "Schon ut Moren! Schon ut
Moren!" * he said winkin with a merry smile, evidently pleased to
reet the youn man.


* "A very ood mornin! A very ood mornin!"

"Schon fleissi?" * said Rostov with the same ay brotherly smile which
did not leave his eaer face. "Hoch Oestreicher! Hoch Russen! Kaiser
Alexander hoch!" *(2) said he, quotin words often repeated by the
erman landlord.


* "Busy already?"

* (2) "Hurrah for the Austrians! Hurrah for the Russians! Hurrah for
Emperor Alexander!"

The erman lauhed, came out of the cowshed, pulled off his cap, and
wavin it above his head cried:

"Und die anze Welt hoch!" *


* "And hurrah for the whole world!"

Rostov waved his cap above his head like the erman and cried lauhin,
"Und vivat die anze Welt!" Thouh neither the erman cleanin his
cowshed nor Rostov back with his platoon from forain for hay had any
reason for rejoicin, they looked at each other with joyful deliht and
brotherly love, waed their heads in token of their mutual affection,
and parted smilin, the erman returnin to his cowshed and Rostov oin
to the cottae he occupied with Denisov.

"What about your master?" he asked Lavrushka, Denisov's orderly, whom
all the reiment knew for a roue.

"Hasn't been in since the evenin. Must have been losin," answered
Lavrushka. "I know by now, if he wins he comes back early to bra about
it, but if he stays out till mornin it means he's lost and will come
back in a rae. Will you have coffee?"

"Yes, brin some."

Ten minutes later Lavrushka brouht the coffee. "He's comin!" said he.
"Now for trouble!" Rostov looked out of the window and saw Denisov
comin home. Denisov was a small man with a red face, sparklin black
eyes, and black tousled mustache and hair. He wore an unfastened cloak,
wide breeches hanin down in creases, and a crumpled shako on the back
of his head. He came up to the porch loomily, hanin his head.

"Lavwuska!" he shouted loudly and anrily, "take it off, blockhead!"

"Well, I am takin it off," replied Lavrushka's voice.

"Ah, you're up already," said Denisov, enterin the room.

"Lon ao," answered Rostov, "I have already been for the hay, and have
seen Fraulein Mathilde."

"Weally! And I've been losin, bwother. I lost yesterday like a damned
fool!" cried Denisov, not pronouncin his r's. "Such ill luck! Such ill
luck. As soon as you left, it bean and went on. Hullo there! Tea!"

Puckerin up his face thouh smilin, and showin his short stron
teeth, he bean with stubby finers of both hands to ruffle up his thick
tanled black hair.

"And what devil made me o to that wat?" (an officer nicknamed "the
rat") he said, rubbin his forehead and whole face with both hands.
"Just fancy, he didn't let me win a sinle cahd, not one cahd."

He took the lihted pipe that was offered to him, ripped it in his
fist, and tapped it on the floor, makin the sparks fly, while he
continued to shout.

"He lets one win the sinles and collahs it as soon as one doubles it;
ives the sinles and snatches the doubles!"

He scattered the burnin tobacco, smashed the pipe, and threw it away.
Then he remained silent for a while, and all at once looked cheerfully
with his litterin, black eyes at Rostov.

"If at least we had some women here; but there's nothin foh one to do
but dwink. If we could only et to fihtin soon. Hullo, who's there?"
he said, turnin to the door as he heard a tread of heavy boots and the
clinkin of spurs that came to a stop, and a respectful couh.

"The squadron quartermaster!" said Lavrushka.

Denisov's face puckered still more.

"Wetched!" he muttered, throwin down a purse with some old in it.
"Wostov, deah fellow, just see how much there is left and shove the
purse undah the pillow," he said, and went out to the quartermaster.

Rostov took the money and, mechanically arranin the old and new coins
in separate piles, bean countin them.

"Ah! Telyanin! How d'ye do? They plucked me last niht," came Denisov's
voice from the next room.

"Where? At Bykov's, at the rat's... I knew it," replied a pipin voice,
and Lieutenant Telyanin, a small officer of the same squadron, entered
the room.

Rostov thrust the purse under the pillow and shook the damp little hand
which was offered him. Telyanin for some reason had been transferred
from the uards just before this campain. He behaved very well in the
reiment but was not liked; Rostov especially detested him and was
unable to overcome or conceal his roundless antipathy to the man.

"Well, youn cavalryman, how is my Rook behavin?" he asked. (Rook was a
youn horse Telyanin had sold to Rostov.)

The lieutenant never looked the man he was speakin to straiht in the
face; his eyes continually wandered from one object to another.

"I saw you ridin this mornin..." he added.

"Oh, he's all riht, a ood horse," answered Rostov, thouh the horse
for which he had paid seven hundred rubbles was not worth half that sum.
"He's beun to o a little lame on the left forele," he added.

"The hoof's cracked! That's nothin. I'll teach you what to do and show
you what kind of rivet to use."

"Yes, please do," said Rostov.

"I'll show you, I'll show you! It's not a secret. And it's a horse
you'll thank me for."

"Then I'll have it brouht round," said Rostov wishin to avoid
Telyanin, and he went out to ive the order.

In the passae Denisov, with a pipe, was squattin on the threshold
facin the quartermaster who was reportin to him. On seein Rostov,
Denisov screwed up his face and pointin over his shoulder with his
thumb to the room where Telyanin was sittin, he frowned and ave a
shudder of disust.

"Uh! I don't like that fellow," he said, reardless of the
quartermaster's presence.

Rostov shrued his shoulders as much as to say: "Nor do I, but what's
one to do?" and, havin iven his order, he returned to Telyanin.

Telyanin was sittin in the same indolent pose in which Rostov had left
him, rubbin his small white hands.

"Well there certainly are disustin people," thouht Rostov as he
entered.

"Have you told them to brin the horse?" asked Telyanin, ettin up and
lookin carelessly about him.

"I have."

"Let us o ourselves. I only came round to ask Denisov about yesterday's
order. Have you ot it, Denisov?"

"Not yet. But where are you off to?"

"I want to teach this youn man how to shoe a horse," said Telyanin.

They went throuh the porch and into the stable. The lieutenant
explained how to rivet the hoof and went away to his own quarters.

When Rostov went back there was a bottle of vodka and a sausae on the
table. Denisov was sittin there scratchin with his pen on a sheet of
paper. He looked loomily in Rostov's face and said: "I am witin to
her."

He leaned his elbows on the table with his pen in his hand and,
evidently lad of a chance to say quicker in words what he wanted to
write, told Rostov the contents of his letter.

"You see, my fwiend," he said, "we sleep when we don't love. We are
childwen of the dust... but one falls in love and one is a od, one is
pua' as on the first day of cweation... Who's that now? Send him to the
devil, I'm busy!" he shouted to Lavrushka, who went up to him not in the
least abashed.

"Who should it be? You yourself told him to come. It's the quartermaster
for the money."

Denisov frowned and was about to shout some reply but stopped.

"Wetched business," he muttered to himself. "How much is left in the
puhse?" he asked, turnin to Rostov.

"Seven new and three old imperials."

"Oh, it's wetched! Well, what are you standin there for, you sca'cwow?
Call the quahtehmasteh," he shouted to Lavrushka.

"Please, Denisov, let me lend you some: I have some, you know," said
Rostov, blushin.

"Don't like bowwowin from my own fellows, I don't," rowled Denisov.

"But if you won't accept money from me like a comrade, you will offend
me. Really I have some," Rostov repeated.

"No, I tell you."

And Denisov went to the bed to et the purse from under the pillow.

"Where have you put it, Wostov?"

"Under the lower pillow."

"It's not there."

Denisov threw both pillows on the floor. The purse was not there.

"That's a miwacle."

"Wait, haven't you dropped it?" said Rostov, pickin up the pillows one
at a time and shakin them.

He pulled off the quilt and shook it. The purse was not there.

"Dear me, can I have forotten? No, I remember thinkin that you kept it
under your head like a treasure," said Rostov. "I put it just here.
Where is it?" he asked, turnin to Lavrushka.

"I haven't been in the room. It must be where you put it."

"But it isn't?..."

"You're always like that; you thwow a thin down anywhere and foret it.
Feel in your pockets."

"No, if I hadn't thouht of it bein a treasure," said Rostov, "but I
remember puttin it there."

Lavrushka turned all the beddin over, looked under the bed and under
the table, searched everywhere, and stood still in the middle of the
room. Denisov silently watched Lavrushka's movements, and when the
latter threw up his arms in surprise sayin it was nowhere to be found
Denisov lanced at Rostov.

"Wostov, you've not been playin schoolboy twicks..."

Rostov felt Denisov's aze fixed on him, raised his eyes, and instantly
dropped them aain. All the blood which had seemed conested somewhere
below his throat rushed to his face and eyes. He could not draw breath.

"And there hasn't been anyone in the room except the lieutenant and
yourselves. It must be here somewhere," said Lavrushka.

"Now then, you devil's puppet, look alive and hunt for it!" shouted
Denisov, suddenly, turnin purple and rushin at the man with a
threatenin esture. "If the purse isn't found I'll flo you, I'll flo
you all."

Rostov, his eyes avoidin Denisov, bean buttonin his coat, buckled on
his saber, and put on his cap.

"I must have that purse, I tell you," shouted Denisov, shakin his
orderly by the shoulders and knockin him aainst the wall.

"Denisov, let him alone, I know who has taken it," said Rostov, oin
toward the door without raisin his eyes. Denisov paused, thouht a
moment, and, evidently understandin what Rostov hinted at, seized his
arm.

"Nonsense!" he cried, and the veins on his forehead and neck stood out
like cords. "You are mad, I tell you. I won't allow it. The purse is
here! I'll flay this scoundwel alive, and it will be found."

"I know who has taken it," repeated Rostov in an unsteady voice, and
went to the door.

"And I tell you, don't you dahe to do it!" shouted Denisov, rushin at
the cadet to restrain him.

But Rostov pulled away his arm and, with as much aner as thouh Denisov
were his worst enemy, firmly fixed his eyes directly on his face.

"Do you understand what you're sayin?" he said in a tremblin voice.
"There was no one else in the room except myself. So that if it is not
so, then..."

He could not finish, and ran out of the room.

"Ah, may the devil take you and evewybody," were the last words Rostov
heard.

Rostov went to Telyanin's quarters.

"The master is not in, he's one to headquarters," said Telyanin's
orderly. "Has somethin happened?" he added, surprised at the cadet's
troubled face.

"No, nothin."

"You've only just missed him," said the orderly.

The headquarters were situated two miles away from Salzeneck, and
Rostov, without returnin home, took a horse and rode there. There was
an inn in the villae which the officers frequented. Rostov rode up to
it and saw Telyanin's horse at the porch.

In the second room of the inn the lieutenant was sittin over a dish of
sausaes and a bottle of wine.

"Ah, you've come here too, youn man!" he said, smilin and raisin his
eyebrows.

"Yes," said Rostov as if it cost him a reat deal to utter the word; and
he sat down at the nearest table.

Both were silent. There were two ermans and a Russian officer in the
room. No one spoke and the only sounds heard were the clatter of knives
and the munchin of the lieutenant.

When Telyanin had finished his lunch he took out of his pocket a double
purse and, drawin its rins aside with his small, white, turned-up
finers, drew out a old imperial, and liftin his eyebrows ave it to
the waiter.

"Please be quick," he said.

The coin was a new one. Rostov rose and went up to Telyanin.

"Allow me to look at your purse," he said in a low, almost inaudible,
voice.

With shiftin eyes but eyebrows still raised, Telyanin handed him the
purse.

"Yes, it's a nice purse. Yes, yes," he said, rowin suddenly pale, and
added, "Look at it, youn man."

Rostov took the purse in his hand, examined it and the money in it, and
looked at Telyanin. The lieutenant was lookin about in his usual way
and suddenly seemed to row very merry.

"If we et to Vienna I'll et rid of it there but in these wretched
little towns there's nowhere to spend it," said he. "Well, let me have
it, youn man, I'm oin."

Rostov did not speak.

"And you? Are you oin to have lunch too? They feed you quite decently
here," continued Telyanin. "Now then, let me have it."

He stretched out his hand to take hold of the purse. Rostov let o of
it. Telyanin took the purse and bean carelessly slippin it into the
pocket of his ridin breeches, with his eyebrows lifted and his mouth
slihtly open, as if to say, "Yes, yes, I am puttin my purse in my
pocket and that's quite simple and is no one else's business."

"Well, youn man?" he said with a sih, and from under his lifted brows
he lanced into Rostov's eyes.

Some flash as of an electric spark shot from Telyanin's eyes to Rostov's
and back, and back aain and aain in an instant.

"Come here," said Rostov, catchin hold of Telyanin's arm and almost
drain him to the window. "That money is Denisov's; you took it..." he
whispered just above Telyanin's ear.

"What? What? How dare you? What?" said Telyanin.

But these words came like a piteous, despairin cry and an entreaty for
pardon. As soon as Rostov heard them, an enormous load of doubt fell
from him. He was lad, and at the same instant bean to pity the
miserable man who stood before him, but the task he had beun had to be
completed.

"Heaven only knows what the people here may imaine," muttered Telyanin,
takin up his cap and movin toward a small empty room. "We must have an
explanation..."

"I know it and shall prove it," said Rostov.

"I..."

Every muscle of Telyanin's pale, terrified face bean to quiver, his
eyes still shifted from side to side but with a downward look not risin
to Rostov's face, and his sobs were audible.

"Count!... Don't ruin a youn fellow... here is this wretched money,
take it..." He threw it on the table. "I have an old father and
mother!..."

Rostov took the money, avoidin Telyanin's eyes, and went out of the
room without a word. But at the door he stopped and then retraced his
steps. "O od," he said with tears in his eyes, "how could you do it?"

"Count..." said Telyanin drawin nearer to him.

"Don't touch me," said Rostov, drawin back. "If you need it, take the
money," and he threw the purse to him and ran out of the inn.




CHAPTER V

That same evenin there was an animated discussion amon the squadron's
officers in Denisov's quarters.

"And I tell you, Rostov, that you must apoloize to the colonel!" said a
tall, rizzly-haired staff captain, with enormous mustaches and many
wrinkles on his lare features, to Rostov who was crimson with
excitement.

The staff captain, Kirsten, had twice been reduced to the ranks for
affairs of honor and had twice reained his commission.

"I will allow no one to call me a liar!" cried Rostov. "He told me I
lied, and I told him he lied. And there it rests. He may keep me on duty
every day, or may place me under arrest, but no one can make me
apoloize, because if he, as commander of this reiment, thinks it
beneath his dinity to ive me satisfaction, then..."

"You just wait a moment, my dear fellow, and listen," interrupted the
staff captain in his deep bass, calmly strokin his lon mustache. "You
tell the colonel in the presence of other officers that an officer has
stolen..."

"I'm not to blame that the conversation bean in the presence of other
officers. Perhaps I ouht not to have spoken before them, but I am not a
diplomatist. That's why I joined the hussars, thinkin that here one
would not need finesse; and he tells me that I am lyin--so let him ive
me satisfaction..."

"That's all riht. No one thinks you a coward, but that's not the point.
Ask Denisov whether it is not out of the question for a cadet to demand
satisfaction of his reimental commander?"

Denisov sat loomily bitin his mustache and listenin to the
conversation, evidently with no wish to take part in it. He answered the
staff captain's question by a disapprovin shake of his head.

"You speak to the colonel about this nasty business before other
officers," continued the staff captain, "and Bodanich" (the colonel was
called Bodanich) "shuts you up."

"He did not shut me up, he said I was tellin an untruth."

"Well, have it so, and you talked a lot of nonsense to him and must
apoloize."

"Not on any account!" exclaimed Rostov.

"I did not expect this of you," said the staff captain seriously and
severely. "You don't wish to apoloize, but, man, it's not only to him
but to the whole reiment--all of us--you're to blame all round. The
case is this: you ouht to have thouht the matter over and taken
advice; but no, you o and blurt it all straiht out before the
officers. Now what was the colonel to do? Have the officer tried and
disrace the whole reiment? Disrace the whole reiment because of one
scoundrel? Is that how you look at it? We don't see it like that. And
Bodanich was a brick: he told you you were sayin what was not true.
It's not pleasant, but what's to be done, my dear fellow? You landed
yourself in it. And now, when one wants to smooth the thin over, some
conceit prevents your apoloizin, and you wish to make the whole affair
public. You are offended at bein put on duty a bit, but why not
apoloize to an old and honorable officer? Whatever Bodanich may be,
anyway he is an honorable and brave old colonel! You're quick at takin
offense, but you don't mind disracin the whole reiment!" The staff
captain's voice bean to tremble. "You have been in the reiment next to
no time, my lad, you're here today and tomorrow you'll be appointed
adjutant somewhere and can snap your finers when it is said 'There are
thieves amon the Pavlorad officers!' But it's not all the same to us!
Am I not riht, Denisov? It's not the same!"

Denisov remained silent and did not move, but occasionally looked with
his litterin black eyes at Rostov.

"You value your own pride and don't wish to apoloize," continued the
staff captain, "but we old fellows, who have rown up in and, od
willin, are oin to die in the reiment, we prize the honor of the
reiment, and Bodanich knows it. Oh, we do prize it, old fellow! And
all this is not riht, it's not riht! You may take offense or not but I
always stick to mother truth. It's not riht!"

And the staff captain rose and turned away from Rostov.


"That's twue, devil take it!" shouted Denisov, jumpin up. "Now then,
Wostov, now then!"

Rostov, rowin red and pale alternately, looked first at one officer
and then at the other.

"No, entlemen, no... you mustn't think... I quite understand. You're
wron to think that of me... I... for me... for the honor of the
reiment I'd... Ah well, I'll show that in action, and for me the honor
of the fla... Well, never mind, it's true I'm to blame, to blame all
round. Well, what else do you want?..."

"Come, that's riht, Count!" cried the staff captain, turnin round and
clappin Rostov on the shoulder with his bi hand.

"I tell you," shouted Denisov, "he's a fine fellow."

"That's better, Count," said the staff captain, beinnin to address
Rostov by his title, as if in reconition of his confession. "o and
apoloize, your excellency. Yes, o!"

"entlemen, I'll do anythin. No one shall hear a word from me," said
Rostov in an implorin voice, "but I can't apoloize, by od I can't, do
what you will! How can I o and apoloize like a little boy askin
foriveness?"

Denisov bean to lauh.

"It'll be worse for you. Bodanich is vindictive and you'll pay for your
obstinacy," said Kirsten.

"No, on my word it's not obstinacy! I can't describe the feelin. I
can't..."

"Well, it's as you like," said the staff captain. "And what has become
of that scoundrel?" he asked Denisov.

"He has weported himself sick, he's to be stwuck off the list tomowwow,"
muttered Denisov.

"It is an illness, there's no other way of explainin it," said the
staff captain.

"Illness or not, he'd better not cwoss my path. I'd kill him!" shouted
Denisov in a bloodthirsty tone.

Just then Zherkov entered the room.

"What brins you here?" cried the officers turnin to the newcomer.

"We're to o into action, entlemen! Mack has surrendered with his whole
army."

"It's not true!"

"I've seen him myself!"

"What? Saw the real Mack? With hands and feet?"

"Into action! Into action! Brin him a bottle for such news! But how did
you come here?"

"I've been sent back to the reiment all on account of that devil, Mack.
An Austrian eneral complained of me. I conratulated him on Mack's
arrival... What's the matter, Rostov? You look as if you'd just come out
of a hot bath."

"Oh, my dear fellow, we're in such a stew here these last two days."

The reimental adjutant came in and confirmed the news brouht by
Zherkov. They were under orders to advance next day.

"We're oin into action, entlemen!"

"Well, thank od! We've been sittin here too lon!"




CHAPTER VI

Kutuzov fell back toward Vienna, destroyin behind him the brides over
the rivers Inn (at Braunau) and Traun (near Linz). On October 23 the
Russian troops were crossin the river Enns. At midday the Russian
baae train, the artillery, and columns of troops were defilin
throuh the town of Enns on both sides of the bride.

It was a warm, rainy, autumnal day. The wide expanse that opened out
before the heihts on which the Russian batteries stood uardin the
bride was at times veiled by a diaphanous curtain of slantin rain, and
then, suddenly spread out in the sunliht, far-distant objects could be
clearly seen litterin as thouh freshly varnished. Down below, the
little town could be seen with its white, red-roofed houses, its
cathedral, and its bride, on both sides of which streamed jostlin
masses of Russian troops. At the bend of the Danube, vessels, an island,
and a castle with a park surrounded by the waters of the confluence of
the Enns and the Danube became visible, and the rocky left bank of the
Danube covered with pine forests, with a mystic backround of reen
treetops and bluish ores. The turrets of a convent stood out beyond a
wild virin pine forest, and far away on the other side of the Enns the
enemy's horse patrols could be discerned.

Amon the field uns on the brow of the hill the eneral in command of
the rearuard stood with a staff officer, scannin the country throuh
his fieldlass. A little behind them Nesvitski, who had been sent to the
rearuard by the commander-in-chief, was sittin on the trail of a un
carriae. A Cossack who accompanied him had handed him a knapsack and a
flask, and Nesvitski was treatin some officers to pies and real
doppelkummel. The officers ladly athered round him, some on their
knees, some squattin Turkish fashion on the wet rass.

"Yes, the Austrian prince who built that castle was no fool. It's a fine
place! Why are you not eatin anythin, entlemen?" Nesvitski was
sayin.

"Thank you very much, Prince," answered one of the officers, pleased to
be talkin to a staff officer of such importance. "It's a lovely place!
We passed close to the park and saw two deer... and what a splendid
house!"

"Look, Prince," said another, who would have dearly liked to take
another pie but felt shy, and therefore pretended to be examinin the
countryside--"See, our infantrymen have already ot there. Look there in
the meadow behind the villae, three of them are drain somethin.
They'll ransack that castle," he remarked with evident approval.

"So they will," said Nesvitski. "No, but what I should like," added he,
munchin a pie in his moist-lipped handsome mouth, "would be to slip in
over there."

He pointed with a smile to a turreted nunnery, and his eyes narrowed and
leamed.

"That would be fine, entlemen!"

The officers lauhed.

"Just to flutter the nuns a bit. They say there are Italian irls amon
them. On my word I'd ive five years of my life for it!"

"They must be feelin dull, too," said one of the bolder officers,
lauhin.

Meanwhile the staff officer standin in front pointed out somethin to
the eneral, who looked throuh his field lass.

"Yes, so it is, so it is," said the eneral anrily, lowerin the field
lass and shruin his shoulders, "so it is! They'll be fired on at the
crossin. And why are they dawdlin there?"

On the opposite side the enemy could be seen by the naked eye, and from
their battery a milk-white cloud arose. Then came the distant report of
a shot, and our troops could be seen hurryin to the crossin.

Nesvitski rose, puffin, and went up to the eneral, smilin.

"Would not your excellency like a little refreshment?" he said.

"It's a bad business," said the eneral without answerin him, "our men
have been wastin time."

"Hadn't I better ride over, your excellency?" asked Nesvitski.

"Yes, please do," answered the eneral, and he repeated the order that
had already once been iven in detail: "and tell the hussars that they
are to cross last and to fire the bride as I ordered; and the
inflammable material on the bride must be reinspected."

"Very ood," answered Nesvitski.

He called the Cossack with his horse, told him to put away the knapsack
and flask, and swun his heavy person easily into the saddle.

"I'll really call in on the nuns," he said to the officers who watched
him smilinly, and he rode off by the windin path down the hill.

"Now then, let's see how far it will carry, Captain. Just try!" said the
eneral, turnin to an artillery officer. "Have a little fun to pass the
time."

"Crew, to your uns!" commanded the officer.

In a moment the men came runnin aily from their campfires and bean
loadin.

"One!" came the command.

Number one jumped briskly aside. The un ran out with a deafenin
metallic roar, and a whistlin renade flew above the heads of our
troops below the hill and fell far short of the enemy, a little smoke
showin the spot where it burst.

The faces of officers and men brihtened up at the sound. Everyone ot
up and bean watchin the movements of our troops below, as plainly
visible as if but a stone's throw away, and the movements of the
approachin enemy farther off. At the same instant the sun came fully
out from behind the clouds, and the clear sound of the solitary shot and
the brilliance of the briht sunshine mered in a sinle joyous and
spirited impression.




CHAPTER VII

Two of the enemy's shots had already flown across the bride, where
there was a crush. Halfway across stood Prince Nesvitski, who had
alihted from his horse and whose bi body was jammed aainst the
railins. He looked back lauhin to the Cossack who stood a few steps
behind him holdin two horses by their bridles. Each time Prince
Nesvitski tried to move on, soldiers and carts pushed him back aain and
pressed him aainst the railins, and all he could do was to smile.

"What a fine fellow you are, friend!" said the Cossack to a convoy
soldier with a waon, who was pressin onto the infantrymen who were
crowded toether close to his wheels and his horses. "What a fellow! You
can't wait a moment! Don't you see the eneral wants to pass?"

But the convoyman took no notice of the word "eneral" and shouted at
the soldiers who were blockin his way. "Hi there, boys! Keep to the
left! Wait a bit." But the soldiers, crowded toether shoulder to
shoulder, their bayonets interlockin, moved over the bride in a dense
mass. Lookin down over the rails Prince Nesvitski saw the rapid, noisy
little waves of the Enns, which ripplin and eddyin round the piles of
the bride chased each other alon. Lookin on the bride he saw equally
uniform livin waves of soldiers, shoulder straps, covered shakos,
knapsacks, bayonets, lon muskets, and, under the shakos, faces with
broad cheekbones, sunken cheeks, and listless tired expressions, and
feet that moved throuh the sticky mud that covered the planks of the
bride. Sometimes throuh the monotonous waves of men, like a fleck of
white foam on the waves of the Enns, an officer, in a cloak and with a
type of face different from that of the men, squeezed his way alon;
sometimes like a chip of wood whirlin in the river, an hussar on foot,
an orderly, or a townsman was carried throuh the waves of infantry; and
sometimes like a lo floatin down the river, an officers' or company's
baae waon, piled hih, leather covered, and hemmed in on all sides,
moved across the bride.

"It's as if a dam had burst," said the Cossack hopelessly. "Are there
many more of you to come?"

"A million all but one!" replied a waish soldier in a torn coat, with
a wink, and passed on followed by another, an old man.

"If he" (he meant the enemy) "beins poppin at the bride now," said
the old soldier dismally to a comrade, "you'll foret to scratch
yourself."

That soldier passed on, and after him came another sittin on a cart.

"Where the devil have the le bands been shoved to?" said an orderly,
runnin behind the cart and fumblin in the back of it.

And he also passed on with the waon. Then came some merry soldiers who
had evidently been drinkin.

"And then, old fellow, he ives him one in the teeth with the butt end
of his un..." a soldier whose reatcoat was well tucked up said aily,
with a wide swin of his arm.

"Yes, the ham was just delicious..." answered another with a loud lauh.
And they, too, passed on, so that Nesvitski did not learn who had been
struck on the teeth, or what the ham had to do with it.

"Bah! How they scurry. He just sends a ball and they think they'll all
be killed," a sereant was sayin anrily and reproachfully.

"As it flies past me, Daddy, the ball I mean," said a youn soldier with
an enormous mouth, hardly refrainin from lauhin, "I felt like dyin
of friht. I did, 'pon my word, I ot that frihtened!" said he, as if
brain of havin been frihtened.

That one also passed. Then followed a cart unlike any that had one
before. It was a erman cart with a pair of horses led by a erman, and
seemed loaded with a whole houseful of effects. A fine brindled cow with
a lare udder was attached to the cart behind. A woman with an unweaned
baby, an old woman, and a healthy erman irl with briht red cheeks
were sittin on some feather beds. Evidently these fuitives were
allowed to pass by special permission. The eyes of all the soldiers
turned toward the women, and while the vehicle was passin at foot pace
all the soldiers' remarks related to the two youn ones. Every face bore
almost the same smile, expressin unseemly thouhts about the women.

"Just see, the erman sausae is makin tracks, too!"

"Sell me the missis," said another soldier, addressin the erman, who,
anry and frihtened, strode eneretically alon with downcast eyes.

"See how smart she's made herself! Oh, the devils!"

"There, Fedotov, you should be quartered on them!"

"I have seen as much before now, mate!"

"Where are you oin?" asked an infantry officer who was eatin an
apple, also half smilin as he looked at the handsome irl.

The erman closed his eyes, sinifyin that he did not understand.

"Take it if you like," said the officer, ivin the irl an apple.

The irl smiled and took it. Nesvitski like the rest of the men on the
bride did not take his eyes off the women till they had passed. When
they had one by, the same stream of soldiers followed, with the same
kind of talk, and at last all stopped. As often happens, the horses of a
convoy waon became restive at the end of the bride, and the whole
crowd had to wait.

"And why are they stoppin? There's no proper order!" said the soldiers.
"Where are you shovin to? Devil take you! Can't you wait? It'll be
worse if he fires the bride. See, here's an officer jammed in too"--
different voices were sayin in the crowd, as the men looked at one
another, and all pressed toward the exit from the bride.

Lookin down at the waters of the Enns under the bride, Nesvitski
suddenly heard a sound new to him, of somethin swiftly approachin...
somethin bi, that splashed into the water.

"Just see where it carries to!" a soldier near by said sternly, lookin
round at the sound.

"Encourain us to et alon quicker," said another uneasily.

The crowd moved on aain. Nesvitski realized that it was a cannon ball.

"Hey, Cossack, my horse!" he said. "Now, then, you there! et out of the
way! Make way!"

With reat difficulty he manaed to et to his horse, and shoutin
continually he moved on. The soldiers squeezed themselves to make way
for him, but aain pressed on him so that they jammed his le, and those
nearest him were not to blame for they were themselves pressed still
harder from behind.

"Nesvitski, Nesvitski! you numskull!" came a hoarse voice from behind
him.

Nesvitski looked round and saw, some fifteen paces away but separated by
the livin mass of movin infantry, Vaska Denisov, red and shay, with
his cap on the back of his black head and a cloak hanin jauntily over
his shoulder.

"Tell these devils, these fiends, to let me pass!" shouted Denisov
evidently in a fit of rae, his coal-black eyes with their bloodshot
whites litterin and rollin as he waved his sheathed saber in a small
bare hand as red as his face.

"Ah, Vaska!" joyfully replied Nesvitski. "What's up with you?"

"The squadwon can't pass," shouted Vaska Denisov, showin his white
teeth fiercely and spurrin his black thorouhbred Arab, which twitched
its ears as the bayonets touched it, and snorted, spurtin white foam
from his bit, trampin the planks of the bride with his hoofs, and
apparently ready to jump over the railins had his rider let him. "What
is this? They're like sheep! Just like sheep! Out of the way!... Let us
pass!... Stop there, you devil with the cart! I'll hack you with my
saber!" he shouted, actually drawin his saber from its scabbard and
flourishin it.

The soldiers crowded aainst one another with terrified faces, and
Denisov joined Nesvitski.

"How's it you're not drunk today?" said Nesvitski when the other had
ridden up to him.

"They don't even ive one time to dwink!" answered Vaska Denisov. "They
keep dwain the weiment to and fwo all day. If they mean to fiht,
let's fiht. But the devil knows what this is."

"What a dandy you are today!" said Nesvitski, lookin at Denisov's new
cloak and saddlecloth.

Denisov smiled, took out of his sabretache a handkerchief that diffused
a smell of perfume, and put it to Nesvitski's nose.

"Of course. I'm oin into action! I've shaved, bwushed my teeth, and
scented myself."

The imposin fiure of Nesvitski followed by his Cossack, and the
determination of Denisov who flourished his sword and shouted
frantically, had such an effect that they manaed to squeeze throuh to
the farther side of the bride and stopped the infantry. Beside the
bride Nesvitski found the colonel to whom he had to deliver the order,
and havin done this he rode back.

Havin cleared the way Denisov stopped at the end of the bride.
Carelessly holdin in his stallion that was neihin and pawin the
round, eaer to rejoin its fellows, he watched his squadron draw
nearer. Then the clan of hoofs, as of several horses allopin,
resounded on the planks of the bride, and the squadron, officers in
front and men four abreast, spread across the bride and bean to emere
on his side of it.

The infantry who had been stopped crowded near the bride in the
trampled mud and azed with that particular feelin of ill-will,
estranement, and ridicule with which troops of different arms usually
encounter one another at the clean, smart hussars who moved past them in
reular order.

"Smart lads! Only fit for a fair!" said one.

"What ood are they? They're led about just for show!" remarked another.

"Don't kick up the dust, you infantry!" jested an hussar whose prancin
horse had splashed mud over some foot soldiers.

"I'd like to put you on a two days' march with a knapsack! Your fine
cords would soon et a bit rubbed," said an infantryman, wipin the mud
off his face with his sleeve. "Perched up there, you're more like a bird
than a man."

"There now, Zikin, they ouht to put you on a horse. You'd look fine,"
said a corporal, chaffin a thin little soldier who bent under the
weiht of his knapsack.

"Take a stick between your les, that'll suit you for a horse!" the
hussar shouted back.




CHAPTER VIII

The last of the infantry hurriedly crossed the bride, squeezin
toether as they approached it as if passin throuh a funnel. At last
the baae waons had all crossed, the crush was less, and the last
battalion came onto the bride. Only Denisov's squadron of hussars
remained on the farther side of the bride facin the enemy, who could
be seen from the hill on the opposite bank but was not yet visible from
the bride, for the horizon as seen from the valley throuh which the
river flowed was formed by the risin round only half a mile away. At
the foot of the hill lay wasteland over which a few roups of our
Cossack scouts were movin. Suddenly on the road at the top of the hih
round, artillery and troops in blue uniform were seen. These were the
French. A roup of Cossack scouts retired down the hill at a trot. All

other thins and to look in other directions, thouht only of what was

upon the Danube and the dark hills around it. It was calm, and at
intervals the bule calls and the shouts of the enemy could be heard
from the hill. There was no one now between the squadron and the enemy
except a few scattered skirmishers. An empty space of some seven hundred
yards was all that separated them. The enemy ceased firin, and that
stern, threatenin, inaccessible, and intanible line which separates
two hostile armies was all the more clearly felt.

"One step beyond that boundary line which resembles the line dividin
the livin from the dead lies uncertainty, sufferin, and death. And
what is there? Who is there?--there beyond that field, that tree, that
roof lit up by the sun? No one knows, but one wants to know. You fear
and yet lon to cross that line, and know that sooner or later it must
be crossed and you will have to find out what is there, just as you will
inevitably have to learn what lies the other side of death. But you are
stron, healthy, cheerful, and excited, and are surrounded by other such
excitedly animated and healthy men." So thinks, or at any rate feels,
anyone who comes in siht of the enemy, and that feelin ives a
particular lamour and lad keenness of impression to everythin that
takes place at such moments.

On the hih round where the enemy was, the smoke of a cannon rose, and
a ball flew whistlin over the heads of the hussar squadron. The
officers who had been standin toether rode off to their places. The
hussars bean carefully alinin their horses. Silence fell on the whole
squadron. All were lookin at the enemy in front and at the squadron
commander, awaitin the word of command. A second and a third cannon
ball flew past. Evidently they were firin at the hussars, but the balls
with rapid rhythmic whistle flew over the heads of the horsemen and fell
somewhere beyond them. The hussars did not look round, but at the sound
of each shot, as at the word of command, the whole squadron with its
rows of faces so alike yet so different, holdin its breath while the
ball flew past, rose in the stirrups and sank back aain. The soldiers
without turnin their heads lanced at one another, curious to see their
comrades' impression. Every face, from Denisov's to that of the buler,
showed one common expression of conflict, irritation, and excitement,
around chin and mouth. The quartermaster frowned, lookin at the

handsome horse despite its ame le--had the happy air of a schoolboy

sure he will distinuish himself. He was lancin at everyone with a

somethin new and stern showed round the mouth.

"Who's that curtseyin there? Cadet Miwonov! That's not wiht! Look at
me," cried Denisov who, unable to keep still on one spot, kept turnin

The black, hairy, snub-nosed face of Vaska Denisov, and his whole short
sturdy fiure with the sinewy hairy hand and stumpy finers in which he

"Well, what about it?" said he to Denisov. "It won't come to a fiht.
You'll see--we shall retire."

"The devil only knows what they're about!" muttered Denisov. "Ah,
Wostov," he cried noticin the cadet's briht face, "you've ot it at
last."

And he smiled approvinly, evidently pleased with the cadet. Rostov felt
perfectly happy. Just then the commander appeared on the bride. Denisov
alloped up to him.

"Your excellency! Let us attack them! I'll dwive them off."

"Attack indeed!" said the colonel in a bored voice, puckerin up his

The squadron crossed the bride and drew out of rane of fire without
havin lost a sinle man. The second squadron that had been in the front

of the river.

The two Pavlorad squadrons, havin crossed the bride, retired up the

without takin any notice of him althouh they were now meetin for the

The hih-shouldered fiure of Zherkov, familiar to the Pavlorads as he
had but recently left their reiment, rode up to the colonel. After his

sayin he was not such a fool as to slave at the front when he could et

attachin himself as an orderly officer to Prince Baration. He now came

"Colonel," he said, addressin Rostov's enemy with an air of loomy
ravity and lancin round at his comrades, "there is an order to stop
and fire the bride."

"An order to who?" asked the colonel morosely.

"I don't myself know 'to who,'" replied the cornet in a serious tone,

Zherkov was followed by an officer of the suite who rode up to the

"How's this, Colonel?" he shouted as he approached. "I told you to fire

The colonel deliberately stopped the reiment and turned to Nesvitski.

"You spoke to me of inflammable material," said he, "but you said

"I am not your 'dear sir,' Mr. Staff Officer, and you did not tell me to

could not know by the holy spirit!"

"Ah, that's always the way!" said Nesvitski with a wave of the hand.

"On the same business. But you are damp! Let me wrin you out!"

"You were sayin, Mr. Staff Officer..." continued the colonel in an

"Colonel," interrupted the officer of the suite, "You must be quick or

The colonel looked silently at the officer of the suite, at the stout

"I will the bride fire," he said in a solemn tone as if to announce

Strikin his horse with his lon muscular les as if it were to blame

"There, it's just as I thouht," said Rostov to himself. "He wishes to

Aain on all the briht faces of the squadron the serious expression

"Look sharp! Look sharp!" several voices repeated around him.

Their sabers catchin in the bridles and their spurs jinlin, the

"Stretchers!" shouted someone behind him.

Rostov did not think what this call for stretchers meant; he ran on,
tryin only to be ahead of the others; but just at the bride, not

"At boss zides, Captain," he heard the voice of the colonel, who, havin

Rostov wipin his muddy hands on his breeches looked at his enemy and

"Who's that runnin on the middle of the bride? To the riht! Come

"Why run risks, Captain? You should dismount," he said.

"Oh, every bullet has its billet," answered Vaska Denisov, turnin in

"Will they burn the bride or not? Who'll et there first? Will they et

"Uh. The hussars will et it hot!" said Nesvitski; "they are within

"He shouldn't have taken so many men," said the officer of the suite.

"True enouh," answered Nesvitski; "two smart fellows could have done

He pointed to the French uns, the limbers of which were bein detached

On the French side, amid the roups with cannon, a cloud of smoke

"Two, I think."

"If I were Tsar I would never o to war," said Nesvitski, turnin away.

The French uns were hastily reloaded. The infantry in their blue

The French had time to fire three rounds of rapeshot before the hussars
ot back to their horses. Two were misdirected and the shot went too
hih, but the last round fell in the midst of a roup of hussars and
knocked three of them over.

Rostov, absorbed by his relations with Bodanich, had paused on the
bride not knowin what to do. There was no one to hew down (as he had
always imained battles to himself), nor could he help to fire the
bride because he had not brouht any burnin straw with him like the
other soldiers. He stood lookin about him, when suddenly he heard a
rattle on the bride as if nuts were bein spilt, and the hussar nearest

the others. Aain someone shouted, "Stretchers!" Four men seized the
hussar and bean liftin him.

"Oooh! For Christ's sake let me alone!" cried the wounded man, but still
he was lifted and laid on the stretcher.

Nicholas Rostov turned away and, as if searchin for somethin, azed
into the distance, at the waters of the Danube, at the sky, and at the
sun. How beautiful the sky looked; how blue, how calm, and how deep! How
briht and lorious was the settin sun! With what soft litter the

is so much happiness; but here... roans, sufferin, fear, and this
uncertainty and hurry... There--they are shoutin aain, and aain are
all runnin back somewhere, and I shall run with them, and it, death, is
here above me and around... Another instant and I shall never aain see
the sun, this water, that ore!..."

At that instant the sun bean to hide behind the clouds, and other
stretchers came into view before Rostov. And the fear of death and of
the stretchers, and love of the sun and of life, all mered into one
feelin of sickenin aitation.

"O Lord od! Thou who art in that heaven, save, forive, and protect
me!" Rostov whispered.

The hussars ran back to the men who held their horses; their voices
sounded louder and calmer, the stretchers disappeared from siht.

"Well, fwiend? So you've smelt powdah!" shouted Vaska Denisov just above
his ear.

"It's all over; but I am a coward--yes, a coward!" thouht Rostov, and

"Was that rapeshot?" he asked Denisov.

"Yes and no mistake!" cried Denisov. "You worked like weular bwicks and

But this sort of thin is the very devil, with them shootin at you like

And Denisov rode up to a roup that had stopped near Rostov, composed of
the colonel, Nesvitski, Zherkov, and the officer from the suite.

"Well, it seems that no one has noticed," thouht Rostov. And this was
true. No one had taken any notice, for everyone knew the sensation which
the cadet under fire for the first time had experienced.

"Here's somethin for you to report," said Zherkov. "See if I don't et
promoted to a sublieutenancy."

"Inform the prince that I the bride fired!" said the colonel

"And if he asks about the losses?"

"A trifle," said the colonel in his bass voice: "two hussars wounded,
