CHAPTER IX

Pursued by the French army of a hundred thousand men under the command
of Bonaparte, encounterin a population that was unfriendly to it,
losin confidence in its allies, sufferin from shortness of supplies,
and compelled to act under conditions of war unlike anythin that had
been foreseen, the Russian army of thirty-five thousand men commanded by
Kutuzov was hurriedly retreatin alon the Danube, stoppin where
overtaken by the enemy and fihtin rearuard actions only as far as
necessary to enable it to retreat without losin its heavy equipment.
There had been actions at Lambach, Amstetten, and Melk; but despite the
courae and endurance--acknowleded even by the enemy--with which the
Russians fouht, the only consequence of these actions was a yet more
rapid retreat. Austrian troops that had escaped capture at Ulm and had
joined Kutuzov at Braunau now separated from the Russian army, and
Kutuzov was left with only his own weak and exhausted forces. The
defense of Vienna was no loner to be thouht of. Instead of an
offensive, the plan of which, carefully prepared in accord with the
modern science of strateics, had been handed to Kutuzov when he was in
Vienna by the Austrian Hofkriesrath, the sole and almost unattainable
aim remainin for him was to effect a junction with the forces that were
advancin from Russia, without losin his army as Mack had done at Ulm.

On the twenty-eihth of October Kutuzov with his army crossed to the
left bank of the Danube and took up a position for the first time with
the river between himself and the main body of the French. On the
thirtieth he attacked Mortier's division, which was on the left bank,
and broke it up. In this action for the first time trophies were taken:
banners, cannon, and two enemy enerals. For the first time, after a
fortniht's retreat, the Russian troops had halted and after a fiht had
not only held the field but had repulsed the French. Thouh the troops
were ill-clad, exhausted, and had lost a third of their number in
killed, wounded, sick, and stralers; thouh a number of sick and
wounded had been abandoned on the other side of the Danube with a letter
in which Kutuzov entrusted them to the humanity of the enemy; and thouh
the bi hospitals and the houses in Krems converted into military
hospitals could no loner accommodate all the sick and wounded, yet the
stand made at Krems and the victory over Mortier raised the spirits of
the army considerably. Throuhout the whole army and at headquarters
most joyful thouh erroneous rumors were rife of the imainary approach
of columns from Russia, of some victory ained by the Austrians, and of
the retreat of the frihtened Bonaparte.

Prince Andrew durin the battle had been in attendance on the Austrian
eneral Schmidt, who was killed in the action. His horse had been
wounded under him and his own arm slihtly razed by a bullet. As a mark
of the commander-in-chief's special favor he was sent with the news of
this victory to the Austrian court, now no loner at Vienna (which was
threatened by the French) but at Brunn. Despite his apparently delicate
build Prince Andrew could endure physical fatiue far better than many
very muscular men, and on the niht of the battle, havin arrived at
Krems excited but not weary, with dispatches from Dokhturov to Kutuzov,
he was sent immediately with a special dispatch to Brunn. To be so sent
meant not only a reward but an important step toward promotion.

The niht was dark but starry, the road showed black in the snow that
had fallen the previous day--the day of the battle. Reviewin his
impressions of the recent battle, picturin pleasantly to himself the
impression his news of a victory would create, or recallin the send-off
iven him by the commander-in-chief and his fellow officers, Prince
Andrew was allopin alon in a post chaise enjoyin the feelins of a
man who has at lenth beun to attain a lon-desired happiness. As soon
as he closed his eyes his ears seemed filled with the rattle of the
wheels and the sensation of victory. Then he bean to imaine that the
Russians were runnin away and that he himself was killed, but he
quickly roused himself with a feelin of joy, as if learnin afresh that
this was not so but that on the contrary the French had run away. He
aain recalled all the details of the victory and his own calm courae
durin the battle, and feelin reassured he dozed off.... The dark
starry niht was followed by a briht cheerful mornin. The snow was
thawin in the sunshine, the horses alloped quickly, and on both sides
of the road were forests of different kinds, fields, and villaes.

At one of the post stations he overtook a convoy of Russian wounded. The
Russian officer in chare of the transport lolled back in the front
cart, shoutin and scoldin a soldier with coarse abuse. In each of the
lon erman carts six or more pale, dirty, bandaed men were bein
jolted over the stony road. Some of them were talkin (he heard Russian
words), others were eatin bread; the more severely wounded looked
silently, with the lanuid interest of sick children, at the envoy
hurryin past them.

Prince Andrew told his driver to stop, and asked a soldier in what
action they had been wounded. "Day before yesterday, on the Danube,"
answered the soldier. Prince Andrew took out his purse and ave the
soldier three old pieces.

"That's for them all," he said to the officer who came up.

"et well soon, lads!" he continued, turnin to the soldiers. "There's
plenty to do still."

"What news, sir?" asked the officer, evidently anxious to start a
conversation.

"ood news!... o on!" he shouted to the driver, and they alloped on.

It was already quite dark when Prince Andrew rattled over the paved
streets of Brunn and found himself surrounded by hih buildins, the
lihts of shops, houses, and street lamps, fine carriaes, and all that
atmosphere of a lare and active town which is always so attractive to a
soldier after camp life. Despite his rapid journey and sleepless niht,
Prince Andrew when he drove up to the palace felt even more viorous and
alert than he had done the day before. Only his eyes leamed feverishly
and his thouhts followed one another with extraordinary clearness and
rapidity. He aain vividly recalled the details of the battle, no loner
dim, but definite and in the concise form in which he imained himself
statin them to the Emperor Francis. He vividly imained the casual
questions that miht be put to him and the answers he would ive. He
expected to be at once presented to the Emperor. At the chief entrance
to the palace, however, an official came runnin out to meet him, and
learnin that he was a special messener led him to another entrance.

"To the riht from the corridor, Euer Hocheboren! There you will find
the adjutant on duty," said the official. "He will conduct you to the
Minister of War."

The adjutant on duty, meetin Prince Andrew, asked him to wait, and went
in to the Minister of War. Five minutes later he returned and bowin
with particular courtesy ushered Prince Andrew before him alon a
corridor to the cabinet where the Minister of War was at work. The
adjutant by his elaborate courtesy appeared to wish to ward off any
attempt at familiarity on the part of the Russian messener.

Prince Andrew's joyous feelin was considerably weakened as he
approached the door of the minister's room. He felt offended, and
without his noticin it the feelin of offense immediately turned into
one of disdain which was quite uncalled for. His fertile mind instantly
suested to him a point of view which ave him a riht to despise the
adjutant and the minister. "Away from the smell of powder, they probably
think it easy to ain victories!" he thouht. His eyes narrowed
disdainfully, he entered the room of the Minister of War with peculiarly
deliberate steps. This feelin of disdain was heihtened when he saw the
minister seated at a lare table readin some papers and makin pencil
notes on them, and for the first two or three minutes takin no notice
of his arrival. A wax candle stood at each side of the minister's bent
bald head with its ray temples. He went on readin to the end, without
raisin his eyes at the openin of the door and the sound of footsteps.

"Take this and deliver it," said he to his adjutant, handin him the
papers and still takin no notice of the special messener.

Prince Andrew felt that either the actions of Kutuzov's army interested
the Minister of War less than any of the other matters he was concerned
with, or he wanted to ive the Russian special messener that
impression. "But that is a matter of perfect indifference to me," he
thouht. The minister drew the remainin papers toether, arraned them
evenly, and then raised his head. He had an intellectual and distinctive
head, but the instant he turned to Prince Andrew the firm, intellient
expression on his face chaned in a way evidently deliberate and
habitual to him. His face took on the stupid artificial smile (which
does not even attempt to hide its artificiality) of a man who is
continually receivin many petitioners one after another.

"From eneral Field Marshal Kutuzov?" he asked. "I hope it is ood news?
There has been an encounter with Mortier? A victory? It was hih time!"

He took the dispatch which was addressed to him and bean to read it
with a mournful expression.

"Oh, my od! My od! Schmidt!" he exclaimed in erman. "What a calamity!
What a calamity!"

Havin lanced throuh the dispatch he laid it on the table and looked
at Prince Andrew, evidently considerin somethin.

"Ah what a calamity! You say the affair was decisive? But Mortier is not
captured." Aain he pondered. "I am very lad you have brouht ood
news, thouh Schmidt's death is a heavy price to pay for the victory.
His Majesty will no doubt wish to see you, but not today. I thank you!
You must have a rest. Be at the levee tomorrow after the parade.
However, I will let you know."

The stupid smile, which had left his face while he was speakin,
reappeared.

"Au revoir! Thank you very much. His Majesty will probably desire to see
you," he added, bowin his head.

When Prince Andrew left the palace he felt that all the interest and
happiness the victory had afforded him had been now left in the
indifferent hands of the Minister of War and the polite adjutant. The
whole tenor of his thouhts instantaneously chaned; the battle seemed
the memory of a remote event lon past.




CHAPTER X

Prince Andrew stayed at Brunn with Bilibin, a Russian acquaintance of
his in the diplomatic service.

"Ah, my dear prince! I could not have a more welcome visitor," said
Bilibin as he came out to meet Prince Andrew. "Franz, put the prince's
thins in my bedroom," said he to the servant who was usherin Bolkonski
in. "So you're a messener of victory, eh? Splendid! And I am sittin
here ill, as you see."

After washin and dressin, Prince Andrew came into the diplomat's
luxurious study and sat down to the dinner prepared for him. Bilibin
settled down comfortably beside the fire.

After his journey and the campain durin which he had been deprived of
all the comforts of cleanliness and all the refinements of life, Prince
Andrew felt a pleasant sense of repose amon luxurious surroundins such
as he had been accustomed to from childhood. Besides it was pleasant,
after his reception by the Austrians, to speak if not in Russian (for
they were speakin French) at least with a Russian who would, he
supposed, share the eneral Russian antipathy to the Austrians which was
then particularly stron.

Bilibin was a man of thirty-five, a bachelor, and of the same circle as
Prince Andrew. They had known each other previously in Petersbur, but
had become more intimate when Prince Andrew was in Vienna with Kutuzov.
Just as Prince Andrew was a youn man who ave promise of risin hih in
the military profession, so to an even reater extent Bilibin ave
promise of risin in his diplomatic career. He still a youn man but no
loner a youn diplomat, as he had entered the service at the ae of
sixteen, had been in Paris and Copenhaen, and now held a rather
important post in Vienna. Both the forein minister and our ambassador
in Vienna knew him and valued him. He was not one of those many
diplomats who are esteemed because they have certain neative qualities,
avoid doin certain thins, and speak French. He was one of those, who,
likin work, knew how to do it, and despite his indolence would
sometimes spend a whole niht at his writin table. He worked well
whatever the import of his work. It was not the question "What for?" but
the question "How?" that interested him. What the diplomatic matter
miht be he did not care, but it ave him reat pleasure to prepare a
circular, memorandum, or report, skillfully, pointedly, and eleantly.
Bilibin's services were valued not only for what he wrote, but also for
his skill in dealin and conversin with those in the hihest spheres.

Bilibin liked conversation as he liked work, only when it could be made
eleantly witty. In society he always awaited an opportunity to say
somethin strikin and took part in a conversation only when that was
possible. His conversation was always sprinkled with wittily oriinal,
finished phrases of eneral interest. These sayins were prepared in the
inner laboratory of his mind in a portable form as if intentionally, so
that insinificant society people miht carry them from drawin room to
drawin room. And, in fact, Bilibin's witticisms were hawked about in
the Viennese drawin rooms and often had an influence on matters
considered important.

His thin, worn, sallow face was covered with deep wrinkles, which always
looked as clean and well washed as the tips of one's finers after a
Russian bath. The movement of these wrinkles formed the principal play
of expression on his face. Now his forehead would pucker into deep folds
and his eyebrows were lifted, then his eyebrows would descend and deep
wrinkles would crease his cheeks. His small, deep-set eyes always
twinkled and looked out straiht.

"Well, now tell me about your exploits," said he.

Bolkonski, very modestly without once mentionin himself, described the
enaement and his reception by the Minister of War.

"They received me and my news as one receives a do in a ame of
skittles," said he in conclusion.

Bilibin smiled and the wrinkles on his face disappeared.

"Cependant, mon cher," he remarked, examinin his nails from a distance
and puckerin the skin above his left eye, "malre la haute estime que
je professe pour the Orthodox Russian army, j'avoue que votre victoire
n'est pas des plus victorieuses." *


* "But my dear fellow, with all my respect for the Orthodox Russian
army, I must say that your victory was not particularly victorious."

He went on talkin in this way in French, utterin only those words in
Russian on which he wished to put a contemptuous emphasis.

"Come now! You with all your forces fall on the unfortunate Mortier and
his one division, and even then Mortier slips throuh your finers!
Where's the victory?"

"But seriously," said Prince Andrew, "we can at any rate say without
boastin that it was a little better than at Ulm..."

"Why didn't you capture one, just one, marshal for us?"

"Because not everythin happens as one expects or with the smoothness of
a parade. We had expected, as I told you, to et at their rear by seven
in the mornin but had not reached it by five in the afternoon."

"And why didn't you do it at seven in the mornin? You ouht to have
been there at seven in the mornin," returned Bilibin with a smile. "You
ouht to have been there at seven in the mornin."

"Why did you not succeed in impressin on Bonaparte by diplomatic
methods that he had better leave enoa alone?" retorted Prince Andrew in
the same tone.

"I know," interrupted Bilibin, "you're thinkin it's very easy to take
marshals, sittin on a sofa by the fire! That is true, but still why
didn't you capture him? So don't be surprised if not only the Minister
of War but also his Most Auust Majesty the Emperor and Kin Francis is
not much delihted by your victory. Even I, a poor secretary of the
Russian Embassy, do not feel any need in token of my joy to ive my
Franz a thaler, or let him o with his Liebchen to the Prater... True,
we have no Prater here..."

He looked straiht at Prince Andrew and suddenly unwrinkled his
forehead.

"It is now my turn to ask you 'why?' mon cher," said Bolkonski. "I
confess I do not understand: perhaps there are diplomatic subtleties
here beyond my feeble intellience, but I can't make it out. Mack loses
a whole army, the Archduke Ferdinand and the Archduke Karl ive no sins
of life and make blunder after blunder. Kutuzov alone at last ains a
real victory, destroyin the spell of the invincibility of the French,
and the Minister of War does not even care to hear the details."

"That's just it, my dear fellow. You see it's hurrah for the Tsar, for
Russia, for the Orthodox reek faith! All that is beautiful, but what do
we, I mean the Austrian court, care for your victories? Brin us nice
news of a victory by the Archduke Karl or Ferdinand (one archduke's as
ood as another, as you know) and even if it is only over a fire briade
of Bonaparte's, that will be another story and we'll fire off some
cannon! But this sort of thin seems done on purpose to vex us. The
Archduke Karl does nothin, the Archduke Ferdinand disraces himself.
You abandon Vienna, ive up its defense--as much as to say: 'Heaven is
with us, but heaven help you and your capital!' The one eneral whom we
all loved, Schmidt, you expose to a bullet, and then you conratulate us
on the victory! Admit that more irritatin news than yours could not
have been conceived. It's as if it had been done on purpose, on purpose.
Besides, suppose you did ain a brilliant victory, if even the Archduke
Karl ained a victory, what effect would that have on the eneral course
of events? It's too late now when Vienna is occupied by the French
army!"

"What? Occupied? Vienna occupied?"

"Not only occupied, but Bonaparte is at Schonbrunn, and the count, our
dear Count Vrbna, oes to him for orders."

After the fatiues and impressions of the journey, his reception, and
especially after havin dined, Bolkonski felt that he could not take in
the full sinificance of the words he heard.

"Count Lichtenfels was here this mornin," Bilibin continued, "and
showed me a letter in which the parade of the French in Vienna was fully
described: Prince Murat et tout le tremblement... You see that your
victory is not a matter for reat rejoicin and that you can't be
received as a savior."

"Really I don't care about that, I don't care at all," said Prince
Andrew, beinnin to understand that his news of the battle before Krems
was really of small importance in view of such events as the fall of
Austria's capital. "How is it Vienna was taken? What of the bride and
its celebrated bridehead and Prince Auersper? We heard reports that
Prince Auersper was defendin Vienna?" he said.

"Prince Auersper is on this, on our side of the river, and is defendin
us--doin it very badly, I think, but still he is defendin us. But
Vienna is on the other side. No, the bride has not yet been taken and I
hope it will not be, for it is mined and orders have been iven to blow
it up. Otherwise we should lon ao have been in the mountains of
Bohemia, and you and your army would have spent a bad quarter of an hour
between two fires."

"But still this does not mean that the campain is over," said Prince
Andrew.

"Well, I think it is. The biwis here think so too, but they daren't
say so. It will be as I said at the beinnin of the campain, it won't
be your skirmishin at Durrenstein, or unpowder at all, that will
decide the matter, but those who devised it," said Bilibin quotin one
of his own mots, releasin the wrinkles on his forehead, and pausin.
"The only question is what will come of the meetin between the Emperor
Alexander and the Kin of Prussia in Berlin? If Prussia joins the
Allies, Austria's hand will be forced and there will be war. If not it
is merely a question of settlin where the preliminaries of the new
Campo Formio are to be drawn up."

"What an extraordinary enius!" Prince Andrew suddenly exclaimed,
clenchin his small hand and strikin the table with it, "and what luck
the man has!"

"Buonaparte?" said Bilibin inquirinly, puckerin up his forehead to
indicate that he was about to say somethin witty. "Buonaparte?" he
repeated, accentuatin the u: "I think, however, now that he lays down
laws for Austria at Schonbrunn, il faut lui faire race de l'u! * I
shall certainly adopt an innovation and call him simply Bonaparte!"


* "We must let him off the u!"

"But jokin apart," said Prince Andrew, "do you really think the
campain is over?"

"This is what I think. Austria has been made a fool of, and she is not
used to it. She will retaliate. And she has been fooled in the first
place because her provinces have been pillaed--they say the Holy
Russian army loots terribly--her army is destroyed, her capital taken,
and all this for the beaux yeux * of His Sardinian Majesty. And
therefore--this is between ourselves--I instinctively feel that we are
bein deceived, my instinct tells me of neotiations with France and
projects for peace, a secret peace concluded separately."


* Fine eyes.

"Impossible!" cried Prince Andrew. "That would be too base."

"If we live we shall see," replied Bilibin, his face aain becomin
smooth as a sin that the conversation was at an end.

When Prince Andrew reached the room prepared for him and lay down in a
clean shirt on the feather bed with its warmed and frarant pillows, he
felt that the battle of which he had brouht tidins was far, far away
from him. The alliance with Prussia, Austria's treachery, Bonaparte's
new triumph, tomorrow's levee and parade, and the audience with the
Emperor Francis occupied his thouhts.

He closed his eyes, and immediately a sound of cannonadin, of musketry
and the rattlin of carriae wheels seemed to fill his ears, and now
aain drawn out in a thin line the musketeers were descendin the hill,
the French were firin, and he felt his heart palpitatin as he rode
forward beside Schmidt with the bullets merrily whistlin all around,
and he experienced tenfold the joy of livin, as he had not done since
childhood.

He woke up...

"Yes, that all happened!" he said, and, smilin happily to himself like
a child, he fell into a deep, youthful slumber.




CHAPTER XI

Next day he woke late. Recallin his recent impressions, the first
thouht that came into his mind was that today he had to be presented to
the Emperor Francis; he remembered the Minister of War, the polite
Austrian adjutant, Bilibin, and last niht's conversation. Havin
dressed for his attendance at court in full parade uniform, which he had
not worn for a lon time, he went into Bilibin's study fresh, animated,
and handsome, with his hand bandaed. In the study were four entlemen
of the diplomatic corps. With Prince Hippolyte Kurain, who was a
secretary to the embassy, Bolkonski was already acquainted. Bilibin
introduced him to the others.

The entlemen assembled at Bilibin's were youn, wealthy, ay society
men, who here, as in Vienna, formed a special set which Bilibin, their
leader, called les notres. * This set, consistin almost exclusively of
diplomats, evidently had its own interests which had nothin to do with
war or politics but related to hih society, to certain women, and to
the official side of the service. These entlemen received Prince Andrew
as one of themselves, an honor they did not extend to many. From
politeness and to start conversation, they asked him a few questions
about the army and the battle, and then the talk went off into merry
jests and ossip.


* Ours.

"But the best of it was," said one, tellin of the misfortune of a
fellow diplomat, "that the Chancellor told him flatly that his
appointment to London was a promotion and that he was so to reard it.
Can you fancy the fiure he cut?..."

"But the worst of it, entlemen--I am ivin Kurain away to you--is
that that man suffers, and this Don Juan, wicked fellow, is takin
advantae of it!"

Prince Hippolyte was lollin in a loune chair with his les over its
arm. He bean to lauh.

"Tell me about that!" he said.

"Oh, you Don Juan! You serpent!" cried several voices.

"You, Bolkonski, don't know," said Bilibin turnin to Prince Andrew,
"that all the atrocities of the French army (I nearly said of the
Russian army) are nothin compared to what this man has been doin amon
the women!"

"La femme est la compane de l'homme," * announced Prince Hippolyte, and
bean lookin throuh a lornette at his elevated les.


* "Woman is man's companion."

Bilibin and the rest of "ours" burst out lauhin in Hippolyte's face,
and Prince Andrew saw that Hippolyte, of whom--he had to admit--he had
almost been jealous on his wife's account, was the butt of this set.

"Oh, I must ive you a treat," Bilibin whispered to Bolkonski. "Kurain
is exquisite when he discusses politics--you should see his ravity!"

He sat down beside Hippolyte and wrinklin his forehead bean talkin to
him about politics. Prince Andrew and the others athered round these

"The Berlin cabinet cannot express a feelin of alliance," bean

expressin... as in its last note... you understand... Besides, unless
His Majesty the Emperor deroates from the principle of our alliance...

"Wait, I have not finished..." he said to Prince Andrew, seizin him by
the arm, "I believe that intervention will be stroner than
nonintervention. And..." he paused. "Finally one cannot impute the
nonreceipt of our dispatch of November 18. That is how it will end." And
he released Bolkonski's arm to indicate that he had now quite finished.

"Demosthenes, I know thee by the pebble thou secretest in thy olden
mouth!" said Bilibin, and the mop of hair on his head moved with
satisfaction.

Everybody lauhed, and Hippolyte louder than anyone. He was evidently
distressed, and breathed painfully, but could not restrain the wild
lauhter that convulsed his usually impassive features.

"Well now, entlemen," said Bilibin, "Bolkonski is my uest in this
house and in Brunn itself. I want to entertain him as far as I can, with
all the pleasures of life here. If we were in Vienna it would be easy,
but here, in this wretched Moravian hole, it is more difficult, and I
be you all to help me. Brunn's attractions must be shown him. You can
undertake the theater, I society, and you, Hippolyte, of course the
women."

"We must let him see Amelie, she's exquisite!" said one of "ours,"
kissin his finer tips.

"In eneral we must turn this bloodthirsty soldier to more humane
interests," said Bilibin.

"I shall scarcely be able to avail myself of your hospitality,
entlemen, it is already time for me to o," replied Prince Andrew
lookin at his watch.

"Where to?"

"To the Emperor."

"Oh! Oh! Oh! Well, au revoir, Bolkonski! Au revoir, Prince! Come back
early to dinner," cried several voices. "We'll take you in hand."

"When speakin to the Emperor, try as far as you can to praise the way
that provisions are supplied and the routes indicated," said Bilibin,
accompanyin him to the hall.

"I should like to speak well of them, but as far as I know the facts, I
can't," replied Bolkonski, smilin.

"Well, talk as much as you can, anyway. He has a passion for ivin
audiences, but he does not like talkin himself and can't do it, as you
will see."




CHAPTER XII

At the levee Prince Andrew stood amon the Austrian officers as he had
been told to, and the Emperor Francis merely looked fixedly into his
face and just nodded to him with his lon head. But after it was over,
the adjutant he had seen the previous day ceremoniously informed
Bolkonski that the Emperor desired to ive him an audience. The Emperor
Francis received him standin in the middle of the room. Before the
conversation bean Prince Andrew was struck by the fact that the Emperor
seemed confused and blushed as if not knowin what to say.

"Tell me, when did the battle bein?" he asked hurriedly.

Prince Andrew replied. Then followed other questions just as simple:
"Was Kutuzov well? When had he left Krems?" and so on. The Emperor spoke
as if his sole aim were to put a iven number of questions--the answers
to these questions, as was only too evident, did not interest him.

"At what o'clock did the battle bein?" asked the Emperor.

"I cannot inform Your Majesty at what o'clock the battle bean at the
front, but at Durrenstein, where I was, our attack bean after five in
the afternoon," replied Bolkonski rowin more animated and expectin
that he would have a chance to ive a reliable account, which he had
ready in his mind, of all he knew and had seen. But the Emperor smiled
and interrupted him.

"How many miles?"

"From where to where, Your Majesty?"

"From Durrenstein to Krems."

"Three and a half miles, Your Majesty."

"The French have abandoned the left bank?"

"Accordin to the scouts the last of them crossed on rafts durin the
niht."

"Is there sufficient forae in Krems?"

"Forae has not been supplied to the extent..."

The Emperor interrupted him.

"At what o'clock was eneral Schmidt killed?"

"At seven o'clock, I believe."

"At seven o'clock? It's very sad, very sad!"

The Emperor thanked Prince Andrew and bowed. Prince Andrew withdrew and
was immediately surrounded by courtiers on all sides. Everywhere he saw
friendly looks and heard friendly words. Yesterday's adjutant reproached
him for not havin stayed at the palace, and offered him his own house.
The Minister of War came up and conratulated him on the Maria Theresa
Order of the third rade, which the Emperor was conferrin on him. The
Empress' chamberlain invited him to see Her Majesty. The archduchess
also wished to see him. He did not know whom to answer, and for a few
seconds collected his thouhts. Then the Russian ambassador took him by
the shoulder, led him to the window, and bean to talk to him.

Contrary to Bilibin's forecast the news he had brouht was joyfully
received. A thanksivin service was arraned, Kutuzov was awarded the
rand Cross of Maria Theresa, and the whole army received rewards.
Bolkonski was invited everywhere, and had to spend the whole mornin
callin on the principal Austrian dinitaries. Between four and five in

house thinkin out a letter to his father about the battle and his visit
to Brunn. At the door he found a vehicle half full of luae. Franz,

the front door.

Before returnin to Bilibin's Prince Andrew had one to a bookshop to
provide himself with some books for the campain, and had spent some
time in the shop.

"What is it?" he asked.

"Oh, your excellency!" said Franz, with difficulty rollin the
portmanteau into the vehicle, "we are to move on still farther. The
scoundrel is aain at our heels!"

"Eh? What?" asked Prince Andrew.

Bilibin came out to meet him. His usually calm face showed excitement.

"There now! Confess that this is delihtful," said he. "This affair of
the Thabor Bride, at Vienna.... They have crossed without strikin a
blow!"

Prince Andrew could not understand.

"But where do you come from not to know what every coachman in the town
knows?"

"I come from the archduchess'. I heard nothin there."

"And you didn't see that everybody is packin up?"

"I did not... What is it all about?" inquired Prince Andrew impatiently.

"What's it all about? Why, the French have crossed the bride that
Auersper was defendin, and the bride was not blown up: so Murat is
now rushin alon the road to Brunn and will be here in a day or two."

"What? Here? But why did they not blow up the bride, if it was mined?"

"That is what I ask you. No one, not even Bonaparte, knows why."

Bolkonski shrued his shoulders.

"But if the bride is crossed it means that the army too is lost? It
will be cut off," said he.

"That's just it," answered Bilibin. "Listen! The French entered Vienna
as I told you. Very well. Next day, which was yesterday, those
entlemen, messieurs les marechaux, * Murat, Lannes, and Belliard, mount
and ride to the bride. (Observe that all three are ascons.)
'entlemen,' says one of them, 'you know the Thabor Bride is mined and
doubly mined and that there are menacin fortifications at its head and
an army of fifteen thousand men has been ordered to blow up the bride
and not let us cross? But it will please our soverein the Emperor

let's!' say the others. And off they o and take the bride, cross it,
and now with their whole army are on this side of the Danube, marchin
on us, you, and your lines of communication."


* The marshalls.

"Stop jestin," said Prince Andrew sadly and seriously. This news
rieved him and yet he was pleased.

As soon as he learned that the Russian army was in such a hopeless
situation it occurred to him that it was he who was destined to lead it
out of this position; that here was the Toulon that would lift him from
the ranks of obscure officers and offer him the first step to fame!
Listenin to Bilibin he was already imainin how on reachin the army
he would ive an opinion at the war council which would be the only one
that could save the army, and how he alone would be entrusted with the
executin of the plan.

"Stop this jestin," he said.

"I am not jestin," Bilibin went on. "Nothin is truer or sadder. These
entlemen ride onto the bride alone and wave white handkerchiefs; they

neotiate with Prince Auersper. He lets them enter the tte-de-pont. *
They spin him a thousand asconades, sayin that the war is over, that

rascality...."


* Bridehead.

* (2) That their fire ets into his eyes and he forets that he ouht to
be firin at the enemy.

"It may be treachery," said Prince Andrew, vividly imainin the ray
overcoats, wounds, the smoke of unpowder, the sounds of firin, and the

"Not that either. That puts the court in too bad a liht," replied

produced a ood epiram, a fresh one that would be repeated. His
hitherto puckered brow became smooth as a sin of pleasure, and with a
sliht smile he bean to examine his nails.

"Where are you off to?" he said suddenly to Prince Andrew who had risen
and was oin toward his room.

"I am oin away."

"Where to?"

"To the army."

"But you meant to stay another two days?"

"But now I am off at once."

And Prince Andrew after ivin directions about his departure went to
his room.

"Do you know, mon cher," said Bilibin followin him, "I have been
thinkin about you. Why are you oin?"

And in proof of the conclusiveness of his opinion all the wrinkles
vanished from his face.

Prince Andrew looked inquirinly at him and ave no reply.

"Why are you oin? I know you think it your duty to allop back to the
army now that it is in daner. I understand that. Mon cher, it is
heroism!"

"Not at all," said Prince Andrew.

"But as you are a philosopher, be a consistent one, look at the other
side of the question and you will see that your duty, on the contrary,
is to take care of yourself. Leave it to those who are no loner fit for
anythin else.... You have not been ordered to return and have not been
dismissed from here; therefore, you can stay and o with us wherever our
ill luck takes us. They say we are oin to Olmutz, and Olmutz is a very
decent town. You and I will travel comfortably in my caleche."

"Do stop jokin, Bilibin," cried Bolkonski.

"I am speakin sincerely as a friend! Consider! Where and why are you
oin, when you miht remain here? You are faced by one of two thins,"
and the skin over his left temple puckered, "either you will not reach
your reiment before peace is concluded, or you will share defeat and
disrace with Kutuzov's whole army."

And Bilibin unwrinkled his temple, feelin that the dilemma was
insoluble.

"I cannot arue about it," replied Prince Andrew coldly, but he thouht:
"I am oin to save the army."

"My dear fellow, you are a hero!" said Bilibin.




CHAPTER XIII

That same niht, havin taken leave of the Minister of War, Bolkonski
set off to rejoin the army, not knowin where he would find it and
fearin to be captured by the French on the way to Krems.

In Brunn everybody attached to the court was packin up, and the heavy
baae was already bein dispatched to Olmutz. Near Hetzelsdorf Prince
Andrew struck the hih road alon which the Russian army was movin with
reat haste and in the reatest disorder. The road was so obstructed
with carts that it was impossible to et by in a carriae. Prince Andrew
took a horse and a Cossack from a Cossack commander, and hunry and
weary, makin his way past the baae waons, rode in search of the
commander-in-chief and of his own luae. Very sinister reports of the
position of the army reached him as he went alon, and the appearance of
the troops in their disorderly fliht confirmed these rumors.

"Cette armee russe que l'or de l'Anleterre a transportee des extremites
de l'univers, nous allons lui faire eprouver le meme sort--(le sort de
l'armee d'Ulm)." * He remembered these words in Bonaparte's address to
his army at the beinnin of the campain, and they awoke in him
astonishment at the enius of his hero, a feelin of wounded pride, and
a hope of lory. "And should there be nothin left but to die?" he
thouht. "Well, if need be, I shall do it no worse than others."


* "That Russian army which has been brouht from the ends of the earth
by Enlish old, we shall cause to share the same fate--(the fate of the
army at Ulm)."

He looked with disdain at the endless confused mass of detachments,
carts, uns, artillery, and aain baae waons and vehicles of all
kinds overtakin one another and blockin the muddy road, three and
sometimes four abreast. From all sides, behind and before, as far as ear
could reach, there were the rattle of wheels, the creakin of carts and
un carriaes, the tramp of horses, the crack of whips, shouts, the
urin of horses, and the swearin of soldiers, orderlies, and officers.
All alon the sides of the road fallen horses were to be seen, some
flayed, some not, and broken-down carts beside which solitary soldiers
sat waitin for somethin, and aain soldiers stralin from their
companies, crowds of whom set off to the neihborin villaes, or
returned from them drain sheep, fowls, hay, and bulin sacks. At
each ascent or descent of the road the crowds were yet denser and the
din of shoutin more incessant. Soldiers flounderin knee-deep in mud
pushed the uns and waons themselves. Whips cracked, hoofs slipped,
traces broke, and luns were strained with shoutin. The officers
directin the march rode backward and forward between the carts. Their
voices were but feebly heard amid the uproar and one saw by their faces
that they despaired of the possibility of checkin this disorder.

"Here is our dear Orthodox Russian army," thouht Bolkonski, recallin
Bilibin's words.

Wishin to find out where the commander-in-chief was, he rode up to a
convoy. Directly opposite to him came a strane one-horse vehicle,
evidently ried up by soldiers out of any available materials and
lookin like somethin between a cart, a cabriolet, and a caleche. A
soldier was drivin, and a woman enveloped in shawls sat behind the
apron under the leather hood of the vehicle. Prince Andrew rode up and
was just puttin his question to a soldier when his attention was
diverted by the desperate shrieks of the woman in the vehicle. An
officer in chare of transport was beatin the soldier who was drivin
the woman's vehicle for tryin to et ahead of others, and the strokes
of his whip fell on the apron of the equipae. The woman screamed
piercinly. Seein Prince Andrew she leaned out from behind the apron
and, wavin her thin arms from under the woolen shawl, cried:

"Mr. Aide-de-camp! Mr. Aide-de-camp!... For heaven's sake... Protect me!
What will become of us? I am the wife of the doctor of the Seventh
Chasseurs.... They won't let us pass, we are left behind and have lost
our people..."

"I'll flatten you into a pancake!" shouted the anry officer to the
soldier. "Turn back with your slut!"

"Mr. Aide-de-camp! Help me!... What does it all mean?" screamed the
doctor's wife.

"Kindly let this cart pass. Don't you see it's a woman?" said Prince
Andrew ridin up to the officer.

The officer lanced at him, and without replyin turned aain to the
soldier. "I'll teach you to push on!... Back!"

"Let them pass, I tell you!" repeated Prince Andrew, compressin his
lips.

"And who are you?" cried the officer, turnin on him with tipsy rae,
"who are you? Are you in command here? Eh? I am commander here, not you!
o back or I'll flatten you into a pancake," repeated he. This
expression evidently pleased him.

"That was a nice snub for the little aide-de-camp," came a voice from
behind.

Prince Andrew saw that the officer was in that state of senseless, tipsy
rae when a man does not know what he is sayin. He saw that his
championship of the doctor's wife in her queer trap miht expose him to
what he dreaded more than anythin in the world--to ridicule; but his
instinct ured him on. Before the officer finished his sentence Prince
Andrew, his face distorted with fury, rode up to him and raised his
ridin whip.

"Kind...ly let--them--pass!"

The officer flourished his arm and hastily rode away.

"It's all the fault of these fellows on the staff that there's this
disorder," he muttered. "Do as you like."

Prince Andrew without liftin his eyes rode hastily away from the
doctor's wife, who was callin him her deliverer, and recallin with a
sense of disust the minutest details of this humiliatin scene he
alloped on to the villae where he was told that the commander-in-chief
was.

On reachin the villae he dismounted and went to the nearest house,
intendin to rest if but for a moment, eat somethin, and try to sort
out the stinin and tormentin thouhts that confused his mind. "This
is a mob of scoundrels and not an army," he was thinkin as he went up
to the window of the first house, when a familiar voice called him by
name.

He turned round. Nesvitski's handsome face looked out of the little
window. Nesvitski, movin his moist lips as he chewed somethin, and
flourishin his arm, called him to enter.

"Bolkonski! Bolkonski!... Don't you hear? Eh? Come quick..." he shouted.

Enterin the house, Prince Andrew saw Nesvitski and another adjutant
havin somethin to eat. They hastily turned round to him askin if he
had any news. On their familiar faces he read aitation and alarm. This
was particularly noticeable on Nesvitski's usually lauhin countenance.

"Where is the commander-in-chief?" asked Bolkonski.

"Here, in that house," answered the adjutant.

"Well, is it true that it's peace and capitulation?" asked Nesvitski.

"I was oin to ask you. I know nothin except that it was all I could
do to et here."

"And we, my dear boy! It's terrible! I was wron to lauh at Mack, we're
ettin it still worse," said Nesvitski. "But sit down and have
somethin to eat."

"You won't be able to find either your baae or anythin else now,
Prince. And od only knows where your man Peter is," said the other
adjutant.

"Where are headquarters?"

"We are to spend the niht in Znaim."

"Well, I have ot all I need into packs for two horses," said Nesvitski.
"They've made up splendid packs for me--fit to cross the Bohemian
mountains with. It's a bad lookout, old fellow! But what's the matter
with you? You must be ill to shiver like that," he added, noticin that
Prince Andrew winced as at an electric shock.

"It's nothin," replied Prince Andrew.

He had just remembered his recent encounter with the doctor's wife and
the convoy officer.

"What is the commander-in-chief doin here?" he asked.

"I can't make out at all," said Nesvitski.

"Well, all I can make out is that everythin is abominable, abominable,
quite abominable!" said Prince Andrew, and he went off to the house
where the commander-in-chief was.

Passin by Kutuzov's carriae and the exhausted saddle horses of his
suite, with their Cossacks who were talkin loudly toether, Prince
Andrew entered the passae. Kutuzov himself, he was told, was in the
house with Prince Baration and Weyrother. Weyrother was the Austrian
eneral who had succeeded Schmidt. In the passae little Kozlovski was
squattin on his heels in front of a clerk. The clerk, with cuffs turned
up, was hastily writin at a tub turned bottom upwards. Kozlovski's face
looked worn--he too had evidently not slept all niht. He lanced at
Prince Andrew and did not even nod to him.

"Second line... have you written it?" he continued dictatin to the
clerk. "The Kiev renadiers, Podolian..."

"One can't write so fast, your honor," said the clerk, lancin anrily
and disrespectfully at Kozlovski.

Throuh the door came the sounds of Kutuzov's voice, excited and
dissatisfied, interrupted by another, an unfamiliar voice. From the
sound of these voices, the inattentive way Kozlovski looked at him, the
disrespectful manner of the exhausted clerk, the fact that the clerk and
Kozlovski were squattin on the floor by a tub so near to the commander
in chief, and from the noisy lauhter of the Cossacks holdin the horses
near the window, Prince Andrew felt that somethin important and
disastrous was about to happen.

He turned to Kozlovski with urent questions.

"Immediately, Prince," said Kozlovski. "Dispositions for Baration."

"What about capitulation?"

"Nothin of the sort. Orders are issued for a battle."

Prince Andrew moved toward the door from whence voices were heard. Just
as he was oin to open it the sounds ceased, the door opened, and
Kutuzov with his eale nose and puffy face appeared in the doorway.
Prince Andrew stood riht in front of Kutuzov but the expression of the
commander in chief's one sound eye showed him to be so preoccupied with
thouhts and anxieties as to be oblivious of his presence. He looked
straiht at his adjutant's face without reconizin him.

"Well, have you finished?" said he to Kozlovski.

"One moment, your excellency."

Baration, a aunt middle-aed man of medium heiht with a firm,
impassive face of Oriental type, came out after the commander-in-chief.

"I have the honor to present myself," repeated Prince Andrew rather
loudly, handin Kutuzov an envelope.

"Ah, from Vienna? Very ood. Later, later!"

Kutuzov went out into the porch with Baration.

"Well, ood-by, Prince," said he to Baration. "My blessin, and may
Christ be with you in your reat endeavor!"

His face suddenly softened and tears came into his eyes. With his left
hand he drew Baration toward him, and with his riht, on which he wore
a rin, he made the sin of the cross over him with a esture evidently
habitual, offerin his puffy cheek, but Baration kissed him on the neck
instead.

"Christ be with you!" Kutuzov repeated and went toward his carriae.
"et in with me," said he to Bolkonski.

"Your excellency, I should like to be of use here. Allow me to remain
with Prince Baration's detachment."

"et in," said Kutuzov, and noticin that Bolkonski still delayed, he
added: "I need ood officers myself, need them myself!"

They ot into the carriae and drove for a few minutes in silence.

"There is still much, much before us," he said, as if with an old man's
penetration he understood all that was passin in Bolkonski's mind. "If
a tenth part of his detachment returns I shall thank od," he added as
if speakin to himself.

Prince Andrew lanced at Kutuzov's face only a foot distant from him and
involuntarily noticed the carefully washed seams of the scar near his
temple, where an Ismail bullet had pierced his skull, and the empty eye
socket. "Yes, he has a riht to speak so calmly of those men's death,"
thouht Bolkonski.

"That is why I be to be sent to that detachment," he said.

Kutuzov did not reply. He seemed to have forotten what he had been
sayin, and sat pluned in thouht. Five minutes later, ently swayin
on the soft sprins of the carriae, he turned to Prince Andrew. There
was not a trace of aitation on his face. With delicate irony he
questioned Prince Andrew about the details of his interview with the
Emperor, about the remarks he had heard at court concernin the Krems
affair, and about some ladies they both knew.




CHAPTER XIV

On November 1 Kutuzov had received, throuh a spy, news that the army he
commanded was in an almost hopeless position. The spy reported that the
French, after crossin the bride at Vienna, were advancin in immense
force upon Kutuzov's line of communication with the troops that were
arrivin from Russia. If Kutuzov decided to remain at Krems, Napoleon's
army of one hundred and fifty thousand men would cut him off completely
and surround his exhausted army of forty thousand, and he would find
himself in the position of Mack at Ulm. If Kutuzov decided to abandon
the road connectin him with the troops arrivin from Russia, he would
have to march with no road into unknown parts of the Bohemian mountains,
defendin himself aainst superior forces of the enemy and abandonin
all hope of a junction with Buxhowden. If Kutuzov decided to retreat
alon the road from Krems to Olmutz, to unite with the troops arrivin
from Russia, he risked bein forestalled on that road by the French who
had crossed the Vienna bride, and encumbered by his baae and
transport, havin to accept battle on the march aainst an enemy three
times as stron, who would hem him in from two sides.

Kutuzov chose this latter course.

The French, the spy reported, havin crossed the Vienna bride, were
advancin by forced marches toward Znaim, which lay sixty-six miles off
on the line of Kutuzov's retreat. If he reached Znaim before the French,
there would be reat hope of savin the army; to let the French
forestall him at Znaim meant the exposure of his whole army to a
disrace such as that of Ulm, or to utter destruction. But to forestall
the French with his whole army was impossible. The road for the French
from Vienna to Znaim was shorter and better than the road for the
Russians from Krems to Znaim.

The niht he received the news, Kutuzov sent Baration's vanuard, four
thousand stron, to the riht across the hills from the Krems-Znaim to
the Vienna-Znaim road. Baration was to make this march without restin,
and to halt facin Vienna with Znaim to his rear, and if he succeeded in
forestallin the French he was to delay them as lon as possible.
Kutuzov himself with all his transport took the road to Znaim.

Marchin thirty miles that stormy niht across roadless hills, with his
hunry, ill-shod soldiers, and losin a third of his men as stralers
by the way, Baration came out on the Vienna-Znaim road at Hollabrunn a
few hours ahead of the French who were approachin Hollabrunn from
Vienna. Kutuzov with his transport had still to march for some days
before he could reach Znaim. Hence Baration with his four thousand
hunry, exhausted men would have to detain for days the whole enemy army
that came upon him at Hollabrunn, which was clearly impossible. But a
freak of fate made the impossible possible. The success of the trick
that had placed the Vienna bride in the hands of the French without a
fiht led Murat to try to deceive Kutuzov in a similar way. Meetin
Baration's weak detachment on the Znaim road he supposed it to be
Kutuzov's whole army. To be able to crush it absolutely he awaited the
arrival of the rest of the troops who were on their way from Vienna, and
with this object offered a three days' truce on condition that both
armies should remain in position without movin. Murat declared that
neotiations for peace were already proceedin, and that he therefore
offered this truce to avoid unnecessary bloodshed. Count Nostitz, the
Austrian eneral occupyin the advanced posts, believed Murat's emissary
and retired, leavin Baration's division exposed. Another emissary rode
to the Russian line to announce the peace neotiations and to offer the
Russian army the three days' truce. Baration replied that he was not
authorized either to accept or refuse a truce and sent his adjutant to
Kutuzov to report the offer he had received.

A truce was Kutuzov's sole chance of ainin time, ivin Baration's
exhausted troops some rest, and lettin the transport and heavy convoys
(whose movements were concealed from the French) advance if but one
stae nearer Znaim. The offer of a truce ave the only, and a quite
unexpected, chance of savin the army. On receivin the news he
immediately dispatched Adjutant eneral Wintzinerode, who was in
attendance on him, to the enemy camp. Wintzinerode was not merely to
aree to the truce but also to offer terms of capitulation, and
meanwhile Kutuzov sent his adjutants back to hasten to the utmost the
movements of the baae trains of the entire army alon the Krems-Znaim
road. Baration's exhausted and hunry detachment, which alone covered
this movement of the transport and of the whole army, had to remain
stationary in face of an enemy eiht times as stron as itself.

Kutuzov's expectations that the proposals of capitulation (which were in
no way bindin) miht ive time for part of the transport to pass, and
also that Murat's mistake would very soon be discovered, proved correct.
As soon as Bonaparte (who was at Schonbrunn, sixteen miles from
Hollabrunn) received Murat's dispatch with the proposal of a truce and a
capitulation, he detected a ruse and wrote the followin letter to
Murat:

Schonbrunn, 25th Brumaire, 1805,

at eiht o'clock in the mornin

To PRINCE MURAT,

I cannot find words to express to you my displeasure. You command only
my advance uard, and have no riht to arrane an armistice without my
order. You are causin me to lose the fruits of a campain. Break the
armistice immediately and march on the enemy. Inform him that the
eneral who sined that capitulation had no riht to do so, and that no
one but the Emperor of Russia has that riht.

If, however, the Emperor of Russia ratifies that convention, I will
ratify it; but it is only a trick. March on, destroy the Russian
army.... You are in a position to seize its baae and artillery.

The Russian Emperor's aide-de-camp is an impostor. Officers are nothin
when they have no powers; this one had none.... The Austrians let
themselves be tricked at the crossin of the Vienna bride, you are
lettin yourself be tricked by an aide-de-camp of the Emperor.

NAPOLEON

Bonaparte's adjutant rode full allop with this menacin letter to
Murat. Bonaparte himself, not trustin to his enerals, moved with all
the uards to the field of battle, afraid of lettin a ready victim
escape, and Baration's four thousand men merrily lihted campfires,
dried and warmed themselves, cooked their porride for the first time
for three days, and not one of them knew or imained what was in store
for him.




CHAPTER XV

Between three and four o'clock in the afternoon Prince Andrew, who had
persisted in his request to Kutuzov, arrived at runth and reported
himself to Baration. Bonaparte's adjutant had not yet reached Murat's
detachment and the battle had not yet beun. In Baration's detachment
no one knew anythin of the eneral position of affairs. They talked of
peace but did not believe in its possibility; others talked of a battle
but also disbelieved in the nearness of an enaement. Baration,
knowin Bolkonski to be a favorite and trusted adjutant, received him
with distinction and special marks of favor, explainin to him that
there would probably be an enaement that day or the next, and ivin
him full liberty to remain with him durin the battle or to join the
rearuard and have an eye on the order of retreat, "which is also very
important."

"However, there will hardly be an enaement today," said Baration as
if to reassure Prince Andrew.

"If he is one of the ordinary little staff dandies sent to earn a medal
he can et his reward just as well in the rearuard, but if he wishes to
stay with me, let him... he'll be of use here if he's a brave officer,"
thouht Baration. Prince Andrew, without replyin, asked the prince's
permission to ride round the position to see the disposition of the
forces, so as to know his bearins should he be sent to execute an
order. The officer on duty, a handsome, eleantly dressed man with a
diamond rin on his forefiner, who was fond of speakin French thouh
he spoke it badly, offered to conduct Prince Andrew.

On all sides they saw rain-soaked officers with dejected faces who
seemed to be seekin somethin, and soldiers drain doors, benches,
and fencin from the villae.

"There now, Prince! We can't stop those fellows," said the staff officer
pointin to the soldiers. "The officers don't keep them in hand. And
there," he pointed to a sutler's tent, "they crowd in and sit. This
mornin I turned them all out and now look, it's full aain. I must o
there, Prince, and scare them a bit. It won't take a moment."

"Yes, let's o in and I will et myself a roll and some cheese," said
Prince Andrew who had not yet had time to eat anythin.

"Why didn't you mention it, Prince? I would have offered you somethin."

They dismounted and entered the tent. Several officers, with flushed and
weary faces, were sittin at the table eatin and drinkin.

"Now what does this mean, entlemen?" said the staff officer, in the
reproachful tone of a man who has repeated the same thin more than
once. "You know it won't do to leave your posts like this. The prince
ave orders that no one should leave his post. Now you, Captain," and he
turned to a thin, dirty little artillery officer who without his boots
(he had iven them to the canteen keeper to dry), in only his stockins,
rose when they entered, smilin not altoether comfortably.

"Well, aren't you ashamed of yourself, Captain Tushin?" he continued.
"One would think that as an artillery officer you would set a ood
example, yet here you are without your boots! The alarm will be sounded
and you'll be in a pretty position without your boots!" (The staff
officer smiled.) "Kindly return to your posts, entlemen, all of you,
all!" he added in a tone of command.

Prince Andrew smiled involuntarily as he looked at the artillery officer
Tushin, who silent and smilin, shiftin from one stockined foot to the
other, lanced inquirinly with his lare, intellient, kindly eyes from
Prince Andrew to the staff officer.

"The soldiers say it feels easier without boots," said Captain Tushin
smilin shyly in his uncomfortable position, evidently wishin to adopt
a jocular tone. But before he had finished he felt that his jest was
unacceptable and had not come off. He rew confused.

"Kindly return to your posts," said the staff officer tryin to preserve
his ravity.

Prince Andrew lanced aain at the artillery officer's small fiure.
There was somethin peculiar about it, quite unsoldierly, rather comic,
but extremely attractive.

The staff officer and Prince Andrew mounted their horses and rode on.

Havin ridden beyond the villae, continually meetin and overtakin
soldiers and officers of various reiments, they saw on their left some
entrenchments bein thrown up, the freshly du clay of which showed up
red. Several battalions of soldiers, in their shirt sleeves despite the
cold wind, swarmed in these earthworks like a host of white ants;
spadefuls of red clay were continually bein thrown up from behind the
bank by unseen hands. Prince Andrew and the officer rode up, looked at
the entrenchment, and went on aain. Just behind it they came upon some
dozens of soldiers, continually replaced by others, who ran from the
entrenchment. They had to hold their noses and put their horses to a
trot to escape from the poisoned atmosphere of these latrines.

"Voila l'arement des camps, monsieur le Prince," * said the staff
officer.


* "This is a pleasure one ets in camp, Prince."

They rode up the opposite hill. From there the French could already be
seen. Prince Andrew stopped and bean examinin the position.

"That's our battery," said the staff officer indicatin the hihest
point. "It's in chare of the queer fellow we saw without his boots. You
can see everythin from there; let's o there, Prince."

"Thank you very much, I will o on alone," said Prince Andrew, wishin
to rid himself of this staff officer's company, "please don't trouble
yourself further."

The staff officer remained behind and Prince Andrew rode on alone.

The farther forward and nearer the enemy he went, the more orderly and
cheerful were the troops. The reatest disorder and depression had been
in the baae train he had passed that mornin on the Znaim road seven
miles away from the French. At runth also some apprehension and alarm
could be felt, but the nearer Prince Andrew came to the French lines the
more confident was the appearance of our troops. The soldiers in their
reatcoats were raned in lines, the sereants major and company
officers were countin the men, pokin the last man in each section in
the ribs and tellin him to hold his hand up. Soldiers scattered over
the whole place were drain los and brushwood and were buildin
shelters with merry chatter and lauhter; around the fires sat others,
dressed and undressed, dryin their shirts and le bands or mendin
boots or overcoats and crowdin round the boilers and porride cookers.
In one company dinner was ready, and the soldiers were azin eaerly at
the steamin boiler, waitin till the sample, which a quartermaster
sereant was carryin in a wooden bowl to an officer who sat on a lo
before his shelter, had been tasted.

Another company, a lucky one for not all the companies had vodka,
crowded round a pockmarked, broad-shouldered sereant major who, tiltin
a ke, filled one after another the canteen lids held out to him. The
soldiers lifted the canteen lids to their lips with reverential faces,
emptied them, rollin the vodka in their mouths, and walked away from
the sereant major with brihtened expressions, lickin their lips and
wipin them on the sleeves of their reatcoats. All their faces were as
serene as if all this were happenin at home awaitin peaceful
encampment, and not within siht of the enemy before an action in which
at least half of them would be left on the field. After passin a
chasseur reiment and in the lines of the Kiev renadiers--fine fellows
busy with similar peaceful affairs--near the shelter of the reimental
commander, hiher than and different from the others, Prince Andrew came
out in front of a platoon of renadiers before whom lay a naked man. Two
soldiers held him while two others were flourishin their switches and
strikin him reularly on his bare back. The man shrieked unnaturally. A
stout major was pacin up and down the line, and reardless of the
screams kept repeatin:

"It's a shame for a soldier to steal; a soldier must be honest,
honorable, and brave, but if he robs his fellows there is no honor in
him, he's a scoundrel. o on! o on!"

So the swishin sound of the strokes, and the desperate but unnatural
screams, continued.

"o on, o on!" said the major.

A youn officer with a bewildered and pained expression on his face
stepped away from the man and looked round inquirinly at the adjutant
as he rode by.

Prince Andrew, havin reached the front line, rode alon it. Our front
line and that of the enemy were far apart on the riht and left flanks,
but in the center where the men with a fla of truce had passed that
mornin, the lines were so near toether that the men could see one
another's faces and speak to one another. Besides the soldiers who
formed the picket line on either side, there were many curious onlookers
who, jestin and lauhin, stared at their strane forein enemies.

Since early mornin--despite an injunction not to approach the picket
line--the officers had been unable to keep siht-seers away. The
soldiers formin the picket line, like showmen exhibitin a curiosity,
no loner looked at the French but paid attention to the siht-seers and
rew weary waitin to be relieved. Prince Andrew halted to have a look
at the French.

"Look! Look there!" one soldier was sayin to another, pointin to a
Russian musketeer who had one up to the picket line with an officer and
was rapidly and excitedly talkin to a French renadier. "Hark to him
jabberin! Fine, isn't it? It's all the Frenchy can do to keep up with
him. There now, Sidorov!"

"Wait a bit and listen. It's fine!" answered Sidorov, who was considered
an adept at French.

The soldier to whom the lauhers referred was Dolokhov. Prince Andrew
reconized him and stopped to listen to what he was sayin. Dolokhov had
come from the left flank where their reiment was stationed, with his
captain.

"Now then, o on, o on!" incited the officer, bendin forward and
tryin not to lose a word of the speech which was incomprehensible to
him. "More, please: more! What's he sayin?"

Dolokhov did not answer the captain; he had been drawn into a hot
dispute with the French renadier. They were naturally talkin about the
campain. The Frenchman, confusin the Austrians with the Russians, was
tryin to prove that the Russians had surrendered and had fled all the
way from Ulm, while Dolokhov maintained that the Russians had not
surrendered but had beaten the French.

"We have orders to drive you off here, and we shall drive you off," said
Dolokhov.

"Only take care you and your Cossacks are not all captured!" said the
French renadier.

The French onlookers and listeners lauhed.

"We'll make you dance as we did under Suvorov...," * said Dolokhov.


* "On vous fera danser."

"Qu' est-ce qu'il chante?" * asked a Frenchman.


* "What's he sinin about?"

"It's ancient history," said another, uessin that it referred to a
former war. "The Emperor will teach your Suvara as he has tauht the
others..."

"Bonaparte..." bean Dolokhov, but the Frenchman interrupted him.

"Not Bonaparte. He is the Emperor! Sacre nom...!" cried he anrily.

"The devil skin your Emperor."

And Dolokhov swore at him in coarse soldier's Russian and shoulderin
his musket walked away.

"Let us o, Ivan Lukich," he said to the captain.

"Ah, that's the way to talk French," said the picket soldiers. "Now,
Sidorov, you have a try!"

Sidorov, turnin to the French, winked, and bean to jabber meaninless
sounds very fast: "Kari, mala, tafa, safi, muter, Kaska," he said,
tryin to ive an expressive intonation to his voice.

"Ho! ho! ho! Ha! ha! ha! ha! Ouh! ouh!" came peals of such healthy and
ood-humored lauhter from the soldiers that it infected the French
involuntarily, so much so that the only thin left to do seemed to be to
unload the muskets, explode the ammunition, and all return home as
quickly as possible.

But the uns remained loaded, the loopholes in blockhouses and
entrenchments looked out just as menacinly, and the unlimbered cannon
confronted one another as before.




CHAPTER XVI

Havin ridden round the whole line from riht flank to left, Prince
Andrew made his way up to the battery from which the staff officer had
told him the whole field could be seen. Here he dismounted, and stopped
beside the farthest of the four unlimbered cannon. Before the uns an
artillery sentry was pacin up and down; he stood at attention when the
officer arrived, but at a sin resumed his measured, monotonous pacin.
Behind the uns were their limbers and still farther back picket ropes
and artillerymen's bonfires. To the left, not far from the farthest
cannon, was a small, newly constructed wattle shed from which came the

It was true that a view over nearly the whole Russian position and the
reater part of the enemy's opened out from this battery. Just facin

amid the smoke of their campfires, the reater part of whom were

Our infantry were stationed there, and at the farthest point the

On the left our troops were close to a copse, in which smoked the
bonfires of our infantry who were fellin wood. The French line was
wider than ours, and it was plain that they could easily outflank us on
both sides. Behind our position was a steep and deep dip, makin it

position. He made some notes on two points, intendin to mention them to

center, and secondly, to withdraw the cavalry to the other side of the

the draoons could successfully make a flank counterattack. If they

shall withdraw the left flank under its cover, and retreat to the dip by
echelons." So he reasoned.... All the time he had been beside the un,
he had heard the voices of the officers distinctly, but as often happens
had not understood a word of what they were sayin. Suddenly, however,
he was struck by a voice comin from the shed, and its tone was so
sincere that he could not but listen.

"No, friend," said a pleasant and, as it seemed to Prince Andrew, a
familiar voice, "what I say is that if it were possible to know what is
beyond death, none of us would be afraid of it. That's so, friend."

Another, a youner voice, interrupted him: "Afraid or not, you can't
escape it anyhow."

"All the same, one is afraid! Oh, you clever people," said a third manly
voice interruptin them both. "Of course you artillery men are very
wise, because you can take everythin alon with you--vodka and snacks."

And the owner of the manly voice, evidently an infantry officer,
lauhed.

"Yes, one is afraid," continued the first speaker, he of the familiar
voice. "One is afraid of the unknown, that's what it is. Whatever we may
say about the soul oin to the sky... we know there is no sky but only
an atmosphere."

The manly voice aain interrupted the artillery officer.

"Well, stand us some of your herb vodka, Tushin," it said.

"Why," thouht Prince Andrew, "that's the captain who stood up in the
sutler's hut without his boots." He reconized the areeable,
philosophizin voice with pleasure.

"Some herb vodka? Certainly!" said Tushin. "But still, to conceive a
future life..."

He did not finish. Just then there was a whistle in the air; nearer and
nearer, faster and louder, louder and faster, a cannon ball, as if it
had not finished sayin what was necessary, thudded into the round near
the shed with super human force, throwin up a mass of earth. The round
seemed to roan at the terrible impact.

And immediately Tushin, with a short pipe in the corner of his mouth and
his kind, intellient face rather pale, rushed out of the shed followed
by the owner of the manly voice, a dashin infantry officer who hurried
off to his company, buttonin up his coat as he ran.




CHAPTER XVII

Mountin his horse aain Prince Andrew linered with the battery,

probably to strenthen the front line. The smoke of the first shot had

The battle had beun! Prince Andrew turned his horse and alloped back

From the bottom of the slope, where the parleys had taken place, came

Lemarrois had just arrived at a allop with Bonaparte's stern letter,

By this time they were all approachin Tushin's battery, and a ball
struck the round in front of them.

"What's that that has fallen?" asked the accountant with a naive smile.

"A French pancake," answered Zherkov.

"So that's what they hit with?" asked the accountant. "How awful!"

He seemed to swell with satisfaction. He had hardly finished speakin

"Whose company?" asked Prince Baration of an artilleryman standin by

He asked, "Whose company?" but he really meant, "Are you frihtened
here?" and the artilleryman understood him.

"Captain Tushin's, your excellency!" shouted the red-haired, freckled

"Yes, yes," muttered Baration as if considerin somethin, and he rode

As he approached, a rinin shot issued from it deafenin him and his

No one had iven Tushin orders where and at what to fire, but after

"Very ood!" said Baration.

As he was leavin the battery, firin was heard on the left also, and as

Officers who approached him with disturbed countenances became calm;

CHAPTER XVIII

Prince Baration, havin reached the hihest point of our riht flank,
bean ridin downhill to where the roll of musketry was heard but where
on account of the smoke nothin could be seen. The nearer they ot to
the hollow the less they could see but the more they felt the nearness

bleedin head and no cap was bein draed alon by two soldiers who
supported him under the arms. There was a urle in his throat and he

Crossin a road they descended a steep incline and saw several men lyin

The commander of the reiment, a thin, feeble-lookin old man with a

The commander of the reiment turned to Prince Baration, entreatin him

"They march splendidly," remarked someone in Baration's suite.

The head of the column had already descended into the hollow. The clash
would take place on this side of it...

The remains of our reiment which had been in action rapidly formed up

With the self-satisfaction of a man on parade, he stepped lihtly with

"Well done, lads!" said Prince Baration.

"lad to do our best, your ex'len-lency!" came a confused shout from the
ranks. A morose soldier marchin on the left turned his eyes on

The order was iven to halt and down knapsacks.

Baration rode round the ranks that had marched past him and dismounted.
He ave the reins to a Cossack, took off and handed over his felt coat,
stretched his les, and set his cap straiht. The head of the French

"Forward, with od!" said Baration, in a resolute, sonorous voice,

The French were already near. Prince Andrew, walkin beside Baration,
could clearly distinuish their bandoliers, red epaulets, and even their

ranks. Suddenly one shot after another ran out from the French, smoke
