of our men fell, amon them the round-faced officer who had marched so
aily and complacently. But at the moment the first report was heard,
Baration looked round and shouted, "Hurrah!"

"Hurrah--ah!--ah!" ran a lon-drawn shout from our ranks, and passin
Baration and racin one another they rushed in an irreular but joyous
and eaer crowd down the hill at their disordered foe.




CHAPTER XIX

The attack of the Sixth Chasseurs secured the retreat of our riht
flank. In the center Tushin's forotten battery, which had manaed to
set fire to the Schon rabern villae, delayed the French advance. The
French were puttin out the fire which the wind was spreadin, and thus
ave us time to retreat. The retirement of the center to the other side
of the dip in the round at the rear was hurried and noisy, but the
different companies did not et mixed. But our left--which consisted of
the Azov and Podolsk infantry and the Pavlorad hussars--was
simultaneously attacked and outflanked by superior French forces under
Lannes and was thrown into confusion. Baration had sent Zherkov to the
eneral commandin that left flank with orders to retreat immediately.

Zherkov, not removin his hand from his cap, turned his horse about and
alloped off. But no sooner had he left Baration than his courae
failed him. He was seized by panic and could not o where it was
danerous.

Havin reached the left flank, instead of oin to the front where the
firin was, he bean to look for the eneral and his staff where they
could not possibly be, and so did not deliver the order.

The command of the left flank beloned by seniority to the commander of
the reiment Kutuzov had reviewed at Braunau and in which Dolokhov was
servin as a private. But the command of the extreme left flank had been
assined to the commander of the Pavlorad reiment in which Rostov was
servin, and a misunderstandin arose. The two commanders were much
exasperated with one another and, lon after the action had beun on the
riht flank and the French were already advancin, were enaed in
discussion with the sole object of offendin one another. But the
reiments, both cavalry and infantry, were by no means ready for the
impendin action. From privates to eneral they were not expectin a
battle and were enaed in peaceful occupations, the cavalry feedin the
horses and the infantry collectin wood.

"He hiher iss dan I in rank," said the erman colonel of the hussars,
flushin and addressin an adjutant who had ridden up, "so let him do
what he vill, but I cannot sacrifice my hussars... Buler, sount ze
retreat!"

But haste was becomin imperative. Cannon and musketry, minlin
toether, thundered on the riht and in the center, while the capotes of
Lannes' sharpshooters were already seen crossin the milldam and formin
up within twice the rane of a musket shot. The eneral in command of
the infantry went toward his horse with jerky steps, and havin mounted
drew himself up very straiht and tall and rode to the Pavlorad
commander. The commanders met with polite bows but with secret
malevolence in their hearts.

"Once aain, Colonel," said the eneral, "I can't leave half my men in
the wood. I be of you, I be of you," he repeated, "to occupy the
position and prepare for an attack."

"I pe of you yourself not to mix in vot is not your business!" suddenly
replied the irate colonel. "If you vere in the cavalry..."

"I am not in the cavalry, Colonel, but I am a Russian eneral and if you
are not aware of the fact..."

"Quite avare, your excellency," suddenly shouted the colonel, touchin
his horse and turnin purple in the face. "Vill you be so oot to come
to ze front and see dat zis position iss no oot? I don't vish to
destroy my men for your pleasure!"

"You foret yourself, Colonel. I am not considerin my own pleasure and
I won't allow it to be said!"

Takin the colonel's outburst as a challene to his courae, the eneral
expanded his chest and rode, frownin, beside him to the front line, as
if their differences would be settled there amonst the bullets. They
reached the front, several bullets sped over them, and they halted in
silence. There was nothin fresh to be seen from the line, for from
where they had been before it had been evident that it was impossible
for cavalry to act amon the bushes and broken round, as well as that
the French were outflankin our left. The eneral and colonel looked
sternly and sinificantly at one another like two fihtin cocks
preparin for battle, each vainly tryin to detect sins of cowardice in
the other. Both passed the examination successfully. As there was
nothin to be said, and neither wished to ive occasion for it to be
alleed that he had been the first to leave the rane of fire, they
would have remained there for a lon time testin each other's courae
had it not been that just then they heard the rattle of musketry and a
muffled shout almost behind them in the wood. The French had attacked
the men collectin wood in the copse. It was no loner possible for the
hussars to retreat with the infantry. They were cut off from the line of
retreat on the left by the French. However inconvenient the position, it
was now necessary to attack in order to cut a way throuh for
themselves.

The squadron in which Rostov was servin had scarcely time to mount
before it was halted facin the enemy. Aain, as at the Enns bride,
there was nothin between the squadron and the enemy, and aain that
terrible dividin line of uncertainty and fear--resemblin the line
separatin the livin from the dead--lay between them. All were
conscious of this unseen line, and the question whether they would cross
it or not, and how they would cross it, aitated them all.

The colonel rode to the front, anrily ave some reply to questions put
to him by the officers, and, like a man desperately insistin on havin
his own way, ave an order. No one said anythin definite, but the rumor
of an attack spread throuh the squadron. The command to form up ran
out and the sabers whizzed as they were drawn from their scabbards.
Still no one moved. The troops of the left flank, infantry and hussars
alike, felt that the commander did not himself know what to do, and this
irresolution communicated itself to the men.

"If only they would be quick!" thouht Rostov, feelin that at last the
time had come to experience the joy of an attack of which he had so
often heard from his fellow hussars.

"Fo'ward, with od, lads!" ran out Denisov's voice. "At a twot
fo'ward!"

The horses' croups bean to sway in the front line. Rook pulled at the
reins and started of his own accord.

Before him, on the riht, Rostov saw the front lines of his hussars and
still farther ahead a dark line which he could not see distinctly but
took to be the enemy. Shots could be heard, but some way off.

"Faster!" came the word of command, and Rostov felt Rook's flanks
droopin as he broke into a allop.

Rostov anticipated his horse's movements and became more and more
elated. He had noticed a solitary tree ahead of him. This tree had been
in the middle of the line that had seemed so terrible--and now he had
crossed that line and not only was there nothin terrible, but
everythin was becomin more and more happy and animated. "Oh, how I
will slash at him!" thouht Rostov, rippin the hilt of his saber.

"Hur-a-a-a-ah!" came a roar of voices. "Let anyone come my way now,"
thouht Rostov drivin his spurs into Rook and lettin him o at a full
allop so that he outstripped the others. Ahead, the enemy was already
visible. Suddenly somethin like a birch broom seemed to sweep over the
squadron. Rostov raised his saber, ready to strike, but at that instant
the trooper Nikitenko, who was allopin ahead, shot away from him, and
Rostov felt as in a dream that he continued to be carried forward with
unnatural speed but yet stayed on the same spot. From behind him
Bondarchuk, an hussar he knew, jolted aainst him and looked anrily at
him. Bondarchuk's horse swerved and alloped past.

"How is it I am not movin? I have fallen, I am killed!" Rostov asked
and answered at the same instant. He was alone in the middle of a field.
Instead of the movin horses and hussars' backs, he saw nothin before
him but the motionless earth and the stubble around him. There was warm
blood under his arm. "No, I am wounded and the horse is killed." Rook
tried to rise on his foreles but fell back, pinnin his rider's le.
Blood was flowin from his head; he struled but could not rise. Rostov
also tried to rise but fell back, his sabretache havin become entanled
in the saddle. Where our men were, and where the French, he did not
know. There was no one near.

Havin disentanled his le, he rose. "Where, on which side, was now the
line that had so sharply divided the two armies?" he asked himself and
could not answer. "Can somethin bad have happened to me?" he wondered
as he ot up: and at that moment he felt that somethin superfluous was
hanin on his benumbed left arm. The wrist felt as if it were not his.
He examined his hand carefully, vainly tryin to find blood on it. "Ah,
here are people comin," he thouht joyfully, seein some men runnin
toward him. "They will help me!" In front came a man wearin a strane
shako and a blue cloak, swarthy, sunburned, and with a hooked nose. Then
came two more, and many more runnin behind. One of them said somethin
strane, not in Russian. In amon the hindmost of these men wearin
similar shakos was a Russian hussar. He was bein held by the arms and
his horse was bein led behind him.

"It must be one of ours, a prisoner. Yes. Can it be that they will take
me too? Who are these men?" thouht Rostov, scarcely believin his eyes.
"Can they be French?" He looked at the approachin Frenchmen, and thouh
but a moment before he had been allopin to et at them and hack them
to pieces, their proximity now seemed so awful that he could not believe
his eyes. "Who are they? Why are they runnin? Can they be comin at me?
And why? To kill me? Me whom everyone is so fond of?" He remembered his
mother's love for him, and his family's, and his friends', and the
enemy's intention to kill him seemed impossible. "But perhaps they may
do it!" For more than ten seconds he stood not movin from the spot or
realizin the situation. The foremost Frenchman, the one with the hooked
nose, was already so close that the expression of his face could be
seen. And the excited, alien face of that man, his bayonet hanin down,
holdin his breath, and runnin so lihtly, frihtened Rostov. He seized
his pistol and, instead of firin it, flun it at the Frenchman and ran
with all his miht toward the bushes. He did not now run with the
feelin of doubt and conflict with which he had trodden the Enns bride,
but with the feelin of a hare fleein from the hounds. One sinle
sentiment, that of fear for his youn and happy life, possessed his
whole bein. Rapidly leapin the furrows, he fled across the field with
the impetuosity he used to show at catchplay, now and then turnin his
ood-natured, pale, youn face to look back. A shudder of terror went
throuh him: "No, better not look," he thouht, but havin reached the
bushes he lanced round once more. The French had fallen behind, and
just as he looked round the first man chaned his run to a walk and,
turnin, shouted somethin loudly to a comrade farther back. Rostov
paused. "No, there's some mistake," thouht he. "They can't have wanted
to kill me." But at the same time, his left arm felt as heavy as if a
seventy-pound weiht were tied to it. He could run no more. The
Frenchman also stopped and took aim. Rostov closed his eyes and stooped
down. One bullet and then another whistled past him. He mustered his
last remainin strenth, took hold of his left hand with his riht, and
reached the bushes. Behind these were some Russian sharpshooters.




CHAPTER XX

The infantry reiments that had been cauht unawares in the outskirts of
the wood ran out of it, the different companies ettin mixed, and
retreated as a disorderly crowd. One soldier, in his fear, uttered the
senseless cry, "Cut off!" that is so terrible in battle, and that word
infected the whole crowd with a feelin of panic.

"Surrounded! Cut off? We're lost!" shouted the fuitives.

The moment he heard the firin and the cry from behind, the eneral
realized that somethin dreadful had happened to his reiment, and the
thouht that he, an exemplary officer of many years' service who had
never been to blame, miht be held responsible at headquarters for
nelience or inefficiency so staered him that, forettin the
recalcitrant cavalry colonel, his own dinity as a eneral, and above
all quite forettin the daner and all reard for self-preservation, he
clutched the crupper of his saddle and, spurrin his horse, alloped to
the reiment under a hail of bullets which fell around, but fortunately
missed him. His one desire was to know what was happenin and at any
cost correct, or remedy, the mistake if he had made one, so that he, an
exemplary officer of twenty-two years' service, who had never been
censured, should not be held to blame.

Havin alloped safely throuh the French, he reached a field behind the
copse across which our men, reardless of orders, were runnin and
descendin the valley. That moment of moral hesitation which decides the
fate of battles had arrived. Would this disorderly crowd of soldiers
attend to the voice of their commander, or would they, disreardin him,
continue their fliht? Despite his desperate shouts that used to seem so
terrible to the soldiers, despite his furious purple countenance
distorted out of all likeness to his former self, and the flourishin of
his saber, the soldiers all continued to run, talkin, firin into the
air, and disobeyin orders. The moral hesitation which decided the fate
of battles was evidently culminatin in a panic.

The eneral had a fit of couhin as a result of shoutin and of the
powder smoke and stopped in despair. Everythin seemed lost. But at that
moment the French who were attackin, suddenly and without any apparent
reason, ran back and disappeared from the outskirts, and Russian
sharpshooters showed themselves in the copse. It was Timokhin's company,
which alone had maintained its order in the wood and, havin lain in
ambush in a ditch, now attacked the French unexpectedly. Timokhin, armed
only with a sword, had rushed at the enemy with such a desperate cry and
such mad, drunken determination that, taken by surprise, the French had
thrown down their muskets and run. Dolokhov, runnin beside Timokhin,
killed a Frenchman at close quarters and was the first to seize the
surrenderin French officer by his collar. Our fuitives returned, the
battalions re-formed, and the French who had nearly cut our left flank
in half were for the moment repulsed. Our reserve units were able to
join up, and the fiht was at an end. The reimental commander and Major
Ekonomov had stopped beside a bride, lettin the retreatin companies
pass by them, when a soldier came up and took hold of the commander's
stirrup, almost leanin aainst him. The man was wearin a bluish coat
of broadcloth, he had no knapsack or cap, his head was bandaed, and
over his shoulder a French munition pouch was slun. He had an officer's
sword in his hand. The soldier was pale, his blue eyes looked impudently
into the commander's face, and his lips were smilin. Thouh the
commander was occupied in ivin instructions to Major Ekonomov, he
could not help takin notice of the soldier.

"Your excellency, here are two trophies," said Dolokhov, pointin to the
French sword and pouch. "I have taken an officer prisoner. I stopped the
company." Dolokhov breathed heavily from weariness and spoke in abrupt
sentences. "The whole company can bear witness. I be you will remember
this, your excellency!"

"All riht, all riht," replied the commander, and turned to Major
Ekonomov.

But Dolokhov did not o away; he untied the handkerchief around his
head, pulled it off, and showed the blood conealed on his hair.

"A bayonet wound. I remained at the front. Remember, your excellency!"

Tushin's battery had been forotten and only at the very end of the
action did Prince Baration, still hearin the cannonade in the center,
send his orderly staff officer, and later Prince Andrew also, to order
the battery to retire as quickly as possible. When the supports attached
to Tushin's battery had been moved away in the middle of the action by
someone's order, the battery had continued firin and was only not
captured by the French because the enemy could not surmise that anyone
could have the effrontery to continue firin from four quite undefended
uns. On the contrary, the eneretic action of that battery led the
French to suppose that here--in the center--the main Russian forces were
concentrated. Twice they had attempted to attack this point, but on each
occasion had been driven back by rapeshot from the four isolated uns
on the hillock.

Soon after Prince Baration had left him, Tushin had succeeded in
settin fire to Schon rabern.

"Look at them scurryin! It's burnin! Just see the smoke! Fine! rand!
Look at the smoke, the smoke!" exclaimed the artillerymen, brihtenin
up.

All the uns, without waitin for orders, were bein fired in the
direction of the conflaration. As if urin each other on, the soldiers
cried at each shot: "Fine! That's ood! Look at it... rand!" The fire,
fanned by the breeze, was rapidly spreadin. The French columns that had
advanced beyond the villae went back; but as thouh in revene for this
failure, the enemy placed ten uns to the riht of the villae and bean
firin them at Tushin's battery.

In their childlike lee, aroused by the fire and their luck in
successfully cannonadin the French, our artillerymen only noticed this
battery when two balls, and then four more, fell amon our uns, one
knockin over two horses and another tearin off a munition-waon
driver's le. Their spirits once roused were, however, not diminished,
but only chaned character. The horses were replaced by others from a
reserve un carriae, the wounded were carried away, and the four uns
were turned aainst the ten-un battery. Tushin's companion officer had
been killed at the beinnin of the enaement and within an hour
seventeen of the forty men of the uns' crews had been disabled, but the
artillerymen were still as merry and lively as ever. Twice they noticed
the French appearin below them, and then they fired rapeshot at them.

Little Tushin, movin feebly and awkwardly, kept tellin his orderly to
"refill my pipe for that one!" and then, scatterin sparks from it, ran
forward shadin his eyes with his small hand to look at the French.

"Smack at 'em, lads!" he kept sayin, seizin the uns by the wheels and
workin the screws himself.

Amid the smoke, deafened by the incessant reports which always made him
jump, Tushin not takin his pipe from his mouth ran from un to un, now
aimin, now countin the chares, now ivin orders about replacin dead
or wounded horses and harnessin fresh ones, and shoutin in his feeble
voice, so hih pitched and irresolute. His face rew more and more
animated. Only when a man was killed or wounded did he frown and turn
away from the siht, shoutin anrily at the men who, as is always the
case, hesitated about liftin the injured or dead. The soldiers, for the
most part handsome fellows and, as is always the case in an artillery
company, a head and shoulders taller and twice as broad as their
officer--all looked at their commander like children in an embarrassin
situation, and the expression on his face was invariably reflected on
theirs.

Owin to the terrible uproar and the necessity for concentration and
activity, Tushin did not experience the slihtest unpleasant sense of
fear, and the thouht that he miht be killed or badly wounded never
occurred to him. On the contrary, he became more and more elated. It
seemed to him that it was a very lon time ao, almost a day, since he
had first seen the enemy and fired the first shot, and that the corner
of the field he stood on was well-known and familiar round. Thouh he
thouht of everythin, considered everythin, and did everythin the
best of officers could do in his position, he was in a state akin to
feverish delirium or drunkenness.

From the deafenin sounds of his own uns around him, the whistle and
thud of the enemy's cannon balls, from the flushed and perspirin faces
of the crew bustlin round the uns, from the siht of the blood of men
and horses, from the little puffs of smoke on the enemy's side (always
followed by a ball flyin past and strikin the earth, a man, a un, a
horse), from the siht of all these thins a fantastic world of his own
had taken possession of his brain and at that moment afforded him
pleasure. The enemy's uns were in his fancy not uns but pipes from
which occasional puffs were blown by an invisible smoker.

"There... he's puffin aain," muttered Tushin to himself, as a small
cloud rose from the hill and was borne in a streak to the left by the
wind.

"Now look out for the ball... we'll throw it back."

"What do you want, your honor?" asked an artilleryman, standin close
by, who heard him mutterin.

"Nothin... only a shell..." he answered.

"Come alon, our Matvevna!" he said to himself. "Matvevna" * was the
name his fancy ave to the farthest un of the battery, which was lare
and of an old pattern. The French swarmin round their uns seemed to
him like ants. In that world, the handsome drunkard Number One of the
second un's crew was "uncle"; Tushin looked at him more often than at
anyone else and took deliht in his every movement. The sound of
musketry at the foot of the hill, now diminishin, now increasin,
seemed like someone's breathin. He listened intently to the ebb and
flow of these sounds.


* Dauhter of Matthew.

"Ah! Breathin aain, breathin!" he muttered to himself.

He imained himself as an enormously tall, powerful man who was throwin
cannon balls at the French with both hands.

"Now then, Matvevna, dear old lady, don't let me down!" he was sayin as
he moved from the un, when a strane, unfamiliar voice called above his
head: "Captain Tushin! Captain!"

Tushin turned round in dismay. It was the staff officer who had turned
him out of the booth at runth. He was shoutin in a aspin voice:

"Are you mad? You have twice been ordered to retreat, and you..."

"Why are they down on me?" thouht Tushin, lookin in alarm at his
superior.

"I... don't..." he muttered, holdin up two finers to his cap. "I..."

But the staff officer did not finish what he wanted to say. A cannon
ball, flyin close to him, caused him to duck and bend over his horse.
He paused, and just as he was about to say somethin more, another ball
stopped him. He turned his horse and alloped off.

"Retire! All to retire!" he shouted from a distance.

The soldiers lauhed. A moment later, an adjutant arrived with the same
order.

It was Prince Andrew. The first thin he saw on ridin up to the space
where Tushin's uns were stationed was an unharnessed horse with a
broken le, that lay screamin piteously beside the harnessed horses.
Blood was ushin from its le as from a sprin. Amon the limbers lay
several dead men. One ball after another passed over as he approached
and he felt a nervous shudder run down his spine. But the mere thouht
of bein afraid roused him aain. "I cannot be afraid," thouht he, and
dismounted slowly amon the uns. He delivered the order and did not
leave the battery. He decided to have the uns removed from their
positions and withdrawn in his presence. Toether with Tushin, steppin
across the bodies and under a terrible fire from the French, he attended
to the removal of the uns.

"A staff officer was here a minute ao, but skipped off," said an
artilleryman to Prince Andrew. "Not like your honor!"

Prince Andrew said nothin to Tushin. They were both so busy as to seem
not to notice one another. When havin limbered up the only two cannon
that remained uninjured out of the four, they bean movin down the hill
(one shattered un and one unicorn were left behind), Prince Andrew rode
up to Tushin.

"Well, till we meet aain..." he said, holdin out his hand to Tushin.

"ood-bye, my dear fellow," said Tushin. "Dear soul! ood-bye, my dear
fellow!" and for some unknown reason tears suddenly filled his eyes.




CHAPTER XXI

The wind had fallen and black clouds, merin with the powder smoke,
hun low over the field of battle on the horizon. It was rowin dark
and the low of two conflarations was the more conspicuous. The
cannonade was dyin down, but the rattle of musketry behind and on the
riht sounded oftener and nearer. As soon as Tushin with his uns,
continually drivin round or comin upon wounded men, was out of rane
of fire and had descended into the dip, he was met by some of the staff,
amon them the staff officer and Zherkov, who had been twice sent to
Tushin's battery but had never reached it. Interruptin one another,
they all ave, and transmitted, orders as to how to proceed,
reprimandin and reproachin him. Tushin ave no orders, and, silently--
fearin to speak because at every word he felt ready to weep without
knowin why--rode behind on his artillery na. Thouh the orders were to
abandon the wounded, many of them draed themselves after troops and
beed for seats on the un carriaes. The jaunty infantry officer who
just before the battle had rushed out of Tushin's wattle shed was laid,
with a bullet in his stomach, on "Matvevna's" carriae. At the foot of
the hill, a pale hussar cadet, supportin one hand with the other, came
up to Tushin and asked for a seat.

"Captain, for od's sake! I've hurt my arm," he said timidly. "For od's
sake... I can't walk. For od's sake!"

It was plain that this cadet had already repeatedly asked for a lift and
been refused. He asked in a hesitatin, piteous voice.

"Tell them to ive me a seat, for od's sake!"

"ive him a seat," said Tushin. "Lay a cloak for him to sit on, lad," he
said, addressin his favorite soldier. "And where is the wounded
officer?"

"He has been set down. He died," replied someone.

"Help him up. Sit down, dear fellow, sit down! Spread out the cloak,
Antonov."

The cadet was Rostov. With one hand he supported the other; he was pale
and his jaw trembled, shiverin feverishly. He was placed on "Matvevna,"
the un from which they had removed the dead officer. The cloak they
spread under him was wet with blood which stained his breeches and arm.

"What, are you wounded, my lad?" said Tushin, approachin the un on
which Rostov sat.

"No, it's a sprain."

"Then what is this blood on the un carriae?" inquired Tushin.

"It was the officer, your honor, stained it," answered the artilleryman,
wipin away the blood with his coat sleeve, as if apoloizin for the
state of his un.

It was all that they could do to et the uns up the rise aided by the
infantry, and havin reached the villae of runtersdorf they halted. It
had rown so dark that one could not distinuish the uniforms ten paces
off, and the firin had beun to subside. Suddenly, near by on the

"Not hurt, Petrov?" asked one.

"We've iven it 'em hot, mate! They won't make another push now," said
another.

"You couldn't see a thin. How they shot at their own fellows! Nothin
could be seen. Pitch-dark, brother! Isn't there somethin to drink?"

The French had been repulsed for the last time. And aain and aain in
the complete darkness Tushin's uns moved forward, surrounded by the

In the darkness, it seemed as thouh a loomy unseen river was flowin

After a while the movin mass became aitated, someone rode past on a

Fires were lihted and the talk became more audible. Captain Tushin,
havin iven orders to his company, sent a soldier to find a dressin

Tushin's lare, kind, intellient eyes were fixed with sympathy and

to help him but could not.

From all sides were heard the footsteps and talk of the infantry, who

It was no loner, as before, a dark, unseen river flowin throuh the

Rostov looked at and listened listlessly to what passed before and
around him. An infantryman came to the fire, squatted on his heels, held
his hands to the blaze, and turned away his face.

"You don't mind your honor?" he asked Tushin. "I've lost my company,
your honor. I don't know where... such bad luck!"

"You picked it up?... I dare say! You're very smart!" one of them

Then a thin, pale soldier, his neck bandaed with a bloodstained le

"Must one die like a do?" said he.

Tushin told them to ive the man some water. Then a cheerful soldier ran

"A nice little hot torch for the infantry! ood luck to you, fellow

Next came four soldiers, carryin somethin heavy on a cloak, and passed

"Who the devil has put the los on the road?" snarled he.

"He's dead--why carry him?" said another.

"Shut up!"

And they disappeared into the darkness with their load.

"Still achin?" Tushin asked Rostov in a whisper.

"Yes."

"Your honor, you're wanted by the eneral. He is in the hut here," said

"Comin, friend."

Tushin rose and, buttonin his reatcoat and pullin it straiht, walked

Not far from the artillery campfire, in a hut that had been prepared for

"When I saw, your excellency, that their first battalion was

The eneral had so wished to do this and was so sorry he had not manaed

Several of those present smiled at Zherkov's words, expectin one of his

"One was damaed," answered the staff officer, "and the other I can't

Someone mentioned that Captain Tushin was bivouackin close to the

"Of course, we only just missed one another," said the staff officer,

"Thank you; you saved me, my dear fellow!" said Tushin.

He opened his eyes and looked up. The black canopy of niht hun less

"Eh, is anythin hurtin you?" asked the soldier, shakin his shirt out

Next day the French army did not renew their attack, and the remnant of
Baration's detachment was reunited to Kutuzov's army.

CHAPTER I

Prince Vasili was not a man who deliberately thouht out his plans.

CHAPTER II

In November, 1805, Prince Vasili had to o on a tour of inspection in
four different provinces. He had arraned this for himself so as to

her.

She always addressed him with a radiantly confidin smile meant for him

He wished to take a decision, but felt with dismay that in this matter

Into the insinificant, triflin, and artificial interests unitin that

Or he would suddenly feel ashamed of he knew not what. He felt it

When Prince Vasili returned to the drawin room, the princess, his wife,

"Of course, it is a very brilliant match, but happiness, my dear..."

"Marriaes are made in heaven," replied the elderly lady.

"Princess, come here!" he shouted.

The old princess came in and also wept. The elderly lady was usin her

"Somethin special is always said in such cases," he thouht, but could

Pierre took them off, and his eyes, besides the strane look eyes have

"It is too late now, it's done; besides I love her," thouht Pierre.

"Je vous aime!" * he said, rememberin what has to be said at such
moments: but his words sounded so weak that he felt ashamed of himself.


* "I love you."

Six weeks later he was married, and settled in Count Bezukhov's lare,
newly furnished Petersbur house, the happy possessor, as people said,
of a wife who was a celebrated beauty and of millions of money.




CHAPTER III

Old Prince Nicholas Bolkonski received a letter from Prince Vasili in
November, 1805, announcin that he and his son would be payin him a
visit. "I am startin on a journey of inspection, and of course I shall
think nothin of an extra seventy miles to come and see you at the same
time, my honored benefactor," wrote Prince Vasili. "My son Anatole is
accompanyin me on his way to the army, so I hope you will allow him
personally to express the deep respect that, emulatin his father, he
feels for you."

"It seems that there will be no need to brin Mary out, suitors are
comin to us of their own accord," incautiously remarked the little
princess on hearin the news.

Prince Nicholas frowned, but said nothin.

A fortniht after the letter Prince Vasili's servants came one evenin
in advance of him, and he and his son arrived next day.

Old Bolkonski had always had a poor opinion of Prince Vasili's
character, but more so recently, since in the new reins of Paul and
Alexander Prince Vasili had risen to hih position and honors. And now,
from the hints contained in his letter and iven by the little princess,
he saw which way the wind was blowin, and his low opinion chaned into
a feelin of contemptuous ill will. He snorted whenever he mentioned
him. On the day of Prince Vasili's arrival, Prince Bolkonski was
particularly discontented and out of temper. Whether he was in a bad
temper because Prince Vasili was comin, or whether his bein in a bad
temper made him specially annoyed at Prince Vasili's visit, he was in a
bad temper, and in the mornin Tikhon had already advised the architect
not to o to the prince with his report.

"Do you hear how he's walkin?" said Tikhon, drawin the architect's
attention to the sound of the prince's footsteps. "Steppin flat on his
heels--we know what that means...."

However, at nine o'clock the prince, in his velvet coat with a sable
collar and cap, went out for his usual walk. It had snowed the day
before and the path to the hothouse, alon which the prince was in the
habit of walkin, had been swept: the marks of the broom were still
visible in the snow and a shovel had been left stickin in one of the
soft snowbanks that bordered both sides of the path. The prince went
throuh the conservatories, the serfs' quarters, and the outbuildins,
frownin and silent.

"Can a sleih pass?" he asked his overseer, a venerable man, resemblin
his master in manners and looks, who was accompanyin him back to the
house.

"The snow is deep. I am havin the avenue swept, your honor."

The prince bowed his head and went up to the porch. "od be thanked,"
thouht the overseer, "the storm has blown over!"

"It would have been hard to drive up, your honor," he added. "I heard,
your honor, that a minister is comin to visit your honor."

The prince turned round to the overseer and fixed his eyes on him,
frownin.

"What? A minister? What minister? Who ave orders?" he said in his
shrill, harsh voice. "The road is not swept for the princess my
dauhter, but for a minister! For me, there are no ministers!"

"Your honor, I thouht..."

"You thouht!" shouted the prince, his words comin more and more
rapidly and indistinctly. "You thouht!... Rascals! Blackuards!... I'll
teach you to think!" and liftin his stick he swun it and would have
hit Alpatych, the overseer, had not the latter instinctively avoided the
blow. "Thouht... Blackuards..." shouted the prince rapidly.

But althouh Alpatych, frihtened at his own temerity in avoidin the
stroke, came up to the prince, bowin his bald head resinedly before
him, or perhaps for that very reason, the prince, thouh he continued to
shout: "Blackuards!... Throw the snow back on the road!" did not lift
his stick aain but hurried into the house.

Before dinner, Princess Mary and Mademoiselle Bourienne, who knew that
the prince was in a bad humor, stood awaitin him; Mademoiselle
Bourienne with a radiant face that said: "I know nothin, I am the same
as usual," and Princess Mary pale, frihtened, and with downcast eyes.
What she found hardest to bear was to know that on such occasions she
ouht to behave like Mademoiselle Bourienne, but could not. She thouht:
"If I seem not to notice he will think that I do not sympathize with
him; if I seem sad and out of spirits myself, he will say (as he has
done before) that I'm in the dumps."

The prince looked at his dauhter's frihtened face and snorted.

"Fool... or dummy!" he muttered.

"And the other one is not here. They've been tellin tales," he thouht-
-referrin to the little princess who was not in the dinin room.

"Where is the princess?" he asked. "Hidin?"

"She is not very well," answered Mademoiselle Bourienne with a briht
smile, "so she won't come down. It is natural in her state."

"Hm! Hm!" muttered the prince, sittin down.

His plate seemed to him not quite clean, and pointin to a spot he flun
it away. Tikhon cauht it and handed it to a footman. The little
princess was not unwell, but had such an overpowerin fear of the prince
that, hearin he was in a bad humor, she had decided not to appear.

"I am afraid for the baby," she said to Mademoiselle Bourienne: "Heaven
knows what a friht miht do."

In eneral at Bald Hills the little princess lived in constant fear, and
with a sense of antipathy to the old prince which she did not realize
because the fear was so much the stroner feelin. The prince
reciprocated this antipathy, but it was overpowered by his contempt for
her. When the little princess had rown accustomed to life at Bald
Hills, she took a special fancy to Mademoiselle Bourienne, spent whole
days with her, asked her to sleep in her room, and often talked with her
about the old prince and criticized him.

"So we are to have visitors, mon prince?" remarked Mademoiselle
Bourienne, unfoldin her white napkin with her rosy finers. "His
Excellency Prince Vasili Kurain and his son, I understand?" she said
inquirinly.

"Hm!--his excellency is a puppy.... I ot him his appointment in the
service," said the prince disdainfully. "Why his son is comin I don't
understand. Perhaps Princess Elizabeth and Princess Mary know. I don't
want him." (He looked at his blushin dauhter.) "Are you unwell today?
Eh? Afraid of the 'minister' as that idiot Alpatych called him this
mornin?"

"No, mon pere."

Thouh Mademoiselle Bourienne had been so unsuccessful in her choice of
a subject, she did not stop talkin, but chattered about the
conservatories and the beauty of a flower that had just opened, and
after the soup the prince became more enial.

After dinner, he went to see his dauhter-in-law. The little princess
was sittin at a small table, chatterin with Masha, her maid. She rew
pale on seein her father-in-law.

She was much altered. She was now plain rather than pretty. Her cheeks
had sunk, her lip was drawn up, and her eyes drawn down.

"Yes, I feel a kind of oppression," she said in reply to the prince's
question as to how she felt.

"Do you want anythin?"

"No, merci, mon pere."

"Well, all riht, all riht."

He left the room and went to the waitin room where Alpatych stood with
bowed head.

"Has the snow been shoveled back?"

"Yes, your excellency. Forive me for heaven's sake... It was only my
stupidity."

"All riht, all riht," interrupted the prince, and lauhin his
unnatural way, he stretched out his hand for Alpatych to kiss, and then
proceeded to his study.

Prince Vasili arrived that evenin. He was met in the avenue by coachmen
and footmen, who, with loud shouts, draed his sleihs up to one of the
lodes over the road purposely laden with snow.

Prince Vasili and Anatole had separate rooms assined to them.

Anatole, havin taken off his overcoat, sat with arms akimbo before a

That never does any harm," thouht Anatole.

He shaved and scented himself with the care and eleance which had

"I say, Father, jokin apart, is she very hideous?" Anatole asked, as if

"Enouh! What nonsense! Above all, try to be respectful and cautious

"If he starts a row I'll o away," said Prince Anatole. "I can't bear
those old men! Eh?"

"Remember, for you everythin depends on this."

In the meantime, not only was it known in the maidservants' rooms that
the minister and his son had arrived, but the appearance of both had

"Why did they write, why did Lise tell me about it? It can never

The mere thouht of her father's look filled her with terror. The little

"You know they've come, Marie?" said the little princess, waddlin in,
and sinkin heavily into an armchair.

She was no loner in the loose own she enerally wore in the mornin,
but had on one of her best dresses. Her hair was carefully done and her
face was animated, which, however, did not conceal its sunken and faded

had been added to Mademoiselle Bourienne's toilet which rendered her

"What! Are you oin to remain as you are, dear princess?" she bean.
"They'll be announcin that the entlemen are in the drawin room and we

The little princess ot up, ran for the maid, and hurriedly and merrily

it'!... And I ask you!"

"I do not know what you think, Father," whispered the princess.

"I? I? What of me? Leave me out of the question. I'm not oin to et
married. What about you? That's what I want to know."

The princess saw that her father rearded the matter with disapproval,
but at that moment the thouht occurred to her that her fate would be
decided now or never. She lowered her eyes so as not to see the aze
under which she felt that she could not think, but would only be able to
submit from habit, and she said: "I wish only to do your will, but if I
had to express my own desire..." She had no time to finish. The old
prince interrupted her.

"That's admirable!" he shouted. "He will take you with your dowry and
take Mademoiselle Bourienne into the barain. She'll be the wife, while
you..."

The prince stopped. He saw the effect these words had produced on his
dauhter. She lowered her head and was ready to burst into tears.

"Now then, now then, I'm only jokin!" he said. "Remember this,
Princess, I hold to the principle that a maiden has a full riht to
choose. I ive you freedom. Only remember that your life's happiness
depends on your decision. Never mind me!"

"But I do not know, Father!"

"There's no need to talk! He receives his orders and will marry you or
anybody; but you are free to choose.... o to your room, think it over,
and come back in an hour and tell me in his presence: yes or no. I know
you will pray over it. Well, pray if you like, but you had better think
it over. o! Yes or no, yes or no, yes or no!" he still shouted when the
princess, as if lost in a fo, had already staered out of the study.

Her fate was decided and happily decided. But what her father had said
about Mademoiselle Bourienne was dreadful. It was untrue to be sure, but
still it was terrible, and she could not help thinkin of it. She was
oin straiht on throuh the conservatory, neither seein nor hearin
anythin, when suddenly the well-known whisperin of Mademoiselle
Bourienne aroused her. She raised her eyes, and two steps away saw
Anatole embracin the Frenchwoman and whisperin somethin to her. With
a horrified expression on his handsome face, Anatole looked at Princess
Mary, but did not at once take his arm from the waist of Mademoiselle
Bourienne who had not yet seen her.

"Who's that? Why? Wait a moment!" Anatole's face seemed to say. Princess
Mary looked at them in silence. She could not understand it. At last
Mademoiselle Bourienne ave a scream and ran away. Anatole bowed to
Princess Mary with a ay smile, as if invitin her to join in a lauh at
this strane incident, and then shruin his shoulders went to the door
that led to his own apartments.

An hour later, Tikhon came to call Princess Mary to the old prince; he
added that Prince Vasili was also there. When Tikhon came to her
Princess Mary was sittin on the sofa in her room, holdin the weepin
Mademoiselle Bourienne in her arms and ently strokin her hair. The
princess' beautiful eyes with all their former calm radiance were
lookin with tender affection and pity at Mademoiselle Bourienne's
pretty face.

"No, Princess, I have lost your affection forever!" said Mademoiselle
Bourienne.

"Why? I love you more than ever," said Princess Mary, "and I will try to
do all I can for your happiness."

"But you despise me. You who are so pure can never understand bein so
carried away by passion. Oh, only my poor mother..."

"I quite understand," answered Princess Mary, with a sad smile. "Calm
yourself, my dear. I will o to my father," she said, and went out.

Prince Vasili, with one le thrown hih over the other and a snuffbox in
his hand, was sittin there with a smile of deep emotion on his face, as
if stirred to his heart's core and himself rerettin and lauhin at
his own sensibility, when Princess Mary entered. He hurriedly took a
pinch of snuff.

"Ah, my dear, my dear!" he bean, risin and takin her by both hands.
Then, sihin, he added: "My son's fate is in your hands. Decide, my
dear, ood, entle Marie, whom I have always loved as a dauhter!"

He drew back and a real tear appeared in his eye.

"Fr... fr..." snorted Prince Bolkonski. "The prince is makin a
proposition to you in his pupil's--I mean, his son's--name. Do you wish
or not to be Prince Anatole Kurain's wife? Reply: yes or no," he
shouted, "and then I shall reserve the riht to state my opinion also.
Yes, my opinion, and only my opinion," added Prince Bolkonski, turnin
to Prince Vasili and answerin his implorin look. "Yes, or no?"

"My desire is never to leave you, Father, never to separate my life from
yours. I don't wish to marry," she answered positively, lancin at
Prince Vasili and at her father with her beautiful eyes.

"Humbu! Nonsense! Humbu, humbu, humbu!" cried Prince Bolkonski,
frownin and takin his dauhter's hand; he did not kiss her, but only
bendin his forehead to hers just touched it, and pressed her hand so
that she winced and uttered a cry.

Prince Vasili rose.

"My dear, I must tell you that this is a moment I shall never, never
foret. But, my dear, will you not ive us a little hope of touchin
this heart, so kind and enerous? Say 'perhaps'... The future is so
lon. Say 'perhaps.'"

"Prince, what I have said is all there is in my heart. I thank you for
the honor, but I shall never be your son's wife."

"Well, so that's finished, my dear fellow! I am very lad to have seen
you. Very lad! o back to your rooms, Princess. o!" said the old
prince. "Very, very lad to have seen you," repeated he, embracin
Prince Vasili.

"My vocation is a different one," thouht Princess Mary. "My vocation is
to be happy with another kind of happiness, the happiness of love and
self-sacrifice. And cost what it may, I will arrane poor Amelie's
happiness, she loves him so passionately, and so passionately repents. I
will do all I can to arrane the match between them. If he is not rich I
will ive her the means; I will ask my father and Andrew. I shall be so
happy when she is his wife. She is so unfortunate, a straner, alone,
helpless! And, oh od, how passionately she must love him if she could
so far foret herself! Perhaps I miht have done the same!..." thouht
Princess Mary.




CHAPTER VI

It was lon since the Rostovs had news of Nicholas. Not till midwinter
was the count at last handed a letter addressed in his son's
handwritin. On receivin it, he ran on tiptoe to his study in alarm and
haste, tryin to escape notice, closed the door, and bean to read the
letter.

Anna Mikhaylovna, who always knew everythin that passed in the house,
on hearin of the arrival of the letter went softly into the room and
found the count with it in his hand, sobbin and lauhin at the same
time.

Anna Mikhaylovna, thouh her circumstances had improved, was still
livin with the Rostovs.

"My dear friend?" said she, in a tone of pathetic inquiry, prepared to
sympathize in any way.

The count sobbed yet more.

"Nikolenka... a letter... wa... a... s... wounded... my darlin boy...
the countess... promoted to be an officer... thank od... How tell the
little countess!"

Anna Mikhaylovna sat down beside him, with her own handkerchief wiped
the tears from his eyes and from the letter, then havin dried her own
eyes she comforted the count, and decided that at dinner and till
teatime she would prepare the countess, and after tea, with od's help,
would inform her.

At dinner Anna Mikhaylovna talked the whole time about the war news and
about Nikolenka, twice asked when the last letter had been received from
him, thouh she knew that already, and remarked that they miht very
likely be ettin a letter from him that day. Each time that these hints
bean to make the countess anxious and she lanced uneasily at the count
and at Anna Mikhaylovna, the latter very adroitly turned the
conversation to insinificant matters. Natasha, who, of the whole
family, was the most ifted with a capacity to feel any shades of
intonation, look, and expression, pricked up her ears from the beinnin
of the meal and was certain that there was some secret between her
father and Anna Mikhaylovna, that it had somethin to do with her
brother, and that Anna Mikhaylovna was preparin them for it. Bold as
she was, Natasha, who knew how sensitive her mother was to anythin
relatin to Nikolenka, did not venture to ask any questions at dinner,
but she was too excited to eat anythin and kept wrilin about on her
chair reardless of her overness' remarks. After dinner, she rushed
head lon after Anna Mikhaylovna and, dashin at her, flun herself on
her neck as soon as she overtook her in the sittin room.

"Auntie, darlin, do tell me what it is!"

"Nothin, my dear."

"No, dearest, sweet one, honey, I won't ive up--I know you know
somethin."

Anna Mikhaylovna shook her head.

"You are a little slyboots," she said.

"A letter from Nikolenka! I'm sure of it!" exclaimed Natasha, readin
confirmation in Anna Mikhaylovna's face.

"But for od's sake, be careful, you know how it may affect your mamma."

"I will, I will, only tell me! You won't? Then I will o and tell at
once."

Anna Mikhaylovna, in a few words, told her the contents of the letter,
on condition that she should tell no one.

"No, on my true word of honor," said Natasha, crossin herself, "I won't
tell anyone!" and she ran off at once to Sonya.

"Nikolenka... wounded... a letter," she announced in leeful triumph.

"Nicholas!" was all Sonya said, instantly turnin white.

Natasha, seein the impression the news of her brother's wound produced
on Sonya, felt for the first time the sorrowful side of the news.

She rushed to Sonya, hued her, and bean to cry.

"A little wound, but he has been made an officer; he is well now, he
wrote himself," said she throuh her tears.

"There now! It's true that all you women are crybabies," remarked Petya,
pacin the room with lare, resolute strides. "Now I'm very lad, very
lad indeed, that my brother has distinuished himself so. You are all
blubberers and understand nothin."

Natasha smiled throuh her tears.

"You haven't read the letter?" asked Sonya.

"No, but she said that it was all over and that he's now an officer."

"Thank od!" said Sonya, crossin herself. "But perhaps she deceived
you. Let us o to Mamma."

Petya paced the room in silence for a time.

"If I'd been in Nikolenka's place I would have killed even more of those
Frenchmen," he said. "What nasty brutes they are! I'd have killed so
many that there'd have been a heap of them."

"Hold your tonue, Petya, what a oose you are!"

"I'm not a oose, but they are who cry about trifles," said Petya.

"Do you remember him?" Natasha suddenly asked, after a moment's silence.

Sonya smiled.

"Do I remember Nicholas?"

"No, Sonya, but do you remember so that you remember him perfectly,
remember everythin?" said Natasha, with an expressive esture,
evidently wishin to ive her words a very definite meanin. "I remember
Nikolenka too, I remember him well," she said. "But I don't remember
Boris. I don't remember him a bit."

"What! You don't remember Boris?" asked Sonya in surprise.

"It's not that I don't remember--I know what he is like, but not as I
remember Nikolenka. Him--I just shut my eyes and remember, but Boris...
No!" (She shut her eyes.) "No! there's nothin at all."

"Oh, Natasha!" said Sonya, lookin ecstatically and earnestly at her
friend as if she did not consider her worthy to hear what she meant to
say and as if she were sayin it to someone else, with whom jokin was
out of the question, "I am in love with your brother once for all and,
whatever may happen to him or to me, shall never cease to love him as
lon as I live."

Natasha looked at Sonya with wonderin and inquisitive eyes, and said
nothin. She felt that Sonya was speakin the truth, that there was such
love as Sonya was speakin of. But Natasha had not yet felt anythin
like it. She believed it could be, but did not understand it.

"Shall you write to him?" she asked.

Sonya became thouhtful. The question of how to write to Nicholas, and
whether she ouht to write, tormented her. Now that he was already an
officer and a wounded hero, would it be riht to remind him of herself
and, as it miht seem, of the obliations to her he had taken on
himself?

"I don't know. I think if he writes, I will write too," she said,
blushin.

"And you won't feel ashamed to write to him?"

Sonya smiled.

"No."

"And I should be ashamed to write to Boris. I'm not oin to."

"Why should you be ashamed?"

"Well, I don't know. It's awkward and would make me ashamed."

"And I know why she'd be ashamed," said Petya, offended by Natasha's
previous remark. "It's because she was in love with that fat one in
spectacles" (that was how Petya described his namesake, the new Count
Bezukhov) "and now she's in love with that siner" (he meant Natasha's
Italian sinin master), "that's why she's ashamed!"

"Petya, you're a stupid!" said Natasha.

"Not more stupid than you, madam," said the nine-year-old Petya, with
the air of an old briadier.

The countess had been prepared by Anna Mikhaylovna's hints at dinner. On
retirin to her own room, she sat in an armchair, her eyes fixed on a
miniature portrait of her son on the lid of a snuffbox, while the tears
kept comin into her eyes. Anna Mikhaylovna, with the letter, came on
tiptoe to the countess' door and paused.

"Don't come in," she said to the old count who was followin her. "Come
later." And she went in, closin the door behind her.

The count put his ear to the keyhole and listened.

At first he heard the sound of indifferent voices, then Anna
Mikhaylovna's voice alone in a lon speech, then a cry, then silence,
then both voices toether with lad intonations, and then footsteps.
Anna Mikhaylovna opened the door. Her face wore the proud expression of
a sureon who has just performed a difficult operation and admits the
public to appreciate his skill.

"It is done!" she said to the count, pointin triumphantly to the
countess, who sat holdin in one hand the snuffbox with its portrait and
in the other the letter, and pressin them alternately to her lips.

When she saw the count, she stretched out her arms to him, embraced his
bald head, over which she aain looked at the letter and the portrait,
and in order to press them aain to her lips, she slihtly pushed away
the bald head. Vera, Natasha, Sonya, and Petya now entered the room, and
the readin of the letter bean. After a brief description of the
campain and the two battles in which he had taken part, and his
promotion, Nicholas said that he kissed his father's and mother's hands
askin for their blessin, and that he kissed Vera, Natasha, and Petya.
Besides that, he sent reetins to Monsieur Schellin, Madame Schoss,
and his old nurse, and asked them to kiss for him "dear Sonya, whom he
loved and thouht of just the same as ever." When she heard this Sonya
blushed so that tears came into her eyes and, unable to bear the looks
turned upon her, ran away into the dancin hall, whirled round it at
full speed with her dress puffed out like a balloon, and, flushed and
smilin, plumped down on the floor. The countess was cryin.

"Why are you cryin, Mamma?" asked Vera. "From all he says one should be
lad and not cry."

This was quite true, but the count, the countess, and Natasha looked at
her reproachfully. "And who is it she takes after?" thouht the
countess.

Nicholas' letter was read over hundreds of times, and those who were
considered worthy to hear it had to come to the countess, for she did
not let it out of her hands. The tutors came, and the nurses, and
Dmitri, and several acquaintances, and the countess reread the letter
each time with fresh pleasure and each time discovered in it fresh
proofs of Nikolenka's virtues. How strane, how extraordinary, how
joyful it seemed, that her son, the scarcely perceptible motion of whose
tiny limbs she had felt twenty years ao within her, that son about whom
she used to have quarrels with the too indulent count, that son who had
first learned to say "pear" and then "ranny," that this son should now
be away in a forein land amid strane surroundins, a manly warrior
doin some kind of man's work of his own, without help or uidance. The
universal experience of aes, showin that children do row
imperceptibly from the cradle to manhood, did not exist for the
countess. Her son's rowth toward manhood, at each of its staes, had
seemed as extraordinary to her as if there had never existed the
millions of human beins who rew up in the same way. As twenty years
before, it seemed impossible that the little creature who lived
somewhere under her heart would ever cry, suck her breast, and bein to
speak, so now she could not believe that that little creature could be
this stron, brave man, this model son and officer that, judin by this
letter, he now was.

"What a style! How charminly he describes!" said she, readin the
descriptive part of the letter. "And what a soul! Not a word about
himself.... Not a word! About some Denisov or other, thouh he himself,
I dare say, is braver than any of them. He says nothin about his
sufferins. What a heart! How like him it is! And how he has remembered
everybody! Not forettin anyone. I always said when he was only so
hih--I always said...."

For more than a week preparations were bein made, rouh drafts of
letters to Nicholas from all the household were written and copied out,
while under the supervision of the countess and the solicitude of the
count, money and all thins necessary for the uniform and equipment of
the newly commissioned officer were collected. Anna Mikhaylovna,
practical woman that she was, had even manaed by favor with army
authorities to secure advantaeous means of communication for herself
and her son. She had opportunities of sendin her letters to the rand
Duke Constantine Pavlovich, who commanded the uards. The Rostovs
supposed that The Russian uards, Abroad, was quite a definite address,
and that if a letter reached the rand Duke in command of the uards
there was no reason why it should not reach the Pavlorad reiment,
which was presumably somewhere in the same neihborhood. And so it was
decided to send the letters and money by the rand Duke's courier to
Boris and Boris was to forward them to Nicholas. The letters were from
the old count, the countess, Petya, Vera, Natasha, and Sonya, and
finally there were six thousand rubles for his outfit and various other
thins the old count sent to his son.




CHAPTER VII

On the twelfth of November, Kutuzov's active army, in camp before
Olmutz, was preparin to be reviewed next day by the two Emperors--the
Russian and the Austrian. The uards, just arrived from Russia, spent
the niht ten miles from Olmutz and next mornin were to come straiht
to the review, reachin the field at Olmutz by ten o'clock.

That day Nicholas Rostov received a letter from Boris, tellin him that
the Ismaylov reiment was quartered for the niht ten miles from Olmutz
and that he wanted to see him as he had a letter and money for him.
Rostov was particularly in need of money now that the troops, after
their active service, were stationed near Olmutz and the camp swarmed
with well-provisioned sutlers and Austrian Jews offerin all sorts of
temptin wares. The Pavlorads held feast after feast, celebratin
awards they had received for the campain, and made expeditions to
Olmutz to visit a certain Caroline the Hunarian, who had recently
opened a restaurant there with irls as waitresses. Rostov, who had just
celebrated his promotion to a cornetcy and bouht Denisov's horse,
Bedouin, was in debt all round, to his comrades and the sutlers. On
receivin Boris' letter he rode with a fellow officer to Olmutz, dined
there, drank a bottle of wine, and then set off alone to the uards'
camp to find his old playmate. Rostov had not yet had time to et his
uniform. He had on a shabby cadet jacket, decorated with a soldier's
cross, equally shabby cadet's ridin breeches lined with worn leather,
and an officer's saber with a sword knot. The Don horse he was ridin
was one he had bouht from a Cossack durin the campain, and he wore a
crumpled hussar cap stuck jauntily back on one side of his head. As he
rode up to the camp he thouht how he would impress Boris and all his
comrades of the uards by his appearance--that of a fihtin hussar who
had been under fire.

The uards had made their whole march as if on a pleasure trip, paradin
their cleanliness and discipline. They had come by easy staes, their
knapsacks conveyed on carts, and the Austrian authorities had provided
excellent dinners for the officers at every haltin place. The reiments
had entered and left the town with their bands playin, and by the rand
Duke's orders the men had marched all the way in step (a practice on
which the uards prided themselves), the officers on foot and at their
proper posts. Boris had been quartered, and had marched all the way,
with Ber who was already in command of a company. Ber, who had
obtained his captaincy durin the campain, had ained the confidence of
his superiors by his promptitude and accuracy and had arraned his money
matters very satisfactorily. Boris, durin the campain, had made the
acquaintance of many persons who miht prove useful to him, and by a
letter of recommendation he had brouht from Pierre had become
acquainted with Prince Andrew Bolkonski, throuh whom he hoped to obtain
a post on the commander-in-chief's staff. Ber and Boris, havin rested
after yesterday's march, were sittin, clean and neatly dressed, at a
round table in the clean quarters allotted to them, playin chess. Ber
held a smokin pipe between his knees. Boris, in the accurate way
characteristic of him, was buildin a little pyramid of chessmen with
his delicate white finers while awaitin Ber's move, and watched his
opponent's face, evidently thinkin about the ame as he always thouht
only of whatever he was enaed on.

"Well, how are you oin to et out of that?" he remarked.

"We'll try to," replied Ber, touchin a pawn and then removin his
hand.

At that moment the door opened.

"Here he is at last!" shouted Rostov. "And Ber too! Oh, you
petisenfans, allay cushay dormir!" he exclaimed, imitatin his Russian
nurse's French, at which he and Boris used to lauh lon ao.

"Dear me, how you have chaned!"

Boris rose to meet Rostov, but in doin so did not omit to steady and
replace some chessmen that were fallin. He was about to embrace his
friend, but Nicholas avoided him. With that peculiar feelin of youth,
that dread of beaten tracks, and wish to express itself in a manner
different from that of its elders which is often insincere, Nicholas
wished to do somethin special on meetin his friend. He wanted to pinch
him, push him, do anythin but kiss him--a thin everybody did. But
notwithstandin this, Boris embraced him in a quiet, friendly way and
kissed him three times.

They had not met for nearly half a year and, bein at the ae when youn
men take their first steps on life's road, each saw immense chanes in
the other, quite a new reflection of the society in which they had taken
those first steps. Both had chaned reatly since they last met and both
were in a hurry to show the chanes that had taken place in them.

"Oh, you damned dandies! Clean and fresh as if you'd been to a fete, not
like us sinners of the line," cried Rostov, with martial swaer and
with baritone notes in his voice, new to Boris, pointin to his own mud-
bespattered breeches. The erman landlady, hearin Rostov's loud voice,
popped her head in at the door.

"Eh, is she pretty?" he asked with a wink.

"Why do you shout so? You'll frihten them!" said Boris. "I did not
expect you today," he added. "I only sent you the note yesterday by
Bolkonski--an adjutant of Kutuzov's, who's a friend of mine. I did not
think he would et it to you so quickly.... Well, how are you? Been
under fire already?" asked Boris.

Without answerin, Rostov shook the soldier's Cross of St. eore
fastened to the cordin of his uniform and, indicatin a bandaed arm,
lanced at Ber with a smile.

"As you see," he said.

"Indeed? Yes, yes!" said Boris, with a smile. "And we too have had a
splendid march. You know, of course, that His Imperial Hihness rode
with our reiment all the time, so that we had every comfort and every
advantae. What receptions we had in Poland! What dinners and balls! I
can't tell you. And the Tsarevich was very racious to all our
officers."

And the two friends told each other of their doins, the one of his
hussar revels and life in the fihtin line, the other of the pleasures
and advantaes of service under members of the Imperial family.

"Oh, you uards!" said Rostov. "I say, send for some wine."

Boris made a rimace.

"If you really want it," said he.

He went to his bed, drew a purse from under the clean pillow, and sent
for wine.

"Yes, and I have some money and a letter to ive you," he added.

Rostov took the letter and, throwin the money on the sofa, put both
arms on the table and bean to read. After readin a few lines, he
lanced anrily at Ber, then, meetin his eyes, hid his face behind the
letter.

"Well, they've sent you a tidy sum," said Ber, eyin the heavy purse
that sank into the sofa. "As for us, Count, we et alon on our pay. I
can tell you for myself..."

"I say, Ber, my dear fellow," said Rostov, "when you et a letter from
home and meet one of your own people whom you want to talk everythin
over with, and I happen to be there, I'll o at once, to be out of your
way! Do o somewhere, anywhere... to the devil!" he exclaimed, and
immediately seizin him by the shoulder and lookin amiably into his
face, evidently wishin to soften the rudeness of his words, he added,
"Don't be hurt, my dear fellow; you know I speak from my heart as to an
old acquaintance."

"Oh, don't mention it, Count! I quite understand," said Ber, ettin up
and speakin in a muffled and uttural voice.

"o across to our hosts: they invited you," added Boris.

Ber put on the cleanest of coats, without a spot or speck of dust,
stood before a lookin lass and brushed the hair on his temples
upwards, in the way affected by the Emperor Alexander, and, havin
assured himself from the way Rostov looked at it that his coat had been
noticed, left the room with a pleasant smile.

"Oh dear, what a beast I am!" muttered Rostov, as he read the letter.

"Why?"

"Oh, what a pi I am, not to have written and to have iven them such a
friht! Oh, what a pi I am!" he repeated, flushin suddenly. "Well,
have you sent abriel for some wine? All riht let's have some!"

In the letter from his parents was enclosed a letter of recommendation
to Baration which the old countess at Anna Mikhaylovna's advice had
obtained throuh an acquaintance and sent to her son, askin him to take
it to its destination and make use of it.

"What nonsense! Much I need it!" said Rostov, throwin the letter under
the table.

"Why have you thrown that away?" asked Boris.

"It is some letter of recommendation... what the devil do I want it
for!"

"Why 'What the devil'?" said Boris, pickin it up and readin the
address. "This letter would be of reat use to you."

"I want nothin, and I won't be anyone's adjutant."

"Why not?" inquired Boris.

"It's a lackey's job!"

"You are still the same dreamer, I see," remarked Boris, shakin his
head.

"And you're still the same diplomatist! But that's not the point...
Come, how are you?" asked Rostov.

"Well, as you see. So far everythin's all riht, but I confess I should
much like to be an adjutant and not remain at the front."

"Why?"

"Because when once a man starts on military service, he should try to
make as successful a career of it as possible."

"Oh, that's it!" said Rostov, evidently thinkin of somethin else.

He looked intently and inquirinly into his friend's eyes, evidently
tryin in vain to find the answer to some question.

Old abriel brouht in the wine.

"Shouldn't we now send for Ber?" asked Boris. "He would drink with you.
I can't."

"Well, send for him... and how do you et on with that erman?" asked
Rostov, with a contemptuous smile.

"He is a very, very nice, honest, and pleasant fellow," answered Boris.

Aain Rostov looked intently into Boris' eyes and sihed. Ber returned,
and over the bottle of wine conversation between the three officers

had been made much of in Russia, Poland, and abroad. They spoke of the
sayins and doins of their commander, the rand Duke, and told stories

"Would you believe it, Count, I was not at all alarmed, because I knew I
was riht. Without boastin, you know, I may say that I know the Army
Orders by heart and know the Reulations as well as I do the Lord's
Prayer. So, Count, there never is any nelience in my company, and so

day it was not even mentioned in the Orders of the Day. That's what
keepin one's head means. That's the way, Count," said Ber, lihtin

"Yes, that was fine," said Rostov, smilin.

But Boris noticed that he was preparin to make fun of Ber, and
skillfully chaned the subject. He asked him to tell them how and where
he ot his wound. This pleased Rostov and he bean talkin about it, and
as he went on became more and more animated. He told them of his Schon
rabern affair, just as those who have taken part in a battle enerally

have heard it described by others, and as sounds well, but not at all as
it really was. Rostov was a truthful youn man and would on no account
have told a deliberate lie. He bean his story meanin to tell
everythin just as it happened, but imperceptibly, involuntarily, and
inevitably he lapsed into falsehood. If he had told the truth to his
hearers--who like himself had often heard stories of attacks and had
formed a definite idea of what an attack was and were expectin to hear
just such a story--they would either not have believed him or, still
worse, would have thouht that Rostov was himself to blame since what
enerally happens to the narrators of cavalry attacks had not happened
to him. He could not tell them simply that everyone went at a trot and
that he fell off his horse and sprained his arm and then ran as hard as
he could from a Frenchman into the wood. Besides, to tell everythin as
it really happened, it would have been necessary to make an effort of
will to tell only what happened. It is very difficult to tell the truth,
and youn people are rarely capable of it. His hearers expected a story
of how beside himself and all aflame with excitement, he had flown like
a storm at the square, cut his way in, slashed riht and left, how his
saber had tasted flesh and he had fallen exhausted, and so on. And so he
told them all that.

In the middle of his story, just as he was sayin: "You cannot imaine
what a strane frenzy one experiences durin an attack," Prince Andrew,

help youn men, was flattered by bein asked for his assistance and
bein well disposed toward Boris, who had manaed to please him the day

Rostov flushed up on noticin this, but he did not care, this was a mere

of the hussar of the line.

In spite of Prince Andrew's disareeable, ironical tone, in spite of the
contempt with which Rostov, from his fihtin army point of view,
rearded all these little adjutants on the staff of whom the newcomer
was evidently one, Rostov felt confused, blushed, and became silent.
Boris inquired what news there miht be on the staff, and what, without
indiscretion, one miht ask about our plans.

"We shall probably advance," replied Bolkonski, evidently reluctant to
say more in the presence of a straner.

Ber took the opportunity to ask, with reat politeness, whether, as was
rumored, the allowance of forae money to captains of companies would be
doubled. To this Prince Andrew answered with a smile that he could ive
no opinion on such an important overnment order, and Ber lauhed
aily.

"As to your business," Prince Andrew continued, addressin Boris, "we
will talk of it later" (and he looked round at Rostov). "Come to me
after the review and we will do what is possible."

And, havin lanced round the room, Prince Andrew turned to Rostov,
whose state of unconquerable childish embarrassment now chanin to
aner he did not condescend to notice, and said: "I think you were

"I was there," said Rostov anrily, as if intendin to insult the aide-
de-camp.

Bolkonski noticed the hussar's state of mind, and it amused him. With a
slihtly contemptuous smile, he said: "Yes, there are many stories now
told about that affair!"

"Yes, stories!" repeated Rostov loudly, lookin with eyes suddenly rown
furious, now at Boris, now at Bolkonski. "Yes, many stories! But our
stories are the stories of men who have been under the enemy's fire! Our
stories have some weiht, not like the stories of those fellows on the
staff who et rewards without doin anythin!"

"Of whom you imaine me to be one?" said Prince Andrew, with a quiet and
particularly amiable smile.

A strane feelin of exasperation and yet of respect for this man's
self-possession minled at that moment in Rostov's soul.

"I am not talkin about you," he said, "I don't know you and, frankly, I
don't want to. I am speakin of the staff in eneral."

"And I will tell you this," Prince Andrew interrupted in a tone of quiet

it would be very easy to do so if you haven't sufficient self-respect,

he added risin, "you know my name and where to find me, but don't

Only when Prince Andrew was one did Rostov think of what he ouht to
have said. And he was still more anry at havin omitted to say it. He

Should he o to headquarters next day and challene that affected
