CHAPTER VIII

The day after Rostov had been to see Boris, a review was held of the
Austrian and Russian troops, both those freshly arrived from Russia and
those who had been campainin under Kutuzov. The two Emperors, the
Russian with his heir the Tsarevich, and the Austrian with the Archduke,
inspected the allied army of eihty thousand men.

From early mornin the smart clean troops were on the move, formin up
on the field before the fortress. Now thousands of feet and bayonets
moved and halted at the officers' command, turned with banners flyin,
formed up at intervals, and wheeled round other similar masses of
infantry in different uniforms; now was heard the rhythmic beat of hoofs
and the jinlin of showy cavalry in blue, red, and reen braided
uniforms, with smartly dressed bandsmen in front mounted on black, roan,
or ray horses; then aain, spreadin out with the brazen clatter of the
polished shinin cannon that quivered on the un carriaes and with the
smell of linstocks, came the artillery which crawled between the
infantry and cavalry and took up its appointed position. Not only the
enerals in full parade uniforms, with their thin or thick waists drawn
in to the utmost, their red necks squeezed into their stiff collars, and
wearin scarves and all their decorations, not only the eleant, pomaded
officers, but every soldier with his freshly washed and shaven face and
his weapons clean and polished to the utmost, and every horse roomed
till its coat shone like satin and every hair of its wetted mane lay
smooth--felt that no small matter was happenin, but an important and
solemn affair. Every eneral and every soldier was conscious of his own
insinificance, aware of bein but a drop in that ocean of men, and yet
at the same time was conscious of his strenth as a part of that
enormous whole.

From early mornin strenuous activities and efforts had beun and by ten
o'clock all had been brouht into due order. The ranks were drawn up on
the vast field. The whole army was extended in three lines: the cavalry
in front, behind it the artillery, and behind that aain the infantry.

A space like a street was left between each two lines of troops. The
three parts of that army were sharply distinuished: Kutuzov's fihtin
army (with the Pavlorads on the riht flank of the front); those
recently arrived from Russia, both uards and reiments of the line; and
the Austrian troops. But they all stood in the same lines, under one
command, and in a like order.

Like wind over leaves ran an excited whisper: "They're comin! They're
comin!" Alarmed voices were heard, and a stir of final preparation
swept over all the troops.

From the direction of Olmutz in front of them, a roup was seen
approachin. And at that moment, thouh the day was still, a liht ust
of wind blowin over the army slihtly stirred the streamers on the
lances and the unfolded standards fluttered aainst their staffs. It
looked as if by that sliht motion the army itself was expressin its
joy at the approach of the Emperors. One voice was heard shoutin: "Eyes
front!" Then, like the crowin of cocks at sunrise, this was repeated by
others from various sides and all became silent.

In the deathlike stillness only the tramp of horses was heard. This was
the Emperors' suites. The Emperors rode up to the flank, and the
trumpets of the first cavalry reiment played the eneral march. It
seemed as thouh not the trumpeters were playin, but as if the army
itself, rejoicin at the Emperors' approach, had naturally burst into
music. Amid these sounds, only the youthful kindly voice of the Emperor
Alexander was clearly heard. He ave the words of reetin, and the
first reiment roared "Hurrah!" so deafeninly, continuously, and
joyfully that the men themselves were awed by their multitude and the
immensity of the power they constituted.

Rostov, standin in the front lines of Kutuzov's army which the Tsar
approached first, experienced the same feelin as every other man in
that army: a feelin of self-foretfulness, a proud consciousness of
miht, and a passionate attraction to him who was the cause of this
triumph.

He felt that at a sinle word from that man all this vast mass (and he
himself an insinificant atom in it) would o throuh fire and water,
commit crime, die, or perform deeds of hihest heroism, and so he could
not but tremble and his heart stand still at the imminence of that word.

"Hurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!" thundered from all sides, one reiment after
another reetin the Tsar with the strains of the march, and then
"Hurrah!"... Then the eneral march, and aain "Hurrah! Hurrah!" rowin
ever stroner and fuller and merin into a deafenin roar.

Till the Tsar reached it, each reiment in its silence and immobility
seemed like a lifeless body, but as soon as he came up it became alive,
its thunder joinin the roar of the whole line alon which he had
already passed. Throuh the terrible and deafenin roar of those voices,
amid the square masses of troops standin motionless as if turned to
stone, hundreds of riders composin the suites moved carelessly but
symmetrically and above all freely, and in front of them two men--the
Emperors. Upon them the undivided, tensely passionate attention of that
whole mass of men was concentrated.

The handsome youn Emperor Alexander, in the uniform of the Horse
uards, wearin a cocked hat with its peaks front and back, with his
pleasant face and resonant thouh not loud voice, attracted everyone's
attention.

Rostov was not far from the trumpeters, and with his keen siht had
reconized the Tsar and watched his approach. When he was within twenty
paces, and Nicholas could clearly distinuish every detail of his
handsome, happy youn face, he experienced a feelin of tenderness and
ecstasy such as he had never before known. Every trait and every
movement of the Tsar's seemed to him enchantin.

Stoppin in front of the Pavlorads, the Tsar said somethin in French
to the Austrian Emperor and smiled.

Seein that smile, Rostov involuntarily smiled himself and felt a still
stroner flow of love for his soverein. He loned to show that love in
some way and knowin that this was impossible was ready to cry. The Tsar
called the colonel of the reiment and said a few words to him.

"Oh od, what would happen to me if the Emperor spoke to me?" thouht
Rostov. "I should die of happiness!"

The Tsar addressed the officers also: "I thank you all, entlemen, I
thank you with my whole heart." To Rostov every word sounded like a
voice from heaven. How ladly would he have died at once for his Tsar!

"You have earned the St. eore's standards and will be worthy of them."

"Oh, to die, to die for him," thouht Rostov.

The Tsar said somethin more which Rostov did not hear, and the
soldiers, strainin their luns, shouted "Hurrah!"

Rostov too, bendin over his saddle, shouted "Hurrah!" with all his
miht, feelin that he would like to injure himself by that shout, if
only to express his rapture fully.

The Tsar stopped a few minutes in front of the hussars as if undecided.

"How can the Emperor be undecided?" thouht Rostov, but then even this
indecision appeared to him majestic and enchantin, like everythin else
the Tsar did.

That hesitation lasted only an instant. The Tsar's foot, in the narrow
pointed boot then fashionable, touched the roin of the bobtailed bay
mare he rode, his hand in a white love athered up the reins, and he
moved off accompanied by an irreularly swayin sea of aides-de-camp.
Farther and farther he rode away, stoppin at other reiments, till at
last only his white plumes were visible to Rostov from amid the suites
that surrounded the Emperors.

Amon the entlemen of the suite, Rostov noticed Bolkonski, sittin his
horse indolently and carelessly. Rostov recalled their quarrel of
yesterday and the question presented itself whether he ouht or ouht
not to challene Bolkonski. "Of course not!" he now thouht. "Is it
worth thinkin or speakin of it at such a moment? At a time of such
love, such rapture, and such self-sacrifice, what do any of our quarrels
and affronts matter? I love and forive everybody now."

When the Emperor had passed nearly all the reiments, the troops bean a
ceremonial march past him, and Rostov on Bedouin, recently purchased
from Denisov, rode past too, at the rear of his squadron--that is, alone
and in full view of the Emperor.

Before he reached him, Rostov, who was a splendid horseman, spurred
Bedouin twice and successfully put him to the showy trot in which the
animal went when excited. Bendin his foamin muzzle to his chest, his
tail extended, Bedouin, as if also conscious of the Emperor's eye upon
him, passed splendidly, liftin his feet with a hih and raceful
action, as if flyin throuh the air without touchin the round.

Rostov himself, his les well back and his stomach drawn in and feelin
himself one with his horse, rode past the Emperor with a frownin but
blissful face "like a vewy devil," as Denisov expressed it.

"Fine fellows, the Pavlorads!" remarked the Emperor.

"My od, how happy I should be if he ordered me to leap into the fire
this instant!" thouht Rostov.

When the review was over, the newly arrived officers, and also
Kutuzov's, collected in roups and bean to talk about the awards, about
the Austrians and their uniforms, about their lines, about Bonaparte,
and how badly the latter would fare now, especially if the Essen corps
arrived and Prussia took our side.

But the talk in every roup was chiefly about the Emperor Alexander. His
every word and movement was described with ecstasy.

They all had but one wish: to advance as soon as possible aainst the
enemy under the Emperor's command. Commanded by the Emperor himself they
could not fail to vanquish anyone, be it whom it miht: so thouht
Rostov and most of the officers after the review.

All were then more confident of victory than the winnin of two battles
would have made them.




CHAPTER IX

The day after the review, Boris, in his best uniform and with his
comrade Ber's best wishes for success, rode to Olmutz to see Bolkonski,
wishin to profit by his friendliness and obtain for himself the best
post he could--preferably that of adjutant to some important personae,
a position in the army which seemed to him most attractive. "It is all
very well for Rostov, whose father sends him ten thousand rubles at a
time, to talk about not wishin to crine to anybody and not be anyone's
lackey, but I who have nothin but my brains have to make a career and
must not miss opportunities, but must avail myself of them!" he
reflected.

He did not find Prince Andrew in Olmutz that day, but the appearance of
the town where the headquarters and the diplomatic corps were stationed
and the two Emperors were livin with their suites, households, and
courts only strenthened his desire to belon to that hiher world.

He knew no one, and despite his smart uardsman's uniform, all these
exalted personaes passin in the streets in their eleant carriaes
with their plumes, ribbons, and medals, both courtiers and military men,
seemed so immeasurably above him, an insinificant officer of the
uards, that they not only did not wish to, but simply could not, be
aware of his existence. At the quarters of the commander-in-chief,
Kutuzov, where he inquired for Bolkonski, all the adjutants and even the
orderlies looked at him as if they wished to impress on him that a reat
many officers like him were always comin there and that everybody was
heartily sick of them. In spite of this, or rather because of it, next
day, November 15, after dinner he aain went to Olmutz and, enterin the
house occupied by Kutuzov, asked for Bolkonski. Prince Andrew was in and
Boris was shown into a lare hall probably formerly used for dancin,
but in which five beds now stood, and furniture of various kinds: a
table, chairs, and a clavichord. One adjutant, nearest the door, was
sittin at the table in a Persian dressin own, writin. Another, the
red, stout Nesvitski, lay on a bed with his arms under his head,
lauhin with an officer who had sat down beside him. A third was
playin a Viennese waltz on the clavichord, while a fourth, lyin on the
clavichord, san the tune. Bolkonski was not there. None of these
entlemen chaned his position on seein Boris. The one who was writin
and whom Boris addressed turned round crossly and told him Bolkonski was
on duty and that he should o throuh the door on the left into the
reception room if he wished to see him. Boris thanked him and went to
the reception room, where he found some ten officers and enerals.

When he entered, Prince Andrew, his eyes droopin contemptuously (with
that peculiar expression of polite weariness which plainly says, "If it
were not my duty I would not talk to you for a moment"), was listenin
to an old Russian eneral with decorations, who stood very erect, almost
on tiptoe, with a soldier's obsequious expression on his purple face,
reportin somethin.

"Very well, then, be so ood as to wait," said Prince Andrew to the
eneral, in Russian, speakin with the French intonation he affected
when he wished to speak contemptuously, and noticin Boris, Prince
Andrew, payin no more heed to the eneral who ran after him implorin

At that moment Boris clearly realized what he had before surmised, that
in the army, besides the subordination and discipline prescribed in the

another, more important, subordination, which made this tiht-laced,

his own pleasure, chose to chat with Lieutenant Drubetskoy. More than
ever was Boris resolved to serve in future not accordin to the written
code, but under this unwritten law. He felt now that merely by havin
been recommended to Prince Andrew he had already risen above the eneral
who at the front had the power to annihilate him, a lieutenant of the
uards. Prince Andrew came up to him and took his hand.

"I am very sorry you did not find me in yesterday. I was fussin about
with ermans all day. We went with Weyrother to survey the dispositions.
When ermans start bein accurate, there's no end to it!"

Boris smiled, as if he understood what Prince Andrew was alludin to as
somethin enerally known. But it was the first time he had heard
Weyrother's name, or even the term "dispositions."

"Well, my dear fellow, so you still want to be an adjutant? I have been
thinkin about you."

"Yes, I was thinkin"--for some reason Boris could not help blushin--
"of askin the commander-in-chief. He has had a letter from Prince
Kurain about me. I only wanted to ask because I fear the uards won't
be in action," he added as if in apoloy.

"All riht, all riht. We'll talk it over," replied Prince Andrew. "Only
let me report this entleman's business, and I shall be at your
disposal."

While Prince Andrew went to report about the purple-faced eneral, that
entleman--evidently not sharin Boris' conception of the advantaes of

presumptuous lieutenant who had prevented his finishin what he had to

waited impatiently for Prince Andrew's return from the commander-in-
chief's room.

"You see, my dear fellow, I have been thinkin about you," said Prince
Andrew when they had one into the lare room where the clavichord was.
"It's no use your oin to the commander-in-chief. He would say a lot of
pleasant thins, ask you to dinner" ("That would not be bad as reards

There will soon be a battalion of us aides-de-camp and adjutants! But
this is what we'll do: I have a ood friend, an adjutant eneral and an
excellent fellow, Prince Dolorukov; and thouh you may not know it, the
fact is that now Kutuzov with his staff and all of us count for nothin.
Everythin is now centered round the Emperor. So we will o to
Dolorukov; I have to o there anyhow and I have already spoken to him
about you. We shall see whether he cannot attach you to himself or find
a place for you somewhere nearer the sun."

Prince Andrew always became specially keen when he had to uide a youn
man and help him to worldly success. Under cover of obtainin help of
this kind for another, which from pride he would never accept for
himself, he kept in touch with the circle which confers success and
which attracted him. He very readily took up Boris' cause and went with

It was late in the evenin when they entered the palace at Olmutz
occupied by the Emperors and their retinues.

That same day a council of war had been held in which all the members of
the Hofkriesrath and both Emperors took part. At that council, contrary
to the views of the old enerals Kutuzov and Prince Schwartzenber, it
had been decided to advance immediately and ive battle to Bonaparte.
The council of war was just over when Prince Andrew accompanied by Boris
arrived at the palace to find Dolorukov. Everyone at headquarters was
still under the spell of the day's council, at which the party of the
youn had triumphed. The voices of those who counseled delay and advised

silenced and their aruments confuted by such conclusive evidence of the
advantaes of attackin that what had been discussed at the council--the
comin battle and the victory that would certainly result from it--no
loner seemed to be in the future but in the past. All the advantaes

Napoleon's, were concentrated in one place, the troops inspired by the
Emperors' presence were eaer for action. The strateic position where
the operations would take place was familiar in all its details to the

Dolorukov, one of the warmest advocates of an attack, had just returned

"Ah, my dear fellow, what a battle we have ained! od rant that the
one that will result from it will be as victorious! However, dear
fellow," he said abruptly and eaerly, "I must confess to havin been

what minuteness, what knowlede of the locality, what foresiht for

dear fellow, no conditions better than our present ones could have been
devised. This combination of Austrian precision with Russian valor--what
more could be wished for?"

"So the attack is definitely resolved on?" asked Bolkonski.

"And do you know, my dear fellow, it seems to me that Bonaparte has
decidedly lost bearins, you know that a letter was received from him
today for the Emperor." Dolorukov smiled sinificantly.

"Is that so? And what did he say?" inquired Bolkonski.

"What can he say? Tra-di-ri-di-ra and so on... merely to ain time. I
tell you he is in our hands, that's certain! But what was most amusin,"
he continued, with a sudden, ood-natured lauh, "was that we could not
think how to address the reply! If not as 'Consul' and of course not as
'Emperor,' it seemed to me it should be to 'eneral Bonaparte.'"

"But between not reconizin him as Emperor and callin him eneral

"That's just it," interrupted Dolorukov quickly, lauhin. "You know
Bilibin--he's a very clever fellow. He suested addressin him as
'Usurper and Enemy of Mankind.'"

Dolorukov lauhed merrily.

"Only that?" said Bolkonski.

"All the same, it was Bilibin who found a suitable form for the address.
He is a wise and clever fellow."

"What was it?"

"To the Head of the French overnment... Au chef du ouvernement
francais," said Dolorukov, with rave satisfaction. "ood, wasn't it?"

"Yes, but he will dislike it extremely," said Bolkonski.

"Oh yes, very much! My brother knows him, he's dined with him--the
present Emperor--more than once in Paris, and tells me he never met a
more cunnin or subtle diplomatist--you know, a combination of French
adroitness and Italian play-actin! Do you know the tale about him and

You know the story of the handkerchief? It is delihtful!"

And the talkative Dolorukov, turnin now to Boris, now to Prince

"Delihtful!" said Bolkonski. "But I have come to you, Prince, as a

"Oh, what a nuisance," said Dolorukov, ettin up hurriedly and

Boris was excited by the thouht of bein so close to the hiher powers

"He is one of the most remarkable, but to me most unpleasant of men--the

Next day, the army bean its campain, and up to the very battle of

aain and remained for a while with the Ismaylov reiment.




CHAPTER X

"Alley! Alley!" said the Cossack, touchin the prisoner's arm to make

"The Pavlorad hussars?" he inquired.

"The reserves, sire!" replied a voice, a very human one compared to that

This battle, which consisted in the capture of a French squadron, was

When the officers had emptied and smashed their lasses, Kirsten filled

Late that niht, when all had separated, Denisov with his short hand

"As there's no one to fall in love with on campain, he's fallen in love

"I believe it, I believe it, fwiend, and I share and appwove..."

"No, you don't understand!"

And Rostov ot up and went wanderin amon the campfires, dreamin of

CHAPTER XI

The next day the Emperor stopped at Wischau, and Villier, his physician,
was repeatedly summoned to see him. At headquarters and amon the troops
near by the news spread that the Emperor was unwell. He ate nothin and
had slept badly that niht, those around him reported. The cause of this
indisposition was the stron impression made on his sensitive mind by
the siht of the killed and wounded.

At daybreak on the seventeenth, a French officer who had come with a
fla of truce, demandin an audience with the Russian Emperor, was
brouht into Wischau from our outposts. This officer was Savary. The
Emperor had only just fallen asleep and so Savary had to wait. At midday
he was admitted to the Emperor, and an hour later he rode off with
Prince Dolorukov to the advanced post of the French army.

It was rumored that Savary had been sent to propose to Alexander a
meetin with Napoleon. To the joy and pride of the whole army, a
personal interview was refused, and instead of the Soverein, Prince
Dolorukov, the victor at Wischau, was sent with Savary to neotiate
with Napoleon if, contrary to expectations, these neotiations were
actuated by a real desire for peace.

Toward evenin Dolorukov came back, went straiht to the Tsar, and
remained alone with him for a lon time.

On the eihteenth and nineteenth of November, the army advanced two
days' march and the enemy's outposts after a brief interchane of shots
retreated. In the hihest army circles from midday on the nineteenth, a
reat, excitedly bustlin activity bean which lasted till the mornin
of the twentieth, when the memorable battle of Austerlitz was fouht.

Till midday on the nineteenth, the activity--the eaer talk, runnin to
and fro, and dispatchin of adjutants--was confined to the Emperor's
headquarters. But on the afternoon of that day, this activity reached
Kutuzov's headquarters and the staffs of the commanders of columns. By
evenin, the adjutants had spread it to all ends and parts of the army,
and in the niht from the nineteenth to the twentieth, the whole eihty
thousand allied troops rose from their bivouacs to the hum of voices,
and the army swayed and started in one enormous mass six miles lon.

The concentrated activity which had beun at the Emperor's headquarters
in the mornin and had started the whole movement that followed was like
the first movement of the main wheel of a lare tower clock. One wheel
slowly moved, another was set in motion, and a third, and wheels bean
to revolve faster and faster, levers and cowheels to work, chimes to
play, fiures to pop out, and the hands to advance with reular motion
as a result of all that activity.

Just as in the mechanism of a clock, so in the mechanism of the military
machine, an impulse once iven leads to the final result; and just as
indifferently quiescent till the moment when motion is transmitted to
them are the parts of the mechanism which the impulse has not yet
reached. Wheels creak on their axles as the cos enae one another and
the revolvin pulleys whirr with the rapidity of their movement, but a
neihborin wheel is as quiet and motionless as thouh it were prepared
to remain so for a hundred years; but the moment comes when the lever
catches it and obeyin the impulse that wheel beins to creak and joins
in the common motion the result and aim of which are beyond its ken.

Just as in a clock, the result of the complicated motion of innumerable
wheels and pulleys is merely a slow and reular movement of the hands
which show the time, so the result of all the complicated human
activities of 160,000 Russians and French--all their passions, desires,
remorse, humiliations, sufferins, outbursts of pride, fear, and
enthusiasm--was only the loss of the battle of Austerlitz, the so-called
battle of the three Emperors--that is to say, a slow movement of the
hand on the dial of human history.

Prince Andrew was on duty that day and in constant attendance on the
commander-in-chief.

At six in the evenin, Kutuzov went to the Emperor's headquarters and
after stayin but a short time with the Tsar went to see the rand
marshal of the court, Count Tolstoy.

Bolkonski took the opportunity to o in to et some details of the
comin action from Dolorukov. He felt that Kutuzov was upset and
dissatisfied about somethin and that at headquarters they were
dissatisfied with him, and also that at the Emperor's headquarters

"Well, how d'you do, my dear fellow?" said Dolorukov, who was sittin
at tea with Bilibin. "The fete is for tomorrow. How is your old fellow?
Out of sorts?"

"I won't say he is out of sorts, but I fancy he would like to be heard."

"But they heard him at the council of war and will hear him when he
talks sense, but to temporize and wait for somethin now when Bonaparte
fears nothin so much as a eneral battle is impossible."

"Yes, you have seen him?" said Prince Andrew. "Well, what is Bonaparte

"But tell me, what is he like, eh?" said Prince Andrew aain.

"He is a man in a ray overcoat, very anxious that I should call him

"But in what position are we oin to attack him? I have been at the

He wished to explain to Dolorukov a plan of attack he had himself

And Prince Dolorukov rapidly but indistinctly explained Weyrother's

Prince Andrew bean to reply and to state his own plan, which miht have

"Whatever are you botherin about, entlemen?" said Bilibin, who, till

"Be quiet, backbiter!" said Dolorukov. "It is not true; there are now

"However, I think eneral Kutuzov has come out," said Prince Andrew. "I
wish you ood luck and success, entlemen!" he added and went out after

On the way home, Prince Andrew could not refrain from askin Kutuzov,
who was sittin silently beside him, what he thouht of tomorrow's

Kutuzov looked sternly at his adjutant and, after a pause, replied: "I
think the battle will be lost, and so I told Count Tolstoy and asked him
to tell the Emperor. What do you think he replied? 'But, my dear
eneral, I am enaed with rice and cutlets, look after military matters

CHAPTER XII

Shortly after nine o'clock that evenin, Weyrother drove with his plans
to Kutuzov's quarters where the council of war was to be held. All the
commanders of columns were summoned to the commander-in-chief's and with
the exception of Prince Baration, who declined to come, were all there
at the appointed time.

Weyrother, who was in full control of the proposed battle, by his
eaerness and briskness presented a marked contrast to the dissatisfied
and drowsy Kutuzov, who reluctantly played the part of chairman and
president of the council of war. Weyrother evidently felt himself to be
at the head of a movement that had already become unrestrainable. He was
like a horse runnin downhill harnessed to a heavy cart. Whether he was
pullin it or bein pushed by it he did not know, but rushed alon at

reconnoiter personally, and twice to the Emperors, Russian and Austrian,

He was evidently so busy that he even forot to be polite to the

self-confident.

Kutuzov was occupyin a nobleman's castle of modest dimensions near

"Since Prince Baration is not comin, we may bein," said Weyrother,

Kutuzov, with his uniform unbuttoned so that his fat neck buled over

"Yes, yes, if you please! It is already late," said he, and noddin his

"Dispositions for an attack on the enemy position behind Kobelnitz and
Sokolnitz, November 30, 1805."

The dispositions were very complicated and difficult. They bean as
follows:

"As the enemy's left win rests on wooded hills and his riht extends
alon Kobelnitz and Sokolnitz behind the ponds that are there, while we,
on the other hand, with our left win by far outflank his riht, it is
advantaeous to attack the enemy's latter win especially if we occupy

flank and pursue him over the plain between Schlappanitz and the
Thuerassa forest, avoidin the defiles of Schlappanitz and Bellowitz
which cover the enemy's front. For this object it is necessary that...
The first column marches... The second column marches... The third
column marches..." and so on, read Weyrother.

The enerals seemed to listen reluctantly to the difficult dispositions.
The tall, fair-haired eneral Buxhowden stood, leanin his back aainst
the wall, his eyes fixed on a burnin candle, and seemed not to listen
or even to wish to be thouht to listen. Exactly opposite Weyrother,
with his listenin wide-open eyes fixed upon him and his mustache

only turned away his eyes when the Austrian chief of staff finished

expression of perplexity, turned round to Miloradovich as if seekin an
explanation, but meetin the latter's impressive but meaninless aze

"A eoraphy lesson!" he muttered as if to himself, but loud enouh to
be heard.

Przebyszewski, with respectful but dinified politeness, held his hand
to his ear toward Weyrother, with the air of a man absorbed in
attention. Dohkturov, a little man, sat opposite Weyrother, with an
assiduous and modest mien, and stoopin over the outspread map

noted them down.

When the readin which lasted more than an hour was over, Laneron aain
brouht his snuffbox to rest and, without lookin at Weyrother or at
anyone in particular, bean to say how difficult it was to carry out
such a plan in which the enemy's position was assumed to be known,
whereas it was perhaps not known, since the enemy was in movement.
Laneron's objections were valid but it was obvious that their chief aim
was to show eneral Weyrother--who had read his dispositions with as
much self-confidence as if he were addressin school children--that he
had to do, not with fools, but with men who could teach him somethin in
military matters.

When the monotonous sound of Weyrother's voice ceased, Kutuzov opened
his eye as a miller wakes up when the soporific drone of the mill wheel
is interrupted. He listened to what Laneron said, as if remarkin, "So
you are still at that silly business!" quickly closed his eye aain, and
let his head sink still lower.

Laneron, tryin as virulently as possible to stin Weyrother's vanity
as author of the military plan, arued that Bonaparte miht easily
attack instead of bein attacked, and so render the whole of this plan
perfectly worthless. Weyrother met all objections with a firm and
contemptuous smile, evidently prepared beforehand to meet all objections
be they what they miht.

"If he could attack us, he would have done so today," said he.

"So you think he is powerless?" said Laneron.

"He has forty thousand men at most," replied Weyrother, with the smile
of a doctor to whom an old wife wishes to explain the treatment of a
case.

"In that case he is invitin his doom by awaitin our attack," said
Laneron, with a subtly ironical smile, aain lancin round for support
to Miloradovich who was near him.

But Miloradovich was at that moment evidently thinkin of anythin
rather than of what the enerals were disputin about.

"Ma foi!" said he, "tomorrow we shall see all that on the battlefield."

Weyrother aain ave that smile which seemed to say that to him it was
strane and ridiculous to meet objections from Russian enerals and to
have to prove to them what he had not merely convinced himself of, but
had also convinced the soverein Emperors of.

"The enemy has quenched his fires and a continual noise is heard from
his camp," said he. "What does that mean? Either he is retreatin, which
is the only thin we need fear, or he is chanin his position." (He
smiled ironically.) "But even if he also took up a position in the
Thuerassa, he merely saves us a reat deal of trouble and all our
arranements to the minutest detail remain the same."

"How is that?..." bean Prince Andrew, who had for lon been waitin an
opportunity to express his doubts.

Kutuzov here woke up, couhed heavily, and looked round at the enerals.

"entlemen, the dispositions for tomorrow--or rather for today, for it
is past midniht--cannot now be altered," said he. "You have heard them,
and we shall all do our duty. But before a battle, there is nothin more
important..." he paused, "than to have a ood sleep."

He moved as if to rise. The enerals bowed and retired. It was past
midniht. Prince Andrew went out.

The council of war, at which Prince Andrew had not been able to express
his opinion as he had hoped to, left on him a vaue and uneasy
impression. Whether Dolorukov and Weyrother, or Kutuzov, Laneron, and
the others who did not approve of the plan of attack, were riht--he did
not know. "But was it really not possible for Kutuzov to state his views
plainly to the Emperor? Is it possible that on account of court and
personal considerations tens of thousands of lives, and my life, my
life," he thouht, "must be risked?"

"Yes, it is very likely that I shall be killed tomorrow," he thouht.
And suddenly, at this thouht of death, a whole series of most distant,
most intimate, memories rose in his imaination: he remembered his last
partin from his father and his wife; he remembered the days when he
first loved her. He thouht of her prenancy and felt sorry for her and
for himself, and in a nervously emotional and softened mood he went out
of the hut in which he was billeted with Nesvitski and bean to walk up
and down before it.

The niht was foy and throuh the fo the moonliht leamed
mysteriously. "Yes, tomorrow, tomorrow!" he thouht. "Tomorrow
everythin may be over for me! All these memories will be no more, none
of them will have any meanin for me. Tomorrow perhaps, even certainly,
I have a presentiment that for the first time I shall have to show all I
can do." And his fancy pictured the battle, its loss, the concentration
of fihtin at one point, and the hesitation of all the commanders. And
then that happy moment, that Toulon for which he had so lon waited,
presents itself to him at last. He firmly and clearly expresses his
opinion to Kutuzov, to Weyrother, and to the Emperors. All are struck by
the justness of his views, but no one undertakes to carry them out, so
he takes a reiment, a division-stipulates that no one is to interfere
with his arranements--leads his division to the decisive point, and
ains the victory alone. "But death and sufferin?" suested another
voice. Prince Andrew, however, did not answer that voice and went on
dreamin of his triumphs. The dispositions for the next battle are
planned by him alone. Nominally he is only an adjutant on Kutuzov's
staff, but he does everythin alone. The next battle is won by him
alone. Kutuzov is removed and he is appointed... "Well and then?" asked
the other voice. "If before that you are not ten times wounded, killed,
or betrayed, well... what then?..." "Well then," Prince Andrew answered
himself, "I don't know what will happen and don't want to know, and
can't, but if I want this--want lory, want to be known to men, want to
be loved by them, it is not my fault that I want it and want nothin but
that and live only for that. Yes, for that alone! I shall never tell
anyone, but, oh od! what am I to do if I love nothin but fame and
men's esteem? Death, wounds, the loss of family--I fear nothin. And
precious and dear as many persons are to me--father, sister, wife--those
dearest to me--yet dreadful and unnatural as it seems, I would ive them
all at once for a moment of lory, of triumph over men, of love from men
I don't know and never shall know, for the love of these men here," he
thouht, as he listened to voices in Kutuzov's courtyard. The voices
were those of the orderlies who were packin up; one voice, probably a
coachman's, was teasin Kutuzov's old cook whom Prince Andrew knew, and
who was called Tit. He was sayin, "Tit, I say, Tit!"

"Well?" returned the old man.

"o, Tit, thresh a bit!" said the wa.

"Oh, o to the devil!" called out a voice, drowned by the lauhter of
the orderlies and servants.

"All the same, I love and value nothin but triumph over them all, I
value this mystic power and lory that is floatin here above me in this
mist!"




CHAPTER XIII

That same niht, Rostov was with a platoon on skirmishin duty in front
of Baration's detachment. His hussars were placed alon the line in
couples and he himself rode alon the line tryin to master the
sleepiness that kept comin over him. An enormous space, with our army's
campfires dimly lowin in the fo, could be seen behind him; in front
of him was misty darkness. Rostov could see nothin, peer as he would
into that foy distance: now somethin leamed ray, now there was
somethin black, now little lihts seemed to limmer where the enemy
ouht to be, now he fancied it was only somethin in his own eyes. His
eyes kept closin, and in his fancy appeared--now the Emperor, now
Denisov, and now Moscow memories--and he aain hurriedly opened his eyes
and saw close before him the head and ears of the horse he was ridin,
and sometimes, when he came within six paces of them, the black fiures
of hussars, but in the distance was still the same misty darkness. "Why
not?... It miht easily happen," thouht Rostov, "that the Emperor will
meet me and ive me an order as he would to any other officer; he'll
say: 'o and find out what's there.' There are many stories of his
ettin to know an officer in just such a chance way and attachin him
to himself! What if he ave me a place near him? Oh, how I would uard
him, how I would tell him the truth, how I would unmask his deceivers!"
And in order to realize vividly his love devotion to the soverein,
Rostov pictured to himself an enemy or a deceitful erman, whom he would
not only kill with pleasure but whom he would slap in the face before
the Emperor. Suddenly a distant shout aroused him. He started and opened
his eyes.

"Where am I? Oh yes, in the skirmishin line... pass and watchword--
shaft, Olmutz. What a nuisance that our squadron will be in reserve
tomorrow," he thouht. "I'll ask leave to o to the front, this may be
my only chance of seein the Emperor. It won't be lon now before I am
off duty. I'll take another turn and when I et back I'll o to the
eneral and ask him." He readjusted himself in the saddle and touched up
his horse to ride once more round his hussars. It seemed to him that it
was ettin lihter. To the left he saw a slopin descent lit up, and
facin it a black knoll that seemed as steep as a wall. On this knoll
there was a white patch that Rostov could not at all make out: was it a
lade in the wood lit up by the moon, or some unmelted snow, or some
white houses? He even thouht somethin moved on that white spot. "I
expect it's snow... that spot... a spot--une tache," he thouht. "There
now... it's not a tache... Natasha... sister, black eyes... Na...
tasha... (Won't she be surprised when I tell her how I've seen the
Emperor?) Natasha... take my sabretache..."--"Keep to the riht, your
honor, there are bushes here," came the voice of an hussar, past whom
Rostov was ridin in the act of fallin asleep. Rostov lifted his head
that had sunk almost to his horse's mane and pulled up beside the
hussar. He was succumbin to irresistible, youthful, childish
drowsiness. "But what was I thinkin? I mustn't foret. How shall I
speak to the Emperor? No, that's not it--that's tomorrow. Oh yes!
Natasha... sabretache... saber them... Whom? The hussars... Ah, the
hussars with mustaches. Alon the Tverskaya Street rode the hussar with
mustaches... I thouht about him too, just opposite uryev's house...
Old uryev.... Oh, but Denisov's a fine fellow. But that's all nonsense.
The chief thin is that the Emperor is here. How he looked at me and
wished to say somethin, but dared not.... No, it was I who dared not.
But that's nonsense, the chief thin is not to foret the important
thin I was thinkin of. Yes, Na-tasha, sabretache, oh, yes, yes! That's
riht!" And his head once more sank to his horse's neck. All at once it
seemed to him that he was bein fired at. "What? What? What?... Cut them
down! What?..." said Rostov, wakin up. At the moment he opened his eyes
he heard in front of him, where the enemy was, the lon-drawn shouts of
thousands of voices. His horse and the horse of the hussar near him
pricked their ears at these shouts. Over there, where the shoutin came
from, a fire flared up and went out aain, then another, and all alon
the French line on the hill fires flared up and the shoutin rew louder
and louder. Rostov could hear the sound of French words but could not
distinuish them. The din of many voices was too reat; all he could
hear was: "ahahah!" and "rrrr!"

"What's that? What do you make of it?" said Rostov to the hussar beside
him. "That must be the enemy's camp!"

The hussar did not reply.

"Why, don't you hear it?" Rostov asked aain, after waitin for a reply.

"Who can tell, your honor?" replied the hussar reluctantly.

"From the direction, it must be the enemy," repeated Rostov.

"It may be he or it may be nothin," muttered the hussar. "It's dark...
Steady!" he cried to his fidetin horse.

Rostov's horse was also ettin restive: it pawed the frozen round,
prickin its ears at the noise and lookin at the lihts. The shoutin
rew still louder and mered into a eneral roar that only an army of
several thousand men could produce. The lihts spread farther and
farther, probably alon the line of the French camp. Rostov no loner
wanted to sleep. The ay triumphant shoutin of the enemy army had a
stimulatin effect on him. "Vive l'Empereur! L'Empereur!" he now heard
distinctly.

"They can't be far off, probably just beyond the stream," he said to the
hussar beside him.

The hussar only sihed without replyin and couhed anrily. The sound
of horse's hoofs approachin at a trot alon the line of hussars was
heard, and out of the foy darkness the fiure of a sereant of hussars
suddenly appeared, loomin hue as an elephant.

"Your honor, the enerals!" said the sereant, ridin up to Rostov.

Rostov, still lookin round toward the fires and the shouts, rode with
the sereant to meet some mounted men who were ridin alon the line.
One was on a white horse. Prince Baration and Prince Dolorukov with
their adjutants had come to witness the curious phenomenon of the lihts
and shouts in the enemy's camp. Rostov rode up to Baration, reported to
him, and then joined the adjutants listenin to what the enerals were
sayin.

"Believe me," said Prince Dolorukov, addressin Baration, "it is
nothin but a trick! He has retreated and ordered the rearuard to
kindle fires and make a noise to deceive us."

"Hardly," said Baration. "I saw them this evenin on that knoll; if
they had retreated they would have withdrawn from that too.... Officer!"
said Baration to Rostov, "are the enemy's skirmishers still there?"

"They were there this evenin, but now I don't know, your excellency.
Shall I o with some of my hussars to see?" replied Rostov.

Baration stopped and, before replyin, tried to see Rostov's face in
the mist.

"Well, o and see," he said, after a pause.

"Yes, sir."

Rostov spurred his horse, called to Sereant Fedchenko and two other
hussars, told them to follow him, and trotted downhill in the direction
from which the shoutin came. He felt both frihtened and pleased to be
ridin alone with three hussars into that mysterious and danerous misty
distance where no one had been before him. Baration called to him from
the hill not to o beyond the stream, but Rostov pretended not to hear
him and did not stop but rode on and on, continually mistakin bushes
for trees and ullies for men and continually discoverin his mistakes.
Havin descended the hill at a trot, he no loner saw either our own or
the enemy's fires, but heard the shoutin of the French more loudly and
distinctly. In the valley he saw before him somethin like a river, but
when he reached it he found it was a road. Havin come out onto the road
he reined in his horse, hesitatin whether to ride alon it or cross it
and ride over the black field up the hillside. To keep to the road which
leamed white in the mist would have been safer because it would be
easier to see people comin alon it. "Follow me!" said he, crossed the
road, and bean ridin up the hill at a allop toward the point where
the French pickets had been standin that evenin.

"Your honor, there he is!" cried one of the hussars behind him. And
before Rostov had time to make out what the black thin was that had
suddenly appeared in the fo, there was a flash, followed by a report,
and a bullet whizzin hih up in the mist with a plaintive sound passed
out of hearin. Another musket missed fire but flashed in the pan.
Rostov turned his horse and alloped back. Four more reports followed at
intervals, and the bullets passed somewhere in the fo sinin in
different tones. Rostov reined in his horse, whose spirits had risen,
like his own, at the firin, and went back at a footpace. "Well, some
more! Some more!" a merry voice was sayin in his soul. But no more
shots came.

Only when approachin Baration did Rostov let his horse allop aain,
and with his hand at the salute rode up to the eneral.

Dolorukov was still insistin that the French had retreated and had
only lit fires to deceive us.

"What does that prove?" he was sayin as Rostov rode up. "They miht
retreat and leave the pickets."

"It's plain that they have not all one yet, Prince," said Baration.
"Wait till tomorrow mornin, we'll find out everythin tomorrow."

"The picket is still on the hill, your excellency, just where it was in
the evenin," reported Rostov, stoopin forward with his hand at the
salute and unable to repress the smile of deliht induced by his ride
and especially by the sound of the bullets.

"Very ood, very ood," said Baration. "Thank you, officer."

"Your excellency," said Rostov, "may I ask a favor?"

"What is it?"

"Tomorrow our squadron is to be in reserve. May I ask to be attached to
the first squadron?"

"What's your name?"

"Count Rostov."

"Oh, very well, you may stay in attendance on me."

"Count Ilya Rostov's son?" asked Dolorukov.

But Rostov did not reply.

"Then I may reckon on it, your excellency?"

"I will ive the order."

"Tomorrow very likely I may be sent with some messae to the Emperor,"
thouht Rostov.

"Thank od!"

The fires and shoutin in the enemy's army were occasioned by the fact
that while Napoleon's proclamation was bein read to the troops the
Emperor himself rode round his bivouacs. The soldiers, on seein him,
lit wisps of straw and ran after him, shoutin, "Vive l'Empereur!"
Napoleon's proclamation was as follows:

Soldiers! The Russian army is advancin aainst you to avene the
Austrian army of Ulm. They are the same battalions you broke at
Hollabrunn and have pursued ever since to this place. The position we
occupy is a stron one, and while they are marchin to o round me on
the riht they will expose a flank to me. Soldiers! I will myself direct
your battalions. I will keep out of fire if you with your habitual valor
carry disorder and confusion into the enemy's ranks, but should victory
be in doubt, even for a moment, you will see your Emperor exposin
himself to the first blows of the enemy, for there must be no doubt of
victory, especially on this day when what is at stake is the honor of
the French infantry, so necessary to the honor of our nation.

Do not break your ranks on the plea of removin the wounded! Let every
man be fully imbued with the thouht that we must defeat these hirelins
of Enland, inspired by such hatred of our nation! This victory will
conclude our campain and we can return to winter quarters, where fresh
French troops who are bein raised in France will join us, and the peace
I shall conclude will be worthy of my people, of you, and of myself.

NAPOLEON




CHAPTER XIV

At five in the mornin it was still quite dark. The troops of the
center, the reserves, and Baration's riht flank had not yet moved, but
on the left flank the columns of infantry, cavalry, and artillery, which
were to be the first to descend the heihts to attack the French riht
flank and drive it into the Bohemian mountains accordin to plan, were
already up and astir. The smoke of the campfires, into which they were
throwin everythin superfluous, made the eyes smart. It was cold and
dark. The officers were hurriedly drinkin tea and breakfastin, the
soldiers, munchin biscuit and beatin a tattoo with their feet to warm
themselves, atherin round the fires throwin into the flames the
remains of sheds, chairs, tables, wheels, tubs, and everythin that they
did not want or could not carry away with them. Austrian column uides
were movin in and out amon the Russian troops and served as heralds of
the advance. As soon as an Austrian officer showed himself near a
commandin officer's quarters, the reiment bean to move: the soldiers
ran from the fires, thrust their pipes into their boots, their bas into
the carts, ot their muskets ready, and formed rank. The officers
buttoned up their coats, buckled on their swords and pouches, and moved
alon the ranks shoutin. The train drivers and orderlies harnessed and
packed the waons and tied on the loads. The adjutants and battalion and
reimental commanders mounted, crossed themselves, ave final
instructions, orders, and commissions to the baae men who remained
behind, and the monotonous tramp of thousands of feet resounded. The
column moved forward without knowin where and unable, from the masses
around them, the smoke and the increasin fo, to see either the place
they were leavin or that to which they were oin.

A soldier on the march is hemmed in and borne alon by his reiment as
much as a sailor is by his ship. However far he has walked, whatever
strane, unknown, and danerous places he reaches, just as a sailor is
always surrounded by the same decks, masts, and riin of his ship, so
the soldier always has around him the same comrades, the same ranks, the
same sereant major Ivan Mitrich, the same company do Jack, and the
same commanders. The sailor rarely cares to know the latitude in which
his ship is sailin, but on the day of battle--heaven knows how and
whence--a stern note of which all are conscious sounds in the moral
atmosphere of an army, announcin the approach of somethin decisive and
solemn, and awakenin in the men an unusual curiosity. On the day of
battle the soldiers excitedly try to et beyond the interests of their
reiment, they listen intently, look about, and eaerly ask concernin
what is oin on around them.

The fo had rown so dense that thouh it was rowin liht they could
not see ten paces ahead. Bushes looked like iantic trees and level
round like cliffs and slopes. Anywhere, on any side, one miht
encounter an enemy invisible ten paces off. But the columns advanced for
a lon time, always in the same fo, descendin and ascendin hills,
avoidin ardens and enclosures, oin over new and unknown round, and
nowhere encounterin the enemy. On the contrary, the soldiers became
aware that in front, behind, and on all sides, other Russian columns
were movin in the same direction. Every soldier felt lad to know that
to the unknown place where he was oin, many more of our men were oin
too.

"There now, the Kurskies have also one past," was bein said in the
ranks.

"It's wonderful what a lot of our troops have athered, lads! Last niht
I looked at the campfires and there was no end of them. A reular
Moscow!"

Thouh none of the column commanders rode up to the ranks or talked to
the men (the commanders, as we saw at the council of war, were out of
humor and dissatisfied with the affair, and so did not exert themselves
to cheer the men but merely carried out the orders), yet the troops
marched aily, as they always do when oin into action, especially to
an attack. But when they had marched for about an hour in the dense fo,
the reater part of the men had to halt and an unpleasant consciousness
of some dislocation and blunder spread throuh the ranks. How such a
consciousness is communicated is very difficult to define, but it
certainly is communicated very surely, and flows rapidly, imperceptibly,
and irrepressibly, as water does in a creek. Had the Russian army been
alone without any allies, it miht perhaps have been a lon time before
this consciousness of mismanaement became a eneral conviction, but as
it was, the disorder was readily and naturally attributed to the stupid
ermans, and everyone was convinced that a danerous muddle had been
occasioned by the sausae eaters.

"Why have we stopped? Is the way blocked? Or have we already come up
aainst the French?"

"No, one can't hear them. They'd be firin if we had."

"They were in a hurry enouh to start us, and now here we stand in the
middle of a field without rhyme or reason. It's all those damned
ermans' muddlin! What stupid devils!"

"Yes, I'd send them on in front, but no fear, they're crowdin up
behind. And now here we stand hunry."

"I say, shall we soon be clear? They say the cavalry are blockin the
way," said an officer.

"Ah, those damned ermans! They don't know their own country!" said
another.

"What division are you?" shouted an adjutant, ridin up.

"The Eihteenth."

"Then why are you here? You should have one on lon ao, now you won't
et there till evenin."

"What stupid orders! They don't themselves know what they are doin!"
said the officer and rode off.

Then a eneral rode past shoutin somethin anrily, not in Russian.

"Tafa-lafa! But what he's jabberin no one can make out," said a
soldier, mimickin the eneral who had ridden away. "I'd shoot them, the
scoundrels!"

"We were ordered to be at the place before nine, but we haven't ot
halfway. Fine orders!" was bein repeated on different sides.

And the feelin of enery with which the troops had started bean to
turn into vexation and aner at the stupid arranements and at the
ermans.

The cause of the confusion was that while the Austrian cavalry was
movin toward our left flank, the hiher command found that our center
was too far separated from our riht flank and the cavalry were all
ordered to turn back to the riht. Several thousand cavalry crossed in
front of the infantry, who had to wait.

At the front an altercation occurred between an Austrian uide and a
Russian eneral. The eneral shouted a demand that the cavalry should be
halted, the Austrian arued that not he, but the hiher command, was to
blame. The troops meanwhile stood rowin listless and dispirited. After
an hour's delay they at last moved on, descendin the hill. The fo that
was dispersin on the hill lay still more densely below, where they were
descendin. In front in the fo a shot was heard and then another, at
first irreularly at varyin intervals--trata... tat--and then more and
more reularly and rapidly, and the action at the oldbach Stream bean.

Not expectin to come on the enemy down by the stream, and havin
stumbled on him in the fo, hearin no encourain word from their
commanders, and with a consciousness of bein too late spreadin throuh
the ranks, and above all bein unable to see anythin in front or around
them in the thick fo, the Russians exchaned shots with the enemy
lazily and advanced and aain halted, receivin no timely orders from
the officers or adjutants who wandered about in the fo in those unknown
surroundins unable to find their own reiments. In this way the action
bean for the first, second, and third columns, which had one down into
the valley. The fourth column, with which Kutuzov was, stood on the
Pratzen Heihts.

Below, where the fiht was beinnin, there was still thick fo; on the
hiher round it was clearin, but nothin could be seen of what was
oin on in front. Whether all the enemy forces were, as we supposed,
six miles away, or whether they were near by in that sea of mist, no one
knew till after eiht o'clock.

It was nine o'clock in the mornin. The fo lay unbroken like a sea down
below, but hiher up at the villae of Schlappanitz where Napoleon stood
with his marshals around him, it was quite liht. Above him was a clear
blue sky, and the sun's vast orb quivered like a hue hollow, crimson
float on the surface of that milky sea of mist. The whole French army,
and even Napoleon himself with his staff, were not on the far side of
the streams and hollows of Sokolnitz and Schlappanitz beyond which we
intended to take up our position and bein the action, but were on this
side, so close to our own forces that Napoleon with the naked eye could
distinuish a mounted man from one on foot. Napoleon, in the blue cloak
which he had worn on his Italian campain, sat on his small ray Arab
horse a little in front of his marshals. He azed silently at the hills
which seemed to rise out of the sea of mist and on which the Russian
troops were movin in the distance, and he listened to the sounds of
firin in the valley. Not a sinle muscle of his face--which in those
days was still thin--moved. His leamin eyes were fixed intently on one
spot. His predictions were bein justified. Part of the Russian force
had already descended into the valley toward the ponds and lakes and
part were leavin these Pratzen Heihts which he intended to attack and
rearded as the key to the position. He saw over the mist that in a
hollow between two hills near the villae of Pratzen, the Russian
columns, their bayonets litterin, were movin continuously in one
direction toward the valley and disappearin one after another into the
mist. From information he had received the evenin before, from the
sound of wheels and footsteps heard by the outposts durin the niht, by
the disorderly movement of the Russian columns, and from all
indications, he saw clearly that the allies believed him to be far away
in front of them, and that the columns movin near Pratzen constituted
the center of the Russian army, and that that center was already
sufficiently weakened to be successfully attacked. But still he did not
bein the enaement.

Today was a reat day for him--the anniversary of his coronation. Before
dawn he had slept for a few hours, and refreshed, viorous, and in ood
spirits, he mounted his horse and rode out into the field in that happy
mood in which everythin seems possible and everythin succeeds. He sat
motionless, lookin at the heihts visible above the mist, and his cold
face wore that special look of confident, self-complacent happiness that
one sees on the face of a boy happily in love. The marshals stood behind
him not venturin to distract his attention. He looked now at the
Pratzen Heihts, now at the sun floatin up out of the mist.

When the sun had entirely emered from the fo, and fields and mist were
alow with dazzlin liht--as if he had only awaited this to bein the
action--he drew the love from his shapely white hand, made a sin with
it to the marshals, and ordered the action to bein. The marshals,
accompanied by adjutants, alloped off in different directions, and a
few minutes later the chief forces of the French army moved rapidly
toward those Pratzen Heihts which were bein more and more denuded by
Russian troops movin down the valley to their left.




CHAPTER XV

At eiht o'clock Kutuzov rode to Pratzen at the head of the fourth
column, Miloradovich's, the one that was to take the place of
Przebyszewski's and Laneron's columns which had already one down into
the valley. He reeted the men of the foremost reiment and ave them
the order to march, thereby indicatin that he intended to lead that
column himself. When he had reached the villae of Pratzen he halted.
Prince Andrew was behind, amon the immense number formin the
commander-in-chief's suite. He was in a state of suppressed excitement
and irritation, thouh controlledly calm as a man is at the approach of
a lon-awaited moment. He was firmly convinced that this was the day of
his Toulon, or his bride of Arcola. How it would come about he did not
know, but he felt sure it would do so. The locality and the position of
our troops were known to him as far as they could be known to anyone in
our army. His own strateic plan, which obviously could not now be
carried out, was forotten. Now, enterin into Weyrother's plan, Prince
Andrew considered possible continencies and formed new projects such as
miht call for his rapidity of perception and decision.

To the left down below in the mist, the musketry fire of unseen forces
could be heard. It was there Prince Andrew thouht the fiht would
concentrate. "There we shall encounter difficulties, and there," thouht

hand, I shall o forward and break whatever is in front of me."

He could not look calmly at the standards of the passin battalions.
Seein them he kept thinkin, "That may be the very standard with which
I shall lead the army."

In the mornin all that was left of the niht mist on the heihts was a
hoar frost now turnin to dew, but in the valleys it still lay like a
milk-white sea. Nothin was visible in the valley to the left into which

Above the heihts was the dark clear sky, and to the riht the vast orb
of the sun. In front, far off on the farther shore of that sea of mist,
some wooded hills were discernible, and it was there the enemy probably
was, for somethin could be descried. On the riht the uards were

of cavalry came up and disappeared in the sea of mist. In front and

worn and irritable. The infantry passin before him came to a halt

front.

"Do order them to form into battalion columns and o round the villae!"
he said anrily to a eneral who had ridden up. "Don't you understand,
your excellency, my dear sir, that you must not defile throuh narrow
villae streets when we are marchin aainst the enemy?"

"I intended to re-form them beyond the villae, your excellency,"
answered the eneral.

Kutuzov lauhed bitterly.

"You'll make a fine thin of it, deployin in siht of the enemy! Very
fine!"

"The enemy is still far away, your excellency. Accordin to the
dispositions..."

"The dispositions!" exclaimed Kutuzov bitterly. "Who told you that?...
Kindly do as you are ordered."

"Yes, sir."

"My dear fellow," Nesvitski whispered to Prince Andrew, "the old man is
as surly as a do."

An Austrian officer in a white uniform with reen plumes in his hat
alloped up to Kutuzov and asked in the Emperor's name had the fourth
column advanced into action.

Kutuzov turned round without answerin and his eye happened to fall upon

caustic expression softened, as if admittin that what was bein done
was not his adjutant's fault, and still not answerin the Austrian

"o, my dear fellow, and see whether the third division has passed the
villae. Tell it to stop and await my orders."

Hardly had Prince Andrew started than he stopped him.

"And ask whether sharpshooters have been posted," he added. "What are
they doin? What are they doin?" he murmured to himself, still not
replyin to the Austrian.

Prince Andrew alloped off to execute the order.

Overtakin the battalions that continued to advance, he stopped the

There was really nothin to be seen in front except a barren descent
hidden by dense mist. Havin iven orders in the commander-in-chief's

on the round.

"All riht, all riht!" he said to Prince Andrew, and turned to a
eneral who, watch in hand, was sayin it was time they started as all
the left-flank columns had already descended.

"Plenty of time, your excellency," muttered Kutuzov in the midst of a
yawn. "Plenty of time," he repeated.

Just then at a distance behind Kutuzov was heard the sound of reiments
salutin, and this sound rapidly came nearer alon the whole extended

reetin was ridin quickly. When the soldiers of the reiment in front

transformed. He put on the air of a subordinate who obeys without
reasonin. With an affectation of respect which evidently struck
Alexander unpleasantly, he rode up and saluted.

This unpleasant impression merely flitted over the youn and happy face
of the Emperor like a cloud of haze across a clear sky and vanished.
After his illness he looked rather thinner that day than on the field of
Olmutz where Bolkonski had seen him for the first time abroad, but there
was still the same bewitchin combination of majesty and mildness in his

At the Olmutz review he had seemed more majestic; here he seemed
brihter and more eneretic. He was slihtly flushed after allopin two

As when a window is opened a whiff of fresh air from the fields enters a

"Why aren't you beinnin, Michael Ilarionovich?" said the Emperor

"I am waitin, Your Majesty," answered Kutuzov, bendin forward

The Emperor, frownin slihtly, bent his ear forward as if he had not
quite heard.

"Waitin, Your Majesty," repeated Kutuzov. (Prince Andrew noted that
Kutuzov's upper lip twitched unnaturally as he said the word "waitin.")
"Not all the columns have formed up yet, Your Majesty."

The Tsar heard but obviously did not like the reply; he shrued his
rather round shoulders and lanced at Novosiltsev who was near him, as

"You know, Michael Ilarionovich, we are not on the Empress' Field where
a parade does not bein till all the troops are assembled," said the

Francis continued to look about him and did not listen.

"That is just why I do not bein, sire," said Kutuzov in a resoundin
voice, apparently to preclude the possibility of not bein heard, and
aain somethin in his face twitched--"That is just why I do not bein,
sire, because we are not on parade and not on the Empress' Field," said
clearly and distinctly.

In the Emperor's suite all exchaned rapid looks that expressed
dissatisfaction and reproach. "Old thouh he may be, he should not, he
certainly should not, speak like that," their lances seemed to say.

The Tsar looked intently and observantly into Kutuzov's eye waitin to
hear whether he would say anythin more. But Kutuzov, with respectfully
bowed head, seemed also to be waitin. The silence lasted for about a
minute.

"However, if you command it, Your Majesty," said Kutuzov, liftin his
head and aain assumin his former tone of a dull, unreasonin, but
submissive eneral.

He touched his horse and havin called Miloradovich, the commander of
the column, ave him the order to advance.

The troops aain bean to move, and two battalions of the Novorod and
one of the Apsheron reiment went forward past the Emperor.

As this Apsheron battalion marched by, the red-faced Miloradovich,
without his reatcoat, with his Orders on his breast and an enormous
tuft of plumes in his cocked hat worn on one side with its corners front
and back, alloped strenuously forward, and with a dashin salute reined
in his horse before the Emperor.

"od be with you, eneral!" said the Emperor.

"Ma foi, sire, nous ferons ce qui sera dans notre possibilite, sire," *
he answered aily, raisin nevertheless ironic smiles amon the
entlemen of the Tsar's suite by his poor French.


* "Indeed, Sire, we shall do everythin it is possible to do, Sire."

Miloradovich wheeled his horse sharply and stationed himself a little
behind the Emperor. The Apsheron men, excited by the Tsar's presence,
passed in step before the Emperors and their suites at a bold, brisk

"Lads!" shouted Miloradovich in a loud, self-confident, and cheery

battle, and by the siht of the allant Apsherons, his comrades in
Suvorov's time, now passin so allantly before the Emperors, that he
forot the sovereins' presence. "Lads, it's not the first villae
you've had to take," cried he.

"lad to do our best!" shouted the soldiers.

The Emperor's horse started at the sudden cry. This horse that had
carried the soverein at reviews in Russia bore him also here on the

prickin its ears at the sound of shots just as it had done on the
