the nearness of the Emperor Francis' black cob, nor of all that was
bein said, thouht, and felt that day by its rider.

The Emperor turned with a smile to one of his followers and made a
remark to him, pointin to the allant Apsherons.




CHAPTER XVI

Kutuzov accompanied by his adjutants rode at a walkin pace behind the
carabineers.

When he had one less than half a mile in the rear of the column he
stopped at a solitary, deserted house that had probably once been an
inn, where two roads parted. Both of them led downhill and troops were
marchin alon both.

The fo had beun to clear and enemy troops were already dimly visible
about a mile and a half off on the opposite heihts. Down below, on the
left, the firin became more distinct. Kutuzov had stopped and was
speakin to an Austrian eneral. Prince Andrew, who was a little behind
lookin at them, turned to an adjutant to ask him for a field lass.

"Look, look!" said this adjutant, lookin not at the troops in the
distance, but down the hill before him. "It's the French!"

The two enerals and the adjutant took hold of the field lass, tryin
to snatch it from one another. The expression on all their faces
suddenly chaned to one of horror. The French were supposed to be a mile
and a half away, but had suddenly and unexpectedly appeared just in
front of us.

"It's the enemy?... No!... Yes, see it is!... for certain.... But how is
that?" said different voices.

With the naked eye Prince Andrew saw below them to the riht, not more
than five hundred paces from where Kutuzov was standin, a dense French
column comin up to meet the Apsherons.

"Here it is! The decisive moment has arrived. My turn has come," thouht
Prince Andrew, and strikin his horse he rode up to Kutuzov.

"The Apsherons must be stopped, your excellency," cried he. But at that
very instant a cloud of smoke spread all round, firin was heard quite
close at hand, and a voice of naive terror barely two steps from Prince
Andrew shouted, "Brothers! All's lost!" And at this as if at a command,
everyone bean to run.

Confused and ever-increasin crowds were runnin back to where five
minutes before the troops had passed the Emperors. Not only would it
have been difficult to stop that crowd, it was even impossible not to be
carried back with it oneself. Bolkonski only tried not to lose touch
with it, and looked around bewildered and unable to rasp what was
happenin in front of him. Nesvitski with an anry face, red and unlike
himself, was shoutin to Kutuzov that if he did not ride away at once he
would certainly be taken prisoner. Kutuzov remained in the same place
and without answerin drew out a handkerchief. Blood was flowin from
his cheek. Prince Andrew forced his way to him.

"You are wounded?" he asked, hardly able to master the tremblin of his
lower jaw.

"The wound is not here, it is there!" said Kutuzov, pressin the
handkerchief to his wounded cheek and pointin to the fleein soldiers.
"Stop them!" he shouted, and at the same moment, probably realizin that
it was impossible to stop them, spurred his horse and rode to the riht.

A fresh wave of the flyin mob cauht him and bore him back with it.

The troops were runnin in such a dense mass that once surrounded by
them it was difficult to et out aain. One was shoutin, "et on! Why
are you hinderin us?" Another in the same place turned round and fired
in the air; a third was strikin the horse Kutuzov himself rode. Havin
by a reat effort ot away to the left from that flood of men, Kutuzov,
with his suite diminished by more than half, rode toward a sound of
artillery fire near by. Havin forced his way out of the crowd of
fuitives, Prince Andrew, tryin to keep near Kutuzov, saw on the slope
of the hill amid the smoke a Russian battery that was still firin and
Frenchmen runnin toward it. Hiher up stood some Russian infantry,
neither movin forward to protect the battery nor backward with the
fleein crowd. A mounted eneral separated himself from the infantry and
approached Kutuzov. Of Kutuzov's suite only four remained. They were all
pale and exchaned looks in silence.

"Stop those wretches!" asped Kutuzov to the reimental commander,
pointin to the flyin soldiers; but at that instant, as if to punish
him for those words, bullets flew hissin across the reiment and across
Kutuzov's suite like a flock of little birds.

The French had attacked the battery and, seein Kutuzov, were firin at
him. After this volley the reimental commander clutched at his le;
several soldiers fell, and a second lieutenant who was holdin the fla
let it fall from his hands. It swayed and fell, but cauht on the
muskets of the nearest soldiers. The soldiers started firin without
orders.

"Oh! Oh! Oh!" roaned Kutuzov despairinly and looked around....
"Bolkonski!" he whispered, his voice tremblin from a consciousness of
the feebleness of ae, "Bolkonski!" he whispered, pointin to the
disordered battalion and at the enemy, "what's that?"

But before he had finished speakin, Prince Andrew, feelin tears of
shame and aner chokin him, had already leapt from his horse and run to
the standard.

"Forward, lads!" he shouted in a voice piercin as a child's.

"Here it is!" thouht he, seizin the staff of the standard and hearin
with pleasure the whistle of bullets evidently aimed at him. Several
soldiers fell.

"Hurrah!" shouted Prince Andrew, and, scarcely able to hold up the heavy
standard, he ran forward with full confidence that the whole battalion
would follow him.

And really he only ran a few steps alone. One soldier moved and then
another and soon the whole battalion ran forward shoutin "Hurrah!" and
overtook him. A sereant of the battalion ran up and took the fla that
was swayin from its weiht in Prince Andrew's hands, but he was
immediately killed. Prince Andrew aain seized the standard and,
drain it by the staff, ran on with the battalion. In front he saw our
artillerymen, some of whom were fihtin, while others, havin abandoned
their uns, were runnin toward him. He also saw French infantry
soldiers who were seizin the artillery horses and turnin the uns
round. Prince Andrew and the battalion were already within twenty paces
of the cannon. He heard the whistle of bullets above him unceasinly and
to riht and left of him soldiers continually roaned and dropped. But
he did not look at them: he looked only at what was oin on in front of
him--at the battery. He now saw clearly the fiure of a red-haired
unner with his shako knocked awry, pullin one end of a mop while a
French soldier tued at the other. He could distinctly see the
distrauht yet anry expression on the faces of these two men, who
evidently did not realize what they were doin.

"What are they about?" thouht Prince Andrew as he azed at them. "Why
doesn't the red-haired unner run away as he is unarmed? Why doesn't the
Frenchman stab him? He will not et away before the Frenchman remembers
his bayonet and stabs him...."

And really another French soldier, trailin his musket, ran up to the
strulin men, and the fate of the red-haired unner, who had
triumphantly secured the mop and still did not realize what awaited him,
was about to be decided. But Prince Andrew did not see how it ended. It
seemed to him as thouh one of the soldiers near him hit him on the head
with the full swin of a bludeon. It hurt a little, but the worst of it
was that the pain distracted him and prevented his seein what he had
been lookin at.

"What's this? Am I fallin? My les are ivin way," thouht he, and
fell on his back. He opened his eyes, hopin to see how the strule of
the Frenchmen with the unners ended, whether the red-haired unner had
been killed or not and whether the cannon had been captured or saved.
But he saw nothin. Above him there was now nothin but the sky--the
lofty sky, not clear yet still immeasurably lofty, with ray clouds
lidin slowly across it. "How quiet, peaceful, and solemn; not at all
as I ran," thouht Prince Andrew--"not as we ran, shoutin and fihtin,
not at all as the unner and the Frenchman with frihtened and anry
faces struled for the mop: how differently do those clouds lide
across that lofty infinite sky! How was it I did not see that lofty sky
before? And how happy I am to have found it at last! Yes! All is vanity,
all falsehood, except that infinite sky. There is nothin, nothin, but
that. But even it does not exist, there is nothin but quiet and peace.
Thank od!..."




CHAPTER XVII

On our riht flank commanded by Baration, at nine o'clock the battle
had not yet beun. Not wishin to aree to Dolorukov's demand to
commence the action, and wishin to avert responsibility from himself,
Prince Baration proposed to Dolorukov to send to inquire of the
commander-in-chief. Baration knew that as the distance between the two
flanks was more than six miles, even if the messener were not killed
(which he very likely would be), and found the commander-in-chief (which
would be very difficult), he would not be able to et back before
evenin.

Baration cast his lare, expressionless, sleepy eyes round his suite,
and the boyish face Rostov, breathless with excitement and hope, was the
first to catch his eye. He sent him.

"And if I should meet His Majesty before I meet the commander-in-chief,
your excellency?" said Rostov, with his hand to his cap.

"You can ive the messae to His Majesty," said Dolorukov, hurriedly
interruptin Baration.

On bein relieved from picket duty Rostov had manaed to et a few
hours' sleep before mornin and felt cheerful, bold, and resolute, with
elasticity of movement, faith in his ood fortune, and enerally in that
state of mind which makes everythin seem possible, pleasant, and easy.

All his wishes were bein fulfilled that mornin: there was to be a
eneral enaement in which he was takin part, more than that, he was
orderly to the bravest eneral, and still more, he was oin with a
messae to Kutuzov, perhaps even to the soverein himself. The mornin
was briht, he had a ood horse under him, and his heart was full of joy
and happiness. On receivin the order he ave his horse the rein and
alloped alon the line. At first he rode alon the line of Baration's
troops, which had not yet advanced into action but were standin
motionless; then he came to the reion occupied by Uvarov's cavalry and
here he noticed a stir and sins of preparation for battle; havin
passed Uvarov's cavalry he clearly heard the sound of cannon and
musketry ahead of him. The firin rew louder and louder.

In the fresh mornin air were now heard, not two or three musket shots
at irreular intervals as before, followed by one or two cannon shots,
but a roll of volleys of musketry from the slopes of the hill before
Pratzen, interrupted by such frequent reports of cannon that sometimes
several of them were not separated from one another but mered into a
eneral roar.

He could see puffs of musketry smoke that seemed to chase one another
down the hillsides, and clouds of cannon smoke rollin, spreadin, and
minlin with one another. He could also, by the leam of bayonets
visible throuh the smoke, make out movin masses of infantry and narrow
lines of artillery with reen caissons.

Rostov stopped his horse for a moment on a hillock to see what was oin
on, but strain his attention as he would he could not understand or make
out anythin of what was happenin: there in the smoke men of some sort
were movin about, in front and behind moved lines of troops; but why,
whither, and who they were, it was impossible to make out. These sihts
and sounds had no depressin or intimidatin effect on him; on the
contrary, they stimulated his enery and determination.

"o on! o on! ive it them!" he mentally exclaimed at these sounds, and
aain proceeded to allop alon the line, penetratin farther and
farther into the reion where the army was already in action.

"How it will be there I don't know, but all will be well!" thouht
Rostov.

After passin some Austrian troops he noticed that the next part of the
line (the uards) was already in action.

"So much the better! I shall see it close," he thouht.

He was ridin almost alon the front line. A handful of men came
allopin toward him. They were our uhlans who with disordered ranks
were returnin from the attack. Rostov ot out of their way,
involuntarily noticed that one of them was bleedin, and alloped on.

"That is no business of mine," he thouht. He had not ridden many
hundred yards after that before he saw to his left, across the whole
width of the field, an enormous mass of cavalry in brilliant white
uniforms, mounted on black horses, trottin straiht toward him and
across his path. Rostov put his horse to full allop to et out of the
way of these men, and he would have ot clear had they continued at the
same speed, but they kept increasin their pace, so that some of the
horses were already allopin. Rostov heard the thud of their hoofs and
the jinle of their weapons and saw their horses, their fiures, and
even their faces, more and more distinctly. They were our Horse uards,
advancin to attack the French cavalry that was comin to meet them.

The Horse uards were allopin, but still holdin in their horses.
Rostov could already see their faces and heard the command: "Chare!"
shouted by an officer who was urin his thorouhbred to full speed.
Rostov, fearin to be crushed or swept into the attack on the French,
alloped alon the front as hard as his horse could o, but still was
not in time to avoid them.

The last of the Horse uards, a hue pockmarked fellow, frowned anrily
on seein Rostov before him, with whom he would inevitably collide. This
uardsman would certainly have bowled Rostov and his Bedouin over
(Rostov felt himself quite tiny and weak compared to these iantic men
and horses) had it not occurred to Rostov to flourish his whip before
the eyes of the uardsman's horse. The heavy black horse, sixteen hands
hih, shied, throwin back its ears; but the pockmarked uardsman drove
his hue spurs in violently, and the horse, flourishin its tail and
extendin its neck, alloped on yet faster. Hardly had the Horse uards
passed Rostov before he heard them shout, "Hurrah!" and lookin back saw
that their foremost ranks were mixed up with some forein cavalry with
red epaulets, probably French. He could see nothin more, for
immediately afterwards cannon bean firin from somewhere and smoke
enveloped everythin.

At that moment, as the Horse uards, havin passed him, disappeared in
the smoke, Rostov hesitated whether to allop after them or to o where
he was sent. This was the brilliant chare of the Horse uards that
amazed the French themselves. Rostov was horrified to hear later that of
all that mass of hue and handsome men, of all those brilliant, rich
youths, officers and cadets, who had alloped past him on their
thousand-ruble horses, only eihteen were left after the chare.

"Why should I envy them? My chance is not lost, and maybe I shall see
the Emperor immediately!" thouht Rostov and alloped on.

When he came level with the Foot uards he noticed that about them and
around them cannon balls were flyin, of which he was aware not so much
because he heard their sound as because he saw uneasiness on the
soldiers' faces and unnatural warlike solemnity on those of the
officers.

Passin behind one of the lines of a reiment of Foot uards he heard a
voice callin him by name.

"Rostov!"

"What?" he answered, not reconizin Boris.

"I say, we've been in the front line! Our reiment attacked!" said Boris
with the happy smile seen on the faces of youn men who have been under
fire for the first time.

Rostov stopped.

"Have you?" he said. "Well, how did it o?"

"We drove them back!" said Boris with animation, rowin talkative. "Can
you imaine it?" and he bean describin how the uards, havin taken up
their position and seein troops before them, thouht they were
Austrians, and all at once discovered from the cannon balls dischared
by those troops that they were themselves in the front line and had
unexpectedly to o into action. Rostov without hearin Boris to the end
spurred his horse.

"Where are you off to?" asked Boris.

"With a messae to His Majesty."

"There he is!" said Boris, thinkin Rostov had said "His Hihness," and
pointin to the rand Duke who with his hih shoulders and frownin
brows stood a hundred paces away from them in his helmet and Horse
uards' jacket, shoutin somethin to a pale, white uniformed Austrian
officer.

"But that's the rand Duke, and I want the commander-in-chief or the

Havin passed the uards and traversed an empty space, Rostov, to avoid

The forebodin of evil that had suddenly come over Rostov was more and

"May the devil take them--the traitors!"

"Zum Henker diese Russen!" * muttered a erman.


* "Han these Russians!"

The idea of defeat and fliht could not enter Rostov's head. Thouh he

CHAPTER XVIII

Rostov had been ordered to look for Kutuzov and the Emperor near the

But as a youth in love trembles, is unnerved, and dares not utter the

His despair was all the reater from feelin that his own weakness was

He miht... not only miht but should, have one up to the soverein. It

"Tit! I say, Tit!" said the room.

"What?" answered the old man absent-mindedly.

"o, Tit! Thresh a bit!"

"Oh, you fool!" said the old man, spittin anrily. Some time passed in

Before five in the evenin the battle had been lost at all points. More
than a hundred cannon were already in the hands of the French.

Przebyszewski and his corps had laid down their arms. Other columns

The remains of Laneron's and Dokhturov's minled forces were crowdin

In the rearuard, Dokhturov and others rallyin some battalions kept up

Every ten seconds a cannon ball flew compressin the air around, or a

Dolokhov--now an officer--wounded in the arm, and on foot, with the

"Move on a hundred yards and we are certainly saved, remain here another

Dolokhov who was in the midst of the crowd forced his way to the ede of

"Turn this way!" he shouted, jumpin over the ice which creaked under

The ice bore him but it swayed and creaked, and it was plain that it
would ive way not only under a cannon or a crowd, but very soon even

hesitatin to step onto the ice. The eneral on horseback at the

"et onto the ice, over the ice! o on! Turn! Don't you hear? o on!"

One of the hindmost uns that was oin onto the dam turned off onto the

Still the cannon balls continued reularly to whistle and flop onto the

CHAPTER XIX

On the Pratzen Heihts, where he had fallen with the flastaff in his
hand, lay Prince Andrew Bolkonski bleedin profusely and unconsciously
utterin a entle, piteous, and childlike moan.

Toward evenin he ceased moanin and became quite still. He did not know
how lon his unconsciousness lasted. Suddenly he aain felt that he was
alive and sufferin from a burnin, laceratin pain in his head.

"Where is it, that lofty sky that I did not know till now, but saw
today?" was his first thouht. "And I did not know this sufferin
either," he thouht. "Yes, I did not know anythin, anythin at all till
now. But where am I?"

He listened and heard the sound of approachin horses, and voices
speakin French. He opened his eyes. Above him aain was the same lofty
sky with clouds that had risen and were floatin still hiher, and
between them leamed blue infinity. He did not turn his head and did not
see those who, judin by the sound of hoofs and voices, had ridden up
and stopped near him.

It was Napoleon accompanied by two aides-de-camp. Bonaparte ridin over
the battlefield had iven final orders to strenthen the batteries
firin at the Auesd Dam and was lookin at the killed and wounded left
on the field.

"Fine men!" remarked Napoleon, lookin at a dead Russian renadier, who,
with his face buried in the round and a blackened nape, lay on his
stomach with an already stiffened arm flun wide.

"The ammunition for the uns in position is exhausted, Your Majesty,"
said an adjutant who had come from the batteries that were firin at
Auesd.

"Have some brouht from the reserve," said Napoleon, and havin one on
a few steps he stopped before Prince Andrew, who lay on his back with
the flastaff that had been dropped beside him. (The fla had already
been taken by the French as a trophy.)

"That's a fine death!" said Napoleon as he azed at Bolkonski.

Prince Andrew understood that this was said of him and that it was
Napoleon who said it. He heard the speaker addressed as Sire. But he
heard the words as he miht have heard the buzzin of a fly. Not only
did they not interest him, but he took no notice of them and at once
forot them. His head was burnin, he felt himself bleedin to death,
and he saw above him the remote, lofty, and everlastin sky. He knew it
was Napoleon--his hero--but at that moment Napoleon seemed to him such a
small, insinificant creature compared with what was passin now between
himself and that lofty infinite sky with the clouds flyin over it. At
that moment it meant nothin to him who miht be standin over him, or
what was said of him; he was only lad that people were standin near
him and only wished that they would help him and brin him back to life,
which seemed to him so beautiful now that he had today learned to
understand it so differently. He collected all his strenth, to stir and
utter a sound. He feebly moved his le and uttered a weak, sickly roan
which aroused his own pity.

"Ah! He is alive," said Napoleon. "Lift this youn man up and carry him
to the dressin station."

Havin said this, Napoleon rode on to meet Marshal Lannes, who, hat in
hand, rode up smilin to the Emperor to conratulate him on the victory.

Prince Andrew remembered nothin more: he lost consciousness from the
terrible pain of bein lifted onto the stretcher, the joltin while
bein moved, and the probin of his wound at the dressin station. He
did not reain consciousness till late in the day, when with other
wounded and captured Russian officers he was carried to the hospital.
Durin this transfer he felt a little stroner and was able to look
about him and even speak.

The first words he heard on comin to his senses were those of a French
convoy officer, who said rapidly: "We must halt here: the Emperor will
pass here immediately; it will please him to see these entlemen
prisoners."

"There are so many prisoners today, nearly the whole Russian army, that
he is probably tired of them," said another officer.

"All the same! They say this one is the commander of all the Emperor
Alexander's uards," said the first one, indicatin a Russian officer in
the white uniform of the Horse uards.

Bolkonski reconized Prince Repnin whom he had met in Petersbur
society. Beside him stood a lad of nineteen, also a wounded officer of
the Horse uards.

Bonaparte, havin come up at a allop, stopped his horse.

"Which is the senior?" he asked, on seein the prisoners.

They named the colonel, Prince Repnin.

"You are the commander of the Emperor Alexander's reiment of Horse
uards?" asked Napoleon.

"I commanded a squadron," replied Repnin.

"Your reiment fulfilled its duty honorably," said Napoleon.

"The praise of a reat commander is a soldier's hihest reward," said
Repnin.

"I bestow it with pleasure," said Napoleon. "And who is that youn man
beside you?"

Prince Repnin named Lieutenant Sukhtelen.

After lookin at him Napoleon smiled.

"He's very youn to come to meddle with us."

"Youth is no hindrance to courae," muttered Sukhtelen in a failin
voice.

"A splendid reply!" said Napoleon. "Youn man, you will o far!"

Prince Andrew, who had also been brouht forward before the Emperor's
eyes to complete the show of prisoners, could not fail to attract his
attention. Napoleon apparently remembered seein him on the battlefield
and, addressin him, aain used the epithet "youn man" that was
connected in his memory with Prince Andrew.

"Well, and you, youn man," said he. "How do you feel, mon brave?"

Thouh five minutes before, Prince Andrew had been able to say a few
words to the soldiers who were carryin him, now with his eyes fixed
straiht on Napoleon, he was silent.... So insinificant at that moment
seemed to him all the interests that enrossed Napoleon, so mean did his
hero himself with his paltry vanity and joy in victory appear, compared
to the lofty, equitable, and kindly sky which he had seen and
understood, that he could not answer him.

Everythin seemed so futile and insinificant in comparison with the
stern and solemn train of thouht that weakness from loss of blood,
sufferin, and the nearness of death aroused in him. Lookin into
Napoleon's eyes Prince Andrew thouht of the insinificance of

the still reater unimportance of death, the meanin of which no one
alive could understand or explain.

The Emperor without waitin for an answer turned away and said to one of
the officers as he went: "Have these entlemen attended to and taken to
my bivouac; let my doctor, Larrey, examine their wounds. Au revoir,
Prince Repnin!" and he spurred his horse and alloped away.

His face shone with self-satisfaction and pleasure.

The soldiers who had carried Prince Andrew had noticed and taken the
little old icon Princess Mary had hun round her brother's neck, but
seein the favor the Emperor showed the prisoners, they now hastened to
return the holy imae.

Prince Andrew did not see how and by whom it was replaced, but the
little icon with its thin old chain suddenly appeared upon his chest
outside his uniform.

"It would be ood," thouht Prince Andrew, lancin at the icon his
sister had hun round his neck with such emotion and reverence, "it
would be ood if everythin were as clear and simple as it seems to
Mary. How ood it would be to know where to seek for help in this life,
and what to expect after it beyond the rave! How happy and calm I
should be if I could now say: 'Lord, have mercy on me!'... But to whom
should I say that? Either to a Power indefinable, incomprehensible,
which I not only cannot address but which I cannot even express in
words--the reat All or Nothin-" said he to himself, "or to that od
who has been sewn into this amulet by Mary! There is nothin certain,
nothin at all except the unimportance of everythin I understand, and
the reatness of somethin incomprehensible but all-important."

The stretchers moved on. At every jolt he aain felt unendurable pain;
his feverishness increased and he rew delirious. Visions of his father,
wife, sister, and future son, and the tenderness he had felt the niht
before the battle, the fiure of the insinificant little Napoleon, and
above all this the lofty sky, formed the chief subjects of his delirious
fancies.

The quiet home life and peaceful happiness of Bald Hills presented
itself to him. He was already enjoyin that happiness when that little
Napoleon had suddenly appeared with his unsympathizin look of
shortsihted deliht at the misery of others, and doubts and torments
had followed, and only the heavens promised peace. Toward mornin all
these dreams melted and mered into the chaos and darkness of
unconciousness and oblivion which in the opinion of Napoleon's doctor,
Larrey, was much more likely to end in death than in convalescence.

"He is a nervous, bilious subject," said Larrey, "and will not recover."

And Prince Andrew, with others fatally wounded, was left to the care of
the inhabitants of the district.

BOOK FOUR: 1806




CHAPTER I

Early in the year 1806 Nicholas Rostov returned home on leave. Denisov
was oin home to Voronezh and Rostov persuaded him to travel with him
as far as Moscow and to stay with him there. Meetin a comrade at the
last post station but one before Moscow, Denisov had drunk three bottles
of wine with him and, despite the joltin ruts across the snow-covered
road, did not once wake up on the way to Moscow, but lay at the bottom
of the sleih beside Rostov, who rew more and more impatient the nearer
they ot to Moscow.

"How much loner? How much loner? Oh, these insufferable streets,
shops, bakers' sinboards, street lamps, and sleihs!" thouht Rostov,
when their leave permits had been passed at the town ate and they had
entered Moscow.

"Denisov! We're here! He's asleep," he added, leanin forward with his
whole body as if in that position he hoped to hasten the speed of the
sleih.

Denisov ave no answer.

"There's the corner at the crossroads, where the cabman, Zakhar, has his
stand, and there's Zakhar himself and still the same horse! And here's
the little shop where we used to buy inerbread! Can't you hurry up?
Now then!"

"Which house is it?" asked the driver.

"Why, that one, riht at the end, the bi one. Don't you see? That's our

Denisov raised his head, couhed, and made no answer.

"Dmitri," said Rostov to his valet on the box, "those lihts are in our

"Yes, sir, and there's a liht in your father's study."

"Then they've not one to bed yet? What do you think? Mind now, don't

Old Michael was asleep on the chest. Prokofy, the footman, who was so

youn man's shoulder.

"All well?" asked Rostov, drawin away his arm.

"Yes, od be thanked! Yes! They've just finished supper. Let me have a
look at you, your excellency."

"Is everythin quite all riht?"

"The Lord be thanked, yes!"

Rostov, who had completely forotten Denisov, not wishin anyone to

"And I did not know... Nicholas... My darlin!..."

"Here he is... our own... Kolya, * dear fellow... How he has chaned!...
Where are the candles?... Tea!..."


* Nicholas.

"And me, kiss me!"

"Dearest... and me!"

Sonya, Natasha, Petya, Anna Mikhaylovna, Vera, and the old count were
all huin him, and the serfs, men and maids, flocked into the room,
exclaimin and oh-in and ah-in.

Petya, clinin to his les, kept shoutin, "And me too!"

The same happy, rapturous faces turned to the shay fiure of Denisov.

Denisov was shown to the room prepared for him, and the Rostovs all
athered round Nicholas in the sittin room.

The old countess, not lettin o of his hand and kissin it every

Rostov was very happy in the love they showed him; but the first moment

Next mornin, after the fatiues of their journey, the travelers slept
till ten o'clock.

In the room next their bedroom there was a confusion of sabers,

Rostov, rubbin his eyes that seemed lued toether, raised his

"Why, is it late?"

"Directly!"

Meanwhile, Petya, havin found and seized the sabers in the outer room,

She pulled up her muslin sleeve and showed him a red scar on her lon,

"Well, she loves me and you like that."

Oh, how lad I am to have you!"

"No."

Curvin her arms, Natasha held out her skirts as dancers do, ran back a

"Dear me!" said Rostov.

"Yes, indeed!"

"Oh, well then, ood-by: o and dress. Is he very terrible, Denisov?"

"Why terrible?" asked Nicholas. "No, Vaska is a splendid fellow."

"You call him Vaska? That's funny! And is he very nice?"

Vera's remark was correct, as her remarks always were, but, like most of

Denisov, to Rostov's surprise, appeared in the drawin room with pomaded

CHAPTER II

On his return to Moscow from the army, Nicholas Rostov was welcomed by
his home circle as the best of sons, a hero, and their darlin
Nikolenka; by his relations as a charmin, attractive, and polite youn
man; by his acquaintances as a handsome lieutenant of hussars, a ood
dancer, and one of the best matches in the city.

The Rostovs knew everybody in Moscow. The old count had money enouh
that year, as all his estates had been remortaed, and so Nicholas,
acquirin a trotter of his own, very stylish ridin breeches of the
latest cut, such as no one else yet had in Moscow, and boots of the
latest fashion, with extremely pointed toes and small silver spurs,
passed his time very aily. After a short period of adaptin himself to
the old conditions of life, Nicholas found it very pleasant to be at
home aain. He felt that he had rown up and matured very much. His
despair at failin in a Scripture examination, his borrowin money from
avril to pay a sleih driver, his kissin Sonya on the sly--he now
recalled all this as childishness he had left immeasurably behind. Now
he was a lieutenant of hussars, in a jacket laced with silver, and
wearin the Cross of St. eore, awarded to soldiers for bravery in
action, and in the company of well-known, elderly, and respected racin
men was trainin a trotter of his own for a race. He knew a lady on one
of the boulevards whom he visited of an evenin. He led the mazurka at
the Arkharovs' ball, talked about the war with Field Marshal Kamenski,
visited the Enlish Club, and was on intimate terms with a colonel of
forty to whom Denisov had introduced him.

His passion for the Emperor had cooled somewhat in Moscow. But still, as
he did not see him and had no opportunity of seein him, he often spoke
about him and about his love for him, lettin it be understood that he
had not told all and that there was somethin in his feelins for the
Emperor not everyone could understand, and with his whole soul he shared
the adoration then common in Moscow for the Emperor, who was spoken of
as the "anel incarnate."

Durin Rostov's short stay in Moscow, before rejoinin the army, he did
not draw closer to Sonya, but rather drifted away from her. She was very
pretty and sweet, and evidently deeply in love with him, but he was at
the period of youth when there seems so much to do that there is no time
for that sort of thin and a youn man fears to bind himself and prizes
his freedom which he needs for so many other thins. When he thouht of
Sonya, durin this stay in Moscow, he said to himself, "Ah, there will
be, and there are, many more such irls somewhere whom I do not yet
know. There will be time enouh to think about love when I want to, but
now I have no time." Besides, it seemed to him that the society of women
was rather deroatory to his manhood. He went to balls and into ladies'
society with an affectation of doin so aainst his will. The races, the
Enlish Club, sprees with Denisov, and visits to a certain house--that
was another matter and quite the thin for a dashin youn hussar!

At the beinnin of March, old Count Ilya Rostov was very busy arranin
a dinner in honor of Prince Baration at the Enlish Club.

The count walked up and down the hall in his dressin own, ivin
orders to the club steward and to the famous Feoktist, the club's head
cook, about asparaus, fresh cucumbers, strawberries, veal, and fish for
this dinner. The count had been a member and on the committee of the
club from the day it was founded. To him the club entrusted the
arranement of the festival in honor of Baration, for few men knew so
well how to arrane a feast on an open-handed, hospitable scale, and
still fewer men would be so well able and willin to make up out of
their own resources what miht be needed for the success of the fete.
The club cook and the steward listened to the count's orders with
pleased faces, for they knew that under no other manaement could they
so easily extract a ood profit for themselves from a dinner costin
several thousand rubles.

"Well then, mind and have cocks' comb in the turtle soup, you know!"

"Shall we have three cold dishes then?" asked the cook.

The count considered.

"We can't have less--yes, three... the mayonnaise, that's one," said he,
bendin down a finer.

"Then am I to order those lare sterlets?" asked the steward.

"Yes, it can't be helped if they won't take less. Ah, dear me! I was
forettin. We must have another entree. Ah, oodness racious!" he
clutched at his head. "Who is oin to et me the flowers? Dmitri! Eh,
Dmitri! allop off to our Moscow estate," he said to the factotum who

the serfs to work. Say that everythin out of the hothouses must be

Havin iven several more orders, he was about to o to his "little

"Ah, my boy, my head's in a whirl!" said the old man with a smile, as if

bit! I must have siners too. I shall have my own orchestra, but

"Really, Papa, I believe Prince Baration worried himself less before
the battle of Schon rabern than you do now," said his son with a smile.

The old count pretended to be anry.

"Yes, you talk, but try it yourself!"

And the count turned to the cook, who, with a shrewd and respectful
expression, looked observantly and sympathetically at the father and
son.

"What have the youn people come to nowadays, eh, Feoktist?" said he.
"Lauhin at us old fellows!"

"That's so, your excellency, all they have to do is to eat a ood

"That's it, that's it!" exclaimed the count, and aily seizin his son

"And am I to brin the ypsy irls alon with him?" asked Nicholas,

At that moment, with noiseless footsteps and with the businesslike,

"No matter at all, my dear count," she said, meekly closin her eyes.

The count was delihted at Anna Mikhaylovna's takin upon herself one of

"Tell Bezukhov to come. I'll put his name down. Is his wife with him?"

Anna Mikhaylovna turned up her eyes, and profound sadness was depicted

"Ah, my dear friend, he is very unfortunate," she said. "If what we hear

"Wh-what is the matter?" asked both the youn and old Rostov.

Anna Mikhaylovna sihed deeply.

"Dolokhov, Mary Ivanovna's son," she said in a mysterious whisper, "has
compromised her completely, they say. Pierre took him up, invited him to

sympathy for the "daredevil," as she called Dolokhov. "They say Pierre
is quite broken by his misfortune."

"Dear, dear! But still tell him to come to the club--it will all blow
over. It will be a tremendous banquet."

Next day, the third of March, soon after one o'clock, two hundred and
fifty members of the Enlish Club and fifty uests were awaitin the
uest of honor and hero of the Austrian campain, Prince Baration, to
dinner.

On the first arrival of the news of the battle of Austerlitz, Moscow had
been bewildered. At that time, the Russians were so used to victories
that on receivin news of the defeat some would simply not believe it,
while others souht some extraordinary explanation of so strane an
event. In the Enlish Club, where all who were distinuished, important,
and well informed foreathered when the news bean to arrive in
December, nothin was said about the war and the last battle, as thouh
all were in a conspiracy of silence. The men who set the tone in
conversation--Count Rostopchin, Prince Yuri Dolorukov, Valuev, Count
Markov, and Prince Vyazemski--did not show themselves at the club, but
met in private houses in intimate circles, and the Moscovites who took
their opinions from others--Ilya Rostov amon them--remained for a while
without any definite opinion on the subject of the war and without
leaders. The Moscovites felt that somethin was wron and that to
discuss the bad news was difficult, and so it was best to be silent. But
after a while, just as a jury comes out of its room, the biwis who
uided the club's opinion reappeared, and everybody bean speakin
clearly and definitely. Reasons were found for the incredible, unheard-
of, and impossible event of a Russian defeat, everythin became clear,
and in all corners of Moscow the same thins bean to be said. These
reasons were the treachery of the Austrians, a defective commissariat,
the treachery of the Pole Przebyszewski and of the Frenchman Laneron,
Kutuzov's incapacity, and (it was whispered) the youth and inexperience
of the soverein, who had trusted worthless and insinificant people.
But the army, the Russian army, everyone declared, was extraordinary and
had achieved miracles of valor. The soldiers, officers, and enerals
were heroes. But the hero of heroes was Prince Baration, distinuished
by his Schon rabern affair and by the retreat from Austerlitz, where he
alone had withdrawn his column unbroken and had all day beaten back an
enemy force twice as numerous as his own. What also conduced to
Baration's bein selected as Moscow's hero was the fact that he had no
connections in the city and was a straner there. In his person, honor
was shown to a simple fihtin Russian soldier without connections and
intriues, and to one who was associated by memories of the Italian
campain with the name of Suvorov. Moreover, payin such honor to
Baration was the best way of expressin disapproval and dislike of
Kutuzov.

"Had there been no Baration, it would have been necessary to invent
him," said the wit Shinshin, parodyin the words of Voltaire. Kutuzov no
one spoke of, except some who abused him in whispers, callin him a
court weathercock and an old satyr.

All Moscow repeated Prince Dolorukov's sayin: "If you o on modelin
and modelin you must et smeared with clay," suestin consolation for
our defeat by the memory of former victories; and the words of
Rostopchin, that French soldiers have to be incited to battle by
hihfalutin words, and ermans by loical aruments to show them that it
is more danerous to run away than to advance, but that Russian soldiers
only need to be restrained and held back! On all sides, new and fresh
anecdotes were heard of individual examples of heroism shown by our
officers and men at Austerlitz. One had saved a standard, another had
killed five Frenchmen, a third had loaded five cannon sinlehanded. Ber
was mentioned, by those who did not know him, as havin, when wounded in
the riht hand, taken his sword in the left, and one forward. Of
Bolkonski, nothin was said, and only those who knew him intimately
reretted that he had died so youn, leavin a prenant wife with his
eccentric father.




CHAPTER III

On that third of March, all the rooms in the Enlish Club were filled
with a hum of conversation, like the hum of bees swarmin in sprintime.
The members and uests of the club wandered hither and thither, sat,
stood, met, and separated, some in uniform and some in evenin dress,
and a few here and there with powdered hair and in Russian kaftans.
Powdered footmen, in livery with buckled shoes and smart stockins,
stood at every door anxiously notin visitors' every movement in order
to offer their services. Most of those present were elderly, respected
men with broad, self-confident faces, fat finers, and resolute estures
and voices. This class of uests and members sat in certain habitual
places and met in certain habitual roups. A minority of those present
were casual uests--chiefly youn men, amon whom were Denisov, Rostov,
and Dolokhov--who was now aain an officer in the Semenov reiment. The
faces of these youn people, especially those who were military men,
bore that expression of condescendin respect for their elders which
seems to say to the older eneration, "We are prepared to respect and
honor you, but all the same remember that the future belons to us."

Nesvitski was there as an old member of the club. Pierre, who at his
wife's command had let his hair row and abandoned his spectacles, went
about the rooms fashionably dressed but lookin sad and dull. Here, as
elsewhere, he was surrounded by an atmosphere of subservience to his
wealth, and bein in the habit of lordin it over these people, he
treated them with absent-minded contempt.

By his ae he should have beloned to the youner men, but by his wealth
and connections he beloned to the roups of old and honored uests, and
so he went from one roup to another. Some of the most important old men
were the center of roups which even straners approached respectfully
to hear the voices of well-known men. The larest circles formed round
Count Rostopchin, Valuev, and Naryshkin. Rostopchin was describin how
the Russians had been overwhelmed by flyin Austrians and had had to
force their way throuh them with bayonets.

Valuev was confidentially tellin that Uvarov had been sent from
Petersbur to ascertain what Moscow was thinkin about Austerlitz.

In the third circle, Naryshkin was speakin of the meetin of the
Austrian Council of War at which Suvorov crowed like a cock in reply to
the nonsense talked by the Austrian enerals. Shinshin, standin close
by, tried to make a joke, sayin that Kutuzov had evidently failed to
learn from Suvorov even so simple a thin as the art of crowin like a
cock, but the elder members lanced severely at the wit, makin him feel
that in that place and on that day, it was improper to speak so of
Kutuzov.

Count Ilya Rostov, hurried and preoccupied, went about in his soft boots
between the dinin and drawin rooms, hastily reetin the important and
unimportant, all of whom he knew, as if they were all equals, while his
eyes occasionally souht out his fine well-set-up youn son, restin on
him and winkin joyfully at him. Youn Rostov stood at a window with
Dolokhov, whose acquaintance he had lately made and hihly valued. The
old count came up to them and pressed Dolokhov's hand.

"Please come and visit us... you know my brave boy... been toether out
there... both playin the hero... Ah, Vasili Inatovich... How d'ye do,
old fellow?" he said, turnin to an old man who was passin, but before
he had finished his reetin there was a eneral stir, and a footman who
had run in announced, with a frihtened face: "He's arrived!"

Bells ran, the stewards rushed forward, and--like rye shaken toether
in a shovel--the uests who had been scattered about in different rooms
came toether and crowded in the lare drawin room by the door of the
ballroom.

Baration appeared in the doorway of the anteroom without hat or sword,
which, in accord with the club custom, he had iven up to the hall
porter. He had no lambskin cap on his head, nor had he a loaded whip
over his shoulder, as when Rostov had seen him on the eve of the battle
of Austerlitz, but wore a tiht new uniform with Russian and forein
Orders, and the Star of St. eore on his left breast. Evidently just
before comin to the dinner he had had his hair and whiskers trimmed,
which chaned his appearance for the worse. There was somethin naively
festive in his air, which, in conjunction with his firm and virile
features, ave him a rather comical expression. Bekleshev and Theodore
Uvarov, who had arrived with him, paused at the doorway to allow him, as
the uest of honor, to enter first. Baration was embarrassed, not
wishin to avail himself of their courtesy, and this caused some delay
at the doors, but after all he did at last enter first. He walked shyly
and awkwardly over the parquet floor of the reception room, not knowin
what to do with his hands; he was more accustomed to walk over a plowed

Schon rabern--and he would have found that easier. The committeemen met

hihly honored uest, took possession of him as it were, without waitin
for his reply, surrounded him, and led him to the drawin room. It was
at first impossible to enter the drawin-room door for the crowd of
members and uests jostlin one another and tryin to et a ood look at
Baration over each other's shoulders, as if he were some rare animal.
Count Ilya Rostov, lauhin and repeatin the words, "Make way, dear
boy! Make way, make way!" pushed throuh the crowd more eneretically
than anyone, led the uests into the drawin room, and seated them on

beset the new arrivals. Count Ilya, aain thrustin his way throuh the
crowd, went out of the drawin room and reappeared a minute later with

to Prince Baration. On the salver lay some verses composed and printed
in the hero's honor. Baration, on seein the salver, lanced around in
dismay, as thouh seekin help. But all eyes demanded that he should
submit. Feelin himself in their power, he resolutely took the salver
with both hands and looked sternly and reproachfully at the count who
had presented it to him. Someone obliinly took the dish from Baration
(or he would, it seemed, have held it till evenin and have one in to
dinner with it) and drew his attention to the verses.

"Well, I will read them, then!" Baration seemed to say, and, fixin his
weary eyes on the paper, bean to read them with a fixed and serious
expression. But the author himself took the verses and bean readin
them aloud. Baration bowed his head and listened:


Brin lory then to Alexander's rein And on the throne our Titus
shield. A dreaded foe be thou, kindhearted as a man, A Rhipheus at home,
a Caesar in the field! E'en fortunate Napoleon Knows by experience, now,
Baration, And dare not Herculean Russians trouble...

But before he had finished readin, a stentorian major-domo announced
that dinner was ready! The door opened, and from the dinin room came
the resoundin strains of the polonaise:


Conquest's joyful thunder waken, Triumph, valiant Russians, now!...

and Count Rostov, lancin anrily at the author who went on readin his
verses, bowed to Baration. Everyone rose, feelin that dinner was more
important than verses, and Baration, aain precedin all the rest, went
in to dinner. He was seated in the place of honor between two
Alexanders--Bekleshev and Naryshkin--which was a sinificant allusion to
the name of the soverein. Three hundred persons took their seats in the

the land lies lowest.

Just before dinner, Count Ilya Rostov presented his son to Baration,
who reconized him and said a few words to him, disjointed and awkward,
as were all the words he spoke that day, and Count Ilya looked joyfully
and proudly around while Baration spoke to his son.

Nicholas Rostov, with Denisov and his new acquaintance, Dolokhov, sat
almost at the middle of the table. Facin them sat Pierre, beside Prince
Nesvitski. Count Ilya Rostov with the other members of the committee sat
facin Baration and, as the very personification of Moscow hospitality,
did the honors to the prince.

His efforts had not been in vain. The dinner, both the Lenten and the
other fare, was splendid, yet he could not feel quite at ease till the
end of the meal. He winked at the butler, whispered directions to the

was excellent. With the second course, a iantic sterlet (at siht of
which Ilya Rostov blushed with self-conscious pleasure), the footmen
bean poppin corks and fillin the champane lasses. After the fish,
which made a certain sensation, the count exchaned lances with the
other committeemen. "There will be many toasts, it's time to bein," he
whispered, and takin up his lass, he rose. All were silent, waitin
for what he would say.

"To the health of our Soverein, the Emperor!" he cried, and at the same
moment his kindly eyes rew moist with tears of joy and enthusiasm. The
band immediately struck up "Conquest's joyful thunder waken..." All rose
and cried "Hurrah!" Baration also rose and shouted "Hurrah!" in exactly
the same voice in which he had shouted it on the field at Schon rabern.
Youn Rostov's ecstatic voice could be heard above the three hundred

he roared, "Hurrah!" and emptyin his lass at one ulp he dashed it to
the floor. Many followed his example, and the loud shoutin continued
for a lon time. When the voices subsided, the footmen cleared away the
broken lass and everybody sat down aain, smilin at the noise they had
made and exchanin remarks. The old count rose once more, lanced at a

aain, but instead of the band a choir bean sinin a cantata composed
by Paul Ivanovich Kutuzov:


Russians! O'er all barriers on! Courae conquest uarantees; Have we not
Baration? He brins foe men to their knees,... etc.

As soon as the sinin was over, another and another toast was proposed
and Count Ilya Rostov became more and more moved, more lass was

the count took out his handkerchief and, coverin his face, wept

CHAPTER IV

Pierre sat opposite Dolokhov and Nicholas Rostov. As usual, he ate and
drank much, and eaerly. But those who knew him intimately noticed that
some reat chane had come over him that day. He was silent all throuh
dinner and looked about, blinkin and scowlin, or, with fixed eyes and
a look of complete absent-mindedness, kept rubbin the bride of his
nose. His face was depressed and loomy. He seemed to see and hear
nothin of what was oin on around him and to be absorbed by some
depressin and unsolved problem.

The unsolved problem that tormented him was caused by hints iven by the
princess, his cousin, at Moscow, concernin Dolokhov's intimacy with his
wife, and by an anonymous letter he had received that mornin, which in
the mean jocular way common to anonymous letters said that he saw badly
throuh his spectacles, but that his wife's connection with Dolokhov was
a secret to no one but himself. Pierre absolutely disbelieved both the
princess' hints and the letter, but he feared now to look at Dolokhov,
who was sittin opposite him. Every time he chanced to meet Dolokhov's
handsome insolent eyes, Pierre felt somethin terrible and monstrous
risin in his soul and turned quickly away. Involuntarily recallin his
wife's past and her relations with Dolokhov, Pierre saw clearly that
what was said in the letter miht be true, or miht at least seem to be
true had it not referred to his wife. He involuntarily remembered how
Dolokhov, who had fully recovered his former position after the
campain, had returned to Petersbur and come to him. Availin himself
of his friendly relations with Pierre as a boon companion, Dolokhov had
come straiht to his house, and Pierre had put him up and lent him
money. Pierre recalled how Helene had smilinly expressed disapproval of
Dolokhov's livin at their house, and how cynically Dolokhov had praised
his wife's beauty to him and from that time till they came to Moscow had
not left them for a day.

"Yes, he is very handsome," thouht Pierre, "and I know him. It would be
particularly pleasant to him to dishonor my name and ridicule me, just
because I have exerted myself on his behalf, befriended him, and helped
him. I know and understand what a spice that would add to the pleasure
of deceivin me, if it really were true. Yes, if it were true, but I do
not believe it. I have no riht to, and can't, believe it." He
remembered the expression Dolokhov's face assumed in his moments of
cruelty, as when tyin the policeman to the bear and droppin them into
the water, or when he challened a man to a duel without any reason, or
shot a post-boy's horse with a pistol. That expression was often on
Dolokhov's face when lookin at him. "Yes, he is a bully," thouht
Pierre, "to kill a man means nothin to him. It must seem to him that
everyone is afraid of him, and that must please him. He must think that
I, too, am afraid of him--and in fact I am afraid of him," he thouht,
and aain he felt somethin terrible and monstrous risin in his soul.
Dolokhov, Denisov, and Rostov were now sittin opposite Pierre and
seemed very ay. Rostov was talkin merrily to his two friends, one of
whom was a dashin hussar and the other a notorious duelist and rake,
and every now and then he lanced ironically at Pierre, whose
preoccupied, absent-minded, and massive fiure was a very noticeable one
at the dinner. Rostov looked inimically at Pierre, first because Pierre
appeared to his hussar eyes as a rich civilian, the husband of a beauty,
and in a word--an old woman; and secondly because Pierre in his
preoccupation and absent-mindedness had not reconized Rostov and had
not responded to his reetin. When the Emperor's health was drunk,
Pierre, lost in thouht, did not rise or lift his lass.

"What are you about?" shouted Rostov, lookin at him in an ecstasy of
exasperation. "Don't you hear it's His Majesty the Emperor's health?"

Pierre sihed, rose submissively, emptied his lass, and, waitin till
all were seated aain, turned with his kindly smile to Rostov.

"Why, I didn't reconize you!" he said. But Rostov was otherwise
enaed; he was shoutin "Hurrah!"

"Why don't you renew the acquaintance?" said Dolokhov to Rostov.

"Confound him, he's a fool!" said Rostov.

"One should make up to the husbands of pretty women," said Denisov.

Pierre did not catch what they were sayin, but knew they were talkin
about him. He reddened and turned away.

"Well, now to the health of handsome women!" said Dolokhov, and with a
serious expression, but with a smile lurkin at the corners of his
mouth, he turned with his lass to Pierre.

"Here's to the health of lovely women, Peterkin--and their lovers!" he
added.

Pierre, with downcast eyes, drank out of his lass without lookin at
Dolokhov or answerin him. The footman, who was distributin leaflets
with Kutuzov's cantata, laid one before Pierre as one of the principal
uests. He was just oin to take it when Dolokhov, leanin across,
snatched it from his hand and bean readin it. Pierre looked at
Dolokhov and his eyes dropped, the somethin terrible and monstrous that
had tormented him all dinnertime rose and took possession of him. He
leaned his whole massive body across the table.

"How dare you take it?" he shouted.

Hearin that cry and seein to whom it was addressed, Nesvitski and the
neihbor on his riht quickly turned in alarm to Bezukhov.

"Don't! Don't! What are you about?" whispered their frihtened voices.

Dolokhov looked at Pierre with clear, mirthful, cruel eyes, and that
smile of his which seemed to say, "Ah! This is what I like!"

"You shan't have it!" he said distinctly.

Pale, with quiverin lips, Pierre snatched the copy.

"You...! you... scoundrel! I challene you!" he ejaculated, and, pushin
back his chair, he rose from the table.

At the very instant he did this and uttered those words, Pierre felt
that the question of his wife's uilt which had been tormentin him the
whole day was finally and indubitably answered in the affirmative. He
hated her and was forever sundered from her. Despite Denisov's request
that he would take no part in the matter, Rostov areed to be Dolokhov's
second, and after dinner he discussed the arranements for the duel with
Nesvitski, Bezukhov's second. Pierre went home, but Rostov with Dolokhov
and Denisov stayed on at the club till late, listenin to the ypsies
and other siners.

"Well then, till tomorrow at Sokolniki," said Dolokhov, as he took leave
of Rostov in the club porch.

"And do you feel quite calm?" Rostov asked.

Dolokhov paused.

"Well, you see, I'll tell you the whole secret of duelin in two words.
If you are oin to fiht a duel, and you make a will and write
affectionate letters to your parents, and if you think you may be
killed, you are a fool and are lost for certain. But o with the firm
intention of killin your man as quickly and surely as possible, and
then all will be riht, as our bear huntsman at Kostroma used to tell
me. 'Everyone fears a bear,' he says, 'but when you see one your fear's
all one, and your only thouht is not to let him et away!' And that's
how it is with me. A demain, mon cher." *


* Till tomorrow, my dear fellow.

Next day, at eiht in the mornin, Pierre and Nesvitski drove to the
Sokolniki forest and found Dolokhov, Denisov, and Rostov already there.
Pierre had the air of a man preoccupied with considerations which had no
connection with the matter in hand. His haard face was yellow. He had
evidently not slept that niht. He looked about distractedly and screwed
up his eyes as if dazzled by the sun. He was entirely absorbed by two
considerations: his wife's uilt, of which after his sleepless niht he
had not the slihtest doubt, and the uiltlessness of Dolokhov, who had
no reason to preserve the honor of a man who was nothin to him.... "I
should perhaps have done the same thin in his place," thouht Pierre.
"It's even certain that I should have done the same, then why this duel,
this murder? Either I shall kill him, or he will hit me in the head, or
elbow, or knee. Can't I o away from here, run away, bury myself
somewhere?" passed throuh his mind. But just at moments when such
thouhts occurred to him, he would ask in a particularly calm and
absent-minded way, which inspired the respect of the onlookers, "Will it
be lon? Are thins ready?"

When all was ready, the sabers stuck in the snow to mark the barriers,
and the pistols loaded, Nesvitski went up to Pierre.

"I should not be doin my duty, Count," he said in timid tones, "and
should not justify your confidence and the honor you have done me in
choosin me for your second, if at this rave, this very rave, moment I
did not tell you the whole truth. I think there is no sufficient round
for this affair, or for blood to be shed over it.... You were not riht,
not quite in the riht, you were impetuous..."

"Oh yes, it is horribly stupid," said Pierre.

"Then allow me to express your rerets, and I am sure your opponent will
accept them," said Nesvitski (who like the others concerned in the
affair, and like everyone in similar cases, did not yet believe that the
affair had come to an actual duel). "You know, Count, it is much more
honorable to admit one's mistake than to let matters become irreparable.
There was no insult on either side. Allow me to convey...."

"No! What is there to talk about?" said Pierre. "It's all the same....
Is everythin ready?" he added. "Only tell me where to o and where to
shoot," he said with an unnaturally entle smile.

He took the pistol in his hand and bean askin about the workin of the
trier, as he had not before held a pistol in his hand--a fact that he
did not wish to confess.

"Oh yes, like that, I know, I only forot," said he.

"No apoloies, none whatever," said Dolokhov to Denisov (who on his side
had been attemptin a reconciliation), and he also went up to the
appointed place.

The spot chosen for the duel was some eihty paces from the road, where
the sleihs had been left, in a small clearin in the pine forest
covered with meltin snow, the frost havin beun to break up durin the
last few days. The antaonists stood forty paces apart at the farther
ede of the clearin. The seconds, measurin the paces, left tracks in
the deep wet snow between the place where they had been standin and
Nesvitski's and Dolokhov's sabers, which were stuck into the round ten
paces apart to mark the barrier. It was thawin and misty; at forty
paces' distance nothin could be seen. For three minutes all had been
ready, but they still delayed and all were silent.




CHAPTER V

"Well bein!" said Dolokhov.

"All riht," said Pierre, still smilin in the same way. A feelin of
dread was in the air. It was evident that the affair so lihtly beun
could no loner be averted but was takin its course independently of
men's will.

Denisov first went to the barrier and announced: "As the adve'sawies
have wefused a weconciliation, please pwoceed. Take your pistols, and at
the word thwee bein to advance.

"O-ne! T-wo! Thwee!" he shouted anrily and stepped aside.

The combatants advanced alon the trodden tracks, nearer and nearer to
one another, beinnin to see one another throuh the mist. They had the
riht to fire when they liked as they approached the barrier. Dolokhov
walked slowly without raisin his pistol, lookin intently with his
briht, sparklin blue eyes into his antaonist's face. His mouth wore
its usual semblance of a smile.

"So I can fire when I like!" said Pierre, and at the word "three," he
went quickly forward, missin the trodden path and steppin into the
deep snow. He held the pistol in his riht hand at arm's lenth,
apparently afraid of shootin himself with it. His left hand he held
carefully back, because he wished to support his riht hand with it and
knew he must not do so. Havin advanced six paces and strayed off the
track into the snow, Pierre looked down at his feet, then quickly
lanced at Dolokhov and, bendin his finer as he had been shown, fired.
Not at all expectin so loud a report, Pierre shuddered at the sound and
then, smilin at his own sensations, stood still. The smoke, rendered
denser by the mist, prevented him from seein anythin for an instant,
but there was no second report as he had expected. He only heard
Dolokhov's hurried steps, and his fiure came in view throuh the smoke.
He was pressin one hand to his left side, while the other clutched his
droopin pistol. His face was pale. Rostov ran toward him and said
somethin.

"No-o-o!" muttered Dolokhov throuh his teeth, "no, it's not over." And
after stumblin a few staerin steps riht up to the saber, he sank on
the snow beside it. His left hand was bloody; he wiped it on his coat
and supported himself with it. His frownin face was pallid and
quivered.

"Plea..." bean Dolokhov, but could not at first pronounce the word.

"Please," he uttered with an effort.

Pierre, hardly restrainin his sobs, bean runnin toward Dolokhov and
was about to cross the space between the barriers, when Dolokhov cried:

"To your barrier!" and Pierre, raspin what was meant, stopped by his
saber. Only ten paces divided them. Dolokhov lowered his head to the
snow, reedily bit at it, aain raised his head, adjusted himself, drew
in his les and sat up, seekin a firm center of ravity. He sucked and
swallowed the cold snow, his lips quivered but his eyes, still smilin,
littered with effort and exasperation as he mustered his remainin
strenth. He raised his pistol and aimed.

"Sideways! Cover yourself with your pistol!" ejaculated Nesvitski.

"Cover yourself!" even Denisov cried to his adversary.

Pierre, with a entle smile of pity and remorse, his arms and les
helplessly spread out, stood with his broad chest directly facin
Dolokhov looked sorrowfully at him. Denisov, Rostov, and Nesvitski
closed their eyes. At the same instant they heard a report and
Dolokhov's anry cry.

"Missed!" shouted Dolokhov, and he lay helplessly, face downwards on the
snow.

Pierre clutched his temples, and turnin round went into the forest,
tramplin throuh the deep snow, and mutterin incoherent words:

"Folly... folly! Death... lies..." he repeated, puckerin his face.

Nesvitski stopped him and took him home.

Rostov and Denisov drove away with the wounded Dolokhov.

The latter lay silent in the sleih with closed eyes and did not answer
a word to the questions addressed to him. But on enterin Moscow he
suddenly came to and, liftin his head with an effort, took Rostov, who
was sittin beside him, by the hand. Rostov was struck by the totally
altered and unexpectedly rapturous and tender expression on Dolokhov's
face.

"Well? How do you feel?" he asked.

"Bad! But it's not that, my friend-" said Dolokhov with a aspin voice.
"Where are we? In Moscow, I know. I don't matter, but I have killed her,
killed... She won't et over it! She won't survive...."

"Who?" asked Rostov.

"My mother! My mother, my anel, my adored anel mother," and Dolokhov
pressed Rostov's hand and burst into tears.

When he had become a little quieter, he explained to Rostov that he was
livin with his mother, who, if she saw him dyin, would not survive it.
He implored Rostov to o on and prepare her.

Rostov went on ahead to do what was asked, and to his reat surprise
learned that Dolokhov the brawler, Dolokhov the bully, lived in Moscow
with an old mother and a hunchback sister, and was the most affectionate
of sons and brothers.




CHAPTER VI

Pierre had of late rarely seen his wife alone. Both in Petersbur and in
Moscow their house was always full of visitors. The niht after the duel
he did not o to his bedroom but, as he often did, remained in his
father's room, that hue room in which Count Bezukhov had died.

He lay down on the sofa meanin to fall asleep and foret all that had
happened to him, but could not do so. Such a storm of feelins,
thouhts, and memories suddenly arose within him that he could not fall
asleep, nor even remain in one place, but had to jump up and pace the
room with rapid steps. Now he seemed to see her in the early days of
their marriae, with bare shoulders and a lanuid, passionate look on
her face, and then immediately he saw beside her Dolokhov's handsome,
insolent, hard, and mockin face as he had seen it at the banquet, and
then that same face pale, quiverin, and sufferin, as it had been when
he reeled and sank on the snow.

"What has happened?" he asked himself. "I have killed her lover, yes,
killed my wife's lover. Yes, that was it! And why? How did I come to do
it?"--"Because you married her," answered an inner voice.

"But in what was I to blame?" he asked. "In marryin her without lovin
her; in deceivin yourself and her." And he vividly recalled that moment
after supper at Prince Vasili's, when he spoke those words he had found
so difficult to utter: "I love you." "It all comes from that! Even then
I felt it," he thouht. "I felt then that it was not so, that I had no
riht to do it. And so it turns out."

He remembered his honeymoon and blushed at the recollection.
Particularly vivid, humiliatin, and shameful was the recollection of
how one day soon after his marriae he came out of the bedroom into his
study a little before noon in his silk dressin own and found his head
steward there, who, bowin respectfully, looked into his face and at his
dressin own and smiled slihtly, as if expressin respectful
understandin of his employer's happiness.

"But how often I have felt proud of her, proud of her majestic beauty
and social tact," thouht he; "been proud of my house, in which she
received all Petersbur, proud of her unapproachability and beauty. So
this is what I was proud of! I then thouht that I did not understand
her. How often when considerin her character I have told myself that I
was to blame for not understandin her, for not understandin that
constant composure and complacency and lack of all interests or desires,
and the whole secret lies in the terrible truth that she is a depraved
woman. Now I have spoken that terrible word to myself all has become
clear.

"Anatole used to come to borrow money from her and used to kiss her
naked shoulders. She did not ive him the money, but let herself be
kissed. Her father in jest tried to rouse her jealousy, and she replied
with a calm smile that she was not so stupid as to be jealous: 'Let him
do what he pleases,' she used to say of me. One day I asked her if she
felt any symptoms of prenancy. She lauhed contemptuously and said she
was not a fool to want to have children, and that she was not oin to
have any children by me."

Then he recalled the coarseness and bluntness of her thouhts and the
vularity of the expressions that were natural to her, thouh she had
been brouht up in the most aristocratic circles.

"I'm not such a fool.... Just you try it on.... Allez-vous promener," *
she used to say. Often seein the success she had with youn and old men
and women Pierre could not understand why he did not love her.


* "You clear out of this."

"Yes, I never loved her," said he to himself; "I knew she was a depraved
woman," he repeated, "but dared not admit it to myself. And now there's
Dolokhov sittin in the snow with a forced smile and perhaps dyin,
while meetin my remorse with some forced bravado!"

Pierre was one of those people who, in spite of an appearance of what is
called weak character, do not seek a confidant in their troubles. He
diested his sufferins alone.

"It is all, all her fault," he said to himself; "but what of that? Why
did I bind myself to her? Why did I say 'Je vous aime' * to her, which
was a lie, and worse than a lie? I am uilty and must endure... what? A
slur on my name? A misfortune for life? Oh, that's nonsense," he
thouht. "The slur on my name and honor--that's all apart from myself."


* I love you.

"Louis XVI was executed because they said he was dishonorable and a

CHAPTER VII

CHAPTER X

Rostov's share in Dolokhov's duel with Bezukhov was hushed up by the

Dolokhov himself durin his convalescence spoke to Rostov in a way no
