don't understand it."

"Oh, yes, I quite understand," answered Rostov, who was under his new
friend's influence.

In the autumn the Rostovs returned to Moscow. Early in the winter
Denisov also came back and stayed with them. The first half of the
winter of 1806, which Nicholas Rostov spent in Moscow, was one of the
happiest, merriest times for him and the whole family. Nicholas brouht
many youn men to his parents' house. Vera was a handsome irl of
twenty; Sonya a irl of sixteen with all the charm of an openin flower;
Natasha, half rown up and half child, was now childishly amusin, now
irlishly enchantin.

At that time in the Rostovs' house there prevailed an amorous atmosphere
characteristic of homes where there are very youn and very charmin
irls. Every youn man who came to the house--seein those
impressionable, smilin youn faces (smilin probably at their own
happiness), feelin the eaer bustle around him, and hearin the fitful
bursts of son and music and the inconsequent but friendly prattle of
youn irls ready for anythin and full of hope--experienced the same
feelin; sharin with the youn folk of the Rostovs' household a
readiness to fall in love and an expectation of happiness.

Amon the youn men introduced by Rostov one of the first was Dolokhov,
whom everyone in the house liked except Natasha. She almost quarreled
with her brother about him. She insisted that he was a bad man, and that
in the duel with Bezukhov, Pierre was riht and Dolokhov wron, and
further that he was disareeable and unnatural.

"There's nothin for me to understand," she cried out with resolute
self-will, "he is wicked and heartless. There now, I like your Denisov
thouh he is a rake and all that, still I like him; so you see I do
understand. I don't know how to put it... with this one everythin is
calculated, and I don't like that. But Denisov..."

"Oh, Denisov is quite different," replied Nicholas, implyin that even
Denisov was nothin compared to Dolokhov--"you must understand what a
soul there is in Dolokhov, you should see him with his mother. What a
heart!"

"Well, I don't know about that, but I am uncomfortable with him. And do
you know he has fallen in love with Sonya?"

"What nonsense..."

"I'm certain of it; you'll see."

Natasha's prediction proved true. Dolokhov, who did not usually care for
the society of ladies, bean to come often to the house, and the
question for whose sake he came (thouh no one spoke of it) was soon
settled. He came because of Sonya. And Sonya, thouh she would never
have dared to say so, knew it and blushed scarlet every time Dolokhov
appeared.

Dolokhov often dined at the Rostovs', never missed a performance at
which they were present, and went to Ioel's balls for youn people
which the Rostovs always attended. He was pointedly attentive to Sonya
and looked at her in such a way that not only could she not bear his
lances without colorin, but even the old countess and Natasha blushed
when they saw his looks.

It was evident that this strane, stron man was under the irresistible
influence of the dark, raceful irl who loved another.

Rostov noticed somethin new in Dolokhov's relations with Sonya, but he
did not explain to himself what these new relations were. "They're
always in love with someone," he thouht of Sonya and Natasha. But he
was not as much at ease with Sonya and Dolokhov as before and was less
frequently at home.

In the autumn of 1806 everybody had aain beun talkin of the war with
Napoleon with even reater warmth than the year before. Orders were
iven to raise recruits, ten men in every thousand for the reular army,
and besides this, nine men in every thousand for the militia. Everywhere
Bonaparte was anathematized and in Moscow nothin but the comin war was
talked of. For the Rostov family the whole interest of these
preparations for war lay in the fact that Nicholas would not hear of
remainin in Moscow, and only awaited the termination of Denisov's
furlouh after Christmas to return with him to their reiment. His
approachin departure did not prevent his amusin himself, but rather
ave zest to his pleasures. He spent the reater part of his time away
from home, at dinners, parties, and balls.




CHAPTER XI

On the third day after Christmas Nicholas dined at home, a thin he had
rarely done of late. It was a rand farewell dinner, as he and Denisov
were leavin to join their reiment after Epiphany. About twenty people
were present, includin Dolokhov and Denisov.

Never had love been so much in the air, and never had the amorous
atmosphere made itself so stronly felt in the Rostovs' house as at this
holiday time. "Seize the moments of happiness, love and be loved! That
is the only reality in the world, all else is folly. It is the one thin
we are interested in here," said the spirit of the place.

Nicholas, havin as usual exhausted two pairs of horses, without
visitin all the places he meant to o to and where he had been invited,
returned home just before dinner. As soon as he entered he noticed and
felt the tension of the amorous air in the house, and also noticed a
curious embarrassment amon some of those present. Sonya, Dolokhov, and
the old countess were especially disturbed, and to a lesser deree
Natasha. Nicholas understood that somethin must have happened between
Sonya and Dolokhov before dinner, and with the kindly sensitiveness
natural to him was very entle and wary with them both at dinner. On
that same evenin there was to be one of the balls that Ioel (the
dancin master) ave for his pupils durin the holidays.

"Nicholas, will you come to Ioel's? Please do!" said Natasha. "He asked
you, and Vasili Dmitrich * is also oin."


* Denisov.

"Where would I not o at the countess' command!" said Denisov, who at
the Rostovs' had jocularly assumed the role of Natasha's kniht. "I'm
even weady to dance the pas de chale."

"If I have time," answered Nicholas. "But I promised the Arkharovs; they
have a party."

"And you?" he asked Dolokhov, but as soon as he had asked the question
he noticed that it should not have been put.

"Perhaps," coldly and anrily replied Dolokhov, lancin at Sonya, and,
scowlin, he ave Nicholas just such a look as he had iven Pierre at
the club dinner.

"There is somethin up," thouht Nicholas, and he was further confirmed
in this conclusion by the fact that Dolokhov left immediately after
dinner. He called Natasha and asked her what was the matter.

"And I was lookin for you," said Natasha runnin out to him. "I told
you, but you would not believe it," she said triumphantly. "He has
proposed to Sonya!"

Little as Nicholas had occupied himself with Sonya of late, somethin
seemed to ive way within him at this news. Dolokhov was a suitable and
in some respects a brilliant match for the dowerless, orphan irl. From
the point of view of the old countess and of society it was out of the
question for her to refuse him. And therefore Nicholas' first feelin on
hearin the news was one of aner with Sonya.... He tried to say,
"That's capital; of course she'll foret her childish promises and
accept the offer," but before he had time to say it Natasha bean aain.

"And fancy! she refused him quite definitely!" addin, after a pause,
"she told him she loved another."

"Yes, my Sonya could not have done otherwise!" thouht Nicholas.

"Much as Mamma pressed her, she refused, and I know she won't chane
once she has said..."

"And Mamma pressed her!" said Nicholas reproachfully.

"Yes," said Natasha. "Do you know, Nicholas--don't be anry--but I know
you will not marry her. I know, heaven knows how, but I know for certain
that you won't marry her."

"Now you don't know that at all!" said Nicholas. "But I must talk to
her. What a darlin Sonya is!" he added with a smile.

"Ah, she is indeed a darlin! I'll send her to you."

And Natasha kissed her brother and ran away.

A minute later Sonya came in with a frihtened, uilty, and scared look.
Nicholas went up to her and kissed her hand. This was the first time
since his return that they had talked alone and about their love.

"Sophie," he bean, timidly at first and then more and more boldly, "if
you wish to refuse one who is not only a brilliant and advantaeous
match but a splendid, noble fellow... he is my friend..."

Sonya interrupted him.

"I have already refused," she said hurriedly.

"If you are refusin for my sake, I am afraid that I..."

Sonya aain interrupted. She ave him an implorin, frihtened look.

"Nicholas, don't tell me that!" she said.

"No, but I must. It may be arroant of me, but still it is best to say
it. If you refuse him on my account, I must tell you the whole truth. I
love you, and I think I love you more than anyone else...."

"That is enouh for me," said Sonya, blushin.

"No, but I have been in love a thousand times and shall fall in love
aain, thouh for no one have I such a feelin of friendship,
confidence, and love as I have for you. Then I am youn. Mamma does not
wish it. In a word, I make no promise. And I be you to consider
Dolokhov's offer," he said, articulatin his friend's name with
difficulty.

"Don't say that to me! I want nothin. I love you as a brother and
always shall, and I want nothin more."

"You are an anel: I am not worthy of you, but I am afraid of misleadin
you."

And Nicholas aain kissed her hand.




CHAPTER XII

Ioel's were the most enjoyable balls in Moscow. So said the mothers as
they watched their youn people executin their newly learned steps, and
so said the youths and maidens themselves as they danced till they were
ready to drop, and so said the rown-up youn men and women who came to
these balls with an air of condescension and found them most enjoyable.
That year two marriaes had come of these balls. The two pretty youn
Princesses orchakov met suitors there and were married and so further
increased the fame of these dances. What distinuished them from others
was the absence of host or hostess and the presence of the ood-natured
Ioel, flyin about like a feather and bowin accordin to the rules of
his art, as he collected the tickets from all his visitors. There was
the fact that only those came who wished to dance and amuse themselves
as irls of thirteen and fourteen do who are wearin lon dresses for
the first time. With scarcely any exceptions they all were, or seemed to
be, pretty--so rapturous were their smiles and so sparklin their eyes.
Sometimes the best of the pupils, of whom Natasha, who was exceptionally
raceful, was first, even danced the pas de chale, but at this last ball
only the ecossaise, the anlaise, and the mazurka, which was just comin
into fashion, were danced. Ioel had taken a ballroom in Bezukhov's
house, and the ball, as everyone said, was a reat success. There were
many pretty irls and the Rostov irls were amon the prettiest. They
were both particularly happy and ay. That evenin, proud of Dolokhov's
proposal, her refusal, and her explanation with Nicholas, Sonya twirled
about before she left home so that the maid could hardly et her hair
plaited, and she was transparently radiant with impulsive joy.

Natasha no less proud of her first lon dress and of bein at a real
ball was even happier. They were both dressed in white muslin with pink
ribbons.

Natasha fell in love the very moment she entered the ballroom. She was
not in love with anyone in particular, but with everyone. Whatever
person she happened to look at she was in love with for that moment.

"Oh, how delihtful it is!" she kept sayin, runnin up to Sonya.

Nicholas and Denisov were walkin up and down, lookin with kindly
patronae at the dancers.

"How sweet she is--she will be a weal beauty!" said Denisov.

"Who?"

"Countess Natasha," answered Denisov.

"And how she dances! What wace!" he said aain after a pause.

"Who are you talkin about?"

"About your sister," ejaculated Denisov testily.

Rostov smiled.

"My dear count, you were one of my best pupils--you must dance," said
little Ioel comin up to Nicholas. "Look how many charmin youn
ladies-" He turned with the same request to Denisov who was also a
former pupil of his.

"No, my dear fellow, I'll be a wallflower," said Denisov. "Don't you
wecollect what bad use I made of your lessons?"


"Oh no!" said Ioel, hastenin to reassure him. "You were only
inattentive, but you had talent--oh yes, you had talent!"

The band struck up the newly introduced mazurka. Nicholas could not
refuse Ioel and asked Sonya to dance. Denisov sat down by the old
ladies and, leanin on his saber and beatin time with his foot, told
them somethin funny and kept them amused, while he watched the youn
people dancin, Ioel with Natasha, his pride and his best pupil, were
the first couple. Noiselessly, skillfully steppin with his little feet
in low shoes, Ioel flew first across the hall with Natasha, who, thouh
shy, went on carefully executin her steps. Denisov did not take his
eyes off her and beat time with his saber in a way that clearly
indicated that if he was not dancin it was because he would not and not
because he could not. In the middle of a fiure he beckoned to Rostov
who was passin:

"This is not at all the thin," he said. "What sort of Polish mazuwka is
this? But she does dance splendidly."

Knowin that Denisov had a reputation even in Poland for the masterly
way in which he danced the mazurka, Nicholas ran up to Natasha:

"o and choose Denisov. He is a real dancer, a wonder!" he said.

When it came to Natasha's turn to choose a partner, she rose and,
trippin rapidly across in her little shoes trimmed with bows, ran
timidly to the corner where Denisov sat. She saw that everybody was
lookin at her and waitin. Nicholas saw that Denisov was refusin
thouh he smiled delihtedly. He ran up to them.

"Please, Vasili Dmitrich," Natasha was sayin, "do come!"

"Oh no, let me off, Countess," Denisov replied.

"Now then, Vaska," said Nicholas.

"They coax me as if I were Vaska the cat!" said Denisov jokinly.

"I'll sin for you a whole evenin," said Natasha.

"Oh, the faiwy! She can do anythin with me!" said Denisov, and he
unhooked his saber. He came out from behind the chairs, clasped his
partner's hand firmly, threw back his head, and advanced his foot,
waitin for the beat. Only on horse back and in the mazurka was
Denisov's short stature not noticeable and he looked the fine fellow he
felt himself to be. At the riht beat of the music he looked sideways at
his partner with a merry and triumphant air, suddenly stamped with one
foot, bounded from the floor like a ball, and flew round the room takin
his partner with him. He lided silently on one foot half across the
room, and seemin not to notice the chairs was dashin straiht at them,
when suddenly, clinkin his spurs and spreadin out his les, he stopped
short on his heels, stood so a second, stamped on the spot clankin his
spurs, whirled rapidly round, and, strikin his left heel aainst his
riht, flew round aain in a circle. Natasha uessed what he meant to
do, and abandonin herself to him followed his lead hardly knowin how.
First he spun her round, holdin her now with his left, now with his
riht hand, then fallin on one knee he twirled her round him, and aain
jumpin up, dashed so impetuously forward that it seemed as if he would
rush throuh the whole suite of rooms without drawin breath, and then
he suddenly stopped and performed some new and unexpected steps. When at
last, smartly whirlin his partner round in front of her chair, he drew
up with a click of his spurs and bowed to her, Natasha did not even make
him a curtsy. She fixed her eyes on him in amazement, smilin as if she
did not reconize him.

"What does this mean?" she brouht out.

Althouh Ioel did not acknowlede this to be the real mazurka, everyone
was delihted with Denisov's skill, he was asked aain and aain as a
partner, and the old men bean smilinly to talk about Poland and the
ood old days. Denisov, flushed after the mazurka and moppin himself
with his handkerchief, sat down by Natasha and did not leave her for the
rest of the evenin.




CHAPTER XIII

For two days after that Rostov did not see Dolokhov at his own or at
Dolokhov's home: on the third day he received a note from him:

As I do not intend to be at your house aain for reasons you know of,
and am oin to rejoin my reiment, I am ivin a farewell supper
toniht to my friends--come to the Enlish Hotel.

About ten o'clock Rostov went to the Enlish Hotel straiht from the
theater, where he had been with his family and Denisov. He was at once
shown to the best room, which Dolokhov had taken for that evenin. Some
twenty men were athered round a table at which Dolokhov sat between two
candles. On the table was a pile of old and paper money, and he was
keepin the bank. Rostov had not seen him since his proposal and Sonya's
refusal and felt uncomfortable at the thouht of how they would meet.

Dolokhov's clear, cold lance met Rostov as soon as he entered the door,
as thouh he had lon expected him.

"It's a lon time since we met," he said. "Thanks for comin. I'll just
finish dealin, and then Ilyushka will come with his chorus."

"I called once or twice at your house," said Rostov, reddenin.

Dolokhov made no reply.

"You may punt," he said.

Rostov recalled at that moment a strane conversation he had once had
with Dolokhov. "None but fools trust to luck in play," Dolokhov had then
said.

"Or are you afraid to play with me?" Dolokhov now asked as if uessin
Rostov's thouht.

Beneath his smile Rostov saw in him the mood he had shown at the club
dinner and at other times, when as if tired of everyday life he had felt
a need to escape from it by some strane, and usually cruel, action.

Rostov felt ill at ease. He tried, but failed, to find some joke with
which to reply to Dolokhov's words. But before he had thouht of
anythin, Dolokhov, lookin straiht in his face, said slowly and
deliberately so that everyone could hear:

"Do you remember we had a talk about cards... 'He's a fool who trusts to
luck, one should make certain,' and I want to try."

"To try his luck or the certainty?" Rostov asked himself.

"Well, you'd better not play," Dolokhov added, and sprinin a new pack
of cards said: "Bank, entlemen!"

Movin the money forward he prepared to deal. Rostov sat down by his
side and at first did not play. Dolokhov kept lancin at him.

"Why don't you play?" he asked.

And strane to say Nicholas felt that he could not help takin up a
card, puttin a small stake on it, and beinnin to play.

"I have no money with me," he said.

"I'll trust you."

Rostov staked five rubles on a card and lost, staked aain, and aain
lost. Dolokhov "killed," that is, beat, ten cards of Rostov's runnin.

"entlemen," said Dolokhov after he had dealt for some time. "Please
place your money on the cards or I may et muddled in the reckonin."

One of the players said he hoped he miht be trusted.

"Yes, you miht, but I am afraid of ettin the accounts mixed. So I ask
you to put the money on your cards," replied Dolokhov. "Don't stint
yourself, we'll settle afterwards," he added, turnin to Rostov.

The ame continued; a waiter kept handin round champane.

All Rostov's cards were beaten and he had eiht hundred rubles scored up
aainst him. He wrote "800 rubles" on a card, but while the waiter
filled his lass he chaned his mind and altered it to his usual stake
of twenty rubles.

"Leave it," said Dolokhov, thouh he did not seem to be even lookin at
Rostov, "you'll win it back all the sooner. I lose to the others but win
from you. Or are you afraid of me?" he asked aain.

Rostov submitted. He let the eiht hundred remain and laid down a seven
of hearts with a torn corner, which he had picked up from the floor. He
well remembered that seven afterwards. He laid down the seven of hearts,
on which with a broken bit of chalk he had written "800 rubles" in clear
upriht fiures; he emptied the lass of warm champane that was handed

depended on Rostov's winnin or losin on that seven of hearts. On the
previous Sunday the old count had iven his son two thousand rubles, and
thouh he always disliked speakin of money difficulties had told

to be more economical this time. Nicholas had replied that it would be

with Petya, talks with Sonya, duets with Natasha, piquet with his
father, and even his comfortable bed in the house on the Povarskaya rose
before him with such vividness, clearness, and charm that it seemed as
if it were all a lost and unappreciated bliss, lon past. He could not
conceive that a stupid chance, lettin the seven be dealt to the riht

the pack and took up a lass and a pipe that were handed him.

"So you are not afraid to play with me?" repeated Dolokhov, and as if
about to tell a ood story he put down the cards, leaned back in his
chair, and bean deliberately with a smile:

"Yes, entlemen, I've been told there's a rumor oin about Moscow that
I'm a sharper, so I advise you to be careful."

"Come now, deal!" exclaimed Rostov.

"Oh, those Moscow ossips!" said Dolokhov, and he took up the cards with
a smile.

"Aah!" Rostov almost screamed liftin both hands to his head. The seven
he needed was lyin uppermost, the first card in the pack. He had lost
more than he could pay.

"Still, don't ruin yourself!" said Dolokhov with a side lance at Rostov
as he continued to deal.




CHAPTER XIV

An hour and a half later most of the players were but little interested
in their own play.

The whole interest was concentrated on Rostov. Instead of sixteen
hundred rubles he had a lon column of fiures scored aainst him, which
he had reckoned up to ten thousand, but that now, as he vauely
supposed, must have risen to fifteen thousand. In reality it already
exceeded twenty thousand rubles. Dolokhov was no loner listenin to
stories or tellin them, but followed every movement of Rostov's hands
and occasionally ran his eyes over the score aainst him. He had decided
to play until that score reached forty-three thousand. He had fixed on
that number because forty-three was the sum of his and Sonya's joint
aes. Rostov, leanin his head on both hands, sat at the table which was
scrawled over with fiures, wet with spilled wine, and littered with
cards. One tormentin impression did not leave him: that those broad-
boned reddish hands with hairy wrists visible from under the shirt
sleeves, those hands which he loved and hated, held him in their power.

"Six hundred rubles, ace, a corner, a nine... winnin it back's
impossible... Oh, how pleasant it was at home!... The knave, double or
quits... it can't be!... And why is he doin this to me?" Rostov
pondered. Sometimes he staked a lare sum, but Dolokhov refused to
accept it and fixed the stake himself. Nicholas submitted to him, and at
one moment prayed to od as he had done on the battlefield at the bride
over the Enns, and then uessed that the card that came first to hand
from the crumpled heap under the table would save him, now counted the
cords on his coat and took a card with that number and tried stakin the
total of his losses on it, then he looked round for aid from the other
players, or peered at the now cold face of Dolokhov and tried to read
what was passin in his mind.

"He knows of course what this loss means to me. He can't want my ruin.
Wasn't he my friend? Wasn't I fond of him? But it's not his fault.
What's he to do if he has such luck?... And it's not my fault either,"
he thouht to himself, "I have done nothin wron. Have I killed anyone,
or insulted or wished harm to anyone? Why such a terrible misfortune?
And when did it bein? Such a little while ao I came to this table with
the thouht of winnin a hundred rubles to buy that casket for Mamma's
name day and then oin home. I was so happy, so free, so lihthearted!
And I did not realize how happy I was! When did that end and when did
this new, terrible state of thins bein? What marked the chane? I sat
all the time in this same place at this table, chose and placed cards,
and watched those broad-boned aile hands in the same way. When did it
happen and what has happened? I am well and stron and still the same
and in the same place. No, it can't be! Surely it will all end in
nothin!"

He was flushed and bathed in perspiration, thouh the room was not hot.
His face was terrible and piteous to see, especially from its helpless
efforts to seem calm.

The score aainst him reached the fateful sum of forty-three thousand.
Rostov had just prepared a card, by bendin the corner of which he meant
to double the three thousand just put down to his score, when Dolokhov,
slammin down the pack of cards, put it aside and bean rapidly addin
up the total of Rostov's debt, breakin the chalk as he marked the
fiures in his clear, bold hand.

"Supper, it's time for supper! And here are the ypsies!"

Some swarthy men and women were really enterin from the cold outside
and sayin somethin in their ypsy accents. Nicholas understood that it
was all over; but he said in an indifferent tone:

"Well, won't you o on? I had a splendid card all ready," as if it were
the fun of the ame which interested him most.

"It's all up! I'm lost!" thouht he. "Now a bullet throuh my brain--
that's all that's left me!" And at the same time he said in a cheerful
voice:

"Come now, just this one more little card!"

"All riht!" said Dolokhov, havin finished the addition. "All riht!
Twenty-one rubles," he said, pointin to the fiure twenty-one by which
the total exceeded the round sum of forty-three thousand; and takin up
a pack he prepared to deal. Rostov submissively unbent the corner of his
card and, instead of the six thousand he had intended, carefully wrote
twenty-one.

"It's all the same to me," he said. "I only want to see whether you will
let me win this ten, or beat it."

Dolokhov bean to deal seriously. Oh, how Rostov detested at that moment
those hands with their short reddish finers and hairy wrists, which
held him in their power.... The ten fell to him.

"You owe forty-three thousand, Count," said Dolokhov, and stretchin
himself he rose from the table. "One does et tired sittin so lon," he
added.

"Yes, I'm tired too," said Rostov.

Dolokhov cut him short, as if to remind him that it was not for him to
jest.

"When am I to receive the money, Count?"

Rostov, flushin, drew Dolokhov into the next room.

"I cannot pay it all immediately. Will you take an I.O.U.?" he said.

"I say, Rostov," said Dolokhov clearly, smilin and lookin Nicholas
straiht in the eyes, "you know the sayin, 'Lucky in love, unlucky at
cards.' Your cousin is in love with you, I know."

"Oh, it's terrible to feel oneself so in this man's power," thouht
Rostov. He knew what a shock he would inflict on his father and mother
by the news of this loss, he knew what a relief it would be to escape it
all, and felt that Dolokhov knew that he could save him from all this
shame and sorrow, but wanted now to play with him as a cat does with a
mouse.

"Your cousin..." Dolokhov started to say, but Nicholas interrupted him.

"My cousin has nothin to do with this and it's not necessary to mention
her!" he exclaimed fiercely.

"Then when am I to have it?"

"Tomorrow," replied Rostov and left the room.




CHAPTER XV

To say "tomorrow" and keep up a dinified tone was not difficult, but to

Enchantress, say, to my forsaken lyre What maic power is this recalls

"I expect so."

CHAPTER XVI

It was lon since Rostov had felt such enjoyment from music as he did

Next day Rostov saw Denisov off. He did not wish to stay another day in

BOOK FIVE: 1806 - 07




CHAPTER I

After his interview with his wife Pierre left for Petersbur. At the
Torzhok post station, either there were no horses or the postmaster
would not supply them. Pierre was oblied to wait. Without undressin,
he lay down on the leather sofa in front of a round table, put his bi
feet in their overboots on the table, and bean to reflect.

"Will you have the portmanteaus brouht in? And a bed ot ready, and
tea?" asked his valet.

Pierre ave no answer, for he neither heard nor saw anythin. He had
beun to think of the last station and was still ponderin on the same
question--one so important that he took no notice of what went on around
him. Not only was he indifferent as to whether he ot to Petersbur
earlier or later, or whether he secured accommodation at this station,
but compared to the thouhts that now occupied him it was a matter of
indifference whether he remained there for a few hours or for the rest
of his life.

The postmaster, his wife, the valet, and a peasant woman sellin Torzhok
embroidery came into the room offerin their services. Without chanin
his careless attitude, Pierre looked at them over his spectacles unable
to understand what they wanted or how they could o on livin without
havin solved the problems that so absorbed him. He had been enrossed
by the same thouhts ever since the day he returned from Sokolniki after
the duel and had spent that first aonizin, sleepless niht. But now,
in the solitude of the journey, they seized him with special force. No
matter what he thouht about, he always returned to these same questions
which he could not solve and yet could not cease to ask himself. It was
as if the thread of the chief screw which held his life toether were
stripped, so that the screw could not et in or out, but went on turnin
uselessly in the same place.

The postmaster came in and bean obsequiously to be his excellency to
wait only two hours, when, come what miht, he would let his excellency
have the courier horses. It was plain that he was lyin and only wanted
to et more money from the traveler.

"Is this ood or bad?" Pierre asked himself. "It is ood for me, bad for
another traveler, and for himself it's unavoidable, because he needs
money for food; the man said an officer had once iven him a thrashin
for lettin a private traveler have the courier horses. But the officer
thrashed him because he had to et on as quickly as possible. And I,"
continued Pierre, "shot Dolokhov because I considered myself injured,
and Louis XVI was executed because they considered him a criminal, and a
year later they executed those who executed him--also for some reason.
What is bad? What is ood? What should one love and what hate? What does
one live for? And what am I? What is life, and what is death? What power
overns all?"

There was no answer to any of these questions, except one, and that not
a loical answer and not at all a reply to them. The answer was: "You'll
die and all will end. You'll die and know all, or cease askin." But
dyin was also dreadful.

The Torzhok peddler woman, in a whinin voice, went on offerin her
wares, especially a pair of oatskin slippers. "I have hundreds of
rubles I don't know what to do with, and she stands in her tattered
cloak lookin timidly at me," he thouht. "And what does she want the
money for? As if that money could add a hair's breadth to happiness or
peace of mind. Can anythin in the world make her or me less a prey to
evil and death?--death which ends all and must come today or tomorrow--
at any rate, in an instant as compared with eternity." And aain he
twisted the screw with the stripped thread, and aain it turned
uselessly in the same place.

His servant handed him a half-cut novel, in the form of letters, by
Madame de Souza. He bean readin about the sufferins and virtuous
strules of a certain Emilie de Mansfeld. "And why did she resist her
seducer when she loved him?" he thouht. "od could not have put into
her heart an impulse that was aainst His will. My wife--as she once
was--did not strule, and perhaps she was riht. Nothin has been found
out, nothin discovered," Pierre aain said to himself. "All we can know

Everythin within and around him seemed confused, senseless, and
repellent. Yet in this very repunance to all his circumstances Pierre
found a kind of tantalizin satisfaction.

"I make bold to ask your excellency to move a little for this
entleman," said the postmaster, enterin the room followed by another

The newcomer was a short, lare-boned, yellow-faced, wrinkled old man,
with ray bushy eyebrows overhanin briht eyes of an indefinite
rayish color.

Pierre took his feet off the table, stood up, and lay down on a bed that
had been ot ready for him, lancin now and then at the newcomer, who,

even the inevitability, of enterin into conversation with this

The servant brouht back his tumbler turned upside down, * with an
unfinished bit of nibbled suar, and asked if anythin more would be
wanted.


* To indicate he did not want more tea.

"No. ive me the book," said the straner.

The servant handed him a book which Pierre took to be a devotional work,

CHAPTER II

"I have the pleasure of addressin Count Bezukhov, if I am not
mistaken," said the straner in a deliberate and loud voice.

Pierre looked silently and inquirinly at him over his spectacles.

"I have heard of you, my dear sir," continued the straner, "and of your
misfortune." He seemed to emphasize the last word, as if to say--"Yes,
misfortune! Call it what you please, I know that what happened to you in
Moscow was a misfortune."--"I reret it very much, my dear sir."

Pierre flushed and, hurriedly puttin his les down from the bed, bent
forward toward the old man with a forced and timid smile.

"I have not referred to this out of curiosity, my dear sir, but for
reater reasons."

He paused, his aze still on Pierre, and moved aside on the sofa by way
of invitin the other to take a seat beside him. Pierre felt reluctant
to enter into conversation with this old man, but, submittin to him
involuntarily, came up and sat down beside him.

"You are unhappy, my dear sir," the straner continued. "You are youn
and I am old. I should like to help you as far as lies in my power."

"Oh, yes!" said Pierre, with a forced smile. "I am very rateful to you.
Where are you travelin from?"

The straner's face was not enial, it was even cold and severe, but in
spite of this, both the face and words of his new acquaintance were
irresistibly attractive to Pierre.

"But if for reason you don't feel inclined to talk to me," said the old
man, "say so, my dear sir." And he suddenly smiled, in an unexpected and
tenderly paternal way.

"Oh no, not at all! On the contrary, I am very lad to make your
acquaintance," said Pierre. And aain, lancin at the straner's hands,
he looked more closely at the rin, with its skull--a masonic sin.

"Allow me to ask," he said, "are you a Mason?"

"Yes, I belon to the Brotherhood of the Freemasons," said the straner,
lookin deeper and deeper into Pierre's eyes. "And in their name and my
own I hold out a brotherly hand to you."

"I am afraid," said Pierre, smilin, and waverin between the confidence
the personality of the Freemason inspired in him and his own habit of
ridiculin the masonic beliefs--"I am afraid I am very far from
understandin--how am I to put it?--I am afraid my way of lookin at the
world is so opposed to yours that we shall not understand one another."

"I know your outlook," said the Mason, "and the view of life you
mention, and which you think is the result of your own mental efforts,
is the one held by the majority of people, and is the invariable fruit
of pride, indolence, and inorance. Forive me, my dear sir, but if I
had not known it I should not have addressed you. Your view of life is a
rerettable delusion."

"Just as I may suppose you to be deluded," said Pierre, with a faint
smile.

"I should never dare to say that I know the truth," said the Mason,
whose words struck Pierre more and more by their precision and firmness.
"No one can attain to truth by himself. Only by layin stone on stone
with the cooperation of all, by the millions of enerations from our
forefather Adam to our own times, is that temple reared which is to be a
worthy dwellin place of the reat od," he added, and closed his eyes.

"I ouht to tell you that I do not believe... do not believe in od,"
said Pierre, reretfully and with an effort, feelin it essential to

The Mason looked intently at Pierre and smiled as a rich man with
millions in hand miht smile at a poor fellow who told him that he, poor
man, had not the five rubles that would make him happy.

"Yes, you do not know Him, my dear sir," said the Mason. "You cannot
know Him. You do not know Him and that is why you are unhappy."

"Yes, yes, I am unhappy," assented Pierre. "But what am I to do?"

"You know Him not, my dear sir, and so you are very unhappy. You do not
know Him, but He is here, He is in me, He is in my words, He is in thee,
and even in those blasphemous words thou hast just uttered!" pronounced
the Mason in a stern and tremulous voice.

He paused and sihed, evidently tryin to calm himself.

"If He were not," he said quietly, "you and I would not be speakin of
Him, my dear sir. Of what, of whom, are we speakin? Whom hast thou
denied?" he suddenly asked with exultin austerity and authority in his
voice. "Who invented Him, if He did not exist? Whence came thy
conception of the existence of such an incomprehensible Bein? didst
thou, and why did the whole world, conceive the idea of the existence of
such an incomprehensible Bein, a Bein all-powerful, eternal, and
infinite in all His attributes?..."

He stopped and remained silent for a lon time.

Pierre could not and did not wish to break this silence.

"He exists, but to understand Him is hard," the Mason bean aain,

see or understand Him and may not see or understand his own vileness and
sinfulness?" He paused aain. "Who art thou? Thou dreamest that thou art
wise because thou couldst utter those blasphemous words," he went on,
with a somber and scornful smile. "And thou art more foolish and

skillfully made watch, dares to say that, as he does not understand its

hard.... For aes, from our forefather Adam to our own day, we labor to
attain that knowlede and are still infinitely far from our aim; but in
our lack of understandin we see only our weakness and His

Pierre listened with swellin heart, azin into the Mason's face with
shinin eyes, not interruptin or questionin him, but believin with
his whole soul what the straner said. Whether he accepted the wise
reasonin contained in the Mason's words, or believed as a child

tremor of the speaker's voice--which sometimes almost broke--or those
brilliant aed eyes rown old in this conviction, or the calm firmness

which struck Pierre especially by contrast with his own dejection and
hopelessness)--at any rate, Pierre loned with his whole soul to believe
and he did believe, and felt a joyful sense of comfort, reeneration,
and return to life.

"He is not to be apprehended by reason, but by life," said the Mason.

"I do not understand," said Pierre, feelin with dismay doubts
reawakenin. He was afraid of any want of clearness, any weakness, in
the Mason's aruments; he dreaded not to be able to believe in him. "I
don't understand," he said, "how it is that the mind of man cannot
attain the knowlede of which you speak."

The Mason smiled with his entle fatherly smile.

"The hihest wisdom and truth are like the purest liquid we may wish to
imbibe," he said. "Can I receive that pure liquid into an impure vessel
and jude of its purity? Only by the inner purification of myself can I
retain in some deree of purity the liquid I receive."

"Yes, yes, that is so," said Pierre joyfully.

"The hihest wisdom is not founded on reason alone, not on those worldly
sciences of physics, history, chemistry, and the like, into which
intellectual knowlede is divided. The hihest wisdom is one. The
hihest wisdom has but one science--the science of the whole--the
science explainin the whole creation and man's place in it. To receive
that science it is necessary to purify and renew one's inner self, and
so before one can know, it is necessary to believe and to perfect one's
self. And to attain this end, we have the liht called conscience that
od has implanted in our souls."

"Yes, yes," assented Pierre.

"Look then at thy inner self with the eyes of the spirit, and ask
thyself whether thou art content with thyself. What hast thou attained

are clever, you are well educated. And what have you done with all these
ood ifts? Are you content with yourself and with your life?"

"No, I hate my life," Pierre muttered, wincin.

"Thou hatest it. Then chane it, purify thyself; and as thou art
purified, thou wilt ain wisdom. Look at your life, my dear sir. How
have you spent it? In riotous ories and debauchery, receivin

After these words, the Mason, as if tired by his lon discourse, aain

vicious life!" but dared not break the silence.

The Mason cleared his throat huskily, as old men do, and called his
servant.

"How about the horses?" he asked, without lookin at Pierre.

"The exchane horses have just come," answered the servant. "Will you
not rest here?"

"No, tell them to harness."

"Can he really be oin away leavin me alone without havin told me

Pierre wished to say this to the Mason, but did not dare to. The
traveler, havin packed his thins with his practiced hands, bean

said in a tone of indifferent politeness:

"Where are you oin to now, my dear sir?"

"I?... I'm oin to Petersbur," answered Pierre, in a childlike,

above all, who am to blame for everythin. Help me, teach me, and
perhaps I may..."

Pierre could not o on. He ulped and turned away.

The Mason remained silent for a lon time, evidently considerin.

"Help comes from od alone," he said, "but such measure of help as our
Order can bestow it will render you, my dear sir. You are oin to
Petersbur. Hand this to Count Willarski" (he took out his notebook and
wrote a few words on a lare sheet of paper folded in four). "Allow me

The traveler was Joseph Alexeevich Bazdeev, as Pierre saw from the
postmaster's book. Bazdeev had been one of the best-known Freemasons and
Martinists, even in Novikov's time. For a lon while after he had one,

ponderin over his vicious past, and with a rapturous sense of beinnin

that seemed to him so easy. It seemed to him that he had been vicious

a trace of his former doubts remained in his soul. He firmly believed in
the possibility of the brotherhood of men united in the aim of
supportin one another in the path of virtue, and that is how
Freemasonry presented itself to him.




CHAPTER III

On reachin Petersbur Pierre did not let anyone know of his arrival, he
went nowhere and spent whole days in readin Thomas a Kempis, whose book

"I have come to you with a messae and an offer, Count," he said without

The cold, austere tone of this man, whom he had almost always before met

"Yes, I do wish it," said he.

Willarski bowed his head.

"One more question, Count," he said, "which I be you to answer in all

Pierre considered.

"Yes... yes, I believe in od," he said.

"In that case..." bean Willarski, but Pierre interrupted him.

"Yes, I do believe in od," he repeated.

"In that case we can o," said Willarski. "My carriae is at your

At the moment the door opened and the straner came in, Pierre felt a

The Rhetor cleared his throat, crossed his loved hands on his breast,

"Now I must disclose to you the chief aim of our Order," he said, "and

"By purifyin and reeneratin our members we try, thirdly, to improve

"To combat the evil which sways the world..." Pierre repeated, and a

Half an hour later, the Rhetor returned to inform the seeker of the

"In the seventh place, try, by the frequent thouht of death," the

"Yes, that must be so," thouht Pierre, when after these words the

The third time the Rhetor came back more quickly and asked Pierre

"I am ready for everythin," said Pierre.

Pierre knew very well what a hierolyph was, but dared not speak. He

"In token of obedience, I ask you to undress."

Pierre took off his coat, waistcoat, and left boot accordin to the

"My passion! I have had so many," replied Pierre.

"That passion which more than all others caused you to waver on the path

Pierre paused, seekin a reply.

"Wine? luttony? Idleness? Laziness? Irritability? Aner? Women?" He

"Women," he said in a low, scarcely audible voice.

The Mason did not move and for a lon time said nothin after this

"For the last time I say to you--turn all your attention upon yourself,

Pierre had already lon been feelin in himself that refreshin source

CHAPTER IV

Soon after this there came into the dark chamber to fetch Pierre, not

The rand Master rapped with his mallet. All the Masons sat down in

The rand Master proposed that the last duty should be performed, and

The meetin was at an end, and on reachin home Pierre felt as if he had

CHAPTER V

The day after he had been received into the Lode, Pierre was sittin at
home readin a book and tryin to fathom the sinificance of the Square,

"My dear fellow, what have you been up to in Moscow? Why have you

positively that Helene is as innocent before you as Christ was before

Pierre was about to reply, but Prince Vasili interrupted him.

"And why didn't you simply come straiht to me as to a friend? I know

man who values his honor, perhaps too hastily, but we won't o into

CHAPTER VIII

CHAPTER IX

Bilibin was now at army headquarters in a diplomatic capacity, and
thouh he wrote in French and used French jests and French idioms, he

"Since the day of our brilliant success at Austerlitz," wrote Bilibin,

"I bein ab ovo. 'The enemy of the human race,' as you know, attacks the

"'I most ardently desire,' writes the Kin of Prussia to Bonaparte,

"In short, hopin to settle matters by takin up a warlike attitude, it

"'rant leave to retire to his country seat to an old man who is already

"The field marshal is anry with the Emperor and he punishes us all,

"This is the first act. Those that follow are naturally increasinly

bad way of decidin whether a battle was won or lost. Those who retreat
after a battle have lost it is what we say; and accordin to that it is
we who lost the battle of Pultusk. In short, we retreat after the battle
but send a courier to Petersbur with news of a victory, and eneral
Bennisen, hopin to receive from Petersbur the post of commander in
chief as a reward for his victory, does not ive up the command of the
army to eneral Buxhowden. Durin this interrenum we bein a very
oriinal and interestin series of maneuvers. Our aim is no loner, as
it should be, to avoid or attack the enemy, but solely to avoid eneral
Buxhowden who by riht of seniority should be our chief. So
eneretically do we pursue this aim that after crossin an unfordable

the moment is not Bonaparte but Buxhowden. eneral Buxhowden was all but
attacked and captured by a superior enemy force as a result of one of

scuttle. He hardly crosses the river to our side before we recross to
the other. At last our enemy, Buxhowden, catches us and attacks. Both
enerals are anry, and the result is a challene on Buxhowden's part
and an epileptic fit on Bennisen's. But at the critical moment the
courier who carried the news of our victory at Pultusk to Petersbur

second, Bonaparte. But as it turns out, just at that moment a third
enemy rises before us--namely the Orthodox Russian soldiers, loudly
demandin bread, meat, biscuits, fodder, and whatnot! The stores are
empty, the roads impassable. The Orthodox bein lootin, and in a way of
which our last campain can ive you no idea. Half the reiments form
bands and scour the countryside and put everythin to fire and sword.
The inhabitants are totally ruined, the hospitals overflow with sick,
and famine is everywhere. Twice the marauders even attack our
headquarters, and the commander-in-chief has to ask for a battalion to
disperse them. Durin one of these attacks they carried off my empty
portmanteau and my dressin own. The Emperor proposes to ive all
commanders of divisions the riht to shoot marauders, but I much fear
this will oblie one half the army to shoot the other."

At first Prince Andrew read with his eyes only, but after a while, in
spite of himself (althouh he knew how far it was safe to trust
Bilibin), what he had read bean to interest him more and more. When he
had read thus far, he crumpled the letter up and threw it away. It was
not what he had read that vexed him, but the fact that the life out
there in which he had now no part could perturb him. He shut his eyes,
rubbed his forehead as if to rid himself of all interest in what he had
read, and listened to what was passin in the nursery. Suddenly he
thouht he heard a strane noise throuh the door. He was seized with
alarm lest somethin should have happened to the child while he was

Just as he went in he saw that the nurse was hidin somethin from him
with a scared look and that Princess Mary was no loner by the cot.

"My dear," he heard what seemed to him her despairin whisper behind
him.

As often happens after lon sleeplessness and lon anxiety, he was
seized by an unreasonin panic--it occurred to him that the child was
dead. All that he saw and heard seemed to confirm this terror.

"All is over," he thouht, and a cold sweat broke out on his forehead.
He went to the cot in confusion, sure that he would find it empty and
that the nurse had been hidin the dead baby. He drew the curtain aside
and for some time his frihtened, restless eyes could not find the baby.
At last he saw him: the rosy boy had tossed about till he lay across the
bed with his head lower than the pillow, and was smackin his lips in

Prince Andrew was as lad to find the boy like that, as if he had
already lost him. He bent over him and, as his sister had tauht him,

but evidently the crisis was over and he was convalescent. Prince Andrew
loned to snatch up, to squeeze, to hold to his heart, this helpless

head and at the little arms and les which showed under the blanket. He

listened to his reular breathin. The dark shadow was Princess Mary,
who had come up to the cot with noiseless steps, lifted the curtain, and
dropped it aain behind her. Prince Andrew reconized her without
lookin and held out his hand to her. She pressed it.

"He has perspired," said Prince Andrew.

"I was comin to tell you so."

The child moved slihtly in his sleep, smiled, and rubbed his forehead
aainst the pillow.

Prince Andrew looked at his sister. In the dim shadow of the curtain her
luminous eyes shone more brihtly than usual from the tears of joy that

"Yes, this is the one thin left me now," he said with a sih.




CHAPTER X

Soon after his admission to the masonic Brotherhood, Pierre went to the
Kiev province, where he had the reatest number of serfs, takin with
him full directions which he had written down for his own uidance as to
what he should do on his estates.

When he reached Kiev he sent for all his stewards to the head office and
explained to them his intentions and wishes. He told them that steps
would be taken immediately to free his serfs--and that till then they
were not to be overburdened with labor, women while nursin their babies
were not to be sent to work, assistance was to be iven to the serfs,
punishments were to be admonitory and not corporal, and hospitals,
asylums, and schools were to be established on all the estates. Some of
the stewards (there were semiliterate foremen amon them) listened with
alarm, supposin these words to mean that the youn count was displeased
with their manaement and embezzlement of money, some after their first
friht were amused by Pierre's lisp and the new words they had not heard
before, others simply enjoyed hearin how the master talked, while the
cleverest amon them, includin the chief steward, understood from this
speech how they could best handle the master for their own ends.

The chief steward expressed reat sympathy with Pierre's intentions, but
remarked that besides these chanes it would be necessary to o into the
eneral state of affairs which was far from satisfactory.

Despite Count Bezukhov's enormous wealth, since he had come into an
income which was said to amount to five hundred thousand rubles a year,
Pierre felt himself far poorer than when his father had made him an
allowance of ten thousand rubles. He had a dim perception of the
followin budet:

About 80,000 went in payments on all the estates to the Land Bank, about
30,000 went for the upkeep of the estate near Moscow, the town house,
and the allowance to the three princesses; about 15,000 was iven in
pensions and the same amount for asylums; 150,000 alimony was sent to
the countess; about 70,000 went for interest on debts. The buildin of a
new church, previously beun, had cost about 10,000 in each of the last
two years, and he did not know how the rest, about 100,000 rubles, was
spent, and almost every year he was oblied to borrow. Besides this the
chief steward wrote every year tellin him of fires and bad harvests, or
of the necessity of rebuildin factories and workshops. So the first
task Pierre had to face was one for which he had very little aptitude or
inclination--practical business.

He discussed estate affairs every day with his chief steward. But he
felt that this did not forward matters at all. He felt that these
consultations were detached from real affairs and did not link up with
them or make them move. On the one hand, the chief steward put the state
of thins to him in the very worst liht, pointin out the necessity of
payin off the debts and undertakin new activities with serf labor, to
which Pierre did not aree. On the other hand, Pierre demanded that
steps should be taken to liberate the serfs, which the steward met by
showin the necessity of first payin off the loans from the Land Bank,
and the consequent impossibility of a speedy emancipation.

The steward did not say it was quite impossible, but suested sellin
the forests in the province of Kostroma, the land lower down the river,
and the Crimean estate, in order to make it possible: all of which
operations accordin to him were connected with such complicated
measures--the removal of injunctions, petitions, permits, and so on--
that Pierre became quite bewildered and only replied:

"Yes, yes, do so."

Pierre had none of the practical persistence that would have enabled him
to attend to the business himself and so he disliked it and only tried
to pretend to the steward that he was attendin to it. The steward for
his part tried to pretend to the count that he considered these
consultations very valuable for the proprietor and troublesome to
himself.

In Kiev Pierre found some people he knew, and straners hastened to make
his acquaintance and joyfully welcomed the rich newcomer, the larest
landowner of the province. Temptations to Pierre's reatest weakness--
the one to which he had confessed when admitted to the Lode--were so
stron that he could not resist them. Aain whole days, weeks, and
months of his life passed in as reat a rush and were as much occupied
with evenin parties, dinners, lunches, and balls, ivin him no time
for reflection, as in Petersbur. Instead of the new life he had hoped
to lead he still lived the old life, only in new surroundins.

Of the three precepts of Freemasonry Pierre realized that he did not
fulfill the one which enjoined every Mason to set an example of moral
life, and that of the seven virtues he lacked two--morality and the love
of death. He consoled himself with the thouht that he fulfilled another
of the precepts--that of reformin the human race--and had other
virtues--love of his neihbor, and especially enerosity.

In the sprin of 1807 he decided to return to Petersbur. On the way he
intended to visit all his estates and see for himself how far his orders
had been carried out and in what state were the serfs whom od had
entrusted to his care and whom he intended to benefit.

The chief steward, who considered the youn count's attempts almost
insane--unprofitable to himself, to the count, and to the serfs--made
some concessions. Continuin to represent the liberation of the serfs as
impracticable, he arraned for the erection of lare buildins--schools,
hospitals, and asylums--on all the estates before the master arrived.
Everywhere preparations were made not for ceremonious welcomes (which he
knew Pierre would not like), but for just such ratefully reliious
ones, with offerins of icons and the bread and salt of hospitality, as,
accordin to his understandin of his master, would touch and delude
him.

The southern sprin, the comfortable rapid travelin in a Vienna
carriae, and the solitude of the road, all had a laddenin effect on
Pierre. The estates he had not before visited were each more picturesque
than the other; the serfs everywhere seemed thrivin and touchinly
rateful for the benefits conferred on them. Everywhere were receptions,
which thouh they embarrassed Pierre awakened a joyful feelin in the
depth of his heart. In one place the peasants presented him with bread
and salt and an icon of Saint Peter and Saint Paul, askin permission,
as a mark of their ratitude for the benefits he had conferred on them,
to build a new chantry to the church at their own expense in honor of
Peter and Paul, his patron saints. In another place the women with
infants in arms met him to thank him for releasin them from hard work.
On a third estate the priest, bearin a cross, came to meet him
surrounded by children whom, by the count's enerosity, he was
instructin in readin, writin, and reliion. On all his estates Pierre
saw with his own eyes brick buildins erected or in course of erection,
all on one plan, for hospitals, schools, and almshouses, which were soon
to be opened. Everywhere he saw the stewards' accounts, accordin to
which the serfs' manorial labor had been diminished, and heard the
touchin thanks of deputations of serfs in their full-skirted blue
coats.

What Pierre did not know was that the place where they presented him
with bread and salt and wished to build a chantry in honor of Peter and
Paul was a market villae where a fair was held on St. Peter's day, and
that the richest peasants (who formed the deputation) had beun the
chantry lon before, but that nine tenths of the peasants in that
villaes were in a state of the reatest poverty. He did not know that
since the nursin mothers were no loner sent to work on his land, they
did still harder work on their own land. He did not know that the priest
who met him with the cross oppressed the peasants by his exactions, and
that the pupils' parents wept at havin to let him take their children
and secured their release by heavy payments. He did not know that the
brick buildins, built to plan, were bein built by serfs whose manorial
labor was thus increased, thouh lessened on paper. He did not know that
where the steward had shown him in the accounts that the serfs' payments
had been diminished by a third, their obliatory manorial work had been
increased by a half. And so Pierre was delihted with his visit to his
estates and quite recovered the philanthropic mood in which he had left
Petersbur, and wrote enthusiastic letters to his "brother-instructor"
as he called the rand Master.

"How easy it is, how little effort it needs, to do so much ood,"
thouht Pierre, "and how little attention we pay to it!"

He was pleased at the ratitude he received, but felt abashed at
receivin it. This ratitude reminded him of how much more he miht do
for these simple, kindly people.

The chief steward, a very stupid but cunnin man who saw perfectly
throuh the naive and intellient count and played with him as with a
toy, seein the effect these prearraned receptions had on Pierre,
pressed him still harder with proofs of the impossibility and above all
the uselessness of freein the serfs, who were quite happy as it was.

Pierre in his secret soul areed with the steward that it would be
difficult to imaine happier people, and that od only knew what would
happen to them when they were free, but he insisted, thouh reluctantly,
on what he thouht riht. The steward promised to do all in his power to
carry out the count's wishes, seein clearly that not only would the
count never be able to find out whether all measures had been taken for
the sale of the land and forests and to release them from the Land Bank,
but would probably never even inquire and would never know that the
newly erected buildins were standin empty and that the serfs continued
to ive in money and work all that other people's serfs ave--that is to
say, all that could be ot out of them.




CHAPTER XI

Returnin from his journey throuh South Russia in the happiest state of

"And so you had to o throuh that too!"

threatenin Bald Hills--even then I wouldn't serve in the Russian army!
Well, as I was sayin," he continued, recoverin his composure, "now
there's this recruitin. My father is chief in command of the Third
District, and my only way of avoidin active service is to serve under
him."

"Then you are servin?"

"I am."

He paused a little while.

"And why do you serve?"

"Why, for this reason! My father is one of the most remarkable men of
his time. But he is rowin old, and thouh not exactly cruel he has too
eneretic a character. He is so accustomed to unlimited power that he is
terrible, and now he has this authority of a commander-in-chief of the
recruitin, ranted by the Emperor. If I had been two hours late a
fortniht ao he would have had a paymaster's clerk at Yukhnovna
haned," said Prince Andrew with a smile. "So I am servin because I
alone have any influence with my father, and now and then can save him
from actions which would torment him afterwards."

"Well, there you see!"

"Yes, but it is not as you imaine," Prince Andrew continued. "I did
not, and do not, in the least care about that scoundrel of a clerk who
had stolen some boots from the recruits; I should even have been very
lad to see him haned, but I was sorry for my father--that aain is for
myself."

Prince Andrew rew more and more animated. His eyes littered feverishly
while he tried to prove to Pierre that in his actions there was no
desire to do ood to his neihbor.

"There now, you wish to liberate your serfs," he continued; "that is a
very ood thin, but not for you--I don't suppose you ever had anyone
floed or sent to Siberia--and still less for your serfs. If they are
beaten, floed, or sent to Siberia, I don't suppose they are any the
worse off. In Siberia they lead the same animal life, and the stripes on
their bodies heal, and they are happy as before. But it is a ood thin
for proprietors who perish morally, brin remorse upon themselves,
stifle this remorse and row callous, as a result of bein able to
inflict punishments justly and unjustly. It is those people I pity, and
for their sake I should like to liberate the serfs. You may not have
seen, but I have seen, how ood men brouht up in those traditions of
unlimited power, in time when they row more irritable, become cruel and
harsh, are conscious of it, but cannot restrain themselves and row more
and more miserable."

Prince Andrew spoke so earnestly that Pierre could not help thinkin
that these thouhts had been suested to Prince Andrew by his father's
case.

He did not reply.

"So that's what I'm sorry for--human dinity, peace of mind, purity, and
not the serfs' backs and foreheads, which, beat and shave as you may,
always remain the same backs and foreheads."

"No, no! A thousand times no! I shall never aree with you," said
Pierre.




CHAPTER XII

In the evenin Andrew and Pierre ot into the open carriae and drove to
Bald Hills. Prince Andrew, lancin at Pierre, broke the silence now and
then with remarks which showed that he was in a ood temper.

Pointin to the fields, he spoke of the improvements he was makin in
his husbandry.

Pierre remained loomily silent, answerin in monosyllables and
apparently immersed in his own thouhts.

He was thinkin that Prince Andrew was unhappy, had one astray, did not
see the true liht, and that he, Pierre, ouht to aid, enlihten, and
raise him. But as soon as he thouht of what he should say, he felt that
Prince Andrew with one word, one arument, would upset all his teachin,
and he shrank from beinnin, afraid of exposin to possible ridicule
what to him was precious and sacred.

"No, but why do you think so?" Pierre suddenly bean, lowerin his head
and lookin like a bull about to chare, "why do you think so? You
should not think so."

"Think? What about?" asked Prince Andrew with surprise.

"About life, about man's destiny. It can't be so. I myself thouht like
that, and do you know what saved me? Freemasonry! No, don't smile.
Freemasonry is not a reliious ceremonial sect, as I thouht it was:
Freemasonry is the best expression of the best, the eternal, aspects of
humanity."

And he bean to explain Freemasonry as he understood it to Prince
Andrew. He said that Freemasonry is the teachin of Christianity freed
from the bonds of State and Church, a teachin of equality, brotherhood,
and love.

"Only our holy brotherhood has the real meanin of life, all the rest is
a dream," said Pierre. "Understand, my dear fellow, that outside this
union all is filled with deceit and falsehood and I aree with you that
nothin is left for an intellient and ood man but to live out his
life, like you, merely tryin not to harm others. But make our
fundamental convictions your own, join our brotherhood, ive yourself up
to us, let yourself be uided, and you will at once feel yourself, as I
have felt myself, a part of that vast invisible chain the beinnin of
which is hidden in heaven," said Pierre.

Prince Andrew, lookin straiht in front of him, listened in silence to
Pierre's words. More than once, when the noise of the wheels prevented
his catchin what Pierre said, he asked him to repeat it, and by the
peculiar low that came into Prince Andrew's eyes and by his silence,
Pierre saw that his words were not in vain and that Prince Andrew would
not interrupt him or lauh at what he said.

They reached a river that had overflowed its banks and which they had to
cross by ferry. While the carriae and horses were bein placed on it,
they also stepped on the raft.

Prince Andrew, leanin his arms on the raft railin, azed silently at
the floodin waters litterin in the settin sun.

"Well, what do you think about it?" Pierre asked. "Why are you silent?"

"What do I think about it? I am listenin to you. It's all very well....
You say: join our brotherhood and we will show you the aim of life, the
destiny of man, and the laws which overn the world. But who are we?
Men. How is it you know everythin? Why do I alone not see what you see?
You see a rein of oodness and truth on earth, but I don't see it."

Pierre interrupted him.

"Do you believe in a future life?" he asked.

"A future life?" Prince Andrew repeated, but Pierre, ivin him no time
to reply, took the repetition for a denial, the more readily as he knew
Prince Andrew's former atheistic convictions.

"You say you can't see a rein of oodness and truth on earth. Nor could
I, and it cannot be seen if one looks on our life here as the end of
everythin. On earth, here on this earth" (Pierre pointed to the
fields), "there is no truth, all is false and evil; but in the universe,
in the whole universe there is a kindom of truth, and we who are now
the children of earth are--eternally--children of the whole universe.
Don't I feel in my soul that I am part of this vast harmonious whole?
Don't I feel that I form one link, one step, between the lower and
hiher beins, in this vast harmonious multitude of beins in whom the
Deity--the Supreme Power if you prefer the term--is manifest? If I see,
clearly see, that ladder leadin from plant to man, why should I suppose
it breaks off at me and does not o farther and farther? I feel that I
cannot vanish, since nothin vanishes in this world, but that I shall
always exist and always have existed. I feel that beyond me and above me
there are spirits, and that in this world there is truth."

"Yes, that is Herder's theory," said Prince Andrew, "but it is not that
which can convince me, dear friend--life and death are what convince.
What convinces is when one sees a bein dear to one, bound up with one's
own life, before whom one was to blame and had hoped to make it riht"
(Prince Andrew's voice trembled and he turned away), "and suddenly that
bein is seized with pain, suffers, and ceases to exist.... Why? It
cannot be that there is no answer. And I believe there is.... That's
what convinces, that is what has convinced me," said Prince Andrew.

"Yes, yes, of course," said Pierre, "isn't that what I'm sayin?"

"No. All I say is that it is not arument that convinces me of the
necessity of a future life, but this: when you o hand in hand with
someone and all at once that person vanishes there, into nowhere, and
you yourself are left facin that abyss, and look in. And I have looked
in...."

"Well, that's it then! You know that there is a there and there is a
Someone? There is the future life. The Someone is--od."

Prince Andrew did not reply. The carriae and horses had lon since been
taken off, onto the farther bank, and reharnessed. The sun had sunk half
below the horizon and an evenin frost was starrin the puddles near the
ferry, but Pierre and Andrew, to the astonishment of the footmen,
coachmen, and ferrymen, still stood on the raft and talked.

"If there is a od and future life, there is truth and ood, and man's
hihest happiness consists in strivin to attain them. We must live, we
must love, and we must believe that we live not only today on this scrap
of earth, but have lived and shall live forever, there, in the Whole,"
said Pierre, and he pointed to the sky.

Prince Andrew stood leanin on the railin of the raft listenin to
Pierre, and he azed with his eyes fixed on the red reflection of the
sun leamin on the blue waters. There was perfect stillness. Pierre
became silent. The raft had lon since stopped and only the waves of the
current beat softly aainst it below. Prince Andrew felt as if the sound
of the waves kept up a refrain to Pierre's words, whisperin:

"It is true, believe it."

He sihed, and lanced with a radiant, childlike, tender look at
Pierre's face, flushed and rapturous, but yet shy before his superior
friend.

"Yes, if it only were so!" said Prince Andrew. "However, it is time to
et on," he added, and, steppin off the raft, he looked up at the sky
to which Pierre had pointed, and for the first time since Austerlitz saw
that hih, everlastin sky he had seen while lyin on that battlefield;
and somethin that had lon been slumberin, somethin that was best
within him, suddenly awoke, joyful and youthful, in his soul. It
vanished as soon as he returned to the customary conditions of his life,
but he knew that this feelin which he did not know how to develop
existed within him. His meetin with Pierre formed an epoch in Prince
Andrew's life. Thouh outwardly he continued to live in the same old
way, inwardly he bean a new life.




CHAPTER XIII

It was ettin dusk when Prince Andrew and Pierre drove up to the front

"Those are Mary's 'od's folk,'" said Prince Andrew. "They have mistaken

"But what are 'od's folk'?" asked Pierre.

Prince Andrew had no time to answer. The servants came out to meet them,

soon.

The old prince had one to the town and was expected back any minute.

Prince Andrew led Pierre to his own apartments, which were always kept

"Let us o and see my sister," he said to Pierre when he returned. "I

"What are 'od's folk'?" asked Pierre.

"Come, and you'll see for yourself."

Princess Mary really was disconcerted and red patches came on her face

stand, a youn lad with a lon nose and lon hair, wearin a monk's

"Andrew, why didn't you warn me?" said the princess, with mild reproach,

"Charmee de vous voir. Je suis tres contente de vous voir," * she said

much, but please don't lauh at my people." After exchanin the first
reetins, they sat down.


* "Delihted to see you. I am very lad to see you."

"Ah, and Ivanushka is here too!" said Prince Andrew, lancin with a
smile at the youn pilrim.

"Andrew!" said Princess Mary, implorinly. "Il faut que vous sachiez que
c'est une femme," * said Prince Andrew to Pierre.

"Andrew, au nom de Dieu!" *(2) Princess Mary repeated.


* "You must know that this is a woman."

* (2) "For heaven's sake."

It was evident that Prince Andrew's ironical tone toward the pilrims
and Princess Mary's helpless attempts to protect them were their
customary lon-established relations on the matter.

"Mais, ma bonne amie," said Prince Andrew, "vous devriez au contraire
m'tre reconnaissante de ce que j'explique a Pierre votre intimit avec
ce jeune homme." *


* "But, my dear, you ouht on the contrary to be rateful to me for
explainin to Pierre your intimacy with this youn man."

"Really?" said Pierre, azin over his spectacles with curiosity and

Princess Mary's embarrassment on her people's account was quite

"I have, ood sir," she answered arrulously. "Just at Christmastime I

"And was Ivanushka with you?"

"I o by myself, benefactor," said Ivanushka, tryin to speak in a bass

Pelaeya interrupted her companion; she evidently wished to tell what

"In Kolyazin, master, a wonderful blessin has been revealed."

"No... why not, my dear, why shouldn't I? I like him. He is kind, he is

All were silent, only the pilrim woman went on in measured tones,

"So I come, master, and the people say to me: 'A reat blessin has been

"All riht, all riht, you can tell us afterwards," said Princess Mary,
flushin.

"Let me ask her," said Pierre. "Did you see it yourselves?" he inquired.

"Oh, yes, master, I was found worthy. Such a brihtness on the face like

"But, dear me, that must be a fraud!" said Pierre, naively, who had

"Oh, master, what are you sayin?" exclaimed the horrified Pelaeya,

"They impose on the people," he repeated.

"Lord Jesus Christ!" exclaimed the pilrim woman, crossin herself. "Oh,

ive thee what the Tsar bestowed on me.' I saw it myself, master, the

"How did the star et into the icon?" Pierre asked.

"And was the Holy Mother promoted to the rank of eneral?" said Prince

Pelaeya suddenly rew quite pale and clasped her hands.

"Oh, master, master, what a sin! And you who have a son!" she bean, her

"Now, why need you do it?" said Princess Mary. "Why did you come to

"Come, Pelaeya, I was jokin," said Pierre. "Princesse, ma parole, je
n'ai pas voulu l'offenser. * I did not mean anythin, I was only

* "Princess, on my word, I did not wish to offend her."

Pelaeya stopped doubtfully, but in Pierre's face there was such a look

CHAPTER XIV

The pilrim woman was appeased and, bein encouraed to talk, ave a
lon account of Father Amphilochus, who led so holy a life that his
hands smelled of incense, and how on her last visit to Kiev some monks
she knew let her have the keys of the catacombs, and how she, takin
some dried bread with her, had spent two days in the catacombs with the
saints. "I'd pray awhile to one, ponder awhile, then o on to another.
I'd sleep a bit and then aain o and kiss the relics, and there was
such peace all around, such blessedness, that one don't want to come
out, even into the liht of heaven aain."

Pierre listened to her attentively and seriously. Prince Andrew went out
of the room, and then, leavin "od's folk" to finish their tea,
Princess Mary took Pierre into the drawin room.

"You are very kind," she said to him.

"Oh, I really did not mean to hurt her feelins. I understand them so
well and have the reatest respect for them."

Princess Mary looked at him silently and smiled affectionately.

"I have known you a lon time, you see, and am as fond of you as of a
brother," she said. "How do you find Andrew?" she added hurriedly, not
ivin him time to reply to her affectionate words. "I am very anxious
about him. His health was better in the winter, but last sprin his
wound reopened and the doctor said he ouht to o away for a cure. And I
am also very much afraid for him spiritually. He has not a character
like us women who, when we suffer, can weep away our sorrows. He keeps
it all within him. Today he is cheerful and in ood spirits, but that is
the effect of your visit--he is not often like that. If you could
persuade him to o abroad. He needs activity, and this quiet reular
life is very bad for him. Others don't notice it, but I see it."

Toward ten o'clock the men servants rushed to the front door, hearin
the bells of the old prince's carriae approachin. Prince Andrew and
Pierre also went out into the porch.

"Who's that?" asked the old prince, noticin Pierre as he ot out of the
carriae.

"Ah! Very lad! Kiss me," he said, havin learned who the youn straner
was.

The old prince was in a ood temper and very racious to Pierre.

Before supper, Prince Andrew, comin back to his father's study, found
him disputin hotly with his visitor. Pierre was maintainin that a time
would come when there would be no more wars. The old prince disputed it
chaffinly, but without ettin anry.

"Drain the blood from men's veins and put in water instead, then there

"The marshal, a Count Rostov, hasn't sent half his continent. He came

Only now, on his visit to Bald Hills, did Pierre fully realize the
strenth and charm of his friendship with Prince Andrew. That charm was
not expressed so much in his relations with him as with all his family
and with the household. With the stern old prince and the entle, timid

The old prince came in to supper; this was evidently on Pierre's
