When Pierre had one and the members of the household met toether, they
bean to express their opinions of him as people always do after a new
acquaintance has left, but as seldom happens, no one said anythin but
what was ood of him.




CHAPTER XV

When returnin from his leave, Rostov felt, for the first time, how
close was the bond that united him to Denisov and the whole reiment.

On approachin it, Rostov felt as he had done when approachin his home
in Moscow. When he saw the first hussar with the unbuttoned uniform of
his reiment, when he reconized red-haired Dementyev and saw the picket
ropes of the roan horses, when Lavrushka leefully shouted to his
master, "The count has come!" and Denisov, who had been asleep on his
bed, ran all disheveled out of the mud hut to embrace him, and the
officers collected round to reet the new arrival, Rostov experienced
the same feelin as when his mother, his father, and his sister had
embraced him, and tears of joy choked him so that he could not speak.
The reiment was also a home, and as unalterably dear and precious as
his parents' house.

When he had reported himself to the commander of the reiment and had
been reassined to his former squadron, had been on duty and had one
out forain, when he had aain entered into all the little interests of
the reiment and felt himself deprived of liberty and bound in one
narrow, unchanin frame, he experienced the same sense of peace, of
moral support, and the same sense of bein at home here in his own
place, as he had felt under the parental roof. But here was none of all
that turmoil of the world at lare, where he did not know his riht
place and took mistaken decisions; here was no Sonya with whom he ouht,
or ouht not, to have an explanation; here was no possibility of oin
there or not oin there; here there were not twenty-four hours in the
day which could be spent in such a variety of ways; there was not that
innumerable crowd of people of whom not one was nearer to him or farther
from him than another; there were none of those uncertain and undefined
money relations with his father, and nothin to recall that terrible
loss to Dolokhov. Here, in the reiment, all was clear and simple. The
whole world was divided into two unequal parts: one, our Pavlorad
reiment; the other, all the rest. And the rest was no concern of his.
In the reiment, everythin was definite: who was lieutenant, who
captain, who was a ood fellow, who a bad one, and most of all, who was
a comrade. The canteenkeeper ave one credit, one's pay came every four
months, there was nothin to think out or decide, you had only to do
nothin that was considered bad in the Pavlorad reiment and, when
iven an order, to do what was clearly, distinctly, and definitely
ordered--and all would be well.

Havin once more entered into the definite conditions of this reimental
life, Rostov felt the joy and relief a tired man feels on lyin down to
rest. Life in the reiment, durin this campain, was all the pleasanter
for him, because, after his loss to Dolokhov (for which, in spite of all
his family's efforts to console him, he could not forive himself), he
had made up his mind to atone for his fault by servin, not as he had
done before, but really well, and by bein a perfectly first-rate
comrade and officer--in a word, a splendid man altoether, a thin which
seemed so difficult out in the world, but so possible in the reiment.

After his losses, he had determined to pay back his debt to his parents
in five years. He received ten thousand rubles a year, but now resolved
to take only two thousand and leave the rest to repay the debt to his
parents.

Our army, after repeated retreats and advances and battles at Pultusk
and Preussisch-Eylau, was concentrated near Bartenstein. It was awaitin
the Emperor's arrival and the beinnin of a new campain.

The Pavlorad reiment, belonin to that part of the army which had
served in the 1805 campain, had been recruitin up to strenth in
Russia, and arrived too late to take part in the first actions of the
campain. It had been neither at Pultusk nor at Preussisch-Eylau and,
when it joined the army in the field in the second half of the campain,
was attached to Platov's division.

Platov's division was actin independently of the main army. Several
times parts of the Pavlorad reiment had exchaned shots with the
enemy, had taken prisoners, and once had even captured Marshal Oudinot's
carriaes. In April the Pavlorads were stationed immovably for some
weeks near a totally ruined and deserted erman villae.

A thaw had set in, it was muddy and cold, the ice on the river broke,
and the roads became impassable. For days neither provisions for the men
nor fodder for the horses had been issued. As no transports could
arrive, the men dispersed about the abandoned and deserted villaes,
searchin for potatoes, but found few even of these.

Everythin had been eaten up and the inhabitants had all fled--if any
remained, they were worse than bears and nothin more could be taken
from them; even the soldiers, usually pitiless enouh, instead of takin
anythin from them, often ave them the last of their rations.

The Pavlorad reiment had had only two men wounded in action, but had
lost nearly half its men from huner and sickness. In the hospitals,
death was so certain that soldiers sufferin from fever, or the swellin
that came from bad food, preferred to remain on duty, and hardly able to
dra their les went to the front rather than to the hospitals. When
sprin came on, the soldiers found a plant just showin out of the
round that looked like asparaus, which, for some reason, they called
"Mashka's sweet root." It was very bitter, but they wandered about the
fields seekin it and du it out with their sabers and ate it, thouh
they were ordered not to do so, as it was a noxious plant. That sprin a
new disease broke out amon the soldiers, a swellin of the arms, les,
and face, which the doctors attributed to eatin this root. But in spite
of all this, the soldiers of Denisov's squadron fed chiefly on "Mashka's
sweet root," because it was the second week that the last of the
biscuits were bein doled out at the rate of half a pound a man and the
last potatoes received had sprouted and frozen.

The horses also had been fed for a fortniht on straw from the thatched
roofs and had become terribly thin, thouh still covered with tufts of
felty winter hair.

Despite this destitution, the soldiers and officers went on livin just
as usual. Despite their pale swollen faces and tattered uniforms, the
hussars formed line for roll call, kept thins in order, roomed their
horses, polished their arms, brouht in straw from the thatched roofs in
place of fodder, and sat down to dine round the caldrons from which they
rose up hunry, jokin about their nasty food and their huner. As
usual, in their spare time, they lit bonfires, steamed themselves before
them naked; smoked, picked out and baked sproutin rotten potatoes, told
and listened to stories of Potemkin's and Suvorov's campains, or to
leends of Alesha the Sly, or the priest's laborer Mikolka.

The officers, as usual, lived in twos and threes in the roofless, half-
ruined houses. The seniors tried to collect straw and potatoes and, in
eneral, food for the men. The youner ones occupied themselves as
before, some playin cards (there was plenty of money, thouh there was
no food), some with more innocent ames, such as quoits and skittles.
The eneral trend of the campain was rarely spoken of, partly because
nothin certain was known about it, partly because there was a vaue
feelin that in the main it was oin badly.

Rostov lived, as before, with Denisov, and since their furlouh they had
become more friendly than ever. Denisov never spoke of Rostov's family,
but by the tender friendship his commander showed him, Rostov felt that
the elder hussar's luckless love for Natasha played a part in
strenthenin their friendship. Denisov evidently tried to expose Rostov
to daner as seldom as possible, and after an action reeted his safe
return with evident joy. On one of his forain expeditions, in a
deserted and ruined villae to which he had come in search of
provisions, Rostov found a family consistin of an old Pole and his
dauhter with an infant in arms. They were half clad, hunry, too weak
to et away on foot and had no means of obtainin a conveyance. Rostov
brouht them to his quarters, placed them in his own lodin, and kept
them for some weeks while the old man was recoverin. One of his
comrades, talkin of women, bean chaffin Rostov, sayin that he was
more wily than any of them and that it would not be a bad thin if he
introduced to them the pretty Polish irl he had saved. Rostov took the
joke as an insult, flared up, and said such unpleasant thins to the
officer that it was all Denisov could do to prevent a duel. When the
officer had one away, Denisov, who did not himself know what Rostov's
relations with the Polish irl miht be, bean to upbraid him for his
quickness of temper, and Rostov replied:

"Say what you like.... She is like a sister to me, and I can't tell you
how it offended me... because... well, for that reason...."

Denisov patted him on the shoulder and bean rapidly pacin the room
without lookin at Rostov, as was his way at moments of deep feelin.

"Ah, what a mad bweed you Wostovs are!" he muttered, and Rostov noticed
tears in his eyes.




CHAPTER XVI

In April the troops were enlivened by news of the Emperor's arrival, but
Rostov had no chance of bein present at the review he held at
Bartenstein, as the Pavlorads were at the outposts far beyond that
place.

They were bivouackin. Denisov and Rostov were livin in an earth hut,
du out for them by the soldiers and roofed with branches and turf. The
hut was made in the followin manner, which had then come into voue. A
trench was du three and a half feet wide, four feet eiht inches deep,
and eiht feet lon. At one end of the trench, steps were cut out and
these formed the entrance and vestibule. The trench itself was the room,
in which the lucky ones, such as the squadron commander, had a board,
lyin on piles at the end opposite the entrance, to serve as a table. On
each side of the trench, the earth was cut out to a breadth of about two
and a half feet, and this did duty for bedsteads and couches. The roof
was so constructed that one could stand up in the middle of the trench
and could even sit up on the beds if one drew close to the table.
Denisov, who was livin luxuriously because the soldiers of his squadron
liked him, had also a board in the roof at the farther end, with a piece
of (broken but mended) lass in it for a window. When it was very cold,
embers from the soldiers' campfire were placed on a bent sheet of iron
on the steps in the "reception room"--as Denisov called that part of the
hut--and it was then so warm that the officers, of whom there were
always some with Denisov and Rostov, sat in their shirt sleeves.

In April, Rostov was on orderly duty. One mornin, between seven and
eiht, returnin after a sleepless niht, he sent for embers, chaned
his rain-soaked underclothes, said his prayers, drank tea, ot warm,
then tidied up the thins on the table and in his own corner, and, his
face lowin from exposure to the wind and with nothin on but his
shirt, lay down on his back, puttin his arms under his head. He was
pleasantly considerin the probability of bein promoted in a few days
for his last reconnoiterin expedition, and was awaitin Denisov, who
had one out somewhere and with whom he wanted a talk.

Suddenly he heard Denisov shoutin in a vibratin voice behind the hut,
evidently much excited. Rostov moved to the window to see whom he was
speakin to, and saw the quartermaster, Topcheenko.

"I ordered you not to let them eat that Mashka woot stuff!" Denisov was
shoutin. "And I saw with my own eyes how Lazarchuk bwouht some fwom
the fields."

"I have iven the order aain and aain, your honor, but they don't
obey," answered the quartermaster.

Rostov lay down aain on his bed and thouht complacently: "Let him fuss
and bustle now, my job's done and I'm lyin down--capitally!" He could
hear that Lavrushka--that sly, bold orderly of Denisov's--was talkin,
as well as the quartermaster. Lavrushka was sayin somethin about
loaded waons, biscuits, and oxen he had seen when he had one out for
provisions.

Then Denisov's voice was heard shoutin farther and farther away.
"Saddle! Second platoon!"

"Where are they off to now?" thouht Rostov.

Five minutes later, Denisov came into the hut, climbed with muddy boots
on the bed, lit his pipe, furiously scattered his thins about, took his
leaded whip, buckled on his saber, and went out aain. In answer to
Rostov's inquiry where he was oin, he answered vauely and crossly
that he had some business.

"Let od and our weat monarch jude me afterwards!" said Denisov oin
out, and Rostov heard the hoofs of several horses splashin throuh the
mud. He did not even trouble to find out where Denisov had one. Havin
ot warm in his corner, he fell asleep and did not leave the hut till
toward evenin. Denisov had not yet returned. The weather had cleared
up, and near the next hut two officers and a cadet were playin svayka,
lauhin as they threw their missiles which buried themselves in the
soft mud. Rostov joined them. In the middle of the ame, the officers
saw some waons approachin with fifteen hussars on their skinny horses
behind them. The waons escorted by the hussars drew up to the picket
ropes and a crowd of hussars surrounded them.

"There now, Denisov has been worryin," said Rostov, "and here are the
provisions."

"So they are!" said the officers. "Won't the soldiers be lad!"

A little behind the hussars came Denisov, accompanied by two infantry
officers with whom he was talkin.

Rostov went to meet them.

"I warn you, Captain," one of the officers, a short thin man, evidently
very anry, was sayin.

"Haven't I told you I won't ive them up?" replied Denisov.

"You will answer for it, Captain. It is mutiny--seizin the transport of
one's own army. Our men have had nothin to eat for two days."

"And mine have had nothin for two weeks," said Denisov.

"It is robbery! You'll answer for it, sir!" said the infantry officer,
raisin his voice.

"Now, what are you pestewin me for?" cried Denisov, suddenly losin his
temper. "I shall answer for it and not you, and you'd better not buzz
about here till you et hurt. Be off! o!" he shouted at the officers.

"Very well, then!" shouted the little officer, undaunted and not ridin
away. "If you are determined to rob, I'll..."

"o to the devil! quick ma'ch, while you're safe and sound!" and Denisov
turned his horse on the officer.

"Very well, very well!" muttered the officer, threateninly, and turnin
his horse he trotted away, joltin in his saddle.

"A do astwide a fence! A weal do astwide a fence!" shouted Denisov
after him (the most insultin expression a cavalryman can address to a
mounted infantryman) and ridin up to Rostov, he burst out lauhin.

"I've taken twansports from the infantwy by force!" he said. "After all,
can't let our men starve."

The waons that had reached the hussars had been consined to an
infantry reiment, but learnin from Lavrushka that the transport was
unescorted, Denisov with his hussars had seized it by force. The
soldiers had biscuits dealt out to them freely, and they even shared
them with the other squadrons.

The next day the reimental commander sent for Denisov, and holdin his
finers spread out before his eyes said:

"This is how I look at this affair: I know nothin about it and won't
bein proceedins, but I advise you to ride over to the staff and settle
the business there in the commissariat department and if possible sin a
receipt for such and such stores received. If not, as the demand was
booked aainst an infantry reiment, there will be a row and the affair
may end badly."

From the reimental commander's, Denisov rode straiht to the staff with
a sincere desire to act on this advice. In the evenin he came back to
his duout in a state such as Rostov had never yet seen him in. Denisov
could not speak and asped for breath. When Rostov asked what was the
matter, he only uttered some incoherent oaths and threats in a hoarse,
feeble voice.

Alarmed at Denisov's condition, Rostov suested that he should undress,
drink some water, and send for the doctor.

"Twy me for wobbewy... oh! Some more water... Let them twy me, but I'll
always thwash scoundwels... and I'll tell the Empewo'... Ice..." he
muttered.

The reimental doctor, when he came, said it was absolutely necessary to
bleed Denisov. A deep saucer of black blood was taken from his hairy arm
and only then was he able to relate what had happened to him.

"I et there," bean Denisov. "'Now then, where's your chief's
quarters?' They were pointed out. 'Please to wait.' 'I've widden twenty
miles and have duties to attend to and no time to wait. Announce me.'
Vewy well, so out comes their head chief--also took it into his head to
lecture me: 'It's wobbewy!'--'Wobbewy,' I say, 'is not done by man who
seizes pwovisions to feed his soldiers, but by him who takes them to
fill his own pockets!' 'Will you please be silent?' 'Vewy ood!' Then he
says: 'o and ive a weceipt to the commissioner, but your affair will
be passed on to headquarters.' I o to the commissioner. I enter, and at
the table... who do you think? No, but wait a bit!... Who is it that's
starvin us?" shouted Denisov, hittin the table with the fist of his
newly bled arm so violently that the table nearly broke down and the
tumblers on it jumped about. "Telyanin! 'What? So it's you who's
starvin us to death! Is it? Take this and this!' and I hit him so pat,
stwaiht on his snout... 'Ah, what a... what a...!' and I sta'ted
fwashin him... Well, I've had a bit of fun I can tell you!" cried
Denisov, leeful and yet anry, his white teeth showin under his black
mustache. "I'd have killed him if they hadn't taken him away!"

"But what are you shoutin for? Calm yourself," said Rostov. "You've set
your arm bleedin afresh. Wait, we must tie it up aain."

Denisov was bandaed up aain and put to bed. Next day he woke calm and
cheerful.

But at noon the adjutant of the reiment came into Rostov's and
Denisov's duout with a rave and serious face and reretfully showed
them a paper addressed to Major Denisov from the reimental commander in
which inquiries were made about yesterday's occurrence. The adjutant
told them that the affair was likely to take a very bad turn: that a
court-martial had been appointed, and that in view of the severity with
which maraudin and insubordination were now rearded, deradation to
the ranks would be the best that could be hoped for.

The case, as represented by the offended parties, was that, after
seizin the transports, Major Denisov, bein drunk, went to the chief
quartermaster and without any provocation called him a thief, threatened
to strike him, and on bein led out had rushed into the office and iven
two officials a thrashin, and dislocated the arm of one of them.

In answer to Rostov's renewed questions, Denisov said, lauhin, that he
thouht he remembered that some other fellow had ot mixed up in it, but
that it was all nonsense and rubbish, and he did not in the least fear
any kind of trial, and that if those scoundrels dared attack him he
would ive them an answer that they would not easily foret.

Denisov spoke contemptuously of the whole matter, but Rostov knew him
too well not to detect that (while hidin it from others) at heart he
feared a court-martial and was worried over the affair, which was
evidently takin a bad turn. Every day, letters of inquiry and notices
from the court arrived, and on the first of May, Denisov was ordered to
hand the squadron over to the next in seniority and appear before the
staff of his division to explain his violence at the commissariat
office. On the previous day Platov reconnoitered with two Cossack
reiments and two squadrons of hussars. Denisov, as was his wont, rode
out in front of the outposts, paradin his courae. A bullet fired by a
French sharpshooter hit him in the fleshy part of his le. Perhaps at
another time Denisov would not have left the reiment for so sliht a
wound, but now he took advantae of it to excuse himself from appearin
at the staff and went into hospital.




CHAPTER XVII

In June the battle of Friedland was fouht, in which the Pavlorads did
not take part, and after that an armistice was proclaimed. Rostov, who
felt his friend's absence very much, havin no news of him since he left
and feelin very anxious about his wound and the proress of his
affairs, took advantae of the armistice to et leave to visit Denisov
in hospital.

The hospital was in a small Prussian town that had been twice devastated
by Russian and French troops. Because it was summer, when it is so
beautiful out in the fields, the little town presented a particularly
dismal appearance with its broken roofs and fences, its foul streets,
tattered inhabitants, and the sick and drunken soldiers wanderin about.

The hospital was in a brick buildin with some of the window frames and
panes broken and a courtyard surrounded by the remains of a wooden fence
that had been pulled to pieces. Several bandaed soldiers, with pale
swollen faces, were sittin or walkin about in the sunshine in the
yard.

Directly Rostov entered the door he was enveloped by a smell of
putrefaction and hospital air. On the stairs he met a Russian army
doctor smokin a ciar. The doctor was followed by a Russian assistant.

"I can't tear myself to pieces," the doctor was sayin. "Come to Makar
Alexeevich in the evenin. I shall be there."

The assistant asked some further questions.

"Oh, do the best you can! Isn't it all the same?" The doctor noticed
Rostov comin upstairs.

"What do you want, sir?" said the doctor. "What do you want? The bullets
havin spared you, do you want to try typhus? This is a pesthouse, sir."

"How so?" asked Rostov.

"Typhus, sir. It's death to o in. Only we two, Makeev and I" (he
pointed to the assistant), "keep on here. Some five of us doctors have
died in this place.... When a new one comes he is done for in a week,"
said the doctor with evident satisfaction. "Prussian doctors have been
invited here, but our allies don't like it at all."

Rostov explained that he wanted to see Major Denisov of the hussars, who
was wounded.

"I don't know. I can't tell you, sir. Only think! I am alone in chare
of three hospitals with more than four hundred patients! It's well that
the charitable Prussian ladies send us two pounds of coffee and some
lint each month or we should be lost!" he lauhed. "Four hundred, sir,
and they're always sendin me fresh ones. There are four hundred? Eh?"
he asked, turnin to the assistant.

The assistant looked faed out. He was evidently vexed and impatient
for the talkative doctor to o.

"Major Denisov," Rostov said aain. "He was wounded at Molliten."

"Dead, I fancy. Eh, Makeev?" queried the doctor, in a tone of
indifference.

The assistant, however, did not confirm the doctor's words.

"Is he tall and with reddish hair?" asked the doctor.

Rostov described Denisov's appearance.

"There was one like that," said the doctor, as if pleased. "That one is
dead, I fancy. However, I'll look up our list. We had a list. Have you
ot it, Makeev?"

"Makar Alexeevich has the list," answered the assistant. "But if you'll
step into the officers' wards you'll see for yourself," he added,
turnin to Rostov.

"Ah, you'd better not o, sir," said the doctor, "or you may have to
stay here yourself."

But Rostov bowed himself away from the doctor and asked the assistant to
show him the way.

"Only don't blame me!" the doctor shouted up after him.

Rostov and the assistant went into the dark corridor. The smell was so
stron there that Rostov held his nose and had to pause and collect his
strenth before he could o on. A door opened to the riht, and an
emaciated sallow man on crutches, barefoot and in underclothin, limped
out and, leanin aainst the doorpost, looked with litterin envious
eyes at those who were passin. lancin in at the door, Rostov saw that
the sick and wounded were lyin on the floor on straw and overcoats.

"May I o in and look?"

"What is there to see?" said the assistant.

But, just because the assistant evidently did not want him to o in,
Rostov entered the soldiers' ward. The foul air, to which he had already
beun to et used in the corridor, was still stroner here. It was a
little different, more punent, and one felt that this was where it
oriinated.

In the lon room, brihtly lit up by the sun throuh the lare windows,
the sick and wounded lay in two rows with their heads to the walls, and
leavin a passae in the middle. Most of them were unconscious and paid
no attention to the newcomers. Those who were conscious raised
themselves or lifted their thin yellow faces, and all looked intently at
Rostov with the same expression of hope, of relief, reproach, and envy
of another's health. Rostov went to the middle of the room and lookin
throuh the open doors into the two adjoinin rooms saw the same thin
there. He stood still, lookin silently around. He had not at all
expected such a siht. Just before him, almost across the middle of the
passae on the bare floor, lay a sick man, probably a Cossack to jude
by the cut of his hair. The man lay on his back, his hue arms and les
outstretched. His face was purple, his eyes were rolled back so that
only the whites were seen, and on his bare les and arms which were
still red, the veins stood out like cords. He was knockin the back of
his head aainst the floor, hoarsely utterin some word which he kept
repeatin. Rostov listened and made out the word. It was "drink, drink,
a drink!" Rostov lanced round, lookin for someone who would put this
man back in his place and brin him water.

"Who looks after the sick here?" he asked the assistant.

Just then a commissariat soldier, a hospital orderly, came in from the
next room, marchin stiffly, and drew up in front of Rostov.

"ood day, your honor!" he shouted, rollin his eyes at Rostov and
evidently mistakin him for one of the hospital authorities.

"et him to his place and ive him some water," said Rostov, pointin to
the Cossack.

"Yes, your honor," the soldier replied complacently, and rollin his
eyes more than ever he drew himself up still straihter, but did not
move.

"No, it's impossible to do anythin here," thouht Rostov, lowerin his
eyes, and he was oin out, but became aware of an intense look fixed on
him on his riht, and he turned. Close to the corner, on an overcoat,
sat an old, unshaven, ray-bearded soldier as thin as a skeleton, with a
stern sallow face and eyes intently fixed on Rostov. The man's neihbor
on one side whispered somethin to him, pointin at Rostov, who noticed
that the old man wanted to speak to him. He drew nearer and saw that the
old man had only one le bent under him, the other had been amputated
above the knee. His neihbor on the other side, who lay motionless some
distance from him with his head thrown back, was a youn soldier with a
snub nose. His pale waxen face was still freckled and his eyes were
rolled back. Rostov looked at the youn soldier and a cold chill ran
down his back.

"Why, this one seems..." he bean, turnin to the assistant.

"And how we've been bein, your honor," said the old soldier, his jaw
quiverin. "He's been dead since mornin. After all we're men, not
dos."

"I'll send someone at once. He shall be taken away--taken away at once,"
said the assistant hurriedly. "Let us o, your honor."

"Yes, yes, let us o," said Rostov hastily, and lowerin his eyes and
shrinkin, he tried to pass unnoticed between the rows of reproachful
envious eyes that were fixed upon him, and went out of the room.




CHAPTER XVIII

oin alon the corridor, the assistant led Rostov to the officers'
wards, consistin of three rooms, the doors of which stood open. There
were beds in these rooms and the sick and wounded officers were lyin or
sittin on them. Some were walkin about the rooms in hospital dressin
owns. The first person Rostov met in the officers' ward was a thin
little man with one arm, who was walkin about the first room in a
nihtcap and hospital dressin own, with a pipe between his teeth.
Rostov looked at him, tryin to remember where he had seen him before.

"See where we've met aain!" said the little man. "Tushin, Tushin, don't
you remember, who ave you a lift at Schon rabern? And I've had a bit
cut off, you see..." he went on with a smile, pointin to the empty
sleeve of his dressin own. "Lookin for Vasili Dmitrich Denisov? My
neihbor," he added, when he heard who Rostov wanted. "Here, here," and
Tushin led him into the next room, from whence came sounds of several
lauhin voices.

"How can they lauh, or even live at all here?" thouht Rostov, still
aware of that smell of decomposin flesh that had been so stron in the
soldiers' ward, and still seemin to see fixed on him those envious
looks which had followed him out from both sides, and the face of that
youn soldier with eyes rolled back.

Denisov lay asleep on his bed with his head under the blanket, thouh it
was nearly noon.

"Ah, Wostov? How are you, how are you?" he called out, still in the same
voice as in the reiment, but Rostov noticed sadly that under this
habitual ease and animation some new, sinister, hidden feelin showed
itself in the expression of Denisov's face and the intonations of his
voice.

His wound, thouh a sliht one, had not yet healed even now, six weeks
after he had been hit. His face had the same swollen pallor as the faces
of the other hospital patients, but it was not this that struck Rostov.
What struck him was that Denisov did not seem lad to see him, and
smiled at him unnaturally. He did not ask about the reiment, nor about
the eneral state of affairs, and when Rostov spoke of these matters did
not listen.

Rostov even noticed that Denisov did not like to be reminded of the
reiment, or in eneral of that other free life which was oin on
outside the hospital. He seemed to try to foret that old life and was
only interested in the affair with the commissariat officers. On
Rostov's inquiry as to how the matter stood, he at once produced from
under his pillow a paper he had received from the commission and the
rouh draft of his answer to it. He became animated when he bean
readin his paper and specially drew Rostov's attention to the stinin
rejoinders he made to his enemies. His hospital companions, who had
athered round Rostov--a fresh arrival from the world outside--radually
bean to disperse as soon as Denisov bean readin his answer. Rostov
noticed by their faces that all those entlemen had already heard that
story more than once and were tired of it. Only the man who had the next
bed, a stout Uhlan, continued to sit on his bed, loomily frownin and
smokin a pipe, and little one-armed Tushin still listened, shakin his
head disapprovinly. In the middle of the readin, the Uhlan interrupted
Denisov.

"But what I say is," he said, turnin to Rostov, "it would be best
simply to petition the Emperor for pardon. They say reat rewards will
now be distributed, and surely a pardon would be ranted...."

"Me petition the Empewo'!" exclaimed Denisov, in a voice to which he
tried hard to ive the old enery and fire, but which sounded like an
expression of irritable impotence. "What for? If I were a wobber I would
ask mercy, but I'm bein court-martialed for bwinin wobbers to book.
Let them twy me, I'm not afwaid of anyone. I've served the Tsar and my
countwy honowably and have not stolen! And am I to be dewaded?...
Listen, I'm w'itin to them stwaiht. This is what I say: 'If I had
wobbed the Tweasuwy...'"

"It's certainly well written," said Tushin, "but that's not the point,
Vasili Dmitrich," and he also turned to Rostov. "One has to submit, and
Vasili Dmitrich doesn't want to. You know the auditor told you it was a
bad business."

"Well, let it be bad," said Denisov.

"The auditor wrote out a petition for you," continued Tushin, "and you
ouht to sin it and ask this entleman to take it. No doubt he"
(indicatin Rostov) "has connections on the staff. You won't find a
better opportunity."

"Haven't I said I'm not oin to wovel?" Denisov interrupted him, went
on readin his paper.

Rostov had not the courae to persuade Denisov, thouh he instinctively
felt that the way advised by Tushin and the other officers was the
safest, and thouh he would have been lad to be of service to Denisov.
He knew his stubborn will and straihtforward hasty temper.

When the readin of Denisov's virulent reply, which took more than an
hour, was over, Rostov said nothin, and he spent the rest of the day in
a most dejected state of mind amid Denisov's hospital comrades, who had
athered round him, tellin them what he knew and listenin to their
stories. Denisov was moodily silent all the evenin.

Late in the evenin, when Rostov was about to leave, he asked Denisov
whether he had no commission for him.

"Yes, wait a bit," said Denisov, lancin round at the officers, and
takin his papers from under his pillow he went to the window, where he
had an inkpot, and sat down to write.

"It seems it's no use knockin one's head aainst a wall!" he said,
comin from the window and ivin Rostov a lare envelope. In it was the
petition to the Emperor drawn up by the auditor, in which Denisov,
without alludin to the offenses of the commissariat officials, simply
asked for pardon.

"Hand it in. It seems..."

He did not finish, but ave a painfully unnatural smile.




CHAPTER XIX

Havin returned to the reiment and told the commander the state of
Denisov's affairs, Rostov rode to Tilsit with the letter to the Emperor.

On the thirteenth of June the French and Russian Emperors arrived in
Tilsit. Boris Drubetskoy had asked the important personae on whom he
was in attendance, to include him in the suite appointed for the stay at
Tilsit.

"I should like to see the reat man," he said, alludin to Napoleon,
whom hitherto he, like everyone else, had always called Buonaparte.

"You are speakin of Buonaparte?" asked the eneral, smilin.

Boris looked at his eneral inquirinly and immediately saw that he was
bein tested.

"I am speakin, Prince, of the Emperor Napoleon," he replied. The
eneral patted him on the shoulder, with a smile.

"You will o far," he said, and took him to Tilsit with him.

Boris was amon the few present at the Niemen on the day the two
Emperors met. He saw the raft, decorated with monorams, saw Napoleon
pass before the French uards on the farther bank of the river, saw the
pensive face of the Emperor Alexander as he sat in silence in a tavern
on the bank of the Niemen awaitin Napoleon's arrival, saw both Emperors
et into boats, and saw how Napoleon--reachin the raft first--stepped
quickly forward to meet Alexander and held out his hand to him, and how
they both retired into the pavilion. Since he had beun to move in the
hihest circles Boris had made it his habit to watch attentively all
that went on around him and to note it down. At the time of the meetin
at Tilsit he asked the names of those who had come with Napoleon and
about the uniforms they wore, and listened attentively to words spoken
by important personaes. At the moment the Emperors went into the
pavilion he looked at his watch, and did not foret to look at it aain
when Alexander came out. The interview had lasted an hour and fifty-
three minutes. He noted this down that same evenin, amon other facts
he felt to be of historic importance. As the Emperor's suite was a very
small one, it was a matter of reat importance, for a man who valued his
success in the service, to be at Tilsit on the occasion of this
interview between the two Emperors, and havin succeeded in this, Boris
felt that henceforth his position was fully assured. He had not only
become known, but people had rown accustomed to him and accepted him.
Twice he had executed commissions to the Emperor himself, so that the
latter knew his face, and all those at court, far from cold-shoulderin
him as at first when they considered him a newcomer, would now have been
surprised had he been absent.

Boris loded with another adjutant, the Polish Count Zhilinski.
Zhilinski, a Pole brouht up in Paris, was rich, and passionately fond
of the French, and almost every day of the stay at Tilsit, French
officers of the uard and from French headquarters were dinin and
lunchin with him and Boris.

On the evenin of the twenty-fourth of June, Count Zhilinski arraned a
supper for his French friends. The uest of honor was an aide-de-camp of
Napoleon's, there were also several French officers of the uard, and a
pae of Napoleon's, a youn lad of an old aristocratic French family.
That same day, Rostov, profitin by the darkness to avoid bein
reconized in civilian dress, came to Tilsit and went to the lodin
occupied by Boris and Zhilinski.

Rostov, in common with the whole army from which he came, was far from
havin experienced the chane of feelin toward Napoleon and the French-
-who from bein foes had suddenly become friends--that had taken place
at headquarters and in Boris. In the army, Bonaparte and the French were
still rearded with minled feelins of aner, contempt, and fear. Only
recently, talkin with one of Platov's Cossack officers, Rostov had
arued that if Napoleon were taken prisoner he would be treated not as a
soverein, but as a criminal. Quite lately, happenin to meet a wounded
French colonel on the road, Rostov had maintained with heat that peace
was impossible between a leitimate soverein and the criminal
Bonaparte. Rostov was therefore unpleasantly struck by the presence of
French officers in Boris' lodin, dressed in uniforms he had been
accustomed to see from quite a different point of view from the outposts
of the flank. As soon as he noticed a French officer, who thrust his
head out of the door, that warlike feelin of hostility which he always
experienced at the siht of the enemy suddenly seized him. He stopped at
the threshold and asked in Russian whether Drubetskoy lived there.
Boris, hearin a strane voice in the anteroom, came out to meet him. An
expression of annoyance showed itself for a moment on his face on first
reconizin Rostov.

"Ah, it's you? Very lad, very lad to see you," he said, however,
comin toward him with a smile. But Rostov had noticed his first
impulse.

"I've come at a bad time I think. I should not have come, but I have
business," he said coldly.

"No, I only wonder how you manaed to et away from your reiment. Dans
un moment je suis a vous," * he said, answerin someone who called him.


* "In a minute I shall be at your disposal."

"I see I'm intrudin," Rostov repeated.

The look of annoyance had already disappeared from Boris' face: havin
evidently reflected and decided how to act, he very quietly took both
Rostov's hands and led him into the next room. His eyes, lookin
serenely and steadily at Rostov, seemed to be veiled by somethin, as if
screened by blue spectacles of conventionality. So it seemed to Rostov.

"Oh, come now! As if you could come at a wron time!" said Boris, and he
led him into the room where the supper table was laid and introduced him
to his uests, explainin that he was not a civilian, but an hussar
officer, and an old friend of his.

"Count Zhilinski--le Comte N. N.--le Capitaine S. S.," said he, namin
his uests. Rostov looked frowninly at the Frenchmen, bowed
reluctantly, and remained silent.

Zhilinski evidently did not receive this new Russian person very
willinly into his circle and did not speak to Rostov. Boris did not
appear to notice the constraint the newcomer produced and, with the same
pleasant composure and the same veiled look in his eyes with which he
had met Rostov, tried to enliven the conversation. One of the Frenchmen,
with the politeness characteristic of his countrymen, addressed the
obstinately taciturn Rostov, sayin that the latter had probably come to
Tilsit to see the Emperor.

"No, I came on business," replied Rostov, briefly.

Rostov had been out of humor from the moment he noticed the look of
dissatisfaction on Boris' face, and as always happens to those in a bad
humor, it seemed to him that everyone rearded him with aversion and
that he was in everybody's way. He really was in their way, for he alone
took no part in the conversation which aain became eneral. The looks
the visitors cast on him seemed to say: "And what is he sittin here
for?" He rose and went up to Boris.

"Anyhow, I'm in your way," he said in a low tone. "Come and talk over my
business and I'll o away."

"Oh, no, not at all," said Boris. "But if you are tired, come and lie
down in my room and have a rest."

"Yes, really..."

They went into the little room where Boris slept. Rostov, without
sittin down, bean at once, irritably (as if Boris were to blame in
some way) tellin him about Denisov's affair, askin him whether,
throuh his eneral, he could and would intercede with the Emperor on
Denisov's behalf and et Denisov's petition handed in. When he and Boris

over the other and strokin his left hand with the slender finers of

subordinate, now lookin aside and now azin straiht into Rostov's
eyes with the same veiled look. Each time this happened Rostov felt
uncomfortable and cast down his eyes.

"I have heard of such cases and know that His Majesty is very severe in
such affairs. I think it would be best not to brin it before the
Emperor, but to apply to the commander of the corps.... But in eneral,
I think..."

"So you don't want to do anythin? Well then, say so!" Rostov almost
shouted, not lookin Boris in the face.

Boris smiled.

"On the contrary, I will do what I can. Only I thouht..."

At that moment Zhilinski's voice was heard callin Boris.

"Well then, o, o, o..." said Rostov, and refusin supper and
remainin alone in the little room, he walked up and down for a lon
time, hearin the lihthearted French conversation from the next room.




CHAPTER XX

Rostov had come to Tilsit the day least suitable for a petition on
Denisov's behalf. He could not himself o to the eneral in attendance
as he was in mufti and had come to Tilsit without permission to do so,
and Boris, even had he wished to, could not have done so on the
followin day. On that day, June 27, the preliminaries of peace were
sined. The Emperors exchaned decorations: Alexander received the Cross

Deree, and a dinner had been arraned for the evenin, iven by a

Emperors were to be present at that banquet.

Rostov felt so ill at ease and uncomfortable with Boris that, when the

"Boris doesn't want to help me and I don't want to ask him. That's
settled," thouht Nicholas. "All is over between us, but I won't leave
here without havin done all I can for Denisov and certainly not without
ettin his letter to the Emperor. The Emperor!... He is here!" thouht
Rostov, who had unconsciously returned to the house where Alexander
loded.

Saddled horses were standin before the house and the suite were

"I may see him at any moment," thouht Rostov. "If only I were to hand
the letter direct to him and tell him all... could they really arrest me

justice lies. He understands everythin, knows everythin. Who can be
more just, more mananimous than he? And even if they did arrest me for
bein here, what would it matter?" thouht he, lookin at an officer who
was enterin the house the Emperor occupied. "After all, people do o
in.... It's all nonsense! I'll o in and hand the letter to the Emperor
myself so much the worse for Drubetskoy who drives me to it!" And
suddenly with a determination he himself did not expect, Rostov felt for
the letter in his pocket and went straiht to the house.

"No, I won't miss my opportunity now, as I did after Austerlitz," he

the blood that rushed to his heart at the thouht. "I will fall at his
feet and beseech him. He will lift me up, will listen, and will even
thank me. 'I am happy when I can do ood, but to remedy injustice is the
reatest happiness,'" Rostov fancied the soverein sayin. And passin

A broad staircase led straiht up from the entry, and to the riht he
saw a closed door. Below, under the staircase, was a door leadin to the

"Whom do you want?" someone inquired.

"To hand in a letter, a petition, to His Majesty," said Nicholas, with a
tremor in his voice.

"A petition? This way, to the officer on duty" (he was shown the door
leadin downstairs), "only it won't be accepted."

On hearin this indifferent voice, Rostov rew frihtened at what he was
doin; the thouht of meetin the Emperor at any moment was so

A short stout man of about thirty, in white breeches and hih boots and

"A ood fiure and in her first bloom," he was sayin, but on seein

"What is it? A petition?"

"What is it?" asked the person in the other room.

"Another petitioner," answered the man with the braces.

"Tell him to come later. He'll be comin out directly, we must o."

"Later... later! Tomorrow. It's too late..."

Rostov turned and was about to o, but the man in the braces stopped
him.

"Whom have you come from? Who are you?"

"I come from Major Denisov," answered Rostov.

"Are you an officer?"

"Lieutenant Count Rostov."

"What audacity! Hand it in throuh your commander. And o alon with
you... o," and he continued to put on the uniform the valet handed him.

Rostov went back into the hall and noticed that in the porch there were
many officers and enerals in full parade uniform, whom he had to pass.

Cursin his temerity, his heart sinkin at the thouht of findin

"What are you doin here, sir, in civilian dress?" asked a deep voice.

It was a cavalry eneral who had obtained the Emperor's special favor

Rostov, in dismay, bean justifyin himself, but seein the kindly,

"I'm sorry, sorry for that fine fellow. ive me the letter."

Hardly had Rostov handed him the letter and finished explainin

that same face and same look and step, and the same union of majesty and

brihtenin everythin around by his lance. He spoke a few words to
some of the enerals, and, reconizin the former commander of Rostov's
division, smiled and beckoned to him.

All the suite drew back and Rostov saw the eneral talkin for some time
to the Emperor.

The Emperor said a few words to him and took a step toward his horse.
Aain the crowd of members of the suite and street azers (amon whom
was Rostov) moved nearer to the Emperor. Stoppin beside his horse, with
his hand on the saddle, the Emperor turned to the cavalry eneral and
said in a loud voice, evidently wishin to be heard by all:

"I cannot do it, eneral. I cannot, because the law is stroner than I,"
and he raised his foot to the stirrup.

The eneral bowed his head respectfully, and the monarch mounted and
rode down the street at a allop. Beside himself with enthusiasm, Rostov
ran after him with the crowd.




CHAPTER XXI

The Emperor rode to the square where, facin one another, a battalion of
the Preobrazhensk reiment stood on the riht and a battalion of the
French uards in their bearskin caps on the left.

As the Tsar rode up to one flank of the battalions, which presented
arms, another roup of horsemen alloped up to the opposite flank, and
at the head of them Rostov reconized Napoleon. It could be no one else.
He came at a allop, wearin a small hat, a blue uniform open over a
white vest, and the St. Andrew ribbon over his shoulder. He was ridin a
very fine thorouhbred ray Arab horse with a crimson old-embroidered

Napoleon did not sit well or firmly in the saddle. The battalions

Alexander, and both Emperors dismounted and took each other's hands.
Napoleon's face wore an unpleasant and artificial smile. Alexander was
sayin somethin affable to him.

In spite of the tramplin of the French endarmes' horses, which were

Alexander and Bonaparte. It struck him as a surprise that Alexander
treated Bonaparte as an equal and that the latter was quite at ease with
the Tsar, as if such relations with an Emperor were an everyday matter
to him.

Alexander and Napoleon, with the lon train of their suites, approached

to the Emperors that Rostov, standin in the front row, was afraid he
miht be reconized.

"Sire, I ask your permission to present the Leion of Honor to the
bravest of your soldiers," said a sharp, precise voice, articulatin

This was said by the undersized Napoleon, lookin up straiht into
Alexander's eyes. Alexander listened attentively to what was said to him

"To him who has borne himself most bravely in this last war," added

before him, who all presented arms with their eyes fixed on their
Emperor.

"Will Your Majesty allow me to consult the colonel?" said Alexander and

battalion.

Bonaparte meanwhile bean takin the love off his small white hand,
tore it in doin so, and threw it away. An aide-de-camp behind him
rushed forward and picked it up.

"To whom shall it be iven?" the Emperor Alexander asked Koslovski, in
Russian in a low voice.

"To whomever Your Majesty commands."

The Emperor knit his brows with dissatisfaction and, lancin back,
remarked:

"But we must ive him an answer."

Kozlovski scanned the ranks resolutely and included Rostov in his
scrutiny.

"Can it be me?" thouht Rostov.

"Lazarev!" the colonel called, with a frown, and Lazarev, the first
soldier in the rank, stepped briskly forward.

"Where are you off to? Stop here!" voices whispered to Lazarev who did
not know where to o. Lazarev stopped, castin a sidelon look at his

Napoleon slihtly turned his head, and put his plump little hand out
behind him as if to take somethin. The members of his suite, uessin

Officious hands, Russian and French, immediately seized the cross and

The Emperors remounted and rode away. The Preobrazhensk battalion,

Lazarev sat in the place of honor. Russian and French officers embraced

"What d'you think of the treat? All on silver plate," one of them was

"I have."

"Tomorrow, I hear, the Preobrazhenskis will ive them a dinner."

"Yes, but what luck for Lazarev! Twelve hundred francs' pension for
life."

"Here's a cap, lads!" shouted a Preobrazhensk soldier, donnin a shay
French cap.

"It's a fine thin! First-rate!"

"Have you heard the password?" asked one uards' officer of another.
"The day before yesterday it was 'Napoleon, France, bravoure';
yesterday, 'Alexandre, Russie, randeur.' One day our Emperor ives it
and next day Napoleon. Tomorrow our Emperor will send a St. eore's
Cross to the bravest of the French uards. It has to be done. He must

Boris, too, with his friend Zhilinski, came to see the Preobrazhensk
banquet. On his way back, he noticed Rostov standin by the corner of a

"Rostov! How d'you do? We missed one another," he said, and could not
refrain from askin what was the matter, so stranely dismal and
troubled was Rostov's face.

"Nothin, nothin," replied Rostov.

"You'll call round?"

"Yes, I will."

Rostov stood at that corner for a lon time, watchin the feast from a
distance. In his mind, a painful process was oin on which he could not
brin to a conclusion. Terrible doubts rose in his soul. Now he
remembered Denisov with his chaned expression, his submission, and the

and those dead men?... Then aain he thouht of Lazarev rewarded and
Denisov punished and unpardoned. He cauht himself harborin such
strane thouhts that he was frihtened.

The smell of the food the Preobrazhenskis were eatin and a sense of
huner recalled him from these reflections; he had to et somethin to

Nicholas ate and drank (chiefly the latter) in silence. He finished a

"How can you jude what's best?" he cried, the blood suddenly rushin to
his face. "How can you jude the Emperor's actions? What riht have we
to arue? We cannot comprehend either the Emperor's aims or his
actions!"

"But I never said a word about the Emperor!" said the officer,
justifyin himself, and unable to understand Rostov's outburst, except
on the supposition that he was drunk.

But Rostov did not listen to him.

"We are not diplomatic officials, we are soldiers and nothin more," he
went on. "If we are ordered to die, we must die. If we're punished, it
means that we have deserved it, it's not for us to jude. If the Emperor
pleases to reconize Bonaparte as Emperor and to conclude an alliance
with him, it means that that is the riht thin to do. If once we bein
judin and aruin about everythin, nothin sacred will be left! That
way we shall be sayin there is no od--nothin!" shouted Nicholas,
banin the table--very little to the point as it seemed to his
listeners, but quite relevantly to the course of his own thouhts.

"Our business is to do our duty, to fiht and not to think! That's
all...." said he.

"And to drink," said one of the officers, not wishin to quarrel.

"Yes, and to drink," assented Nicholas. "Hullo there! Another bottle!"
he shouted.

In 1808 the Emperor Alexander went to Erfurt for a fresh interview with
the Emperor Napoleon, and in the upper circles of Petersbur there was
much talk of the randeur of this important meetin.




CHAPTER XXII

In 1809 the intimacy between "the world's two arbiters," as Napoleon and
Alexander were called, was such that when Napoleon declared war on
Austria a Russian corps crossed the frontier to co-operate with our old
enemy Bonaparte aainst our old ally the Emperor of Austria, and in
court circles the possibility of marriae between Napoleon and one of
Alexander's sisters was spoken of. But besides considerations of forein
policy, the attention of Russian society was at that time keenly
directed on the internal chanes that were bein undertaken in all the
departments of overnment.

Life meanwhile--real life, with its essential interests of health and
sickness, toil and rest, and its intellectual interests in thouht,
science, poetry, music, love, friendship, hatred, and passions--went on
as usual, independently of and apart from political friendship or enmity
with Napoleon Bonaparte and from all the schemes of reconstruction.

BOOK SIX: 1808 - 10




CHAPTER I

Prince Andrew had spent two years continuously in the country.

All the plans Pierre had attempted on his estates--and constantly
chanin from one thin to another had never accomplished--were carried
out by Prince Andrew without display and without perceptible difficulty.

He had in the hihest deree a practical tenacity which Pierre lacked,
and without fuss or strain on his part this set thins oin.

On one of his estates the three hundred serfs were liberated and became
free aricultural laborers--this bein one of the first examples of the
kind in Russia. On other estates the serfs' compulsory labor was
commuted for a quitrent. A trained midwife was enaed for Boucharovo
at his expense, and a priest was paid to teach readin and writin to
the children of the peasants and household serfs.

Prince Andrew spent half his time at Bald Hills with his father and his
son, who was still in the care of nurses. The other half he spent in
"Boucharovo Cloister," as his father called Prince Andrew's estate.
Despite the indifference to the affairs of the world he had expressed to
Pierre, he diliently followed all that went on, received many books,
and to his surprise noticed that when he or his father had visitors from
Petersbur, the very vortex of life, these people laed behind himself-
-who never left the country--in knowlede of what was happenin in home
and forein affairs.

Besides bein occupied with his estates and readin a reat variety of
books, Prince Andrew was at this time busy with a critical survey of our
last two unfortunate campains, and with drawin up a proposal for a
reform of the army rules and reulations.

In the sprin of 1809 he went to visit the Ryazan estates which had been
inherited by his son, whose uardian he was.

Warmed by the sprin sunshine he sat in the caleche lookin at the new
rass, the first leaves on the birches, and the first puffs of white
sprin clouds floatin across the clear blue sky. He was not thinkin of
anythin, but looked absent-mindedly and cheerfully from side to side.

They crossed the ferry where he had talked with Pierre the year before.
They went throuh the muddy villae, past threshin floors and reen

forest the horses bean to snort and sweated visibly.

Peter the footman made some remark to the coachman; the latter assented.
But apparently the coachman's sympathy was not enouh for Peter, and he
turned on the box toward his master.

"How pleasant it is, your excellency!" he said with a respectful smile.

"What?"

"It's pleasant, your excellency!"


"What is he talkin about?" thouht Prince Andrew. "Oh, the sprin, I
suppose," he thouht as he turned round. "Yes, really everythin is
reen already.... How early! The birches and cherry and alders too are
comin out.... But the oaks show no sin yet. Ah, here is one oak!"

At the ede of the road stood an oak. Probably ten times the ae of the
birches that formed the forest, it was ten times as thick and twice as

could embrace, and evidently lon ao some of its branches had been

refused to yield to the charm of sprin or notice either the sprin or

"Sprin, love, happiness!" this oak seemed to say. "Are you not weary of
that stupid, meaninless, constantly repeated fraud? Always the same and
always a fraud? There is no sprin, no sun, no happiness! Look at those
cramped dead firs, ever the same, and at me too, stickin out my broken

As he passed throuh the forest Prince Andrew turned several times to

misshapen, and rim as ever.

"Yes, the oak is riht, a thousand times riht," thouht Prince Andrew.
"Let others--the youn--yield afresh to that fraud, but we know life,
our life is finished!"

A whole sequence of new thouhts, hopeless but mournfully pleasant, rose

were, considered his life afresh and arrived at his old conclusion,
restful in its hopelessness: that it was not for him to bein anythin
anew--but that he must live out his life, content to do no harm, and not
disturbin himself or desirin anythin.




CHAPTER II

Prince Andrew had to see the Marshal of the Nobility for the district in

trustee. This Marshal was Count Ilya Rostov, and in the middle of May
Prince Andrew went to visit him.

It was now hot sprin weather. The whole forest was already clothed in

In 1809 Count Ilya Rostov was livin at Otradnoe just as he had done in

Durin the dull day, in the course of which he was entertained by his

That niht, alone in new surroundins, he was lon unable to sleep. He

His room was on the first floor. Those in the rooms above were also

"Just once more," said a irlish voice above him which Prince Andrew

"But when are you comin to bed?" replied another voice.

"I won't, I can't sleep, what's the use? Come now for the last time."


Two irlish voices san a musical passae--the end of some son.

"Oh, how lovely! Now o to sleep, and there's an end of it."

"You o to sleep, but I can't," said the first voice, comin nearer to

Sonya made some reluctant reply.

"Do just come and see what a moon!... Oh, how lovely! Come here....
Darlin, sweetheart, come here! There, you see? I feel like sittin down

"Take care, you'll fall out."

He heard the sound of a scuffle and Sonya's disapprovin voice: "It's

"Oh, you only spoil thins for me. All riht, o, o!"

Aain all was silent, but Prince Andrew knew she was still sittin

In his soul there suddenly arose such an unexpected turmoil of youthful

CHAPTER III

Next mornin, havin taken leave of no one but the count, and not

It was already the beinnin of June when on his return journey he drove

On reachin home Prince Andrew decided to o to Petersbur that autumn

"My dear," Princess Mary enterin at such a moment would say, "little

"If it were hot," Prince Andrew would reply at such times very dryly to

At such moments Princess Mary would think how intellectual work dries
men up.




CHAPTER IV

Prince Andrew arrived in Petersbur in Auust, 1809. It was the time
when the youthful Speranski was at the zenith of his fame and his

"I know myself that one cannot help one's sympathies and antipathies,"

He mentioned what he had written to an old field marshal, a friend of

On the appointed day Prince Andrew entered Count Arakcheev's waitin

He did not know Arakcheev personally, had never seen him, and all he had

Durin his service, chiefly as an adjutant, Prince Andrew had seen the

"What is your petition?" asked Arakcheev.

"I am not petitionin, your excellency," returned Prince Andrew quietly.

Arakcheev's eyes turned toward him.

"Sit down," said he. "Prince Bolkonski?"

"I am not petitionin about anythin. His Majesty the Emperor has

"You see, my dear sir, I have read your project," interrupted Arakcheev,

"I came at His Majesty the Emperor's wish to learn from your excellency

"To what committee has the memorandum been referred?" inquired Prince

"To the Committee on Army Reulations, and I have recommended that your

Prince Andrew smiled.

"I don't want one."

"A member without salary," repeated Arakcheev. "I have the honor... Eh!

CHAPTER V

While waitin for the announcement of his appointment to the committee

Prince Andrew was most favorably placed to secure ood reception in the

"Mon cher, even in this case you can't do without Michael Mikhaylovich

personality.

"rounds of personal ambition maybe," Speranski put in quietly.

"And of state interest to some extent," said Prince Andrew.

"What do you mean?" asked Speranski quietly, lowerin his eyes.

"I am an admirer of Montesquieu," replied Prince Andrew, "and his idea
that le principe des monarchies est l'honneur me parait incontestable.
Certains droits et privilees de la noblesse me paraissent etre des
moyens de soutenir ce sentiment." *


* "The principle of monarchies is honor seems to me incontestable.
Certain rihts and privilees for the aristocracy appear to me a means
of maintainin that sentiment."

The smile vanished from Speranski's white face, which was much improved
by the chane. Probably Prince Andrew's thouht interested him.

"Si vous envisaez la question sous ce point de vue," * he bean,
pronouncin French with evident difficulty, and speakin even slower
than in Russian but quite calmly.


* "If you reard the question from that point of view."

Speranski went on to say that honor, l'honneur, cannot be upheld by
privilees harmful to the service; that honor, l'honneur, is either a
neative concept of not doin what is blameworthy or it is a source of
emulation in pursuit of commendation and rewards, which reconize it.
His aruments were concise, simple, and clear.

"An institution upholdin honor, the source of emulation, is one similar

"I do not dispute that, but it cannot be denied that court privilees

"Yet you do not care to avail yourself of the privilee, Prince," said

Closin his eyes, he bowed a la francaise, without takin leave, and

CHAPTER VI

Durin the first weeks of his stay in Petersbur Prince Andrew felt the
whole trend of thouht he had formed durin his life of seclusion quite

On returnin home in the evenin he would jot down in his notebook four

absorbed the reater part of his vital enery. He did nothin, did not

successfully, of what he had thouht while in the country.

He sometimes noticed with dissatisfaction that he repeated the same

whole days toether that he had no time to notice that he was thinkin

As he had done on their first meetin at Kochubey's, Speranski produced

To Bolkonski so many people appeared contemptible and insinificant

appreciated the other's capacity or because he considered it necessary

that one's companion is the only man besides oneself capable of

and profundity of one's own ideas.

Durin their lon conversation on Wednesday evenin, Speranski more than
once remarked: "We reard everythin that is above the common level of
rooted custom..." or, with a smile: "But we want the wolves to be fed
and the sheep to be safe..." or: "They cannot understand this..." and
all in a way that seemed to say: "We, you and I, understand what they
are and who we are."

This first lon conversation with Speranski only strenthened in Prince
Andrew the feelin he had experienced toward him at their first meetin.
He saw in him a remarkable, clear-thinkin man of vast intellect who by
his enery and persistence had attained power, which he was usin solely

life reasonably, considered important only what was rational, and was

involuntarily areed with him about everythin. If he replied and

possess power. This mirrorlike aze and those delicate hands irritated

boldly, it seemed to Prince Andrew, from one to another. Now he would
take up the position of a practical man and condemn dreamers; now that

loical, or suddenly rise to the realm of metaphysics. (This last
resource was one he very frequently employed.) He would transfer a
question to metaphysical heihts, pass on to definitions of space, time,
and thouht, and, havin deduced the refutation he needed, would aain
descend to the level of the oriinal discussion.

In eneral the trait of Speranski's mentality which struck Prince Andrew
most was his absolute and unshakable belief in the power and authority

impossible to express all one thinks; and that he had never felt the

peculiarity of Speranski's mind that particularly attracted Prince

Durin the first period of their acquaintance Bolkonski felt a

On that first evenin Bolkonski spent with him, havin mentioned the

had stuck labels on the correspondin pararaphs of the different codes.

"And that is all the state has for the millions it has spent," said he.
"We want to ive the Senate new juridical powers, but we have no laws.
That is why it is a sin for men like you, Prince, not to serve in these
times!"

Prince Andrew said that for that work an education in jurisprudence was
needed which he did not possess.

"But nobody possesses it, so what would you have? It is a vicious circle
from which we must break a way out."

A week later Prince Andrew was a member of the Committee on Army
Reulations and--what he had not at all expected--was chairman of a
section of the committee for the revision of the laws. At Speranski's
request he took the first part of the Civil Code that was bein drawn up

CHAPTER VII

Nearly two years before this, in 1808, Pierre on returnin to Petersbur

His life meanwhile continued as before, with the same infatuations and

Amid the turmoil of his activities and distractions, however, Pierre at

At the same time he felt that the deeper the round sank under him the

Joseph Alexeevich was not in Petersbur--he had of late stood aside from

He divided the Brothers he knew into four cateories. In the first he
put those who did not take an active part in the affairs of the lodes

science of the order: with questions of the threefold desination of

meanin of the square and all the various fiures of the temple of

aspect of Freemasonry.

In the second cateory Pierre reckoned himself and others like him,
seekin and vacillatin, who had not yet found in Freemasonry a straiht
and comprehensible path, but hoped to do so.

In the third cateory he included those Brothers (the majority) who saw
nothin in Freemasonry but the external forms and ceremonies, and prized
the strict performance of these forms without troublin about their

Finally, to the fourth cateory also a reat many Brothers beloned,

Pierre bean to feel dissatisfied with what he was doin. Freemasonry,
at any rate as he saw it here, sometimes seemed to him based merely on

In the summer of 1809 Pierre returned to Petersbur. Our Freemasons knew
from correspondence with those abroad that Bezukhov had obtained the

A solemn meetin of the lode of the second deree was convened, at

"For the dissemination of pure truth and to secure the triumph of

education of the youn, unite ourselves in indissoluble bonds with the
wisest men, boldly yet prudently overcome superstitions, infidelity, and
folly, and form of those devoted to us a body linked toether by unity
of purpose and possessed of authority and power.

"To attain this end we must secure a preponderance of virtue over vice
and must endeavor to secure that the honest man may, even in this world,
receive a lastin reward for his virtue. But in these reat endeavors we
are ravely hampered by the political institutions of today. What is to
be done in these circumstances? To favor revolutions, overthrow
everythin, repel force by force?... No! We are very far from that.
Every violent reform deserves censure, for it quite fails to remedy evil
while men remain what they are, and also because wisdom needs no
violence.

"The whole plan of our order should be based on the idea of preparin
men of firmness and virtue bound toether by unity of conviction--aimin

raisin worthy men from the dust and attachin them to our Brotherhood.
Only then will our order have the power unobtrusively to bind the hands

It tauht men to be wise and ood and for their own benefit to follow

"At that time, when everythin was pluned in darkness, preachin alone

necessary that man, overned by his senses, should find in virtue a
charm palpable to those senses. It is impossible to eradicate the
passions; but we must strive to direct them to a noble aim, and it is
therefore necessary that everyone should be able to satisfy his passions

"As soon as we have a certain number of worthy men in every state, each
of them aain trainin two others and all bein closely united,

This speech not only made a stron impression, but created excitement in

presentin itself identically to two persons. Even those members who
seemed to be on his side understood him in their own way with

wanted most was to convey his thouht to others just as he himself

* The Illuminati souht to substitute republican for monarchical
institutions.

At the end of the meetin the rand Master with irony and ill-will

Pierre did not answer him and asked briefly whether his proposal would

CHAPTER VIII

Aain Pierre was overtaken by the depression he so dreaded. For three

It was just then that he received a letter from his wife, who implored

wished to devote her whole life to him.

At the end of the letter she informed him that in a few days she would
return to Petersbur from abroad.

Followin this letter one of the masonic Brothers whom Pierre respected

"No one is riht and no one is to blame; so she too is not to blame," he

Without replyin either to his wife or his mother-in-law, Pierre late

Moscow, 17th November

I have just returned from my benefactor, and hasten to write down what I
have experienced. Joseph Alexeevich is livin poorly and has for three

order: (1) The preservation and study of the mystery. (2) The
purification and reformation of oneself for its reception, and (3) The
improvement of the human race by strivin for such purification. Which

self-purification. Only to this aim can we always strive independently

impurity we are unworthy to receive, or seek the reformation of the

profliacy. Illuminism is not a pure doctrine, just because it is

Petersbur, 23rd November

I am aain livin with my wife. My mother-in-law came to me in tears and

CHAPTER IX

At that time, as always happens, the hihest society that met at court
and at the rand balls was divided into several circles, each with its

Helene had been at Erfurt durin the famous meetin of the Emperors and

established that she could say the emptiest and stupidest thins and
everybody would o into raptures over every word of hers and look for a
profound meanin in it of which she herself had no conception.


* "That's a superb animal."

* (2) "Of a charmin woman, as witty as she is lovely."

Pierre was just the husband needed for a brilliant society woman. He was
that absent-minded crank, a rand seineur husband who was in no one's

Amon the many youn men who frequented her house every day, Boris

"No, now that she has become a bluestockin she has finally renounced

"What a strane antipathy," thouht Pierre, "yet I used to like him very

In the eyes of the world Pierre was a reat entleman, the rather blind

CHAPTER X

Pierre went on with his diary, and this is what he wrote in it durin
that time:

24th November

ot up at eiht, read the Scriptures, then went to my duties. (By Joseph

I am oin to bed with a happy and tranquil mind. reat od, help me to

27th November

I ot up late. On wakin I lay lon in bed yieldin to sloth. O od,

After this, three paes were left blank in the diary, and then the
followin was written:

I have had a lon and instructive talk alone with Brother V., who
advised me to hold fast by Brother A. Thouh I am unworthy, much was

which means the All. Talks with Brother V. strenthen, refresh, and

The distinction between the poor teachins of mundane science and our
sacred all-embracin teachin is clear to me. Human sciences dissect
everythin to comprehend it, and kill everythin to examine it. In the
holy science of our order all is one, all is known in its entirety and
life. The Trinity--the three elements of matter--are sulphur, mercury,
and salt. Sulphur is of an oily and fiery nature; in combination with
salt by its fiery nature it arouses a desire in the latter by means of
which it attracts mercury, seizes it, holds it, and in combination
produces other bodies. Mercury is a fluid, volatile, spiritual essence.
Christ, the Holy Spirit, Him!...

3rd December

Awoke late, read the Scriptures but was apathetic. Afterwards went and

7th December

I dreamed that Joseph Alexeevich was sittin in my house, and that I was

9th December

I had a dream from which I awoke with a throbbin heart. I saw that I

CHAPTER XI

The Rostovs' monetary affairs had not improved durin the two years they
had spent in the country.

Thouh Nicholas Rostov had kept firmly to his resolution and was still
servin modestly in an obscure reiment, spendin comparatively little,

particular--was such that the debts inevitably increased every year. The
only resource obviously presentin itself to the old count was to apply
for an official post, so he had come to Petersbur to look for one and
also, as he said, to let the lassies enjoy themselves for the last time.

Soon after their arrival in Petersbur Ber proposed to Vera and was
accepted.

Thouh in Moscow the Rostovs beloned to the best society without
themselves ivin it a thouht, yet in Petersbur their circle of

inquirin to what set they beloned, here looked down on them.

The Rostovs lived in the same hospitable way in Petersbur as in Moscow,

dauhter, Countess Vera, the attentions a youn man pays when he intends
to propose.

Not in vain had Ber shown everybody his riht hand wounded at
Austerlitz and held a perfectly unnecessary sword in his left. He
narrated that episode so persistently and with so important an air that
everyone believed in the merit and usefulness of his deed, and he had
obtained two decorations for Austerlitz.

In the Finnish war he also manaed to distinuish himself. He had picked
up the scrap of a renade that had killed an aide-de-camp standin near

done after Austerlitz, he related this occurrence at such lenth and so

lucrative posts in Petersbur.

Thouh some skeptics smiled when told of Ber's merits, it could not be
denied that he was a painstakin and brave officer, on excellent terms
with his superiors, and a moral youn man with a brilliant career before
him and an assured position in society.

Four years before, meetin a erman comrade in the stalls of a Moscow

his mind to marry her. Now in Petersbur, havin considered the Rostovs'
position and his own, he decided that the time had come to propose.


* "That irl shall be my wife."

Ber's proposal was at first received with a perplexity that was not
flatterin to him. At first it seemed strane that the son of an obscure
Livonian entleman should propose marriae to a Countess Rostova; but
Ber's chief characteristic was such a naive and ood natured eotism
that the Rostovs involuntarily came to think it would be a ood thin,

"You see," said Ber to his comrade, whom he called "friend" only

were in any way unsuitable. But on the contrary, my papa and mamma are

and a husband his. I have my position in the service, she has
connections and some means. In our times that is worth somethin, isn't

Ber blushed and smiled.

"And I love her, because her character is sensible and very ood. Now
the other sister, thouh they are the same family, is quite different--
an unpleasant character and has not the same intellience. She is so...
you know?... Unpleasant... But my fiancee!... Well, you will be comin,"
he was oin to say, "to dine," but chaned his mind and said "to take
tea with us," and quickly doublin up his tonue he blew a small round

After the first feelin of perplexity aroused in the parents by Ber's

In the family's feelin toward this weddin a certain awkwardness and

he any money.

Ber had already been enaed a month, and only a week remained before
the weddin, but the count had not yet decided in his own mind the

count thouht of ivin her the Ryazan estate or of sellin a forest, at

lon-foreseen inquiry that without consideration he ave the first reply
that came into his head. "I like your bein businesslike about it.... I
like it. You shall be satisfied...."

And pattin Ber on the shoulder he ot up, wishin to end the
conversation. But Ber, smilin pleasantly, explained that if he did not
know for certain how much Vera would have and did not receive at least
part of the dowry in advance, he would have to break matters off.

"Because, consider, Count--if I allowed myself to marry now without
havin definite means to maintain my wife, I should be actin badly...."

The conversation ended by the count, who wished to be enerous and to
avoid further importunity, sayin that he would ive a note of hand for

note of hand for only sixty thousand."

"Yes, yes, all riht!" said the count hurriedly. "Only excuse me, my
