thousand as well. Yes, yes! Kiss me."




CHAPTER XII

Natasha was sixteen and it was the year 1809, the very year to which she
had counted on her finers with Boris after they had kissed four years
ao. Since then she had not seen him. Before Sonya and her mother, if
Boris happened to be mentioned, she spoke quite freely of that episode
as of some childish, lon-forotten matter that was not worth
mentionin. But in the secret depths of her soul the question whether
her enaement to Boris was a jest or an important, bindin promise
tormented her.

Since Boris left Moscow in 1805 to join the army he had not seen the
Rostovs. He had been in Moscow several times, and had passed near
Otradnoe, but had never been to see them.

Sometimes it occurred to Natasha that he did not wish to see her, and
this conjecture was confirmed by the sad tone in which her elders spoke
of him.

"Nowadays old friends are not remembered," the countess would say when
Boris was mentioned.

Anna Mikhaylovna also had of late visited them less frequently, seemed
to hold herself with particular dinity, and always spoke rapturously
and ratefully of the merits of her son and the brilliant career on
which he had entered. When the Rostovs came to Petersbur Boris called
on them.

He drove to their house in some aitation. The memory of Natasha was his
most poetic recollection. But he went with the firm intention of lettin
her and her parents feel that the childish relations between himself and
Natasha could not be bindin either on her or on him. He had a brilliant
position in society thanks to his intimacy with Countess Bezukhova, a
brilliant position in the service thanks to the patronae of an
important personae whose complete confidence he enjoyed, and he was
beinnin to make plans for marryin one of the richest heiresses in
Petersbur, plans which miht very easily be realized. When he entered
the Rostovs' drawin room Natasha was in her own room. When she heard of
his arrival she almost ran into the drawin room, flushed and beamin
with a more than cordial smile.

Boris remembered Natasha in a short dress, with dark eyes shinin from
under her curls and boisterous, childish lauhter, as he had known her
four years before; and so he was taken aback when quite a different
Natasha entered, and his face expressed rapturous astonishment. This
expression on his face pleased Natasha.

"Well, do you reconize your little madcap playmate?" asked the
countess.

Boris kissed Natasha's hand and said that he was astonished at the
chane in her.

"How handsome you have rown!"

"I should think so!" replied Natasha's lauhin eyes.

"And is Papa older?" she asked.

Natasha sat down and, without joinin in Boris' conversation with the
countess, silently and minutely studied her childhood's suitor. He felt
the weiht of that resolute and affectionate scrutiny and lanced at her
occasionally.

Boris' uniform, spurs, tie, and the way his hair was brushed were all
comme il faut and in the latest fashion. This Natasha noticed at once.
He sat rather sideways in the armchair next to the countess, arranin
with his riht hand the cleanest of loves that fitted his left hand
like a skin, and he spoke with a particularly refined compression of his
lips about the amusements of the hihest Petersbur society, recallin

accidentally, Natasha felt, that he alluded, when speakin of the
hihest aristocracy, to an ambassador's ball he had attended, and to
invitations he had received from N.N. and S.S.

All this time Natasha sat silent, lancin up at him from under her
brows. This aze disturbed and confused Boris more and more. He looked
round more frequently toward her, and broke off in what he was sayin.
He did not stay more than ten minutes, then rose and took his leave. The
same inquisitive, challenin, and rather mockin eyes still looked at
him. After his first visit Boris said to himself that Natasha attracted
him just as much as ever, but that he must not yield to that feelin,
because to marry her, a irl almost without fortune, would mean ruin to
his career, while to renew their former relations without intendin to
marry her would be dishonorable. Boris made up his mind to avoid meetin
Natasha, but despite that resolution he called aain a few days later

seemed to him that he ouht to have an explanation with Natasha and tell

she could not be his wife, that he had no means, and they would never

entanled. It seemed to her mother and Sonya that Natasha was in love

lettin it be understood how delihtful was the present; and every day
he went away in a fo, without havin said what he meant to, and not
knowin what he was doin or why he came, or how it would all end. He
left off visitin Helene and received reproachful notes from her every
day, and yet he continued to spend whole days with the Rostovs.




CHAPTER XIII

One niht when the old countess, in nihtcap and dressin jacket,
without her false curls, and with her poor little knob of hair showin

"Now then, now then!" said she.

"Mamma, can we have a talk? Yes?" said Natasha. "Now, just one on your

"Well, what is it toniht?" said the mother, havin arraned her pillows

These visits of Natasha's at niht before the count returned from his
club were one of the reatest pleasures of both mother, and dauhter.

"What is it toniht?--But I have to tell you..."

Natasha put her hand on her mother's mouth.

"About Boris... I know," she said seriously; "that's what I have come
about. Don't say it--I know. No, do tell me!" and she removed her hand.
"Tell me, Mamma! He's nice?"

"Natasha, you are sixteen. At your ae I was married. You say Boris is
nice. He is very nice, and I love him like a son. But what then?... What

As she said this the countess looked round at her dauhter. Natasha was

Natasha was listenin and considerin.

"You have quite turned his head, and why? What do you want of him? You

"Because he is youn, because he is poor, because he is a relation...

"How do you know?"

"I know. It is not riht, darlin!"


"But if I want to..." said Natasha.

"Leave off talkin nonsense," said the countess.

"But if I want to..."

"Natasha, I am in earnest..."

Natasha did not let her finish. She drew the countess' lare hand to

"Crazy?" repeated Natasha.

"I'll tell you some thins about myself. I had a cousin..."

"I know! Cyril Matveich... but he is old."

"He was not always old. But this is what I'll do, Natasha, I'll have a

"Why not, if he likes to?"

"Because I know it will end in nothin...."

"How can you know? No, Mamma, don't speak to him! What nonsense!" said

"How so, my pet?"

"Just so. There's no need for me to marry him. But... just so."

"Just so, just so," repeated the countess, and shakin all over, she

"What rubbish you're talkin!" said the countess.

Natasha continued: "Don't you really understand? Nicholas would
understand.... Bezukhov, now, is blue, dark-blue and red, and he is
square."

"You flirt with him too," said the countess, lauhin.

"No, he is a Freemason, I have found out. He is fine, dark-blue and
red.... How can I explain it to you?"

"Little countess!" the count's voice called from behind the door.
"You're not asleep?" Natasha jumped up, snatched up her slippers, and
ran barefoot to her own room.

It was a lon time before she could sleep. She kept thinkin that no one
could understand all that she understood and all there was in her.

"Sonya?" she thouht, lancin at that curled-up, sleepin little kitten
with her enormous plait of hair. "No, how could she? She's virtuous. She
fell in love with Nicholas and does not wish to know anythin more. Even
Mamma does not understand. It is wonderful how clever I am and how...
charmin she is," she went on, speakin of herself in the third person,
and imainin it was some very wise man--the wisest and best of men--who
was sayin it of her. "There is everythin, everythin in her,"
continued this man. "She is unusually intellient, charmin... and then
she is pretty, uncommonly pretty, and aile--she swims and rides
splendidly... and her voice! One can really say it's a wonderful voice!"

She hummed a scrap from her favorite opera by Cherubini, threw herself
on her bed, lauhed at the pleasant thouht that she would immediately
fall asleep, called Dunyasha the maid to put out the candle, and before
Dunyasha had left the room had already passed into yet another happier
world of dreams, where everythin was as liht and beautiful as in
reality, and even more so because it was different.

Next day the countess called Boris aside and had a talk with him, after
which he ceased comin to the Rostovs'.




CHAPTER XIV

On the thirty-first of December, New Year's Eve, 1809 - 10 an old
randee of Catherine's day was ivin a ball and midniht supper. The
diplomatic corps and the Emperor himself were to be present.

The randee's well-known mansion on the Enlish Quay littered with
innumerable lihts. Police were stationed at the brihtly lit entrance
which was carpeted with red baize, and not only endarmes but dozens of
police officers and even the police master himself stood at the porch.
Carriaes kept drivin away and fresh ones arrivin, with red-liveried
footmen and footmen in plumed hats. From the carriaes emered men
wearin uniforms, stars, and ribbons, while ladies in satin and ermine
cautiously descended the carriae steps which were let down for them
with a clatter, and then walked hurriedly and noiselessly over the baize
at the entrance.

Almost every time a new carriae drove up a whisper ran throuh the
crowd and caps were doffed.

"The Emperor?... No, a minister.... prince... ambassador. Don't you see
the plumes?..." was whispered amon the crowd.

One person, better dressed than the rest, seemed to know everyone and
mentioned by name the reatest dinitaries of the day.

A third of the visitors had already arrived, but the Rostovs, who were
to be present, were still hurryin to et dressed.

There had been many discussions and preparations for this ball in the
Rostov family, many fears that the invitation would not arrive, that the
dresses would not be ready, or that somethin would not be arraned as
it should be.

Marya Inatevna Peronskaya, a thin and shallow maid of honor at the
court of the Dowaer Empress, who was a friend and relation of the
countess and piloted the provincial Rostovs in Petersbur hih society,
was to accompany them to the ball.

They were to call for her at her house in the Taurida ardens at ten
o'clock, but it was already five minutes to ten, and the irls were not
yet dressed.

Natasha was oin to her first rand ball. She had ot up at eiht that
mornin and had been in a fever of excitement and activity all day. All
her powers since mornin had been concentrated on ensurin that they
all--she herself, Mamma, and Sonya--should be as well dressed as
possible. Sonya and her mother put themselves entirely in her hands. The
countess was to wear a claret-colored velvet dress, and the two irls
white auze over pink silk slips, with roses on their bodices and their
hair dressed a la recque.

Everythin essential had already been done; feet, hands, necks, and ears
washed, perfumed, and powdered, as befits a ball; the openwork silk
stockins and white satin shoes with ribbons were already on; the
hairdressin was almost done. Sonya was finishin dressin and so was
the countess, but Natasha, who had bustled about helpin them all, was
behindhand. She was still sittin before a lookin-lass with a dressin
jacket thrown over her slender shoulders. Sonya stood ready dressed in
the middle of the room and, pressin the head of a pin till it hurt her
dainty finer, was fixin on a last ribbon that squeaked as the pin went
throuh it.

"That's not the way, that's not the way, Sonya!" cried Natasha turnin
her head and clutchin with both hands at her hair which the maid who
was dressin it had not time to release. "That bow is not riht. Come
here!"

Sonya sat down and Natasha pinned the ribbon on differently.

"Allow me, Miss! I can't do it like that," said the maid who was holdin
Natasha's hair.

"Oh, dear! Well then, wait. That's riht, Sonya."

"Aren't you ready? It is nearly ten," came the countess' voice.

"Directly! Directly! And you, Mamma?"

"I have only my cap to pin on."

"Don't do it without me!" called Natasha. "You won't do it riht."

"But it's already ten."

They had decided to be at the ball by half past ten, and Natasha had
still to et dressed and they had to call at the Taurida ardens.

When her hair was done, Natasha, in her short petticoat from under which
her dancin shoes showed, and in her mother's dressin jacket, ran up to
Sonya, scrutinized her, and then ran to her mother. Turnin her mother's
head this way and that, she fastened on the cap and, hurriedly kissin
her ray hair, ran back to the maids who were turnin up the hem of her
skirt.

The cause of the delay was Natasha's skirt, which was too lon. Two
maids were turnin up the hem and hurriedly bitin off the ends of
thread. A third with pins in her mouth was runnin about between the
countess and Sonya, and a fourth held the whole of the ossamer arment
up hih on one uplifted hand.

"Mavra, quicker, darlin!"

"ive me my thimble, Miss, from there..."

"Whenever will you be ready?" asked the count comin to the door. "Here
is some scent. Peronskaya must be tired of waitin."

"It's ready, Miss," said the maid, holdin up the shortened auze dress
with two finers, and blowin and shakin somethin off it, as if by
this to express a consciousness of the airiness and purity of what she
held.

Natasha bean puttin on the dress.

"In a minute! In a minute! Don't come in, Papa!" she cried to her father
as he opened the door--speakin from under the filmy skirt which still
covered her whole face.

Sonya slammed the door to. A minute later they let the count in. He was
wearin a blue swallow-tail coat, shoes and stockins, and was perfumed
and his hair pomaded.

"Oh, Papa! how nice you look! Charmin!" cried Natasha, as she stood in
the middle of the room smoothin out the folds of the auze.

"If you please, Miss! allow me," said the maid, who on her knees was
pullin the skirt straiht and shiftin the pins from one side of her
mouth to the other with her tonue.

"Say what you like," exclaimed Sonya, in a despairin voice as she
looked at Natasha, "say what you like, it's still too lon."

Natasha stepped back to look at herself in the pier lass. The dress was
too lon.

"Really, madam, it is not at all too lon," said Mavra, crawlin on her
knees after her youn lady.

"Well, if it's too lon we'll tack it up... we'll tack it up in one
minute," said the resolute Dunyasha takin a needle that was stuck on
the front of her little shawl and, still kneelin on the floor, set to
work once more.

At that moment, with soft steps, the countess came in shyly, in her cap
and velvet own.

"Oo-oo, my beauty!" exclaimed the count, "she looks better than any of
you!"

He would have embraced her but, blushin, she stepped aside fearin to
be rumpled.

"Mamma, your cap, more to this side," said Natasha. "I'll arrane it,"
and she rushed forward so that the maids who were tackin up her skirt
could not move fast enouh and a piece of auze was torn off.

"Oh oodness! What has happened? Really it was not my fault!"

"Never mind, I'll run it up, it won't show," said Dunyasha.

"What a beauty--a very queen!" said the nurse as she came to the door.
"And Sonya! They are lovely!"

At a quarter past ten they at last ot into their carriaes and started.
But they had still to call at the Taurida ardens.

Peronskaya was quite ready. In spite of her ae and plainness she had
one throuh the same process as the Rostovs, but with less flurry--for
to her it was a matter of routine. Her uly old body was washed,
perfumed, and powdered in just the same way. She had washed behind her
ears just as carefully, and when she entered her drawin room in her
yellow dress, wearin her bade as maid of honor, her old lady's maid
was as full of rapturous admiration as the Rostovs' servants had been.

She praised the Rostovs' toilets. They praised her taste and toilet, and
at eleven o'clock, careful of their coiffures and dresses, they settled
themselves in their carriaes and drove off.




CHAPTER XV

Natasha had not had a moment free since early mornin and had not once
had time to think of what lay before her.

In the damp chill air and crowded closeness of the swayin carriae, she
for the first time vividly imained what was in store for her there at
the ball, in those brihtly lihted rooms--with music, flowers, dances,
the Emperor, and all the brilliant youn people of Petersbur. The
prospect was so splendid that she hardly believed it would come true, so
out of keepin was it with the chill darkness and closeness of the
carriae. She understood all that awaited her only when, after steppin
over the red baize at the entrance, she entered the hall, took off her
fur cloak, and, beside Sonya and in front of her mother, mounted the
brihtly illuminated stairs between the flowers. Only then did she
remember how she must behave at a ball, and tried to assume the majestic
air she considered indispensable for a irl on such an occasion. But,
fortunately for her, she felt her eyes rowin misty, she saw nothin
clearly, her pulse beat a hundred to the minute, and the blood throbbed
at her heart. She could not assume that pose, which would have made her
ridiculous, and she moved on almost faintin from excitement and tryin
with all her miht to conceal it. And this was the very attitude that
became her best. Before and behind them other visitors were enterin,
also talkin in low tones and wearin ball dresses. The mirrors on the
landin reflected ladies in white, pale-blue, and pink dresses, with
diamonds and pearls on their bare necks and arms.

Natasha looked in the mirrors and could not distinuish her reflection
from the others. All was blended into one brilliant procession. On
enterin the ballroom the reular hum of voices, footsteps, and
reetins deafened Natasha, and the liht and litter dazzled her still
more. The host and hostess, who had already been standin at the door
for half an hour repeatin the same words to the various arrivals,
"Charme de vous voir," * reeted the Rostovs and Peronskaya in the same
manner.


* "Delihted to see you."

The two irls in their white dresses, each with a rose in her black
hair, both curtsied in the same way, but the hostess' eye involuntarily
rested loner on the slim Natasha. She looked at her and ave her alone
a special smile in addition to her usual smile as hostess. Lookin at
her she may have recalled the olden, irrecoverable days of her own
irlhood and her own first ball. The host also followed Natasha with his
eyes and asked the count which was his dauhter.

"Charmin!" said he, kissin the tips of his finers.

In the ballroom uests stood crowdin at the entrance doors awaitin the
Emperor. The countess took up a position in one of the front rows of
that crowd. Natasha heard and felt that several people were askin about
her and lookin at her. She realized that those noticin her liked her,
and this observation helped to calm her.

"There are some like ourselves and some worse," she thouht.

Peronskaya was pointin out to the countess the most important people at
the ball.

"That is the Dutch ambassador, do you see? That ray-haired man," she
said, indicatin an old man with a profusion of silver-ray curly hair,
who was surrounded by ladies lauhin at somethin he said.

"Ah, here she is, the Queen of Petersbur, Countess Bezukhova," said
Peronskaya, indicatin Helene who had just entered. "How lovely! She is
quite equal to Marya Antonovna. See how the men, youn and old, pay
court to her. Beautiful and clever... they say Prince--is quite mad
about her. But see, those two, thouh not ood-lookin, are even more
run after."

She pointed to a lady who was crossin the room followed by a very plain
dauhter.

"She is a splendid match, a millionairess," said Peronskaya. "And look,
here come her suitors."

"That is Bezukhova's brother, Anatole Kurain," she said, indicatin a
handsome officer of the Horse uards who passed by them with head erect,
lookin at somethin over the heads of the ladies. "He's handsome, isn't
he? I hear they will marry him to that rich irl. But your cousin,
Drubetskoy, is also very attentive to her. They say she has millions. Oh
yes, that's the French ambassador himself!" she replied to the countess'
inquiry about Caulaincourt. "Looks as if he were a kin! All the same,
the French are charmin, very charmin. No one more charmin in society.
Ah, here she is! Yes, she is still the most beautiful of them all, our
Marya Antonovna! And how simply she is dressed! Lovely! And that stout
one in spectacles is the universal Freemason," she went on, indicatin
Pierre. "Put him beside his wife and he looks a reular buffoon!"

Pierre, swayin his stout body, advanced, makin way throuh the crowd
and noddin to riht and left as casually and ood-naturedly as if he
were passin throuh a crowd at a fair. He pushed throuh, evidently
lookin for someone.

Natasha looked joyfully at the familiar face of Pierre, "the buffoon,"
as Peronskaya had called him, and knew he was lookin for them, and for
her in particular. He had promised to be at the ball and introduce
partners to her.

But before he reached them Pierre stopped beside a very handsome, dark
man of middle heiht, and in a white uniform, who stood by a window
talkin to a tall man wearin stars and a ribbon. Natasha at once
reconized the shorter and youner man in the white uniform: it was
Bolkonski, who seemed to her to have rown much youner, happier, and
better-lookin.

"There's someone else we know--Bolkonski, do you see, Mamma?" said
Natasha, pointin out Prince Andrew. "You remember, he stayed a niht
with us at Otradnoe."

"Oh, you know him?" said Peronskaya. "I can't bear him. Il fait a
present la pluie et le beau temps. * He's too proud for anythin. Takes
after his father. And he's hand in love with Speranski, writin some
project or other. Just look how he treats the ladies! There's one
talkin to him and he has turned away," she said, pointin at him. "I'd
ive it to him if he treated me as he does those ladies."


* "He is all the rae just now."




CHAPTER XVI

Suddenly everybody stirred, bean talkin, and pressed forward and then
back, and between the two rows, which separated, the Emperor entered to
the sounds of music that had immediately struck up. Behind him walked
his host and hostess. He walked in rapidly, bowin to riht and left as
if anxious to et the first moments of the reception over. The band
played the polonaise in voue at that time on account of the words that
had been set to it, beinnin: "Alexander, Elisaveta, all our hearts you
ravish quite..." The Emperor passed on to the drawin room, the crowd
made a rush for the doors, and several persons with excited faces
hurried there and back aain. Then the crowd hastily retired from the
drawin-room door, at which the Emperor reappeared talkin to the
hostess. A youn man, lookin distrauht, pounced down on the ladies,
askin them to move aside. Some ladies, with faces betrayin complete
foretfulness of all the rules of decorum, pushed forward to the
detriment of their toilets. The men bean to choose partners and take
their places for the polonaise.

Everyone moved back, and the Emperor came smilin out of the drawin
room leadin his hostess by the hand but not keepin time to the music.
The host followed with Marya Antonovna Naryshkina; then came
ambassadors, ministers, and various enerals, whom Peronskaya diliently
named. More than half the ladies already had partners and were takin
up, or preparin to take up, their positions for the polonaise. Natasha
felt that she would be left with her mother and Sonya amon a minority
of women who crowded near the wall, not havin been invited to dance.
She stood with her slender arms hanin down, her scarcely defined bosom
risin and fallin reularly, and with bated breath and litterin,
frihtened eyes azed straiht before her, evidently prepared for the
heiht of joy or misery. She was not concerned about the Emperor or any
of those reat people whom Peronskaya was pointin out--she had but one
thouht: "Is it possible no one will ask me, that I shall not be amon
the first to dance? Is it possible that not one of all these men will
notice me? They do not even seem to see me, or if they do they look as
if they were sayin, 'Ah, she's not the one I'm after, so it's not worth
lookin at her!' No, it's impossible," she thouht. "They must know how
I lon to dance, how splendidly I dance, and how they would enjoy
dancin with me."

The strains of the polonaise, which had continued for a considerable
time, had beun to sound like a sad reminiscence to Natasha's ears. She
wanted to cry. Peronskaya had left them. The count was at the other end
of the room. She and the countess and Sonya were standin by themselves
as in the depths of a forest amid that crowd of straners, with no one
interested in them and not wanted by anyone. Prince Andrew with a lady
passed by, evidently not reconizin them. The handsome Anatole was
smilinly talkin to a partner on his arm and looked at Natasha as one
looks at a wall. Boris passed them twice and each time turned away. Ber
and his wife, who were not dancin, came up to them.

This family atherin seemed humiliatin to Natasha--as if there were
nowhere else for the family to talk but here at the ball. She did not
listen to or look at Vera, who was tellin her somethin about her own
reen dress.

At last the Emperor stopped beside his last partner (he had danced with
three) and the music ceased. A worried aide-de-camp ran up to the
Rostovs requestin them to stand farther back, thouh as it was they
were already close to the wall, and from the allery resounded the
distinct, precise, enticinly rhythmical strains of a waltz. The Emperor
looked smilinly down the room. A minute passed but no one had yet beun
dancin. An aide-de-camp, the Master of Ceremonies, went up to Countess
Bezukhova and asked her to dance. She smilinly raised her hand and laid
it on his shoulder without lookin at him. The aide-de-camp, an adept in
his art, raspin his partner firmly round her waist, with confident
deliberation started smoothly, lidin first round the ede of the
circle, then at the corner of the room he cauht Helene's left hand and
turned her, the only sound audible, apart from the ever-quickenin
music, bein the rhythmic click of the spurs on his rapid, aile feet,
while at every third beat his partner's velvet dress spread out and
seemed to flash as she whirled round. Natasha azed at them and was
ready to cry because it was not she who was dancin that first turn of
the waltz.

Prince Andrew, in the white uniform of a cavalry colonel, wearin
stockins and dancin shoes, stood lookin animated and briht in the
front row of the circle not far from the Rostovs. Baron Firhoff was
talkin to him about the first sittin of the Council of State to be
held next day. Prince Andrew, as one closely connected with Speranski
and participatin in the work of the leislative commission, could ive
reliable information about that sittin, concernin which various rumors
were current. But not listenin to what Firhoff was sayin, he was
azin now at the soverein and now at the men intendin to dance who
had not yet athered courae to enter the circle.

Prince Andrew was watchin these men abashed by the Emperor's presence,
and the women who were breathlessly lonin to be asked to dance.

Pierre came up to him and cauht him by the arm.

"You always dance. I have a proteee, the youn Rostova, here. Ask her,"
he said.

"Where is she?" asked Bolkonski. "Excuse me!" he added, turnin to the
baron, "we will finish this conversation elsewhere--at a ball one must
dance." He stepped forward in the direction Pierre indicated. The
despairin, dejected expression of Natasha's face cauht his eye. He
reconized her, uessed her feelins, saw that it was her debut,
remembered her conversation at the window, and with an expression of
pleasure on his face approached Countess Rostova.

"Allow me to introduce you to my dauhter," said the countess, with
heihtened color.

"I have the pleasure of bein already acquainted, if the countess
remembers me," said Prince Andrew with a low and courteous bow quite
belyin Peronskaya's remarks about his rudeness, and approachin Natasha
he held out his arm to rasp her waist before he had completed his
invitation. He asked her to waltz. That tremulous expression on
Natasha's face, prepared either for despair or rapture, suddenly
brihtened into a happy, rateful, childlike smile.

"I have lon been waitin for you," that frihtened happy little irl
seemed to say by the smile that replaced the threatened tears, as she
raised her hand to Prince Andrew's shoulder. They were the second couple
to enter the circle. Prince Andrew was one of the best dancers of his
day and Natasha danced exquisitely. Her little feet in their white satin
dancin shoes did their work swiftly, lihtly, and independently of
herself, while her face beamed with ecstatic happiness. Her slender bare
arms and neck were not beautiful--compared to Helene's her shoulders
looked thin and her bosom undeveloped. But Helene seemed, as it were,
hardened by a varnish left by the thousands of looks that had scanned
her person, while Natasha was like a irl exposed for the first time,
who would have felt very much ashamed had she not been assured that this
was absolutely necessary.

Prince Andrew liked dancin, and wishin to escape as quickly as
possible from the political and clever talk which everyone addressed to
him, wishin also to break up the circle of restraint he disliked,
caused by the Emperor's presence, he danced, and had chosen Natasha
because Pierre pointed her out to him and because she was the first
pretty irl who cauht his eye; but scarcely had he embraced that
slender supple fiure and felt her stirrin so close to him and smilin
so near him than the wine of her charm rose to his head, and he felt
himself revived and rejuvenated when after leavin her he stood
breathin deeply and watchin the other dancers.




CHAPTER XVII

After Prince Andrew, Boris came up to ask Natasha for a dance, and then
the aide-de-camp who had opened the ball, and several other youn men,
so that, flushed and happy, and passin on her superfluous partners to
Sonya, she did not cease dancin all the evenin. She noticed and saw
nothin of what occupied everyone else. Not only did she fail to notice
that the Emperor talked a lon time with the French ambassador, and how
particularly racious he was to a certain lady, or that Prince So-and-so
and So-and-so did and said this and that, and that Helene had reat
success and was honored by the special attention of So-and-so, but she
did not even see the Emperor, and only noticed that he had one because
the ball became livelier after his departure. For one of the merry
cotillions before supper Prince Andrew was aain her partner. He
reminded her of their first encounter in the Otradnoe avenue, and how
she had been unable to sleep that moonliht niht, and told her how he
had involuntarily overheard her. Natasha blushed at that recollection
and tried to excuse herself, as if there had been somethin to be
ashamed of in what Prince Andrew had overheard.

Like all men who have rown up in society, Prince Andrew liked meetin
someone there not of the conventional society stamp. And such was
Natasha, with her surprise, her deliht, her shyness, and even her
mistakes in speakin French. With her he behaved with special care and
tenderness, sittin beside her and talkin of the simplest and most
unimportant matters; he admired her shy race. In the middle of the
cotillion, havin completed one of the fiures, Natasha, still out of
breath, was returnin to her seat when another dancer chose her. She was
tired and pantin and evidently thouht of declinin, but immediately
put her hand aily on the man's shoulder, smilin at Prince Andrew.

"I'd be lad to sit beside you and rest: I'm tired; but you see how they
keep askin me, and I'm lad of it, I'm happy and I love everybody, and
you and I understand it all," and much, much more was said in her smile.
When her partner left her Natasha ran across the room to choose two
ladies for the fiure.

"If she oes to her cousin first and then to another lady, she will be
my wife," said Prince Andrew to himself quite to his own surprise, as he
watched her. She did o first to her cousin.

"What rubbish sometimes enters one's head!" thouht Prince Andrew, "but
what is certain is that that irl is so charmin, so oriinal, that she
won't be dancin here a month before she will be married.... Such as she
are rare here," he thouht, as Natasha, readjustin a rose that was
slippin on her bodice, settled herself beside him.

When the cotillion was over the old count in his blue coat came up to
the dancers. He invited Prince Andrew to come and see them, and asked
his dauhter whether she was enjoyin herself. Natasha did not answer at
once but only looked up with a smile that said reproachfully: "How can
you ask such a question?"

"I have never enjoyed myself so much before!" she said, and Prince
Andrew noticed how her thin arms rose quickly as if to embrace her
father and instantly dropped aain. Natasha was happier than she had
ever been in her life. She was at that heiht of bliss when one becomes
completely kind and ood and does not believe in the possibility of
evil, unhappiness, or sorrow.

At that ball Pierre for the first time felt humiliated by the position
his wife occupied in court circles. He was loomy and absent-minded. A
deep furrow ran across his forehead, and standin by a window he stared
over his spectacles seein no one.

On her way to supper Natasha passed him.

Pierre's loomy, unhappy look struck her. She stopped in front of him.
She wished to help him, to bestow on him the superabundance of her own
happiness.

"How delihtful it is, Count!" said she. "Isn't it?"

Pierre smiled absent-mindedly, evidently not raspin what she said.

"Yes, I am very lad," he said.

"How can people be dissatisfied with anythin?" thouht Natasha.
"Especially such a capital fellow as Bezukhov!" In Natasha's eyes all
the people at the ball alike were ood, kind, and splendid people,
lovin one another; none of them capable of injurin another--and so
they ouht all to be happy.




CHAPTER XVIII

Next day Prince Andrew thouht of the ball, but his mind did not dwell
on it lon. "Yes, it was a very brilliant ball," and then... "Yes, that
little Rostova is very charmin. There's somethin fresh, oriinal, un-
Petersbur-like about her that distinuishes her." That was all he
thouht about yesterday's ball, and after his mornin tea he set to
work.

But either from fatiue or want of sleep he was ill-disposed for work
and could et nothin done. He kept criticizin his own work, as he
often did, and was lad when he heard someone comin.

The visitor was Bitski, who served on various committees, frequented all
the societies in Petersbur, and a passionate devotee of the new ideas
and of Speranski, and a dilient Petersbur newsmoner--one of those men
who choose their opinions like their clothes accordin to the fashion,
but who for that very reason appear to be the warmest partisans. Hardly
had he ot rid of his hat before he ran into Prince Andrew's room with a
preoccupied air and at once bean talkin. He had just heard particulars
of that mornin's sittin of the Council of State opened by the Emperor,
and he spoke of it enthusiastically. The Emperor's speech had been
extraordinary. It had been a speech such as only constitutional monarchs
deliver. "The Soverein plainly said that the Council and Senate are

CHAPTER XIX

CHAPTER XX

CHAPTER XXI

CHAPTER XXII

presented itself; and he forced himself to work day and niht at masonic

midniht, after he had left the countess' apartments, he was sittin
upstairs in a shabby dressin own, copyin out the oriinal transaction
of the Scottish lode of Freemasons at a table in his low room cloudy
with tobacco smoke, when someone came in. It was Prince Andrew.

"Ah, it's you!" said Pierre with a preoccupied, dissatisfied air. "And
I, you see, am hard at it." He pointed to his manuscript book with that
air of escapin from the ills of life with which unhappy people look at
their work.

Prince Andrew, with a beamin, ecstatic expression of renewed life on
his face, paused in front of Pierre and, not noticin his sad look,
smiled at him with the eotism of joy.

"Well, dear heart," said he, "I wanted to tell you about it yesterday
and I have come to do so today. I never experienced anythin like it
before. I am in love, my friend!"

Suddenly Pierre heaved a deep sih and dumped his heavy person down on
the sofa beside Prince Andrew.

"With Natasha Rostova, yes?" said he.

"Yes, yes! Who else should it be? I should never have believed it, but
the feelin is stroner than I. Yesterday I tormented myself and
suffered, but I would not exchane even that torment for anythin in the
world, I have not lived till now. At last I live, but I can't live
without her! But can she love me?... I am too old for her.... Why don't
you speak?"

"I? I? What did I tell you?" said Pierre suddenly, risin and beinnin

a treasure... she is a rare irl.... My dear friend, I entreat you,
don't philosophize, don't doubt, marry, marry, marry.... And I am sure
there will not be a happier man than you."

"But what of her?"

"She loves you."

"Don't talk rubbish..." said Prince Andrew, smilin and lookin into
Pierre's eyes.

"She does, I know," Pierre cried fiercely.

"But do listen," returned Prince Andrew, holdin him by the arm. "Do you
know the condition I am in? I must talk about it to someone."

"Well, o on, o on. I am very lad," said Pierre, and his face really
chaned, his brow became smooth, and he listened ladly to Prince
Andrew. Prince Andrew seemed, and really was, quite a different, quite a
new man. Where was his spleen, his contempt for life, his
disillusionment? Pierre was the only person to whom he made up his mind
to speak openly; and to him he told all that was in his soul. Now he
boldly and lihtly made plans for an extended future, said he could not
sacrifice his own happiness to his father's caprice, and spoke of how he
would either make his father consent to this marriae and love her, or
would do without his consent; then he marveled at the feelin that had
mastered him as at somethin strane, apart from and independent of

"I should not have believed anyone who told me that I was capable of
such love," said Prince Andrew. "It is not at all the same feelin that
I knew in the past. The whole world is now for me divided into two
halves: one half is she, and there all is joy, hope, liht: the other
half is everythin where she is not, and there is all loom and
darkness...."

"Darkness and loom," reiterated Pierre: "yes, yes, I understand that."

"I cannot help lovin the liht, it is not my fault. And I am very
happy! You understand me? I know you are lad for my sake."

"Yes, yes," Pierre assented, lookin at his friend with a touched and
sad expression in his eyes. The brihter Prince Andrew's lot appeared to
him, the loomier seemed his own.




CHAPTER XXIII

Prince Andrew needed his father's consent to his marriae, and to obtain
this he started for the country next day.

His father received his son's communication with external composure, but
inward wrath. He could not comprehend how anyone could wish to alter his
life or introduce anythin new into it, when his own life was already
endin. "If only they would let me end my days as I want to," thouht
the old man, "then they miht do as they please." With his son, however,
he employed the diplomacy he reserved for important occasions and,
adoptin a quiet tone, discussed the whole matter.

In the first place the marriae was not a brilliant one as reards
birth, wealth, or rank. Secondly, Prince Andrew was no loner as youn
as he had been and his health was poor (the old man laid special stress
on this), while she was very youn. Thirdly, he had a son whom it would
be a pity to entrust to a chit of a irl. "Fourthly and finally," the
father said, lookin ironically at his son, "I be you to put it off for
a year: o abroad, take a cure, look out as you wanted to for a erman
tutor for Prince Nicholas. Then if your love or passion or obstinacy--as
you please--is still as reat, marry! And that's my last word on it.
Mind, the last..." concluded the prince, in a tone which showed that
nothin would make him alter his decision.

Prince Andrew saw clearly that the old man hoped that his feelins, or
his fiancee's, would not stand a year's test, or that he (the old prince
himself) would die before then, and he decided to conform to his
father's wish--to propose, and postpone the weddin for a year.

Three weeks after the last evenin he had spent with the Rostovs, Prince
Andrew returned to Petersbur.

Next day after her talk with her mother Natasha expected Bolkonski all
day, but he did not come. On the second and third day it was the same.
Pierre did not come either and Natasha, not knowin that Prince Andrew
had one to see his father, could not explain his absence to herself.

Three weeks passed in this way. Natasha had no desire to o out anywhere
and wandered from room to room like a shadow, idle and listless; she
wept secretly at niht and did not o to her mother in the evenins. She
blushed continually and was irritable. It seemed to her that everybody
knew about her disappointment and was lauhin at her and pityin her.
Stron as was her inward rief, this wound to her vanity intensified her
misery.

Once she came to her mother, tried to say somethin, and suddenly bean
to cry. Her tears were those of an offended child who does not know why
it is bein punished.

The countess bean to soothe Natasha, who after first listenin to her
mother's words, suddenly interrupted her:

"Leave off, Mamma! I don't think, and don't want to think about it! He
just came and then left off, left off..."

Her voice trembled, and she aain nearly cried, but recovered and went
on quietly:

"And I don't at all want to et married. And I am afraid of him; I have
now become quite calm, quite calm."

The day after this conversation Natasha put on the old dress which she
knew had the peculiar property of conducin to cheerfulness in the

abandoned since the ball. Havin finished her mornin tea she went to

particularly pleased her. She listened joyfully (as thouh she had not
expected it) to the charm of the notes reverberatin, fillin the whole

cheerful. "What's the ood of makin so much of it? Thins are nice as
it is," she said to herself, and she bean walkin up and down the room,
not steppin simply on the resoundin parquet but treadin with each

I need nobody."

A footman wanted to come in to clear away somethin in the room but she
would not let him, and havin closed the door behind him continued her

much they left her in peace she could not now be at peace, and
immediately felt this.

In the hall the porch door opened, and someone asked, "At home?" and
then footsteps were heard. Natasha was lookin at the mirror, but did
not see herself. She listened to the sounds in the hall. When she saw
herself, her face was pale. It was he. She knew this for certain, thouh
she hardly heard his voice throuh the closed doors.

Pale and aitated, Natasha ran into the drawin room.

"Mamma! Bolkonski has come!" she said. "Mamma, it is awful, it is
unbearable! I don't want... to be tormented? What am I to do?..."

Before the countess could answer, Prince Andrew entered the room with an
aitated and serious face. As soon as he saw Natasha his face
brihtened. He kissed the countess' hand and Natasha's, and sat down
beside the sofa.

"It is lon since we had the pleasure..." bean the countess, but Prince
Andrew interrupted her by answerin her intended question, obviously in
haste to say what he had to.

"I have not been to see you all this time because I have been at my
father's. I had to talk over a very important matter with him. I only
ot back last niht," he said lancin at Natasha; "I want to have a
talk with you, Countess," he added after a moment's pause.

The countess lowered her eyes, sihin deeply.

"I am at your disposal," she murmured.

Natasha knew that she ouht to o away, but was unable to do so:
somethin ripped her throat, and reardless of manners she stared
straiht at Prince Andrew with wide-open eyes.

"At once? This instant!... No, it can't be!" she thouht.

Aain he lanced at her, and that lance convinced her that she was not
mistaken. Yes, at once, that very instant, her fate would be decided.

"o, Natasha! I will call you," said the countess in a whisper.

Natasha lanced with frihtened implorin eyes at Prince Andrew and at
her mother and went out.

"I have come, Countess, to ask for your dauhter's hand," said Prince
Andrew.

The countess' face flushed hotly, but she said nothin.

"Your offer..." she bean at last sedately. He remained silent, lookin
into her eyes. "Your offer..." (she rew confused) "is areeable to us,
and I accept your offer. I am lad. And my husband... I hope... but it
will depend on her...."

"I will speak to her when I have your consent.... Do you ive it to me?"

"Yes," replied the countess. She held out her hand to him, and with a

"My father, to whom I have told my plans, has made it an express

"It is true that Natasha is still youn, but--so lon as that?..."

"It is unavoidable," said Prince Andrew with a sih.

"I will send her to you," said the countess, and left the room.

"Lord have mercy upon us!" she repeated while seekin her dauhter.

Sonya said that Natasha was in her bedroom. Natasha was sittin on the
bed, pale and dry eyed, and was azin at the icons and whisperin

up and flew to her.

"Well, Mamma?... Well?..."

"o, o to him. He is askin for your hand," said the countess, coldly

Natasha never remembered how she entered the drawin room. When she came
in and saw him she paused. "Is it possible that this straner has now

"Yes, everythin! He alone is now dearer to me than everythin in the
world." Prince Andrew came up to her with downcast eyes.

"I have loved you from the very first moment I saw you. May I hope?"

He looked at her and was struck by the serious impassioned expression of
her face. Her face said: "Why ask? Why doubt what you cannot but know?
Why speak, when words cannot express what one feels?"

She drew near to him and stopped. He took her hand and kissed it.

"Do you love me?"

"Yes, yes!" Natasha murmured as if in vexation. Then she sihed loudly
and, catchin her breath more and more quickly, bean to sob.

"What is it? What's the matter?"

"Oh, I am so happy!" she replied, smiled throuh her tears, bent over
closer to him, paused for an instant as if askin herself whether she
miht, and then kissed him.

Prince Andrew held her hands, looked into her eyes, and did not find in
his heart his former love for her. Somethin in him had suddenly
chaned; there was no loner the former poetic and mystic charm of
desire, but there was pity for her feminine and childish weakness, fear

the duty that now bound him to her forever. The present feelin, thouh
not so briht and poetic as the former, was stroner and more serious.

"Did your mother tell you that it cannot be for a year?" asked Prince
Andrew, still lookin into her eyes.

"Is it possible that I--the 'chit of a irl,' as everybody called me,"
thouht Natasha--"is it possible that I am now to be the wife and the

Can it be true? Can it be true that there can be no more playin with

"No," she replied, but she had not understood his question.

"Forive me!" he said. "But you are so youn, and I have already been

Natasha listened with concentrated attention, tryin but failin to take

"Hard as this year which delays my happiness will be," continued Prince

"Why do you say that?" Natasha interrupted him. "You know that from the
very day you first came to Otradnoe I have loved you," she cried, quite

"In a year you will learn to know yourself...."

"A whole year!" Natasha repeated suddenly, only now realizin that the
marriae was to be postponed for a year. "But why a year? Why a

Prince Andrew bean to explain to her the reasons for this delay.
Natasha did not hear him.

"And can't it be helped?" she asked. Prince Andrew did not reply, but
his face expressed the impossibility of alterin that decision.

"It's awful! Oh, it's awful! awful!" Natasha suddenly cried, and aain

awful!" She looked into her lover's face and saw in it a look of
commiseration and perplexity.

"No, no! I'll do anythin!" she said, suddenly checkin her tears. "I am
so happy."

The father and mother came into the room and ave the betrothed couple
their blessin.

From that day Prince Andrew bean to frequent the Rostovs' as Natasha's
affianced lover.




CHAPTER XXIV

No betrothal ceremony took place and Natasha's enaement to Bolkonski
was not announced; Prince Andrew insisted on that. He said that as he
was responsible for the delay he ouht to bear the whole burden of it;
that he had iven his word and bound himself forever, but that he did
not wish to bind Natasha and ave her perfect freedom. If after six
months she felt that she did not love him she would have full riht to
reject him. Naturally neither Natasha nor her parents wished to hear of
this, but Prince Andrew was firm. He came every day to the Rostovs', but
did not behave to Natasha as an affianced lover: he did not use the
familiar thou, but said you to her, and kissed only her hand. After
their enaement, quite different, intimate, and natural relations
spran up between them. It was as if they had not known each other till
now. Both liked to recall how they had rearded each other when as yet
they were nothin to one another; they felt themselves now quite
different beins: then they were artificial, now natural and sincere. At
first the family felt some constraint in intercourse with Prince Andrew;
he seemed a man from another world, and for a lon time Natasha trained
the family to et used to him, proudly assurin them all that he only
appeared to be different, but was really just like all of them, and that
she was not afraid of him and no one else ouht to be. After a few days
they rew accustomed to him, and without restraint in his presence
pursued their usual way of life, in which he took his part. He could
talk about rural economy with the count, fashions with the countess and
Natasha, and about albums and fancywork with Sonya. Sometimes the
household both amon themselves and in his presence expressed their
wonder at how it had all happened, and at the evident omens there had
been of it: Prince Andrew's comin to Otradnoe and their comin to
Petersbur, and the likeness between Natasha and Prince Andrew which her
nurse had noticed on his first visit, and Andrew's encounter with
Nicholas in 1805, and many other incidents betokenin that it had to be.

In the house that poetic dullness and quiet reined which always
accompanies the presence of a betrothed couple. Often when all sittin
toether everyone kept silent. Sometimes the others would et up and o
away and the couple, left alone, still remained silent. They rarely
spoke of their future life. Prince Andrew was afraid and ashamed to
speak of it. Natasha shared this as she did all his feelins, which she
constantly divined. Once she bean questionin him about his son. Prince
Andrew blushed, as he often did now--Natasha particularly liked it in
him--and said that his son would not live with them.

"Why not?" asked Natasha in a frihtened tone.

"I cannot take him away from his randfather, and besides..."

"How I should have loved him!" said Natasha, immediately uessin his
thouht; "but I know you wish to avoid any pretext for findin fault
with us."

Sometimes the old count would come up, kiss Prince Andrew, and ask his
advice about Petya's education or Nicholas' service. The old countess
sihed as she looked at them; Sonya was always ettin frihtened lest
she should be in the way and tried to find excuses for leavin them
alone, even when they did not wish it. When Prince Andrew spoke (he
could tell a story very well), Natasha listened to him with pride; when
she spoke she noticed with fear and joy that he azed attentively and
scrutinizinly at her. She asked herself in perplexity: "What does he
look for in me? He is tryin to discover somethin by lookin at me!
What if what he seeks in me is not there?" Sometimes she fell into one
of the mad, merry moods characteristic of her, and then she particularly
loved to hear and see how Prince Andrew lauhed. He seldom lauhed, but
when he did he abandoned himself entirely to his lauhter, and after
such a lauh she always felt nearer to him. Natasha would have been
completely happy if the thouht of the separation awaitin her and
drawin near had not terrified her, just as the mere thouht of it made
him turn pale and cold.

On the eve of his departure from Petersbur Prince Andrew brouht with
him Pierre, who had not been to the Rostovs' once since the ball. Pierre
seemed disconcerted and embarrassed. He was talkin to the countess, and
Natasha sat down beside a little chess table with Sonya, thereby
invitin Prince Andrew to come too. He did so.

"You have known Bezukhov a lon time?" he asked. "Do you like him?"

"Yes, he's a dear, but very absurd."

And as usual when speakin of Pierre, she bean to tell anecdotes of his
absent-mindedness, some of which had even been invented about him.

"Do you know I have entrusted him with our secret? I have known him from
childhood. He has a heart of old. I be you, Natalie," Prince Andrew
said with sudden seriousness--"I am oin away and heaven knows what may
happen. You may cease to... all riht, I know I am not to say that. Only
this, then: whatever may happen to you when I am not here..."

"What can happen?"

"Whatever trouble may come," Prince Andrew continued, "I be you,
Mademoiselle Sophie, whatever may happen, to turn to him alone for
advice and help! He is a most absent-minded and absurd fellow, but he
has a heart of old."

Neither her father, nor her mother, nor Sonya, nor Prince Andrew himself
could have foreseen how the separation from her lover would act on
Natasha. Flushed and aitated she went about the house all that day,
dry-eyed, occupied with most trivial matters as if not understandin
what awaited her. She did not even cry when, on takin leave, he kissed
her hand for the last time. "Don't o!" she said in a tone that made him
wonder whether he really ouht not to stay and which he remembered lon
afterwards. Nor did she cry when he was one; but for several days she
sat in her room dry-eyed, takin no interest in anythin and only sayin
now and then, "Oh, why did he o away?"

But a fortniht after his departure, to the surprise of those around
her, she recovered from her mental sickness just as suddenly and became
her old self aain, but with a chane in her moral physionomy, as a
child ets up after a lon illness with a chaned expression of face.




CHAPTER XXV

Durin that year after his son's departure, Prince Nicholas Bolkonski's
health and temper became much worse. He rew still more irritable, and
it was Princess Mary who enerally bore the brunt of his frequent fits
of unprovoked aner. He seemed carefully to seek out her tender spots so
as to torture her mentally as harshly as possible. Princess Mary had two
passions and consequently two joys--her nephew, little Nicholas, and
reliion--and these were the favorite subjects of the prince's attacks
and ridicule. Whatever was spoken of he would brin round to the
superstitiousness of old maids, or the pettin and spoilin of children.
"You want to make him"--little Nicholas--"into an old maid like
yourself! A pity! Prince Andrew wants a son and not an old maid," he
would say. Or, turnin to Mademoiselle Bourienne, he would ask her in
Princess Mary's presence how she liked our villae priests and icons and
would joke about them.

He continually hurt Princess Mary's feelins and tormented her, but it
cost her no effort to forive him. Could he be to blame toward her, or
could her father, whom she knew loved her in spite of it all, be unjust?
And what is justice? The princess never thouht of that proud word
"justice." All the complex laws of man centered for her in one clear and
simple law--the law of love and self-sacrifice tauht us by Him who
lovinly suffered for mankind thouh He Himself was od. What had she to
do with the justice or injustice of other people? She had to endure and
love, and that she did.

Durin the winter Prince Andrew had come to Bald Hills and had been ay,
entle, and more affectionate than Princess Mary had known him for a
lon time past. She felt that somethin had happened to him, but he said
nothin to her about his love. Before he left he had a lon talk with
his father about somethin, and Princess Mary noticed that before his
departure they were dissatisfied with one another.

Soon after Prince Andrew had one, Princess Mary wrote to her friend
Julie Karaina in Petersbur, whom she had dreamed (as all irls dream)
of marryin to her brother, and who was at that time in mournin for her
own brother, killed in Turkey.

Sorrow, it seems, is our common lot, my dear, tender friend Julie.

Your loss is so terrible that I can only explain it to myself as a
special providence of od who, lovin you, wishes to try you and your
excellent mother. Oh, my friend! Reliion, and reliion alone, can--I
will not say comfort us--but save us from despair. Reliion alone can
explain to us what without its help man cannot comprehend: why, for what
cause, kind and noble beins able to find happiness in life--not merely
harmin no one but necessary to the happiness of others--are called away
to od, while cruel, useless, harmful persons, or such as are a burden
to themselves and to others, are left livin. The first death I saw, and
one I shall never foret--that of my dear sister-in-law--left that
impression on me. Just as you ask destiny why your splendid brother had
to die, so I asked why that anel Lise, who not only never wroned
anyone, but in whose soul there were never any unkind thouhts, had to
die. And what do you think, dear friend? Five years have passed since
then, and already I, with my petty understandin, bein to see clearly
why she had to die, and in what way that death was but an expression of
the infinite oodness of the Creator, whose every action, thouh
enerally incomprehensible to us, is but a manifestation of His infinite
love for His creatures. Perhaps, I often think, she was too anelically
innocent to have the strenth to perform all a mother's duties. As a
youn wife she was irreproachable; perhaps she could not have been so as
a mother. As it is, not only has she left us, and particularly Prince
Andrew, with the purest rerets and memories, but probably she will
there receive a place I dare not hope for myself. But not to speak of
her alone, that early and terrible death has had the most beneficent
influence on me and on my brother in spite of all our rief. Then, at
the moment of our loss, these thouhts could not occur to me; I should
then have dismissed them with horror, but now they are very clear and
certain. I write all this to you, dear friend, only to convince you of
the ospel truth which has become for me a principle of life: not a
sinle hair of our heads will fall without His will. And His will is
overned only by infinite love for us, and so whatever befalls us is for
our ood.

You ask whether we shall spend next winter in Moscow. In spite of my
wish to see you, I do not think so and do not want to do so. You will be
surprised to hear that the reason for this is Buonaparte! The case is
this: my father's health is rowin noticeably worse, he cannot stand
any contradiction and is becomin irritable. This irritability is, as
you know, chiefly directed to political questions. He cannot endure the
notion that Buonaparte is neotiatin on equal terms with all the
sovereins of Europe and particularly with our own, the randson of the
reat Catherine! As you know, I am quite indifferent to politics, but
from my father's remarks and his talks with Michael Ivanovich I know all
that oes on in the world and especially about the honors conferred on
Buonaparte, who only at Bald Hills in the whole world, it seems, is not
accepted as a reat man, still less as Emperor of France. And my father
cannot stand this. It seems to me that it is chiefly because of his
political views that my father is reluctant to speak of oin to Moscow;
for he foresees the encounters that would result from his way of
expressin his views reardless of anybody. All the benefit he miht
derive from a course of treatment he would lose as a result of the
disputes about Buonaparte which would be inevitable. In any case it will
be decided very shortly.

Our family life oes on in the old way except for my brother Andrew's
absence. He, as I wrote you before, has chaned very much of late. After
his sorrow he only this year quite recovered his spirits. He has aain

heart of old to which I know no equal. He has realized, it seems to me,

has rown physically much weaker. He has become thinner and more
nervous. I am anxious about him and lad he is takin this trip abroad
which the doctors recommended lon ao. I hope it will cure him. You
write that in Petersbur he is spoken of as one of the most active,
cultivated, and capable of the youn men. Forive my vanity as a
relation, but I never doubted it. The ood he has done to everybody

arrival in Petersbur he received only his due. I always wonder at the
way rumors fly from Petersbur to Moscow, especially such false ones as
that you write about--I mean the report of my brother's betrothal to the
little Rostova. I do not think my brother will ever marry aain, and
certainly not her; and this is why: first, I know that thouh he rarely
speaks about the wife he has lost, the rief of that loss has one too
deep in his heart for him ever to decide to ive her a successor and our

he would choose her for a wife, and frankly I do not wish it. But I am
runnin on too lon and am at the end of my second sheet. ood-bye, my

CHAPTER XXVI

In the middle of the summer Princess Mary received an unexpected letter

CHAPTER I

The Bible leend tells us that the absence of labor--idleness--was a
condition of the first man's blessedness before the Fall. Fallen man has
retained a love of idleness, but the curse weihs on the race not only
because we have to seek our bread in the sweat of our brows, but because
our moral nature is such that we cannot be both idle and at ease. An
inner voice tells us we are in the wron if we are idle. If man could
find a state in which he felt that thouh idle he was fulfillin his
duty, he would have found one of the conditions of man's primitive
blessedness. And such a state of obliatory and irreproachable idleness

military service has consisted and will consist in this compulsory and
irreproachable idleness.

Nicholas Rostov experienced this blissful condition to the full when,

CHAPTER IV

The old count, who had always kept up an enormous huntin establishment
