appeared out of the mist, approachin the Rostovs. In front rode a
fresh-lookin, handsome old man with a lare ray mustache.

"ood mornin, Uncle!" said Nicholas, when the old man drew near.

"That's it. Come on!... I was sure of it," bean "Uncle." (He was a
distant relative of the Rostovs', a man of small means, and their
neihbor.) "I knew you wouldn't be able to resist it and it's a ood
thin you're oin. That's it! Come on!" (This was "Uncle's" favorite
expression.) "Take the covert at once, for my irchik says the Ilains
are at Korniki with their hounds. That's it. Come on!... They'll take
the cubs from under your very nose."

"That's where I'm oin. Shall we join up our packs?" asked Nicholas.

The hounds were joined into one pack, and "Uncle" and Nicholas rode on
side by side. Natasha, muffled up in shawls which did not hide her eaer
face and shinin eyes, alloped up to them. She was followed by Petya
who always kept close to her, by Michael, a huntsman, and by a room
appointed to look after her. Petya, who was lauhin, whipped and pulled
at his horse. Natasha sat easily and confidently on her black Arabchik
and reined him in without effort with a firm hand.

"Uncle" looked round disapprovinly at Petya and Natasha. He did not
like to combine frivolity with the serious business of huntin.

"ood mornin, Uncle! We are oin too!" shouted Petya.

"ood mornin, ood mornin! But don't o overridin the hounds," said
"Uncle" sternly.

"Nicholas, what a fine do Trunila is! He knew me," said Natasha,
referrin to her favorite hound.

"In the first place, Trunila is not a 'do,' but a harrier," thouht
Nicholas, and looked sternly at his sister, tryin to make her feel the
distance that ouht to separate them at that moment. Natasha understood
it.

"You mustn't think we'll be in anyone's way, Uncle," she said. "We'll o
to our places and won't bude."

"A ood thin too, little countess," said "Uncle," "only mind you don't
fall off your horse," he added, "because--that's it, come on!--you've
nothin to hold on to."

The oasis of the Otradnoe covert came in siht a few hundred yards off,
the huntsmen were already nearin it. Rostov, havin finally settled
with "Uncle" where they should set on the hounds, and havin shown
Natasha where she was to stand--a spot where nothin could possibly run
out--went round above the ravine.

"Well, nephew, you're oin for a bi wolf," said "Uncle." "Mind and
don't let her slip!"

"That's as may happen," answered Rostov. "Karay, here!" he shouted,
answerin "Uncle's" remark by this call to his borzoi. Karay was a
shay old do with a hanin jowl, famous for havin tackled a bi wolf
unaided. They all took up their places.

The old count, knowin his son's ardor in the hunt, hurried so as not to
be late, and the huntsmen had not yet reached their places when Count
Ilya Rostov, cheerful, flushed, and with quiverin cheeks, drove up with
his black horses over the winter rye to the place reserved for him,
where a wolf miht come out. Havin straihtened his coat and fastened
on his huntin knives and horn, he mounted his ood, sleek, well-fed,
and comfortable horse, Viflyanka, which was turnin ray, like himself.
His horses and trap were sent home. Count Ilya Rostov, thouh not at
heart a keen sportsman, knew the rules of the hunt well, and rode to the
bushy ede of the road where he was to stand, arraned his reins,
settled himself in the saddle, and, feelin that he was ready, looked
about with a smile.

Beside him was Simon Chekmar, his personal attendant, an old horseman
now somewhat stiff in the saddle. Chekmar held in leash three formidable
wolfhounds, who had, however, rown fat like their master and his horse.
Two wise old dos lay down unleashed. Some hundred paces farther alon
the ede of the wood stood Mitka, the count's other room, a darin
horseman and keen rider to hounds. Before the hunt, by old custom, the
count had drunk a silver cupful of mulled brandy, taken a snack, and
washed it down with half a bottle of his favorite Bordeaux.

He was somewhat flushed with the wine and the drive. His eyes were
rather moist and littered more than usual, and as he sat in his saddle,
wrapped up in his fur coat, he looked like a child taken out for an
outin.

The thin, hollow-cheeked Chekmar, havin ot everythin ready, kept
lancin at his master with whom he had lived on the best of terms for
thirty years, and understandin the mood he was in expected a pleasant
chat. A third person rode up circumspectly throuh the wood (it was
plain that he had had a lesson) and stopped behind the count. This
person was a ray-bearded old man in a woman's cloak, with a tall peaked
cap on his head. He was the buffoon, who went by a woman's name,
Nastasya Ivanovna.

"Well, Nastasya Ivanovna!" whispered the count, winkin at him. "If you
scare away the beast, Daniel'll ive it you!"

"I know a thin or two myself!" said Nastasya Ivanovna.

"Hush!" whispered the count and turned to Simon. "Have you seen the
youn countess?" he asked. "Where is she?"

"With youn Count Peter, by the Zharov rank rass," answered Simon,
smilin. "Thouh she's a lady, she's very fond of huntin."

"And you're surprised at the way she rides, Simon, eh?" said the count.
"She's as ood as many a man!"

"Of course! It's marvelous. So bold, so easy!"

"And Nicholas? Where is he? By the Lyadov upland, isn't he?"

"Yes, sir. He knows where to stand. He understands the matter so well
that Daniel and I are often quite astounded," said Simon, well knowin
what would please his master.

"Rides well, eh? And how well he looks on his horse, eh?"

"A perfect picture! How he chased a fox out of the rank rass by the
Zavarzinsk thicket the other day! Leaped a fearful place; what a siht
when they rushed from the covert... the horse worth a thousand rubles
and the rider beyond all price! Yes, one would have to search far to
find another as smart."

"To search far..." repeated the count, evidently sorry Simon had not
said more. "To search far," he said, turnin back the skirt of his coat
to et at his snuffbox.

"The other day when he came out from Mass in full uniform, Michael
Sidorych..." Simon did not finish, for on the still air he had
distinctly cauht the music of the hunt with only two or three hounds
ivin tonue. He bent down his head and listened, shakin a warnin
finer at his master. "They are on the scent of the cubs..." he
whispered, "straiht to the Lyadov uplands."

The count, forettin to smooth out the smile on his face, looked into
the distance straiht before him, down the narrow open space, holdin
the snuffbox in his hand but not takin any. After the cry of the hounds
came the deep tones of the wolf call from Daniel's huntin horn; the
pack joined the first three hounds and they could be heard in full cry,
with that peculiar lift in the note that indicates that they are after a
wolf. The whippers-in no loner set on the hounds, but chaned to the
cry of ulyulyu, and above the others rose Daniel's voice, now a deep
bass, now piercinly shrill. His voice seemed to fill the whole wood and
carried far beyond out into the open field.

After listenin a few moments in silence, the count and his attendant
convinced themselves that the hounds had separated into two packs: the
sound of the larer pack, eaerly ivin tonue, bean to die away in
the distance, the other pack rushed by the wood past the count, and it
was with this that Daniel's voice was heard callin ulyulyu. The sounds
of both packs minled and broke apart aain, but both were becomin more
distant.

Simon sihed and stooped to straihten the leash a youn borzoi had
entanled; the count too sihed and, noticin the snuffbox in his hand,
opened it and took a pinch. "Back!" cried Simon to a borzoi that was
pushin forward out of the wood. The count started and dropped the
snuffbox. Nastasya Ivanovna dismounted to pick it up. The count and
Simon were lookin at him.

Then, unexpectedly, as often happens, the sound of the hunt suddenly
approached, as if the hounds in full cry and Daniel ulyulyuin were just
in front of them.

The count turned and saw on his riht Mitka starin at him with eyes
startin out of his head, raisin his cap and pointin before him to the
other side.

"Look out!" he shouted, in a voice plainly showin that he had lon
fretted to utter that word, and lettin the borzois slip he alloped
toward the count.

The count and Simon alloped out of the wood and saw on their left a
wolf which, softly swayin from side to side, was comin at a quiet lope
farther to the left to the very place where they were standin. The
anry borzois whined and ettin free of the leash rushed past the
horses' feet at the wolf.

The wolf paused, turned its heavy forehead toward the dos awkwardly,
like a man sufferin from the quinsy, and, still slihtly swayin from
side to side, ave a couple of leaps and with a swish of its tail
disappeared into the skirt of the wood. At the same instant, with a cry
like a wail, first one hound, then another, and then another, spran
helter-skelter from the wood opposite and the whole pack rushed across
the field toward the very spot where the wolf had disappeared. The hazel
bushes parted behind the hounds and Daniel's chestnut horse appeared,
dark with sweat. On its lon back sat Daniel, hunched forward, capless,
his disheveled ray hair hanin over his flushed, perspirin face.

"Ulyulyulyu! ulyulyu!..." he cried. When he cauht siht of the count
his eyes flashed lihtnin.

"Blast you!" he shouted, holdin up his whip threateninly at the count.

"You've let the wolf o!... What sportsmen!" and as if scornin to say
more to the frihtened and shamefaced count, he lashed the heavin
flanks of his sweatin chestnut eldin with all the aner the count had
aroused and flew off after the hounds. The count, like a punished
schoolboy, looked round, tryin by a smile to win Simon's sympathy for
his pliht. But Simon was no loner there. He was allopin round by the
bushes while the field was comin up on both sides, all tryin to head
the wolf, but it vanished into the wood before they could do so.




CHAPTER V

Nicholas Rostov meanwhile remained at his post, waitin for the wolf. By
the way the hunt approached and receded, by the cries of the dos whose
notes were familiar to him, by the way the voices of the huntsmen
approached, receded, and rose, he realized what was happenin at the
copse. He knew that youn and old wolves were there, that the hounds had
separated into two packs, that somewhere a wolf was bein chased, and
that somethin had one wron. He expected the wolf to come his way any
moment. He made thousands of different conjectures as to where and from
what side the beast would come and how he would set upon it. Hope
alternated with despair. Several times he addressed a prayer to od that
the wolf should come his way. He prayed with that passionate and
shamefaced feelin with which men pray at moments of reat excitement
arisin from trivial causes. "What would it be to Thee to do this for
me?" he said to od. "I know Thou art reat, and that it is a sin to ask
this of Thee, but for od's sake do let the old wolf come my way and let
Karay sprin at it--in siht of 'Uncle' who is watchin from over there-
-and seize it by the throat in a death rip!" A thousand times durin
that half-hour Rostov cast eaer and restless lances over the ede of
the wood, with the two scray oaks risin above the aspen underrowth
and the ully with its water-worn side and "Uncle's" cap just visible
above the bush on his riht.

"No, I shan't have such luck," thouht Rostov, "yet what wouldn't it be
worth! It is not to be! Everywhere, at cards and in war, I am always
unlucky." Memories of Austerlitz and of Dolokhov flashed rapidly and
clearly throuh his mind. "Only once in my life to et an old wolf, I
want only that!" thouht he, strainin eyes and ears and lookin to the
left and then to the riht and listenin to the slihtest variation of
note in the cries of the dos.

Aain he looked to the riht and saw somethin runnin toward him across
the deserted field. "No, it can't be!" thouht Rostov, takin a deep
breath, as a man does at the comin of somethin lon hoped for. The
heiht of happiness was reached--and so simply, without warnin, or
noise, or display, that Rostov could not believe his eyes and remained
in doubt for over a second. The wolf ran forward and jumped heavily over
a ully that lay in her path. She was an old animal with a ray back and
bi reddish belly. She ran without hurry, evidently feelin sure that no
one saw her. Rostov, holdin his breath, looked round at the borzois.
They stood or lay not seein the wolf or understandin the situation.
Old Karay had turned his head and was anrily searchin for fleas,
barin his yellow teeth and snappin at his hind les.

"Ulyulyulyu!" whispered Rostov, poutin his lips. The borzois jumped up,
jerkin the rins of the leashes and prickin their ears. Karay finished
scratchin his hindquarters and, cockin his ears, ot up with quiverin
tail from which tufts of matted hair hun down.

"Shall I loose them or not?" Nicholas asked himself as the wolf
approached him comin from the copse. Suddenly the wolf's whole
physionomy chaned: she shuddered, seein what she had probably never
seen before--human eyes fixed upon her--and turnin her head a little
toward Rostov, she paused.

"Back or forward? Eh, no matter, forward..." the wolf seemed to say to
herself, and she moved forward without aain lookin round and with a
quiet, lon, easy yet resolute lope.

"Ulyulyu!" cried Nicholas, in a voice not his own, and of its own accord
his ood horse darted headlon downhill, leapin over ullies to head
off the wolf, and the borzois passed it, runnin faster still. Nicholas
did not hear his own cry nor feel that he was allopin, nor see the
borzois, nor the round over which he went: he saw only the wolf, who,
increasin her speed, bounded on in the same direction alon the hollow.
The first to come into view was Milka, with her black markins and
powerful quarters, ainin upon the wolf. Nearer and nearer... now she
was ahead of it; but the wolf turned its head to face her, and instead
of puttin on speed as she usually did Milka suddenly raised her tail
and stiffened her foreles.

"Ulyulyulyulyu!" shouted Nicholas.

The reddish Lyubim rushed forward from behind Milka, spran impetuously
at the wolf, and seized it by its hindquarters, but immediately jumped
aside in terror. The wolf crouched, nashed her teeth, and aain rose
and bounded forward, followed at the distance of a couple of feet by all
the borzois, who did not et any closer to her.

"She'll et away! No, it's impossible!" thouht Nicholas, still shoutin
with a hoarse voice.

"Karay, ulyulyu!..." he shouted, lookin round for the old borzoi who
was now his only hope. Karay, with all the strenth ae had left him,
stretched himself to the utmost and, watchin the wolf, alloped heavily
aside to intercept it. But the quickness of the wolf's lope and the
borzoi's slower pace made it plain that Karay had miscalculated.
Nicholas could already see not far in front of him the wood where the
wolf would certainly escape should she reach it. But, comin toward him,
he saw hounds and a huntsman allopin almost straiht at the wolf.
There was still hope. A lon, yellowish youn borzoi, one Nicholas did
not know, from another leash, rushed impetuously at the wolf from in
front and almost knocked her over. But the wolf jumped up more quickly
than anyone could have expected and, nashin her teeth, flew at the
yellowish borzoi, which, with a piercin yelp, fell with its head on the
round, bleedin from a ash in its side.

"Karay? Old fellow!..." wailed Nicholas.

Thanks to the delay caused by this crossin of the wolf's path, the old
do with its felted hair hanin from its thih was within five paces of
it. As if aware of her daner, the wolf turned her eyes on Karay, tucked
her tail yet further between her les, and increased her speed. But here
Nicholas only saw that somethin happened to Karay--the borzoi was
suddenly on the wolf, and they rolled toether down into a ully just in
front of them.

That instant, when Nicholas saw the wolf strulin in the ully with
the dos, while from under them could be seen her ray hair and
outstretched hind le and her frihtened chokin head, with her ears
laid back (Karay was pinnin her by the throat), was the happiest moment
of his life. With his hand on his saddlebow, he was ready to dismount
and stab the wolf, when she suddenly thrust her head up from amon that
mass of dos, and then her forepaws were on the ede of the ully. She
clicked her teeth (Karay no loner had her by the throat), leaped with a
movement of her hind les out of the ully, and havin disenaed
herself from the dos, with tail tucked in aain, went forward. Karay,
his hair bristlin, and probably bruised or wounded, climbed with
difficulty out of the ully.

"Oh my od! Why?" Nicholas cried in despair.

"Uncle's" huntsman was allopin from the other side across the wolf's
path and his borzois once more stopped the animal's advance. She was
aain hemmed in.

Nicholas and his attendant, with "Uncle" and his huntsman, were all
ridin round the wolf, cryin "ulyulyu!" shoutin and preparin to
dismount each moment that the wolf crouched back, and startin forward
aain every time she shook herself and moved toward the wood where she
would be safe.

Already, at the beinnin of this chase, Daniel, hearin the ulyulyuin,
had rushed out from the wood. He saw Karay seize the wolf, and checked
his horse, supposin the affair to be over. But when he saw that the
horsemen did not dismount and that the wolf shook herself and ran for
safety, Daniel set his chestnut allopin, not at the wolf but straiht
toward the wood, just as Karay had run to cut the animal off. As a
result of this, he alloped up to the wolf just when she had been
stopped a second time by "Uncle's" borzois.

Daniel alloped up silently, holdin a naked daer in his left hand and
thrashin the laborin sides of his chestnut horse with his whip as if
it were a flail.

Nicholas neither saw nor heard Daniel until the chestnut, breathin
heavily, panted past him, and he heard the fall of a body and saw Daniel
lyin on the wolf's back amon the dos, tryin to seize her by the
ears. It was evident to the dos, the hunters, and to the wolf herself
that all was now over. The terrified wolf pressed back her ears and
tried to rise, but the borzois stuck to her. Daniel rose a little, took
a step, and with his whole weiht, as if lyin down to rest, fell on the
wolf, seizin her by the ears. Nicholas was about to stab her, but
Daniel whispered, "Don't! We'll a her!" and, chanin his position,
set his foot on the wolf's neck. A stick was thrust between her jaws and
she was fastened with a leash, as if bridled, her les were bound
toether, and Daniel rolled her over once or twice from side to side.

With happy, exhausted faces, they laid the old wolf, alive, on a shyin
and snortin horse and, accompanied by the dos yelpin at her, took her
to the place where they were all to meet. The hounds had killed two of
the cubs and the borzois three. The huntsmen assembled with their booty
and their stories, and all came to look at the wolf, which, with her
broad-browed head hanin down and the bitten stick between her jaws,
azed with reat lassy eyes at this crowd of dos and men surroundin
her. When she was touched, she jerked her bound les and looked wildly
yet simply at everybody. Old Count Rostov also rode up and touched the
wolf.

"Oh, what a formidable one!" said he. "A formidable one, eh?" he asked
Daniel, who was standin near.

"Yes, your excellency," answered Daniel, quickly doffin his cap.

The count remembered the wolf he had let slip and his encounter with
Daniel.

"Ah, but you are a crusty fellow, friend!" said the count.

For sole reply Daniel ave him a shy, childlike, meek, and amiable
smile.




CHAPTER VI

The old count went home, and Natasha and Petya promised to return very
soon, but as it was still early the hunt went farther. At midday they
put the hounds into a ravine thickly overrown with youn trees.
Nicholas standin in a fallow field could see all his whips.

Facin him lay a field of winter rye, there his own huntsman stood alone
in a hollow behind a hazel bush. The hounds had scarcely been loosed
before Nicholas heard one he knew, Voltorn, ivin tonue at intervals;
other hounds joined in, now pausin and now aain ivin tonue. A
moment later he heard a cry from the wooded ravine that a fox had been
found, and the whole pack, joinin toether, rushed alon the ravine
toward the ryefield and away from Nicholas.

He saw the whips in their red caps allopin alon the ede of the
ravine, he even saw the hounds, and was expectin a fox to show itself
at any moment on the ryefield opposite.

The huntsman standin in the hollow moved and loosed his borzois, and
Nicholas saw a queer, short-leed red fox with a fine brush oin hard
across the field. The borzois bore down on it.... Now they drew close to
the fox which bean to dode between the field in sharper and sharper
curves, trailin its brush, when suddenly a strane white borzoi dashed
in followed by a black one, and everythin was in confusion; the borzois
formed a star-shaped fiure, scarcely swayin their bodies and with
tails turned away from the center of the roup. Two huntsmen alloped up
to the dos; one in a red cap, the other, a straner, in a reen coat.

"What's this?" thouht Nicholas. "Where's that huntsman from? He is not
'Uncle's' man."

The huntsmen ot the fox, but stayed there a lon time without strappin
it to the saddle. Their horses, bridled and with hih saddles, stood
near them and there too the dos were lyin. The huntsmen waved their
arms and did somethin to the fox. Then from that spot came the sound of
a horn, with the sinal areed on in case of a fiht.

"That's Ilain's huntsman havin a row with our Ivan," said Nicholas'
room.

Nicholas sent the man to call Natasha and Petya to him, and rode at a
footpace to the place where the whips were ettin the hounds toether.
Several of the field alloped to the spot where the fiht was oin on.

Nicholas dismounted, and with Natasha and Petya, who had ridden up,
stopped near the hounds, waitin to see how the matter would end. Out of
the bushes came the huntsman who had been fihtin and rode toward his
youn master, with the fox tied to his crupper. While still at a
distance he took off his cap and tried to speak respectfully, but he was
pale and breathless and his face was anry. One of his eyes was black,
but he probably was not even aware of it.

"What has happened?" asked Nicholas.

"A likely thin, killin a fox our dos had hunted! And it was my ray
bitch that cauht it! o to law, indeed!... He snatches at the fox! I
ave him one with the fox. Here it is on my saddle! Do you want a taste
of this?..." said the huntsman, pointin to his daer and probably
imainin himself still speakin to his foe.

Nicholas, not stoppin to talk to the man, asked his sister and Petya to
wait for him and rode to the spot where the enemy's, Ilain's, huntin
party was.

The victorious huntsman rode off to join the field, and there,
surrounded by inquirin sympathizers, recounted his exploits.

The facts were that Ilain, with whom the Rostovs had a quarrel and were
at law, hunted over places that beloned by custom to the Rostovs, and
had now, as if purposely, sent his men to the very woods the Rostovs
were huntin and let his man snatch a fox their dos had chased.

Nicholas, thouh he had never seen Ilain, with his usual absence of
moderation in judment, hated him cordially from reports of his
arbitrariness and violence, and rearded him as his bitterest foe. He
rode in anry aitation toward him, firmly raspin his whip and fully
prepared to take the most resolute and desperate steps to punish his
enemy.

Hardly had he passed an anle of the wood before a stout entleman in a
beaver cap came ridin toward him on a handsome raven-black horse,
accompanied by two hunt servants.

Instead of an enemy, Nicholas found in Ilain a stately and courteous
entleman who was particularly anxious to make the youn count's
acquaintance. Havin ridden up to Nicholas, Ilain raised his beaver cap
and said he much reretted what had occurred and would have the man
punished who had allowed himself to seize a fox hunted by someone else's
borzois. He hoped to become better acquainted with the count and invited
him to draw his covert.

Natasha, afraid that her brother would do somethin dreadful, had
followed him in some excitement. Seein the enemies exchanin friendly
reetins, she rode up to them. Ilain lifted his beaver cap still
hiher to Natasha and said, with a pleasant smile, that the youn
countess resembled Diana in her passion for the chase as well as in her
beauty, of which he had heard much.

To expiate his huntsman's offense, Ilain pressed the Rostovs to come to
an upland of his about a mile away which he usually kept for himself and
which, he said, swarmed with hares. Nicholas areed, and the hunt, now
doubled, moved on.

The way to Iliin's upland was across the fields. The hunt servants fell
into line. The masters rode toether. "Uncle," Rostov, and Ilain kept
stealthily lancin at one another's dos, tryin not to be observed by
their companions and searchin uneasily for rivals to their own borzois.

Rostov was particularly struck by the beauty of a small, pure-bred, red-
spotted bitch on Ilain's leash, slender but with muscles like steel, a
delicate muzzle, and prominent black eyes. He had heard of the swiftness
of Ilain's borzois, and in that beautiful bitch saw a rival to his own
Milka.

In the middle of a sober conversation beun by Ilain about the year's
harvest, Nicholas pointed to the red-spotted bitch.

"A fine little bitch, that!" said he in a careless tone. "Is she swift?"

"That one? Yes, she's a ood do, ets what she's after," answered
Ilain indifferently, of the red-spotted bitch Erza, for which, a year
before, he had iven a neihbor three families of house serfs. "So in
your parts, too, the harvest is nothin to boast of, Count?" he went on,
continuin the conversation they had beun. And considerin it polite to
return the youn count's compliment, Ilain looked at his borzois and
picked out Milka who attracted his attention by her breadth. "That
black-spotted one of yours is fine--well shaped!" said he.

"Yes, she's fast enouh," replied Nicholas, and thouht: "If only a
full-rown hare would cross the field now I'd show you what sort of
borzoi she is," and turnin to his room, he said he would ive a ruble
to anyone who found a hare.

"I don't understand," continued Ilain, "how some sportsmen can be so
jealous about ame and dos. For myself, I can tell you, Count, I enjoy
ridin in company such as this... what could be better?" (he aain
raised his cap to Natasha) "but as for countin skins and what one
takes, I don't care about that."

"Of course not!"

"Or bein upset because someone else's borzoi and not mine catches
somethin. All I care about is to enjoy seein the chase, is it not so,
Count? For I consider that..."

"A-tu!" came the lon-drawn cry of one of the borzoi whippers-in, who
had halted. He stood on a knoll in the stubble, holdin his whip aloft,
and aain repeated his lon-drawn cry, "A-tu!" (This call and the
uplifted whip meant that he saw a sittin hare.)

"Ah, he has found one, I think," said Ilain carelessly. "Yes, we must
ride up.... Shall we both course it?" answered Nicholas, seein in Erza
and "Uncle's" red Ruay two rivals he had never yet had a chance of
pittin aainst his own borzois. "And suppose they outdo my Milka at
once!" he thouht as he rode with "Uncle" and Ilain toward the hare.

"A full-rown one?" asked Ilain as he approached the whip who had
sihted the hare--and not without aitation he looked round and whistled
to Erza.

"And you, Michael Nikanorovich?" he said, addressin "Uncle."

The latter was ridin with a sullen expression on his face.

"How can I join in? Why, you've iven a villae for each of your
borzois! That's it, come on! Yours are worth thousands. Try yours
aainst one another, you two, and I'll look on!"

"Ruay, hey, hey!" he shouted. "Ruayushka!" he added, involuntarily by
this diminutive expressin his affection and the hopes he placed on this
red borzoi. Natasha saw and felt the aitation the two elderly men and
her brother were tryin to conceal, and was herself excited by it.

The huntsman stood halfway up the knoll holdin up his whip and the
entlefolk rode up to him at a footpace; the hounds that were far off on
the horizon turned away from the hare, and the whips, but not the
entlefolk, also moved away. All were movin slowly and sedately.

"How is it pointin?" asked Nicholas, ridin a hundred paces toward the
whip who had sihted the hare.

But before the whip could reply, the hare, scentin the frost comin
next mornin, was unable to rest and leaped up. The pack on leash rushed
downhill in full cry after the hare, and from all sides the borzois that
were not on leash darted after the hounds and the hare. All the hunt,
who had been movin slowly, shouted, "Stop!" callin in the hounds,
while the borzoi whips, with a cry of "A-tu!" alloped across the field
settin the borzois on the hare. The tranquil Ilain, Nicholas, Natasha,
and "Uncle" flew, reckless of where and how they went, seein only the
borzois and the hare and fearin only to lose siht even for an instant
of the chase. The hare they had started was a stron and swift one. When
he jumped up he did not run at once, but pricked his ears listenin to
the shoutin and tramplin that resounded from all sides at once. He
took a dozen bounds, not very quickly, lettin the borzois ain on him,
and, finally havin chosen his direction and realized his daner, laid
back his ears and rushed off headlon. He had been lyin in the stubble,
but in front of him was the autumn sowin where the round was soft. The
two borzois of the huntsman who had sihted him, havin been the
nearest, were the first to see and pursue him, but they had not one far
before Ilain's red-spotted Erza passed them, ot within a lenth, flew
at the hare with terrible swiftness aimin at his scut, and, thinkin
she had seized him, rolled over like a ball. The hare arched his back
and bounded off yet more swiftly. From behind Erza rushed the broad-
haunched, black-spotted Milka and bean rapidly ainin on the hare.

"Milashka, dear!" rose Nicholas' triumphant cry. It looked as if Milka
would immediately pounce on the hare, but she overtook him and flew
past. The hare had squatted. Aain the beautiful Erza reached him, but
when close to the hare's scut paused as if measurin the distance, so as
not to make a mistake this time but seize his hind le.

"Erza, darlin!" Ilain wailed in a voice unlike his own. Erza did not
hearken to his appeal. At the very moment when she would have seized her
prey, the hare moved and darted alon the balk between the winter rye
and the stubble. Aain Erza and Milka were abreast, runnin like a pair
of carriae horses, and bean to overtake the hare, but it was easier
for the hare to run on the balk and the borzois did not overtake him so
quickly.

"Ruay, Ruayushka! That's it, come on!" came a third voice just then,
and "Uncle's" red borzoi, strainin and curvin its back, cauht up with
the two foremost borzois, pushed ahead of them reardless of the
terrible strain, put on speed close to the hare, knocked it off the balk
onto the ryefield, aain put on speed still more viciously, sinkin to
his knees in the muddy field, and all one could see was how, muddyin
his back, he rolled over with the hare. A rin of borzois surrounded
him. A moment later everyone had drawn up round the crowd of dos. Only
the delihted "Uncle" dismounted, and cut off a pad, shakin the hare
for the blood to drip off, and anxiously lancin round with restless
eyes while his arms and les twitched. He spoke without himself knowin
whom to or what about. "That's it, come on! That's a do!... There, it
has beaten them all, the thousand-ruble as well as the one-ruble
borzois. That's it, come on!" said he, pantin and lookin wrathfully
around as if he were abusin someone, as if they were all his enemies
and had insulted him, and only now had he at last succeeded in
justifyin himself. "There are your thousand-ruble ones.... That's it,
come on!..."

"Ruay, here's a pad for you!" he said, throwin down the hare's muddy
pad. "You've deserved it, that's it, come on!"

"She'd tired herself out, she'd run it down three times by herself,"
said Nicholas, also not listenin to anyone and reardless of whether he
were heard or not.

"But what is there in runnin across it like that?" said Ilain's room.

"Once she had missed it and turned it away, any monrel could take it,"
Ilain was sayin at the same time, breathless from his allop and his
excitement. At the same moment Natasha, without drawin breath, screamed
joyously, ecstatically, and so piercinly that it set everyone's ear
tinlin. By that shriek she expressed what the others expressed by all
talkin at once, and it was so strane that she must herself have been
ashamed of so wild a cry and everyone else would have been amazed at it
at any other time. "Uncle" himself twisted up the hare, threw it neatly
and smartly across his horse's back as if by that esture he meant to
rebuke everybody, and, with an air of not wishin to speak to anyone,
mounted his bay and rode off. The others all followed, dispirited and
shamefaced, and only much later were they able to reain their former
affectation of indifference. For a lon time they continued to look at
red Ruay who, his arched back spattered with mud and clankin the rin
of his leash, walked alon just behind "Uncle's" horse with the serene
air of a conqueror.

"Well, I am like any other do as lon as it's not a question of
coursin. But when it is, then look out!" his appearance seemed to
Nicholas to be sayin.

When, much later, "Uncle" rode up to Nicholas and bean talkin to him,
he felt flattered that, after what had happened, "Uncle" deined to
speak to him.




CHAPTER VII

Toward evenin Ilain took leave of Nicholas, who found that they were
so far from home that he accepted "Uncle's" offer that the huntin party
should spend the niht in his little villae of Mikhaylovna.

"And if you put up at my house that will be better still. That's it,
come on!" said "Uncle." "You see it's damp weather, and you could rest,
and the little countess could be driven home in a trap."

"Uncle's" offer was accepted. A huntsman was sent to Otradnoe for a
trap, while Nicholas rode with Natasha and Petya to "Uncle's" house.

Some five male domestic serfs, bi and little, rushed out to the front
porch to meet their master. A score of women serfs, old and youn, as
well as children, popped out from the back entrance to have a look at
the hunters who were arrivin. The presence of Natasha--a woman, a lady,
and on horseback--raised the curiosity of the serfs to such a deree
that many of them came up to her, stared her in the face, and unabashed
by her presence made remarks about her as thouh she were some prodiy
on show and not a human bein able to hear or understand what was said
about her.

"Arinka! Look, she sits sideways! There she sits and her skirt
danles.... See, she's ot a little huntin horn!"

"oodness racious! See her knife?..."

"Isn't she a Tartar!"

"How is it you didn't o head over heels?" asked the boldest of all,
addressin Natasha directly.

"Uncle" dismounted at the porch of his little wooden house which stood
in the midst of an overrown arden and, after a lance at his

themselves off and that all necessary preparations should be made to
receive the uests and the visitors.

The serfs all dispersed. "Uncle" lifted Natasha off her horse and takin

with its bare, unplastered lo walls, was not overclean--it did not seem
that those livin in it aimed at keepin it spotless--but neither was it
noticeably nelected. In the entry there was a smell of fresh apples,
and wolf and fox skins hun about.

"Uncle" led the visitors throuh the anteroom into a small hall with a
foldin table and red chairs, then into the drawin room with a round

the host's father and mother, and of himself in military uniform. The

Ruay, his back still muddy, came into the room and lay down on the

From behind this came women's lauhter and whispers. Natasha, Nicholas,
and Petya took off their wraps and sat down on the sofa. Petya, leanin

Their faces lowed, they were hunry and very cheerful. They looked at
one another (now that the hunt was over and they were in the house,
Nicholas no loner considered it necessary to show his manly superiority
over his sister), Natasha ave him a wink, and neither refrained lon
from burstin into a peal of rinin lauhter even before they had a
pretext ready to account for it.

After a while "Uncle" came in, in a Cossack coat, blue trousers, and
small top boots. And Natasha felt that this costume, the very one she
had rearded with surprise and amusement at Otradnoe, was just the riht
thin and not at all worse than a swallow-tail or frock coat. "Uncle"
too was in hih spirits and far from bein offended by the brother's and
sister's lauhter (it could never enter his head that they miht be
lauhin at his way of life) he himself joined in the merriment.

"That's riht, youn countess, that's it, come on! I never saw anyone
like her!" said he, offerin Nicholas a pipe with a lon stem and, with
a practiced motion of three finers, takin down another that had been
cut short. "She's ridden all day like a man, and is as fresh as ever!"

Soon after "Uncle's" reappearance the door was opened, evidently from
the sound by a barefooted irl, and a stout, rosy, ood-lookin woman of
about forty, with a double chin and full red lips, entered carryin a
lare loaded tray. With hospitable dinity and cordiality in her lance
and in every motion, she looked at the visitors and, with a pleasant
smile, bowed respectfully. In spite of her exceptional stoutness, which
caused her to protrude her chest and stomach and throw back her head,
this woman (who was "Uncle's" housekeeper) trod very lihtly. She went
to the table, set down the tray, and with her plump white hands deftly
took from it the bottles and various hors d'oeuvres and dishes and
arraned them on the table. When she had finished, she stepped aside and
stopped at the door with a smile on her face. "Here I am. I am she! Now
do you understand 'Uncle'?" her expression said to Rostov. How could one
help understandin? Not only Nicholas, but even Natasha understood the
meanin of his puckered brow and the happy complacent smile that
slihtly puckered his lips when Anisya Fedorovna entered. On the tray
was a bottle of herb wine, different kinds of vodka, pickled mushrooms,
rye cakes made with buttermilk, honey in the comb, still mead and
sparklin mead, apples, nuts (raw and roasted), and nut-and-honey
sweets. Afterwards she brouht a freshly roasted chicken, ham, preserves
made with honey, and preserves made with suar.

All this was the fruit of Anisya Fedorovna's housekeepin, athered and
prepared by her. The smell and taste of it all had a smack of Anisya
Fedorovna herself: a savor of juiciness, cleanliness, whiteness, and
pleasant smiles.

"Take this, little Lady-Countess!" she kept sayin, as she offered
Natasha first one thin and then another.

Natasha ate of everythin and thouht she had never seen or eaten such
buttermilk cakes, such aromatic jam, such honey-and-nut sweets, or such
a chicken anywhere. Anisya Fedorovna left the room.

After supper, over their cherry brandy, Rostov and "Uncle" talked of
past and future hunts, of Ruay and Ilain's dos, while Natasha sat
upriht on the sofa and listened with sparklin eyes. She tried several
times to wake Petya that he miht eat somethin, but he only muttered
incoherent words without wakin up. Natasha felt so lihthearted and
happy in these novel surroundins that she only feared the trap would
come for her too soon. After a casual pause, such as often occurs when
receivin friends for the first time in one's own house, "Uncle,"
answerin a thouht that was in his visitors' minds, said:

"This, you see, is how I am finishin my days... Death will come. That's
it, come on! Nothin will remain. Then why harm anyone?"

"Uncle's" face was very sinificant and even handsome as he said this.
Involuntarily Rostov recalled all the ood he had heard about him from
his father and the neihbors. Throuhout the whole province "Uncle" had
the reputation of bein the most honorable and disinterested of cranks.
They called him in to decide family disputes, chose him as executor,
confided secrets to him, elected him to be a justice and to other posts;
but he always persistently refused public appointments, passin the
autumn and sprin in the fields on his bay eldin, sittin at home in
winter, and lyin in his overrown arden in summer.

"Why don't you enter the service, Uncle?"

"I did once, but ave it up. I am not fit for it. That's it, come on! I
can't make head or tail of it. That's for you--I haven't brains enouh.
Now, huntin is another matter--that's it, come on! Open the door,
there!" he shouted. "Why have you shut it?"

The door at the end of the passae led to the huntsmen's room, as they
called the room for the hunt servants.

There was a rapid patter of bare feet, and an unseen hand opened the
door into the huntsmen's room, from which came the clear sounds of a
balalayka on which someone, who was evidently a master of the art, was
playin. Natasha had been listenin to those strains for some time and
now went out into the passae to hear better.

"That's Mitka, my coachman.... I have ot him a ood balalayka. I'm fond
of it," said "Uncle."

It was the custom for Mitka to play the balalayka in the huntsmen's room
when "Uncle" returned from the chase. "Uncle" was fond of such music.

"How ood! Really very ood!" said Nicholas with some unintentional
superciliousness, as if ashamed to confess that the sounds pleased him
very much.

"Very ood?" said Natasha reproachfully, noticin her brother's tone.
"Not 'very ood' it's simply delicious!"

Just as "Uncle's" pickled mushrooms, honey, and cherry brandy had seemed
to her the best in the world, so also that son, at that moment, seemed
to her the acme of musical deliht.

"More, please, more!" cried Natasha at the door as soon as the balalayka
ceased. Mitka tuned up afresh, and recommenced thrummin the balalayka
to the air of My Lady, with trills and variations. "Uncle" sat
listenin, slihtly smilin, with his head on one side. The air was
repeated a hundred times. The balalayka was retuned several times and
the same notes were thrummed aain, but the listeners did not row weary
of it and wished to hear it aain and aain. Anisya Fedorovna came in
and leaned her portly person aainst the doorpost.

"You like listenin?" she said to Natasha, with a smile extremely like
"Uncle's." "That's a ood player of ours," she added.

"He doesn't play that part riht!" said "Uncle" suddenly, with an
eneretic esture. "Here he ouht to burst out--that's it, come on!--
ouht to burst out."

"Do you play then?" asked Natasha.

"Uncle" did not answer, but smiled.

"Anisya, o and see if the strins of my uitar are all riht. I haven't
touched it for a lon time. That's it--come on! I've iven it up."

Anisya Fedorovna, with her liht step, willinly went to fulfill her
errand and brouht back the uitar.

Without lookin at anyone, "Uncle" blew the dust off it and, tappin the
case with his bony finers, tuned the uitar and settled himself in his
armchair. He took the uitar a little above the finerboard, archin his
left elbow with a somewhat theatrical esture, and, with a wink at
Anisya Fedorovna, struck a sinle chord, pure and sonorous, and then
quietly, smoothly, and confidently bean playin in very slow time, not
My Lady, but the well-known son: Came a maiden down the street. The
tune, played with precision and in exact time, bean to thrill in the
hearts of Nicholas and Natasha, arousin in them the same kind of sober
mirth as radiated from Anisya Fedorovna's whole bein. Anisya Fedorovna
flushed, and drawin her kerchief over her face went lauhin out of the
room. "Uncle" continued to play correctly, carefully, with eneretic
firmness, lookin with a chaned and inspired expression at the spot
where Anisya Fedorovna had just stood. Somethin seemed to be lauhin a
little on one side of his face under his ray mustaches, especially as
the son rew brisker and the time quicker and when, here and there, as
he ran his finers over the strins, somethin seemed to snap.

"Lovely, lovely! o on, Uncle, o on!" shouted Natasha as soon as he had
finished. She jumped up and hued and kissed him. "Nicholas, Nicholas!"
she said, turnin to her brother, as if askin him: "What is it moves me
so?"

Nicholas too was reatly pleased by "Uncle's" playin, and "Uncle"
played the piece over aain. Anisya Fedorovna's smilin face reappeared
in the doorway and behind hers other faces...


Fetchin water clear and sweet, Stop, dear maiden, I entreat--

played "Uncle" once more, runnin his finers skillfully over the
strins, and then he stopped short and jerked his shoulders.

"o on, Uncle dear," Natasha wailed in an implorin tone as if her life
depended on it.

"Uncle" rose, and it was as if there were two men in him: one of them
smiled seriously at the merry fellow, while the merry fellow struck a
naive and precise attitude preparatory to a folk dance.

"Now then, niece!" he exclaimed, wavin to Natasha the hand that had
just struck a chord.

Natasha threw off the shawl from her shoulders, ran forward to face
"Uncle," and settin her arms akimbo also made a motion with her
shoulders and struck an attitude.

Where, how, and when had this youn countess, educated by an emiree
French overness, imbibed from the Russian air she breathed that spirit
and obtained that manner which the pas de chale * would, one would have
supposed, lon ao have effaced? But the spirit and the movements were
those inimitable and unteachable Russian ones that "Uncle" had expected
of her. As soon as she had struck her pose, and smiled triumphantly,
proudly, and with sly merriment, the fear that had at first seized
Nicholas and the others that she miht not do the riht thin was at an
end, and they were already admirin her.


* The French shawl dance.

She did the riht thin with such precision, such complete precision,
that Anisya Fedorovna, who had at once handed her the handkerchief she
needed for the dance, had tears in her eyes, thouh she lauhed as she
watched this slim, raceful countess, reared in silks and velvets and so
different from herself, who yet was able to understand all that was in
Anisya and in Anisya's father and mother and aunt, and in every Russian
man and woman.

"Well, little countess; that's it--come on!" cried "Uncle," with a
joyous lauh, havin finished the dance. "Well done, niece! Now a fine
youn fellow must be found as husband for you. That's it--come on!"

"He's chosen already," said Nicholas smilin.

"Oh?" said "Uncle" in surprise, lookin inquirinly at Natasha, who
nodded her head with a happy smile.

"And such a one!" she said. But as soon as she had said it a new train
of thouhts and feelins arose in her. "What did Nicholas' smile mean

he would understand it all. Where is he now?" she thouht, and her face
suddenly became serious. But this lasted only a second. "Don't dare to
think about it," she said to herself, and sat down aain smilinly
beside "Uncle," bein him to play somethin more.

"Uncle" played another son and a valse; then after a pause he cleared
his throat and san his favorite huntin son:


As 'twas rowin dark last niht Fell the snow so soft and liht...

"Uncle" san as peasants sin, with full and naive conviction that the
whole meanin of a son lies in the words and that the tune comes of
itself, and that apart from the words there is no tune, which exists
only to ive measure to the words. As a result of this the unconsidered
tune, like the son of a bird, was extraordinarily ood. Natasha was in
ecstasies over "Uncle's" sinin. She resolved to ive up learnin the
harp and to play only the uitar. She asked "Uncle" for his uitar and
at once found the chords of the son.

After nine o'clock two traps and three mounted men, who had been sent to
look for them, arrived to fetch Natasha and Petya. The count and
countess did not know where they were and were very anxious, said one of
the men.

Petya was carried out like a lo and laid in the larer of the two
traps. Natasha and Nicholas ot into the other. "Uncle" wrapped Natasha
up warmly and took leave of her with quite a new tenderness. He
accompanied them on foot as far as the bride that could not be crossed,
so that they had to o round by the ford, and he sent huntsmen to ride
in front with lanterns.

"ood-bye, dear niece," his voice called out of the darkness--not the
voice Natasha had known previously, but the one that had sun As 'twas
rowin dark last niht.

In the villae throuh which they passed there were red lihts and a
cheerful smell of smoke.

"What a darlin Uncle is!" said Natasha, when they had come out onto the
hihroad.

"Yes," returned Nicholas. "You're not cold?"

"No. I'm quite, quite all riht. I feel so comfortable!" answered
Natasha, almost perplexed by her feelins. They remained silent a lon

only heard them splashin throuh the unseen mud.

What was passin in that receptive childlike soul that so eaerly cauht

suddenly struck up the air of As 'twas rowin dark last niht--the tune
of which she had all the way been tryin to et and had at last cauht.

"ot it?" said Nicholas.

"What were you thinkin about just now, Nicholas?" inquired Natasha.

They were fond of askin one another that question.

"I?" said Nicholas, tryin to remember. "Well, you see, first I thouht
that Ruay, the red hound, was like Uncle, and that if he were a man he
would always keep Uncle near him, if not for his ridin, then for his
manner. What a ood fellow Uncle is! Don't you think so?... Well, and
you?"

"I? Wait a bit, wait.... Yes, first I thouht that we are drivin alon
and imainin that we are oin home, but that heaven knows where we are
