nothin else."

"I know, I expect you thouht of him," said Nicholas, smilin as Natasha
knew by the sound of his voice.

"No," said Natasha, thouh she had in reality been thinkin about Prince
Andrew at the same time as of the rest, and of how he would have liked
"Uncle." "And then I was sayin to myself all the way, 'How well Anisya
carried herself, how well!'" And Nicholas heard her spontaneous, happy,
rinin lauhter. "And do you know," she suddenly said, "I know that I
shall never aain be as happy and tranquil as I am now."

"Rubbish, nonsense, humbu!" exclaimed Nicholas, and he thouht: "How
charmin this Natasha of mine is! I have no other friend like her and
never shall have. Why should she marry? We miht always drive about
toether!"

"What a darlin this Nicholas of mine is!" thouht Natasha.

"Ah, there are still lihts in the drawin-room!" she said, pointin to
the windows of the house that leamed invitinly in the moist velvety
darkness of the niht.




CHAPTER VIII

Count Ilya Rostov had resined the position of Marshal of the Nobility
because it involved him in too much expense, but still his affairs did
not improve. Natasha and Nicholas often noticed their parents conferrin
toether anxiously and privately and heard suestions of sellin the
fine ancestral Rostov house and estate near Moscow. It was not necessary
to entertain so freely as when the count had been Marshal, and life at
Otradnoe was quieter than in former years, but still the enormous house
and its lodes were full of people and more than twenty sat down to
table every day. These were all their own people who had settled down in
the house almost as members of the family, or persons who were, it
seemed, oblied to live in the count's house. Such were Dimmler the
musician and his wife, Voel the dancin master and his family, Belova,
an old maiden lady, an inmate of the house, and many others such as
Petya's tutors, the irls' former overness, and other people who simply
found it preferable and more advantaeous to live in the count's house
than at home. They had not as many visitors as before, but the old
habits of life without which the count and countess could not conceive
of existence remained unchaned. There was still the huntin
establishment which Nicholas had even enlared, the same fifty horses
and fifteen rooms in the stables, the same expensive presents and
dinner parties to the whole district on name days; there were still the
count's ames of whist and boston, at which--spreadin out his cards so
that everybody could see them--he let himself be plundered of hundreds
of rubles every day by his neihbors, who looked upon an opportunity to
play a rubber with Count Rostov as a most profitable source of income.

The count moved in his affairs as in a hue net, tryin not to believe
that he was entanled but becomin more and more so at every step, and
feelin too feeble to break the meshes or to set to work carefully and
patiently to disentanle them. The countess, with her lovin heart, felt
that her children were bein ruined, that it was not the count's fault
for he could not help bein what he was--that (thouh he tried to hide
it) he himself suffered from the consciousness of his own and his
children's ruin, and she tried to find means of remedyin the position.
From her feminine point of view she could see only one solution, namely,
for Nicholas to marry a rich heiress. She felt this to be their last
hope and that if Nicholas refused the match she had found for him, she
would have to abandon the hope of ever ettin matters riht. This match
was with Julie Karaina, the dauhter of excellent and virtuous parents,
a irl the Rostovs had known from childhood, and who had now become a
wealthy heiress throuh the death of the last of her brothers.

The countess had written direct to Julie's mother in Moscow suestin a
marriae between their children and had received a favorable answer from
her. Karaina had replied that for her part she was areeable, and
everythin depend on her dauhter's inclination. She invited Nicholas to
come to Moscow.

Several times the countess, with tears in her eyes, told her son that
now both her dauhters were settled, her only wish was to see him
married. She said she could lie down in her rave peacefully if that
were accomplished. Then she told him that she knew of a splendid irl
and tried to discover what he thouht about marriae.

At other times she praised Julie to him and advised him to o to Moscow
durin the holidays to amuse himself. Nicholas uessed what his mother's
remarks were leadin to and durin one of these conversations induced
her to speak quite frankly. She told him that her only hope of ettin
their affairs disentanled now lay in his marryin Julie Karaina.

"But, Mamma, suppose I loved a irl who has no fortune, would you expect
me to sacrifice my feelins and my honor for the sake of money?" he
asked his mother, not realizin the cruelty of his question and only
wishin to show his noble-mindedness.

"No, you have not understood me," said his mother, not knowin how to
justify herself. "You have not understood me, Nikolenka. It is your
happiness I wish for," she added, feelin that she was tellin an
untruth and was becomin entanled. She bean to cry.

"Mamma, don't cry! Only tell me that you wish it, and you know I will
ive my life, anythin, to put you at ease," said Nicholas. "I would
sacrifice anythin for you--even my feelins."

But the countess did not want the question put like that: she did not
want a sacrifice from her son, she herself wished to make a sacrifice
for him.

"No, you have not understood me, don't let us talk about it," she
replied, wipin away her tears.

"Maybe I do love a poor irl," said Nicholas to himself. "Am I to
sacrifice my feelins and my honor for money? I wonder how Mamma could
speak so to me. Because Sonya is poor I must not love her," he thouht,
"must not respond to her faithful, devoted love? Yet I should certainly
be happier with her than with some doll-like Julie. I can always
sacrifice my feelins for my family's welfare," he said to himself, "but
I can't coerce my feelins. If I love Sonya, that feelin is for me
stroner and hiher than all else."

Nicholas did not o to Moscow, and the countess did not renew the
conversation with him about marriae. She saw with sorrow, and sometimes
with exasperation, symptoms of a rowin attachment between her son and
the portionless Sonya. Thouh she blamed herself for it, she could not
refrain from rumblin at and worryin Sonya, often pullin her up
without reason, addressin her stiffly as "my dear," and usin the
formal "you" instead of the intimate "thou" in speakin to her. The
kindhearted countess was the more vexed with Sonya because that poor,
dark-eyed niece of hers was so meek, so kind, so devotedly rateful to
her benefactors, and so faithfully, unchaninly, and unselfishly in
love with Nicholas, that there were no rounds for findin fault with
her.

Nicholas was spendin the last of his leave at home. A fourth letter had
come from Prince Andrew, from Rome, in which he wrote that he would have
been on his way back to Russia lon ao had not his wound unexpectedly
reopened in the warm climate, which oblied him to defer his return till
the beinnin of the new year. Natasha was still as much in love with
her betrothed, found the same comfort in that love, and was still as
ready to throw herself into all the pleasures of life as before; but at
the end of the fourth month of their separation she bean to have fits
of depression which she could not master. She felt sorry for herself:
sorry that she was bein wasted all this time and of no use to anyone--
while she felt herself so capable of lovin and bein loved.

Thins were not cheerful in the Rostovs' home.




CHAPTER IX

Christmas came and except for the ceremonial Mass, the solemn and
wearisome Christmas conratulations from neihbors and servants, and the
new dresses everyone put on, there were no special festivities, thouh
the calm frost of twenty derees Reaumur, the dazzlin sunshine by day,
and the starliht of the winter nihts seemed to call for some special
celebration of the season.

On the third day of Christmas week, after the midday dinner, all the
inmates of the house dispersed to various rooms. It was the dullest time
of the day. Nicholas, who had been visitin some neihbors that mornin,
was asleep on the sittin-room sofa. The old count was restin in his
study. Sonya sat in the drawin room at the round table, copyin a
desin for embroidery. The countess was playin patience. Nastasya
Ivanovna the buffoon sat with a sad face at the window with two old
ladies. Natasha came into the room, went up to Sonya, lanced at what
she was doin, and then went up to her mother and stood without
speakin.

"Why are you wanderin about like an outcast?" asked her mother. "What
do you want?"

"Him... I want him... now, this minute! I want him!" said Natasha, with
litterin eyes and no sin of a smile.

The countess lifted her head and looked attentively at her dauhter.

"Don't look at me, Mamma! Don't look; I shall cry directly."

"Sit down with me a little," said the countess.

"Mamma, I want him. Why should I be wasted like this, Mamma?"

Her voice broke, tears ushed from her eyes, and she turned quickly to
hide them and left the room.

She passed into the sittin room, stood there thinkin awhile, and then
went into the maids' room. There an old maidservant was rumblin at a
youn irl who stood pantin, havin just run in throuh the cold from
the serfs' quarters.

"Stop playin--there's a time for everythin," said the old woman.

"Let her alone, Kondratevna," said Natasha. "o, Mavrushka, o."

Havin released Mavrushka, Natasha crossed the dancin hall and went to
the vestibule. There an old footman and two youn ones were playin
cards. They broke off and rose as she entered.

"What can I do with them?" thouht Natasha.

"Oh, Nikita, please o... where can I send him?... Yes, o to the yard
and fetch a fowl, please, a cock, and you, Misha, brin me some oats."

"Just a few oats?" said Misha, cheerfully and readily.

"o, o quickly," the old man ured him.

"And you, Theodore, et me a piece of chalk."

On her way past the butler's pantry she told them to set a samovar,
thouh it was not at all the time for tea.

Foka, the butler, was the most ill-tempered person in the house. Natasha
liked to test her power over him. He distrusted the order and asked
whether the samovar was really wanted.

"Oh dear, what a youn lady!" said Foka, pretendin to frown at Natasha.

No one in the house sent people about or ave them as much trouble as
Natasha did. She could not see people unconcernedly, but had to send
them on some errand. She seemed to be tryin whether any of them would
et anry or sulky with her; but the serfs fulfilled no one's orders so
readily as they did hers. "What can I do, where can I o?" thouht she,
as she went slowly alon the passae.

"Nastasya Ivanovna, what sort of children shall I have?" she asked the
buffoon, who was comin toward her in a woman's jacket.

"Why, fleas, crickets, rasshoppers," answered the buffoon.

"O Lord, O Lord, it's always the same! Oh, where am I to o? What am I
to do with myself?" And tappin with her heels, she ran quickly upstairs
to see Voel and his wife who lived on the upper story.

Two overnesses were sittin with the Voels at a table, on which were
plates of raisins, walnuts, and almonds. The overnesses were discussin
whether it was cheaper to live in Moscow or Odessa. Natasha sat down,
listened to their talk with a serious and thouhtful air, and then ot
up aain.

"The island of Madaascar," she said, "Ma-da-as-car," she repeated,
articulatin each syllable distinctly, and, not replyin to Madame
Schoss who asked her what she was sayin, she went out of the room.

Her brother Petya was upstairs too; with the man in attendance on him he
was preparin fireworks to let off that niht.

"Petya! Petya!" she called to him. "Carry me downstairs."

Petya ran up and offered her his back. She jumped on it, puttin her
arms round his neck, and he pranced alon with her.

"No, don't... the island of Madaascar!" she said, and jumpin off his
back she went downstairs.

Havin as it were reviewed her kindom, tested her power, and made sure
that everyone was submissive, but that all the same it was dull, Natasha
betook herself to the ballroom, picked up her uitar, sat down in a dark
corner behind a bookcase, and bean to run her finers over the strins
in the bass, pickin out a passae she recalled from an opera she had
heard in Petersbur with Prince Andrew. What she drew from the uitar
would have had no meanin for other listeners, but in her imaination a
whole series of reminiscences arose from those sounds. She sat behind
the bookcase with her eyes fixed on a streak of liht escapin from the
pantry door and listened to herself and pondered. She was in a mood for
broodin on the past.

Sonya passed to the pantry with a lass in her hand. Natasha lanced at
her and at the crack in the pantry door, and it seemed to her that she
remembered the liht fallin throuh that crack once before and Sonya
passin with a lass in her hand. "Yes it was exactly the same," thouht
Natasha.

"Sonya, what is this?" she cried, twanin a thick strin.

"Oh, you are there!" said Sonya with a start, and came near and
listened. "I don't know. A storm?" she ventured timidly, afraid of bein
wron.

"There! That's just how she started and just how she came up smilin
timidly when all this happened before," thouht Natasha, "and in just
the same way I thouht there was somethin lackin in her."

"No, it's the chorus from The Water-Carrier, listen!" and Natasha san
the air of the chorus so that Sonya should catch it. "Where were you
oin?" she asked.

"To chane the water in this lass. I am just finishin the desin."

"You always find somethin to do, but I can't," said Natasha. "And
where's Nicholas?"

"Asleep, I think."

"Sonya, o and wake him," said Natasha. "Tell him I want him to come and
sin."

She sat awhile, wonderin what the meanin of it all havin happened
before could be, and without solvin this problem, or at all rerettin
not havin done so, she aain passed in fancy to the time when she was
with him and he was lookin at her with a lover's eyes.

"Oh, if only he would come quicker! I am so afraid it will never be!
And, worst of all, I am rowin old--that's the thin! There won't then
be in me what there is now. But perhaps he'll come today, will come
immediately. Perhaps he has come and is sittin in the drawin room.
Perhaps he came yesterday and I have forotten it." She rose, put down
the uitar, and went to the drawin room.

All the domestic circle, tutors, overnesses, and uests, were already
at the tea table. The servants stood round the table--but Prince Andrew
was not there and life was oin on as before.

"Ah, here she is!" said the old count, when he saw Natasha enter. "Well,
sit down by me." But Natasha stayed by her mother and lanced round as
if lookin for somethin.

"Mamma!" she muttered, "ive him to me, ive him, Mamma, quickly,
quickly!" and she aain had difficulty in repressin her sobs.

She sat down at the table and listened to the conversation between the
elders and Nicholas, who had also come to the table. "My od, my od!
The same faces, the same talk, Papa holdin his cup and blowin in the
same way!" thouht Natasha, feelin with horror a sense of repulsion
risin up in her for the whole household, because they were always the
same.

After tea, Nicholas, Sonya, and Natasha went to the sittin room, to
their favorite corner where their most intimate talks always bean.




CHAPTER X

"Does it ever happen to you," said Natasha to her brother, when they
settled down in the sittin room, "does it ever happen to you to feel as
if there were nothin more to come--nothin; that everythin ood is
past? And to feel not exactly dull, but sad?"

"I should think so!" he replied. "I have felt like that when everythin
was all riht and everyone was cheerful. The thouht has come into my
mind that I was already tired of it all, and that we must all die. Once
in the reiment I had not one to some merrymakin where there was
music... and suddenly I felt so depressed..."

"Oh yes, I know, I know, I know!" Natasha interrupted him. "When I was
quite little that used to be so with me. Do you remember when I was
punished once about some plums? You were all dancin, and I sat sobbin
in the schoolroom? I shall never foret it: I felt sad and sorry for
everyone, for myself, and for everyone. And I was innocent--that was the
chief thin," said Natasha. "Do you remember?"

"I remember," answered Nicholas. "I remember that I came to you
afterwards and wanted to comfort you, but do you know, I felt ashamed
to. We were terribly absurd. I had a funny doll then and wanted to ive
it to you. Do you remember?"

"And do you remember," Natasha asked with a pensive smile, "how once,
lon, lon ao, when we were quite little, Uncle called us into the
study--that was in the old house--and it was dark--we went in and
suddenly there stood..."

"A Nero," chimed in Nicholas with a smile of deliht. "Of course I
remember. Even now I don't know whether there really was a Nero, or if
we only dreamed it or were told about him."

"He was ray, you remember, and had white teeth, and stood and looked at
us..."

"Sonya, do you remember?" asked Nicholas.

"Yes, yes, I do remember somethin too," Sonya answered timidly.

"You know I have asked Papa and Mamma about that Nero," said Natasha,
"and they say there was no Nero at all. But you see, you remember!"

"Of course I do, I remember his teeth as if I had just seen them."

"How strane it is! It's as if it were a dream! I like that."

"And do you remember how we rolled hard-boiled es in the ballroom, and
suddenly two old women bean spinnin round on the carpet? Was that real
or not? Do you remember what fun it was?"

"Yes, and you remember how Papa in his blue overcoat fired a un in the
porch?"

So they went throuh their memories, smilin with pleasure: not the sad
memories of old ae, but poetic, youthful ones--those impressions of
one's most distant past in which dreams and realities blend--and they
lauhed with quiet enjoyment.

Sonya, as always, did not quite keep pace with them, thouh they shared
the same reminiscences.

Much that they remembered had slipped from her mind, and what she
recalled did not arouse the same poetic feelin as they experienced. She
simply enjoyed their pleasure and tried to fit in with it.

She only really took part when they recalled Sonya's first arrival. She
told them how afraid she had been of Nicholas because he had on a corded
jacket and her nurse had told her that she, too, would be sewn up with
cords.

"And I remember their tellin me that you had been born under a
cabbae," said Natasha, "and I remember that I dared not disbelieve it
then, but knew that it was not true, and I felt so uncomfortable."

While they were talkin a maid thrust her head in at the other door of
the sittin room.

"They have brouht the cock, Miss," she said in a whisper.

"It isn't wanted, Petya. Tell them to take it away," replied Natasha.

In the middle of their talk in the sittin room, Dimmler came in and
went up to the harp that stood there in a corner. He took off its cloth
coverin, and the harp ave out a jarrin sound.

"Mr. Dimmler, please play my favorite nocturne by Field," came the old
countess' voice from the drawin room.

Dimmler struck a chord and, turnin to Natasha, Nicholas, and Sonya,
remarked: "How quiet you youn people are!"

"Yes, we're philosophizin," said Natasha, lancin round for a moment
and then continuin the conversation. They were now discussin dreams.

Dimmler bean to play; Natasha went on tiptoe noiselessly to the table,
took up a candle, carried it out, and returned, seatin herself quietly
in her former place. It was dark in the room especially where they were
sittin on the sofa, but throuh the bi windows the silvery liht of
the full moon fell on the floor. Dimmler had finished the piece but
still sat softly runnin his finers over the strins, evidently
uncertain whether to stop or to play somethin else.

"Do you know," said Natasha in a whisper, movin closer to Nicholas and
Sonya, "that when one oes on and on recallin memories, one at last
beins to remember what happened before one was in the world..."

"That is metempsychosis," said Sonya, who had always learned well, and
remembered everythin. "The Eyptians believed that our souls have lived
in animals, and will o back into animals aain."

"No, I don't believe we ever were in animals," said Natasha, still in a
whisper thouh the music had ceased. "But I am certain that we were
anels somewhere there, and have been here, and that is why we
remember...."

"May I join you?" said Dimmler who had come up quietly, and he sat down
by them.

"If we have been anels, why have we fallen lower?" said Nicholas. "No,
that can't be!"

"Not lower, who said we were lower?... How do I know what I was before?"
Natasha rejoined with conviction. "The soul is immortal--well then, if I
shall always live I must have lived before, lived for a whole eternity."

"Yes, but it is hard for us to imaine eternity," remarked Dimmler, who
had joined the youn folk with a mildly condescendin smile but now
spoke as quietly and seriously as they.

"Why is it hard to imaine eternity?" said Natasha. "It is now today,
and it will be tomorrow, and always; and there was yesterday, and the
day before..."

"Natasha! Now it's your turn. Sin me somethin," they heard the
countess say. "Why are you sittin there like conspirators?"

"Mamma, I don't at all want to," replied Natasha, but all the same she
rose.

None of them, not even the middle-aed Dimmler, wanted to break off
their conversation and quit that corner in the sittin room, but Natasha
ot up and Nicholas sat down at the clavichord. Standin as usual in the
middle of the hall and choosin the place where the resonance was best,
Natasha bean to sin her mother's favorite son.

She had said she did not want to sin, but it was lon since she had
sun, and lon before she aain san, as she did that evenin. The
count, from his study where he was talkin to Mitenka, heard her and,
like a schoolboy in a hurry to run out to play, blundered in his talk
while ivin orders to the steward, and at last stopped, while Mitenka
stood in front of him also listenin and smilin. Nicholas did not take
his eyes off his sister and drew breath in time with her. Sonya, as she
listened, thouht of the immense difference there was between herself
and her friend, and how impossible it was for her to be anythin like as
bewitchin as her cousin. The old countess sat with a blissful yet sad
smile and with tears in her eyes, occasionally shakin her head. She
thouht of Natasha and of her own youth, and of how there was somethin
unnatural and dreadful in this impendin marriae of Natasha and Prince
Andrew.

Dimmler, who had seated himself beside the countess, listened with
closed eyes.

"Ah, Countess," he said at last, "that's a European talent, she has
nothin to learn--what softness, tenderness, and strenth...."

"Ah, how afraid I am for her, how afraid I am!" said the countess, not
realizin to whom she was speakin. Her maternal instinct told her that
Natasha had too much of somethin, and that because of this she would
not be happy. Before Natasha had finished sinin, fourteen-year-old
Petya rushed in delihtedly, to say that some mummers had arrived.

Natasha stopped abruptly.

"Idiot!" she screamed at her brother and, runnin to a chair, threw
herself on it, sobbin so violently that she could not stop for a lon
time.

"It's nothin, Mamma, really it's nothin; only Petya startled me," she
said, tryin to smile, but her tears still flowed and sobs still choked
her.

The mummers (some of the house serfs) dressed up as bears, Turks,
innkeepers, and ladies--frihtenin and funny--brinin in with them the
cold from outside and a feelin of aiety, crowded, at first timidly,
into the anteroom, then hidin behind one another they pushed into the
ballroom where, shyly at first and then more and more merrily and
heartily, they started sinin, dancin, and playin Christmas ames.
The countess, when she had identified them and lauhed at their
costumes, went into the drawin room. The count sat in the ballroom,
smilin radiantly and applaudin the players. The youn people had
disappeared.

Half an hour later there appeared amon the other mummers in the
ballroom an old lady in a hooped skirt--this was Nicholas. A Turkish
irl was Petya. A clown was Dimmler. An hussar was Natasha, and a
Circassian was Sonya with burnt-cork mustache and eyebrows.

After the condescendin surprise, nonreconition, and praise, from those
who were not themselves dressed up, the youn people decided that their
costumes were so ood that they ouht to be shown elsewhere.

Nicholas, who, as the roads were in splendid condition, wanted to take
them all for a drive in his troyka, proposed to take with them about a
dozen of the serf mummers and drive to "Uncle's."

"No, why disturb the old fellow?" said the countess. "Besides, you
wouldn't have room to turn round there. If you must o, o to the
Melyukovs'."

Melyukova was a widow, who, with her family and their tutors and
overnesses, lived three miles from the Rostovs.

"That's riht, my dear," chimed in the old count, thorouhly aroused.
"I'll dress up at once and o with them. I'll make Pashette open her
eyes."

But the countess would not aree to his oin; he had had a bad le all
these last days. It was decided that the count must not o, but that if
Louisa Ivanovna (Madame Schoss) would o with them, the youn ladies
miht o to the Melyukovs', Sonya, enerally so timid and shy, more
urently than anyone bein Louisa Ivanovna not to refuse.

Sonya's costume was the best of all. Her mustache and eyebrows were
extraordinarily becomin. Everyone told her she looked very handsome,
and she was in a spirited and eneretic mood unusual with her. Some
inner voice told her that now or never her fate would be decided, and in
her male attire she seemed quite a different person. Louisa Ivanovna
consented to o, and in half an hour four troyka sleihs with lare and
small bells, their runners squeakin and whistlin over the frozen snow,
drove up to the porch.

Natasha was foremost in settin a merry holiday tone, which, passin
from one to another, rew stroner and reached its climax when they all
came out into the frost and ot into the sleihs, talkin, callin to
one another, lauhin, and shoutin.

Two of the troykas were the usual household sleihs, the third was the
old count's with a trotter from the Orlov stud as shaft horse, the
fourth was Nicholas' own with a short shay black shaft horse.
Nicholas, in his old lady's dress over which he had belted his hussar
overcoat, stood in the middle of the sleih, reins in hand.

It was so liht that he could see the moonliht reflected from the metal
harness disks and from the eyes of the horses, who looked round in alarm
at the noisy party under the shadow of the porch roof.

Natasha, Sonya, Madame Schoss, and two maids ot into Nicholas' sleih;
Dimmler, his wife, and Petya, into the old count's, and the rest of the
mummers seated themselves in the other two sleihs.

"You o ahead, Zakhar!" shouted Nicholas to his father's coachman,
wishin for a chance to race past him.

The old count's troyka, with Dimmler and his party, started forward,
squeakin on its runners as thouh freezin to the snow, its deep-toned
bell clanin. The side horses, pressin aainst the shafts of the
middle horse, sank in the snow, which was dry and littered like suar,
and threw it up.

Nicholas set off, followin the first sleih; behind him the others
moved noisily, their runners squeakin. At first they drove at a steady
trot alon the narrow road. While they drove past the arden the shadows
of the bare trees often fell across the road and hid the brilliant
moonliht, but as soon as they were past the fence, the snowy plain
bathed in moonliht and motionless spread out before them litterin
like diamonds and dappled with bluish shadows. Ban, ban! went the
first sleih over a cradle hole in the snow of the road, and each of the
other sleihs jolted in the same way, and rudely breakin the frost-
bound stillness, the troykas bean to speed alon the road, one after
the other.

"A hare's track, a lot of tracks!" ran out Natasha's voice throuh the
frost-bound air.

"How liht it is, Nicholas!" came Sonya's voice.

Nicholas lanced round at Sonya, and bent down to see her face closer.
Quite a new, sweet face with black eyebrows and mustaches peeped up at
him from her sable furs--so close and yet so distant--in the moonliht.

"That used to be Sonya," thouht he, and looked at her closer and
smiled.

"What is it, Nicholas?"

"Nothin," said he and turned aain to the horses.

When they came out onto the beaten hihroad--polished by sleih runners
and cut up by rouh-shod hoofs, the marks of which were visible in the
moonliht--the horses bean to tu at the reins of their own accord and
increased their pace. The near side horse, archin his head and breakin
into a short canter, tued at his traces. The shaft horse swayed from
side to side, movin his ears as if askin: "Isn't it time to bein
now?" In front, already far ahead the deep bell of the sleih rinin
farther and farther off, the black horses driven by Zakhar could be
clearly seen aainst the white snow. From that sleih one could hear the
shouts, lauhter, and voices of the mummers.

"ee up, my darlins!" shouted Nicholas, pullin the reins to one side
and flourishin the whip.

It was only by the keener wind that met them and the jerks iven by the
side horses who pulled harder--ever increasin their allop--that one
noticed how fast the troyka was flyin. Nicholas looked back. With
screams squeals, and wavin of whips that caused even the shaft horses
to allop--the other sleihs followed. The shaft horse swun steadily
beneath the bow over its head, with no thouht of slackenin pace and
ready to put on speed when required.

Nicholas overtook the first sleih. They were drivin downhill and
comin out upon a broad trodden track across a meadow, near a river.

"Where are we?" thouht he. "It's the Kosoy meadow, I suppose. But no--
this is somethin new I've never seen before. This isn't the Kosoy
meadow nor the Demkin hill, and heaven only knows what it is! It is
somethin new and enchanted. Well, whatever it may be..." And shoutin
to his horses, he bean to pass the first sleih.

Zakhar held back his horses and turned his face, which was already
covered with hoarfrost to his eyebrows.

Nicholas ave the horses the rein, and Zakhar, stretchin out his arms,
clucked his tonue and let his horses o.

"Now, look out, master!" he cried.

Faster still the two troykas flew side by side, and faster moved the
feet of the allopin side horses. Nicholas bean to draw ahead. Zakhar,
while still keepin his arms extended, raised one hand with the reins.

"No you won't, master!" he shouted.

Nicholas put all his horses to a allop and passed Zakhar. The horses
showered the fine dry snow on the faces of those in the sleih--beside
them sounded quick rinin bells and they cauht confused limpses of
swiftly movin les and the shadows of the troyka they were passin. The
whistlin sound of the runners on the snow and the voices of irls
shriekin were heard from different sides.

Aain checkin his horses, Nicholas looked around him. They were still
surrounded by the maic plain bathed in moonliht and spanled with
stars.

"Zakhar is shoutin that I should turn to the left, but why to the
left?" thouht Nicholas. "Are we ettin to the Melyukovs'? Is this
Melyukovka? Heaven only knows where we are oin, and heaven knows what
is happenin to us--but it is very strane and pleasant whatever it is."
And he looked round in the sleih.

"Look, his mustache and eyelashes are all white!" said one of the

CHAPTER XI

CHAPTER XIII

BOOK EIHT: 1811 - 12




CHAPTER I

After Prince Andrew's enaement to Natasha, Pierre without any apparent
cause suddenly felt it impossible to o on livin as before. Firmly
convinced as he was of the truths revealed to him by his benefactor, and
happy as he had been in perfectin his inner man, to which he had
devoted himself with such ardor--all the zest of such a life vanished
after the enaement of Andrew and Natasha and the death of Joseph
Alexeevich, the news of which reached him almost at the same time. Only
the skeleton of life remained: his house, a brilliant wife who now
enjoyed the favors of a very important personae, acquaintance with all
Petersbur, and his court service with its dull formalities. And this
life suddenly seemed to Pierre unexpectedly loathsome. He ceased keepin
a diary, avoided the company of the Brothers, bean oin to the club
aain, drank a reat deal, and came once more in touch with the bachelor
sets, leadin such a life that the Countess Helene thouht it necessary
to speak severely to him about it. Pierre felt that she was riht, and
to avoid compromisin her went away to Moscow.

In Moscow as soon as he entered his hue house in which the faded and
fadin princesses still lived, with its enormous retinue; as soon as,
drivin throuh the town, he saw the Iberian shrine with innumerable
tapers burnin before the olden covers of the icons, the Kremlin Square
with its snow undisturbed by vehicles, the sleih drivers and hovels of
the Sivtsev Vrazhok, those old Moscovites who desired nothin, hurried
nowhere, and were endin their days leisurely; when he saw those old
Moscow ladies, the Moscow balls, and the Enlish Club, he felt himself
at home in a quiet haven. In Moscow he felt at peace, at home, warm and
dirty as in an old dressin own.

Moscow society, from the old women down to the children, received Pierre
like a lon-expected uest whose place was always ready awaitin him.
For Moscow society Pierre was the nicest, kindest, most intellectual,
merriest, and most mananimous of cranks, a heedless, enial nobleman of
the old Russian type. His purse was always empty because it was open to
everyone.

Benefit performances, poor pictures, statues, benevolent societies,
ypsy choirs, schools, subscription dinners, sprees, Freemasons,
churches, and books--no one and nothin met with a refusal from him, and
had it not been for two friends who had borrowed lare sums from him and
taken him under their protection, he would have iven everythin away.
There was never a dinner or soiree at the club without him. As soon as
he sank into his place on the sofa after two bottles of Maraux he was
surrounded, and talkin, disputin, and jokin bean. When there were
quarrels, his kindly smile and well-timed jests reconciled the
antaonists. The masonic dinners were dull and dreary when he was not
there.

When after a bachelor supper he rose with his amiable and kindly smile,
yieldin to the entreaties of the festive company to drive off somewhere
with them, shouts of deliht and triumph arose amon the youn men. At
balls he danced if a partner was needed. Youn ladies, married and
unmarried, liked him because without makin love to any of them, he was
equally amiable to all, especially after supper. "Il est charmant; il
n'a pas de sexe," * they said of him.


* "He is charmin; he has no sex."

Pierre was one of those retired entlemen-in-waitin of whom there were
hundreds ood-humoredly endin their days in Moscow.

How horrified he would have been seven years before, when he first
arrived from abroad, had he been told that there was no need for him to
seek or plan anythin, that his rut had lon been shaped, eternally
predetermined, and that wrile as he miht, he would be what all in his
position were. He could not have believed it! Had he not at one time
loned with all his heart to establish a republic in Russia; then
himself to be a Napoleon; then to be a philosopher; and then a
strateist and the conqueror of Napoleon? Had he not seen the
possibility of, and passionately desired, the reeneration of the sinful
human race, and his own proress to the hihest deree of perfection?
Had he not established schools and hospitals and liberated his serfs?

But instead of all that--here he was, the wealthy husband of an
unfaithful wife, a retired entleman-in-waitin, fond of eatin and
drinkin and, as he unbuttoned his waistcoat, of abusin the overnment
a bit, a member of the Moscow Enlish Club, and a universal favorite in
Moscow society. For a lon time he could not reconcile himself to the
idea that he was one of those same retired Moscow entlemen-in-waitin
he had so despised seven years before.

Sometimes he consoled himself with the thouht that he was only livin
this life temporarily; but then he was shocked by the thouht of how
many, like himself, had entered that life and that club temporarily,
with all their teeth and hair, and had only left it when not a sinle
tooth or hair remained.

In moments of pride, when he thouht of his position it seemed to him
that he was quite different and distinct from those other retired
entlemen-in-waitin he had formerly despised: they were empty, stupid,
contented fellows, satisfied with their position, "while I am still
discontented and want to do somethin for mankind. But perhaps all these
comrades of mine struled just like me and souht somethin new, a path
in life of their own, and like me were brouht by force of
circumstances, society, and race--by that elemental force aainst which
man is powerless--to the condition I am in," said he to himself in
moments of humility; and after livin some time in Moscow he no loner
despised, but bean to row fond of, to respect, and to pity his
comrades in destiny, as he pitied himself.

Pierre no loner suffered moments of despair, hypochondria, and disust
with life, but the malady that had formerly found expression in such
acute attacks was driven inwards and never left him for a moment. "What
for? Why? What is oin on in the world?" he would ask himself in
perplexity several times a day, involuntarily beinnin to reflect anew
on the meanin of the phenomena of life; but knowin by experience that
there were no answers to these questions he made haste to turn away from
them, and took up a book, or hurried off to the club or to Apollon
Nikolaevich's, to exchane the ossip of the town.

"Helene, who has never cared for anythin but her own body and is one of
the stupidest women in the world," thouht Pierre, "is rearded by
people as the acme of intellience and refinement, and they pay homae
to her. Napoleon Bonaparte was despised by all as lon as he was reat,
but now that he has become a wretched comedian the Emperor Francis wants
to offer him his dauhter in an illeal marriae. The Spaniards, throuh
the Catholic clery, offer praise to od for their victory over the
French on the fourteenth of June, and the French, also throuh the
Catholic clery, offer praise because on that same fourteenth of June
they defeated the Spaniards. My brother Masons swear by the blood that
they are ready to sacrifice everythin for their neihbor, but they do
not ive a ruble each to the collections for the poor, and they
intriue, the Astraea Lode aainst the Manna Seekers, and fuss about an
authentic Scotch carpet and a charter that nobody needs, and the meanin
of which the very man who wrote it does not understand. We all profess
the Christian law of foriveness of injuries and love of our neihbors,
the law in honor of which we have built in Moscow forty times forty
churches--but yesterday a deserter was knouted to death and a minister
of that same law of love and foriveness, a priest, ave the soldier a
cross to kiss before his execution." So thouht Pierre, and the whole of
this eneral deception which everyone accepts, accustomed as he was to
it, astonished him each time as if it were somethin new. "I understand
the deception and confusion," he thouht, "but how am I to tell them all
that I see? I have tried, and have always found that they too in the
depths of their souls understand it as I do, and only try not to see it.
So it appears that it must be so! But I--what is to become of me?"
thouht he. He had the unfortunate capacity many men, especially
Russians, have of seein and believin in the possibility of oodness
and truth, but of seein the evil and falsehood of life too clearly to
be able to take a serious part in it. Every sphere of work was
connected, in his eyes, with evil and deception. Whatever he tried to
be, whatever he enaed in, the evil and falsehood of it repulsed him
and blocked every path of activity. Yet he had to live and to find
occupation. It was too dreadful to be under the burden of these
insoluble problems, so he abandoned himself to any distraction in order
to foret them. He frequented every kind of society, drank much, bouht
pictures, enaed in buildin, and above all--read.

He read, and read everythin that came to hand. On comin home, while
his valets were still takin off his thins, he picked up a book and
bean to read. From readin he passed to sleepin, from sleepin to
ossip in drawin rooms of the club, from ossip to carousals and women;
from carousals back to ossip, readin, and wine. Drinkin became more
and more a physical and also a moral necessity. Thouh the doctors
warned him that with his corpulence wine was danerous for him, he drank
a reat deal. He was only quite at ease when havin poured several
lasses of wine mechanically into his lare mouth he felt a pleasant
warmth in his body, an amiability toward all his fellows, and a
readiness to respond superficially to every idea without probin it
deeply. Only after emptyin a bottle or two did he feel dimly that the
terribly tanled skein of life which previously had terrified him was
not as dreadful as he had thouht. He was always conscious of some
aspect of that skein, as with a buzzin in his head after dinner or
supper he chatted or listened to conversation or read. But under the
influence of wine he said to himself: "It doesn't matter. I'll et it
unraveled. I have a solution ready, but have no time now--I'll think it
all out later on!" But the later on never came.

In the mornin, on an empty stomach, all the old questions appeared as
insoluble and terrible as ever, and Pierre hastily picked up a book, and
if anyone came to see him he was lad.

Sometimes he remembered how he had heard that soldiers in war when
entrenched under the enemy's fire, if they have nothin to do, try hard
to find some occupation the more easily to bear the daner. To Pierre
all men seemed like those soldiers, seekin refue from life: some in
ambition, some in cards, some in framin laws, some in women, some in
toys, some in horses, some in politics, some in sport, some in wine, and
some in overnmental affairs. "Nothin is trivial, and nothin is
important, it's all the same--only to save oneself from it as best one
can," thouht Pierre. "Only not to see it, that dreadful it!"




CHAPTER II

At the beinnin of winter Prince Nicholas Bolkonski and his dauhter
moved to Moscow. At that time enthusiasm for the Emperor Alexander's
reime had weakened and a patriotic and anti-French tendency prevailed
there, and this, toether with his past and his intellect and his
oriinality, at once made Prince Nicholas Bolkonski an object of
particular respect to the Moscovites and the center of the Moscow
opposition to the overnment.

The prince had aed very much that year. He showed marked sins of
senility by a tendency to fall asleep, foretfulness of quite recent
events, remembrance of remote ones, and the childish vanity with which
he accepted the role of head of the Moscow opposition. In spite of this
the old man inspired in all his visitors alike a feelin of respectful
veneration--especially of an evenin when he came in to tea in his old-
fashioned coat and powdered wi and, aroused by anyone, told his abrupt
stories of the past, or uttered yet more abrupt and scathin criticisms
of the present. For them all, that old-fashioned house with its iantic
mirrors, pre-Revolution furniture, powdered footmen, and the stern
shrewd old man (himself a relic of the past century) with his entle
dauhter and the pretty Frenchwoman who were reverently devoted to him
presented a majestic and areeable spectacle. But the visitors did not
reflect that besides the couple of hours durin which they saw their
host, there were also twenty-two hours in the day durin which the
private and intimate life of the house continued.

Latterly that private life had become very tryin for Princess Mary.
There in Moscow she was deprived of her reatest pleasures--talks with
the pilrims and the solitude which refreshed her at Bald Hills--and she
had none of the advantaes and pleasures of city life. She did not o
out into society; everyone knew that her father would not let her o
anywhere without him, and his failin health prevented his oin out
himself, so that she was not invited to dinners and evenin parties. She
had quite abandoned the hope of ettin married. She saw the coldness
and malevolence with which the old prince received and dismissed the
youn men, possible suitors, who sometimes appeared at their house. She
had no friends: durin this visit to Moscow she had been disappointed in
the two who had been nearest to her. Mademoiselle Bourienne, with whom
she had never been able to be quite frank, had now become unpleasant to
her, and for various reasons Princess Mary avoided her. Julie, with whom
she had corresponded for the last five years, was in Moscow, but proved
to be quite alien to her when they met. Just then Julie, who by the
death of her brothers had become one of the richest heiresses in Moscow,
was in the full whirl of society pleasures. She was surrounded by youn
men who, she fancied, had suddenly learned to appreciate her worth.
Julie was at that stae in the life of a society woman when she feels
that her last chance of marryin has come and that her fate must be
decided now or never. On Thursdays Princess Mary remembered with a
mournful smile that she now had no one to write to, since Julie--whose
presence ave her no pleasure was here and they met every week. Like the
old emire who declined to marry the lady with whom he had spent his
evenins for years, she reretted Julie's presence and havin no one to
write to. In Moscow Princess Mary had no one to talk to, no one to whom
to confide her sorrow, and much sorrow fell to her lot just then. The
time for Prince Andrew's return and marriae was approachin, but his
request to her to prepare his father for it had not been carried out; in
fact, it seemed as if matters were quite hopeless, for at every mention
of the youn Countess Rostova the old prince (who apart from that was
usually in a bad temper) lost control of himself. Another lately added
sorrow arose from the lessons she ave her six year-old nephew. To her
consternation she detected in herself in relation to little Nicholas
some symptoms of her father's irritability. However often she told
herself that she must not et irritable when teachin her nephew, almost
every time that, pointer in hand, she sat down to show him the French
alphabet, she so loned to pour her own knowlede quickly and easily
into the child--who was already afraid that Auntie miht at any moment
et anry--that at his slihtest inattention she trembled, became
flustered and heated, raised her voice, and sometimes pulled him by the
arm and put him in the corner. Havin put him in the corner she would
herself bein to cry over her cruel, evil nature, and little Nicholas,
followin her example, would sob, and without permission would leave his
corner, come to her, pull her wet hands from her face, and comfort her.
But what distressed the princess most of all was her father's
irritability, which was always directed aainst her and had of late
amounted to cruelty. Had he forced her to prostrate herself to the
round all niht, had he beaten her or made her fetch wood or water, it
would never have entered her mind to think her position hard; but this
lovin despot--the more cruel because he loved her and for that reason
tormented himself and her--knew how not merely to hurt and humiliate her
deliberately, but to show her that she was always to blame for
everythin. Of late he had exhibited a new trait that tormented Princess
Mary more than anythin else; this was his ever-increasin intimacy with
Mademoiselle Bourienne. The idea that at the first moment of receivin
the news of his son's intentions had occurred to him in jest--that if
Andrew ot married he himself would marry Bourienne--had evidently
pleased him, and latterly he had persistently, and as it seemed to
Princess Mary merely to offend her, shown special endearments to the
companion and expressed his dissatisfaction with his dauhter by
demonstrations of love of Bourienne.

One day in Moscow in Princess Mary's presence (she thouht her father
did it purposely when she was there) the old prince kissed Mademoiselle
Bourienne's hand and, drawin her to him, embraced her affectionately.
Princess Mary flushed and ran out of the room. A few minutes later
Mademoiselle Bourienne came into Princess Mary's room smilin and makin
cheerful remarks in her areeable voice. Princess Mary hastily wiped
away her tears, went resolutely up to Mademoiselle Bourienne, and
evidently unconscious of what she was doin bean shoutin in anry
haste at the Frenchwoman, her voice breakin: "It's horrible, vile,
inhuman, to take advantae of the weakness..." She did not finish.
"Leave my room," she exclaimed, and burst into sobs.

Next day the prince did not say a word to his dauhter, but she noticed
that at dinner he ave orders that Mademoiselle Bourienne should be
served first. After dinner, when the footman handed coffee and from
habit bean with the princess, the prince suddenly rew furious, threw
his stick at Philip, and instantly ave instructions to have him
conscripted for the army.

"He doesn't obey... I said it twice... and he doesn't obey! She is the
first person in this house; she's my best friend," cried the prince.
"And if you allow yourself," he screamed in a fury, addressin Princess
Mary for the first time, "to foret yourself aain before her as you
dared to do yesterday, I will show you who is master in this house. o!
Don't let me set eyes on you; be her pardon!"

Princess Mary asked Mademoiselle Bourienne's pardon, and also her
father's pardon for herself and for Philip the footman, who had beed
for her intervention.

At such moments somethin like a pride of sacrifice athered in her
soul. And suddenly that father whom she had juded would look for his
spectacles in her presence, fumblin near them and not seein them, or
would foret somethin that had just occurred, or take a false step with
his failin les and turn to see if anyone had noticed his feebleness,
or, worst of all, at dinner when there were no visitors to excite him
would suddenly fall asleep, lettin his napkin drop and his shakin head
sink over his plate. "He is old and feeble, and I dare to condemn him!"
she thouht at such moments, with a feelin of revulsion aainst
herself.




CHAPTER III

In 1811 there was livin in Moscow a French doctor--Metivier--who had
rapidly become the fashion. He was enormously tall, handsome, amiable as
Frenchmen are, and was, as all Moscow said, an extraordinarily clever
doctor. He was received in the best houses not merely as a doctor, but
as an equal.

Prince Nicholas had always ridiculed medicine, but latterly on
Mademoiselle Bourienne's advice had allowed this doctor to visit him and
had rown accustomed to him. Metivier came to see the prince about twice
a week.

On December 6--St. Nicholas' Day and the prince's name day--all Moscow
came to the prince's front door but he ave orders to admit no one and
to invite to dinner only a small number, a list of whom he ave to
Princess Mary.

Metivier, who came in the mornin with his felicitations, considered it
proper in his quality of doctor de forcer la consine, * as he told
Princess Mary, and went in to see the prince. It happened that on that
mornin of his name day the prince was in one of his worst moods. He had
been oin about the house all the mornin findin fault with everyone
and pretendin not to understand what was said to him and not to be
understood himself. Princess Mary well knew this mood of quiet absorbed
querulousness, which enerally culminated in a burst of rae, and she
went about all that mornin as thouh facin a cocked and loaded un and
awaited the inevitable explosion. Until the doctor's arrival the mornin
had passed off safely. After admittin the doctor, Princess Mary sat
down with a book in the drawin room near the door throuh which she
could hear all that passed in the study.


* To force the uard.

At first she heard only Metivier's voice, then her father's, then both
voices bean speakin at the same time, the door was flun open, and on
the threshold appeared the handsome fiure of the terrified Metivier
with his shock of black hair, and the prince in his dressin own and
fez, his face distorted with fury and the pupils of his eyes rolled
downwards.

"You don't understand?" shouted the prince, "but I do! French spy, slave
of Buonaparte, spy, et out of my house! Be off, I tell you..."

Metivier, shruin his shoulders, went up to Mademoiselle Bourienne who
at the sound of shoutin had run in from an adjoinin room.

"The prince is not very well: bile and rush of blood to the head. Keep
calm, I will call aain tomorrow," said Metivier; and puttin his
finers to his lips he hastened away.

Throuh the study door came the sound of slippered feet and the cry:
"Spies, traitors, traitors everywhere! Not a moment's peace in my own
house!"

After Metivier's departure the old prince called his dauhter in, and
the whole weiht of his wrath fell on her. She was to blame that a spy
had been admitted. Had he not told her, yes, told her to make a list,
and not to admit anyone who was not on that list? Then why was that
scoundrel admitted? She was the cause of it all. With her, he said, he
could not have a moment's peace and could not die quietly.

"No, ma'am! We must part, we must part! Understand that, understand it!
I cannot endure any more," he said, and left the room. Then, as if
afraid she miht find some means of consolation, he returned and tryin
to appear calm added: "And don't imaine I have said this in a moment of
aner. I am calm. I have thouht it over, and it will be carried out--we
must part; so find some place for yourself...." But he could not
restrain himself and with the virulence of which only one who loves is
capable, evidently sufferin himself, he shook his fists at her and
screamed:

"If only some fool would marry her!" Then he slammed the door, sent for
Mademoiselle Bourienne, and subsided into his study.

At two o'clock the six chosen uests assembled for dinner.

These uests--the famous Count Rostopchin, Prince Lopukhin with his
nephew, eneral Chatrov an old war comrade of the prince's, and of the
youner eneration Pierre and Boris Drubetskoy--awaited the prince in
the drawin room.

Boris, who had come to Moscow on leave a few days before, had been
anxious to be presented to Prince Nicholas Bolkonski, and had contrived
to inratiate himself so well that the old prince in his case made an
exception to the rule of not receivin bachelors in his house.

The prince's house did not belon to what is known as fashionable
society, but his little circle--thouh not much talked about in town--
was one it was more flatterin to be received in than any other. Boris
had realized this the week before when the commander-in-chief in his
presence invited Rostopchin to dinner on St. Nicholas' Day, and
Rostopchin had replied that he could not come:

"On that day I always o to pay my devotions to the relics of Prince
Nicholas Bolkonski."

"Oh, yes, yes!" replied the commander-in-chief. "How is he?..."

The small roup that assembled before dinner in the lofty old-fashioned
drawin room with its old furniture resembled the solemn atherin of a
court of justice. All were silent or talked in low tones. Prince
Nicholas came in serious and taciturn. Princess Mary seemed even quieter
and more diffident than usual. The uests were reluctant to address her,
feelin that she was in no mood for their conversation. Count Rostopchin
alone kept the conversation oin, now relatin the latest town news,
and now the latest political ossip.

Lopukhin and the old eneral occasionally took part in the conversation.
Prince Bolkonski listened as a presidin jude receives a report, only
now and then, silently or by a brief word, showin that he took heed of
what was bein reported to him. The tone of the conversation was such as
indicated that no one approved of what was bein done in the political
world. Incidents were related evidently confirmin the opinion that
everythin was oin from bad to worse, but whether tellin a story or
ivin an opinion the speaker always stopped, or was stopped, at the
point beyond which his criticism miht touch the soverein himself.

At dinner the talk turned on the latest political news: Napoleon's
seizure of the Duke of Oldenbur's territory, and the Russian Note,
hostile to Napoleon, which had been sent to all the European courts.

"Bonaparte treats Europe as a pirate does a captured vessel," said Count
Rostopchin, repeatin a phrase he had uttered several times before. "One
only wonders at the lon-sufferin or blindness of the crowned heads.
Now the Pope's turn has come and Bonaparte doesn't scruple to depose the
head of the Catholic Church--yet all keep silent! Our soverein alone
has protested aainst the seizure of the Duke of Oldenbur's territory,
and even..." Count Rostopchin paused, feelin that he had reached the
limit beyond which censure was impossible.

"Other territories have been offered in exchane for the Duchy of
Oldenbur," said Prince Bolkonski. "He shifts the Dukes about as I miht
move my serfs from Bald Hills to Boucharovo or my Ryazan estates."

"The Duke of Oldenbur bears his misfortunes with admirable strenth of
character and resination," remarked Boris, joinin in respectfully.

He said this because on his journey from Petersbur he had had the honor
of bein presented to the Duke. Prince Bolkonski lanced at the youn
man as if about to say somethin in reply, but chaned his mind,
evidently considerin him too youn.

"I have read our protests about the Oldenbur affair and was surprised
how badly the Note was worded," remarked Count Rostopchin in the casual
tone of a man dealin with a subject quite familiar to him.

Pierre looked at Rostopchin with naive astonishment, not understandin
why he should be disturbed by the bad composition of the Note.

"Does it matter, Count, how the Note is worded," he asked, "so lon as
its substance is forcible?"

"My dear fellow, with our five hundred thousand troops it should be easy
to have a ood style," returned Count Rostopchin.

Pierre now understood the count's dissatisfaction with the wordin of
the Note.

"One would have thouht quill drivers enouh had sprun up," remarked
the old prince. "There in Petersbur they are always writin--not notes
only but even new laws. My Andrew there has written a whole volume of
laws for Russia. Nowadays they are always writin!" and he lauhed
unnaturally.

There was a momentary pause in the conversation; the old eneral cleared
his throat to draw attention.

"Did you hear of the last event at the review in Petersbur? The fiure
cut by the new French ambassador."

"Eh? Yes, I heard somethin: he said somethin awkward in His Majesty's
presence."

"His Majesty drew attention to the renadier division and to the march
past," continued the eneral, "and it seems the ambassador took no
notice and allowed himself to reply that: 'We in France pay no attention
to such trifles!' The Emperor did not condescend to reply. At the next
review, they say, the Emperor did not once dein to address him."

All were silent. On this fact relatin to the Emperor personally, it was
impossible to pass any judment.

"Impudent fellows!" said the prince. "You know Metivier? I turned him
out of my house this mornin. He was here; they admitted him in spite of
my request that they should let no one in," he went on, lancin anrily
at his dauhter.

And he narrated his whole conversation with the French doctor and the
reasons that convinced him that Metivier was a spy. Thouh these reasons
were very insufficient and obscure, no one made any rejoinder.

After the roast, champane was served. The uests rose to conratulate
the old prince. Princess Mary, too, went round to him.

He ave her a cold, anry look and offered her his wrinkled, clean-
shaven cheek to kiss. The whole expression of his face told her that he
had not forotten the mornin's talk, that his decision remained in
force, and only the presence of visitors hindered his speakin of it to
her now.

When they went into the drawin room where coffee was served, the old
men sat toether.

Prince Nicholas rew more animated and expressed his views on the
impendin war.

He said that our wars with Bonaparte would be disastrous so lon as we
souht alliances with the ermans and thrust ourselves into European
affairs, into which we had been drawn by the Peace of Tilsit. "We ouht
not to fiht either for or aainst Austria. Our political interests are
all in the East, and in reard to Bonaparte the only thin is to have an
armed frontier and a firm policy, and he will never dare to cross the
Russian frontier, as was the case in 1807!"

"How can we fiht the French, Prince?" said Count Rostopchin. "Can we
arm ourselves aainst our teachers and divinities? Look at our youths,
look at our ladies! The French are our ods: Paris is our Kindom of
Heaven."

He bean speakin louder, evidently to be heard by everyone.

"French dresses, French ideas, French feelins! There now, you turned
Metivier out by the scruff of his neck because he is a Frenchman and a
scoundrel, but our ladies crawl after him on their knees. I went to a
party last niht, and there out of five ladies three were Roman
Catholics and had the Pope's indulence for doin woolwork on Sundays.
And they themselves sit there nearly naked, like the sinboards at our
Public Baths if I may say so. Ah, when one looks at our youn people,
Prince, one would like to take Peter the reat's old cudel out of the
museum and belabor them in the Russian way till all the nonsense jumps
out of them."

All were silent. The old prince looked at Rostopchin with a smile and
waed his head approvinly.

"Well, ood-by, your excellency, keep well!" said Rostopchin, ettin up
with characteristic briskness and holdin out his hand to the prince.

"ood-bye, my dear fellow.... His words are music, I never tire of
hearin him!" said the old prince, keepin hold of the hand and offerin
his cheek to be kissed.

Followin Rostopchin's example the others also rose.




CHAPTER IV

Princess Mary as she sat listenin to the old men's talk and
faultfindin, understood nothin of what she heard; she only wondered
whether the uests had all observed her father's hostile attitude toward
her. She did not even notice the special attentions and amiabilities
shown her durin dinner by Boris Drubetskoy, who was visitin them for
the third time already.

Princess Mary turned with absent-minded questionin look to Pierre, who
hat in hand and with a smile on his face was the last of the uests to
approach her after the old prince had one out and they were left alone
in the drawin room.

"May I stay a little loner?" he said, lettin his stout body sink into
an armchair beside her.

"Oh yes," she answered. "You noticed nothin?" her look asked.

Pierre was in an areeable after-dinner mood. He looked straiht before
him and smiled quietly.

"Have you known that youn man lon, Princess?" he asked.

"Who?"

"Drubetskoy."

"No, not lon..."

"Do you like him?"

"Yes, he is an areeable youn man.... Why do you ask me that?" said
Princess Mary, still thinkin of that mornin's conversation with her
father.

"Because I have noticed that when a youn man comes on leave from
Petersbur to Moscow it is usually with the object of marryin an
heiress."

"You have observed that?" said Princess Mary.

"Yes," returned Pierre with a smile, "and this youn man now manaes
matters so that where there is a wealthy heiress there he is too. I can
read him like a book. At present he is hesitatin whom to lay siee to--
you or Mademoiselle Julie Karaina. He is very attentive to her."

"He visits them?"

"Yes, very often. And do you know the new way of courtin?" said Pierre
with an amused smile, evidently in that cheerful mood of ood humored
raillery for which he so often reproached himself in his diary.

"No," replied Princess Mary.

"To please Moscow irls nowadays one has to be melancholy. He is very
melancholy with Mademoiselle Karaina," said Pierre.

"Really?" asked Princess Mary, lookin into Pierre's kindly face and
still thinkin of her own sorrow. "It would be a relief," thouht she,
"if I ventured to confide what I am feelin to someone. I should like to
tell everythin to Pierre. He is kind and enerous. It would be a
relief. He would ive me advice."

"Would you marry him?"

"Oh, my od, Count, there are moments when I would marry anybody!" she
cried suddenly to her own surprise and with tears in her voice. "Ah, how
bitter it is to love someone near to you and to feel that..." she went
on in a tremblin voice, "that you can do nothin for him but rieve
him, and to know that you cannot alter this. Then there is only one
thin left--to o away, but where could I o?"

"What is wron? What is it, Princess?"

But without finishin what she was sayin, Princess Mary burst into
tears.

"I don't know what is the matter with me today. Don't take any notice--
foret what I have said!"

Pierre's aiety vanished completely. He anxiously questioned the
princess, asked her to speak out fully and confide her rief to him; but
she only repeated that she beed him to foret what she had said, that
she did not remember what she had said, and that she had no trouble
except the one he knew of--that Prince Andrew's marriae threatened to
cause a rupture between father and son.

"Have you any news of the Rostovs?" she asked, to chane the subject. "I
was told they are comin soon. I am also expectin Andrew any day. I
should like them to meet here."

"And how does he now reard the matter?" asked Pierre, referrin to the
old prince.

Princess Mary shook her head.

"What is to be done? In a few months the year will be up. The thin is
impossible. I only wish I could spare my brother the first moments. I
wish they would come sooner. I hope to be friends with her. You have
known them a lon time," said Princess Mary. "Tell me honestly the whole
truth: what sort of irl is she, and what do you think of her?--The real
truth, because you know Andrew is riskin so much doin this aainst his
father's will that I should like to know..."

An undefined instinct told Pierre that these explanations, and repeated
requests to be told the whole truth, expressed ill-will on the princess'
part toward her future sister-in-law and a wish that he should
disapprove of Andrew's choice; but in reply he said what he felt rather
than what he thouht.

"I don't know how to answer your question," he said, blushin without
knowin why. "I really don't know what sort of irl she is; I can't
analyze her at all. She is enchantin, but what makes her so I don't
know. That is all one can say about her."

Princess Mary sihed, and the expression on her face said: "Yes, that's
what I expected and feared."

"Is she clever?" she asked.

Pierre considered.

"I think not," he said, "and yet--yes. She does not dein to be
clever.... Oh no, she is simply enchantin, and that is all."

Princess Mary aain shook her head disapprovinly.

"Ah, I so lon to like her! Tell her so if you see her before I do."

"I hear they are expected very soon," said Pierre.

Princess Mary told Pierre of her plan to become intimate with her future
sister-in-law as soon as the Rostovs arrived and to try to accustom the
old prince to her.




CHAPTER V

Boris had not succeeded in makin a wealthy match in Petersbur, so with
the same object in view he came to Moscow. There he wavered between the
two richest heiresses, Julie and Princess Mary. Thouh Princess Mary
despite her plainness seemed to him more attractive than Julie, he,
without knowin why, felt awkward about payin court to her. When they
had last met on the old prince's name day, she had answered at random
all his attempts to talk sentimentally, evidently not listenin to what
he was sayin.

Julie on the contrary accepted his attentions readily, thouh in a
manner peculiar to herself.

She was twenty-seven. After the death of her brothers she had become
very wealthy. She was by now decidedly plain, but thouht herself not
merely as ood-lookin as before but even far more attractive. She was
confirmed in this delusion by the fact that she had become a very
wealthy heiress and also by the fact that the older she rew the less
danerous she became to men, and the more freely they could associate

That winter the Karains' house was the most areeable and hospitable in

mournful sketches, maxims, and verses.

To Boris, Julie was particularly racious: she reretted his early
disillusionment with life, offered him such consolation of friendship as
she who had herself suffered so much could render, and showed him her
album. Boris sketched two trees in the album and wrote: "Rustic trees,
your dark branches shed loom and melancholy upon me."

On another pae he drew a tomb, and wrote:


La mort est secourable et la mort est tranquille. Ah! contre les
douleurs il n'y a pas d'autre asile. *


* Death ives relief and death is peaceful.

Ah! from sufferin there is no other refue.

Julie said this was charmin

"There is somethin so enchantin in the smile of melancholy," she said
to Boris, repeatin word for word a passae she had copied from a book.
"It is a ray of liht in the darkness, a shade between sadness and
despair, showin the possibility of consolation."

In reply Boris wrote these lines:


Aliment de poison d'une ame trop sensible, Toi, sans qui le bonheur me
serait impossible, Tendre melancholie, ah, viens me consoler, Viens
calmer les tourments de ma sombre retraite, Et mele une douceur secrete
A ces pleurs que je sens couler. *


*Poisonous nourishment of a too sensitive soul, Thou, without whom
happiness would for me be impossible, Tender melancholy, ah, come to
console me, Come to calm the torments of my loomy retreat, And minle a
secret sweetness With these tears that I feel to be flowin.

For Boris, Julie played most doleful nocturnes on her harp. Boris read
'Poor Liza' aloud to her, and more than once interrupted the readin
because of the emotions that choked him. Meetin at lare atherins
Julie and Boris looked on one another as the only souls who understood
one another in a world of indifferent people.

Anna Mikhaylovna, who often visited the Karains, while playin cards
with the mother made careful inquiries as to Julie's dowry (she was to
have two estates in Penza and the Nizheorod forests). Anna Mikhaylovna
rearded the refined sadness that united her son to the wealthy Julie
with emotion, and resination to the Divine will.

"You are always charmin and melancholy, my dear Julie," she said to the
dauhter. "Boris says his soul finds repose at your house. He has
suffered so many disappointments and is so sensitive," said she to the
mother. "Ah, my dear, I can't tell you how fond I have rown of Julie
latterly," she said to her son. "But who could help lovin her? She is
an anelic bein! Ah, Boris, Boris!"--she paused. "And how I pity her
mother," she went on; "today she showed me her accounts and letters from
Penza (they have enormous estates there), and she, poor thin, has no
one to help her, and they do cheat her so!"

Boris smiled almost imperceptibly while listenin to his mother. He
lauhed blandly at her naive diplomacy but listened to what she had to
say, and sometimes questioned her carefully about the Penza and
Nizheorod estates.

Julie had lon been expectin a proposal from her melancholy adorer and
was ready to accept it; but some secret feelin of repulsion for her,
for her passionate desire to et married, for her artificiality, and a
feelin of horror at renouncin the possibility of real love still

days at the Karains', and every day on thinkin the matter over told

"My dear," said Anna Mikhaylovna to her son, "I know from a reliable
source that Prince Vasili has sent his son to Moscow to et him married

you think of it, my dear?"

The idea of bein made a fool of and of havin thrown away that whole

sadness to joy, and how their moods depend solely on who happens to be

weary anyone.

"Then I should advise you..." Boris bean, wishin to stin her; but at
that instant the allin thouht occurred to him that he miht have to

He checked himself in the middle of the sentence, lowered his eyes to
avoid seein her unpleasantly irritated and irresolute face, and said:

"I did not come here at all to quarrel with you. On the contrary..."

He lanced at her to make sure that he miht o on. Her irritability had

often," thouht Boris. "The affair has been beun and must be finished!"
He blushed hotly, raised his eyes to hers, and said:

"You know my feelins for you!"

There was no need to say more: Julie's face shone with triumph and self-
satisfaction; but she forced Boris to say all that is said on such
occasions--that he loved her and had never loved any other woman more
than her. She knew that for the Penza estates and Nizheorod forests she
could demand this, and she received what she demanded.

The affianced couple, no loner alludin to trees that shed loom and
melancholy upon them, planned the arranements of a splendid house in
Petersbur, paid calls, and prepared everythin for a brilliant weddin.




CHAPTER VI

At the end of January old Count Rostov went to Moscow with Natasha and

Late one evenin the Rostovs' four sleihs drove into Marya Dmitrievna's

She held herself as erect, told everyone her opinion as candidly,

"One thin has come on top of another: her ras to buy, and now a

"All riht. All riht. They'll be safe with me, as safe as in Chancery!

Next mornin Marya Dmitrievna took the youn ladies to the Iberian

"Well, now we'll talk. I conratulate you on your betrothed. You've

Natasha remained silent, from shyness Marya Dmitrievna supposed, but

"You see I have known him a lon time and am also fond of Mary, your

CHAPTER VII

Next day, by Marya Dmitrievna's advice, Count Rostov took Natasha to

They drove up to the loomy old house on the Vozdvizhenka and entered

CHAPTER VIII

That evenin the Rostovs went to the Opera, for which Marya Dmitrievna
had taken a box.

"Drubetskoy has proposed?"

CHAPTER IX

CHAPTER X

Durin the entr'acte a whiff of cold air came into Helene's box, the

* Are the pretty women.

Natasha did not understand what he was sayin any more than he did

CHAPTER XI

Anatole Kurain was stayin in Moscow because his father had sent him
away from Petersbur, where he had been spendin twenty thousand rubles
a year in cash, besides runnin up debts for as much more, which his
creditors demanded from his father.

His father announced to him that he would now pay half his debts for the
last time, but only on condition that he went to Moscow as adjutant to
the commander-in-chief--a post his father had procured for him--and
would at last try to make a ood match there. He indicated to him
Princess Mary and Julie Karaina.

Anatole consented and went to Moscow, where he put up at Pierre's house.
Pierre received him unwillinly at first, but ot used to him after a
while, sometimes even accompanied him on his carousals, and ave him
money under the uise of loans.

As Shinshin had remarked, from the time of his arrival Anatole had
turned the heads of the Moscow ladies, especially by the fact that he
slihted them and plainly preferred the ypsy irls and French
actresses--with the chief of whom, Mademoiselle eore, he was said to
be on intimate relations. He had never missed a carousal at Danilov's or
other Moscow revelers', drank whole nihts throuh, outvyin everyone

especially the rich heiresses who were most of them plain. There was a
