reiment in Poland, a Polish landowner of small means had forced him to
marry his dauhter. Anatole had very soon abandoned his wife and, for a
payment which he areed to send to his father-in-law, had arraned to be
free to pass himself off as a bachelor.

Anatole was always content with his position, with himself, and with
others. He was instinctively and thorouhly convinced that it was
impossible for him to live otherwise than as he did and that he had
never in his life done anythin base. He was incapable of considerin
how his actions miht affect others or what the consequences of this or
that action of his miht be. He was convinced that, as a duck is so made
that it must live in water, so od had made him such that he must spend
thirty thousand rubles a year and always occupy a prominent position in
society. He believed this so firmly that others, lookin at him, were
persuaded of it too and did not refuse him either a leadin place in
society or money, which he borrowed from anyone and everyone and
evidently would not repay.

He was not a ambler, at any rate he did not care about winnin. He was
not vain. He did not mind what people thouht of him. Still less could
he be accused of ambition. More than once he had vexed his father by
spoilin his own career, and he lauhed at distinctions of all kinds. He
was not mean, and did not refuse anyone who asked of him. All he cared
about was aiety and women, and as accordin to his ideas there was
nothin dishonorable in these tastes, and he was incapable of
considerin what the ratification of his tastes entailed for others, he
honestly considered himself irreproachable, sincerely despised roues
and bad people, and with a tranquil conscience carried his head hih.

Rakes, those male Madalenes, have a secret feelin of innocence similar
to that which female Madalenes have, based on the same hope of
foriveness. "All will be foriven her, for she loved much; and all will
be foriven him, for he enjoyed much."

Dolokhov, who had reappeared that year in Moscow after his exile and his
Persian adventures, and was leadin a life of luxury, amblin, and
dissipation, associated with his old Petersbur comrade Kurain and made
use of him for his own ends.

Anatole was sincerely fond of Dolokhov for his cleverness and audacity.
Dolokhov, who needed Anatole Kurain's name, position, and connections
as a bait to draw rich youn men into his amblin set, made use of him
and amused himself at his expense without lettin the other feel it.
Apart from the advantae he derived from Anatole, the very process of
dominatin another's will was in itself a pleasure, a habit, and a
necessity to Dolokhov.

Natasha had made a stron impression on Kurain. At supper after the
opera he described to Dolokhov with the air of a connoisseur the
attractions of her arms, shoulders, feet, and hair and expressed his
intention of makin love to her. Anatole had no notion and was incapable
of considerin what miht come of such love-makin, as he never had any
notion of the outcome of any of his actions.

"She's first-rate, my dear fellow, but not for us," replied Dolokhov.

"I will tell my sister to ask her to dinner," said Anatole. "Eh?"

"You'd better wait till she's married...."

"You know, I adore little irls, they lose their heads at once," pursued
Anatole.

"You have been cauht once already by a 'little irl,'" said Dolokhov
who knew of Kurain's marriae. "Take care!"

"Well, that can't happen twice! Eh?" said Anatole, with a ood-humored
lauh.




CHAPTER XII

The day after the opera the Rostovs went nowhere and nobody came to see
them. Marya Dmitrievna talked to the count about somethin which they
concealed from Natasha. Natasha uessed they were talkin about the old
prince and plannin somethin, and this disquieted and offended her. She
was expectin Prince Andrew any moment and twice that day sent a
manservant to the Vozdvizhenka to ascertain whether he had come. He had
not arrived. She suffered more now than durin her first days in Moscow.
To her impatience and pinin for him were now added the unpleasant
recollection of her interview with Princess Mary and the old prince, and
a fear and anxiety of which she did not understand the cause. She
continually fancied that either he would never come or that somethin
would happen to her before he came. She could no loner think of him by
herself calmly and continuously as she had done before. As soon as she

far less tranquil and happy than before.

On Sunday mornin Marya Dmitrievna invited her visitors to Mass at her
parish church--the Church of the Assumption built over the raves of
victims of the plaue.

"I don't like those fashionable churches," she said, evidently pridin
herself on her independence of thouht. "od is the same everywhere. We
have an excellent priest, he conducts the service decently and with
dinity, and the deacon is the same. What holiness is there in ivin
concerts in the choir? I don't like it, it's just self-indulence!"

Marya Dmitrievna liked Sundays and knew how to keep them. Her whole
house was scrubbed and cleaned on Saturdays; neither she nor the
servants worked, and they all wore holiday dress and went to church. At
her table there were extra dishes at dinner, and the servants had vodka
and roast oose or sucklin pi. But in nothin in the house was the
holiday so noticeable as in Marya Dmitrievna's broad, stern face, which
on that day wore an invariable look of solemn festivity.

After Mass, when they had finished their coffee in the dinin room where
the loose covers had been removed from the furniture, a servant
announced that the carriae was ready, and Marya Dmitrievna rose with a
stern air. She wore her holiday shawl, in which she paid calls, and
announced that she was oin to see Prince Nicholas Bolkonski to have an
explanation with him about Natasha.

After she had one, a dressmaker from Madame Suppert-Rouet waited on
the Rostovs, and Natasha, very lad of this diversion, havin shut
herself into a room adjoinin the drawin room, occupied herself tryin
on the new dresses. Just as she had put on a bodice without sleeves and
only tacked toether, and was turnin her head to see in the lass how
the back fitted, she heard in the drawin room the animated sounds of
her father's voice and another's--a woman's--that made her flush. It was
Helene. Natasha had not time to take off the bodice before the door
opened and Countess Bezukhova, dressed in a purple velvet own with a
hih collar, came into the room beamin with ood-humored amiable
smiles.

"Oh, my enchantress!" she cried to the blushin Natasha. "Charmin! No,
this is really beyond anythin, my dear count," said she to Count Rostov
who had followed her in. "How can you live in Moscow and o nowhere? No,
I won't let you off! Mademoiselle eore will recite at my house toniht
and there'll be some people, and if you don't brin your lovely irls--
who are prettier than Mademoiselle eore--I won't know you! My husband
is away in Tver or I would send him to fetch you. You must come. You
positively must! Between eiht and nine."

She nodded to the dressmaker, whom she knew and who had curtsied
respectfully to her, and seated herself in an armchair beside the
lookin lass, drapin the folds of her velvet dress picturesquely. She
did not cease chatterin ood-naturedly and aily, continually praisin
Natasha's beauty. She looked at Natasha's dresses and praised them, as
well as a new dress of her own made of "metallic auze," which she had
received from Paris, and advised Natasha to have one like it.

"But anythin suits you, my charmer!" she remarked.

A smile of pleasure never left Natasha's face. She felt happy and as if
she were blossomin under the praise of this dear Countess Bezukhova who
had formerly seemed to her so unapproachable and important and was now
so kind to her. Natasha brihtened up and felt almost in love with this
woman, who was so beautiful and so kind. Helene for her part was
sincerely delihted with Natasha and wished to ive her a ood time.
Anatole had asked her to brin him and Natasha toether, and she was
callin on the Rostovs for that purpose. The idea of throwin her
brother and Natasha toether amused her.

Thouh at one time, in Petersbur, she had been annoyed with Natasha for
drawin Boris away, she did not think of that now, and in her own way
heartily wished Natasha well. As she was leavin the Rostovs she called
her proteee aside.

"My brother dined with me yesterday--we nearly died of lauhter--he ate
nothin and kept sihin for you, my charmer! He is madly, quite madly,
in love with you, my dear."

Natasha blushed scarlet when she heard this.

"How she blushes, how she blushes, my pretty!" said Helene. "You must
certainly come. If you love somebody, my charmer, that is not a reason
to shut yourself up. Even if you are enaed, I am sure your fiance
would wish you to o into society rather than be bored to death."

"So she knows I am enaed, and she and her husband Pierre--that ood
Pierre--have talked and lauhed about this. So it's all riht." And
aain, under Helene's influence, what had seemed terrible now seemed
simple and natural. "And she is such a rande dame, so kind, and
evidently likes me so much. And why not enjoy myself?" thouht Natasha,
azin at Helene with wide-open, wonderin eyes.

Marya Dmitrievna came back to dinner taciturn and serious, havin
evidently suffered a defeat at the old prince's. She was still too
aitated by the encounter to be able to talk of the affair calmly. In
answer to the count's inquiries she replied that thins were all riht
and that she would tell about it next day. On hearin of Countess
Bezukhova's visit and the invitation for that evenin, Marya Dmitrievna
remarked:

"I don't care to have anythin to do with Bezukhova and don't advise you
to; however, if you've promised--o. It will divert your thouhts," she
added, addressin Natasha.




CHAPTER XIII

Count Rostov took the irls to Countess Bezukhova's. There were a ood
many people there, but nearly all straners to Natasha. Count Rostov was
displeased to see that the company consisted almost entirely of men and
women known for the freedom of their conduct. Mademoiselle eore was
standin in a corner of the drawin room surrounded by youn men. There
were several Frenchmen present, amon them Metivier who from the time
Helene reached Moscow had been an intimate in her house. The count
decided not to sit down to cards or let his irls out of his siht and
to et away as soon as Mademoiselle eore's performance was over.

Anatole was at the door, evidently on the lookout for the Rostovs.
Immediately after reetin the count he went up to Natasha and followed
her. As soon as she saw him she was seized by the same feelin she had
had at the opera--ratified vanity at his admiration of her and fear at
the absence of a moral barrier between them.

Helene welcomed Natasha delihtedly and was loud in admiration of her
beauty and her dress. Soon after their arrival Mademoiselle eore went
out of the room to chane her costume. In the drawin room people bean
arranin the chairs and takin their seats. Anatole moved a chair for
Natasha and was about to sit down beside her, but the count, who never
lost siht of her, took the seat himself. Anatole sat down behind her.

Mademoiselle eore, with her bare, fat, dimpled arms, and a red shawl
draped over one shoulder, came into the space left vacant for her, and
assumed an unnatural pose. Enthusiastic whisperin was audible.

Mademoiselle eore looked sternly and loomily at the audience and
bean recitin some French verses describin her uilty love for her
son. In some places she raised her voice, in others she whispered,
liftin her head triumphantly; sometimes she paused and uttered hoarse
sounds, rollin her eyes.

"Adorable! divine! delicious!" was heard from every side.

Natasha looked at the fat actress, but neither saw nor heard nor
understood anythin of what went on before her. She only felt herself
aain completely borne away into this strane senseless world--so remote
from her old world--a world in which it was impossible to know what was
ood or bad, reasonable or senseless. Behind her sat Anatole, and
conscious of his proximity she experienced a frihtened sense of
expectancy.

After the first monoloue the whole company rose and surrounded
Mademoiselle eore, expressin their enthusiasm.

"How beautiful she is!" Natasha remarked to her father who had also
risen and was movin throuh the crowd toward the actress.

"I don't think so when I look at you!" said Anatole, followin Natasha.
He said this at a moment when she alone could hear him. "You are
enchantin... from the moment I saw you I have never ceased..."

"Come, come, Natasha!" said the count, as he turned back for his
dauhter. "How beautiful she is!" Natasha without sayin anythin
stepped up to her father and looked at him with surprised inquirin
eyes.

After ivin several recitations, Mademoiselle eore left, and Countess
Bezukhova asked her visitors into the ballroom.

The count wished to o home, but Helene entreated him not to spoil her
improvised ball, and the Rostovs stayed on. Anatole asked Natasha for a
valse and as they danced he pressed her waist and hand and told her she
was bewitchin and that he loved her. Durin the ecossaise, which she
also danced with him, Anatole said nothin when they happened to be by
themselves, but merely azed at her. Natasha lifted her frihtened eyes
to him, but there was such confident tenderness in his affectionate look
and smile that she could not, whilst lookin at him, say what she had to
say. She lowered her eyes.

"Don't say such thins to me. I am betrothed and love another," she said
rapidly.... She lanced at him.

Anatole was not upset or pained by what she had said.

"Don't speak to me of that! What can I do?" said he. "I tell you I am
madly, madly, in love with you! Is it my fault that you are
enchantin?... It's our turn to bein."

Natasha, animated and excited, looked about her with wide-open
frihtened eyes and seemed merrier than usual. She understood hardly
anythin that went on that evenin. They danced the ecossaise and the
rossvater. Her father asked her to come home, but she beed to remain.
Wherever she went and whomever she was speakin to, she felt his eyes
upon her. Later on she recalled how she had asked her father to let her
o to the dressin room to rearrane her dress, that Helene had followed
her and spoken lauhinly of her brother's love, and that she aain met
Anatole in the little sittin room. Helene had disappeared leavin them
alone, and Anatole had taken her hand and said in a tender voice:

"I cannot come to visit you but is it possible that I shall never see
you? I love you madly. Can I never...?" and, blockin her path, he
brouht his face close to hers.

His lare, litterin, masculine eyes were so close to hers that she saw
nothin but them.

"Natalie?" he whispered inquirinly while she felt her hands bein
painfully pressed. "Natalie?"

"I don't understand. I have nothin to say," her eyes replied.

Burnin lips were pressed to hers, and at the same instant she felt
herself released, and Helene's footsteps and the rustle of her dress
were heard in the room. Natasha looked round at her, and then, red and
tremblin, threw a frihtened look of inquiry at Anatole and moved
toward the door.

"One word, just one, for od's sake!" cried Anatole.

She paused. She so wanted a word from him that would explain to her what
had happened and to which she could find no answer.

"Natalie, just a word, only one!" he kept repeatin, evidently not
knowin what to say and he repeated it till Helene came up to them.

Helene returned with Natasha to the drawin room. The Rostovs went away
without stayin for supper.

After reachin home Natasha did not sleep all niht. She was tormented
by the insoluble question whether she loved Anatole or Prince Andrew.
She loved Prince Andrew--she remembered distinctly how deeply she loved
him. But she also loved Anatole, of that there was no doubt. "Else how
could all this have happened?" thouht she. "If, after that, I could
return his smile when sayin ood-by, if I was able to let it come to
that, it means that I loved him from the first. It means that he is
kind, noble, and splendid, and I could not help lovin him. What am I to
do if I love him and the other one too?" she asked herself, unable to
find an answer to these terrible questions.




CHAPTER XIV

Mornin came with its cares and bustle. Everyone ot up and bean to
move about and talk, dressmakers came aain. Marya Dmitrievna appeared,
and they were called to breakfast. Natasha kept lookin uneasily at
everybody with wide-open eyes, as if wishin to intercept every lance
directed toward her, and tried to appear the same as usual.

After breakfast, which was her best time, Marya Dmitrievna sat down in
her armchair and called Natasha and the count to her.

"Well, friends, I have now thouht the whole matter over and this is my
advice," she bean. "Yesterday, as you know, I went to see Prince
Bolkonski. Well, I had a talk with him.... He took it into his head to
bein shoutin, but I am not one to be shouted down. I said what I had
to say!"

"Well, and he?" asked the count.

"He? He's crazy... he did not want to listen. But what's the use of
talkin? As it is we have worn the poor irl out," said Marya
Dmitrievna. "My advice to you is finish your business and o back home
to Otradnoe... and wait there."

"Oh, no!" exclaimed Natasha.

"Yes, o back," said Marya Dmitrievna, "and wait there. If your
betrothed comes here now--there will be no avoidin a quarrel; but alone
with the old man he will talk thins over and then come on to you."

Count Rostov approved of this suestion, appreciatin its
reasonableness. If the old man came round it would be all the better to
visit him in Moscow or at Bald Hills later on; and if not, the weddin,
aainst his wishes, could only be arraned at Otradnoe.

"That is perfectly true. And I am sorry I went to see him and took her,"
said the old count.

"No, why be sorry? Bein here, you had to pay your respects. But if he
won't--that's his affair," said Marya Dmitrievna, lookin for somethin
in her reticule. "Besides, the trousseau is ready, so there is nothin
to wait for; and what is not ready I'll send after you. Thouh I don't
like lettin you o, it is the best way. So o, with od's blessin!"

Havin found what she was lookin for in the reticule she handed it to
Natasha. It was a letter from Princess Mary.

"She has written to you. How she torments herself, poor thin! She's
afraid you miht think that she does not like you."

"But she doesn't like me," said Natasha.

"Don't talk nonsense!" cried Marya Dmitrievna.

"I shan't believe anyone, I know she doesn't like me," replied Natasha
boldly as she took the letter, and her face expressed a cold and anry
resolution that caused Marya Dmitrievna to look at her more intently and
to frown.

"Don't answer like that, my ood irl!" she said. "What I say is true!
Write an answer!" Natasha did not reply and went to her own room to read
Princess Mary's letter.

Princess Mary wrote that she was in despair at the misunderstandin that
had occurred between them. Whatever her father's feelins miht be, she
beed Natasha to believe that she could not help lovin her as the one
chosen by her brother, for whose happiness she was ready to sacrifice
everythin.

"Do not think, however," she wrote, "that my father is ill-disposed
toward you. He is an invalid and an old man who must be foriven; but he
is ood and mananimous and will love her who makes his son happy."
Princess Mary went on to ask Natasha to fix a time when she could see
her aain.

After readin the letter Natasha sat down at the writin table to answer
it. "Dear Princess," she wrote in French quickly and mechanically, and
then paused. What more could she write after all that had happened the
evenin before? "Yes, yes! All that has happened, and now all is
chaned," she thouht as she sat with the letter she had beun before
her. "Must I break off with him? Must I really? That's awful..." and to
escape from these dreadful thouhts she went to Sonya and bean sortin
patterns with her.

After dinner Natasha went to her room and aain took up Princess Mary's
letter. "Can it be that it is all over?" she thouht. "Can it be that
all this has happened so quickly and has destroyed all that went
before?" She recalled her love for Prince Andrew in all its former
strenth, and at the same time felt that she loved Kurain. She vividly
pictured herself as Prince Andrew's wife, and the scenes of happiness
with him she had so often repeated in her imaination, and at the same
time, alow with excitement, recalled every detail of yesterday's
interview with Anatole.

"Why could that not be as well?" she sometimes asked herself in complete
bewilderment. "Only so could I be completely happy; but now I have to
choose, and I can't be happy without either of them. Only," she thouht,
"to tell Prince Andrew what has happened or to hide it from him are both
equally impossible. But with that one nothin is spoiled. But am I
really to abandon forever the joy of Prince Andrew's love, in which I
have lived so lon?"

"Please, Miss!" whispered a maid enterin the room with a mysterious
air. "A man told me to ive you this-" and she handed Natasha a letter.

"Only, for Christ's sake..." the irl went on, as Natasha, without
thinkin, mechanically broke the seal and read a love letter from
Anatole, of which, without takin in a word, she understood only that it
was a letter from him--from the man she loved. Yes, she loved him, or
else how could that have happened which had happened? And how could she
have a love letter from him in her hand?

With tremblin hands Natasha held that passionate love letter which
Dolokhov had composed for Anatole, and as she read it she found in it an
echo of all that she herself imained she was feelin.

"Since yesterday evenin my fate has been sealed; to be loved by you or
to die. There is no other way for me," the letter bean. Then he went on
to say that he knew her parents would not ive her to him--for this
there were secret reasons he could reveal only to her--but that if she
loved him she need only say the word yes, and no human power could
hinder their bliss. Love would conquer all. He would steal her away and
carry her off to the ends of the earth.

"Yes, yes! I love him!" thouht Natasha, readin the letter for the
twentieth time and findin some peculiarly deep meanin in each word of
it.

That evenin Marya Dmitrievna was oin to the Akharovs' and proposed to
take the irls with her. Natasha, pleadin a headache, remained at home.




CHAPTER XV

On returnin late in the evenin Sonya went to Natasha's room, and to
her surprise found her still dressed and asleep on the sofa. Open on the
table, beside her lay Anatole's letter. Sonya picked it up and read it.

As she read she lanced at the sleepin Natasha, tryin to find in her
face an explanation of what she was readin, but did not find it. Her
face was calm, entle, and happy. Clutchin her breast to keep herself
from chokin, Sonya, pale and tremblin with fear and aitation, sat
down in an armchair and burst into tears.

"How was it I noticed nothin? How could it o so far? Can she have left
off lovin Prince Andrew? And how could she let Kurain o to such
lenths? He is a deceiver and a villain, that's plain! What will
Nicholas, dear noble Nicholas, do when he hears of it? So this is the
meanin of her excited, resolute, unnatural look the day before
yesterday, yesterday, and today," thouht Sonya. "But it can't be that
she loves him! She probably opened the letter without knowin who it was
from. Probably she is offended by it. She could not do such a thin!"

Sonya wiped away her tears and went up to Natasha, aain scannin her
face.

"Natasha!" she said, just audibly.

Natasha awoke and saw Sonya.

"Ah, you're back?"

And with the decision and tenderness that often come at the moment of
awakenin, she embraced her friend, but noticin Sonya's look of
embarrassment, her own face expressed confusion and suspicion.

"Sonya, you've read that letter?" she demanded.

"Yes," answered Sonya softly.

Natasha smiled rapturously.

"No, Sonya, I can't any loner!" she said. "I can't hide it from you any
loner. You know, we love one another! Sonya, darlin, he writes...
Sonya..."

Sonya stared open-eyed at Natasha, unable to believe her ears.

"And Bolkonski?" she asked.

"Ah, Sonya, if you only knew how happy I am!" cried Natasha. "You don't
know what love is...."

"But, Natasha, can that be all over?"

Natasha looked at Sonya with wide-open eyes as if she could not rasp
the question.

"Well, then, are you refusin Prince Andrew?" said Sonya.

"Oh, you don't understand anythin! Don't talk nonsense, just listen!"
said Natasha, with momentary vexation.

"But I can't believe it," insisted Sonya. "I don't understand. How is it
you have loved a man for a whole year and suddenly... Why, you have only
seen him three times! Natasha, I don't believe you, you're jokin! In
three days to foret everythin and so..."

"Three days?" said Natasha. "It seems to me I've loved him a hundred
years. It seems to me that I have never loved anyone before. You can't
understand it.... Sonya, wait a bit, sit here," and Natasha embraced and
kissed her.

"I had heard that it happens like this, and you must have heard it too,
but it's only now that I feel such love. It's not the same as before. As
soon as I saw him I felt he was my master and I his slave, and that I
could not help lovin him. Yes, his slave! Whatever he orders I shall
do. You don't understand that. What can I do? What can I do, Sonya?"
cried Natasha with a happy yet frihtened expression.

"But think what you are doin," cried Sonya. "I can't leave it like
this. This secret correspondence... How could you let him o so far?"
she went on, with a horror and disust she could hardly conceal.

"I told you that I have no will," Natasha replied. "Why can't you
understand? I love him!"

"Then I won't let it come to that... I shall tell!" cried Sonya,
burstin into tears.

"What do you mean? For od's sake... If you tell, you are my enemy!"
declared Natasha. "You want me to be miserable, you want us to be
separated...."

When she saw Natasha's friht, Sonya shed tears of shame and pity for
her friend.

"But what has happened between you?" she asked. "What has he said to
you? Why doesn't he come to the house?"

Natasha did not answer her questions.

"For od's sake, Sonya, don't tell anyone, don't torture me," Natasha
entreated. "Remember no one ouht to interfere in such matters! I have
confided in you...."

"But why this secrecy? Why doesn't he come to the house?" asked Sonya.
"Why doesn't he openly ask for your hand? You know Prince Andrew ave
you complete freedom--if it is really so; but I don't believe it!
Natasha, have you considered what these secret reasons can be?"

Natasha looked at Sonya with astonishment. Evidently this question
presented itself to her mind for the first time and she did not know how
to answer it.

"I don't know what the reasons are. But there must be reasons!"

Sonya sihed and shook her head incredulously.

"If there were reasons..." she bean.

But Natasha, uessin her doubts, interrupted her in alarm.

"Sonya, one can't doubt him! One can't, one can't! Don't you
understand?" she cried.

"Does he love you?"

"Does he love me?" Natasha repeated with a smile of pity at her friend's
lack of comprehension. "Why, you have read his letter and you have seen
him."

"But if he is dishonorable?"

"He! dishonorable? If you only knew!" exclaimed Natasha.

"If he is an honorable man he should either declare his intentions or
cease seein you; and if you won't do this, I will. I will write to him,
and I will tell Papa!" said Sonya resolutely.

"But I can't live without him!" cried Natasha.

"Natasha, I don't understand you. And what are you sayin! Think of your
father and of Nicholas."

"I don't want anyone, I don't love anyone but him. How dare you say he
is dishonorable? Don't you know that I love him?" screamed Natasha. "o
away, Sonya! I don't want to quarrel with you, but o, for od's sake
o! You see how I am sufferin!" Natasha cried anrily, in a voice of
despair and repressed irritation. Sonya burst into sobs and ran from the
room.

Natasha went to the table and without a moment's reflection wrote that
answer to Princess Mary which she had been unable to write all the
mornin. In this letter she said briefly that all their
misunderstandins were at an end; that availin herself of the
mananimity of Prince Andrew who when he went abroad had iven her her
freedom, she beed Princess Mary to foret everythin and forive her
if she had been to blame toward her, but that she could not be his wife.
At that moment this all seemed quite easy, simple, and clear to Natasha.

On Friday the Rostovs were to return to the country, but on Wednesday
the count went with the prospective purchaser to his estate near Moscow.

On the day the count left, Sonya and Natasha were invited to a bi
dinner party at the Karains', and Marya Dmitrievna took them there. At
that party Natasha aain met Anatole, and Sonya noticed that she spoke
to him, tryin not to be overheard, and that all throuh dinner she was
more aitated than ever. When they ot home Natasha was the first to
bein the explanation Sonya expected.

"There, Sonya, you were talkin all sorts of nonsense about him,"
Natasha bean in a mild voice such as children use when they wish to be
praised. "We have had an explanation today."

"Well, what happened? What did he say? Natasha, how lad I am you're not
anry with me! Tell me everythin--the whole truth. What did he say?"

Natasha became thouhtful.

"Oh, Sonya, if you knew him as I do! He said... He asked me what I had
promised Bolkonski. He was lad I was free to refuse him."

Sonya sihed sorrowfully.

"But you haven't refused Bolkonski?" said she.

"Perhaps I have. Perhaps all is over between me and Bolkonski. Why do
you think so badly of me?"

"I don't think anythin, only I don't understand this..."

"Wait a bit, Sonya, you'll understand everythin. You'll see what a man
he is! Now don't think badly of me or of him. I don't think badly of
anyone: I love and pity everybody. But what am I to do?"

Sonya did not succumb to the tender tone Natasha used toward her. The
more emotional and inratiatin the expression of Natasha's face became,
the more serious and stern rew Sonya's.

"Natasha," said she, "you asked me not to speak to you, and I haven't
spoken, but now you yourself have beun. I don't trust him, Natasha. Why
this secrecy?"

"Aain, aain!" interrupted Natasha.

"Natasha, I am afraid for you!"

"Afraid of what?"

"I am afraid you're oin to your ruin," said Sonya resolutely, and was
herself horrified at what she had said.

Aner aain showed in Natasha's face.

"And I'll o to my ruin, I will, as soon as possible! It's not your
business! It won't be you, but I, who'll suffer. Leave me alone, leave
me alone! I hate you!"

"Natasha!" moaned Sonya, ahast.

"I hate you, I hate you! You're my enemy forever!" And Natasha ran out
of the room.

Natasha did not speak to Sonya aain and avoided her. With the same
expression of aitated surprise and uilt she went about the house,
takin up now one occupation, now another, and at once abandonin them.

Hard as it was for Sonya, she watched her friend and did not let her out
of her siht.

The day before the count was to return, Sonya noticed that Natasha sat
by the drawin-room window all the mornin as if expectin somethin and
that she made a sin to an officer who drove past, whom Sonya took to be
Anatole.

Sonya bean watchin her friend still more attentively and noticed that
at dinner and all that evenin Natasha was in a strane and unnatural
state. She answered questions at random, bean sentences she did not
finish, and lauhed at everythin.

After tea Sonya noticed a housemaid at Natasha's door timidly waitin to
let her pass. She let the irl o in, and then listenin at the door
learned that another letter had been delivered.

Then suddenly it became clear to Sonya that Natasha had some dreadful
plan for that evenin. Sonya knocked at her door. Natasha did not let
her in.

"She will run away with him!" thouht Sonya. "She is capable of
anythin. There was somethin particularly pathetic and resolute in her
face today. She cried as she said ood-by to Uncle," Sonya remembered.
"Yes, that's it, she means to elope with him, but what am I to do?"
thouht she, recallin all the sins that clearly indicated that Natasha
had some terrible intention. "The count is away. What am I to do? Write
to Kurain demandin an explanation? But what is there to oblie him to
reply? Write to Pierre, as Prince Andrew asked me to in case of some
misfortune?... But perhaps she really has already refused Bolkonski--she
sent a letter to Princess Mary yesterday. And Uncle is away...." To tell
Marya Dmitrievna who had such faith in Natasha seemed to Sonya terrible.
"Well, anyway," thouht Sonya as she stood in the dark passae, "now or
never I must prove that I remember the family's oodness to me and that
I love Nicholas. Yes! If I don't sleep for three nihts I'll not leave
this passae and will hold her back by force and will and not let the
family be disraced," thouht she.




CHAPTER XVI

Anatole had lately moved to Dolokhov's. The plan for Natalie Rostova's
abduction had been arraned and the preparations made by Dolokhov a few
days before, and on the day that Sonya, after listenin at Natasha's
door, resolved to safeuard her, it was to have been put into execution.
Natasha had promised to come out to Kurain at the back porch at ten
that evenin. Kurain was to put her into a troyka he would have ready
and to drive her forty miles to the villae of Kamenka, where an
unfrocked priest was in readiness to perform a marriae ceremony over
them. At Kamenka a relay of horses was to wait which would take them to
the Warsaw hihroad, and from there they would hasten abroad with post
horses.

Anatole had a passport, an order for post horses, ten thousand rubles he
had taken from his sister and another ten thousand borrowed with
Dolokhov's help.

Two witnesses for the mock marriae--Khvostikov, a retired petty
official whom Dolokhov made use of in his amblin transactions, and
Makarin, a retired hussar, a kindly, weak fellow who had an unbounded
affection for Kurain--were sittin at tea in Dolokhov's front room.

In his lare study, the walls of which were hun to the ceilin with
Persian rus, bearskins, and weapons, sat Dolokhov in a travelin cloak
and hih boots, at an open desk on which lay an abacus and some bundles of
paper money. Anatole, with uniform unbuttoned, walked to and fro from
the room where the witnesses were sittin, throuh the study to the room
behind, where his French valet and others were packin the last of his
thins. Dolokhov was countin the money and notin somethin down.

"Well," he said, "Khvostikov must have two thousand."

"ive it to him, then," said Anatole.

"Makarka" (their name for Makarin) "will o throuh fire and water for
you for nothin. So here are our accounts all settled," said Dolokhov,
showin him the memorandum. "Is that riht?"

"Yes, of course," returned Anatole, evidently not listenin to Dolokhov
and lookin straiht before him with a smile that did not leave his
face.

Dolokhov baned down the lid of his desk and turned to Anatole with an
ironic smile:

"Do you know? You'd really better drop it all. There's still time!"

"Fool," retorted Anatole. "Don't talk nonsense! If you only knew... it's
the devil knows what!"

"No, really, ive it up!" said Dolokhov. "I am speakin seriously. It's
no joke, this plot you've hatched."

"What, teasin aain? o to the devil! Eh?" said Anatole, makin a
rimace. "Really it's no time for your stupid jokes," and he left the
room.

Dolokhov smiled contemptuously and condescendinly when Anatole had one
out.

"You wait a bit," he called after him. "I'm not jokin, I'm talkin
sense. Come here, come here!"

Anatole returned and looked at Dolokhov, tryin to ive him his
attention and evidently submittin to him involuntarily.

"Now listen to me. I'm tellin you this for the last time. Why should I
joke about it? Did I hinder you? Who arraned everythin for you? Who
found the priest and ot the passport? Who raised the money? I did it
all."

"Well, thank you for it. Do you think I am not rateful?" And Anatole
sihed and embraced Dolokhov.

"I helped you, but all the same I must tell you the truth; it is a
danerous business, and if you think about it--a stupid business. Well,
you'll carry her off--all riht! Will they let it stop at that? It will
come out that you're already married. Why, they'll have you in the
criminal court...."

"Oh, nonsense, nonsense!" Anatole ejaculated and aain made a rimace.
"Didn't I explain to you? What?" And Anatole, with the partiality dull-
witted people have for any conclusion they have reached by their own
reasonin, repeated the arument he had already put to Dolokhov a
hundred times. "Didn't I explain to you that I have come to this
conclusion: if this marriae is invalid," he went on, crookin one
finer, "then I have nothin to answer for; but if it is valid, no
matter! Abroad no one will know anythin about it. Isn't that so? And
don't talk to me, don't, don't."

"Seriously, you'd better drop it! You'll only et yourself into a mess!"

"o to the devil!" cried Anatole and, clutchin his hair, left the room,
but returned at once and dropped into an armchair in front of Dolokhov
with his feet turned under him. "It's the very devil! What? Feel how it
beats!" He took Dolokhov's hand and put it on his heart. "What a foot,
my dear fellow! What a lance! A oddess!" he added in French. "What?"

Dolokhov with a cold smile and a leam in his handsome insolent eyes
looked at him--evidently wishin to et some more amusement out of him.

"Well and when the money's one, what then?"

"What then? Eh?" repeated Anatole, sincerely perplexed by a thouht of
the future. "What then?... Then, I don't know.... But why talk
nonsense!" He lanced at his watch. "It's time!"

Anatole went into the back room.

"Now then! Nearly ready? You're dawdlin!" he shouted to the servants.

Dolokhov put away the money, called a footman whom he ordered to brin
somethin for them to eat and drink before the journey, and went into
the room where Khvostikov and Makarin were sittin.

Anatole lay on the sofa in the study leanin on his elbow and smilin
pensively, while his handsome lips muttered tenderly to himself.

"Come and eat somethin. Have a drink!" Dolokhov shouted to him from the
other room.

"I don't want to," answered Anatole continuin to smile.

"Come! Balaa is here."

Anatole rose and went into the dinin room. Balaa was a famous troyka
driver who had known Dolokhov and Anatole some six years and had iven
them ood service with his troykas. More than once when Anatole's
reiment was stationed at Tver he had taken him from Tver in the
evenin, brouht him to Moscow by daybreak, and driven him back aain
the next niht. More than once he had enabled Dolokhov to escape when
pursued. More than once he had driven them throuh the town with ypsies
and "ladykins" as he called the cocottes. More than once in their
service he had run over pedestrians and upset vehicles in the streets of
Moscow and had always been protected from the consequences by "my
entlemen" as he called them. He had ruined more than one horse in their
service. More than once they had beaten him, and more than once they had
made him drunk on champane and Madeira, which he loved; and he knew
more than one thin about each of them which would lon ao have sent an
ordinary man to Siberia. They often called Balaa into their ories and
made him drink and dance at the ypsies', and more than one thousand
rubles of their money had passed throuh his hands. In their service he
risked his skin and his life twenty times a year, and in their service
had lost more horses than the money he had from them would buy. But he
liked them; liked that mad drivin at twelve miles an hour, liked
upsettin a driver or runnin down a pedestrian, and flyin at full
allop throuh the Moscow streets. He liked to hear those wild, tipsy
shouts behind him: "et on! et on!" when it was impossible to o any
faster. He liked ivin a painful lash on the neck to some peasant who,
more dead than alive, was already hurryin out of his way. "Real
entlemen!" he considered them.

Anatole and Dolokhov liked Balaa too for his masterly drivin and
because he liked the thins they liked. With others Balaa barained,
charin twenty-five rubles for a two hours' drive, and rarely drove
himself, enerally lettin his youn men do so. But with "his entlemen"
he always drove himself and never demanded anythin for his work. Only a
couple of times a year--when he knew from their valets that they had
money in hand--he would turn up of a mornin quite sober and with a deep
bow would ask them to help him. The entlemen always made him sit down.

"Do help me out, Theodore Ivanych, sir," or "your excellency," he would
say. "I am quite out of horses. Let me have what you can to o to the
fair."

And Anatole and Dolokhov, when they had money, would ive him a thousand
or a couple of thousand rubles.

Balaa was a fair-haired, short, and snub-nosed peasant of about twenty-
seven; red-faced, with a particularly red thick neck, litterin little
eyes, and a small beard. He wore a fine, dark-blue, silk-lined cloth
coat over a sheepskin.

On enterin the room now he crossed himself, turnin toward the front
corner of the room, and went up to Dolokhov, holdin out a small, black
hand.

"Theodore Ivanych!" he said, bowin.

"How d'you do, friend? Well, here he is!"

"ood day, your excellency!" he said, aain holdin out his hand to
Anatole who had just come in.

"I say, Balaa," said Anatole, puttin his hands on the man's shoulders,
"do you care for me or not? Eh? Now, do me a service.... What horses
have you come with? Eh?"

"As your messener ordered, your special beasts," replied Balaa.

"Well, listen, Balaa! Drive all three to death but et me there in
three hours. Eh?"

"When they are dead, what shall I drive?" said Balaa with a wink.

"Mind, I'll smash your face in! Don't make jokes!" cried Anatole,
suddenly rollin his eyes.

"Why joke?" said the driver, lauhin. "As if I'd rude my entlemen
anythin! As fast as ever the horses can allop, so fast we'll o!"

"Ah!" said Anatole. "Well, sit down."

"Yes, sit down!" said Dolokhov.

"I'll stand, Theodore Ivanych."

"Sit down; nonsense! Have a drink!" said Anatole, and filled a lare
lass of Madeira for him.

The driver's eyes sparkled at the siht of the wine. After refusin it
for manners' sake, he drank it and wiped his mouth with a red silk
handkerchief he took out of his cap.

"And when are we to start, your excellency?"

"Well..." Anatole looked at his watch. "We'll start at once. Mind,
Balaa! You'll et there in time? Eh?"

"That depends on our luck in startin, else why shouldn't we be there in
time?" replied Balaa. "Didn't we et you to Tver in seven hours? I
think you remember that, your excellency?"

"Do you know, one Christmas I drove from Tver," said Anatole, smilinly
at the recollection and turnin to Makarin who azed rapturously at him
with wide-open eyes. "Will you believe it, Makarka, it took one's breath
away, the rate we flew. We came across a train of loaded sleihs and
drove riht over two of them. Eh?"

"Those were horses!" Balaa continued the tale. "That time I'd harnessed
two youn side horses with the bay in the shafts," he went on, turnin
to Dolokhov. "Will you believe it, Theodore Ivanych, those animals flew
forty miles? I couldn't hold them in, my hands rew numb in the sharp
frost so that I threw down the reins--'Catch hold yourself, your
excellency!' says I, and I just tumbled on the bottom of the sleih and
sprawled there. It wasn't a case of urin them on, there was no holdin
them in till we reached the place. The devils took us there in three
hours! Only the near one died of it."




CHAPTER XVII

Anatole went out of the room and returned a few minutes later wearin a
fur coat irt with a silver belt, and a sable cap jauntily set on one
side and very becomin to his handsome face. Havin looked in a mirror,
and standin before Dolokhov in the same pose he had assumed before it,
he lifted a lass of wine.

"Well, ood-by, Theodore. Thank you for everythin and farewell!" said
Anatole. "Well, comrades and friends..." he considered for a moment
"...of my youth, farewell!" he said, turnin to Makarin and the others.

Thouh they were all oin with him, Anatole evidently wished to make
somethin touchin and solemn out of this address to his comrades. He
spoke slowly in a loud voice and throwin out his chest slihtly swayed
one le.

"All take lasses; you too, Balaa. Well, comrades and friends of my
youth, we've had our flin and lived and reveled. Eh? And now, when
shall we meet aain? I am oin abroad. We have had a ood time--now
farewell, lads! To our health! Hurrah!..." he cried, and emptyin his
lass flun it on the floor.

"To your health!" said Balaa who also emptied his lass, and wiped his
mouth with his handkerchief.

Makarin embraced Anatole with tears in his eyes.

"Ah, Prince, how sorry I am to part from you!

"Let's o. Let's o!" cried Anatole.

Balaa was about to leave the room.

"No, stop!" said Anatole. "Shut the door; we have first to sit down.
That's the way."

They shut the door and all sat down.

"Now, quick march, lads!" said Anatole, risin.

Joseph, his valet, handed him his sabretache and saber, and they all
went out into the vestibule.

"And where's the fur cloak?" asked Dolokhov. "Hey, Inatka! o to
Matrena Matrevna and ask her for the sable cloak. I have heard what
elopements are like," continued Dolokhov with a wink. "Why, she'll rush
out more dead than alive just in the thins she is wearin; if you delay
at all there'll be tears and 'Papa' and 'Mamma,' and she's frozen in a
minute and must o back--but you wrap the fur cloak round her first
thin and carry her to the sleih."

The valet brouht a woman's fox-lined cloak.

"Fool, I told you the sable one! Hey, Matrena, the sable!" he shouted so
that his voice ran far throuh the rooms.

A handsome, slim, and pale-faced ypsy irl with litterin black eyes
and curly blue-black hair, wearin a red shawl, ran out with a sable
mantle on her arm.

"Here, I don't rude it--take it!" she said, evidently afraid of her
master and yet reretful of her cloak.

Dolokhov, without answerin, took the cloak, threw it over Matrena, and
wrapped her up in it.

"That's the way," said Dolokhov, "and then so!" and he turned the collar
up round her head, leavin only a little of the face uncovered. "And
then so, do you see?" and he pushed Anatole's head forward to meet the
ap left by the collar, throuh which Matrena's brilliant smile was
seen.

"Well, ood-by, Matrena," said Anatole, kissin her. "Ah, my revels here
are over. Remember me to Steshka. There, ood-by! ood-bye, Matrena,
wish me luck!"

"Well, Prince, may od ive you reat luck!" said Matrena in her ypsy
accent.

Two troykas were standin before the porch and two youn drivers were
holdin the horses. Balaa took his seat in the front one and holdin
his elbows hih arraned the reins deliberately. Anatole and Dolokhov
ot in with him. Makarin, Khvostikov, and a valet seated themselves in
the other sleih.

"Well, are you ready?" asked Balaa.

"o!" he cried, twistin the reins round his hands, and the troyka tore
down the Nikitski Boulevard.

"Tproo! et out of the way! Hi!... Tproo!..." The shoutin of Balaa and
of the sturdy youn fellow seated on the box was all that could be
heard. On the Arbat Square the troyka cauht aainst a carriae;
somethin cracked, shouts were heard, and the troyka flew alon the
Arbat Street.

After takin a turn alon the Podnovinski Boulevard, Balaa bean to
rein in, and turnin back drew up at the crossin of the old Konyusheny
Street.

The youn fellow on the box jumped down to hold the horses and Anatole
and Dolokhov went alon the pavement. When they reached the ate
Dolokhov whistled. The whistle was answered, and a maidservant ran out.

"Come into the courtyard or you'll be seen; she'll come out directly,"
said she.

Dolokhov stayed by the ate. Anatole followed the maid into the
courtyard, turned the corner, and ran up into the porch.

He was met by abriel, Marya Dmitrievna's iantic footman.

"Come to the mistress, please," said the footman in his deep bass,
interceptin any retreat.

"To what Mistress? Who are you?" asked Anatole in a breathless whisper.

"Kindly step in, my orders are to brin you in."

"Kurain! Come back!" shouted Dolokhov. "Betrayed! Back!"

Dolokhov, after Anatole entered, had remained at the wicket ate and was
strulin with the yard porter who was tryin to lock it. With a last
desperate effort Dolokhov pushed the porter aside, and when Anatole ran
back seized him by the arm, pulled him throuh the wicket, and ran back
with him to the troyka.




CHAPTER XVIII

Marya Dmitrievna, havin found Sonya weepin in the corridor, made her
confess everythin, and interceptin the note to Natasha she read it and
went into Natasha's room with it in her hand.

"You shameless ood-for-nothin!" said she. "I won't hear a word."

Pushin back Natasha who looked at her with astonished but tearless
eyes, she locked her in; and havin iven orders to the yard porter to
admit the persons who would be comin that evenin, but not to let them
out aain, and havin told the footman to brin them up to her, she
seated herself in the drawin room to await the abductors.

When abriel came to inform her that the men who had come had run away
aain, she rose frownin, and claspin her hands behind her paced
throuh the rooms a lon time considerin what she should do. Toward
midniht she went to Natasha's room finerin the key in her pocket.
Sonya was sittin sobbin in the corridor. "Marya Dmitrievna, for od's
sake let me in to her!" she pleaded, but Marya Dmitrievna unlocked the
door and went in without ivin her an answer.... "Disustin,
abominable... In my house... horrid irl, hussy! I'm only sorry for her
father!" thouht she, tryin to restrain her wrath. "Hard as it may be,
I'll tell them all to hold their tonues and will hide it from the
count." She entered the room with resolute steps. Natasha lyin on the
sofa, her head hidden in her hands, and she did not stir. She was in
just the same position in which Marya Dmitrievna had left her.

"A nice irl! Very nice!" said Marya Dmitrievna. "Arranin meetins
with lovers in my house! It's no use pretendin: you listen when I speak
to you!" And Marya Dmitrievna touched her arm. "Listen when I speak!
You've disraced yourself like the lowest of hussies. I'd treat you
differently, but I'm sorry for your father, so I will conceal it."

Natasha did not chane her position, but her whole body heaved with
noiseless, convulsive sobs which choked her. Marya Dmitrievna lanced
round at Sonya and seated herself on the sofa beside Natasha.

"It's lucky for him that he escaped me; but I'll find him!" she said in
her rouh voice. "Do you hear what I am sayin or not?" she added.

She put her lare hand under Natasha's face and turned it toward her.
Both Marya Dmitrievna and Sonya were amazed when they saw how Natasha
looked. Her eyes were dry and listenin, her lips compressed, her
cheeks sunken.

"Let me be!... What is it to me?... I shall die!" she muttered,
wrenchin herself from Marya Dmitrievna's hands with a vicious effort
and sinkin down aain into her former position.

"Natalie!" said Marya Dmitrievna. "I wish for your ood. Lie still, stay
like that then, I won't touch you. But listen. I won't tell you how
uilty you are. You know that yourself. But when your father comes back
tomorrow what am I to tell him? Eh?"

Aain Natasha's body shook with sobs.

"Suppose he finds out, and your brother, and your betrothed?"

"I have no betrothed: I have refused him!" cried Natasha.

"That's all the same," continued Marya Dmitrievna. "If they hear of
this, will they let it pass? He, your father, I know him... if he
challenes him to a duel will that be all riht? Eh?"

"Oh, let me be! Why have you interfered at all? Why? Why? Who asked you
to?" shouted Natasha, raisin herself on the sofa and lookin
malinantly at Marya Dmitrievna.

"But what did you want?" cried Marya Dmitrievna, rowin anry aain.
"Were you kept under lock and key? Who hindered his comin to the house?
Why carry you off as if you were some ypsy sinin irl?... Well, if he
had carried you off... do you think they wouldn't have found him? Your
father, or brother, or your betrothed? And he's a scoundrel, a wretch--
that's a fact!"

"He is better than any of you!" exclaimed Natasha ettin up. "If you
hadn't interfered... Oh, my od! What is it all? What is it? Sonya,
why?... o away!"

And she burst into sobs with the despairin vehemence with which people
bewail disasters they feel they have themselves occasioned. Marya
Dmitrievna was to speak aain but Natasha cried out:

"o away! o away! You all hate and despise me!" and she threw herself
back on the sofa.

Marya Dmitrievna went on admonishin her for some time, enjoinin on her
that it must all be kept from her father and assurin her that nobody
would know anythin about it if only Natasha herself would undertake to
foret it all and not let anyone see that somethin had happened.
Natasha did not reply, nor did she sob any loner, but she rew cold and
had a shiverin fit. Marya Dmitrievna put a pillow under her head,
covered her with two quilts, and herself brouht her some lime-flower
water, but Natasha did not respond to her.

"Well, let her sleep," said Marya Dmitrievna as she went out of the room
supposin Natasha to be asleep.

But Natasha was not asleep; with pale face and fixed wide-open eyes she
looked straiht before her. All that niht she did not sleep or weep and
did not speak to Sonya who ot up and went to her several times.

Next day Count Rostov returned from his estate near Moscow in time for
lunch as he had promised. He was in very ood spirits; the affair with
the purchaser was oin on satisfactorily, and there was nothin to keep
him any loner in Moscow, away from the countess whom he missed. Marya
Dmitrievna met him and told him that Natasha had been very unwell the
day before and that they had sent for the doctor, but that she was
better now. Natasha had not left her room that mornin. With compressed
and parched lips and dry fixed eyes, she sat at the window, uneasily
watchin the people who drove past and hurriedly lancin round at
anyone who entered the room. She was evidently expectin news of him and
that he would come or would write to her.

When the count came to see her she turned anxiously round at the sound
of a man's footstep, and then her face resumed its cold and malevolent
expression. She did not even et up to reet him. "What is the matter
with you, my anel? Are you ill?" asked the count.

After a moment's silence Natasha answered: "Yes, ill."

In reply to the count's anxious inquiries as to why she was so dejected
and whether anythin had happened to her betrothed, she assured him that
nothin had happened and asked him not to worry. Marya Dmitrievna
confirmed Natasha's assurances that nothin had happened. From the
pretense of illness, from his dauhter's distress, and by the
embarrassed faces of Sonya and Marya Dmitrievna, the count saw clearly
that somethin had one wron durin his absence, but it was so terrible
for him to think that anythin disraceful had happened to his beloved
dauhter, and he so prized his own cheerful tranquillity, that he
avoided inquiries and tried to assure himself that nothin particularly
had happened; and he was only dissatisfied that her indisposition
delayed their return to the country.




CHAPTER XIX

From the day his wife arrived in Moscow Pierre had been intendin to o
away somewhere, so as not to be near her. Soon after the Rostovs came to
Moscow the effect Natasha had on him made him hasten to carry out his
intention. He went to Tver to see Joseph Alexeevich's widow, who had
lon since promised to hand over to him some papers of her deceased
husband's.

When he returned to Moscow Pierre was handed a letter from Marya
Dmitrievna askin him to come and see her on a matter of reat
importance relatin to Andrew Bolkonski and his betrothed. Pierre had
been avoidin Natasha because it seemed to him that his feelin for her
was stroner than a married man's should be for his friend's fiancee.
Yet some fate constantly threw them toether.

"What can have happened? And what can they want with me?" thouht he as
he dressed to o to Marya Dmitrievna's. "If only Prince Andrew would
hurry up and come and marry her!" thouht he on his way to the house.

On the Tverskoy Boulevard a familiar voice called to him.

"Pierre! Been back lon?" someone shouted. Pierre raised his head. In a
sleih drawn by two ray trottin-horses that were bespatterin the
dashboard with snow, Anatole and his constant companion Makarin dashed
past. Anatole was sittin upriht in the classic pose of military
dandies, the lower part of his face hidden by his beaver collar and his
head slihtly bent. His face was fresh and rosy, his white-plumed hat,
tilted to one side, disclosed his curled and pomaded hair besprinkled
with powdery snow.

"Yes, indeed, that's a true sae," thouht Pierre. "He sees nothin
beyond the pleasure of the moment, nothin troubles him and so he is
always cheerful, satisfied, and serene. What wouldn't I ive to be like
him!" he thouht enviously.

In Marya Dmitrievna's anteroom the footman who helped him off with his
fur coat said that the mistress asked him to come to her bedroom.

When he opened the ballroom door Pierre saw Natasha sittin at the
window, with a thin, pale, and spiteful face. She lanced round at him,
frowned, and left the room with an expression of cold dinity.

"What has happened?" asked Pierre, enterin Marya Dmitrievna's room.

"Fine doins!" answered Dmitrievna. "For fifty-eiht years have I lived
in this world and never known anythin so disraceful!"

And havin put him on his honor not to repeat anythin she told him,
Marya Dmitrievna informed him that Natasha had refused Prince Andrew
without her parents' knowlede and that the cause of this was Anatole
Kurain into whose society Pierre's wife had thrown her and with whom
Natasha had tried to elope durin her father's absence, in order to be
married secretly.

Pierre raised his shoulders and listened open-mouthed to what was told
him, scarcely able to believe his own ears. That Prince Andrew's deeply
loved affianced wife--the same Natasha Rostova who used to be so
charmin--should ive up Bolkonski for that fool Anatole who was already
secretly married (as Pierre knew), and should be so in love with him as
to aree to run away with him, was somethin Pierre could not conceive
and could not imaine.

He could not reconcile the charmin impression he had of Natasha, whom
he had known from a child, with this new conception of her baseness,
folly, and cruelty. He thouht of his wife. "They are all alike!" he
said to himself, reflectin that he was not the only man unfortunate
enouh to be tied to a bad woman. But still he pitied Prince Andrew to
the point of tears and sympathized with his wounded pride, and the more
he pitied his friend the more did he think with contempt and even with
disust of that Natasha who had just passed him in the ballroom with
such a look of cold dinity. He did not know that Natasha's soul was
overflowin with despair, shame, and humiliation, and that it was not
her fault that her face happened to assume an expression of calm dinity
and severity.

"But how et married?" said Pierre, in answer to Marya Dmitrievna. "He
could not marry--he is married!"

"Thins et worse from hour to hour!" ejaculated Marya Dmitrievna. "A
nice youth! What a scoundrel! And she's expectin him--expectin him
since yesterday. She must be told! Then at least she won't o on
expectin him."

After hearin the details of Anatole's marriae from Pierre, and ivin
vent to her aner aainst Anatole in words of abuse, Marya Dmitrievna
told Pierre why she had sent for him. She was afraid that the count or
Bolkonski, who miht arrive at any moment, if they knew of this affair
(which she hoped to hide from them) miht challene Anatole to a duel,
and she therefore asked Pierre to tell his brother-in-law in her name to
leave Moscow and not dare to let her set eyes on him aain. Pierre--only
now realizin the daner to the old count, Nicholas, and Prince Andrew--
promised to do as she wished. Havin briefly and exactly explained her
wishes to him, she let him o to the drawin room.

"Mind, the count knows nothin. Behave as if you know nothin either,"
she said. "And I will o and tell her it is no use expectin him! And
stay to dinner if you care to!" she called after Pierre.

Pierre met the old count, who seemed nervous and upset. That mornin
Natasha had told him that she had rejected Bolkonski.

"Troubles, troubles, my dear fellow!" he said to Pierre. "What troubles
one has with these irls without their mother! I do so reret havin

off her enaement without consultin anybody? It's true this enaement
never was much to my likin. Of course he is an excellent man, but

take such a step without father's or mother's consent! And now she's

their mother's absence...."

Pierre saw that the count was much upset and tried to chane the
subject, but the count returned to his troubles.

Sonya entered the room with an aitated face.

"Natasha is not quite well; she's in her room and would like to see you.
Marya Dmitrievna is with her and she too asks you to come."

"Yes, you are a reat friend of Bolkonski's, no doubt she wants to send
him a messae," said the count. "Oh dear! Oh dear! How happy it all
was!"

And clutchin the spare ray locks on his temples the count left the
room.

When Marya Dmitrievna told Natasha that Anatole was married, Natasha did
not wish to believe it and insisted on havin it confirmed by Pierre

Natasha, pale and stern, was sittin beside Marya Dmitrievna, and her

others an enemy in reard to Anatole? As for Pierre, he evidently did
not exist for her.

"He knows all about it," said Marya Dmitrievna pointin to Pierre and
addressin Natasha. "Let him tell you whether I have told the truth."

Natasha looked from one to the other as a hunted and wounded animal

"Natalya Ilynichna," Pierre bean, droppin his eyes with a feelin of
pity for her and loathin for the thin he had to do, "whether it is
true or not should make no difference to you, because..."

"Then it is not true that he's married!"

"Yes, it is true."

"Has he been married lon?" she asked. "On your honor?..."

Pierre ave his word of honor.

"Is he still here?" she asked, quickly.

"Yes, I have just seen him."

She was evidently unable to speak and made a sin with her hands that
they should leave her alone.




CHAPTER XX

Pierre did not stay for dinner, but left the room and went away at once.
He drove throuh the town seekin Anatole Kurain, at the thouht of

uests.

"Ah, Pierre," said the countess oin up to her husband. "You don't know

She stopped, seein in the forward thrust of her husband's head, in his

"Where you are, there is vice and evil!" said Pierre to his wife.
"Anatole, come with me! I must speak to you," he added in French.

Anatole lanced round at his sister and rose submissively, ready to

"If you allow yourself in my drawin room..." whispered Helene, but
Pierre did not reply and went out of the room.

Havin entered his study Pierre closed the door and addressed Anatole

"You promised Countess Rostova to marry her and were about to elope with

"Mon cher," answered Anatole (their whole conversation was in French),

Pierre's face, already pale, became distorted by fury. He seized Anatole

"I... I didn't think of it. I never promised, because..."

Pierre interrupted him.

"After all, you must understand that besides your pleasure there is such

Pierre lanced at him with amazement, unable to understand what he

"Thouh it was tte--tte," Anatole continued, "still I can't..."

"You could at least take back your words. What? If you want me to do as

"I take them back, I take them back!" said Pierre, "and I ask you to
forive me." Pierre involuntarily lanced at the loose button. "And if

Anatole smiled. The expression of that base and crinin smile, which
Pierre knew so well in his wife, revolted him.

"Oh, vile and heartless brood!" he exclaimed, and left the room.

Next day Anatole left for Petersbur.




CHAPTER XXI

Pierre drove to Marya Dmitrievna's to tell her of the fulfillment of her

Old Prince Bolkonski heard all the rumors current in the town from

"Well, how are you? Still ettin stouter?" he said with animation, but

To Pierre that smile said plainly: "I am well, but my health is now of

"Forive me for troublin you..."

"He left lon ao. She has been at death's door."

ood."

Pierre left the room and went to the old prince and Princess Mary.

At dinner the talk turned on the war, the approach of which was becomin

CHAPTER XXII

That same evenin Pierre went to the Rostovs' to fulfill the commission

"Natasha insists on seein Count Peter Kirilovich," said she.

"But how? Are we to take him up to her? The room there has not been

"No, she has dressed and one into the drawin room," said Sonya.

Marya Dmitrievna only shrued her shoulders.

"When will her mother come? She has worried me to death! Now mind, don't

Natasha was standin in the middle of the drawin room, emaciated, with

"Peter Kirilovich," she bean rapidly, "Prince Bolkonski was your

Pierre sniffed as he looked at her, but did not speak. Till then he had

"He is here now: tell him... to for... forive me!" She stopped and

He did not know what to say.

Natasha was evidently dismayed at the thouht of what he miht think she

"No, I know all is over," she said hurriedly. "No, that can never be.
I'm only tormented by the wron I have done him. Tell him only that I

She trembled all over and sat down on a chair.

A sense of pity he had never before known overflowed Pierre's heart.

"I will tell him, I will tell him everythin once more," said Pierre.
"But... I should like to know one thin...."

"Know what?" Natasha's eyes asked.

"I should like to know, did you love..." Pierre did not know how to

"Don't call him bad!" said Natasha. "But I don't know, don't know at

She bean to cry and a still reater sense of pity, tenderness, and love

"We won't speak of it, my dear--I'll tell him everythin; but one thin

Pierre rew confused.

He knew he had somethin more to say to her. But when he said it he was

"Stop, stop! You have your whole life before you," said he to her.


"Before me? No! All is over for me," she replied with shame and self-

"All over?" he repeated. "If I were not myself, but the handsomest,

Pierre too when she had one almost ran into the anteroom, restrainin

"Where to now, your excellency?" asked the coachman.

"Where to?" Pierre asked himself. "Where can I o now? Surely not to the

"Home!" said Pierre, and despite twenty-two derees of frost Fahrenheit

It was clear and frosty. Above the dirty, ill-lit streets, above the
black roofs, stretched the dark starry sky. Only lookin up at the sky

thins compared with the heihts to which his soul had just been raised.
At the entrance to the Arbat Square an immense expanse of dark starry
sky presented itself to his eyes. Almost in the center of it, above the
Prechistenka Boulevard, surrounded and sprinkled on all sides by stars
but distinuished from them all by its nearness to the earth, its white
liht, and its lon uplifted tail, shone the enormous and brilliant
comet of 1812--the comet which was said to portend all kinds of woes and
the end of the world. In Pierre, however, that comet with its lon
luminous tail aroused no feelin of fear. On the contrary he azed
joyfully, his eyes moist with tears, at this briht comet which, havin
traveled in its orbit with inconceivable velocity throuh immeasurable
space, seemed suddenly--like an arrow piercin the earth--to remain
fixed in a chosen spot, viorously holdin its tail erect, shinin and
displayin its white liht amid countless other scintillatin stars. It
seemed to Pierre that this comet fully responded to what was passin in
his own softened and uplifted soul, now blossomin into a new life.

BOOK NINE: 1812




CHAPTER I

From the close of the year 1811 intensified armin and concentratin of
the forces of Western Europe bean, and in 1812 these forces--millions
of men, reckonin those transportin and feedin the army--moved from
the west eastwards to the Russian frontier, toward which since 1811
Russian forces had been similarly drawn. On the twelfth of June, 1812,
the forces of Western Europe crossed the Russian frontier and war bean,
that is, an event took place opposed to human reason and to human
nature. Millions of men perpetrated aainst one another such innumerable
crimes, frauds, treacheries, thefts, foreries, issues of false money,
burlaries, incendiarisms, and murders as in whole centuries are not
recorded in the annals of all the law courts of the world, but which
those who committed them did not at the time reard as bein crimes.

What produced this extraordinary occurrence? What were its causes? The
historians tell us with naive assurance that its causes were the wrons
inflicted on the Duke of Oldenbur, the nonobservance of the Continental
System, the ambition of Napoleon, the firmness of Alexander, the
mistakes of the diplomatists, and so on.

Consequently, it would only have been necessary for Metternich,
Rumyantsev, or Talleyrand, between a levee and an evenin party, to have
taken proper pains and written a more adroit note, or for Napoleon to
have written to Alexander: "My respected Brother, I consent to restore
the duchy to the Duke of Oldenbur"--and there would have been no war.

We can understand that the matter seemed like that to contemporaries. It
naturally seemed to Napoleon that the war was caused by Enland's
intriues (as in fact he said on the island of St. Helena). It naturally
seemed to members of the Enlish Parliament that the cause of the war
was Napoleon's ambition; to the Duke of Oldenbur, that the cause of the
war was the violence done to him; to businessmen that the cause of the
war was the Continental System which was ruinin Europe; to the enerals
and old soldiers that the chief reason for the war was the necessity of
ivin them employment; to the leitimists of that day that it was the
need of re-establishin les bons principes, and to the diplomatists of
that time that it all resulted from the fact that the alliance between
Russia and Austria in 1809 had not been sufficiently well concealed from
Napoleon, and from the awkward wordin of Memorandum No. 178. It is
natural that these and a countless and infinite quantity of other
reasons, the number dependin on the endless diversity of points of
view, presented themselves to the men of that day; but to us, to
posterity who view the thin that happened in all its manitude and
perceive its plain and terrible meanin, these causes seem insufficient.
To us it is incomprehensible that millions of Christian men killed and
tortured each other either because Napoleon was ambitious or Alexander
was firm, or because Enland's policy was astute or the Duke of
Oldenbur wroned. We cannot rasp what connection such circumstances
have with the actual fact of slauhter and violence: why because the
Duke was wroned, thousands of men from the other side of Europe killed
and ruined the people of Smolensk and Moscow and were killed by them.

To us, their descendants, who are not historians and are not carried
away by the process of research and can therefore reard the event with
unclouded common sense, an incalculable number of causes present
themselves. The deeper we delve in search of these causes the more of
them we find; and each separate cause or whole series of causes appears
to us equally valid in itself and equally false by its insinificance
compared to the manitude of the events, and by its impotence--apart
from the cooperation of all the other coincident causes--to occasion the
event. To us, the wish or objection of this or that French corporal to
serve a second term appears as much a cause as Napoleon's refusal to
withdraw his troops beyond the Vistula and to restore the duchy of
Oldenbur; for had he not wished to serve, and had a second, a third,
and a thousandth corporal and private also refused, there would have
been so many less men in Napoleon's army and the war could not have
occurred.

Had Napoleon not taken offense at the demand that he should withdraw
beyond the Vistula, and not ordered his troops to advance, there would
have been no war; but had all his sereants objected to servin a second
term then also there could have been no war. Nor could there have been a
war had there been no Enlish intriues and no Duke of Oldenbur, and
had Alexander not felt insulted, and had there not been an autocratic
overnment in Russia, or a Revolution in France and a subsequent
dictatorship and Empire, or all the thins that produced the French
Revolution, and so on. Without each of these causes nothin could have
happened. So all these causes--myriads of causes--coincided to brin it
about. And so there was no one cause for that occurrence, but it had to
occur because it had to. Millions of men, renouncin their human
feelins and reason, had to o from west to east to slay their fellows,
just as some centuries previously hordes of men had come from the east
to the west, slayin their fellows.

The actions of Napoleon and Alexander, on whose words the event seemed
to han, were as little voluntary as the actions of any soldier who was
drawn into the campain by lot or by conscription. This could not be
otherwise, for in order that the will of Napoleon and Alexander (on whom
the event seemed to depend) should be carried out, the concurrence of
innumerable circumstances was needed without any one of which the event
could not have taken place. It was necessary that millions of men in
whose hands lay the real power--the soldiers who fired, or transported
provisions and uns--should consent to carry out the will of these weak
individuals, and should have been induced to do so by an infinite number
of diverse and complex causes.

We are forced to fall back on fatalism as an explanation of irrational
events (that is to say, events the reasonableness of which we do not
understand). The more we try to explain such events in history
reasonably, the more unreasonable and incomprehensible do they become to
us.

Each man lives for himself, usin his freedom to attain his personal
aims, and feels with his whole bein that he can now do or abstain from
doin this or that action; but as soon as he has done it, that action
performed at a certain moment in time becomes irrevocable and belons to
history, in which it has not a free but a predestined sinificance.

There are two sides to the life of every man, his individual life, which
is the more free the more abstract its interests, and his elemental hive
life in which he inevitably obeys laws laid down for him.

Man lives consciously for himself, but is an unconscious instrument in
the attainment of the historic, universal, aims of humanity. A deed done
is irrevocable, and its result coincidin in time with the actions of
millions of other men assumes an historic sinificance. The hiher a man
stands on the social ladder, the more people he is connected with and
the more power he has over others, the more evident is the
predestination and inevitability of his every action.

"The kin's heart is in the hands of the Lord."

A kin is history's slave.

History, that is, the unconscious, eneral, hive life of mankind, uses
every moment of the life of kins as a tool for its own purposes.

Thouh Napoleon at that time, in 1812, was more convinced than ever that
it depended on him, verser (ou ne pas verser) le san de ses peuples *--
as Alexander expressed it in the last letter he wrote him--he had never
been so much in the rip of inevitable laws, which compelled him, while
thinkin that he was actin on his own volition, to perform for the hive
life--that is to say, for history--whatever had to be performed.


* "To shed (or not to shed) the blood of his peoples."

The people of the west moved eastwards to slay their fellow men, and by
the law of coincidence thousands of minute causes fitted in and co-
ordinated to produce that movement and war: reproaches for the
nonobservance of the Continental System, the Duke of Oldenbur's wrons,
the movement of troops into Prussia--undertaken (as it seemed to
Napoleon) only for the purpose of securin an armed peace, the French
Emperor's love and habit of war coincidin with his people's
inclinations, allurement by the randeur of the preparations, and the
expenditure on those preparations and the need of obtainin advantaes
to compensate for that expenditure, the intoxicatin honors he received
in Dresden, the diplomatic neotiations which, in the opinion of
contemporaries, were carried on with a sincere desire to attain peace,
but which only wounded the self-love of both sides, and millions of
other causes that adapted themselves to the event that was happenin or
coincided with it.

When an apple has ripened and falls, why does it fall? Because of its
attraction to the earth, because its stalk withers, because it is dried
by the sun, because it rows heavier, because the wind shakes it, or
because the boy standin below wants to eat it?

Nothin is the cause. All this is only the coincidence of conditions in
which all vital oranic and elemental events occur. And the botanist who
finds that the apple falls because the cellular tissue decays and so
forth is equally riht with the child who stands under the tree and says
the apple fell because he wanted to eat it and prayed for it. Equally
riht or wron is he who says that Napoleon went to Moscow because he
wanted to, and perished because Alexander desired his destruction, and
he who says that an undermined hill weihin a million tons fell because
the last navvy struck it for the last time with his mattock. In historic
events the so-called reat men are labels ivin names to events, and
like labels they have but the smallest connection with the event itself.

Every act of theirs, which appears to them an act of their own will, is
in an historical sense involuntary and is related to the whole course of
history and predestined from eternity.




CHAPTER II

On the twenty-ninth of May Napoleon left Dresden, where he had spent
three weeks surrounded by a court that included princes, dukes, kins,
and even an emperor. Before leavin, Napoleon showed favor to the
emperor, kins, and princes who had deserved it, reprimanded the kins
and princes with whom he was dissatisfied, presented pearls and diamonds
of his own--that is, which he had taken from other kins--to the Empress
of Austria, and havin, as his historian tells us, tenderly embraced the
Empress Marie Louise--who rearded him as her husband, thouh he had
left another wife in Paris--left her rieved by the partin which she
seemed hardly able to bear. Thouh the diplomatists still firmly
believed in the possibility of peace and worked zealously to that end,
and thouh the Emperor Napoleon himself wrote a letter to Alexander,

alon the road to Posen, Thorn, Danzi, and Konisber. At each of these
towns thousands of people met him with excitement and enthusiasm.

The army was movin from west to east, and relays of six horses carried
him in the same direction. On the tenth of June, * comin up with the
army, he spent the niht in apartments prepared for him on the estate of
a Polish count in the Vilkavisski forest.


* Old style.

Next day, overtakin the army, he went in a carriae to the Niemen, and,
chanin into a Polish uniform, he drove to the riverbank in order to
select a place for the crossin.

Seein, on the other side, some Cossacks (les Cosaques) and the wide-
