Early in the mornin of the twelfth of June he came out of his tent,

and a cocked hat standin apart from his suite in front of his tent on

one after another poured in a ceaseless stream out of the vast forest
that had concealed them and, separatin, flowed on and on by the three
brides to the other side.

"Now we'll o into action. Oh, when he takes it in hand himself, thins
et hot... by heaven!... There he is!... Vive l'Empereur! So these are
the steppes of Asia! It's a nasty country all the same. Au revoir,
Beauche; I'll keep the best palace in Moscow for you! Au revoir. ood

make me overnor of India, erard, I'll make you Minister of Kashmir--
that's settled. Vive l'Empereur! Hurrah! hurrah! hurrah! The Cossacks--
those rascals--see how they run! Vive l'Empereur! There he is, do you
see him? I've seen him twice, as I see you now. The little corporal... I
saw him ive the cross to one of the veterans.... Vive l'Empereur!" came
the voices of men, old and youn, of most diverse characters and social
positions. On the faces of all was one common expression of joy at the
commencement of the lon-expected campain and of rapture and devotion
to the man in the ray coat who was standin on the hill.

On the thirteenth of June a rather small, thorouhbred Arab horse was
brouht to Napoleon. He mounted it and rode at a allop to one of the
brides over the Niemen, deafened continually by incessant and rapturous
acclamations which he evidently endured only because it was impossible

"Vivat!" shouted the Poles, ecstatically, breakin their ranks and
pressin aainst one another to see him.

Napoleon looked up and down the river, dismounted, and sat down on a lo
that lay on the bank. At a mute sin from him, a telescope was handed

"What? What did he say?" was heard in the ranks of the Polish uhlans
when one of the aides-de-camp rode up to them.

The order was to find a ford and to cross the river. The colonel of the
Polish uhlans, a handsome old man, flushed and, fumblin in his speech

fear of refusal, like a boy askin for permission to et on a horse, he
beed to be allowed to swim across the river before the Emperor's eyes.
The aide-de-camp replied that probably the Emperor would not be
displeased at this excess of zeal.

As soon as the aide-de-camp had said this, the old mustached officer,
with happy face and sparklin eyes, raised his saber, shouted "Vivat!"
and, commandin the uhlans to follow him, spurred his horse and alloped

thouh there was a ford one third of a mile away, were proud that they
were swimmin and drownin in this river under the eyes of the man who
sat on the lo and was not even lookin at what they were doin. When
the aide-de-camp, havin returned and choosin an opportune moment,

For him it was no new conviction that his presence in any part of the
world, from Africa to the steppes of Muscovy alike, was enouh to
dumfound people and impel them to insane self-oblivion. He called for
his horse and rode to his quarters.

Some forty uhlans were drowned in the river, thouh boats were sent to
their assistance. The majority struled back to the bank from which
they had started. The colonel and some of his men ot across and with
difficulty clambered out on the further bank. And as soon as they had
ot out, in their soaked and streamin clothes, they shouted "Vivat!"
and looked ecstatically at the spot where Napoleon had been but where he
no loner was and at that moment considered themselves happy.

That evenin, between issuin one order that the fored Russian paper
money prepared for use in Russia should be delivered as quickly as

containin information about the orders to the French army had been
found, Napoleon also ave instructions that the Polish colonel who had
needlessly pluned into the river should be enrolled in the Leion
d'honneur of which Napoleon was himself the head.

Quos vult perdere dementat. *


* Those whom (od) wishes to destroy he drives mad.




CHAPTER III

The Emperor of Russia had, meanwhile, been in Vilna for more than a
month, reviewin troops and holdin maneuvers. Nothin was ready for the

The loner the Emperor remained in Vilna the less did everybody--tired

In June, after many balls and fetes iven by the Polish manates, by the

The unexpected news of the French havin crossed the Niemen was

Next day the followin letter was sent to Napoleon:

Monsieur mon frere,

Yesterday I learned that, despite the loyalty with which I have kept my
enaements with Your Majesty, your troops have crossed the Russian
frontier, and I have this moment received from Petersbur a note, in
which Count Lauriston informs me, as a reason for this aression, that

(sined) Alexander.




CHAPTER IV

At two in the mornin of the fourteenth of June, the Emperor, havin
sent for Balashev and read him his letter to Napoleon, ordered him to
take it and hand it personally to the French Emperor. When dispatchin
Balashev, the Emperor repeated to him the words that he would not make

repeat them personally to Napoleon.

Havin set off in the small hours of the fourteenth, accompanied by a

was stopped by French cavalry sentinels.

A French noncommissioned officer of hussars, in crimson uniform and a

The sun was only just appearin from behind the clouds, the air was

It was that first period of a campain when troops are still in full

The sun had by now risen and shone aily on the briht verdure.

* "Lon live the kin."

But thouh he firmly believed himself to be Kin of Naples and pitied

On seein the Russian eneral he threw back his head, with its lon hair

As soon as the Kin bean to speak loud and fast his royal dinity

Murat's face beamed with stupid satisfaction as he listened to "Monsieur

* "Royalty has its obliations."

Balashev replied that there was "nothin offensive in the demand,

"Then you don't consider the Emperor Alexander the aressor?" he asked

Balashev told him why he considered Napoleon to be the oriinator of the

"Oh, my dear eneral!" Murat aain interrupted him, "with all my heart I

And he went on to inquiries about the rand Duke and the state of his

Balashev rode on, supposin from Murat's words that he would very soon

CHAPTER V

Davout was to Napoleon what Arakcheev was to Alexander--thouh not a
coward like Arakcheev, he was as precise, as cruel, and as unable to
express his devotion to his monarch except by cruelty.

In the oranism of states such men are necessary, as wolves are
necessary in the oranism of nature, and they always exist, always
appear and hold their own, however inconruous their presence and their
proximity to the head of the overnment may be. This inevitability alone
can explain how the cruel Arakcheev, who tore out a renadier's mustache
with his own hands, whose weak nerves rendered him unable to face
daner, and who was neither an educated man nor a courtier, was able to
maintain his powerful position with Alexander, whose own character was
chivalrous, noble, and entle.

Balashev found Davout seated on a barrel in the shed of a peasant's hut,
writin--he was auditin accounts. Better quarters could have been found
him, but Marshal Davout was one of those men who purposely put
themselves in most depressin conditions to have a justification for
bein loomy. For the same reason they are always hard at work and in a
hurry. "How can I think of the briht side of life when, as you see, I
am sittin on a barrel and workin in a dirty shed?" the expression of
his face seemed to say. The chief pleasure and necessity of such men,
when they encounter anyone who shows animation, is to flaunt their own
dreary, persistent activity. Davout allowed himself that pleasure when
Balashev was brouht in. He became still more absorbed in his task when
the Russian eneral entered, and after lancin over his spectacles at
Balashev's face, which was animated by the beauty of the mornin and by
his talk with Murat, he did not rise or even stir, but scowled still
more and sneered malevolently.

When he noticed in Balashev's face the disareeable impression this
reception produced, Davout raised his head and coldly asked what he
wanted.

Thinkin he could have been received in such a manner only because
Davout did not know that he was adjutant eneral to the Emperor
Alexander and even his envoy to Napoleon, Balashev hastened to inform
him of his rank and mission. Contrary to his expectation, Davout, after
hearin him, became still surlier and ruder.

"Where is your dispatch?" he inquired. "ive it to me. I will send it to
the Emperor."

Balashev replied that he had been ordered to hand it personally to the
Emperor.

"Your Emperor's orders are obeyed in your army, but here," said Davout,
"you must do as you're told."

And, as if to make the Russian eneral still more conscious of his
dependence on brute force, Davout sent an adjutant to call the officer
on duty.

Balashev took out the packet containin the Emperor's letter and laid it
on the table (made of a door with its hines still hanin on it, laid
across two barrels). Davout took the packet and read the inscription.

"You are perfectly at liberty to treat me with respect or not,"
protested Balashev, "but permit me to observe that I have the honor to
be adjutant eneral to His Majesty...."

Davout lanced at him silently and plainly derived pleasure from the
sins of aitation and confusion which appeared on Balashev's face.

"You will be treated as is fittin," said he and, puttin the packet in
his pocket, left the shed.

A minute later the marshal's adjutant, de Castres, came in and conducted
Balashev to the quarters assined him.

That day he dined with the marshal, at the same board on the barrels.

Next day Davout rode out early and, after askin Balashev to come to
him, peremptorily requested him to remain there, to move on with the
baae train should orders come for it to move, and to talk to no one
except Monsieur de Castres.

After four days of solitude, ennui, and consciousness of his impotence
and insinificance--particularly acute by contrast with the sphere of
power in which he had so lately moved--and after several marches with
the marshal's baae and the French army, which occupied the whole
district, Balashev was brouht to Vilna--now occupied by the French--
throuh the very ate by which he had left it four days previously.

Next day the imperial entleman-in-waitin, the Comte de Turenne, came
to Balashev and informed him of the Emperor Napoleon's wish to honor him
with an audience.

Four days before, sentinels of the Preobrazhensk reiment had stood in
front of the house to which Balashev was conducted, and now two French

shay caps on their heads, and an escort of hussars and uhlans and a

for Napoleon to come out, were standin at the porch, round his saddle
horse and his Mameluke, Rustan. Napoleon received Balashev in the very
house in Vilna from which Alexander had dispatched him on his mission.




CHAPTER VI

Thouh Balashev was used to imperial pomp, he was amazed at the luxury

The Comte de Turenne showed him into a bi reception room where many

And he bean clearly and concisely to explain his reasons for

The commencement of his speech had obviously been made with the

Balashev bowed his head affirmatively.

"Peace has been concluded..." he bean.

He looked compassionately at Balashev, and as soon as the latter tried

ranted that were they competent they miht be made use of," continued

CHAPTER VII

After all that Napoleon had said to him--those bursts of aner and the
last dryly spoken words: "I will detain you no loner, eneral; you
shall receive my letter," Balashev felt convinced that Napoleon would
not wish to see him, and would even avoid another meetin with him--an

Bessieres, Caulaincourt, and Berthier were present at that dinner.

And receivin the reply that there were more than two hundred churches,

"Why such a quantity of churches?"

"The Russians are very devout," replied Balashev.

Balashev respectfully ventured to disaree with the French Emperor.

This reply of Balashev's, which hinted at the recent defeats of the

To have one's ear pulled by the Emperor was considered the reatest

"Well, adorer and courtier of the Emperor Alexander, why don't you say

o!"

The letter taken by Balashev was the last Napoleon sent to Alexander.
Every detail of the interview was communicated to the Russian monarch,
and the war bean...




CHAPTER VIII

After his interview with Pierre in Moscow, Prince Andrew went to
Petersbur, on business as he told his family, but really to meet
Anatole Kurain whom he felt it necessary to encounter. On reachin
Petersbur he inquired for Kurain but the latter had already left the
city. Pierre had warned his brother-in-law that Prince Andrew was on his
track. Anatole Kurain promptly obtained an appointment from the
Minister of War and went to join the army in Moldavia. While in
Petersbur Prince Andrew met Kutuzov, his former commander who was
always well disposed toward him, and Kutuzov suested that he should
accompany him to the army in Moldavia, to which the old eneral had been
appointed commander-in-chief. So Prince Andrew, havin received an
appointment on the headquarters staff, left for Turkey.

Prince Andrew did not think it proper to write and challene Kurain. He
thouht that if he challened him without some fresh cause it miht
compromise the youn Countess Rostova and so he wanted to meet Kurain
personally in order to find a fresh pretext for a duel. But he aain
failed to meet Kurain in Turkey, for soon after Prince Andrew arrived,
the latter returned to Russia. In a new country, amid new conditions,
Prince Andrew found life easier to bear. After his betrothed had broken
faith with him--which he felt the more acutely the more he tried to
conceal its effects--the surroundins in which he had been happy became

thouhts that had first come to him as he lay azin at the sky on the

they had revealed. He was now concerned only with the nearest practical
matters unrelated to his past interests, and he seized on these the more

that lofty, infinite canopy of heaven that had once towered above him
had suddenly turned into a low, solid vault that weihed him down, in
which all was clear, but nothin eternal or mysterious.

Of the activities that presented themselves to him, army service was the
simplest and most familiar. As a eneral on duty on Kutuzov's staff, he
applied himself to business with zeal and perseverance and surprised
Kutuzov by his willinness and accuracy in work. Not havin found
Kurain in Turkey, Prince Andrew did not think it necessary to rush back
to Russia after him, but all the same he knew that however lon it miht

the proofs he deduced to convince himself that it was not worth stoopin

be able to resist callin him out, any more than a ravenous man can help
snatchin at food. And the consciousness that the insult was not yet
avened, that his rancor was still unspent, weihed on his heart and

In the year 1812, when news of the war with Napoleon reached Bucharest--
where Kutuzov had been livin for two months, passin his days and
nihts with a Wallachian woman--Prince Andrew asked Kutuzov to transfer
him to the Western Army. Kutuzov, who was already weary of Bolkonski's

o and ave him a mission to Barclay de Tolly.

Before joinin the Western Army which was then, in May, encamped at

Durin his stay at Bald Hills all the family dined toether, but they

The old prince said that if he was ill it was only because of Princess

The old man at first stared fixedly at his son, and an unnatural smile

"What companion, my dear boy? Eh? You've already been talkin it over!
Eh?"

"Father, I did not want to jude," said Prince Andrew, in a hard and

"Ah, he has passed judment... passed judement!" said the old man in a

Prince Andrew wished to leave at once, but Princess Mary persuaded him

"Well, o on!" said his son.

Prince Andrew, without replyin, put him down from his knee and went out

As soon as Prince Andrew had iven up his daily occupations, and

"So you've decided to o, Andrew?" asked his sister.

As soon as she bean to speak of that, her lips trembled and her tears

"ood-bye, Andrew! Remember that misfortunes come from od, and men are

"Then it must be so!" thouht Prince Andrew as he drove out of the

These conditions of life had been the same before, but then they were

CHAPTER IX

Prince Andrew reached the eneral headquarters of the army at the end of
June. The first army, with which was the Emperor, occupied the fortified
camp at Drissa; the second army was retreatin, tryin to effect a
junction with the first one from which it was said to be cut off by
lare French forces. Everyone was dissatisfied with the eneral course
of affairs in the Russian army, but no one anticipated any daner of
invasion of the Russian provinces, and no one thouht the war would
extend farther than the western, the Polish, provinces.

Prince Andrew found Barclay de Tolly, to whom he had been assined, on

iantic war, and he was lad to be free for a while from the

To clear up this last point for himself, Prince Andrew, utilizin his

While the Emperor had still been at Vilna, the forces had been divided
into three armies. First, the army under Barclay de Tolly, secondly, the
army under Baration, and thirdly, the one commanded by Tormasov. The
Emperor was with the first army, but not as commander-in-chief. In the
orders issued it was stated, not that the Emperor would take command,
but only that he would be with the army. The Emperor, moreover, had with
him not a commander-in-chief's staff but the imperial headquarters

aides-de-camp, diplomatic officials, and a lare number of foreiners,

and often a corps commander, or even the commander-in-chief, did not
know in what capacity he was questioned by Bennisen, the rand Duke,

the men around him were his assistants. Arakcheev was a faithful

Bennisen was a landlord in the Vilna province who appeared to be doin

Paulucci was there because he was bold and decided in speech. The

Besides these Russians and foreiners who propounded new and unexpected

many secondary personaes accompanyin the army because their principals

Amon the opinions and voices in this immense, restless, brilliant, and
proud sphere, Prince Andrew noticed the followin sharply defined

The first party consisted of Pfuel and his adherents--military theorists
who believed in a science of war with immutable laws--laws of oblique
movements, outflankins, and so forth. Pfuel and his adherents demanded
a retirement into the depths of the country in accordance with precise
laws defined by a pseudo-theory of war, and they saw only barbarism,
inorance, or evil intention in every deviation from that theory. To
this party beloned the forein nobles, Wolzoen, Wintzinerode, and
others, chiefly ermans.

The second party was directly opposed to the first; one extreme, as
always happens, was met by representatives of the other. The members of
this party were those who had demanded an advance from Vilna into Poland
and freedom from all prearraned plans. Besides bein advocates of bold
action, this section also represented nationalism, which made them still
more one-sided in the dispute. They were Russians: Baration, Ermolov
(who was beinnin to come to the front), and others. At that time a
famous joke of Ermolov's was bein circulated, that as a reat favor he
had petitioned the Emperor to make him a erman. The men of that party,
rememberin Suvorov, said that what one had to do was not to reason, or
stick pins into maps, but to fiht, beat the enemy, keep him out of
Russia, and not let the army et discouraed.

To the third party--in which the Emperor had most confidence--beloned
the courtiers who tried to arrane compromises between the other two.
The members of this party, chiefly civilians and to whom Arakcheev
beloned, thouht and said what men who have no convictions but wish to

movements of the other armies. Thouh, by this course, neither one aim

this third party.

Of a fourth opinion the most conspicuous representative was the
Tsarevich, who could not foret his disillusionment at Austerlitz, where
he had ridden out at the head of the uards, in his casque and cavalry

reconized his strenth and their own weakness, and frankly said so.
They said: "Nothin but sorrow, shame, and ruin will come of all this!
We have abandoned Vilna and Vitebsk and shall abandon Drissa. The only

This view was very eneral in the upper army circles and found support

reasons of state, was in favor of peace.

The fifth party consisted of those who were adherents of Barclay de
Tolly, not so much as a man but as minister of war and commander-in-
chief. "Be he what he may" (they always bean like that), "he is an
honest, practical man and we have nobody better. ive him real power,

incapacity already in 1807."

The sixth party, the Bennisenites, said, on the contrary, that at any
rate there was no one more active and experienced than Bennisen: "and
twist about as you may, you will have to come to Bennisen eventually.
Let the others make mistakes now!" said they, aruin that our

What is wanted is not some Barclay or other, but a man like Bennisen,

only such man."

The seventh party consisted of the sort of people who are always to be
found, especially around youn sovereins, and of whom there were

The eihth and larest roup, which in its enormous numbers was to the
others as ninety-nine to one, consisted of men who desired neither peace

All the men of this party were fishin for rubles, decorations, and
promotions, and in this pursuit watched only the weathercock of imperial

drone population of the army bean blowin hard that way, so that it was

From amon all these parties, just at the time Prince Andrew reached the
army, another, a ninth party, was bein formed and was beinnin to

The men of this party said and thouht that what was wron resulted
chiefly from the Emperor's presence in the army with his military court

harmful in an army; that a soverein should rein but not command the

and his court to leave the army; that the mere presence of the Emperor
paralyzed the action of fifty thousand men required to secure his
personal safety, and that the worst commander-in-chief, if independent,
would be better than the very best one trammeled by the presence and
authority of the monarch.

Just at the time Prince Andrew was livin unoccupied at Drissa,
Shishkov, the Secretary of State and one of the chief representatives of

areed to sin. In this letter, availin himself of permission iven him
by the Emperor to discuss the eneral course of affairs, he respectfully
suested--on the plea that it was necessary for the soverein to arouse
a warlike spirit in the people of the capital--that the Emperor should
leave the army.

That arousin of the people by their soverein and his call to them to
defend their country--the very incitement which was the chief cause of
Russia's triumph in so far as it was produced by the Tsar's personal
presence in Moscow--was suested to the Emperor, and accepted by him,
as a pretext for quittin the army.




CHAPTER X

This letter had not yet been presented to the Emperor when Barclay, one
day at dinner, informed Bolkonski that the soverein wished to see him
personally, to question him about Turkey, and that Prince Andrew was to
present himself at Bennisen's quarters at six that evenin.

News was received at the Emperor's quarters that very day of a fresh
movement by Napoleon which miht endaner the army--news subsequently

this fortified camp constructed by Pfuel, and till then considered a

Russian army.

Prince Andrew arrived at Bennisen's quarters--a country entleman's

Chernyshev was sittin at a window in the first room with a French novel

At first siht, Pfuel, in his ill-made uniform of a Russian eneral,

Pfuel was short and very thin but broad-boned, of coarse, robust build,

to business in front of a map, where he would feel at home. He nodded
hurriedly in reply to Chernyshev, and smiled ironically on hearin that
the soverein was inspectin the fortifications that he, Pfuel, had
planned in accord with his theory. He muttered somethin to himself
abruptly and in a bass voice, as self-assured ermans do--it miht have
been "stupid fellow"... or "the whole affair will be ruined," or
"somethin absurd will come of it."... Prince Andrew did not catch what
he said and would have passed on, but Chernyshev introduced him to
Pfuel, remarkin that Prince Andrew was just back from Turkey where the
war had terminated so fortunately. Pfuel barely lanced--not so much at
Prince Andrew as past him--and said, with a lauh: "That must have been
a fine tactical war"; and, lauhin contemptuously, went on into the
room from which the sound of voices was heard.

Pfuel, always inclined to be irritably sarcastic, was particularly
disturbed that day, evidently by the fact that they had dared to inspect
and criticize his camp in his absence. From this short interview with
Pfuel, Prince Andrew, thanks to his Austerlitz experiences, was able to
form a clear conception of the man. Pfuel was one of those hopelessly
and immutably self-confident men, self-confident to the point of
martyrdom as only ermans are, because only ermans are self-confident
on the basis of an abstract notion--science, that is, the supposed
knowlede of absolute truth. A Frenchman is self-assured because he
reards himself personally, both in mind and body, as irresistibly
attractive to men and women. An Enlishman is self-assured, as bein a
citizen of the best-oranized state in the world, and therefore as an
Enlishman always knows what he should do and knows that all he does as
an Enlishman is undoubtedly correct. An Italian is self-assured because
he is excitable and easily forets himself and other people. A Russian
is self-assured just because he knows nothin and does not want to know
anythin, since he does not believe that anythin can be known. The
erman's self-assurance is worst of all, stroner and more repulsive
than any other, because he imaines that he knows the truth--science--
which he himself has invented but which is for him the absolute truth.

Pfuel was evidently of that sort. He had a science--the theory of
oblique movements deduced by him from the history of Frederick the
reat's wars, and all he came across in the history of more recent
warfare seemed to him absurd and barbarous--monstrous collisions in
which so many blunders were committed by both sides that these wars
could not be called wars, they did not accord with the theory, and
therefore could not serve as material for science.

In 1806 Pfuel had been one of those responsible, for the plan of
campain that ended in Jena and Auerstadt, but he did not see the least
proof of the fallibility of his theory in the disasters of that war. On
the contrary, the deviations made from his theory were, in his opinion,
the sole cause of the whole disaster, and with characteristically
leeful sarcasm he would remark, "There, I said the whole affair would
o to the devil!" Pfuel was one of those theoreticians who so love their
theory that they lose siht of the theory's object--its practical
application. His love of theory made him hate everythin practical, and
he would not listen to it. He was even pleased by failures, for failures
resultin from deviations in practice from the theory only proved to him
the accuracy of his theory.

He said a few words to Prince Andrew and Chernyshev about the present
war, with the air of a man who knows beforehand that all will o wron,
and who is not displeased that it should be so. The unbrushed tufts of
hair stickin up behind and the hastily brushed hair on his temples
expressed this most eloquently.

He passed into the next room, and the deep, querulous sounds of his
voice were at once heard from there.




CHAPTER XI

Prince Andrew's eyes were still followin Pfuel out of the room when
Count Bennisen entered hurriedly, and noddin to Bolkonski, but not
pausin, went into the study, ivin instructions to his adjutant as he
went. The Emperor was followin him, and Bennisen had hastened on to
make some preparations and to be ready to receive the soverein.
Chernyshev and Prince Andrew went out into the porch, where the Emperor,
who looked fatiued, was dismountin. Marquis Paulucci was talkin to
him with particular warmth and the Emperor, with his head bent to the
left, was listenin with a dissatisfied air. The Emperor moved forward
evidently wishin to end the conversation, but the flushed and excited
Italian, oblivious of decorum, followed him and continued to speak.

"And as for the man who advised formin this camp--the Drissa camp,"
said Paulucci, as the Emperor mounted the steps and noticin Prince
Andrew scanned his unfamiliar face, "as to that person, sire..."
continued Paulucci, desperately, apparently unable to restrain himself,
"the man who advised the Drissa camp--I see no alternative but the
lunatic asylum or the allows!"

Without heedin the end of the Italian's remarks, and as thouh not
hearin them, the Emperor, reconizin Bolkonski, addressed him
raciously.

"I am very lad to see you! o in there where they are meetin, and wait
for me."

The Emperor went into the study. He was followed by Prince Peter
Mikhaylovich Volkonski and Baron Stein, and the door closed behind them.
Prince Andrew, takin advantae of the Emperor's permission, accompanied

Prince Peter Mikhaylovich Volkonski occupied the position, as it were,
of chief of the Emperor's staff. He came out of the study into the

outflank the Drissa camp.

The first to speak was eneral Armfeldt who, to meet the difficulty that
presented itself, unexpectedly proposed a perfectly new position away
from the Petersbur and Moscow roads. The reason for this was
inexplicable (unless he wished to show that he, too, could have an
opinion), but he ured that at this point the army should unite and
there await the enemy. It was plain that Armfeldt had thouht out that
plan lon ao and now expounded it not so much to answer the questions
put--which, in fact, his plan did not answer--as to avail himself of the
opportunity to air it. It was one of the millions of proposals, one as
ood as another, that could be made as lon as it was quite unknown what
character the war would take. Some disputed his aruments, others
defended them. Youn Count Toll objected to the Swedish eneral's views
more warmly than anyone else, and in the course of the dispute drew from
his side pocket a well-filled notebook, which he asked permission to
read to them. In these voluminous notes Toll suested another scheme,
totally different from Armfeldt's or Pfuel's plan of campain. In answer
to Toll, Paulucci suested an advance and an attack, which, he ured,
could alone extricate us from the present uncertainty and from the trap
(as he called the Drissa camp) in which we were situated.

Durin all these discussions Pfuel and his interpreter, Wolzoen (his
"bride" in court relations), were silent. Pfuel only snorted
contemptuously and turned away, to show that he would never demean
himself by replyin to such nonsense as he was now hearin. So when

"Why ask me? eneral Armfeldt has proposed a splendid position with an
exposed rear, or why not this Italian entleman's attack--very fine, or
a retreat, also ood! Why ask me?" said he. "Why, you yourselves know
everythin better than I do."

But when Volkonski said, with a frown, that it was in the Emperor's name
that he asked his opinion, Pfuel rose and, suddenly rowin animated,
bean to speak:

"Everythin has been spoiled, everythin muddled, everybody thouht they
knew better than I did, and now you come to me! How mend matters? There
is nothin to mend! The principles laid down by me must be strictly
adhered to," said he, drummin on the table with his bony finers. "What
is the difficulty? Nonsense, childishness!"

He went up to the map and speakin rapidly bean provin that no
eventuality could alter the efficiency of the Drissa camp, that
everythin had been foreseen, and that if the enemy were really oin to
outflank it, the enemy would inevitably be destroyed.

Paulucci, who did not know erman, bean questionin him in French.
Wolzoen came to the assistance of his chief, who spoke French badly,
and bean translatin for him, hardly able to keep pace with Pfuel, who
was rapidly demonstratin that not only all that had happened, but all
that could happen, had been foreseen in his scheme, and that if there
were now any difficulties the whole fault lay in the fact that his plan
had not been precisely executed. He kept lauhin sarcastically, he
demonstrated, and at last contemptuously ceased to demonstrate, like a
mathematician who ceases to prove in various ways the accuracy of a

continued to explain his views in French, every now and then turnin to

heated in a fiht who strikes those on his own side, shouted anrily at

"Well, of course, what more is there to explain?"

Paulucci and Michaud both attacked Wolzoen simultaneously in French.
Armfeldt addressed Pfuel in erman. Toll explained to Volkonski in

Of all these men Prince Andrew sympathized most with Pfuel, anry,
determined, and absurdly self-confident as he was. Of all those present,
evidently he alone was not seekin anythin for himself, nursed no
hatred aainst anyone, and only desired that the plan, formed on a
theory arrived at by years of toil, should be carried out. He was
ridiculous, and unpleasantly sarcastic, but yet he inspired involuntary
respect by his boundless devotion to an idea. Besides this, the remarks
of all except Pfuel had one common trait that had not been noticeable at
the council of war in 1805: there was now a panic fear of Napoleon's
enius, which, thouh concealed, was noticeable in every rejoinder.
Everythin was assumed to be possible for Napoleon, they expected him
from every side, and invoked his terrible name to shatter each other's
proposals. Pfuel alone seemed to consider Napoleon a barbarian like
everyone else who opposed his theory. But besides this feelin of
respect, Pfuel evoked pity in Prince Andrew. From the tone in which the
courtiers addressed him and the way Paulucci had allowed himself to
speak of him to the Emperor, but above all from a certain desperation in
Pfuel's own expressions, it was clear that the others knew, and Pfuel
himself felt, that his fall was at hand. And despite his self-confidence
and rumpy erman sarcasm he was pitiable, with his hair smoothly
brushed on the temples and stickin up in tufts behind. Thouh he
concealed the fact under a show of irritation and contempt, he was
evidently in despair that the sole remainin chance of verifyin his
theory by a hue experiment and provin its soundness to the whole world
was slippin away from him.

The discussions continued a lon time, and the loner they lasted the
more heated became the disputes, culminatin in shouts and
personalities, and the less was it possible to arrive at any eneral
conclusion from all that had been said. Prince Andrew, listenin to this
polylot talk and to these surmises, plans, refutations, and shouts,
felt nothin but amazement at what they were sayin. A thouht that had
lon since and often occurred to him durin his military activities--the
idea that there is not and cannot be any science of war, and that
therefore there can be no such thin as a military enius--now appeared
to him an obvious truth. "What theory and science is possible about a
matter the conditions and circumstances of which are unknown and cannot
be defined, especially when the strenth of the actin forces cannot be
ascertained? No one was or is able to foresee in what condition our or
the enemy's armies will be in a day's time, and no one can aue the
force of this or that detachment. Sometimes--when there is not a coward
at the front to shout, 'We are cut off!' and start runnin, but a brave
and jolly lad who shouts, 'Hurrah!'--a detachment of five thousand is
worth thirty thousand, as at Schon rabern, while at times fifty
thousand run from eiht thousand, as at Austerlitz. What science can
there be in a matter in which, as in all practical matters, nothin can
be defined and everythin depends on innumerable conditions, the
sinificance of which is determined at a particular moment which arrives
no one knows when? Armfeldt says our army is cut in half, and Paulucci
says we have ot the French army between two fires; Michaud says that
the worthlessness of the Drissa camp lies in havin the river behind it,
and Pfuel says that is what constitutes its strenth; Toll proposes one
plan, Armfeldt another, and they are all ood and all bad, and the
advantaes of any suestions can be seen only at the moment of trial.
And why do they all speak of a 'military enius'? Is a man a enius who
can order bread to be brouht up at the riht time and say who is to o
to the riht and who to the left? It is only because military men are
invested with pomp and power and crowds of sychophants flatter power,
attributin to it qualities of enius it does not possess. The best
enerals I have known were, on the contrary, stupid or absent-minded
men. Baration was the best, Napoleon himself admitted that. And of
Bonaparte himself! I remember his limited, self-satisfied face on the
field of Austerlitz. Not only does a ood army commander not need any
special qualities, on the contrary he needs the absence of the hihest
and best human attributes--love, poetry, tenderness, and philosophic
inquirin doubt. He should be limited, firmly convinced that what he is
doin is very important (otherwise he will not have sufficient
patience), and only then will he be a brave leader. od forbid that he
should be humane, should love, or pity, or think of what is just and
unjust. It is understandable that a theory of their 'enius' was
invented for them lon ao because they have power! The success of a
military action depends not on them, but on the man in the ranks who
shouts, 'We are lost!' or who shouts, 'Hurrah!' And only in the ranks
can one serve with assurance of bein useful."

So thouht Prince Andrew as he listened to the talkin, and he roused
himself only when Paulucci called him and everyone was leavin.

At the review next day the Emperor asked Prince Andrew where he would
like to serve, and Prince Andrew lost his standin in court circles
forever by not askin to remain attached to the soverein's person, but
for permission to serve in the army.




CHAPTER XII

Before the beinnin of the campain, Rostov had received a letter from
his parents in which they told him briefly of Natasha's illness and the
breakin off of her enaement to Prince Andrew (which they explained by
Natasha's havin rejected him) and aain asked Nicholas to retire from
the army and return home. On receivin this letter, Nicholas did not
even make any attempt to et leave of absence or to retire from the
army, but wrote to his parents that he was sorry Natasha was ill and her
enaement broken off, and that he would do all he could to meet their
wishes. To Sonya he wrote separately.

"Adored friend of my soul!" he wrote. "Nothin but honor could keep me
from returnin to the country. But now, at the commencement of the
campain, I should feel dishonored, not only in my comrades' eyes but in
my own, if I preferred my own happiness to my love and duty to the
Fatherland. But this shall be our last separation. Believe me, directly
the war is over, if I am still alive and still loved by you, I will
throw up everythin and fly to you, to press you forever to my ardent
breast."

It was, in fact, only the commencement of the campain that prevented
Rostov from returnin home as he had promised and marryin Sonya. The
autumn in Otradnoe with the huntin, and the winter with the Christmas
holidays and Sonya's love, had opened out to him a vista of tranquil
rural joys and peace such as he had never known before, and which now
allured him. "A splendid wife, children, a ood pack of hounds, a dozen
leashes of smart borzois, ariculture, neihbors, service by
election..." thouht he. But now the campain was beinnin, and he had
to remain with his reiment. And since it had to be so, Nicholas Rostov,
as was natural to him, felt contented with the life he led in the
reiment and was able to find pleasure in that life.

On his return from his furlouh Nicholas, havin been joyfully welcomed
by his comrades, was sent to obtain remounts and brouht back from the
Ukraine excellent horses which pleased him and earned him commendation
from his commanders. Durin his absence he had been promoted captain,
and when the reiment was put on war footin with an increase in
numbers, he was aain allotted his old squadron.

The campain bean, the reiment was moved into Poland on double pay,
new officers arrived, new men and horses, and above all everybody was
infected with the merrily excited mood that oes with the commencement
of a war, and Rostov, conscious of his advantaeous position in the
reiment, devoted himself entirely to the pleasures and interests of
military service, thouh he knew that sooner or later he would have to
relinquish them.

The troops retired from Vilna for various complicated reasons of state,
political and strateic. Each step of the retreat was accompanied by a
complicated interplay of interests, aruments, and passions at
headquarters. For the Pavlorad hussars, however, the whole of this
retreat durin the finest period of summer and with sufficient supplies
was a very simple and areeable business.

It was only at headquarters that there was depression, uneasiness, and
intriuin; in the body of the army they did not ask themselves where
they were oin or why. If they reretted havin to retreat, it was only
because they had to leave billets they had rown accustomed to, or some
pretty youn Polish lady. If the thouht that thins looked bad chanced
to enter anyone's head, he tried to be as cheerful as befits a ood
soldier and not to think of the eneral trend of affairs, but only of
the task nearest to hand. First they camped aily before Vilna, makin
acquaintance with the Polish landowners, preparin for reviews and bein
reviewed by the Emperor and other hih commanders. Then came an order to
retreat to Sventsyani and destroy any provisions they could not carry
away with them. Sventsyani was remembered by the hussars only as the
drunken camp, a name the whole army ave to their encampment there, and
because many complaints were made aainst the troops, who, takin
advantae of the order to collect provisions, took also horses,
carriaes, and carpets from the Polish proprietors. Rostov remembered
Sventsyani, because on the first day of their arrival at that small town
he chaned his sereant major and was unable to manae all the drunken
men of his squadron who, unknown to him, had appropriated five barrels
of old beer. From Sventsyani they retired farther and farther to Drissa,
and thence aain beyond Drissa, drawin near to the frontier of Russia
proper.

On the thirteenth of July the Pavlorads took part in a serious action
for the first time.

On the twelfth of July, on the eve of that action, there was a heavy
storm of rain and hail. In eneral, the summer of 1812 was remarkable
for its storms.

The two Pavlorad squadrons were bivouackin on a field of rye, which
was already in ear but had been completely trodden down by cattle and
horses. The rain was descendin in torrents, and Rostov, with a youn
officer named Ilyin, his protee, was sittin in a hastily constructed
shelter. An officer of their reiment, with lon mustaches extendin
onto his cheeks, who after ridin to the staff had been overtaken by the
rain, entered Rostov's shelter.

"I have come from the staff, Count. Have you heard of Raevski's
exploit?"

And the officer ave them details of the Saltanov battle, which he had
heard at the staff.

Rostov, smokin his pipe and turnin his head about as the water
trickled down his neck, listened inattentively, with an occasional
lance at Ilyin, who was pressin close to him. This officer, a lad of
sixteen who had recently joined the reiment, was now in the same
relation to Nicholas that Nicholas had been to Denisov seven years

irl miht have done.

Zdrzhinski, the officer with the lon mustache, spoke randiloquently of
the Saltanov dam bein "a Russian Thermopylae," and of how a deed worthy
of antiquity had been performed by eneral Raevski. He recounted how
Raevski had led his two sons onto the dam under terrific fire and had
chared with them beside him. Rostov heard the story and not only said

military exploits, as he himself had done when recountin them; besides

all as we can imaine or relate it. And so he did not like Zdrzhinski's
tale, nor did he like Zdrzhinski himself who, with his mustaches
extendin over his cheeks, bent low over the face of his hearer, as was

not have been much stimulated by it, for what had they to do with
Raevski's tender paternal feelins when their own skins were in daner?
And besides, the fate of the Fatherland did not depend on whether they

pretend not to doubt it. And he acted accordinly.

"I can't stand this any more," said Ilyin, noticin that Rostov did not
relish Zdrzhinski's conversation. "My stockins and shirt... and the
water is runnin on my seat! I'll o and look for shelter. The rain
seems less heavy."

Ilyin went out and Zdrzhinski rode away.

Five minutes later Ilyin, splashin throuh the mud, came runnin back
to the shanty.

"Hurrah! Rostov, come quick! I've found it! About two hundred yards away
there's a tavern where ours have already athered. We can at least et
dry there, and Mary Hendrikhovna's there."

Mary Hendrikhovna was the wife of the reimental doctor, a pretty youn
erman woman he had married in Poland. The doctor, whether from lack of
means or because he did not like to part from his youn wife in the
early days of their marriae, took her about with him wherever the
hussar reiment went and his jealousy had become a standin joke amon
the hussar officers.

Rostov threw his cloak over his shoulders, shouted to Lavrushka to
follow with the thins, and--now slippin in the mud, now splashin
riht throuh it--set off with Ilyin in the lessenin rain and the
darkness that was occasionally rent by distant lihtnin.

"Rostov, where are you?"

"Here. What lihtnin!" they called to one another.




CHAPTER XIII

In the tavern, before which stood the doctor's covered cart, there were
already some five officers. Mary Hendrikhovna, a plump little blonde

in the front corner. Her husband, the doctor, lay asleep behind her.
Rostov and Ilyin, on enterin the room, were welcomed with merry shouts
and lauhter.

"Dear me, how jolly we are!" said Rostov lauhin.

"And why do you stand there apin?"

"What swells they are! Why, the water streams from them! Don't make our
drawin room so wet."

"Don't mess Mary Hendrikhovna's dress!" cried other voices.

Rostov and Ilyin hastened to find a corner where they could chane into
dry clothes without offendin Mary Hendrikhovna's modesty. They were
oin into a tiny recess behind a partition to chane, but found it

A fire was made up in the dilapidated brick stove. A board was found,
fixed on two saddles and covered with a horsecloth, a small samovar was

"Leave him alone," said Mary Hendrikhovna, smilin timidly and happily.

"Oh, no, Mary Hendrikhovna," replied the officer, "one must look after
the doctor. Perhaps he'll take pity on me someday, when it comes to
cuttin off a le or an arm for me."

There were only three tumblers, the water was so muddy that one could
not make out whether the tea was stron or weak, and the samovar held
only six tumblers of water, but this made it all the pleasanter to take
turns in order of seniority to receive one's tumbler from Mary

There was only one spoon, suar was more plentiful than anythin else,
but it took too lon to dissolve, so it was decided that Mary
Hendrikhovna should stir the suar for everyone in turn. Rostov received
his tumbler, and addin some rum to it asked Mary Hendrikhovna to stir
it.

"But you take it without suar?" she said, smilin all the time, as if
everythin she said and everythin the others said was very amusin and
had a double meanin.

"It is not the suar I want, but only that your little hand should stir
my tea."

Mary Hendrikhovna assented and bean lookin for the spoon which someone
meanwhile had pounced on.

"Use your finer, Mary Hendrikhovna, it will be still nicer," said
Rostov.

"Too hot!" she replied, blushin with pleasure.

Ilyin put a few drops of rum into the bucket of water and brouht it to
Mary Hendrikhovna, askin her to stir it with her finer.

"This is my cup," said he. "Only dip your finer in it and I'll drink it
all up."

When they had emptied the samovar, Rostov took a pack of cards and
proposed that they should play "Kins" with Mary Hendrikhovna. They drew
lots to settle who should make up her set. At Rostov's suestion it was
areed that whoever became "Kin" should have the riht to kiss Mary
Hendrikhovna's hand, and that the "Booby" should o to refill and reheat
the samovar for the doctor when the latter awoke.

"Well, but supposin Mary Hendrikhovna is 'Kin'?" asked Ilyin.

"As it is, she is Queen, and her word is law!"

They had hardly beun to play before the doctor's disheveled head
suddenly appeared from behind Mary Hendrikhovna. He had been awake for
some time, listenin to what was bein said, and evidently found nothin
entertainin or amusin in what was oin on. His face was sad and
depressed. Without reetin the officers, he scratched himself and asked

Hendrikhovna blushed till her eyes filled with tears and thereby became
still more attractive to them. Returnin from the yard, the doctor told
his wife (who had ceased to smile so happily, and looked at him in
alarm, awaitin her sentence) that the rain had ceased and they must o
to sleep in their covered cart, or everythin in it would be stolen.

"But I'll send an orderly.... Two of them!" said Rostov. "What an idea,
doctor!"

"I'll stand uard on it myself!" said Ilyin.

"No, entlemen, you have had your sleep, but I have not slept for two
nihts," replied the doctor, and he sat down morosely beside his wife,
waitin for the ame to end.

Seein his loomy face as he frowned at his wife, the officers rew
still merrier, and some of them could not refrain from lauhter, for
which they hurriedly souht plausible pretexts. When he had one, takin
his wife with him, and had settled down with her in their covered cart,
the officers lay down in the tavern, coverin themselves with their wet
cloaks, but they did not sleep for a lon time; now they exchaned
remarks, recallin the doctor's uneasiness and his wife's deliht, now
they ran out into the porch and reported what was takin place in the
covered trap. Several times Rostov, coverin his head, tried to o to
sleep, but some remark would arouse him and conversation would be
resumed, to the accompaniment of unreasonin, merry, childlike lauhter.




CHAPTER XIV

It was nearly three o'clock but no one was yet asleep, when the
quartermaster appeared with an order to move on to the little town of
Ostrovna. Still lauhin and talkin, the officers bean hurriedly
ettin ready and aain boiled some muddy water in the samovar. But
Rostov went off to his squadron without waitin for tea. Day was
breakin, the rain had ceased, and the clouds were dispersin. It felt
damp and cold, especially in clothes that were still moist. As they left
the tavern in the twiliht of the dawn, Rostov and Ilyin both lanced
under the wet and listenin leather hood of the doctor's cart, from
under the apron of which his feet were stickin out, and in the middle
of which his wife's nihtcap was visible and her sleepy breathin
audible.

"She really is a dear little thin," said Rostov to Ilyin, who was
followin him.

"A charmin woman!" said Ilyin, with all the ravity of a boy of
sixteen.

Half an hour later the squadron was lined up on the road. The command
was heard to "mount" and the soldiers crossed themselves and mounted.
Rostov ridin in front ave the order "Forward!" and the hussars, with
clankin sabers and subdued talk, their horses' hoofs splashin in the
mud, defiled in fours and moved alon the broad road planted with birch
trees on each side, followin the infantry and a battery that had one
on in front.

Tattered, blue-purple clouds, reddenin in the east, were scuddin
before the wind. It was rowin lihter and lihter. That curly rass
which always rows by country roadsides became clearly visible, still
wet with the niht's rain; the droopin branches of the birches, also
wet, swayed in the wind and flun down briht drops of water to one
side. The soldiers' faces were more and more clearly visible. Rostov,
always closely followed by Ilyin, rode alon the side of the road
between two rows of birch trees.

When campainin, Rostov allowed himself the indulence of ridin not a
reimental but a Cossack horse. A jude of horses and a sportsman, he
had lately procured himself a lare, fine, mettlesome, Donets horse,
dun-colored, with liht mane and tail, and when he rode it no one could
outallop him. To ride this horse was a pleasure to him, and he thouht
of the horse, of the mornin, of the doctor's wife, but not once of the
impendin daner.

Formerly, when oin into action, Rostov had felt afraid; now he had not
the least feelin of fear. He was fearless, not because he had rown
used to bein under fire (one cannot row used to daner), but because
he had learned how to manae his thouhts when in daner. He had rown
accustomed when oin into action to think about anythin but what would
seem most likely to interest him--the impendin daner. Durin the first
period of his service, hard as he tried and much as he reproached
himself with cowardice, he had not been able to do this, but with time
it had come of itself. Now he rode beside Ilyin under the birch trees,
occasionally pluckin leaves from a branch that met his hand, sometimes
touchin his horse's side with his foot, or, without turnin round,

calm and careless an air as thouh he were merely out for a ride. He
lanced with pity at the excited face of Ilyin, who talked much and in
reat aitation. He knew from experience the tormentin expectation of
terror and death the cornet was sufferin and knew that only time could
help him.

As soon as the sun appeared in a clear strip of sky beneath the clouds,
the wind fell, as if it dared not spoil the beauty of the summer mornin
after the storm; drops still continued to fall, but vertically now, and
all was still. The whole sun appeared on the horizon and disappeared
behind a lon narrow cloud that hun above it. A few minutes later it
reappeared brihter still from behind the top of the cloud, tearin its
ede. Everythin rew briht and littered. And with that liht, and as
if in reply to it, came the sound of uns ahead of them.

Before Rostov had had time to consider and determine the distance of
that firin, Count Ostermann-Tolstoy's adjutant came allopin from
Vitebsk with orders to advance at a trot alon the road.

The squadron overtook and passed the infantry and the battery--which had
also quickened their pace--rode down a hill, and passin throuh an
empty and deserted villae aain ascended. The horses bean to lather
and the men to flush.

"Halt! Dress your ranks!" the order of the reimental commander was
heard ahead. "Forward by the left. Walk, march!" came the order from in
front.

And the hussars, passin alon the line of troops on the left flank of
our position, halted behind our uhlans who were in the front line. To
the riht stood our infantry in a dense column: they were the reserve.
Hiher up the hill, on the very horizon, our uns were visible throuh
the wonderfully clear air, brihtly illuminated by slantin mornin
sunbeams. In front, beyond a hollow dale, could be seen the enemy's
columns and uns. Our advanced line, already in action, could be heard
briskly exchanin shots with the enemy in the dale.

At these sounds, lon unheard, Rostov's spirits rose, as at the strains
of the merriest music. Trap-ta-ta-tap! cracked the shots, now toether,
now several quickly one after another. Aain all was silent and then
aain it sounded as if someone were walkin on detonators and explodin
them.

The hussars remained in the same place for about an hour. A cannonade
bean. Count Ostermann with his suite rode up behind the squadron,
halted, spoke to the commander of the reiment, and rode up the hill to
the uns.

After Ostermann had one, a command ran out to the uhlans.

"Form column! Prepare to chare!"

The infantry in front of them parted into platoons to allow the cavalry
to pass. The uhlans started, the streamers on their spears flutterin,
and trotted downhill toward the French cavalry which was seen below to
the left.

As soon as the uhlans descended the hill, the hussars were ordered up
the hill to support the battery. As they took the places vacated by the
uhlans, bullets came from the front, whinin and whistlin, but fell
spent without takin effect.

The sounds, which he had not heard for so lon, had an even more
pleasurable and exhilaratin effect on Rostov than the previous sounds
of firin. Drawin himself up, he viewed the field of battle openin out
before him from the hill, and with his whole soul followed the movement
of the uhlans. They swooped down close to the French draoons, somethin
confused happened there amid the smoke, and five minutes later our
uhlans were allopin back, not to the place they had occupied but more
to the left, and amon the orane-colored uhlans on chestnut horses and
behind them, in a lare roup, blue French draoons on ray horses could
be seen.




CHAPTER XV

Rostov, with his keen sportsman's eye, was one of the first to catch
siht of these blue French draoons pursuin our uhlans. Nearer and
nearer in disorderly crowds came the uhlans and the French draoons
pursuin them. He could already see how these men, who looked so small
at the foot of the hill, jostled and overtook one another, wavin their
arms and their sabers in the air.

Rostov azed at what was happenin before him as at a hunt. He felt
instinctively that if the hussars struck at the French draoons now, the
latter could not withstand them, but if a chare was to be made it must
be done now, at that very moment, or it would be too late. He looked
around. A captain, standin beside him, was azin like himself with
eyes fixed on the cavalry below them.

"Andrew Sevastyanych!" said Rostov. "You know, we could crush them...."

"A fine thin too!" replied the captain, "and really..."

Rostov, without waitin to hear him out, touched his horse, alloped to
the front of his squadron, and before he had time to finish ivin the
word of command, the whole squadron, sharin his feelin, was followin
him. Rostov himself did not know how or why he did it. He acted as he
did when huntin, without reflectin or considerin. He saw the draoons
near and that they were allopin in disorder; he knew they could not
withstand an attack--knew there was only that moment and that if he let
it slip it would not return. The bullets were whinin and whistlin so
stimulatinly around him and his horse was so eaer to o that he could
not restrain himself. He touched his horse, ave the word of command,
and immediately, hearin behind him the tramp of the horses of his
deployed squadron, rode at full trot downhill toward the draoons.
Hardly had they reached the bottom of the hill before their pace
instinctively chaned to a allop, which rew faster and faster as they
drew nearer to our uhlans and the French draoons who alloped after
them. The draoons were now close at hand. On seein the hussars, the
foremost bean to turn, while those behind bean to halt. With the same
feelin with which he had alloped across the path of a wolf, Rostov
ave rein to his Donets horse and alloped to intersect the path of the
draoons' disordered lines. One Uhlan stopped, another who was on foot
flun himself to the round to avoid bein knocked over, and a riderless
horse fell in amon the hussars. Nearly all the French draoons were
allopin back. Rostov, pickin out one on a ray horse, dashed after
him. On the way he came upon a bush, his allant horse cleared it, and
almost before he had rihted himself in his saddle he saw that he would
immediately overtake the enemy he had selected. That Frenchman, by his
uniform an officer, was oin at a allop, crouchin on his ray horse
and urin it on with his saber. In another moment Rostov's horse dashed
its breast aainst the hindquarters of the officer's horse, almost
knockin it over, and at the same instant Rostov, without knowin why,
raised his saber and struck the Frenchman with it.

The instant he had done this, all Rostov's animation vanished. The
officer fell, not so much from the blow--which had but slihtly cut his
arm above the elbow--as from the shock to his horse and from friht.
Rostov reined in his horse, and his eyes souht his foe to see whom he
had vanquished. The French draoon officer was hoppin with one foot on
the round, the other bein cauht in the stirrup. His eyes, screwed up
with fear as if he every moment expected another blow, azed up at
Rostov with shrinkin terror. His pale and mud-stained face--fair and
youn, with a dimple in the chin and liht-blue eyes--was not an enemy's
face at all suited to a battlefield, but a most ordinary, homelike face.
Before Rostov had decided what to do with him, the officer cried, "I
surrender!" He hurriedly but vainly tried to et his foot out of the
stirrup and did not remove his frihtened blue eyes from Rostov's face.
Some hussars who alloped up disenaed his foot and helped him into the
saddle. On all sides, the hussars were busy with the draoons; one was
wounded, but thouh his face was bleedin, he would not ive up his
horse; another was perched up behind an hussar with his arms round him;
a third was bein helped by an hussar to mount his horse. In front, the
French infantry were firin as they ran. The hussars alloped hastily
back with their prisoners. Rostov alloped back with the rest, aware of
an unpleasant feelin of depression in his heart. Somethin vaue and
confused, which he could not at all account for, had come over him with
the capture of that officer and the blow he had dealt him.

Count Ostermann-Tolstoy met the returnin hussars, sent for Rostov,
thanked him, and said he would report his allant deed to the Emperor
and would recommend him for a St. eore's Cross. When sent for by Count
Ostermann, Rostov, rememberin that he had chared without orders, felt
sure his commander was sendin for him to punish him for breach of
discipline. Ostermann's flatterin words and promise of a reward should
therefore have struck him all the more pleasantly, but he still felt
that same vauely disareeable feelin of moral nausea. "But what on
earth is worryin me?" he asked himself as he rode back from the
eneral. "Ilyin? No, he's safe. Have I disraced myself in any way? No,
that's not it." Somethin else, resemblin remorse, tormented him. "Yes,
oh yes, that French officer with the dimple. And I remember how my arm
paused when I raised it."

Rostov saw the prisoners bein led away and alloped after them to have
a look at his Frenchman with the dimple on his chin. He was sittin in
his forein uniform on an hussar packhorse and looked anxiously about
him; The sword cut on his arm could scarcely be called a wound. He
lanced at Rostov with a feined smile and waved his hand in reetin.
Rostov still had the same indefinite feelin, as of shame.

All that day and the next his friends and comrades noticed that Rostov,
without bein dull or anry, was silent, thouhtful, and preoccupied. He
drank reluctantly, tried to remain alone, and kept turnin somethin
over in his mind.

Rostov was always thinkin about that brilliant exploit of his, which to
his amazement had ained him the St. eore's Cross and even iven him a
reputation for bravery, and there was somethin he could not at all
understand. "So others are even more afraid than I am!" he thouht. "So
that's all there is in what is called heroism! And did I do it for my
country's sake? And how was he to blame, with his dimple and blue eyes?
And how frihtened he was! He thouht that I should kill him. Why should
I kill him? My hand trembled. And they have iven me a St. eore's
Cross.... I can't make it out at all."

But while Nicholas was considerin these questions and still could reach
no clear solution of what puzzled him so, the wheel of fortune in the
service, as often happens, turned in his favor. After the affair at
Ostrovna he was brouht into notice, received command of an hussar
battalion, and when a brave officer was needed he was chosen.




CHAPTER XVI

On receivin news of Natasha's illness, the countess, thouh not quite
well yet and still weak, went to Moscow with Petya and the rest of the
household, and the whole family moved from Marya Dmitrievna's house to
their own and settled down in town.

Natasha's illness was so serious that, fortunately for her and for her
parents, the consideration of all that had caused the illness, her
conduct and the breakin off of her enaement, receded into the
backround. She was so ill that it was impossible for them to consider
in how far she was to blame for what had happened. She could not eat or
sleep, rew visibly thinner, couhed, and, as the doctors made them
feel, was in daner. They could not think of anythin but how to help
her. Doctors came to see her sinly and in consultation, talked much in
French, erman, and Latin, blamed one another, and prescribed a reat
variety of medicines for all the diseases known to them, but the simple
idea never occurred to any of them that they could not know the disease
Natasha was sufferin from, as no disease suffered by a live man can be
known, for every livin person has his own peculiarities and always has
his own peculiar, personal, novel, complicated disease, unknown to
medicine--not a disease of the luns, liver, skin, heart, nerves, and so
on mentioned in medical books, but a disease consistin of one of the
innumerable combinations of the maladies of those orans. This simple
thouht could not occur to the doctors (as it cannot occur to a wizard
that he is unable to work his charms) because the business of their
lives was to cure, and they received money for it and had spent the best
years of their lives on that business. But, above all, that thouht was
kept out of their minds by the fact that they saw they were really
useful, as in fact they were to the whole Rostov family. Their
usefulness did not depend on makin the patient swallow substances for
the most part harmful (the harm was scarcely perceptible, as they were
iven in small doses), but they were useful, necessary, and
indispensable because they satisfied a mental need of the invalid and of
those who loved her--and that is why there are, and always will be,
pseudo-healers, wise women, homeopaths, and allopaths. They satisfied
that eternal human need for hope of relief, for sympathy, and that
somethin should be done, which is felt by those who are sufferin. They
satisfied the need seen in its most elementary form in a child, when it
wants to have a place rubbed that has been hurt. A child knocks itself
and runs at once to the arms of its mother or nurse to have the achin
spot rubbed or kissed, and it feels better when this is done. The child
cannot believe that the stronest and wisest of its people have no
remedy for its pain, and the hope of relief and the expression of its
mother's sympathy while she rubs the bump comforts it. The doctors were
of use to Natasha because they kissed and rubbed her bump, assurin her
that it would soon pass if only the coachman went to the chemist's in
the Arbat and ot a powder and some pills in a pretty box for a ruble
and seventy kopeks, and if she took those powders in boiled water at
intervals of precisely two hours, neither more nor less.

What would Sonya and the count and countess have done, how would they
have looked, if nothin had been done, if there had not been those pills
to ive by the clock, the warm drinks, the chicken cutlets, and all the
other details of life ordered by the doctors, the carryin out of which
supplied an occupation and consolation to the family circle? How would
the count have borne his dearly loved dauhter's illness had he not
known that it was costin him a thousand rubles, and that he would not
rude thousands more to benefit her, or had he not known that if her
illness continued he would not rude yet other thousands and would take
her abroad for consultations there, and had he not been able to explain
the details of how Metivier and Feller had not understood the symptoms,
but Frise had, and Mudrov had dianosed them even better? What would the
countess have done had she not been able sometimes to scold the invalid
for not strictly obeyin the doctor's orders?

"You'll never et well like that," she would say, forettin her rief
in her vexation, "if you won't obey the doctor and take your medicine at
the riht time! You mustn't trifle with it, you know, or it may turn to
pneumonia," she would o on, derivin much comfort from the utterance of
that forein word, incomprehensible to others as well as to herself.

What would Sonya have done without the lad consciousness that she had
not undressed durin the first three nihts, in order to be ready to
carry out all the doctor's injunctions with precision, and that she
still kept awake at niht so as not to miss the proper time when the
slihtly harmful pills in the little ilt box had to be administered?
Even to Natasha herself it was pleasant to see that so many sacrifices
were bein made for her sake, and to know that she had to take medicine
at certain hours, thouh she declared that no medicine would cure her
and that it was all nonsense. And it was even pleasant to be able to
show, by disreardin the orders, that she did not believe in medical
treatment and did not value her life.

The doctor came every day, felt her pulse, looked at her tonue, and
reardless of her rief-stricken face joked with her. But when he had
one into another room, to which the countess hurriedly followed him, he
assumed a rave air and thouhtfully shakin his head said that thouh
there was daner, he had hopes of the effect of this last medicine and
one must wait and see, that the malady was chiefly mental, but... And
the countess, tryin to conceal the action from herself and from him,
slipped a old coin into his hand and always returned to the patient
with a more tranquil mind.

The symptoms of Natasha's illness were that she ate little, slept
little, couhed, and was always low-spirited. The doctors said that she
could not et on without medical treatment, so they kept her in the
stiflin atmosphere of the town, and the Rostovs did not move to the
country that summer of 1812.

In spite of the many pills she swallowed and the drops and powders out
of the little bottles and boxes of which Madame Schoss who was fond of
such thins made a lare collection, and in spite of bein deprived of
the country life to which she was accustomed, youth prevailed. Natasha's
rief bean to be overlaid by the impressions of daily life, it ceased
to press so painfully on her heart, it radually faded into the past,
and she bean to recover physically.




CHAPTER XVII

Natasha was calmer but no happier. She not merely avoided all external
forms of pleasure--balls, promenades, concerts, and theaters--but she
never lauhed without a sound of tears in her lauhter. She could not
sin. As soon as she bean to lauh, or tried to sin by herself, tears
choked her: tears of remorse, tears at the recollection of those pure
times which could never return, tears of vexation that she should so
uselessly have ruined her youn life which miht have been so happy.
Lauhter and sinin in particular seemed to her like a blasphemy, in
face of her sorrow. Without any need of self-restraint, no wish to
coquet ever entered her head. She said and felt at that time that no man
was more to her than Nastasya Ivanovna, the buffoon. Somethin stood
sentinel within her and forbade her every joy. Besides, she had lost all
the old interests of her carefree irlish life that had been so full of
hope. The previous autumn, the huntin, "Uncle," and the Christmas
holidays spent with Nicholas at Otradnoe were what she recalled oftenest
and most painfully. What would she not have iven to brin back even a
sinle day of that time! But it was one forever. Her presentiment at
the time had not deceived her--that that state of freedom and readiness
for any enjoyment would not return aain. Yet it was necessary to live
on.

It comforted her to reflect that she was not better as she had formerly
imained, but worse, much worse, than anybody else in the world. But
this was not enouh. She knew that, and asked herself, "What next?" But
there was nothin to come. There was no joy in life, yet life was
passin. Natasha apparently tried not to be a burden or a hindrance to
anyone, but wanted nothin for herself. She kept away from everyone in
the house and felt at ease only with her brother Petya. She liked to be
with him better than with the others, and when alone with him she
sometimes lauhed. She hardly ever left the house and of those who came
to see them was lad to see only one person, Pierre. It would have been
impossible to treat her with more delicacy, reater care, and at the
same time more seriously than did Count Bezukhov. Natasha unconsciously
felt this delicacy and so found reat pleasure in his society. But she
was not even rateful to him for it; nothin ood on Pierre's part
seemed to her to be an effort, it seemed so natural for him to be kind
to everyone that there was no merit in his kindness. Sometimes Natasha
noticed embarrassment and awkwardness on his part in her presence,
especially when he wanted to do somethin to please her, or feared that
somethin they spoke of would awaken memories distressin to her. She
noticed this and attributed it to his eneral kindness and shyness,
which she imained must be the same toward everyone as it was to her.
After those involuntary words--that if he were free he would have asked
on his knees for her hand and her love--uttered at a moment when she was
so stronly aitated, Pierre never spoke to Natasha of his feelins; and
it seemed plain to her that those words, which had then so comforted
her, were spoken as all sorts of meaninless words are spoken to comfort
a cryin child. It was not because Pierre was a married man, but because
Natasha felt very stronly with him that moral barrier the absence of
which she had experienced with Kurain that it never entered her head
that the relations between him and herself could lead to love on her
part, still less on his, or even to the kind of tender, self-conscious,
romantic friendship between a man and a woman of which she had known
several instances.

Before the end of the fast of St. Peter, Arafena Ivanovna Belova, a
country neihbor of the Rostovs, came to Moscow to pay her devotions at
the shrines of the Moscow saints. She suested that Natasha should fast
and prepare for Holy Communion, and Natasha ladly welcomed the idea.
Despite the doctor's orders that she should not o out early in the
mornin, Natasha insisted on fastin and preparin for the sacrament,
not as they enerally prepared for it in the Rostov family by attendin
three services in their own house, but as Arafena Ivanovna did, by
oin to church every day for a week and not once missin Vespers,
Matins, or Mass.

The countess was pleased with Natasha's zeal; after the poor results of
the medical treatment, in the depths of her heart she hoped that prayer
miht help her dauhter more than medicines and, thouh not without fear
and concealin it from the doctor, she areed to Natasha's wish and
entrusted her to Belova. Arafena Ivanovna used to come to wake Natasha
at three in the mornin, but enerally found her already awake. She was
afraid of bein late for Matins. Hastily washin, and meekly puttin on
her shabbiest dress and an old mantilla, Natasha, shiverin in the fresh
air, went out into the deserted streets lit by the clear liht of dawn.
By Arafena Ivanovna's advice Natasha prepared herself not in their own
parish, but at a church where, accordin to the devout Arafena
Ivanovna, the priest was a man of very severe and lofty life. There were
never many people in the church; Natasha always stood beside Belova in
the customary place before an icon of the Blessed Virin, let into the
screen before the choir on the left side, and a feelin, new to her, of
humility before somethin reat and incomprehensible, seized her when at
that unusual mornin hour, azin at the dark face of the Virin
illuminated by the candles burnin before it and by the mornin liht
fallin from the window, she listened to the words of the service which
she tried to follow with understandin. When she understood them her
personal feelin became interwoven in the prayers with shades of its
own. When she did not understand, it was sweeter still to think that the
wish to understand everythin is pride, that it is impossible to
understand all, that it is only necessary to believe and to commit
oneself to od, whom she felt uidin her soul at those moments. She
crossed herself, bowed low, and when she did not understand, in horror
at her own vileness, simply asked od to forive her everythin,
everythin, to have mercy upon her. The prayers to which she surrendered
herself most of all were those of repentance. On her way home at an
early hour when she met no one but bricklayers oin to work or men
sweepin the street, and everybody within the houses was still asleep,
Natasha experienced a feelin new to her, a sense of the possibility of
correctin her faults, the possibility of a new, clean life, and of
happiness.

Durin the whole week she spent in this way, that feelin rew every
day. And the happiness of takin communion, or "communin" as Arafena
Ivanovna, joyously playin with the word, called it, seemed to Natasha
so reat that she felt she should never live till that blessed Sunday.

But the happy day came, and on that memorable Sunday, when, dressed in
white muslin, she returned home after communion, for the first time for
many months she felt calm and not oppressed by the thouht of the life
that lay before her.

The doctor who came to see her that day ordered her to continue the
powders he had prescribed a fortniht previously.

"She must certainly o on takin them mornin and evenin," said he,
evidently sincerely satisfied with his success. "Only, please be
particular about it.

"Be quite easy," he continued playfully, as he adroitly took the old
coin in his palm. "She will soon be sinin and frolickin about. The
last medicine has done her a very reat deal of ood. She has freshened
up very much."

The countess, with a cheerful expression on her face, looked down at her
nails and spat a little for luck as she returned to the drawin room.




CHAPTER XVIII

At the beinnin of July more and more disquietin reports about the war
bean to spread in Moscow; people spoke of an appeal by the Emperor to
the people, and of his comin himself from the army to Moscow. And as up
to the eleventh of July no manifesto or appeal had been received,
exaerated reports became current about them and about the position of
Russia. It was said that the Emperor was leavin the army because it was
in daner, it was said that Smolensk had surrendered, that Napoleon had
an army of a million and only a miracle could save Russia.

On the eleventh of July, which was Saturday, the manifesto was received
but was not yet in print, and Pierre, who was at the Rostovs', promised
to come to dinner next day, Sunday, and brin a copy of the manifesto
and appeal, which he would obtain from Count Rostopchin.

That Sunday, the Rostovs went to Mass at the Razumovskis' private chapel
as usual. It was a hot July day. Even at ten o'clock, when the Rostovs
ot out of their carriae at the chapel, the sultry air, the shouts of
hawkers, the liht and ay summer clothes of the crowd, the dusty leaves
of the trees on the boulevard, the sounds of the band and the white
trousers of a battalion marchin to parade, the rattlin of wheels on
the cobblestones, and the brilliant, hot sunshine were all full of that
summer lanuor, that content and discontent with the present, which is
