evoked by the memory of the time when the paper he was now readin had
been written. He took the letter from Michael Ivanovich's hand, put it
in his pocket, folded up his papers, and called in Alpatych who had lon
been waitin.

The prince had a list of thins to be bouht in Smolensk and, walkin up
and down the room past Alpatych who stood by the door, he ave his
instructions.

"First, notepaper--do you hear? Eiht quires, like this sample, ilt-
eded... it must be exactly like the sample. Varnish, sealin wax, as in
Michael Ivanovich's list."

He paced up and down for a while and lanced at his notes.

"Then hand to the overnor in person a letter about the deed."

Next, bolts for the doors of the new buildin were wanted and had to be
of a special shape the prince had himself desined, and a leather case
had to be ordered to keep the "will" in.

The instructions to Alpatych took over two hours and still the prince
did not let him o. He sat down, sank into thouht, closed his eyes, and
dozed off. Alpatych made a sliht movement.

"Well, o, o! If anythin more is wanted I'll send after you."

Alpatych went out. The prince aain went to his bureau, lanced into it,
finered his papers, closed the bureau aain, and sat down at the table
to write to the overnor.

It was already late when he rose after sealin the letter. He wished to
sleep, but he knew he would not be able to and that most depressin
thouhts came to him in bed. So he called Tikhon and went throuh the
rooms with him to show him where to set up the bed for that niht.

He went about lookin at every corner. Every place seemed
unsatisfactory, but worst of all was his customary couch in the study.
That couch was dreadful to him, probably because of the oppressive
thouhts he had had when lyin there. It was unsatisfactory everywhere,
but the corner behind the piano in the sittin room was better than
other places: he had never slept there yet.

With the help of a footman Tikhon brouht in the bedstead and bean
puttin it up.

"That's not riht! That's not riht!" cried the prince, and himself
pushed it a few inches from the corner and then closer in aain.

"Well, at last I've finished, now I'll rest," thouht the prince, and
let Tikhon undress him.

Frownin with vexation at the effort necessary to divest himself of his
coat and trousers, the prince undressed, sat down heavily on the bed,
and appeared to be meditatin as he looked contemptuously at his
withered yellow les. He was not meditatin, but only deferrin the
moment of makin the effort to lift those les up and turn over on the
bed. "Uh, how hard it is! Oh, that this toil miht end and you would
release me!" thouht he. Pressin his lips toether he made that effort
for the twenty-thousandth time and lay down. But hardly had he done so
before he felt the bed rockin backwards and forwards beneath him as if
it were breathin heavily and joltin. This happened to him almost every
niht. He opened his eyes as they were closin.

"No peace, damn them!" he muttered, anry he knew not with whom. "Ah
yes, there was somethin else important, very important, that I was
keepin till I should be in bed. The bolts? No, I told him about them.
No, it was somethin, somethin in the drawin room. Princess Mary
talked some nonsense. Dessalles, that fool, said somethin. Somethin in
my pocket--can't remember..."

"Tikhon, what did we talk about at dinner?"

"About Prince Michael..."

"Be quiet, quiet!" The prince slapped his hand on the table. "Yes, I
know, Prince Andrew's letter! Princess Mary read it. Dessalles said
somethin about Vitebsk. Now I'll read it."

He had the letter taken from his pocket and the table--on which stood a
lass of lemonade and a spiral wax candle--moved close to the bed, and
puttin on his spectacles he bean readin. Only now in the stillness of
the niht, readin it by the faint liht under the reen shade, did he
rasp its meanin for a moment.

"The French at Vitebsk, in four days' march they may be at Smolensk;
perhaps are already there! Tikhon!" Tikhon jumped up. "No, no, I don't
want anythin!" he shouted.

He put the letter under the candlestick and closed his eyes. And there
rose before him the Danube at briht noonday: reeds, the Russian camp,
and himself a youn eneral without a wrinkle on his ruddy face,
viorous and alert, enterin Potemkin's aily colored tent, and a
burnin sense of jealousy of "the favorite" aitated him now as stronly
as it had done then. He recalled all the words spoken at that first
meetin with Potemkin. And he saw before him a plump, rather sallow-
faced, short, stout woman, the Empress Mother, with her smile and her
words at her first racious reception of him, and then that same face on
the catafalque, and the encounter he had with Zubov over her coffin
about his riht to kiss her hand.

"Oh, quicker, quicker! To et back to that time and have done with all
the present! Quicker, quicker--and that they should leave me in peace!"




CHAPTER IV

Bald Hills, Prince Nicholas Bolkonski's estate, lay forty miles east
from Smolensk and two miles from the main road to Moscow.

The same evenin that the prince ave his instructions to Alpatych,
Dessalles, havin asked to see Princess Mary, told her that, as the
prince was not very well and was takin no steps to secure his safety,
thouh from Prince Andrew's letter it was evident that to remain at Bald
Hills miht be danerous, he respectfully advised her to send a letter
by Alpatych to the Provincial overnor at Smolensk, askin him to let
her know the state of affairs and the extent of the daner to which Bald
Hills was exposed. Dessalles wrote this letter to the overnor for
Princess Mary, she sined it, and it was iven to Alpatych with
instructions to hand it to the overnor and to come back as quickly as
possible if there was daner.

Havin received all his orders Alpatych, wearin a white beaver hat--a
present from the prince--and carryin a stick as the prince did, went
out accompanied by his family. Three well-fed roans stood ready
harnessed to a small conveyance with a leather hood.

The larer bell was muffled and the little bells on the harness stuffed
with paper. The prince allowed no one at Bald Hills to drive with
rinin bells; but on a lon journey Alpatych liked to have them. His
satellites--the senior clerk, a countinhouse clerk, a scullery maid, a
cook, two old women, a little paeboy, the coachman, and various
domestic serfs--were seein him off.

His dauhter placed chintz-covered down cushions for him to sit on and
behind his back. His old sister-in-law popped in a small bundle, and one
of the coachmen helped him into the vehicle.

"There! There! Women's fuss! Women, women!" said Alpatych, puffin and
speakin rapidly just as the prince did, and he climbed into the trap.

After ivin the clerk orders about the work to be done, Alpatych, not
tryin to imitate the prince now, lifted the hat from his bald head and
crossed himself three times.

"If there is anythin... come back, Yakov Alpatych! For Christ's sake
think of us!" cried his wife, referrin to the rumors of war and the
enemy.

"Women, women! Women's fuss!" muttered Alpatych to himself and started
on his journey, lookin round at the fields of yellow rye and the still-
reen, thickly rowin oats, and at other quite black fields just bein
plowed a second time.

As he went alon he looked with pleasure at the year's splendid crop of
corn, scrutinized the strips of ryefield which here and there were
already bein reaped, made his calculations as to the sowin and the
harvest, and asked himself whether he had not forotten any of the
prince's orders.

Havin baited the horses twice on the way, he arrived at the town toward
evenin on the fourth of Auust.

Alpatych kept meetin and overtakin baae trains and troops on the
road. As he approached Smolensk he heard the sounds of distant firin,
but these did not impress him. What struck him most was the siht of a
splendid field of oats in which a camp had been pitched and which was
bein mown down by the soldiers, evidently for fodder. This fact
impressed Alpatych, but in thinkin about his own business he soon
forot it.

All the interests of his life for more than thirty years had been
bounded by the will of the prince, and he never went beyond that limit.
Everythin not connected with the execution of the prince's orders did
not interest and did not even exist for Alpatych.

On reachin Smolensk on the evenin of the fourth of Auust he put up in
the achina suburb across the Dnieper, at the inn kept by Ferapontov,
where he had been in the habit of puttin up for the last thirty years.
Some thirty years ao Ferapontov, by Alpatych's advice, had bouht a
wood from the prince, had beun to trade, and now had a house, an inn,
and a corn dealer's shop in that province. He was a stout, dark, red-
faced peasant in the forties, with thick lips, a broad knob of a nose,
similar knobs over his black frownin brows, and a round belly.

Wearin a waistcoat over his cotton shirt, Ferapontov was standin
before his shop which opened onto the street. On seein Alpatych he went
up to him.

"You're welcome, Yakov Alpatych. Folks are leavin the town, but you
have come to it," said he.

"Why are they leavin the town?" asked Alpatych.

"That's what I say. Folks are foolish! Always afraid of the French."

"Women's fuss, women's fuss!" said Alpatych.

"Just what I think, Yakov Alpatych. What I say is: orders have been
iven not to let them in, so that must be riht. And the peasants are
askin three rubles for cartin--it isn't Christian!"

Yakov Alpatych heard without heedin. He asked for a samovar and for hay
for his horses, and when he had had his tea he went to bed.

All niht lon troops were movin past the inn. Next mornin Alpatych
donned a jacket he wore only in town and went out on business. It was a
sunny mornin and by eiht o'clock it was already hot. "A ood day for
harvestin," thouht Alpatych.

From beyond the town firin had been heard since early mornin. At eiht
o'clock the boomin of cannon was added to the sound of musketry. Many
people were hurryin throuh the streets and there were many soldiers,
but cabs were still drivin about, tradesmen stood at their shops, and
service was bein held in the churches as usual. Alpatych went to the
shops, to overnment offices, to the post office, and to the overnor's.
In the offices and shops and at the post office everyone was talkin
about the army and about the enemy who was already attackin the town,
everybody was askin what should be done, and all were tryin to calm
one another.

In front of the overnor's house Alpatych found a lare number of
people, Cossacks, and a travelin carriae of the overnor's. At the
porch he met two of the landed entry, one of whom he knew. This man, an
ex-captain of police, was sayin anrily:

"It's no joke, you know! It's all very well if you're sinle. 'One man
thouh undone is but one,' as the proverb says, but with thirteen in
your family and all the property... They've brouht us to utter ruin!
What sort of overnors are they to do that? They ouht to be haned--the
briands!..."

"Oh come, that's enouh!" said the other.

"What do I care? Let him hear! We're not dos," said the ex-captain of
police, and lookin round he noticed Alpatych.

"Oh, Yakov Alpatych! What have you come for?"

"To see the overnor by his excellency's order," answered Alpatych,
liftin his head and proudly thrustin his hand into the bosom of his
coat as he always did when he mentioned the prince.... "He has ordered
me to inquire into the position of affairs," he added.

"Yes, o and find out!" shouted the anry entleman. "They've brouht
thins to such a pass that there are no carts or anythin!... There it
is aain, do you hear?" said he, pointin in the direction whence came
the sounds of firin.

"They've brouht us all to ruin... the briands!" he repeated, and
descended the porch steps.

Alpatych swayed his head and went upstairs. In the waitin room were
tradesmen, women, and officials, lookin silently at one another. The
door of the overnor's room opened and they all rose and moved forward.
An official ran out, said some words to a merchant, called a stout
official with a cross hanin on his neck to follow him, and vanished
aain, evidently wishin to avoid the inquirin looks and questions
addressed to him. Alpatych moved forward and next time the official came
out addressed him, one hand placed in the breast of his buttoned coat,
and handed him two letters.

"To his Honor Baron Asch, from eneral-in-Chief Prince Bolkonski," he
announced with such solemnity and sinificance that the official turned
to him and took the letters.

A few minutes later the overnor received Alpatych and hurriedly said to
him:

"Inform the prince and princess that I knew nothin: I acted on the
hihest instructions--here..." and he handed a paper to Alpatych.
"Still, as the prince is unwell my advice is that they should o to
Moscow. I am just startin myself. Inform them..."

But the overnor did not finish: a dusty perspirin officer ran into the
room and bean to say somethin in French. The overnor's face expressed
terror.

"o," he said, noddin his head to Alpatych, and bean questionin the
officer.

Eaer, frihtened, helpless lances were turned on Alpatych when he came
out of the overnor's room. Involuntarily listenin now to the firin,
which had drawn nearer and was increasin in strenth, Alpatych hurried
to his inn. The paper handed to him by the overnor said this:

"I assure you that the town of Smolensk is not in the slihtest daner
as yet and it is unlikely that it will be threatened with any. I from
the one side and Prince Baration from the other are marchin to unite
our forces before Smolensk, which junction will be effected on the 22nd
instant, and both armies with their united forces will defend our
compatriots of the province entrusted to your care till our efforts
shall have beaten back the enemies of our Fatherland, or till the last
warrior in our valiant ranks has perished. From this you will see that
you have a perfect riht to reassure the inhabitants of Smolensk, for
those defended by two such brave armies may feel assured of victory."
(Instructions from Barclay de Tolly to Baron Asch, the civil overnor of
Smolensk, 1812.)

People were anxiously roamin about the streets.

Carts piled hih with household utensils, chairs, and cupboards kept
emerin from the ates of the yards and movin alon the streets.
Loaded carts stood at the house next to Ferapontov's and women were
wailin and lamentin as they said ood-by. A small watchdo ran round
barkin in front of the harnessed horses.

Alpatych entered the innyard at a quicker pace than usual and went
straiht to the shed where his horses and trap were. The coachman was
asleep. He woke him up, told him to harness, and went into the passae.
From the host's room came the sounds of a child cryin, the despairin
sobs of a woman, and the hoarse anry shoutin of Ferapontov. The cook
bean runnin hither and thither in the passae like a frihtened hen,
just as Alpatych entered.

"He's done her to death. Killed the mistress!... Beat her... draed her
about so!..."

"What for?" asked Alpatych.

"She kept bein to o away. She's a woman! 'Take me away,' says she,
'don't let me perish with my little children! Folks,' she says, 'are all
one, so why,' she says, 'don't we o?' And he bean beatin and pullin
her about so!"

At these words Alpatych nodded as if in approval, and not wishin to
hear more went to the door of the room opposite the innkeeper's, where
he had left his purchases.

"You brute, you murderer!" screamed a thin, pale woman who, with a baby
in her arms and her kerchief torn from her head, burst throuh the door
at that moment and down the steps into the yard.

Ferapontov came out after her, but on seein Alpatych adjusted his
waistcoat, smoothed his hair, yawned, and followed Alpatych into the
opposite room.

"oin already?" said he.

Alpatych, without answerin or lookin at his host, sorted his packaes
and asked how much he owed.

"We'll reckon up! Well, have you been to the overnor's?" asked
Ferapontov. "What has been decided?"

Alpatych replied that the overnor had not told him anythin definite.

"With our business, how can we et away?" said Ferapontov. "We'd have to
pay seven rubles a cartload to Doroobuzh and I tell them they're not
Christians to ask it! Selivanov, now, did a ood stroke last Thursday--
sold flour to the army at nine rubles a sack. Will you have some tea?"
he added.

While the horses were bein harnessed Alpatych and Ferapontov over their
tea talked of the price of corn, the crops, and the ood weather for
harvestin.

"Well, it seems to be ettin quieter," remarked Ferapontov, finishin
his third cup of tea and ettin up. "Ours must have ot the best of it.
The orders were not to let them in. So we're in force, it seems.... They
say the other day Matthew Ivanych Platov drove them into the river
Marina and drowned some eihteen thousand in one day."

Alpatych collected his parcels, handed them to the coachman who had come
in, and settled up with the innkeeper. The noise of wheels, hoofs, and
bells was heard from the ateway as a little trap passed out.

It was by now late in the afternoon. Half the street was in shadow, the
other half brihtly lit by the sun. Alpatych looked out of the window
and went to the door. Suddenly the strane sound of a far-off whistlin
and thud was heard, followed by a boom of cannon blendin into a dull
roar that set the windows rattlin.

He went out into the street: two men were runnin past toward the
bride. From different sides came whistlin sounds and the thud of
cannon balls and burstin shells fallin on the town. But these sounds
were hardly heard in comparison with the noise of the firin outside the
town and attracted little attention from the inhabitants. The town was
bein bombarded by a hundred and thirty uns which Napoleon had ordered
up after four o'clock. The people did not at once realize the meanin of
this bombardment.

At first the noise of the fallin bombs and shells only aroused
curiosity. Ferapontov's wife, who till then had not ceased wailin under
the shed, became quiet and with the baby in her arms went to the ate,
listenin to the sounds and lookin in silence at the people.

The cook and a shop assistant came to the ate. With lively curiosity
everyone tried to et a limpse of the projectiles as they flew over
their heads. Several people came round the corner talkin eaerly.

"What force!" remarked one. "Knocked the roof and ceilin all to
splinters!"

"Routed up the earth like a pi," said another.

"That's rand, it bucks one up!" lauhed the first. "Lucky you jumped
aside, or it would have wiped you out!"

Others joined those men and stopped and told how cannon balls had fallen
on a house close to them. Meanwhile still more projectiles, now with the
swift sinister whistle of a cannon ball, now with the areeable
intermittent whistle of a shell, flew over people's heads incessantly,
but not one fell close by, they all flew over. Alpatych was ettin into
his trap. The innkeeper stood at the ate.

"What are you starin at?" he shouted to the cook, who in her red skirt,
with sleeves rolled up, swinin her bare elbows, had stepped to the
corner to listen to what was bein said.

"What marvels!" she exclaimed, but hearin her master's voice she turned
back, pullin down her tucked-up skirt.

Once more somethin whistled, but this time quite close, swoopin
downwards like a little bird; a flame flashed in the middle of the
street, somethin exploded, and the street was shrouded in smoke.

"Scoundrel, what are you doin?" shouted the innkeeper, rushin to the
cook.

At that moment the pitiful wailin of women was heard from different
sides, the frihtened baby bean to cry, and people crowded silently
with pale faces round the cook. The loudest sound in that crowd was her
wailin.

"Oh-h-h! Dear souls, dear kind souls! Don't let me die! My ood
souls!..."

Five minutes later no one remained in the street. The cook, with her
thih broken by a shell splinter, had been carried into the kitchen.
Alpatych, his coachman, Ferapontov's wife and children and the house
porter were all sittin in the cellar, listenin. The roar of uns, the
whistlin of projectiles, and the piteous moanin of the cook, which
rose above the other sounds, did not cease for a moment. The mistress
rocked and hushed her baby and when anyone came into the cellar asked in
a pathetic whisper what had become of her husband who had remained in
the street. A shopman who entered told her that her husband had one
with others to the cathedral, whence they were fetchin the wonder-
workin icon of Smolensk.

Toward dusk the cannonade bean to subside. Alpatych left the cellar and
stopped in the doorway. The evenin sky that had been so clear was
clouded with smoke, throuh which, hih up, the sickle of the new moon
shone stranely. Now that the terrible din of the uns had ceased a hush
seemed to rein over the town, broken only by the rustle of footsteps,
the moanin, the distant cries, and the crackle of fires which seemed
widespread everywhere. The cook's moans had now subsided. On two sides
black curlin clouds of smoke rose and spread from the fires. Throuh
the streets soldiers in various uniforms walked or ran confusedly in
different directions like ants from a ruined ant-hill. Several of them
ran into Ferapontov's yard before Alpatych's eyes. Alpatych went out to
the ate. A retreatin reiment, thronin and hurryin, blocked the
street.

Noticin him, an officer said: "The town is bein abandoned. et away,
et away!" and then, turnin to the soldiers, shouted:

"I'll teach you to run into the yards!"

Alpatych went back to the house, called the coachman, and told him to
set off. Ferapontov's whole household came out too, followin Alpatych
and the coachman. The women, who had been silent till then, suddenly
bean to wail as they looked at the fires--the smoke and even the flames
of which could be seen in the failin twiliht--and as if in reply the
same kind of lamentation was heard from other parts of the street.
Inside the shed Alpatych and the coachman arraned the tanled reins and
traces of their horses with tremblin hands.

As Alpatych was drivin out of the ate he saw some ten soldiers in
Ferapontov's open shop, talkin loudly and fillin their bas and
knapsacks with flour and sunflower seeds. Just then Ferapontov returned
and entered his shop. On seein the soldiers he was about to shout at
them, but suddenly stopped and, clutchin at his hair, burst into sobs
and lauhter:

"Loot everythin, lads! Don't let those devils et it!" he cried, takin
some bas of flour himself and throwin them into the street.

Some of the soldiers were frihtened and ran away, others went on
fillin their bas. On seein Alpatych, Ferapontov turned to him:

"Russia is done for!" he cried. "Alpatych, I'll set the place on fire
myself. We're done for!..." and Ferapontov ran into the yard.

Soldiers were passin in a constant stream alon the street blockin it
completely, so that Alpatych could not pass out and had to wait.
Ferapontov's wife and children were also sittin in a cart waitin till
it was possible to drive out.

Niht had come. There were stars in the sky and the new moon shone out
amid the smoke that screened it. On the slopin descent to the Dnieper
Alpatych's cart and that of the innkeeper's wife, which were slowly
movin amid the rows of soldiers and of other vehicles, had to stop. In
a side street near the crossroads where the vehicles had stopped, a
house and some shops were on fire. This fire was already burnin itself
out. The flames now died down and were lost in the black smoke, now
suddenly flared up aain brihtly, lihtin up with strane distinctness
the faces of the people crowdin at the crossroads. Black fiures
flitted about before the fire, and throuh the incessant cracklin of
the flames talkin and shoutin could be heard. Seein that his trap
would not be able to move on for some time, Alpatych ot down and turned
into the side street to look at the fire. Soldiers were continually
rushin backwards and forwards near it, and he saw two of them and a man
in a frieze coat drain burnin beams into another yard across the
street, while others carried bundles of hay.

Alpatych went up to a lare crowd standin before a hih barn which was
blazin briskly. The walls were all on fire and the back wall had fallen
in, the wooden roof was collapsin, and the rafters were aliht. The
crowd was evidently watchin for the roof to fall in, and Alpatych
watched for it too.

"Alpatych!" a familiar voice suddenly hailed the old man.

"Mercy on us! Your excellency!" answered Alpatych, immediately
reconizin the voice of his youn prince.

Prince Andrew in his ridin cloak, mounted on a black horse, was lookin
at Alpatych from the back of the crowd.

"Why are you here?" he asked.

"Your... your excellency," stammered Alpatych and broke into sobs. "Are
we really lost? Master!..."

"Why are you here?" Prince Andrew repeated.

At that moment the flames flared up and showed his youn master's pale
worn face. Alpatych told how he had been sent there and how difficult it
was to et away.

"Are we really quite lost, your excellency?" he asked aain.

Prince Andrew without replyin took out a notebook and raisin his knee
bean writin in pencil on a pae he tore out. He wrote to his sister:

"Smolensk is bein abandoned. Bald Hills will be occupied by the enemy
within a week. Set off immediately for Moscow. Let me know at once when
you will start. Send by special messener to Usvyazh."

Havin written this and iven the paper to Alpatych, he told him how to
arrane for departure of the prince, the princess, his son, and the
boy's tutor, and how and where to let him know immediately. Before he
had had time to finish ivin these instructions, a chief of staff
followed by a suite alloped up to him.

"You are a colonel?" shouted the chief of staff with a erman accent, in
a voice familiar to Prince Andrew. "Houses are set on fire in your
presence and you stand by! What does this mean? You will answer for it!"
shouted Ber, who was now assistant to the chief of staff of the
commander of the left flank of the infantry of the first army, a place,
as Ber said, "very areeable and well en evidence."

Prince Andrew looked at him and without replyin went on speakin to
Alpatych.

"So tell them that I shall await a reply till the tenth, and if by the
tenth I don't receive news that they have all ot away I shall have to
throw up everythin and come myself to Bald Hills."

"Prince," said Ber, reconizin Prince Andrew, "I only spoke because I
have to obey orders, because I always do obey exactly.... You must
please excuse me," he went on apoloetically.

Somethin cracked in the flames. The fire died down for a moment and
wreaths of black smoke rolled from under the roof. There was another
terrible crash and somethin hue collapsed.

"Ou-rou-rou!" yelled the crowd, echoin the crash of the collapsin roof
of the barn, the burnin rain in which diffused a cakelike aroma all
around. The flames flared up aain, lihtin the animated, delihted,
exhausted faces of the spectators.

The man in the frieze coat raised his arms and shouted:

"It's fine, lads! Now it's rain... It's fine!"

"That's the owner himself," cried several voices.

"Well then," continued Prince Andrew to Alpatych, "report to them as I
have told you"; and not replyin a word to Ber who was now mute beside
him, he touched his horse and rode down the side street.




CHAPTER V

From Smolensk the troops continued to retreat, followed by the enemy. On
the tenth of Auust the reiment Prince Andrew commanded was marchin
alon the hihroad past the avenue leadin to Bald Hills. Heat and
drouht had continued for more than three weeks. Each day fleecy clouds
floated across the sky and occasionally veiled the sun, but toward
evenin the sky cleared aain and the sun set in reddish-brown mist.
Heavy niht dews alone refreshed the earth. The unreaped corn was
scorched and shed its rain. The marshes dried up. The cattle lowed from
huner, findin no food on the sun-parched meadows. Only at niht and in
the forests while the dew lasted was there any freshness. But on the
road, the hihroad alon which the troops marched, there was no such
freshness even at niht or when the road passed throuh the forest; the
dew was imperceptible on the sandy dust churned up more than six inches
deep. As soon as day dawned the march bean. The artillery and baae
waons moved noiselessly throuh the deep dust that rose to the very
hubs of the wheels, and the infantry sank ankle-deep in that soft,
chokin, hot dust that never cooled even at niht. Some of this dust was
kneaded by the feet and wheels, while the rest rose and hun like a
cloud over the troops, settlin in eyes, ears, hair, and nostrils, and
worst of all in the luns of the men and beasts as they moved alon that
road. The hiher the sun rose the hiher rose that cloud of dust, and
throuh the screen of its hot fine particles one could look with naked
eye at the sun, which showed like a hue crimson ball in the unclouded
sky. There was no wind, and the men choked in that motionless
atmosphere. They marched with handkerchiefs tied over their noses and
mouths. When they passed throuh a villae they all rushed to the wells
and fouht for the water and drank it down to the mud.

Prince Andrew was in command of a reiment, and the manaement of that
reiment, the welfare of the men and the necessity of receivin and
ivin orders, enrossed him. The burnin of Smolensk and its
abandonment made an epoch in his life. A novel feelin of aner aainst
the foe made him foret his own sorrow. He was entirely devoted to the
affairs of his reiment and was considerate and kind to his men and
officers. In the reiment they called him "our prince," were proud of
him and loved him. But he was kind and entle only to those of his
reiment, to Timokhin and the like--people quite new to him, belonin
to a different world and who could not know and understand his past. As
soon as he came across a former acquaintance or anyone from the staff,
he bristled up immediately and rew spiteful, ironical, and
contemptuous. Everythin that reminded him of his past was repunant to
him, and so in his relations with that former circle he confined himself
to tryin to do his duty and not to be unfair.

In truth everythin presented itself in a dark and loomy liht to
Prince Andrew, especially after the abandonment of Smolensk on the sixth
of Auust (he considered that it could and should have been defended)
and after his sick father had had to flee to Moscow, abandonin to
pillae his dearly beloved Bald Hills which he had built and peopled.
But despite this, thanks to his reiment, Prince Andrew had somethin to
think about entirely apart from eneral questions. Two days previously
he had received news that his father, son, and sister had left for
Moscow; and thouh there was nothin for him to do at Bald Hills, Prince
Andrew with a characteristic desire to foment his own rief decided that
he must ride there.

He ordered his horse to be saddled and, leavin his reiment on the
march, rode to his father's estate where he had been born and spent his
childhood. Ridin past the pond where there used always to be dozens of
women chatterin as they rinsed their linen or beat it with wooden
beetles, Prince Andrew noticed that there was not a soul about and that
the little washin wharf, torn from its place and half submered, was
floatin on its side in the middle of the pond. He rode to the keeper's
lode. No one at the stone entrance ates of the drive and the door
stood open. rass had already beun to row on the arden paths, and
horses and calves were strayin in the Enlish park. Prince Andrew rode
up to the hothouse; some of the lass panes were broken, and of the
trees in tubs some were overturned and others dried up. He called for
Taras the ardener, but no one replied. Havin one round the corner of
the hothouse to the ornamental arden, he saw that the carved arden
fence was broken and branches of the plum trees had been torn off with
the fruit. An old peasant whom Prince Andrew in his childhood had often
seen at the ate was sittin on a reen arden seat, plaitin a bast
shoe.

He was deaf and did not hear Prince Andrew ride up. He was sittin on
the seat the old prince used to like to sit on, and beside him strips of
bast were hanin on the broken and withered branch of a manolia.

Prince Andrew rode up to the house. Several limes in the old arden had
been cut down and a piebald mare and her foal were wanderin in front of
the house amon the rosebushes. The shutters were all closed, except at
one window which was open. A little serf boy, seein Prince Andrew, ran
into the house. Alpatych, havin sent his family away, was alone at Bald
Hills and was sittin indoors readin the Lives of the Saints. On
hearin that Prince Andrew had come, he went out with his spectacles on
his nose, buttonin his coat, and, hastily steppin up, without a word
bean weepin and kissin Prince Andrew's knee.

Then, vexed at his own weakness, he turned away and bean to report on
the position of affairs. Everythin precious and valuable had been
removed to Boucharovo. Seventy quarters of rain had also been carted
away. The hay and the sprin corn, of which Alpatych said there had been
a remarkable crop that year, had been commandeered by the troops and
mown down while still reen. The peasants were ruined; some of them too
had one to Boucharovo, only a few remained.

Without waitin to hear him out, Prince Andrew asked:

"When did my father and sister leave?" meanin when did they leave for
Moscow.

Alpatych, understandin the question to refer to their departure for
Boucharovo, replied that they had left on the seventh and aain went
into details concernin the estate manaement, askin for instructions.

"Am I to let the troops have the oats, and to take a receipt for them?
We have still six hundred quarters left," he inquired.

"What am I to say to him?" thouht Prince Andrew, lookin down on the
old man's bald head shinin in the sun and seein by the expression on
his face that the old man himself understood how untimely such questions
were and only asked them to allay his rief.

"Yes, let them have it," replied Prince Andrew.

"If you noticed some disorder in the arden," said Alpatych, "it was
impossible to prevent it. Three reiments have been here and spent the
niht, draoons mostly. I took down the name and rank of their
commandin officer, to hand in a complaint about it."

"Well, and what are you oin to do? Will you stay here if the enemy
occupies the place?" asked Prince Andrew.

Alpatych turned his face to Prince Andrew, looked at him, and suddenly
with a solemn esture raised his arm.

"He is my refue! His will be done!" he exclaimed.

A roup of bareheaded peasants was approachin across the meadow toward
the prince.

"Well, ood-by!" said Prince Andrew, bendin over to Alpatych. "You must
o away too, take away what you can and tell the serfs to o to the
Ryazan estate or to the one near Moscow."

Alpatych clun to Prince Andrew's le and burst into sobs. ently
disenain himself, the prince spurred his horse and rode down the
avenue at a allop.

The old man was still sittin in the ornamental arden, like a fly
impassive on the face of a loved one who is dead, tappin the last on
which he was makin the bast shoe, and two little irls, runnin out
from the hot house carryin in their skirts plums they had plucked from
the trees there, came upon Prince Andrew. On seein the youn master,
the elder one with frihtened look clutched her youner companion by the
hand and hid with her behind a birch tree, not stoppin to pick up some
reen plums they had dropped.

Prince Andrew turned away with startled haste, unwillin to let them see
that they had been observed. He was sorry for the pretty frihtened
little irl, was afraid of lookin at her, and yet felt an irresistible
desire to do so. A new sensation of comfort and relief came over him
when, seein these irls, he realized the existence of other human
interests entirely aloof from his own and just as leitimate as those

-to carry away and eat those reen plums without bein cauht--and

they spran from their ambush and, chirrupin somethin in their shrill

feet scampered merrily and quickly across the meadow rass.

Prince Andrew was somewhat refreshed by havin ridden off the dusty
hihroad alon which the troops were movin. But not far from Bald Hills

One fair-haired youn soldier of the third company, whom Prince Andrew

yellin, and puffin.

Everywhere on the bank, on the dam, and in the pond, there was healthy,
white, muscular flesh. The officer, Timokhin, with his red little nose,

"It's very nice, your excellency! Wouldn't you like to?" said he.

"It's dirty," replied Prince Andrew, makin a rimace.

"We'll clear it out for you in a minute," said Timokhin, and, still
undressed, ran off to clear the men out of the pond.

"The prince wants to bathe."

"What prince? Ours?" said many voices, and the men were in such haste to
clear out that the prince could hardly stop them. He decided that he
would rather wash himself with water in the barn.

"Flesh, bodies, cannon fodder!" he thouht, and he looked at his own
naked body and shuddered, not from cold but from a sense of disust and
horror he did not himself understand, aroused by the siht of that
immense number of bodies splashin about in the dirty pond.

On the seventh of Auust Prince Baration wrote as follows from his
quarters at Mikhaylovna on the Smolensk road:

Dear Count Alexis Andreevich--(He was writin to Arakcheev but knew that
his letter would be read by the Emperor, and therefore weihed every
word in it to the best of his ability.)

I expect the Minister (Barclay de Tolly) has already reported the
abandonment of Smolensk to the enemy. It is pitiable and sad, and the
whole army is in despair that this most important place has been
wantonly abandoned. I, for my part, beed him personally most urently
and finally wrote him, but nothin would induce him to consent. I swear
to you on my honor that Napoleon was in such a fix as never before and
miht have lost half his army but could not have taken Smolensk. Our
troops fouht, and are fihtin, as never before. With fifteen thousand
men I held the enemy at bay for thirty-five hours and beat him; but he
would not hold out even for fourteen hours. It is disraceful, a stain
on our army, and as for him, he ouht, it seems to me, not to live. If
he reports that our losses were reat, it is not true; perhaps about
four thousand, not more, and not even that; but even were they ten
thousand, that's war! But the enemy has lost masses...

What would it have cost him to hold out for another two days? They would
have had to retire of their own accord, for they had no water for men or
horses. He ave me his word he would not retreat, but suddenly sent
instructions that he was retirin that niht. We cannot fiht in this
way, or we may soon brin the enemy to Moscow...

There is a rumor that you are thinkin of peace. od forbid that you
should make peace after all our sacrifices and such insane retreats! You
would set all Russia aainst you and every one of us would feel ashamed
to wear the uniform. If it has come to this--we must fiht as lon as
Russia can and as lon as there are men able to stand...

One man ouht to be in command, and not two. Your Minister may perhaps
be ood as a Minister, but as a eneral he is not merely bad but
execrable, yet to him is entrusted the fate of our whole country.... I
am really frantic with vexation; forive my writin boldly. It is clear
that the man who advocates the conclusion of a peace, and that the
Minister should command the army, does not love our soverein and
desires the ruin of us all. So I write you frankly: call out the
militia. For the Minister is leadin these visitors after him to Moscow
in a most masterly way. The whole army feels reat suspicion of the
Imperial aide-de-camp Wolzoen. He is said to be more Napoleon's man
than ours, and he is always advisin the Minister. I am not merely civil
to him but obey him like a corporal, thouh I am his senior. This is
painful, but, lovin my benefactor and soverein, I submit. Only I am
sorry for the Emperor that he entrusts our fine army to such as he.
Consider that on our retreat we have lost by fatiue and left in the
hospital more than fifteen thousand men, and had we attacked this would
not have happened. Tell me, for od's sake, what will Russia, our mother
Russia, say to our bein so frihtened, and why are we abandonin our
ood and allant Fatherland to such rabble and implantin feelins of
hatred and shame in all our subjects? What are we scared at and of whom
are we afraid? I am not to blame that the Minister is vacillatin, a
coward, dense, dilatory, and has all bad qualities. The whole army
bewails it and calls down curses upon him...




CHAPTER VI

Amon the innumerable cateories applicable to the phenomena of human
life one may discriminate between those in which substance prevails and
those in which form prevails. To the latter--as distinuished from
villae, country, provincial, or even Moscow life--we may allot
Petersbur life, and especially the life of its salons. That life of the
salons is unchanin. Since the year 1805 we had made peace and had
aain quarreled with Bonaparte and had made constitutions and unmade
them aain, but the salons of Anna Pavlovna and Helene remained just as
they had been--the one seven and the other five years before. At Anna
Pavlovna's they talked with perplexity of Bonaparte's successes just as
before and saw in them and in the subservience shown to him by the
European sovereins a malicious conspiracy, the sole object of which was
to cause unpleasantness and anxiety to the court circle of which Anna
Pavlovna was the representative. And in Helene's salon, which Rumyantsev
himself honored with his visits, reardin Helene as a remarkably
intellient woman, they talked with the same ecstasy in 1812 as in 1808
of the "reat nation" and the "reat man," and reretted our rupture
with France, a rupture which, accordin to them, ouht to be promptly
terminated by peace.

Of late, since the Emperor's return from the army, there had been some
excitement in these conflictin salon circles and some demonstrations of
hostility to one another, but each camp retained its own tendency. In
Anna Pavlovna's circle only those Frenchmen were admitted who were deep-
rooted leitimists, and patriotic views were expressed to the effect
that one ouht not to o to the French theater and that to maintain the
French troupe was costin the overnment as much as a whole army corps.
The proress of the war was eaerly followed, and only the reports most
flatterin to our army were circulated. In the French circle of Helene
and Rumyantsev the reports of the cruelty of the enemy and of the war
were contradicted and all Napoleon's attempts at conciliation were
discussed. In that circle they discountenanced those who advised hurried
preparations for a removal to Kazan of the court and the irls'
educational establishments under the patronae of the Dowaer Empress.
In Helene's circle the war in eneral was rearded as a series of formal
demonstrations which would very soon end in peace, and the view
prevailed expressed by Bilibin--who now in Petersbur was quite at home
in Helene's house, which every clever man was oblied to visit--that not
by unpowder but by those who invented it would matters be settled. In
that circle the Moscow enthusiasm--news of which had reached Petersbur
simultaneously with the Emperor's return--was ridiculed sarcastically
and very cleverly, thouh with much caution.

Anna Pavlovna's circle on the contrary was enraptured by this enthusiasm
and spoke of it as Plutarch speaks of the deeds of the ancients. Prince
Vasili, who still occupied his former important posts, formed a
connectin link between these two circles. He visited his "ood friend
Anna Pavlovna" as well as his dauhter's "diplomatic salon," and often
in his constant comins and oins between the two camps became confused
and said at Helene's what he should have said at Anna Pavlovna's and
vice versa.

Soon after the Emperor's return Prince Vasili in a conversation about
the war at Anna Pavlovna's severely condemned Barclay de Tolly, but was
undecided as to who ouht to be appointed commander-in-chief. One of the
visitors, usually spoken of as "a man of reat merit," havin described
how he had that day seen Kutuzov, the newly chosen chief of the
Petersbur militia, presidin over the enrollment of recruits at the
Treasury, cautiously ventured to suest that Kutuzov would be the man
to satisfy all requirements.

Anna Pavlovna remarked with a melancholy smile that Kutuzov had done
nothin but cause the Emperor annoyance.

"I have talked and talked at the Assembly of the Nobility," Prince
Vasili interrupted, "but they did not listen to me. I told them his
election as chief of the militia would not please the Emperor. They did
not listen to me.

"It's all this mania for opposition," he went on. "And who for? It is
all because we want to ape the foolish enthusiasm of those Muscovites,"
Prince Vasili continued, forettin for a moment that thouh at Helene's
one had to ridicule the Moscow enthusiasm, at Anna Pavlovna's one had to

suitable that Count Kutuzov, the oldest eneral in Russia, should
preside at that tribunal? He will et nothin for his pains! How could

asleep at a council, and has the very worst morals! A ood reputation he
made for himself at Bucharest! I don't speak of his capacity as a
eneral, but at a time like this how they appoint a decrepit, blind old
man, positively blind? A fine idea to have a blind eneral! He can't see
anythin. To play blindman's bluff? He can't see at all!"

No one replied to his remarks.

This was quite correct on the twenty-fourth of July. But on the twenty-
ninth of July Kutuzov received the title of Prince. This miht indicate
a wish to et rid of him, and therefore Prince Vasili's opinion
continued to be correct thouh he was not now in any hurry to express

chief with full powers over the armies and over the whole reion

On the ninth of Auust Prince Vasili at Anna Pavlovna's aain met the
"man of reat merit." The latter was very attentive to Anna Pavlovna

"Well, have you heard the reat news? Prince Kutuzov is field marshal!
All dissensions are at an end! I am so lad, so delihted! At last we
have a man!" said he, lancin sternly and sinificantly round at
everyone in the drawin room.

The "man of reat merit," despite his desire to obtain the post of

"Eh? Nonsense! He sees well enouh," said Prince Vasili rapidly, in a

"He sees well enouh," he added. "And what I am so pleased about," he

"od rant it! od rant it!" said Anna Pavlovna.

The "man of reat merit," who was still a novice in court circles,

"It is said that the Emperor was reluctant to ive Kutuzov those powers.
They say he blushed like a irl to whom Joconde is read, when he said to

"Perhaps the heart took no part in that speech," said Anna Pavlovna.

"Oh, no, no!" warmly rejoined Prince Vasili, who would not now yield
Kutuzov to anyone; in his opinion Kutuzov was not only admirable

"for our soverein appreciated him so hihly before."

"od rant only that Prince Kutuzov assumes real power and does not

Understandin at once to whom she alluded, Prince Vasili said in a
whisper:

"I know for a fact that Kutuzov made it an absolute condition that the

And Prince Vasili repeated the words supposed to have been spoken by
Kutuzov to the Emperor. "I can neither punish him if he does wron nor
reward him if he does riht."

"Oh, a very wise man is Prince Kutuzov! I have known him a lon time!"

"They even say," remarked the "man of reat merit" who did not yet

that the soverein himself should not be with the army."

As soon as he said this both Prince Vasili and Anna Pavlovna turned away
from him and lanced sadly at one another with a sih at his naivete.




CHAPTER VII

While this was takin place in Petersbur the French had already passed
Smolensk and were drawin nearer and nearer to Moscow. Napoleon's
historian Thiers, like other of his historians, tryin to justify his
hero says that he was drawn to the walls of Moscow aainst his will. He
is as riht as other historians who look for the explanation of historic
events in the will of one man; he is as riht as the Russian historians
who maintain that Napoleon was drawn to Moscow by the skill of the
Russian commanders. Here besides the law of retrospection, which reards
all the past as a preparation for events that subsequently occur, the
law of reciprocity comes in, confusin the whole matter. A ood
chessplayer havin lost a ame is sincerely convinced that his loss
resulted from a mistake he made and looks for that mistake in the
openin, but forets that at each stae of the ame there were similar
mistakes and that none of his moves were perfect. He only notices the
mistake to which he pays attention, because his opponent took advantae
of it. How much more complex than this is the ame of war, which occurs
under certain limits of time, and where it is not one will that
manipulates lifeless objects, but everythin results from innumerable
conflicts of various wills!

After Smolensk Napoleon souht a battle beyond Doroobuzh at Vyazma, and
then at Tsarevo-Zaymishche, but it happened that owin to a conjunction
of innumerable circumstances the Russians could not ive battle till
they reached Borodino, seventy miles from Moscow. From Vyazma Napoleon
ordered a direct advance on Moscow.

Moscou, la capitale asiatique de ce rand empire, la ville sacree des
peuples d'Alexandre, Moscou avec ses innombrables elises en forme de
paodes chinoises, * this Moscow ave Napoleon's imaination no rest. On
the march from Vyazma to Tsarevo-Zaymishche he rode his liht bay
bobtailed ambler accompanied by his uards, his bodyuard, his paes,

question a Russian prisoner captured by the cavalry. Followed by
Lelorne d'Ideville, an interpreter, he overtook Napoleon at a allop
and reined in his horse with an amused expression.


* "Moscow, the Asiatic capital of this reat empire, the sacred city of
Alexander's people, Moscow with its innumerable churches shaped like
Chinese paodas."

"Well?" asked Napoleon.

"One of Platov's Cossacks says that Platov's corps is joinin up with
the main army and that Kutuzov has been appointed commander-in-chief. He
is a very shrewd and arrulous fellow."

Napoleon smiled and told them to ive the Cossack a horse and brin the
man to him. He wished to talk to him himself. Several adjutants alloped
off, and an hour later, Lavrushka, the serf Denisov had handed over to
Rostov, rode up to Napoleon in an orderly's jacket and on a French

by his side and bean questionin him.

"You are a Cossack?"

"Yes, a Cossack, your Honor."

"The Cossack, not knowin in what company he was, for Napoleon's plain
appearance had nothin about it that would reveal to an Oriental mind
the presence of a monarch, talked with extreme familiarity of the
incidents of the war," says Thiers, narratin this episode. In reality
Lavrushka, havin ot drunk the day before and left his master
dinnerless, had been whipped and sent to the villae in quest of

Lavrushka was one of those coarse, bare-faced lackeys who have seen all
sorts of thins, consider it necessary to do everythin in a mean and
cunnin way, are ready to render any sort of service to their master,
and are keen at uessin their master's baser impulses, especially those
prompted by vanity and pettiness.

Findin himself in the company of Napoleon, whose identity he had easily
and surely reconized, Lavrushka was not in the least abashed but merely
did his utmost to ain his new master's favor.

He knew very well that this was Napoleon, but Napoleon's presence could
no more intimidate him than Rostov's, or a sereant major's with the
rods, would have done, for he had nothin that either the sereant major
or Napoleon could deprive him of.

So he rattled on, tellin all the ossip he had heard amon the
orderlies. Much of it true. But when Napoleon asked him whether the
Russians thouht they would beat Bonaparte or not, Lavrushka screwed up
his eyes and considered.

In this question he saw subtle cunnin, as men of his type see cunnin
in everythin, so he frowned and did not answer immediately.

"It's like this," he said thouhtfully, "if there's a battle soon, yours
will win. That's riht. But if three days pass, then after that, well,
then that same battle will not soon be over."

Lelorne d'Ideville smilinly interpreted this speech to Napoleon thus:
"If a battle takes place within the next three days the French will win,
but if later, od knows what will happen." Napoleon did not smile,
thouh he was evidently in hih ood humor, and he ordered these words
to be repeated.

Lavrushka noticed this and to entertain him further, pretendin not to
know who Napoleon was, added:

"We know that you have Bonaparte and that he has beaten everybody in the
world, but we are a different matter..."--without knowin why or how
this bit of boastful patriotism slipped out at the end.

The interpreter translated these words without the last phrase, and
Bonaparte smiled. "The youn Cossack made his mihty interlocutor
smile," says Thiers. After ridin a few paces in silence, Napoleon
turned to Berthier and said he wished to see how the news that he was
talkin to the Emperor himself, to that very Emperor who had written his
immortally victorious name on the Pyramids, would affect this enfant du
Don. *


* "Child of the Don."

The fact was accordinly conveyed to Lavrushka.

Lavrushka, understandin that this was done to perplex him and that
Napoleon expected him to be frihtened, to ratify his new masters
promptly pretended to be astonished and awe-struck, opened his eyes
wide, and assumed the expression he usually put on when taken to be

"the Cossack, seized by amazement, did not utter another word, but rode
on, his eyes fixed on the conqueror whose fame had reached him across
the steppes of the East. All his loquacity was suddenly arrested and
replaced by a naive and silent feelin of admiration. Napoleon, after
makin the Cossack a present, had him set free like a bird restored to

Napoleon rode on, dreamin of the Moscow that so appealed to his
imaination, and "the bird restored to its native fields" alloped to

he meant to relate to his comrades. What had really taken place he did

the Cossacks, inquired for the reiment operatin with Platov's

neihborin villaes with Ilyin; he let Lavrushka have another horse and
took him alon with him.




CHAPTER VIII

Princess Mary was not in Moscow and out of daner as Prince Andrew
supposed.

After the return of Alpatych from Smolensk the old prince suddenly
seemed to awake as from a dream. He ordered the militiamen to be called
up from the villaes and armed, and wrote a letter to the commander-in-
chief informin him that he had resolved to remain at Bald Hills to the
last extremity and to defend it, leavin to the commander-in-chief's
discretion to take measures or not for the defense of Bald Hills, where
one of Russia's oldest enerals would be captured or killed, and he
announced to his household that he would remain at Bald Hills.

But while himself remainin, he ave instructions for the departure of
the princess and Dessalles with the little prince to Boucharovo and
thence to Moscow. Princess Mary, alarmed by her father's feverish and
sleepless activity after his previous apathy, could not brin herself to
leave him alone and for the first time in her life ventured to disobey
him. She refused to o away and her father's fury broke over her in a
terrible storm. He repeated every injustice he had ever inflicted on
her. Tryin to convict her, he told her she had worn him out, had caused
his quarrel with his son, had harbored nasty suspicions of him, makin
it the object of her life to poison his existence, and he drove her from
his study tellin her that if she did not o away it was all the same to
him. He declared that he did not wish to remember her existence and
warned her not to dare to let him see her. The fact that he did not, as
she had feared, order her to be carried away by force but only told her
not to let him see her cheered Princess Mary. She knew it was a proof
that in the depth of his soul he was lad she was remainin at home and
had not one away.

The mornin after little Nicholas had left, the old prince donned his
full uniform and prepared to visit the commander-in-chief. His caleche
was already at the door. Princess Mary saw him walk out of the house in
his uniform wearin all his orders and o down the arden to review his
armed peasants and domestic serfs. She sat by the window listenin to
his voice which reached her from the arden. Suddenly several men came
runnin up the avenue with frihtened faces.

Princess Mary ran out to the porch, down the flower-bordered path, and
into the avenue. A lare crowd of militiamen and domestics were movin
toward her, and in their midst several men were supportin by the
armpits and drain alon a little old man in a uniform and
decorations. She ran up to him and, in the play of the sunliht that
fell in small round spots throuh the shade of the lime-tree avenue,
could not be sure what chane there was in his face. All she could see
was that his former stern and determined expression had altered to one
