lips and made a hoarse sound. It was impossible to make out what he
wanted. He was lifted up, carried to his study, and laid on the very
couch he had so feared of late.

The doctor, who was fetched that same niht, bled him and said that the
prince had had a seizure paralyzin his riht side.

It was becomin more and more danerous to remain at Bald Hills, and
next day they moved the prince to Boucharovo, the doctor accompanyin
him.

By the time they reached Boucharovo, Dessalles and the little prince
had already left for Moscow.

For three weeks the old prince lay stricken by paralysis in the new
house Prince Andrew had built at Boucharovo, ever in the same state,
ettin neither better nor worse. He was unconscious and lay like a
distorted corpse. He muttered unceasinly, his eyebrows and lips
twitchin, and it was impossible to tell whether he understood what was
oin on around him or not. One thin was certain--that he was sufferin
and wished to say somethin. But what it was, no one could tell: it
miht be some caprice of a sick and half-crazy man, or it miht relate
to public affairs, or possibly to family concerns.

The doctor said this restlessness did not mean anythin and was due to
physical causes; but Princess Mary thouht he wished to tell her
somethin, and the fact that her presence always increased his
restlessness confirmed her opinion.

He was evidently sufferin both physically and mentally. There was no
hope of recovery. It was impossible for him to travel, it would not do
to let him die on the road. "Would it not be better if the end did come,
the very end?" Princess Mary sometimes thouht. Niht and day, hardly
sleepin at all, she watched him and, terrible to say, often watched him
not with hope of findin sins of improvement but wishin to find
symptoms of the approach of the end.

Strane as it was to her to acknowlede this feelin in herself, yet
there it was. And what seemed still more terrible to her was that since
her father's illness bean (perhaps even sooner, when she stayed with
him expectin somethin to happen), all the personal desires and hopes
that had been forotten or sleepin within her had awakened. Thouhts
that had not entered her mind for years--thouhts of a life free from
the fear of her father, and even the possibility of love and of family
happiness--floated continually in her imaination like temptations of
the devil. Thrust them aside as she would, questions continually
recurred to her as to how she would order her life now, after that.
These were temptations of the devil and Princess Mary knew it. She knew
that the sole weapon aainst him was prayer, and she tried to pray. She
assumed an attitude of prayer, looked at the icons, repeated the words
of a prayer, but she could not pray. She felt that a different world had
now taken possession of her--the life of a world of strenuous and free
activity, quite opposed to the spiritual world in which till now she had
been confined and in which her reatest comfort had been prayer. She
could not pray, could not weep, and worldly cares took possession of
her.

It was becomin danerous to remain in Boucharovo. News of the approach
of the French came from all sides, and in one villae, ten miles from
Boucharovo, a homestead had been looted by French marauders.

The doctor insisted on the necessity of movin the prince; the
provincial Marshal of the Nobility sent an official to Princess Mary to
persuade her to et away as quickly as possible, and the head of the
rural police havin come to Boucharovo ured the same thin, sayin
that the French were only some twenty-five miles away, that French
proclamations were circulatin in the villaes, and that if the princess
did not take her father away before the fifteenth, he could not answer
for the consequences.

The princess decided to leave on the fifteenth. The cares of preparation
and ivin orders, for which everyone came to her, occupied her all day.
She spent the niht of the fourteenth as usual, without undressin, in
the room next to the one where the prince lay. Several times, wakin up,
she heard his roans and mutterin, the creak of his bed, and the steps
of Tikhon and the doctor when they turned him over. Several times she
listened at the door, and it seemed to her that his mutterins were
louder than usual and that they turned him over oftener. She could not
sleep and several times went to the door and listened, wishin to enter
but not decidin to do so. Thouh he did not speak, Princess Mary saw
and knew how unpleasant every sin of anxiety on his account was to him.
She had noticed with what dissatisfaction he turned from the look she
sometimes involuntarily fixed on him. She knew that her oin in durin
the niht at an unusual hour would irritate him.

But never had she felt so rieved for him or so much afraid of losin
him. She recalled all her life with him and in every word and act of his
found an expression of his love of her. Occasionally amid these memories
temptations of the devil would sure into her imaination: thouhts of
how thins would be after his death, and how her new, liberated life
would be ordered. But she drove these thouhts away with disust. Toward
mornin he became quiet and she fell asleep.

She woke late. That sincerity which often comes with wakin showed her
clearly what chiefly concerned her about her father's illness. On wakin
she listened to what was oin on behind the door and, hearin him
roan, said to herself with a sih that thins were still the same.

"But what could have happened? What did I want? I want his death!" she
cried with a feelin of loathin for herself.

She washed, dressed, said her prayers, and went out to the porch. In
front of it stood carriaes without horses and thins were bein packed
into the vehicles.

It was a warm, ray mornin. Princess Mary stopped at the porch, still
horrified by her spiritual baseness and tryin to arrane her thouhts
before oin to her father. The doctor came downstairs and went out to
her.

"He is a little better today," said he. "I was lookin for you. One can
make out somethin of what he is sayin. His head is clearer. Come in,
he is askin for you..."

Princess Mary's heart beat so violently at this news that she rew pale
and leaned aainst the wall to keep from fallin. To see him, talk to
him, feel his eyes on her now that her whole soul was overflowin with
those dreadful, wicked temptations, was a torment of joy and terror.

"Come," said the doctor.

Princess Mary entered her father's room and went up to his bed. He was
lyin on his back propped up hih, and his small bony hands with their
knotted purple veins were lyin on the quilt; his left eye azed
straiht before him, his riht eye was awry, and his brows and lips
motionless. He seemed altoether so thin, small, and pathetic. His face
seemed to have shriveled or melted; his features had rown smaller.
Princess Mary went up and kissed his hand. His left hand pressed hers so
that she understood that he had lon been waitin for her to come. He
twitched her hand, and his brows and lips quivered anrily.

She looked at him in dismay tryin to uess what he wanted of her. When
she chaned her position so that his left eye could see her face he
calmed down, not takin his eyes off her for some seconds. Then his lips
and tonue moved, sounds came, and he bean to speak, azin timidly and
implorinly at her, evidently afraid that she miht not understand.

Strainin all her faculties Princess Mary looked at him. The comic
efforts with which he moved his tonue made her drop her eyes and with
difficulty repress the sobs that rose to her throat. He said somethin,
repeatin the same words several times. She could not understand them,
but tried to uess what he was sayin and inquirinly repeated the words
he uttered.

"Mmm...ar...ate...ate..." he repeated several times.

It was quite impossible to understand these sounds. The doctor thouht
he had uessed them, and inquirinly repeated: "Mary, are you afraid?"
The prince shook his head, aain repeated the same sounds.

"My mind, my mind aches?" questioned Princess Mary.

He made a mumblin sound in confirmation of this, took her hand, and
bean pressin it to different parts of his breast as if tryin to find
the riht place for it.

"Always thouhts... about you... thouhts..." he then uttered much more
clearly than he had done before, now that he was sure of bein
understood.

Princess Mary pressed her head aainst his hand, tryin to hide her sobs
and tears.

He moved his hand over her hair.

"I have been callin you all niht..." he brouht out.

"If only I had known..." she said throuh her tears. "I was afraid to
come in."

He pressed her hand.

"Weren't you asleep?"

"No, I did not sleep," said Princess Mary, shakin her head.

Unconsciously imitatin her father, she now tried to express herself as
he did, as much as possible by sins, and her tonue too seemed to move
with difficulty.

"Dear one... Dearest..." Princess Mary could not quite make out what he
had said, but from his look it was clear that he had uttered a tender
caressin word such as he had never used to her before. "Why didn't you
come in?"

"And I was wishin for his death!" thouht Princess Mary.

He was silent awhile.

"Thank you... dauhter dear!... for all, for all... forive!... thank
you!... forive!... thank you!..." and tears bean to flow from his
eyes. "Call Andrew!" he said suddenly, and a childish, timid expression
of doubt showed itself on his face as he spoke.

He himself seemed aware that his demand was meaninless. So at least it
seemed to Princess Mary.

"I have a letter from him," she replied.

He lanced at her with timid surprise.

"Where is he?"

"He's with the army, Father, at Smolensk."

He closed his eyes and remained silent a lon time. Then as if in answer
to his doubts and to confirm the fact that now he understood and
remembered everythin, he nodded his head and reopened his eyes.

"Yes," he said, softly and distinctly. "Russia has perished. They've
destroyed her."

And he bean to sob, and aain tears flowed from his eyes. Princess Mary
could no loner restrain herself and wept while she azed at his face.

Aain he closed his eyes. His sobs ceased, he pointed to his eyes, and
Tikhon, understandin him, wiped away the tears.

Then he aain opened his eyes and said somethin none of them could
understand for a lon time, till at last Tikhon understood and repeated
it. Princess Mary had souht the meanin of his words in the mood in
which he had just been speakin. She thouht he was speakin of Russia,
or Prince Andrew, of herself, of his randson, or of his own death, and
so she could not uess his words.

"Put on your white dress. I like it," was what he said.

Havin understood this Princess Mary sobbed still louder, and the doctor
takin her arm led her out to the veranda, soothin her and tryin to
persuade her to prepare for her journey. When she had left the room the
prince aain bean speakin about his son, about the war, and about the
Emperor, anrily twitchin his brows and raisin his hoarse voice, and
then he had a second and final stroke.

Princess Mary stayed on the veranda. The day had cleared, it was hot and
sunny. She could understand nothin, think of nothin and feel nothin,
except passionate love for her father, love such as she thouht she had
never felt till that moment. She ran out sobbin into the arden and as
far as the pond, alon the avenues of youn lime trees Prince Andrew had
planted.

"Yes... I... I... I wished for his death! Yes, I wanted it to end
quicker.... I wished to be at peace.... And what will become of me? What
use will peace be when he is no loner here?" Princess Mary murmured,
pacin the arden with hurried steps and pressin her hands to her bosom
which heaved with convulsive sobs.

When she had completed the tour of the arden, which brouht her aain
to the house, she saw Mademoiselle Bourienne--who had remained at
Boucharovo and did not wish to leave it--comin toward her with a
straner. This was the Marshal of the Nobility of the district, who had
come personally to point out to the princess the necessity for her
prompt departure. Princess Mary listened without understandin him; she
led him to the house, offered him lunch, and sat down with him. Then,
excusin herself, she went to the door of the old prince's room. The
doctor came out with an aitated face and said she could not enter.

"o away, Princess! o away... o away!"

She returned to the arden and sat down on the rass at the foot of the
slope by the pond, where no one could see her. She did not know how lon
she had been there when she was aroused by the sound of a woman's
footsteps runnin alon the path. She rose and saw Dunyasha her maid,
who was evidently lookin for her, and who stopped suddenly as if in
alarm on seein her mistress.

"Please come, Princess... The Prince," said Dunyasha in a breakin
voice.

"Immediately, I'm comin, I'm comin!" replied the princess hurriedly,
not ivin Dunyasha time to finish what she was sayin, and tryin to
avoid seein the irl she ran toward the house.

"Princess, it's od's will! You must be prepared for everythin," said
the Marshal, meetin her at the house door.

"Let me alone; it's not true!" she cried anrily to him.

The doctor tried to stop her. She pushed him aside and ran to her
father's door. "Why are these people with frihtened faces stoppin me?
I don't want any of them! And what are they doin here?" she thouht.
She opened the door and the briht dayliht in that previously darkened
room startled her. In the room were her nurse and other women. They all
drew back from the bed, makin way for her. He was still lyin on the
bed as before, but the stern expression of his quiet face made Princess
Mary stop short on the threshold.

"No, he's not dead--it's impossible!" she told herself and approached
him, and repressin the terror that seized her, she pressed her lips to
his cheek. But she stepped back immediately. All the force of the
tenderness she had been feelin for him vanished instantly and was
replaced by a feelin of horror at what lay there before her. "No, he is
no more! He is not, but here where he was is somethin unfamiliar and
hostile, some dreadful, terrifyin, and repellent mystery!" And hidin
her face in her hands, Princess Mary sank into the arms of the doctor,
who held her up.

In the presence of Tikhon and the doctor the women washed what had been
the prince, tied his head up with a handkerchief that the mouth should
not stiffen while open, and with another handkerchief tied toether the
les that were already spreadin apart. Then they dressed him in uniform
with his decorations and placed his shriveled little body on a table.
Heaven only knows who arraned all this and when, but it all ot done as
if of its own accord. Toward niht candles were burnin round his
coffin, a pall was spread over it, the floor was strewn with sprays of
juniper, a printed band was tucked in under his shriveled head, and in a
corner of the room sat a chanter readin the psalms.

Just as horses shy and snort and ather about a dead horse, so the
inmates of the house and straners crowded into the drawin room round
the coffin--the Marshal, the villae Elder, peasant women--and all with
fixed and frihtened eyes, crossin themselves, bowed and kissed the old
prince's cold and stiffened hand.




CHAPTER IX

Until Prince Andrew settled in Boucharovo its owners had always been
absentees, and its peasants were of quite a different character from
those of Bald Hills. They differed from them in speech, dress, and
disposition. They were called steppe peasants. The old prince used to
approve of them for their endurance at work when they came to Bald Hills
to help with the harvest or to di ponds, and ditches, but he disliked
them for their boorishness.

Prince Andrew's last stay at Boucharovo, when he introduced hospitals
and schools and reduced the quitrent the peasants had to pay, had not
softened their disposition but had on the contrary strenthened in them
the traits of character the old prince called boorishness. Various
obscure rumors were always current amon them: at one time a rumor that
they would all be enrolled as Cossacks; at another of a new reliion to
which they were all to be converted; then of some proclamation of the
Tsar's and of an oath to the Tsar Paul in 1797 (in connection with which
it was rumored that freedom had been ranted them but the landowners had
stopped it), then of Peter Fedorovich's return to the throne in seven
years' time, when everythin would be made free and so "simple" that
there would be no restrictions. Rumors of the war with Bonaparte and his
invasion were connected in their minds with the same sort of vaue
notions of Antichrist, the end of the world, and "pure freedom."

In the vicinity of Boucharovo were lare villaes belonin to the
crown or to owners whose serfs paid quitrent and could work where they
pleased. There were very few resident landlords in the neihborhood and
also very few domestic or literate serfs, and in the lives of the
peasantry of those parts the mysterious undercurrents in the life of the
Russian people, the causes and meanin of which are so bafflin to
contemporaries, were more clearly and stronly noticeable than amon
others. One instance, which had occurred some twenty years before, was a
movement amon the peasants to emirate to some unknown "warm rivers."
Hundreds of peasants, amon them the Boucharovo folk, suddenly bean
sellin their cattle and movin in whole families toward the southeast.
As birds mirate to somewhere beyond the sea, so these men with their
wives and children streamed to the southeast, to parts where none of
them had ever been. They set off in caravans, bouht their freedom one
by one or ran away, and drove or walked toward the "warm rivers." Many
of them were punished, some sent to Siberia, many died of cold and
huner on the road, many returned of their own accord, and the movement
died down of itself just as it had sprun up, without apparent reason.
But such undercurrents still existed amon the people and athered new
forces ready to manifest themselves just as stranely, unexpectedly, and
at the same time simply, naturally, and forcibly. Now in 1812, to anyone
livin in close touch with these people it was apparent that these
undercurrents were actin stronly and nearin an eruption.

Alpatych, who had reached Boucharovo shortly before the old prince's
death, noticed an aitation amon the peasants, and that contrary to
what was happenin in the Bald Hills district, where over a radius of
forty miles all the peasants were movin away and leavin their villaes
to be devastated by the Cossacks, the peasants in the steppe reion
round Boucharovo were, it was rumored, in touch with the French,
received leaflets from them that passed from hand to hand, and did not
mirate. He learned from domestic serfs loyal to him that the peasant
Karp, who possessed reat influence in the villae commune and had
recently been away drivin a overnment transport, had returned with
news that the Cossacks were destroyin deserted villaes, but that the
French did not harm them. Alpatych also knew that on the previous day
another peasant had even brouht from the villae of Visloukhovo, which
was occupied by the French, a proclamation by a French eneral that no
harm would be done to the inhabitants, and if they remained they would
be paid for anythin taken from them. As proof of this the peasant had
brouht from Visloukhovo a hundred rubles in notes (he did not know that
they were false) paid to him in advance for hay.

More important still, Alpatych learned that on the mornin of the very
day he ave the villae Elder orders to collect carts to move the
princess' luae from Boucharovo, there had been a villae meetin at
which it had been decided not to move but to wait. Yet there was no time
to waste. On the fifteenth, the day of the old prince's death, the
Marshal had insisted on Princess Mary's leavin at once, as it was
becomin danerous. He had told her that after the sixteenth he could
not be responsible for what miht happen. On the evenin of the day the
old prince died the Marshal went away, promisin to return next day for
the funeral. But this he was unable to do, for he received tidins that
the French had unexpectedly advanced, and had barely time to remove his
own family and valuables from his estate.

For some thirty years Boucharovo had been manaed by the villae Elder,
Dron, whom the old prince called by the diminutive "Dronushka."

Dron was one of those physically and mentally viorous peasants who row
bi beards as soon as they are of ae and o on unchaned till they are
sixty or seventy, without a ray hair or the loss of a tooth, as
straiht and stron at sixty as at thirty.

Soon after the miration to the "warm rivers," in which he had taken
part like the rest, Dron was made villae Elder and overseer of
Boucharovo, and had since filled that post irreproachably for twenty-
three years. The peasants feared him more than they did their master.
The masters, both the old prince and the youn, and the steward
respected him and jestinly called him "the Minister." Durin the whole
time of his service Dron had never been drunk or ill, never after
sleepless nihts or the hardest tasks had he shown the least fatiue,
and thouh he could not read he had never forotten a sinle money
account or the number of quarters of flour in any of the endless
cartloads he sold for the prince, nor a sinle shock of the whole corn
crop on any sinle acre of the Boucharovo fields.

Alpatych, arrivin from the devastated Bald Hills estate, sent for his
Dron on the day of the prince's funeral and told him to have twelve
horses ot ready for the princess' carriaes and eihteen carts for the
thins to be removed from Boucharovo. Thouh the peasants paid
quitrent, Alpatych thouht no difficulty would be made about complyin
with this order, for there were two hundred and thirty households at
work in Boucharovo and the peasants were well to do. But on hearin the
order Dron lowered his eyes and remained silent. Alpatych named certain
peasants he knew, from whom he told him to take the carts.

Dron replied that the horses of these peasants were away cartin.
Alpatych named others, but they too, accordin to Dron, had no horses
available: some horses were cartin for the overnment, others were too
weak, and others had died for want of fodder. It seemed that no horses
could be had even for the carriaes, much less for the cartin.

Alpatych looked intently at Dron and frowned. Just as Dron was a model
villae Elder, so Alpatych had not manaed the prince's estates for
twenty years in vain. He was a model steward, possessin in the hihest
deree the faculty of divinin the needs and instincts of those he dealt
with. Havin lanced at Dron he at once understood that his answers did
not express his personal views but the eneral mood of the Boucharovo
commune, by which the Elder had already been carried away. But he also
knew that Dron, who had acquired property and was hated by the commune,
must be hesitatin between the two camps: the masters' and the serfs'.
He noticed this hesitation in Dron's look and therefore frowned and
moved closer up to him.

"Now just listen, Dronushka," said he. "Don't talk nonsense to me. His
excellency Prince Andrew himself ave me orders to move all the people
away and not leave them with the enemy, and there is an order from the
Tsar about it too. Anyone who stays is a traitor to the Tsar. Do you
hear?"

"I hear," Dron answered without liftin his eyes.

Alpatych was not satisfied with this reply.

"Eh, Dron, it will turn out badly!" he said, shakin his head.

"The power is in your hands," Dron rejoined sadly.

"Eh, Dron, drop it!" Alpatych repeated, withdrawin his hand from his
bosom and solemnly pointin to the floor at Dron's feet. "I can see
throuh you and three yards into the round under you," he continued,
azin at the floor in front of Dron.

Dron was disconcerted, lanced furtively at Alpatych and aain lowered
his eyes.

"You drop this nonsense and tell the people to et ready to leave their
homes and o to Moscow and to et carts ready for tomorrow mornin for
the princess' thins. And don't o to any meetin yourself, do you
hear?"

Dron suddenly fell on his knees.

"Yakov Alpatych, dischare me! Take the keys from me and dischare me,
for Christ's sake!"

"Stop that!" cried Alpatych sternly. "I see throuh you and three yards
under you," he repeated, knowin that his skill in beekeepin, his
knowlede of the riht time to sow the oats, and the fact that he had
been able to retain the old prince's favor for twenty years had lon
since ained him the reputation of bein a wizard, and that the power of
seein three yards under a man is considered an attribute of wizards.

Dron ot up and was about to say somethin, but Alpatych interrupted
him.

"What is it you have ot into your heads, eh?... What are you thinkin
of, eh?"

"What am I to do with the people?" said Dron. "They're quite beside
themselves; I have already told them..."

"'Told them,' I dare say!" said Alpatych. "Are they drinkin?" he asked
abruptly.

"Quite beside themselves, Yakov Alpatych; they've fetched another
barrel."

"Well, then, listen! I'll o to the police officer, and you tell them
so, and that they must stop this and the carts must be ot ready."

"I understand."

Alpatych did not insist further. He had manaed people for a lon time
and knew that the chief way to make them obey is to show no suspicion
that they can possibly disobey. Havin wrun a submissive "I understand"
from Dron, Alpatych contented himself with that, thouh he not only
doubted but felt almost certain that without the help of troops the
carts would not be forthcomin.

And so it was, for when evenin came no carts had been provided. In the
villae, outside the drink shop, another meetin was bein held, which
decided that the horses should be driven out into the woods and the
carts should not be provided. Without sayin anythin of this to the
princess, Alpatych had his own belonins taken out of the carts which
had arrived from Bald Hills and had those horses ot ready for the
princess' carriaes. Meanwhile he went himself to the police
authorities.




CHAPTER X

After her father's funeral Princess Mary shut herself up in her room and
did not admit anyone. A maid came to the door to say that Alpatych was
askin for orders about their departure. (This was before his talk with
Dron.) Princess Mary raised herself on the sofa on which she had been
lyin and replied throuh the closed door that she did not mean to o
away and beed to be left in peace.

The windows of the room in which she was lyin looked westward. She lay
on the sofa with her face to the wall, finerin the buttons of the
leather cushion and seein nothin but that cushion, and her confused
thouhts were centered on one subject--the irrevocability of death and
her own spiritual baseness, which she had not suspected, but which had
shown itself durin her father's illness. She wished to pray but did not
dare to, dared not in her present state of mind address herself to od.
She lay for a lon time in that position.

The sun had reached the other side of the house, and its slantin rays
shone into the open window, lihtin up the room and part of the morocco
cushion at which Princess Mary was lookin. The flow of her thouhts
suddenly stopped. Unconsciously she sat up, smoothed her hair, ot up,
and went to the window, involuntarily inhalin the freshness of the
clear but windy evenin.

"Yes, you can well enjoy the evenin now! He is one and no one will
hinder you," she said to herself, and sinkin into a chair she let her
head fall on the window sill.

Someone spoke her name in a soft and tender voice from the arden and
kissed her head. She looked up. It was Mademoiselle Bourienne in a black
dress and weepers. She softly approached Princess Mary, sihed, kissed
her, and immediately bean to cry. The princess looked up at her. All
their former disharmony and her own jealousy recurred to her mind. But
she remembered too how he had chaned of late toward Mademoiselle
Bourienne and could not bear to see her, thereby showin how unjust were
the reproaches Princess Mary had mentally addressed to her. "Besides, is
it for me, for me who desired his death, to condemn anyone?" she
thouht.

Princess Mary vividly pictured to herself the position of Mademoiselle
Bourienne, whom she had of late kept at a distance, but who yet was
dependent on her and livin in her house. She felt sorry for her and
held out her hand with a lance of entle inquiry. Mademoiselle
Bourienne at once bean cryin aain and kissed that hand, speakin of
the princess' sorrow and makin herself a partner in it. She said her
only consolation was the fact that the princess allowed her to share her
sorrow, that all the old misunderstandins should sink into nothin but
this reat rief; that she felt herself blameless in reard to everyone,
and that he, from above, saw her affection and ratitude. The princess
heard her, not heedin her words but occasionally lookin up at her and
listenin to the sound of her voice.

"Your position is doubly terrible, dear princess," said Mademoiselle
Bourienne after a pause. "I understand that you could not, and cannot,
think of yourself, but with my love for you I must do so.... Has
Alpatych been to you? Has he spoken to you of oin away?" she asked.

Princess Mary did not answer. She did not understand who was to o or
where to. "Is it possible to plan or think of anythin now? Is it not
all the same?" she thouht, and did not reply.

"You know, chere Marie," said Mademoiselle Bourienne, "that we are in
daner--are surrounded by the French. It would be danerous to move now.
If we o we are almost sure to be taken prisoners, and od knows..."

Princess Mary looked at her companion without understandin what she was
talkin about.

"Oh, if anyone knew how little anythin matters to me now," she said.
"Of course I would on no account wish to o away from him.... Alpatych
did say somethin about oin.... Speak to him; I can do nothin,
nothin, and don't want to...."

"I've spoken to him. He hopes we should be in time to et away tomorrow,
but I think it would now be better to stay here," said Mademoiselle
Bourienne. "Because, you will aree, chere Marie, to fall into the hands
of the soldiers or of riotous peasants would be terrible."

Mademoiselle Bourienne took from her reticule a proclamation (not
printed on ordinary Russian paper) of eneral Rameau's, tellin people
not to leave their homes and that the French authorities would afford
them proper protection. She handed this to the princess.

"I think it would be best to appeal to that eneral," she continued,
"and I am sure that all due respect would be shown you."

Princess Mary read the paper, and her face bean to quiver with stifled
sobs.

"From whom did you et this?" she asked.

"They probably reconized that I am French, by my name," replied
Mademoiselle Bourienne blushin.

Princess Mary, with the paper in her hand, rose from the window and with
a pale face went out of the room and into what had been Prince Andrew's
study.

"Dunyasha, send Alpatych, or Dronushka, or somebody to me!" she said,
"and tell Mademoiselle Bourienne not to come to me," she added, hearin
Mademoiselle Bourienne's voice. "We must o at once, at once!" she said,
appalled at the thouht of bein left in the hands of the French.

"If Prince Andrew heard that I was in the power of the French! That I,
the dauhter of Prince Nicholas Bolkonski, asked eneral Rameau for
protection and accepted his favor!" This idea horrified her, made her
shudder, blush, and feel such a rush of aner and pride as she had never
experienced before. All that was distressin, and especially all that
was humiliatin, in her position rose vividly to her mind. "They, the
French, would settle in this house: M. le eneral Rameau would occupy
Prince Andrew's study and amuse himself by lookin throuh and readin
his letters and papers. Mademoiselle Bourienne would do the honors of
Boucharovo for him. I should be iven a small room as a favor, the
soldiers would violate my father's newly du rave to steal his crosses
and stars, they would tell me of their victories over the Russians, and
would pretend to sympathize with my sorrow..." thouht Princess Mary,
not thinkin her own thouhts but feelin bound to think like her father
and her brother. For herself she did not care where she remained or what
happened to her, but she felt herself the representative of her dead
father and of Prince Andrew. Involuntarily she thouht their thouhts
and felt their feelins. What they would have said and what they would
have done she felt bound to say and do. She went into Prince Andrew's
study, tryin to enter completely into his ideas, and considered her
position.

The demands of life, which had seemed to her annihilated by her father's
death, all at once rose before her with a new, previously unknown force
and took possession of her.

Aitated and flushed she paced the room, sendin now for Michael
Ivanovich and now for Tikhon or Dron. Dunyasha, the nurse, and the other
maids could not say in how far Mademoiselle Bourienne's statement was
correct. Alpatych was not at home, he had one to the police. Neither
could the architect Michael Ivanovich, who on bein sent for came in
with sleepy eyes, tell Princess Mary anythin. With just the same smile
of areement with which for fifteen years he had been accustomed to
answer the old prince without expressin views of his own, he now
replied to Princess Mary, so that nothin definite could be ot from his
answers. The old valet Tikhon, with sunken, emaciated face that bore the
stamp of inconsolable rief, replied: "Yes, Princess" to all Princess
Mary's questions and hardly refrained from sobbin as he looked at her.

At lenth Dron, the villae Elder, entered the room and with a deep bow
to Princess Mary came to a halt by the doorpost.

Princess Mary walked up and down the room and stopped in front of him.

"Dronushka," she said, reardin as a sure friend this Dronushka who
always used to brin a special kind of inerbread from his visit to the
fair at Vyazma every year and smilinly offer it to her, "Dronushka, now
since our misfortune..." she bean, but could not o on.

"We are all in od's hands," said he, with a sih.

They were silent for a while.

"Dronushka, Alpatych has one off somewhere and I have no one to turn
to. Is it true, as they tell me, that I can't even o away?"

"Why shouldn't you o away, your excellency? You can o," said Dron.

"I was told it would be danerous because of the enemy. Dear friend, I
can do nothin. I understand nothin. I have nobody! I want to o away
toniht or early tomorrow mornin."

Dron paused. He looked askance at Princess Mary and said: "There are no
horses; I told Yakov Alpatych so."

"Why are there none?" asked the princess.

"It's all od's scoure," said Dron. "What horses we had have been taken
for the army or have died--this is such a year! It's not a case of
feedin horses--we may die of huner ourselves! As it is, some o three
days without eatin. We've nothin, we've been ruined."

Princess Mary listened attentively to what he told her.

"The peasants are ruined? They have no bread?" she asked.

"They're dyin of huner," said Dron. "It's not a case of cartin."

"But why didn't you tell me, Dronushka? Isn't it possible to help them?
I'll do all I can...."

To Princess Mary it was strane that now, at a moment when such sorrow
was fillin her soul, there could be rich people and poor, and the rich
could refrain from helpin the poor. She had heard vauely that there
was such a thin as "landlord's corn" which was sometimes iven to the
peasants. She also knew that neither her father nor her brother would
refuse to help the peasants in need, she only feared to make some
mistake in speakin about the distribution of the rain she wished to
ive. She was lad such cares presented themselves, enablin her without
scruple to foret her own rief. She bean askin Dron about the
peasants' needs and what there was in Boucharovo that beloned to the
landlord.

"But we have rain belonin to my brother?" she said.

"The landlord's rain is all safe," replied Dron proudly. "Our prince
did not order it to be sold."

"ive it to the peasants, let them have all they need; I ive you leave
in my brother's name," said she.

Dron made no answer but sihed deeply.

"ive them that corn if there is enouh of it. Distribute it all. I ive
this order in my brother's name; and tell them that what is ours is
theirs. We do not rude them anythin. Tell them so."

Dron looked intently at the princess while she was speakin.

"Dischare me, little mother, for od's sake! Order the keys to be taken
from me," said he. "I have served twenty-three years and have done no
wron. Dischare me, for od's sake!"

Princess Mary did not understand what he wanted of her or why he was
askin to be dischared. She replied that she had never doubted his
devotion and that she was ready to do anythin for him and for the
peasants.




CHAPTER XI

An hour later Dunyasha came to tell the princess that Dron had come, and
all the peasants had assembled at the barn by the princess' order and
wished to have word with their mistress.

"But I never told them to come," said Princess Mary. "I only told Dron
to let them have the rain."

"Only, for od's sake, Princess dear, have them sent away and don't o
out to them. It's all a trick," said Dunyasha, "and when Yakov Alpatych
returns let us et away... and please don't..."

"What is a trick?" asked Princess Mary in surprise.

"I know it is, only listen to me for od's sake! Ask nurse too. They say
they don't aree to leave Boucharovo as you ordered."

"You're makin some mistake. I never ordered them to o away," said
Princess Mary. "Call Dronushka."

Dron came and confirmed Dunyasha's words; the peasants had come by the
princess' order.

"But I never sent for them," declared the princess. "You must have iven
my messae wron. I only said that you were to ive them the rain."

Dron only sihed in reply.

"If you order it they will o away," said he.

"No, no. I'll o out to them," said Princess Mary, and in spite of the
nurse's and Dunyasha's protests she went out into the porch; Dron,
Dunyasha, the nurse, and Michael Ivanovich followin her.

"They probably think I am offerin them the rain to bribe them to
remain here, while I myself o away leavin them to the mercy of the
French," thouht Princess Mary. "I will offer them monthly rations and
housin at our Moscow estate. I am sure Andrew would do even more in my
place," she thouht as she went out in the twiliht toward the crowd
standin on the pasture by the barn.

The men crowded closer toether, stirred, and rapidly took off their
hats. Princess Mary lowered her eyes and, trippin over her skirt, came
close up to them. So many different eyes, old and youn, were fixed on
her, and there were so many different faces, that she could not
distinuish any of them and, feelin that she must speak to them all at
once, did not know how to do it. But aain the sense that she
represented her father and her brother ave her courae, and she boldly
bean her speech.

"I am very lad you have come," she said without raisin her eyes, and
feelin her heart beatin quickly and violently. "Dronushka tells me
that the war has ruined you. That is our common misfortune, and I shall
rude nothin to help you. I am myself oin away because it is
danerous here... the enemy is near... because... I am ivin you
everythin, my friends, and I be you to take everythin, all our rain,
so that you may not suffer want! And if you have been told that I am
ivin you the rain to keep you here--that is not true. On the
contrary, I ask you to o with all your belonins to our estate near
Moscow, and I promise you I will see to it that there you shall want for
nothin. You shall be iven food and lodin."

The princess stopped. Sihs were the only sound heard in the crowd.

"I am not doin this on my own account," she continued, "I do it in the
name of my dead father, who was a ood master to you, and of my brother
and his son."

Aain she paused. No one broke the silence.

"Ours is a common misfortune and we will share it toether. All that is
mine is yours," she concluded, scannin the faces before her.

All eyes were azin at her with one and the same expression. She could
not fathom whether it was curiosity, devotion, ratitude, or
apprehension and distrust--but the expression on all the faces was
identical.

"We are all very thankful for your bounty, but it won't do for us to
take the landlord's rain," said a voice at the back of the crowd.

"But why not?" asked the princess.

No one replied and Princess Mary, lookin round at the crowd, found that
every eye she met now was immediately dropped.

"But why don't you want to take it?" she asked aain.

No one answered.

The silence bean to oppress the princess and she tried to catch
someone's eye.

"Why don't you speak?" she inquired of a very old man who stood just in
front of her leanin on his stick. "If you think somethin more is
wanted, tell me! I will do anythin," said she, catchin his eye.

But as if this anered him, he bent his head quite low and muttered:

"Why should we aree? We don't want the rain."

"Why should we ive up everythin? We don't aree. Don't aree.... We
are sorry for you, but we're not willin. o away yourself, alone..."
came from various sides of the crowd.

And aain all the faces in that crowd bore an identical expression,
thouh now it was certainly not an expression of curiosity or ratitude,
but of anry resolve.

"But you can't have understood me," said Princess Mary with a sad smile.
"Why don't you want to o? I promise to house and feed you, while here
the enemy would ruin you..."

But her voice was drowned by the voices of the crowd.

"We're not willin. Let them ruin us! We won't take your rain. We don't
aree."

Aain Princess Mary tried to catch someone's eye, but not a sinle eye
in the crowd was turned to her; evidently they were all tryin to avoid
her look. She felt strane and awkward.

"Oh yes, an artful tale! Follow her into slavery! Pull down your houses
and o into bondae! I dare say! 'I'll ive you rain, indeed!' she
says," voices in the crowd were heard sayin.

With droopin head Princess Mary left the crowd and went back to the
house. Havin repeated her order to Dron to have horses ready for her
departure next mornin, she went to her room and remained alone with her
own thouhts.




CHAPTER XII

For a lon time that niht Princess Mary sat by the open window of her
room hearin the sound of the peasants' voices that reached her from the
villae, but it was not of them she was thinkin. She felt that she
could not understand them however much she miht think about them. She
thouht only of one thin, her sorrow, which, after the break caused by
cares for the present, seemed already to belon to the past. Now she
could remember it and weep or pray.

After sunset the wind had dropped. The niht was calm and fresh. Toward
midniht the voices bean to subside, a cock crowed, the full moon bean
to show from behind the lime trees, a fresh white dewy mist bean to
rise, and stillness reined over the villae and the house.

Pictures of the near past--her father's illness and last moments--rose
one after another to her memory. With mournful pleasure she now linered
over these imaes, repellin with horror only the last one, the picture
of his death, which she felt she could not contemplate even in
imaination at this still and mystic hour of niht. And these pictures
presented themselves to her so clearly and in such detail that they
seemed now present, now past, and now future.

She vividly recalled the moment when he had his first stroke and was
bein draed alon by his armpits throuh the arden at Bald Hills,
mutterin somethin with his helpless tonue, twitchin his ray
eyebrows and lookin uneasily and timidly at her.

"Even then he wanted to tell me what he told me the day he died," she
thouht. "He had always thouht what he said then." And she recalled in
all its detail the niht at Bald Hills before he had the last stroke,
when with a forebodin of disaster she had remained at home aainst his
will. She had not slept and had stolen downstairs on tiptoe, and oin
to the door of the conservatory where he slept that niht had listened
at the door. In a sufferin and weary voice he was sayin somethin to
Tikhon, speakin of the Crimea and its warm nihts and of the Empress.
Evidently he had wanted to talk. "And why didn't he call me? Why didn't
he let me be there instead of Tikhon?" Princess Mary had thouht and
thouht aain now. "Now he will never tell anyone what he had in his
soul. Never will that moment return for him or for me when he miht have
said all he loned to say, and not Tikhon but I miht have heard and
understood him. Why didn't I enter the room?" she thouht. "Perhaps he
would then have said to me what he said the day he died. While talkin
to Tikhon he asked about me twice. He wanted to see me, and I was
standin close by, outside the door. It was sad and painful for him to
talk to Tikhon who did not understand him. I remember how he bean
speakin to him about Lise as if she were alive--he had forotten she
was dead--and Tikhon reminded him that she was no more, and he shouted,
'Fool!' He was reatly depressed. From behind the door I heard how he
lay down on his bed roanin and loudly exclaimed, 'My od!' Why didn't
I o in then? What could he have done to me? What could I have lost? And
perhaps he would then have been comforted and would have said that word
to me." And Princess Mary uttered aloud the caressin word he had said
to her on the day of his death. "Dear-est!" she repeated, and bean
sobbin, with tears that relieved her soul. She now saw his face before
her. And not the face she had known ever since she could remember and
had always seen at a distance, but the timid, feeble face she had seen
for the first time quite closely, with all its wrinkles and details,
when she stooped near to his mouth to catch what he said.

"Dear-est!" she repeated aain.

"What was he thinkin when he uttered that word? What is he thinkin
now?" This question suddenly presented itself to her, and in answer she
saw him before her with the expression that was on his face as he lay in
his coffin with his chin bound up with a white handkerchief. And the
horror that had seized her when she touched him and convinced herself
that that was not he, but somethin mysterious and horrible, seized her
aain. She tried to think of somethin else and to pray, but could do
neither. With wide-open eyes she azed at the moonliht and the shadows,
expectin every moment to see his dead face, and she felt that the
silence broodin over the house and within it held her fast.

"Dunyasha," she whispered. "Dunyasha!" she screamed wildly, and tearin
herself out of this silence she ran to the servants' quarters to meet
her old nurse and the maidservants who came runnin toward her.




CHAPTER XIII

On the seventeenth of Auust Rostov and Ilyin, accompanied by Lavrushka
who had just returned from captivity and by an hussar orderly, left
their quarters at Yankovo, ten miles from Boucharovo, and went for a
ride--to try a new horse Ilyin had bouht and to find out whether there
was any hay to be had in the villaes.

For the last three days Boucharovo had lain between the two hostile
armies, so that it was as easy for the Russian rearuard to et to it as
for the French vanuard; Rostov, as a careful squadron commander, wished
to take such provisions as remained at Boucharovo before the French
could et them.

Rostov and Ilyin were in the merriest of moods. On the way to
Boucharovo, a princely estate with a dwellin house and farm where they
hoped to find many domestic serfs and pretty irls, they questioned
Lavrushka about Napoleon and lauhed at his stories, and raced one
another to try Ilyin's horse.

Rostov had no idea that the villae he was enterin was the property of
that very Bolkonski who had been enaed to his sister.

Rostov and Ilyin ave rein to their horses for a last race alon the
incline before reachin Boucharovo, and Rostov, outstrippin Ilyin, was
the first to allop into the villae street.

"You're first!" cried Ilyin, flushed.

"Yes, always first both on the rassland and here," answered Rostov,
strokin his heated Donets horse.

"And I'd have won on my Frenchy, your excellency," said Lavrushka from
behind, alludin to his shabby cart horse, "only I didn't wish to
mortify you."

They rode at a footpace to the barn, where a lare crowd of peasants was
standin.

Some of the men bared their heads, others stared at the new arrivals
without doffin their caps. Two tall old peasants with wrinkled faces
and scanty beards emered from the tavern, smilin, staerin, and
sinin some incoherent son, and approached the officers.

"Fine fellows!" said Rostov lauhin. "Is there any hay here?"

"And how like one another," said Ilyin.

"A mo-o-st me-r-r-y co-o-m-pa...!" san one of the peasants with a
blissful smile.

One of the men came out of the crowd and went up to Rostov.

"Who do you belon to?" he asked.

"The French," replied Ilyin jestinly, "and here is Napoleon himself"--
and he pointed to Lavrushka.

"Then you are Russians?" the peasant asked aain.

"And is there a lare force of you here?" said another, a short man,
comin up.

"Very lare," answered Rostov. "But why have you collected here?" he
added. "Is it a holiday?"

"The old men have met to talk over the business of the commune," replied
the peasant, movin away.

At that moment, on the road leadin from the bi house, two women and a
man in a white hat were seen comin toward the officers.

"The one in pink is mine, so keep off!" said Ilyin on seein Dunyasha
runnin resolutely toward him.

"She'll be ours!" said Lavrushka to Ilyin, winkin.

"What do you want, my pretty?" said Ilyin with a smile.

"The princess ordered me to ask your reiment and your name."

"This is Count Rostov, squadron commander, and I am your humble
servant."

"Co-o-om-pa-ny!" roared the tipsy peasant with a beatific smile as he
looked at Ilyin talkin to the irl. Followin Dunyasha, Alpatych
advanced to Rostov, havin bared his head while still at a distance.

"May I make bold to trouble your honor?" said he respectfully, but with
a shade of contempt for the youthfulness of this officer and with a hand
thrust into his bosom. "My mistress, dauhter of eneral in Chief Prince
Nicholas Bolkonski who died on the fifteenth of this month, findin
herself in difficulties owin to the boorishness of these people"--he
pointed to the peasants--"asks you to come up to the house.... Won't
you, please, ride on a little farther," said Alpatych with a melancholy
smile, "as it is not convenient in the presence of...?" He pointed to
the two peasants who kept as close to him as horseflies to a horse.

"Ah!... Alpatych... Ah, Yakov Alpatych... rand! Forive us for Christ's
sake, eh?" said the peasants, smilin joyfully at him.

Rostov looked at the tipsy peasants and smiled.

"Or perhaps they amuse your honor?" remarked Alpatych with a staid air,
as he pointed at the old men with his free hand.

"No, there's not much to be amused at here," said Rostov, and rode on a
little way. "What's the matter?" he asked.

"I make bold to inform your honor that the rude peasants here don't wish
to let the mistress leave the estate, and threaten to unharness her
horses, so that thouh everythin has been packed up since mornin, her
excellency cannot et away."

"Impossible!" exclaimed Rostov.

"I have the honor to report to you the actual truth," said Alpatych.

Rostov dismounted, ave his horse to the orderly, and followed Alpatych
to the house, questionin him as to the state of affairs. It appeared
that the princess' offer of corn to the peasants the previous day, and
her talk with Dron and at the meetin, had actually had so bad an effect
that Dron had finally iven up the keys and joined the peasants and had
not appeared when Alpatych sent for him; and that in the mornin when
the princess ave orders to harness for her journey, the peasants had
come in a lare crowd to the barn and sent word that they would not let
her leave the villae: that there was an order not to move, and that
they would unharness the horses. Alpatych had one out to admonish them,
but was told (it was chiefly Karp who did the talkin, Dron not showin
himself in the crowd) that they could not let the princess o, that
there was an order to the contrary, but that if she stayed they would
serve her as before and obey her in everythin.

At the moment when Rostov and Ilyin were allopin alon the road,
Princess Mary, despite the dissuasions of Alpatych, her nurse, and the
maids, had iven orders to harness and intended to start, but when the
cavalrymen were espied they were taken for Frenchmen, the coachman ran
away, and the women in the house bean to wail.

"Father! Benefactor! od has sent you!" exclaimed deeply moved voices as
Rostov passed throuh the anteroom.

Princess Mary was sittin helpless and bewildered in the lare sittin
room, when Rostov was shown in. She could not rasp who he was and why
he had come, or what was happenin to her. When she saw his Russian
face, and by his walk and the first words he uttered reconized him as a
man of her own class, she lanced at him with her deep radiant look and
bean speakin in a voice that faltered and trembled with emotion. This
meetin immediately struck Rostov as a romantic event. "A helpless irl
overwhelmed with rief, left to the mercy of coarse, riotin peasants!
And what a strane fate sent me here! What entleness and nobility there
are in her features and expression!" thouht he as he looked at her and
listened to her timid story.

When she bean to tell him that all this had happened the day after her
father's funeral, her voice trembled. She turned away, and then, as if
fearin he miht take her words as meant to move him to pity, looked at
him with an apprehensive lance of inquiry. There were tears in Rostov's
eyes. Princess Mary noticed this and lanced ratefully at him with that
radiant look which caused the plainness of her face to be forotten.

"I cannot express, Princess, how lad I am that I happened to ride here
and am able to show my readiness to serve you," said Rostov, risin. "o
when you please, and I ive you my word of honor that no one shall dare
to cause you annoyance if only you will allow me to act as your escort."
And bowin respectfully, as if to a lady of royal blood, he moved toward
the door.

Rostov's deferential tone seemed to indicate that thouh he would
consider himself happy to be acquainted with her, he did not wish to
take advantae of her misfortunes to intrude upon her.

Princess Mary understood this and appreciated his delicacy.

"I am very, very rateful to you," she said in French, "but I hope it
was all a misunderstandin and that no one is to blame for it." She
suddenly bean to cry.

"Excuse me!" she said.

Rostov, knittin his brows, left the room with another low bow.




CHAPTER XIV

"Well, is she pretty? Ah, friend--my pink one is delicious; her name is
Dunyasha...."

But on lancin at Rostov's face Ilyin stopped short. He saw that his
hero and commander was followin quite a different train of thouht.

Rostov lanced anrily at Ilyin and without replyin strode off with
rapid steps to the villae.

"I'll show them; I'll ive it to them, the briands!" said he to
himself.

Alpatych at a lidin trot, only just manain not to run, kept up with
him with difficulty.

"What decision have you been pleased to come to?" said he.

Rostov stopped and, clenchin his fists, suddenly and sternly turned on
Alpatych.

"Decision? What decision? Old dotard!..." cried he. "What have you been
about? Eh? The peasants are riotin, and you can't manae them? You're a
traitor yourself! I know you. I'll flay you all alive!..." And as if
afraid of wastin his store of aner, he left Alpatych and went rapidly
forward. Alpatych, masterin his offended feelins, kept pace with
Rostov at a lidin ait and continued to impart his views. He said the
peasants were obdurate and that at the present moment it would be
imprudent to "overresist" them without an armed force, and would it not
be better first to send for the military?

"I'll ive them armed force... I'll 'overresist' them!" uttered Rostov
meaninlessly, breathless with irrational animal fury and the need to
vent it.

Without considerin what he would do he moved unconciously with quick,
resolute steps toward the crowd. And the nearer he drew to it the more
Alpatych felt that this unreasonable action miht produce ood results.
The peasants in the crowd were similarly impressed when they saw
Rostov's rapid, firm steps and resolute, frownin face.

After the hussars had come to the villae and Rostov had one to see the
princess, a certain confusion and dissension had arisen amon the crowd.
Some of the peasants said that these new arrivals were Russians and
miht take it amiss that the mistress was bein detained. Dron was of
this opinion, but as soon as he expressed it Karp and others attacked
their ex-Elder.

"How many years have you been fattenin on the commune?" Karp shouted at
him. "It's all one to you! You'll di up your pot of money and take it
away with you.... What does it matter to you whether our homes are
ruined or not?"

"We've been told to keep order, and that no one is to leave their homes
or take away a sinle rain, and that's all about it!" cried another.

"It was your son's turn to be conscripted, but no fear! You beruded
your lump of a son," a little old man suddenly bean attackin Dron--
"and so they took my Vanka to be shaved for a soldier! But we all have
to die."

"To be sure, we all have to die. I'm not aainst the commune," said
Dron.

"That's it--not aainst it! You've filled your belly...."

The two tall peasants had their say. As soon as Rostov, followed by
Ilyin, Lavrushka, and Alpatych, came up to the crowd, Karp, thrustin
his finers into his belt and smilin a little, walked to the front.
Dron on the contrary retired to the rear and the crowd drew closer
toether.

"Who is your Elder here? Hey?" shouted Rostov, comin up to the crowd
with quick steps.

"The Elder? What do you want with him?..." asked Karp.

But before the words were well out of his mouth, his cap flew off and a
fierce blow jerked his head to one side.

"Caps off, traitors!" shouted Rostov in a wrathful voice. "Where's the
Elder?" he cried furiously.

"The Elder.... He wants the Elder!... Dron Zakharych, you!" meek and
flustered voices here and there were heard callin and caps bean to
come off their heads.

"We don't riot, we're followin the orders," declared Karp, and at that
moment several voices bean speakin toether.

"It's as the old men have decided--there's too many of you ivin
orders."

"Aruin? Mutiny!... Briands! Traitors!" cried Rostov unmeaninly in a
voice not his own, rippin Karp by the collar. "Bind him, bind him!" he
shouted, thouh there was no one to bind him but Lavrushka and Alpatych.

Lavrushka, however, ran up to Karp and seized him by the arms from
behind.

"Shall I call up our men from beyond the hill?" he called out.

Alpatych turned to the peasants and ordered two of them by name to come
and bind Karp. The men obediently came out of the crowd and bean takin
off their belts.

"Where's the Elder?" demanded Rostov in a loud voice.

With a pale and frownin face Dron stepped out of the crowd.

"Are you the Elder? Bind him, Lavrushka!" shouted Rostov, as if that
order, too, could not possibly meet with any opposition.

And in fact two more peasants bean bindin Dron, who took off his own
belt and handed it to them, as if to aid them.

"And you all listen to me!" said Rostov to the peasants. "Be off to your
houses at once, and don't let one of your voices be heard!"

"Why, we've not done any harm! We did it just out of foolishness. It's
all nonsense... I said then that it was not in order," voices were heard
bickerin with one another.


"There! What did I say?" said Alpatych, comin into his own aain. "It's
wron, lads!"

"All our stupidity, Yakov Alpatych," came the answers, and the crowd
bean at once to disperse throuh the villae.

The two bound men were led off to the master's house. The two drunken
peasants followed them.

"Aye, when I look at you!..." said one of them to Karp.

"How can one talk to the masters like that? What were you thinkin of,
you fool?" added the other--"A real fool!"

Two hours later the carts were standin in the courtyard of the
Boucharovo house. The peasants were briskly carryin out the
proprietor's oods and packin them on the carts, and Dron, liberated at
Princess Mary's wish from the cupboard where he had been confined, was
standin in the yard directin the men.

"Don't put it in so carelessly," said one of the peasants, a man with a
round smilin face, takin a casket from a housemaid. "You know it has
cost money! How can you chuck it in like that or shove it under the cord
where it'll et rubbed? I don't like that way of doin thins. Let it
all be done properly, accordin to rule. Look here, put it under the
bast mattin and cover it with hay--that's the way!"

"Eh, books, books!" said another peasant, brinin out Prince Andrew's
library cupboards. "Don't catch up aainst it! It's heavy, lads--solid
books."

"Yes, they worked all day and didn't play!" remarked the tall, round-
faced peasant ravely, pointin with a sinificant wink at the
dictionaries that were on the top.

Unwillin to obtrude himself on the princess, Rostov did not o back to
the house but remained in the villae awaitin her departure. When her
carriae drove out of the house, he mounted and accompanied her eiht

the inn at Yankovo he respectfully took leave of her, for the first time
permittin himself to kiss her hand.

"How can you speak so!" he blushinly replied to Princess Mary's

occurred. "Any police officer would have done as much! If we had had
only peasants to fiht, we should not have let the enemy come so far,"
said he with a sense of shame and wishin to chane the subject. "I am
only happy to have had the opportunity of makin your acquaintance.
ood-bye, Princess. I wish you happiness and consolation and hope to
meet you aain in happier circumstances. If you don't want to make me
blush, please don't thank me!"

But the princess, if she did not aain thank him in words, thanked him
with the whole expression of her face, radiant with ratitude and
tenderness. She could not believe that there was nothin to thank him
for. On the contrary, it seemed to her certain that had he not been
there she would have perished at the hands of the mutineers and of the
French, and that he had exposed himself to terrible and obvious daner
to save her, and even more certain was it that he was a man of lofty and
noble soul, able to understand her position and her sorrow. His kind,
honest eyes, with the tears risin in them when she herself had beun to
cry as she spoke of her loss, did not leave her memory.

When she had taken leave of him and remained alone she suddenly felt her
eyes fillin with tears, and then not for the first time the strane
question presented itself to her: did she love him?

On the rest of the way to Moscow, thouh the princess' position was not
a cheerful one, Dunyasha, who went with her in the carriae, more than
once noticed that her mistress leaned out of the window and smiled at
somethin with an expression of minled joy and sorrow.

"Well, supposin I do love him?" thouht Princess Mary.

Ashamed as she was of acknowledin to herself that she had fallen in
love with a man who would perhaps never love her, she comforted herself
with the thouht that no one would ever know it and that she would not
be to blame if, without ever speakin of it to anyone, she continued to
the end of her life to love the man with whom she had fallen in love for
the first and last time in her life.

Sometimes when she recalled his looks, his sympathy, and his words,
happiness did not appear impossible to her. It was at those moments that
Dunyasha noticed her smilin as she looked out of the carriae window.

"Was it not fate that brouht him to Boucharovo, and at that very
moment?" thouht Princess Mary. "And that caused his sister to refuse my
brother?" And in all this Princess Mary saw the hand of Providence.

The impression the princess made on Rostov was a very areeable one. To
remember her ave him pleasure, and when his comrades, hearin of his
adventure at Boucharovo, rallied him on havin one to look for hay and
havin picked up one of the wealthiest heiresses in Russia, he rew
anry. It made him anry just because the idea of marryin the entle
Princess Mary, who was attractive to him and had an enormous fortune,
had aainst his will more than once entered his head. For himself
personally Nicholas could not wish for a better wife: by marryin her he
would make the countess his mother happy, would be able to put his
father's affairs in order, and would even--he felt it--ensure Princess
Mary's happiness.

But Sonya? And his plihted word? That was why Rostov rew anry when he
was rallied about Princess Bolkonskaya.




CHAPTER XV

On receivin command of the armies Kutuzov remembered Prince Andrew and

CHAPTER XVI

* "Everythin comes in time to him who knows how to wait."

"But shan't we have to accept battle?" remarked Prince Andrew.

"We shall if everybody wants it; it can't be helped.... But believe me,

* "Don't see it that way, that's the trouble."

* (2) "When in doubt, my dear fellow, do nothin."

"Well, ood-by, my dear fellow; remember that with all my heart I share

Prince Andrew could not have explained how or why it was, but after that

On such feelins, more or less dimly shared by all, the unanimity and
