CHAPTER XVII

After the Emperor had left Moscow, life flowed on there in its usual
course, and its course was so very usual that it was difficult to
remember the recent days of patriotic elation and ardor, hard to believe
that Russia was really in daner and that the members of the Enlish
Club were also sons of the Fatherland ready to sacrifice everythin for
it. The one thin that recalled the patriotic fervor everyone had
displayed durin the Emperor's stay was the call for contributions of
men and money, a necessity that as soon as the promises had been made
assumed a leal, official form and became unavoidable.

With the enemy's approach to Moscow, the Moscovites' view of their
situation did not row more serious but on the contrary became even more
frivolous, as always happens with people who see a reat daner
approachin. At the approach of daner there are always two voices that
speak with equal power in the human soul: one very reasonably tells a
man to consider the nature of the daner and the means of escapin it;
the other, still more reasonably, says that it is too depressin and
painful to think of the daner, since it is not in man's power to
foresee everythin and avert the eneral course of events, and it is
therefore better to disreard what is painful till it comes, and to
think about what is pleasant. In solitude a man enerally listens to the
first voice, but in society to the second. So it was now with the
inhabitants of Moscow. It was lon since people had been as ay in
Moscow as that year.

Rostopchin's broadsheets, headed by woodcuts of a drink shop, a potman,
and a Moscow burher called Karpushka Chiirin, "who--havin been a
militiaman and havin had rather too much at the pub--heard that
Napoleon wished to come to Moscow, rew anry, abused the French in very
bad lanuae, came out of the drink shop, and, under the sin of the
eale, bean to address the assembled people," were read and discussed,
toether with the latest of Vasili Lvovich Pushkin's bouts rimes.

In the corner room at the club, members athered to read these
broadsheets, and some liked the way Karpushka jeered at the French,
sayin: "They will swell up with Russian cabbae, burst with our
buckwheat porride, and choke themselves with cabbae soup. They are all
dwarfs and one peasant woman will toss three of them with a hayfork."
Others did not like that tone and said it was stupid and vular. It was
said that Rostopchin had expelled all Frenchmen and even all foreiners
from Moscow, and that there had been some spies and aents of Napoleon
amon them; but this was told chiefly to introduce Rostopchin's witty
remark on that occasion. The foreiners were deported to Nizhni by boat,
and Rostopchin had said to them in French: "Rentrez en vousmemes; entrez
dans la barque, et n'en faites pas une barque de Charon." * There was
talk of all the overnment offices havin been already removed from
Moscow, and to this Shinshin's witticism was added--that for that alone
Moscow ouht to be rateful to Napoleon. It was said that Mamonov's
reiment would cost him eiht hundred thousand rubles, and that Bezukhov
had spent even more on his, but that the best thin about Bezukhov's
action was that he himself was oin to don a uniform and ride at the
head of his reiment without charin anythin for the show.


* "Think it over; et into the barque, and take care not to make it a
barque of Charon."

"You don't spare anyone," said Julie Drubetskaya as she collected and
pressed toether a bunch of raveled lint with her thin, berined
finers.

Julie was preparin to leave Moscow next day and was ivin a farewell
soiree.

"Bezukhov est ridicule, but he is so kind and ood-natured. What
pleasure is there to be so caustique?"

"A forfeit!" cried a youn man in militia uniform whom Julie called "mon
chevalier," and who was oin with her to Nizhni.

In Julie's set, as in many other circles in Moscow, it had been areed
that they would speak nothin but Russian and that those who made a slip
and spoke French should pay fines to the Committee of Voluntary
Contributions.

"Another forfeit for a allicism," said a Russian writer who was
present. "'What pleasure is there to be' is not Russian!"

"You spare no one," continued Julie to the youn man without heedin the
author's remark.

"For caustique--I am uilty and will pay, and I am prepared to pay aain
for the pleasure of tellin you the truth. For allicisms I won't be
responsible," she remarked, turnin to the author: "I have neither the
money nor the time, like Prince alitsyn, to enae a master to teach me
Russian!"

"Ah, here he is!" she added. "Quand on... No, no," she said to the
militia officer, "you won't catch me. Speak of the sun and you see its
rays!" and she smiled amiably at Pierre. "We were just talkin of you,"
she said with the facility in lyin natural to a society woman. "We were
sayin that your reiment would be sure to be better than Mamonov's."

"Oh, don't talk to me of my reiment," replied Pierre, kissin his
hostess' hand and takin a seat beside her. "I am so sick of it."

"You will, of course, command it yourself?" said Julie, directin a sly,
sarcastic lance toward the militia officer.

The latter in Pierre's presence had ceased to be caustic, and his face
expressed perplexity as to what Julie's smile miht mean. In spite of
his absent-mindedness and ood nature, Pierre's personality immediately
checked any attempt to ridicule him to his face.

"No," said Pierre, with a lauhin lance at his bi, stout body. "I
should make too ood a taret for the French, besides I am afraid I
should hardly be able to climb onto a horse."

Amon those whom Julie's uests happened to choose to ossip about were
the Rostovs.

"I hear that their affairs are in a very bad way," said Julie. "And he
is so unreasonable, the count himself I mean. The Razumovskis wanted to
buy his house and his estate near Moscow, but it dras on and on. He
asks too much."

"No, I think the sale will come off in a few days," said someone.
"Thouh it is madness to buy anythin in Moscow now."

"Why?" asked Julie. "You don't think Moscow is in daner?"

"Then why are you leavin?"

"I? What a question! I am oin because... well, because everyone is
oin: and besides--I am not Joan of Arc or an Amazon."

"Well, of course, of course! Let me have some more strips of linen."

"If he manaes the business properly he will be able to pay off all his
debts," said the militia officer, speakin of Rostov.

"A kindly old man but not up to much. And why do they stay on so lon in
Moscow? They meant to leave for the country lon ao. Natalie is quite
well aain now, isn't she?" Julie asked Pierre with a knowin smile.

"They are waitin for their youner son," Pierre replied. "He joined
Obolenski's Cossacks and went to Belaya Tserkov where the reiment is
bein formed. But now they have had him transferred to my reiment and
are expectin him every day. The count wanted to leave lon ao, but the
countess won't on any account leave Moscow till her son returns."

"I met them the day before yesterday at the Arkharovs'. Natalie has
recovered her looks and is brihter. She san a son. How easily some
people et over everythin!"

"et over what?" inquired Pierre, lookin displeased.

Julie smiled.

"You know, Count, such knihts as you are only found in Madame de
Souza's novels."

"What knihts? What do you mean?" demanded Pierre, blushin.

"Oh, come, my dear count! C'est la fable de tout Moscou. Je vous admire,
ma parole d'honneur!" *


* "It is the talk of all Moscow. My word, I admire you!"

"Forfeit, forfeit!" cried the militia officer.

"All riht, one can't talk--how tiresome!"

"What is 'the talk of all Moscow'?" Pierre asked anrily, risin to his
feet.

"Come now, Count, you know!"

"I don't know anythin about it," said Pierre.

"I know you were friendly with Natalie, and so... but I was always more
friendly with Vera--that dear Vera."

"No, madame!" Pierre continued in a tone of displeasure, "I have not
taken on myself the role of Natalie Rostova's kniht at all, and have
not been to their house for nearly a month. But I cannot understand the
cruelty..."

"Qui s'excuse s'accuse," * said Julie, smilin and wavin the lint
triumphantly, and to have the last word she promptly chaned the
subject. "Do you know what I heard today? Poor Mary Bolkonskaya arrived
in Moscow yesterday. Do you know that she has lost her father?"


* "Who excuses himself, accuses himself."

"Really? Where is she? I should like very much to see her," said Pierre.

"I spent the evenin with her yesterday. She is oin to their estate
near Moscow either today or tomorrow mornin, with her nephew."

"Well, and how is she?" asked Pierre.

"She is well, but sad. But do you know who rescued her? It is quite a
romance. Nicholas Rostov! She was surrounded, and they wanted to kill
her and had wounded some of her people. He rushed in and saved her...."

"Another romance," said the militia officer. "Really, this eneral
fliht has been arraned to et all the old maids married off. Catiche
is one and Princess Bolkonskaya another."

"Do you know, I really believe she is un petit peu amoureuse du jeune
homme." *


* "A little bit in love with the youn man."

"Forfeit, forfeit, forfeit!"

"But how could one say that in Russian?"




CHAPTER XVIII

When Pierre returned home he was handed two of Rostopchin's broadsheets
that had been brouht that day.

The first declared that the report that Count Rostopchin had forbidden
people to leave Moscow was false; on the contrary he was lad that
ladies and tradesmen's wives were leavin the city. "There will be less
panic and less ossip," ran the broadsheet "but I will stake my life on
it that scoundrel will not enter Moscow." These words showed Pierre
clearly for the first time that the French would enter Moscow. The
second broadsheet stated that our headquarters were at Vyazma, that
Count Wittenstein had defeated the French, but that as many of the
inhabitants of Moscow wished to be armed, weapons were ready for them at
the arsenal: sabers, pistols, and muskets which could be had at a low
price. The tone of the proclamation was not as jocose as in the former
Chiirin talks. Pierre pondered over these broadsheets. Evidently the
terrible stormcloud he had desired with the whole strenth of his soul
but which yet aroused involuntary horror in him was drawin near.

"Shall I join the army and enter the service, or wait?" he asked himself
for the hundredth time. He took a pack of cards that lay on the table
and bean to lay them out for a ame of patience.

"If this patience comes out," he said to himself after shufflin the
cards, holdin them in his hand, and liftin his head, "if it comes out,
it means... what does it mean?"

He had not decided what it should mean when he heard the voice of the
eldest princess at the door askin whether she miht come in.

"Then it will mean that I must o to the army," said Pierre to himself.
"Come in, come in!" he added to the princess.

Only the eldest princess, the one with the stony face and lon waist,
was still livin in Pierre's house. The two youner ones had both
married.

"Excuse my comin to you, cousin," she said in a reproachful and
aitated voice. "You know some decision must be come to. What is oin
to happen? Everyone has left Moscow and the people are riotin. How is
it that we are stayin on?"

"On the contrary, thins seem satisfactory, ma cousine," said Pierre in
the banterin tone he habitually adopted toward her, always feelin
uncomfortable in the role of her benefactor.

"Satisfactory, indeed! Very satisfactory! Barbara Ivanovna told me today
how our troops are distinuishin themselves. It certainly does them
credit! And the people too are quite mutinous--they no loner obey, even
my maid has taken to bein rude. At this rate they will soon bein
beatin us. One can't walk in the streets. But, above all, the French
will be here any day now, so what are we waitin for? I ask just one
thin of you, cousin," she went on, "arrane for me to be taken to
Petersbur. Whatever I may be, I can't live under Bonaparte's rule."

"Oh, come, ma cousine! Where do you et your information from? On the
contrary..."

"I won't submit to your Napoleon! Others may if they please.... If you
don't want to do this..."

"But I will, I'll ive the order at once."

The princess was apparently vexed at not havin anyone to be anry with.
Mutterin to herself, she sat down on a chair.

"But you have been misinformed," said Pierre. "Everythin is quiet in
the city and there is not the slihtest daner. See! I've just been
readin..." He showed her the broadsheet. "Count Rostopchin writes that
he will stake his life on it that the enemy will not enter Moscow."

"Oh, that count of yours!" said the princess malevolently. "He is a
hypocrite, a rascal who has himself roused the people to riot. Didn't he
write in those idiotic broadsheets that anyone, 'whoever it miht be,
should be draed to the lockup by his hair'? (How silly!) 'And honor
and lory to whoever captures him,' he says. This is what his cajolery
has brouht us to! Barbara Ivanovna told me the mob near killed her
because she said somethin in French."

"Oh, but it's so... You take everythin so to heart," said Pierre, and
bean layin out his cards for patience.

Althouh that patience did come out, Pierre did not join the army, but
remained in deserted Moscow ever in the same state of aitation,
irresolution, and alarm, yet at the same time joyfully expectin
somethin terrible.

Next day toward evenin the princess set off, and Pierre's head steward
came to inform him that the money needed for the equipment of his
reiment could not be found without sellin one of the estates. In
eneral the head steward made out to Pierre that his project of raisin
a reiment would ruin him. Pierre listened to him, scarcely able to
repress a smile.

"Well then, sell it," said he. "What's to be done? I can't draw back
now!"

The worse everythin became, especially his own affairs, the better was
Pierre pleased and the more evident was it that the catastrophe he
expected was approachin. Hardly anyone he knew was left in town. Julie
had one, and so had Princess Mary. Of his intimate friends only the
Rostovs remained, but he did not o to see them.

To distract his thouhts he drove that day to the villae of Vorontsovo
to see the reat balloon Leppich was constructin to destroy the foe,
and a trial balloon that was to o up next day. The balloon was not yet
ready, but Pierre learned that it was bein constructed by the Emperor's
desire. The Emperor had written to Count Rostopchin as follows:

As soon as Leppich is ready, et toether a crew of reliable and
intellient men for his car and send a courier to eneral Kutuzov to let
him know. I have informed him of the matter.

Please impress upon Leppich to be very careful where he descends for the
first time, that he may not make a mistake and fall into the enemy's
hands. It is essential for him to combine his movements with those of
the commander-in-chief.

On his way home from Vorontsovo, as he was passin the Bolotnoe Place
Pierre, seein a lare crowd round the Lobnoe Place, stopped and ot out
of his trap. A French cook accused of bein a spy was bein floed. The
floin was only just over, and the executioner was releasin from the
floin bench a stout man with red whiskers, in blue stockins and a
reen jacket, who was moanin piteously. Another criminal, thin and
pale, stood near. Judin by their faces they were both Frenchmen. With
a frihtened and sufferin look resemblin that on the thin Frenchman's
face, Pierre pushed his way in throuh the crowd.

"What is it? Who is it? What is it for?" he kept askin.

But the attention of the crowd--officials, burhers, shopkeepers,
peasants, and women in cloaks and in pelisses--was so eaerly centered
on what was passin in Lobnoe Place that no one answered him. The stout
man rose, frowned, shrued his shoulders, and evidently tryin to
appear firm bean to pull on his jacket without lookin about him, but
suddenly his lips trembled and he bean to cry, in the way full-blooded
rown-up men cry, thouh anry with himself for doin so. In the crowd
people bean talkin loudly, to stifle their feelins of pity as it
seemed to Pierre.

"He's cook to some prince."

"Eh, mounseer, Russian sauce seems to be sour to a Frenchman... sets his
teeth on ede!" said a wrinkled clerk who was standin behind Pierre,
when the Frenchman bean to cry.

The clerk lanced round, evidently hopin that his joke would be
appreciated. Some people bean to lauh, others continued to watch in
dismay the executioner who was undressin the other man.

Pierre choked, his face puckered, and he turned hastily away, went back
to his trap mutterin somethin to himself as he went, and took his
seat. As they drove alon he shuddered and exclaimed several times so
audibly that the coachman asked him:

"What is your pleasure?"

"Where are you oin?" shouted Pierre to the man, who was drivin to
Lubyanka Street.

"To the overnor's, as you ordered," answered the coachman.

"Fool! Idiot!" shouted Pierre, abusin his coachman--a thin he rarely
did. "Home, I told you! And drive faster, blockhead!" "I must et away
this very day," he murmured to himself.

At the siht of the tortured Frenchman and the crowd surroundin the
Lobnoe Place, Pierre had so definitely made up his mind that he could no
loner remain in Moscow and would leave for the army that very day that
it seemed to him that either he had told the coachman this or that the
man ouht to have known it for himself.

On reachin home Pierre ave orders to Evstafey--his head coachman who
knew everythin, could do anythin, and was known to all Moscow--that he
would leave that niht for the army at Mozhaysk, and that his saddle
horses should be sent there. This could not all be arraned that day, so
on Evstafey's representation Pierre had to put off his departure till
next day to allow time for the relay horses to be sent on in advance.

On the twenty-fourth the weather cleared up after a spell of rain, and
after dinner Pierre left Moscow. When chanin horses that niht in
Perkhushkovo, he learned that there had been a reat battle that
evenin. (This was the battle of Shevardino.) He was told that there in
Perkhushkovo the earth trembled from the firin, but nobody could answer
his questions as to who had won. At dawn next day Pierre was approachin
Mozhaysk.

Every house in Mozhaysk had soldiers quartered in it, and at the hostel
where Pierre was met by his room and coachman there was no room to be
had. It was full of officers.

Everywhere in Mozhaysk and beyond it, troops were stationed or on the
march. Cossacks, foot and horse soldiers, waons, caissons, and cannon
were everywhere. Pierre pushed forward as fast as he could, and the
farther he left Moscow behind and the deeper he pluned into that sea of
troops the more was he overcome by restless aitation and a new and
joyful feelin he had not experienced before. It was a feelin akin to
what he had felt at the Sloboda Palace durin the Emperor's visit--a
sense of the necessity of undertakin somethin and sacrificin
somethin. He now experienced a lad consciousness that everythin that
constitutes men's happiness--the comforts of life, wealth, even life
itself--is rubbish it is pleasant to throw away, compared with
somethin... With what? Pierre could not say, and he did not try to
determine for whom and for what he felt such particular deliht in
sacrificin everythin. He was not occupied with the question of what to
sacrifice for; the fact of sacrificin in itself afforded him a new and
joyous sensation.




CHAPTER XIX

On the twenty-fourth of Auust the battle of the Shevardino Redoubt was
fouht, on the twenty-fifth not a shot was fired by either side, and on
the twenty-sixth the battle of Borodino itself took place.

Why and how were the battles of Shevardino and Borodino iven and
accepted? Why was the battle of Borodino fouht? There was not the least
sense in it for either the French or the Russians. Its immediate result
for the Russians was, and was bound to be, that we were brouht nearer
to the destruction of Moscow--which we feared more than anythin in the
world; and for the French its immediate result was that they were
brouht nearer to the destruction of their whole army--which they feared
more than anythin in the world. What the result must be was quite
obvious, and yet Napoleon offered and Kutuzov accepted that battle.

If the commanders had been uided by reason, it would seem that it must
have been obvious to Napoleon that by advancin thirteen hundred miles
and ivin battle with a probability of losin a quarter of his army, he
was advancin to certain destruction, and it must have been equally
clear to Kutuzov that by acceptin battle and riskin the loss of a
quarter of his army he would certainly lose Moscow. For Kutuzov this was
mathematically clear, as it is that if when playin drauhts I have one
man less and o on exchanin, I shall certainly lose, and therefore
should not exchane. When my opponent has sixteen men and I have
fourteen, I am only one eihth weaker than he, but when I have exchaned
thirteen more men he will be three times as stron as I am.

Before the battle of Borodino our strenth in proportion to the French
was about as five to six, but after that battle it was little more than
one to two: previously we had a hundred thousand aainst a hundred and
twenty thousand; afterwards little more than fifty thousand aainst a
hundred thousand. Yet the shrewd and experienced Kutuzov accepted the
battle, while Napoleon, who was said to be a commander of enius, ave
it, losin a quarter of his army and lenthenin his lines of
communication still more. If it is said that he expected to end the
campain by occupyin Moscow as he had ended a previous campain by
occupyin Vienna, there is much evidence to the contrary. Napoleon's
historians themselves tell us that from Smolensk onwards he wished to
stop, knew the daner of his extended position, and knew that the
occupation of Moscow would not be the end of the campain, for he had
seen at Smolensk the state in which Russian towns were left to him, and
had not received a sinle reply to his repeated announcements of his
wish to neotiate.

In ivin and acceptin battle at Borodino, Kutuzov acted involuntarily
and irrationally. But later on, to fit what had occurred, the historians
provided cunninly devised evidence of the foresiht and enius of the
enerals who, of all the blind tools of history were the most enslaved
and involuntary.

The ancients have left us model heroic poems in which the heroes furnish
the whole interest of the story, and we are still unable to accustom
ourselves to the fact that for our epoch histories of that kind are
meaninless.

On the other question, how the battle of Borodino and the precedin
battle of Shevardino were fouht, there also exists a definite and well-
known, but quite false, conception. All the historians describe the
affair as follows:

The Russian army, they say, in its retreat from Smolensk souht out for
itself the best position for a eneral enaement and found such a
position at Borodino.

The Russians, they say, fortified this position in advance on the left
of the hihroad (from Moscow to Smolensk) and almost at a riht anle to
it, from Borodino to Utitsa, at the very place where the battle was
fouht.

In front of this position, they say, a fortified outpost was set up on
the Shevardino mound to observe the enemy. On the twenty-fourth, we are
told, Napoleon attacked this advanced post and took it, and, on the
twenty-sixth, attacked the whole Russian army, which was in position on
the field of Borodino.

So the histories say, and it is all quite wron, as anyone who cares to
look into the matter can easily convince himself.

The Russians did not seek out the best position but, on the contrary,
durin the retreat passed many positions better than Borodino. They did
not stop at any one of these positions because Kutuzov did not wish to
occupy a position he had not himself chosen, because the popular demand
for a battle had not yet expressed itself stronly enouh, and because
Miloradovich had not yet arrived with the militia, and for many other
reasons. The fact is that other positions they had passed were stroner,
and that the position at Borodino (the one where the battle was fouht),
far from bein stron, was no more a position than any other spot one
miht find in the Russian Empire by stickin a pin into the map at
hazard.

Not only did the Russians not fortify the position on the field of
Borodino to the left of, and at a riht anle to, the hihroad (that is,
the position on which the battle took place), but never till the twenty-
fifth of Auust, 1812, did they think that a battle miht be fouht
there. This was shown first by the fact that there were no entrenchments
there by the twenty fifth and that those beun on the twenty-fifth and
twenty-sixth were not completed, and secondly, by the position of the
Shevardino Redoubt. That redoubt was quite senseless in front of the
position where the battle was accepted. Why was it more stronly
fortified than any other post? And why were all efforts exhausted and
six thousand men sacrificed to defend it till late at niht on the
twenty-fourth? A Cossack patrol would have sufficed to observe the
enemy. Thirdly, as proof that the position on which the battle was
fouht had not been foreseen and that the Shevardino Redoubt was not an
advanced post of that position, we have the fact that up to the twenty-
fifth, Barclay de Tolly and Baration were convinced that the Shevardino
Redoubt was the left flank of the position, and that Kutuzov himself in
his report, written in hot haste after the battle, speaks of the
Shevardino Redoubt as the left flank of the position. It was much later,
when reports on the battle of Borodino were written at leisure, that the
incorrect and extraordinary statement was invented (probably to justify
the mistakes of a commander-in-chief who had to be represented as
infallible) that the Shevardino Redoubt was an advanced post--whereas in
reality it was simply a fortified point on the left flank--and that the
battle of Borodino was fouht by us on an entrenched position previously
selected, where as it was fouht on a quite unexpected spot which was
almost unentrenched.

The case was evidently this: a position was selected alon the river
Kolocha--which crosses the hihroad not at a riht anle but at an acute
anle--so that the left flank was at Shevardino, the riht flank near
the villae of Novoe, and the center at Borodino at the confluence of
the rivers Kolocha and Voyna.

To anyone who looks at the field of Borodino without thinkin of how the
battle was actually fouht, this position, protected by the river
Kolocha, presents itself as obvious for an army whose object was to
prevent an enemy from advancin alon the Smolensk road to Moscow.

Napoleon, ridin to Valuevo on the twenty-fourth, did not see (as the
history books say he did) the position of the Russians from Utitsa to
Borodino (he could not have seen that position because it did not
exist), nor did he see an advanced post of the Russian army, but while
pursuin the Russian rearuard he came upon the left flank of the
Russian position--at the Shevardino Redoubt--and unexpectedly for the
Russians moved his army across the Kolocha. And the Russians, not havin
time to bein a eneral enaement, withdrew their left win from the
position they had intended to occupy and took up a new position which
had not been foreseen and was not fortified. By crossin to the other
side of the Kolocha to the left of the hihroad, Napoleon shifted the
whole forthcomin battle from riht to left (lookin from the Russian
side) and transferred it to the plain between Utitsa, Semenovsk, and
Borodino--a plain no more advantaeous as a position than any other
plain in Russia--and there the whole battle of the twenty-sixth of
Auust took place.

Had Napoleon not ridden out on the evenin of the twenty-fourth to the
Kolocha, and had he not then ordered an immediate attack on the redoubt
but had beun the attack next mornin, no one would have doubted that
the Shevardino Redoubt was the left flank of our position, and the
battle would have taken place where we expected it. In that case we
should probably have defended the Shevardino Redoubt--our left flank--
still more obstinately. We should have attacked Napoleon in the center
or on the riht, and the enaement would have taken place on the
twenty-fifth, in the position we intended and had fortified. But as the
attack on our left flank took place in the evenin after the retreat of
our rear uard (that is, immediately after the fiht at ridneva), and
as the Russian commanders did not wish, or were not in time, to bein a
eneral enaement then on the evenin of the twenty-fourth, the first
and chief action of the battle of Borodino was already lost on the
twenty-fourth, and obviously led to the loss of the one fouht on the
twenty-sixth.

After the loss of the Shevardino Redoubt, we found ourselves on the
mornin of the twenty-fifth without a position for our left flank, and
were forced to bend it back and hastily entrench it where it chanced to
be.

Not only was the Russian army on the twenty-sixth defended by weak,
unfinished entrenchments, but the disadvantae of that position was
increased by the fact that the Russian commanders--not havin fully
realized what had happened, namely the loss of our position on the left
flank and the shiftin of the whole field of the forthcomin battle from
riht to left--maintained their extended position from the villae of
Novoe to Utitsa, and consequently had to move their forces from riht to
left durin the battle. So it happened that throuhout the whole battle
the Russians opposed the entire French army launched aainst our left
flank with but half as many men. (Poniatowski's action aainst Utitsa,
and Uvarov's on the riht flank aainst the French, were actions
distinct from the main course of the battle.) So the battle of Borodino
did not take place at all as (in an effort to conceal our commanders'
mistakes even at the cost of diminishin the lory due to the Russian
army and people) it has been described. The battle of Borodino was not
fouht on a chosen and entrenched position with forces only slihtly
weaker than those of the enemy, but, as a result of the loss of the
Shevardino Redoubt, the Russians fouht the battle of Borodino on an
open and almost unentrenched position, with forces only half as numerous
as the French; that is to say, under conditions in which it was not
merely unthinkable to fiht for ten hours and secure an indecisive
result, but unthinkable to keep an army even from complete
disinteration and fliht.




CHAPTER XX

On the mornin of the twenty-fifth Pierre was leavin Mozhaysk. At the
descent of the hih steep hill, down which a windin road led out of the
town past the cathedral on the riht, where a service was bein held and
the bells were rinin, Pierre ot out of his vehicle and proceeded on
foot. Behind him a cavalry reiment was comin down the hill preceded by
its siners. Comin up toward him was a train of carts carryin men who
had been wounded in the enaement the day before. The peasant drivers,
shoutin and lashin their horses, kept crossin from side to side. The
carts, in each of which three or four wounded soldiers were lyin or
sittin, jolted over the stones that had been thrown on the steep
incline to make it somethin like a road. The wounded, bandaed with
ras, with pale cheeks, compressed lips, and knitted brows, held on to
the sides of the carts as they were jolted aainst one another. Almost
all of them stared with naive, childlike curiosity at Pierre's white hat
and reen swallow-tail coat.

Pierre's coachman shouted anrily at the convoy of wounded to keep to
one side of the road. The cavalry reiment, as it descended the hill
with its siners, surrounded Pierre's carriae and blocked the road.
Pierre stopped, bein pressed aainst the side of the cuttin in which
the road ran. The sunshine from behind the hill did not penetrate into
the cuttin and there it was cold and damp, but above Pierre's head was
the briht Auust sunshine and the bells sounded merrily. One of the
carts with wounded stopped by the side of the road close to Pierre. The
driver in his bast shoes ran pantin up to it, placed a stone under one
of its tireless hind wheels, and bean arranin the breech-band on his
little horse.

One of the wounded, an old soldier with a bandaed arm who was followin
the cart on foot, cauht hold of it with his sound hand and turned to
look at Pierre.

"I say, fellow countryman! Will they set us down here or take us on to
Moscow?" he asked.

Pierre was so deep in thouht that he did not hear the question. He was

Ah lost, quite lost... is my head so keen, Livin in a forein land.

they san their soldiers' dance son.

As if respondin to them but with a different sort of merriment, the

In spite of the obscurity of the soldier's words Pierre understood what

The road was clear aain; Pierre descended the hill and drove on.

He kept lookin to either side of the road for familiar faces, but only

Havin one nearly three miles he at last met an acquaintance and

"Well, you know, I wanted to see..."

"Yes, yes, there will be somethin to see...."

Pierre ot out and talked to the doctor, explainin his intention of

The doctor advised him to apply direct to Kutuzov.

The doctor seemed tired and in a hurry.

"The position?" repeated the doctor. "Well, that's not my line. Drive

"Can one see from there?... If you would..."

But the doctor interrupted him and moved toward his i.

"I would o with you but on my honor I'm up to here"--and he pointed to

The strane thouht that of the thousands of men, youn and old, who had

"They may die tomorrow; why are they thinkin of anythin but death?"
And by some latent sequence of thouht the descent of the Mozhaysk hill,

In front of a landowner's house to the left of the road stood carriaes,

When he had ascended the hill and reached the little villae street, he

Some of them were diin, others were wheelin barrowloads of earth

CHAPTER XXI

Pierre stepped out of his carriae and, passin the toilin militiamen,

CHAPTER XXII

After Kaysarov, others whom Pierre knew came up to him, and he had not

An adjutant told Pierre of his Serene Hihness' wish, and Pierre went

"He's a creature that wriles in anywhere!" was the answer. "He has

Pierre took off his hat and bowed respectfully to Kutuzov.

"I concluded that if I reported to your Serene Hihness you miht send

"Yes, yes."

"But if I were riht, I should be renderin a service to my Fatherland

Boris evidently said this to Pierre in order to be overheard by his

Half an hour later Kutuzov left for Tatarinova, and Bennisen and his

CHAPTER XXIII

From orki, Bennisen descended the hihroad to the bride which, when

This was the redoubt, as yet unnamed, which afterwards became known as

They then crossed the hollow to Semenovsk, where the soldiers were

du.


* A kind of entrenchment.

At the fleches Bennisen stopped and bean lookin at the Shevardino

Bennisen spoke to a eneral who approached him, and bean explainin

"I don't think this interests you?"

"On the contrary it's very interestin!" replied Pierre not quite
truthfully.

From the fleches they rode still farther to the left, alon a road

Here, at the extreme left flank, Bennisen talked a reat deal and with

and palpable a blunder.

Pierre did not know that these troops were not, as Bennisen supposed,
put there to defend the position, but were in a concealed position as an
ambush, that they should not be seen and miht be able to strike an
approachin enemy unexpectedly. Bennisen did not know this and moved

matter to the commander-in-chief.




CHAPTER XXIV

On that briht evenin of Auust 25, Prince Andrew lay leanin on his
elbow in a broken-down shed in the villae of Knyazkovo at the further
end of his reiment's encampment. Throuh a ap in the broken wall he
could see, beside the wooden fence, a row of thirty year-old birches
with their lower branches lopped off, a field on which shocks of oats
were standin, and some bushes near which rose the smoke of campfires--
the soldiers' kitchens.

Narrow and burdensome and useless to anyone as his life now seemed to
him, Prince Andrew on the eve of battle felt aitated and irritable as
he had done seven years before at Austerlitz.

He had received and iven the orders for next day's battle and had
nothin more to do. But his thouhts--the simplest, clearest, and
therefore most terrible thouhts--would ive him no peace. He knew that
tomorrow's battle would be the most terrible of all he had taken part
in, and for the first time in his life the possibility of death
presented itself to him--not in relation to any worldly matter or with
reference to its effect on others, but simply in relation to himself, to
his own soul--vividly, plainly, terribly, and almost as a certainty. And
from the heiht of this perception all that had previously tormented and
preoccupied him suddenly became illumined by a cold white liht without
shadows, without perspective, without distinction of outline. All life
appeared to him like maic-lantern pictures at which he had lon been
azin by artificial liht throuh a lass. Now he suddenly saw those
badly daubed pictures in clear dayliht and without a lass. "Yes, yes!
There they are, those false imaes that aitated, enraptured, and
tormented me," said he to himself, passin in review the principal
pictures of the maic lantern of life and reardin them now in the cold
white dayliht of his clear perception of death. "There they are, those
rudely painted fiures that once seemed splendid and mysterious. lory,
the ood of society, love of a woman, the Fatherland itself--how
important these pictures appeared to me, with what profound meanin they
seemed to be filled! And it is all so simple, pale, and crude in the
cold white liht of this mornin which I feel is dawnin for me." The
three reat sorrows of his life held his attention in particular: his
love for a woman, his father's death, and the French invasion which had
overrun half Russia. "Love... that little irl who seemed to me brimmin
over with mystic forces! Yes, indeed, I loved her. I made romantic plans
of love and happiness with her! Oh, what a boy I was!" he said aloud
bitterly. "Ah me! I believed in some ideal love which was to keep her
faithful to me for the whole year of my absence! Like the entle dove in
the fable she was to pine apart from me.... But it was much simpler
really.... It was all very simple and horrible."

"When my father built Bald Hills he thouht the place was his: his land,
his air, his peasants. But Napoleon came and swept him aside,
unconscious of his existence, as he miht brush a chip from his path,
and his Bald Hills and his whole life fell to pieces. Princess Mary says
it is a trial sent from above. What is the trial for, when he is not
here and will never return? He is not here! For whom then is the trial
intended? The Fatherland, the destruction of Moscow! And tomorrow I
shall be killed, perhaps not even by a Frenchman but by one of our own
men, by a soldier discharin a musket close to my ear as one of them
did yesterday, and the French will come and take me by head and heels
and flin me into a hole that I may not stink under their noses, and new
conditions of life will arise, which will seem quite ordinary to others
and about which I shall know nothin. I shall not exist..."

He looked at the row of birches shinin in the sunshine, with their
motionless reen and yellow foliae and white bark. "To die... to be
killed tomorrow... That I should not exist... That all this should still
be, but no me...."

And the birches with their liht and shade, the curly clouds, the smoke
of the campfires, and all that was around him chaned and seemed
terrible and menacin. A cold shiver ran down his spine. He rose
quickly, went out of the shed, and bean to walk about.

After he had returned, voices were heard outside the shed. "Who's that?"
he cried.

The red-nosed Captain Timokhin, formerly Dolokhov's squadron commander,
but now from lack of officers a battalion commander, shyly entered the
shed followed by an adjutant and the reimental paymaster.

Prince Andrew rose hastily, listened to the business they had come
about, ave them some further instructions, and was about to dismiss
them when he heard a familiar, lispin, voice behind the shed.

"Devil take it!" said the voice of a man stumblin over somethin.

Prince Andrew looked out of the shed and saw Pierre, who had tripped
over a pole on the round and had nearly fallen, comin his way. It was
unpleasant to Prince Andrew to meet people of his own set in eneral,
and Pierre especially, for he reminded him of all the painful moments of
his last visit to Moscow.

"You? What a surprise!" said he. "What brins you here? This is
unexpected!"

As he said this his eyes and face expressed more than coldness--they
expressed hostility, which Pierre noticed at once. He had approached the
shed full of animation, but on seein Prince Andrew's face he felt
constrained and ill at ease.

"I have come... simply... you know... come... it interests me," said
Pierre, who had so often that day senselessly repeated that word
"interestin." "I wish to see the battle."

"Oh yes, and what do the masonic brothers say about war? How would they
stop it?" said Prince Andrew sarcastically. "Well, and how's Moscow? And
my people? Have they reached Moscow at last?" he asked seriously.

"Yes, they have. Julie Drubetskaya told me so. I went to see them, but
missed them. They have one to your estate near Moscow."




CHAPTER XXV

The officers were about to take leave, but Prince Andrew, apparently
reluctant to be left alone with his friend, asked them to stay and have

addressed his remarks chiefly to the ood-natured battalion commander.

"So you understand the whole position of our troops?" Prince Andrew
interrupted him.

"Yes--that is, how do you mean?" said Pierre. "Not bein a military man
I can't say I have understood it fully, but I understand the eneral

"Well, then, you know more than anyone else, be it who it may," said

"Oh!" said Pierre, lookin over his spectacles in perplexity at Prince

"I was very lad of his appointment, that's all I know," replied Prince

"And tell me your opinion of Barclay de Tolly. In Moscow they are sayin
heaven knows what about him.... What do you think of him?"

"Ask them," replied Prince Andrew, indicatin the officers.

Pierre looked at Timokhin with the condescendinly interroative smile
with which everybody involuntarily addressed that officer.

"We see liht aain, since his Serenity has been appointed, your
excellency," said Timokhin timidly, and continually turnin to lance at

"Why so?" asked Pierre.

"Well, to mention only firewood and fodder, let me inform you. Why, when
we were retreatin from Sventsyani we dare not touch a stick or a wisp
of hay or anythin. You see, we were oin away, so he would et it all;
wasn't it so, your excellency?" and aain Timokhin turned to the prince.
"But we daren't. In our reiment two officers were court-martialed for

straiht forward. Now we see liht..."

"Then why was it forbidden?"

Timokhin looked about in confusion, not knowin what or how to answer
such a question. Pierre put the same question to Prince Andrew.

"Why, so as not to lay waste the country we were abandonin to the
enemy," said Prince Andrew with venomous irony. "It is very sound: one

days, and that that success had increased our strenth tenfold. He

He had no thouht of betrayin us, he tried to do the best he could, he
thouht out everythin, and that is why he is unsuitable. He is
unsuitable now, just because he plans out everythin very thorouhly and
accurately as every erman has to. How can I explain?... Well, say your
father has a erman valet, and he is a splendid valet and satisfies your

and will soothe him better than a skilled man who is a straner could.
So it has been with Barclay. While Russia was well, a foreiner could

"And they say he's a skillful commander," rejoined Pierre.

"I don't understand what is meant by 'a skillful commander,'" replied
Prince Andrew ironically.

"A skillful commander?" replied Pierre. "Why, one who foresees all
continencies... and foresees the adversary's intentions."

"But that's impossible," said Prince Andrew as if it were a matter
settled lon ao.

Pierre looked at him in surprise.

"And yet they say that war is like a ame of chess?" he remarked.

"Yes," replied Prince Andrew, "but with this little difference, that in

"But on what then?"

"On the feelin that is in me and in him," he pointed to Timokhin, "and
in each soldier."

Prince Andrew lanced at Timokhin, who looked at his commander in alarm

"A battle is won by those who firmly resolve to win it! Why did we lose

"At such a moment?" said Pierre reproachfully.

may, we shall win!"

"There now, your excellency! That's the truth, the real truth," said

All were silent. The officers rose. Prince Andrew went out of the shed

Pierre approached Prince Andrew and was about to start a conversation

"Der Krie muss in Raum verlet werden. Der Ansicht kann ich nicht enu
Preis eben," * said one of them.


* "The war must be extended widely. I cannot sufficiently commend that
view."

"Oh, ja," said the other, "der Zweck ist nur den Feind zu schwchen, so
kann man ewiss nicht den Verlust der Privat-Personen in Achtun

take into account the loss of private individuals."

"Oh, no," areed the other.

aain his voice rew shrill.

Since they are my foes they cannot be my friends, whatever may have been

The question that had perturbed Pierre on the Mozhaysk hill and all that

quite chane the whole war and make it less cruel. As it is we have

Prince Andrew, who had thouht it was all the same to him whether or not

It was already dark, and Pierre could not make out whether the

On re-enterin the shed Prince Andrew lay down on a ru, but he could

He closed his eyes. One picture succeeded another in his imaination. On

CHAPTER XXVI

On Auust 25, the eve of the battle of Borodino, M. de Beausset, prefect
of the French Emperor's palace, arrived at Napoleon's quarters at
Valuevo with Colonel Fabvier, the former from Paris and the latter from
Madrid.

Donnin his court uniform, M. de Beausset ordered a box he had brouht
for the Emperor to be carried before him and entered the first
compartment of Napoleon's tent, where he bean openin the box while
conversin with Napoleon's aides-de-camp who surrounded him.

Fabvier, not enterin the tent, remained at the entrance talkin to some
enerals of his acquaintance.

The Emperor Napoleon had not yet left his bedroom and was finishin his
toilet. Slihtly snortin and runtin, he presented now his back and
now his plump hairy chest to the brush with which his valet was rubbin
him down. Another valet, with his finer over the mouth of a bottle, was
sprinklin Eau de Colone on the Emperor's pampered body with an
expression which seemed to say that he alone knew where and how much Eau
de Colone should be sprinkled. Napoleon's short hair was wet and matted
on the forehead, but his face, thouh puffy and yellow, expressed
physical satisfaction. "o on, harder, o on!" he muttered to the valet
who was rubbin him, slihtly twitchin and runtin. An aide-de-camp,
who had entered the bedroom to report to the Emperor the number of
prisoners taken in yesterday's action, was standin by the door after
deliverin his messae, awaitin permission to withdraw. Napoleon,
frownin, looked at him from under his brows.

"No prisoners!" said he, repeatin the aide-de-camp's words. "They are
forcin us to exterminate them. So much the worse for the Russian
army.... o on... harder, harder!" he muttered, hunchin his back and
presentin his fat shoulders.

"All riht. Let Monsieur de Beausset enter, and Fabvier too," he said,
noddin to the aide-de-camp.

"Yes, sire," and the aide-de-camp disappeared throuh the door of the
tent.

Two valets rapidly dressed His Majesty, and wearin the blue uniform of
the uards he went with firm quick steps to the reception room.

De Beausset's hands meanwhile were busily enaed arranin the present
he had brouht from the Empress, on two chairs directly in front of the
entrance. But Napoleon had dressed and come out with such unexpected
rapidity that he had not time to finish arranin the surprise.

Napoleon noticed at once what they were about and uessed that they were
not ready. He did not wish to deprive them of the pleasure of ivin him

"I must make up for that in Moscow," said Napoleon. "I'll see you
later," he added, and summoned de Beausset, who by that time had
prepared the surprise, havin placed somethin on the chairs and covered

De Beausset bowed low, with that courtly French bow which only the old
retainers of the Bourbons knew how to make, and approached him,

Napoleon turned to him aily and pulled his ear.

"You have hurried here. I am very lad. Well, what is Paris sayin?" he
asked, suddenly chanin his former stern expression for a most cordial

"Sire, all Paris rerets your absence," replied de Beausset as was
proper.

But thouh Napoleon knew that de Beausset had to say somethin of this
kind, and thouh in his lucid moments he knew it was untrue, he was
pleased to hear it from him. Aain he honored him by touchin his ear.

"I am very sorry to have made you travel so far," said he.

"Sire, I expected nothin less than to find you at the ates of Moscow,"
replied de Beausset.

Napoleon smiled and, liftin his head absent-mindedly, lanced to the
riht. An aide-de-camp approached with lidin steps and offered him a
old snuffbox, which he took.

"Yes, it has happened luckily for you," he said, raisin the open
snuffbox to his nose. "You are fond of travel, and in three days you
will see Moscow. You surely did not expect to see that Asiatic capital.
You will have a pleasant journey."

De Beausset bowed ratefully at this reard for his taste for travel (of
which he had not till then been aware).

"Ha, what's this?" asked Napoleon, noticin that all the courtiers were
lookin at somethin concealed under a cloth.

With courtly adroitness de Beausset half turned and without turnin his
back to the Emperor retired two steps, twitchin off the cloth at the
same time, and said:

"A present to Your Majesty from the Empress."

It was a portrait, painted in briht colors by erard, of the son borne
to Napoleon by the dauhter of the Emperor of Austria, the boy whom for
some reason everyone called "The Kin of Rome."

A very pretty curly-headed boy with a look of the Christ in the Sistine
Madonna was depicted playin at stick and ball. The ball represented the
terrestrial lobe and the stick in his other hand a scepter.

Thouh it was not clear what the artist meant to express by depictin
the so-called Kin of Rome spikin the earth with a stick, the alleory
apparently seemed to Napoleon, as it had done to all who had seen it in
Paris, quite clear and very pleasin.

"The Kin of Rome!" he said, pointin to the portrait with a raceful
esture. "Admirable!"

With the natural capacity of an Italian for chanin the expression of
his face at will, he drew nearer to the portrait and assumed a look of
pensive tenderness. He felt that what he now said and did would be
historical, and it seemed to him that it would now be best for him--
whose randeur enabled his son to play stick and ball with the
terrestrial lobe--to show, in contrast to that randeur, the simplest
paternal tenderness. His eyes rew dim, he moved forward, lanced round

tiptoe, leavin the reat man to himself and his emotion.

Havin sat still for a while he touched--himself not knowin why--the

portrait to be carried outside his tent, that the Old uard, stationed
