Rome, the son and heir of their adored monarch.

And while he was doin M. de Beausset the honor of breakfastin with
him, they heard, as Napoleon had anticipated, the rapturous cries of the
officers and men of the Old uard who had run up to see the portrait.

"Vive l'Empereur! Vive le roi de Rome! Vive l'Empereur!" came those
ecstatic cries.

After breakfast Napoleon in de Beausset's presence dictated his order of
the day to the army.

"Short and eneretic!" he remarked when he had read over the
proclamation which he had dictated straiht off without corrections. It
ran:

Soldiers! This is the battle you have so loned for. Victory depends on
you. It is essential for us; it will ive us all we need: comfortable
quarters and a speedy return to our country. Behave as you did at
Austerlitz, Friedland, Vitebsk, and Smolensk. Let our remotest posterity
recall your achievements this day with pride. Let it be said of each of
you: "He was in the reat battle before Moscow!"

"Before Moscow!" repeated Napoleon, and invitin M. de Beausset, who was
so fond of travel, to accompany him on his ride, he went out of the tent
to where the horses stood saddled.

"Your Majesty is too kind!" replied de Beausset to the invitation to
accompany the Emperor; he wanted to sleep, did not know how to ride and
was afraid of doin so.

But Napoleon nodded to the traveler, and de Beausset had to mount. When
Napoleon came out of the tent the shoutin of the uards before his
son's portrait rew still louder. Napoleon frowned.

"Take him away!" he said, pointin with a racefully majestic esture to
the portrait. "It is too soon for him to see a field of battle."

De Beausset closed his eyes, bowed his head, and sihed deeply, to
indicate how profoundly he valued and comprehended the Emperor's words.




CHAPTER XXVII

On the twenty-fifth of Auust, so his historians tell us, Napoleon spent
the whole day on horseback inspectin the locality, considerin plans
submitted to him by his marshals, and personally ivin commands to his
enerals.

The oriinal line of the Russian forces alon the river Kolocha had been
dislocated by the capture of the Shevardino Redoubt on the twenty-
fourth, and part of the line--the left flank--had been drawn back. That
part of the line was not entrenched and in front of it the round was
more open and level than elsewhere. It was evident to anyone, military
or not, that it was here the French should attack. It would seem that
not much consideration was needed to reach this conclusion, nor any
particular care or trouble on the part of the Emperor and his marshals,
nor was there any need of that special and supreme quality called enius
that people are so apt to ascribe to Napoleon; yet the historians who
described the event later and the men who then surrounded Napoleon, and
he himself, thouht otherwise.

Napoleon rode over the plain and surveyed the locality with a profound
air and in silence, nodded with approval or shook his head dubiously,
and without communicatin to the enerals around him the profound course
of ideas which uided his decisions merely ave them his final
conclusions in the form of commands. Havin listened to a suestion
from Davout, who was now called Prince d'Eckmuhl, to turn the Russian
left win, Napoleon said it should not be done, without explainin why
not. To a proposal made by eneral Campan (who was to attack the
fleches) to lead his division throuh the woods, Napoleon areed, thouh
the so-called Duke of Elchinen (Ney) ventured to remark that a movement
throuh the woods was danerous and miht disorder the division.

Havin inspected the country opposite the Shevardino Redoubt, Napoleon
pondered a little in silence and then indicated the spots where two
batteries should be set up by the morrow to act aainst the Russian
entrenchments, and the places where, in line with them, the field
artillery should be placed.

After ivin these and other commands he returned to his tent, and the
dispositions for the battle were written down from his dictation.

These dispositions, of which the French historians write with enthusiasm
and other historians with profound respect, were as follows:

At dawn the two new batteries established durin the niht on the plain
occupied by the Prince d'Eckmuhl will open fire on the opposin
batteries of the enemy.

At the same time the commander of the artillery of the 1st Corps,
eneral Pernetti, with thirty cannon of Campan's division and all the
howitzers of Dessaix's and Friant's divisions, will move forward, open
fire, and overwhelm with shellfire the enemy's battery, aainst which
will operate:


24 uns of the artillery of the uards 30 uns of Campan's division

and     8 uns of Friant's and Dessaix's divisions --

in all 62 uns.

The commander of the artillery of the 3rd Corps, eneral Fouche, will
place the howitzers of the 3rd and 8th Corps, sixteen in all, on the
flanks of the battery that is to bombard the entrenchment on the left,
which will have forty uns in all directed aainst it.

eneral Sorbier must be ready at the first order to advance with all the
howitzers of the uard's artillery aainst either one or other of the
entrenchments.

Durin the cannonade Prince Poniatowski is to advance throuh the wood
on the villae and turn the enemy's position.

eneral Campan will move throuh the wood to seize the first
fortification.

After the advance has beun in this manner, orders will be iven in
accordance with the enemy's movements.

The cannonade on the left flank will bein as soon as the uns of the
riht win are heard. The sharpshooters of Morand's division and of the
vice-Kin's division will open a heavy fire on seein the attack
commence on the riht win.

The vice-Kin will occupy the villae and cross by its three brides,
advancin to the same heihts as Morand's and ibrard's divisions, which
under his leadership will be directed aainst the redoubt and come into
line with the rest of the forces.

All this must be done in ood order (le tout se fera avec ordre et
methode) as far as possible retainin troops in reserve.

The Imperial Camp near Mozhaysk,

September, 6, 1812.

These dispositions, which are very obscure and confused if one allows
oneself to reard the arranements without reliious awe of his enius,
related to Napoleon's orders to deal with four points--four different
orders. Not one of these was, or could be, carried out.

In the disposition it is said first that the batteries placed on the
spot chosen by Napoleon, with the uns of Pernetti and Fouche; which
were to come in line with them, 102 uns in all, were to open fire and
shower shells on the Russian fleches and redoubts. This could not be
done, as from the spots selected by Napoleon the projectiles did not
carry to the Russian works, and those 102 uns shot into the air until
the nearest commander, contrary to Napoleon's instructions, moved them
forward.

The second order was that Poniatowski, movin to the villae throuh the
wood, should turn the Russian left flank. This could not be done and was
not done, because Poniatowski, advancin on the villae throuh the
wood, met Tuchkov there barrin his way, and could not and did not turn
the Russian position.

The third order was: eneral Campan will move throuh the wood to seize
the first fortification. eneral Campan's division did not seize the
first fortification but was driven back, for on emerin from the wood
it had to reform under rapeshot, of which Napoleon was unaware.

The fourth order was: The vice-Kin will occupy the villae (Borodino)
and cross by its three brides, advancin to the same heihts as
Morand's and ibrard's divisions (for whose movements no directions are
iven), which under his leadership will be directed aainst the redoubt
and come into line with the rest of the forces.

As far as one can make out, not so much from this unintelliible
sentence as from the attempts the vice-Kin made to execute the orders
iven him, he was to advance from the left throuh Borodino to the
redoubt while the divisions of Morand and erard were to advance
simultaneously from the front.

All this, like the other parts of the disposition, was not and could not
be executed. After passin throuh Borodino the vice-Kin was driven
back to the Kolocha and could et no farther; while the divisions of
Morand and erard did not take the redoubt but were driven back, and the
redoubt was only taken at the end of the battle by the cavalry (a thin
probably unforeseen and not heard of by Napoleon). So not one of the
orders in the disposition was, or could be, executed. But in the
disposition it is said that, after the fiht has commenced in this
manner, orders will be iven in accordance with the enemy's movements,
and so it miht be supposed that all necessary arranements would be
made by Napoleon durin the battle. But this was not and could not be
done, for durin the whole battle Napoleon was so far away that, as
appeared later, he could not know the course of the battle and not one
of his orders durin the fiht could be executed.




CHAPTER XXVIII

Many historians say that the French did not win the battle of Borodino
because Napoleon had a cold, and that if he had not had a cold the
orders he ave before and durin the battle would have been still more
full of enius and Russia would have been lost and the face of the world
have been chaned. To historians who believe that Russia was shaped by
the will of one man--Peter the reat--and that France from a republic
became an empire and French armies went to Russia at the will of one
man--Napoleon--to say that Russia remained a power because Napoleon had
a bad cold on the twenty-fourth of Auust may seem loical and
convincin.

If it had depended on Napoleon's will to fiht or not to fiht the
battle of Borodino, and if this or that other arranement depended on
his will, then evidently a cold affectin the manifestation of his will
miht have saved Russia, and consequently the valet who omitted to brin
Napoleon his waterproof boots on the twenty-fourth would have been the
savior of Russia. Alon that line of thouht such a deduction is
indubitable, as indubitable as the deduction Voltaire made in jest
(without knowin what he was jestin at) when he saw that the Massacre
of St. Bartholomew was due to Charles IX's stomach bein deraned. But
to men who do not admit that Russia was formed by the will of one man,
Peter I, or that the French Empire was formed and the war with Russia
beun by the will of one man, Napoleon, that arument seems not merely
untrue and irrational, but contrary to all human reality. To the
question of what causes historic events another answer presents itself,
namely, that the course of human events is predetermined from on hih--
depends on the coincidence of the wills of all who take part in the
events, and that a Napoleon's influence on the course of these events is
purely external and fictitious.

Strane as at first lance it may seem to suppose that the Massacre of
St. Bartholomew was not due to Charles IX's will, thouh he ave the
order for it and thouht it was done as a result of that order; and
strane as it may seem to suppose that the slauhter of eihty thousand
men at Borodino was not due to Napoleon's will, thouh he ordered the
commencement and conduct of the battle and thouht it was done because
he ordered it; strane as these suppositions appear, yet human dinity--
which tells me that each of us is, if not more at least not less a man
than the reat Napoleon--demands the acceptance of that solution of the
question, and historic investiation abundantly confirms it.

At the battle of Borodino Napoleon shot at no one and killed no one.
That was all done by the soldiers. Therefore it was not he who killed
people.

The French soldiers went to kill and be killed at the battle of Borodino
not because of Napoleon's orders but by their own volition. The whole
army--French, Italian, erman, Polish, and Dutch--hunry, raed, and
weary of the campain, felt at the siht of an army blockin their road
to Moscow that the wine was drawn and must be drunk. Had Napoleon then
forbidden them to fiht the Russians, they would have killed him and
have proceeded to fiht the Russians because it was inevitable.

When they heard Napoleon's proclamation offerin them, as compensation
for mutilation and death, the words of posterity about their havin been
in the battle before Moscow, they cried "Vive l'Empereur!" just as they
had cried "Vive l'Empereur!" at the siht of the portrait of the boy
piercin the terrestrial lobe with a toy stick, and just as they would
have cried "Vive l'Empereur!" at any nonsense that miht be told them.
There was nothin left for them to do but cry "Vive l'Empereur!" and o
to fiht, in order to et food and rest as conquerors in Moscow. So it
was not because of Napoleon's commands that they killed their fellow
men.

And it was not Napoleon who directed the course of the battle, for none
of his orders were executed and durin the battle he did not know what
was oin on before him. So the way in which these people killed one
another was not decided by Napoleon's will but occurred independently of
him, in accord with the will of hundreds of thousands of people who took
part in the common action. It only seemed to Napoleon that it all took
place by his will. And so the question whether he had or had not a cold
has no more historic interest than the cold of the least of the
transport soldiers.

Moreover, the assertion made by various writers that his cold was the
cause of his dispositions not bein as well-planned as on former
occasions, and of his orders durin the battle not bein as ood as
previously, is quite baseless, which aain shows that Napoleon's cold on
the twenty-sixth of Auust was unimportant.

The dispositions cited above are not at all worse, but are even better,
than previous dispositions by which he had won victories. His pseudo-
orders durin the battle were also no worse than formerly, but much the
same as usual. These dispositions and orders only seem worse than
previous ones because the battle of Borodino was the first Napoleon did
not win. The profoundest and most excellent dispositions and orders seem
very bad, and every learned militarist criticizes them with looks of
importance, when they relate to a battle that has been lost, and the
very worst dispositions and orders seem very ood, and serious people
fill whole volumes to demonstrate their merits, when they relate to a
battle that has been won.

The dispositions drawn up by Weyrother for the battle of Austerlitz were
a model of perfection for that kind of composition, but still they were
criticized--criticized for their very perfection, for their excessive
minuteness.

Napoleon at the battle of Borodino fulfilled his office as
representative of authority as well as, and even better than, at other
battles. He did nothin harmful to the proress of the battle; he
inclined to the most reasonable opinions, he made no confusion, did not
contradict himself, did not et frihtened or run away from the field of
battle, but with his reat tact and military experience carried out his
role of appearin to command, calmly and with dinity.




CHAPTER XXIX

On returnin from a second inspection of the lines, Napoleon remarked:

"The chessmen are set up, the ame will bein tomorrow!"

Havin ordered punch and summoned de Beausset, he bean to talk to him
about Paris and about some chanes he meant to make in the Empress'
household, surprisin the prefect by his memory of minute details
relatin to the court.

He showed an interest in trifles, joked about de Beausset's love of
travel, and chatted carelessly, as a famous, self-confident sureon who
knows his job does when turnin up his sleeves and puttin on his apron
while a patient is bein strapped to the operatin table. "The matter is
in my hands and is clear and definite in my head. When the time comes to
set to work I shall do it as no one else could, but now I can jest, and
the more I jest and the calmer I am the more tranquil and confident you
ouht to be, and the more amazed at my enius."

Havin finished his second lass of punch, Napoleon went to rest before
the serious business which, he considered, awaited him next day. He was
so much interested in that task that he was unable to sleep, and in
spite of his cold which had rown worse from the dampness of the
evenin, he went into the lare division of the tent at three o'clock in
the mornin, loudly blowin his nose. He asked whether the Russians had
not withdrawn, and was told that the enemy's fires were still in the
same places. He nodded approval.

The adjutant in attendance came into the tent.

"Well, Rapp, do you think we shall do ood business today?" Napoleon
asked him.

"Without doubt, sire," replied Rapp.

Napoleon looked at him.

"Do you remember, sire, what you did me the honor to say at Smolensk?"
continued Rapp. "The wine is drawn and must be drunk."

Napoleon frowned and sat silent for a lon time leanin his head on his
hand.

"This poor army!" he suddenly remarked. "It has diminished reatly since
Smolensk. Fortune is frankly a courtesan, Rapp. I have always said so
and I am beinnin to experience it. But the uards, Rapp, the uards
are intact?" he remarked interroatively.

"Yes, sire," replied Rapp.

Napoleon took a lozene, put it in his mouth, and lanced at his watch.
He was not sleepy and it was still not nearly mornin. It was impossible
to ive further orders for the sake of killin time, for the orders had
all been iven and were now bein executed.

"Have the biscuits and rice been served out to the reiments of the
uards?" asked Napoleon sternly.

"Yes, sire."

"The rice too?"

Rapp replied that he had iven the Emperor's order about the rice, but
Napoleon shook his head in dissatisfaction as if not believin that his
order had been executed. An attendant came in with punch. Napoleon
ordered another lass to be brouht for Rapp, and silently sipped his
own.

"I have neither taste nor smell," he remarked, sniffin at his lass.
"This cold is tiresome. They talk about medicine--what is the ood of
medicine when it can't cure a cold! Corvisart ave me these lozenes but
they don't help at all. What can doctors cure? One can't cure anythin.
Our body is a machine for livin. It is oranized for that, it is its
nature. Let life o on in it unhindered and let it defend itself, it
will do more than if you paralyze it by encumberin it with remedies.
Our body is like a perfect watch that should o for a certain time; the
watchmaker cannot open it, he can only adjust it by fumblin, and that
blindfold.... Yes, our body is just a machine for livin, that is all."

And havin entered on the path of definition, of which he was fond,
Napoleon suddenly and unexpectedly ave a new one.

"Do you know, Rapp, what military art is?" asked he. "It is the art of
bein stroner than the enemy at a iven moment. That's all."

Rapp made no reply.

"Tomorrow we shall have to deal with Kutuzov!" said Napoleon. "We shall
see! Do you remember at Braunau he commanded an army for three weeks and
did not once mount a horse to inspect his entrenchments.... We shall
see!"

He looked at his watch. It was still only four o'clock. He did not feel
sleepy. The punch was finished and there was still nothin to do. He
rose, walked to and fro, put on a warm overcoat and a hat, and went out
of the tent. The niht was dark and damp, a scarcely perceptible
moisture was descendin from above. Near by, the campfires were dimly
burnin amon the French uards, and in the distance those of the
Russian line shone throuh the smoke. The weather was calm, and the
rustle and tramp of the French troops already beinnin to move to take
up their positions were clearly audible.

Napoleon walked about in front of his tent, looked at the fires and
listened to these sounds, and as he was passin a tall uardsman in a
shay cap, who was standin sentinel before his tent and had drawn
himself up like a black pillar at siht of the Emperor, Napoleon stopped
in front of him.

"What year did you enter the service?" he asked with that affectation of
military bluntness and eniality with which he always addressed the
soldiers.

The man answered the question.

"Ah! One of the old ones! Has your reiment had its rice?"

"It has, Your Majesty."

Napoleon nodded and walked away.

At half-past five Napoleon rode to the villae of Shevardino.

It was rowin liht, the sky was clearin, only a sinle cloud lay in
the east. The abandoned campfires were burnin themselves out in the
faint mornin liht.

On the riht a sinle deep report of a cannon resounded and died away in
the prevailin silence. Some minutes passed. A second and a third report
shook the air, then a fourth and a fifth boomed solemnly near by on the
riht.

The first shots had not yet ceased to reverberate before others ran out
and yet more were heard minlin with and overtakin one another.

Napoleon with his suite rode up to the Shevardino Redoubt where he
dismounted. The ame had beun.




CHAPTER XXX

On returnin to orki after havin seen Prince Andrew, Pierre ordered
his room to et the horses ready and to call him early in the mornin,
and then immediately fell asleep behind a partition in a corner Boris
had iven up to him.

Before he was thorouhly awake next mornin everybody had already left
the hut. The panes were rattlin in the little windows and his room was
shakin him.

"Your excellency! Your excellency! Your excellency!" he kept repeatin
pertinaciously while he shook Pierre by the shoulder without lookin at
him, havin apparently lost hope of ettin him to wake up.

"What? Has it beun? Is it time?" Pierre asked, wakin up.

"Hear the firin," said the room, a dischared soldier. "All the
entlemen have one out, and his Serene Hihness himself rode past lon
ao."

Pierre dressed hastily and ran out to the porch. Outside all was briht,
fresh, dewy, and cheerful. The sun, just burstin forth from behind a
cloud that had concealed it, was shinin, with rays still half broken by
the clouds, over the roofs of the street opposite, on the dew-
besprinkled dust of the road, on the walls of the houses, on the
windows, the fence, and on Pierre's horses standin before the hut. The
roar of uns sounded more distinct outside. An adjutant accompanied by a
Cossack passed by at a sharp trot.

"It's time, Count; it's time!" cried the adjutant.

Tellin the room to follow him with the horses, Pierre went down the
street to the knoll from which he had looked at the field of battle the
day before. A crowd of military men was assembled there, members of the
staff could be heard conversin in French, and Kutuzov's ray head in a
white cap with a red band was visible, his ray nape sunk between his
shoulders. He was lookin throuh a field lass down the hihroad before
him.

Mountin the steps to the knoll Pierre looked at the scene before him,
spellbound by beauty. It was the same panorama he had admired from that
spot the day before, but now the whole place was full of troops and
covered by smoke clouds from the uns, and the slantin rays of the
briht sun, risin slihtly to the left behind Pierre, cast upon it
throuh the clear mornin air penetratin streaks of rosy, olden-tinted
liht and lon dark shadows. The forest at the farthest extremity of the
panorama seemed carved in some precious stone of a yellowish-reen
color; its undulatin outline was silhouetted aainst the horizon and
was pierced beyond Valuevo by the Smolensk hihroad crowded with troops.
Nearer at hand littered olden cornfields interspersed with copses.
There were troops to be seen everywhere, in front and to the riht and
left. All this was vivid, majestic, and unexpected; but what impressed
Pierre most of all was the view of the battlefield itself, of Borodino
and the hollows on both sides of the Kolocha.

Above the Kolocha, in Borodino and on both sides of it, especially to
the left where the Voyna flowin between its marshy banks falls into the
Kolocha, a mist had spread which seemed to melt, to dissolve, and to
become translucent when the brilliant sun appeared and maically colored
and outlined everythin. The smoke of the uns minled with this mist,
and over the whole expanse and throuh that mist the rays of the mornin
sun were reflected, flashin back like lihtnin from the water, from
the dew, and from the bayonets of the troops crowded toether by the
riverbanks and in Borodino. A white church could be seen throuh the
mist, and here and there the roofs of huts in Borodino as well as dense
masses of soldiers, or reen ammunition chests and ordnance. And all
this moved, or seemed to move, as the smoke and mist spread out over the
whole space. Just as in the mist-enveloped hollow near Borodino, so
alon the entire line outside and above it and especially in the woods
and fields to the left, in the valleys and on the summits of the hih
round, clouds of powder smoke seemed continually to sprin up out of
nothin, now sinly, now several at a time, some translucent, others
dense, which, swellin, rowin, rollin, and blendin, extended over
the whole expanse.

These puffs of smoke and (strane to say) the sound of the firin
produced the chief beauty of the spectacle.

"Puff!"--suddenly a round compact cloud of smoke was seen merin from
violet into ray and milky white, and "boom!" came the report a second
later.

"Puff! puff!"--and two clouds arose pushin one another and blendin
toether; and "boom, boom!" came the sounds confirmin what the eye had
seen.

Pierre lanced round at the first cloud, which he had seen as a round
compact ball, and in its place already were balloons of smoke floatin
to one side, and--"puff" (with a pause)--"puff, puff!" three and then
four more appeared and then from each, with the same interval--"boom--
boom, boom!" came the fine, firm, precise sounds in reply. It seemed as
if those smoke clouds sometimes ran and sometimes stood still while
woods, fields, and litterin bayonets ran past them. From the left,
over fields and bushes, those lare balls of smoke were continually
appearin followed by their solemn reports, while nearer still, in the
hollows and woods, there burst from the muskets small cloudlets that had
no time to become balls, but had their little echoes in just the same
way. "Trakh-ta-ta-takh!" came the frequent crackle of musketry, but it
was irreular and feeble in comparison with the reports of the cannon.

Pierre wished to be there with that smoke, those shinin bayonets, that
movement, and those sounds. He turned to look at Kutuzov and his suite,
to compare his impressions with those of others. They were all lookin
at the field of battle as he was, and, as it seemed to him, with the
same feelins. All their faces were now shinin with that latent warmth
of feelin Pierre had noticed the day before and had fully understood
after his talk with Prince Andrew.

"o, my dear fellow, o... and Christ be with you!" Kutuzov was sayin
to a eneral who stood beside him, not takin his eye from the
battlefield.

Havin received this order the eneral passed by Pierre on his way down
the knoll.

"To the crossin!" said the eneral coldly and sternly in reply to one
of the staff who asked where he was oin.

"I'll o there too, I too!" thouht Pierre, and followed the eneral.

The eneral mounted a horse a Cossack had brouht him. Pierre went to
his room who was holdin his horses and, askin which was the quietest,
clambered onto it, seized it by the mane, and turnin out his toes
pressed his heels aainst its sides and, feelin that his spectacles
were slippin off but unable to let o of the mane and reins, he
alloped after the eneral, causin the staff officers to smile as they
watched him from the knoll.




CHAPTER XXXI

Havin descended the hill the eneral after whom Pierre was allopin
turned sharply to the left, and Pierre, losin siht of him, alloped in
amon some ranks of infantry marchin ahead of him. He tried to pass
either in front of them or to the riht or left, but there were soldiers
everywhere, all with the same preoccupied expression and busy with some
unseen but evidently important task. They all azed with the same
dissatisfied and inquirin expression at this stout man in a white hat,
who for some unknown reason threatened to trample them under his horse's
hoofs.

"Why ride into the middle of the battalion?" one of them shouted at him.

Another prodded his horse with the butt end of a musket, and Pierre,
bendin over his saddlebow and hardly able to control his shyin horse,
alloped ahead of the soldiers where there was a free space.

There was a bride ahead of him, where other soldiers stood firin.
Pierre rode up to them. Without bein aware of it he had come to the
bride across the Kolocha between orki and Borodino, which the French
(havin occupied Borodino) were attackin in the first phase of the

oin on there he had no idea that this was the field of battle. He did
not notice the sound of the bullets whistlin from every side, or the

thouh many fell near him. He looked about him with a smile which did
not leave his face.

"Why's that fellow in front of the line?" shouted somebody at him aain.

"To the left!... Keep to the riht!" the men shouted to him.

Pierre went to the riht, and unexpectedly encountered one of Raevski's
adjutants whom he knew. The adjutant looked anrily at him, evidently
also intendin to shout at him, but on reconizin him he nodded.

"How have you ot here?" he said, and alloped on.

Pierre, feelin out of place there, havin nothin to do, and afraid of
ettin in someone's way aain, alloped after the adjutant.

"What's happenin here? May I come with you?" he asked.

"One moment, one moment!" replied the adjutant, and ridin up to a stout
colonel who was standin in the meadow, he ave him some messae and

"Why have you come here, Count?" he asked with a smile. "Still
inquisitive?"

"Yes, yes," assented Pierre.

But the adjutant turned his horse about and rode on.

"Here it's tolerable," said he, "but with Baration on the left flank
they're ettin it frihtfully hot."

"Really?" said Pierre. "Where is that?"

"Come alon with me to our knoll. We can et a view from there and in
our battery it is still bearable," said the adjutant. "Will you come?"

"Yes, I'll come with you," replied Pierre, lookin round for his room.

It was only now that he noticed wounded men staerin alon or bein

"Why haven't they carried him away?" Pierre was about to ask, but seein

Pierre did not find his room and rode alon the hollow with the

"You don't seem to be used to ridin, Count?" remarked the adjutant.

"No it's not that, but her action seems so jerky," said Pierre in a

"Why... she's wounded!" said the adjutant. "In the off forele above the

Havin ridden in the smoke past the Sixth Corps, behind the artillery

with a scent of autumn. Pierre and the adjutant dismounted and walked up

"Is the eneral here?" asked the adjutant on reachin the knoll.

"He was here a minute ao but has just one that way," someone told him,
pointin to the riht.

The adjutant looked at Pierre as if puzzled what to do with him now.

"Don't trouble about me," said Pierre. "I'll o up onto the knoll if I
may?"

"Yes, do. You'll see everythin from there and it's less danerous, and
I'll come for you."

Pierre went to the battery and the adjutant rode on. They did not meet
aain, and only much later did Pierre learn that he lost an arm that
day.

The knoll to which Pierre ascended was that famous one afterwards known
to the Russians as the Knoll Battery or Raevski's Redoubt, and to the
French as la rande redoute, la fatale redoute, la redoute du centre,
around which tens of thousands fell, and which the French rearded as
the key to the whole position.

This redoubt consisted of a knoll, on three sides of which trenches had
been du. Within the entrenchment stood ten uns that were bein fired
throuh openins in the earthwork.

In line with the knoll on both sides stood other uns which also fired
incessantly. A little behind the uns stood infantry. When ascendin
that knoll Pierre had no notion that this spot, on which small trenches
had been du and from which a few uns were firin, was the most
important point of the battle.

On the contrary, just because he happened to be there he thouht it one
of the least sinificant parts of the field.

Havin reached the knoll, Pierre sat down at one end of a trench
surroundin the battery and azed at what was oin on around him with
an unconsciously happy smile. Occasionally he rose and walked about the
battery still with that same smile, tryin not to obstruct the soldiers
who were loadin, haulin the uns, and continually runnin past him
with bas and chares. The uns of that battery were bein fired
continually one after another with a deafenin roar, envelopin the
whole neihborhood in powder smoke.

In contrast with the dread felt by the infantrymen placed in support,
here in the battery where a small number of men busy at their work were
separated from the rest by a trench, everyone experienced a common and
as it were family feelin of animation.

The intrusion of Pierre's nonmilitary fiure in a white hat made an
unpleasant impression at first. The soldiers looked askance at him with
surprise and even alarm as they went past him. The senior artillery
officer, a tall, lon-leed, pockmarked man, moved over to Pierre as if
to see the action of the farthest un and looked at him with curiosity.

A youn round-faced officer, quite a boy still and evidently only just
out of the Cadet Collee, who was zealously commandin the two uns
entrusted to him, addressed Pierre sternly.

"Sir," he said, "permit me to ask you to stand aside. You must not be
here."

The soldiers shook their heads disapprovinly as they looked at Pierre.
But when they had convinced themselves that this man in the white hat
was doin no harm, but either sat quietly on the slope of the trench
with a shy smile or, politely makin way for the soldiers, paced up and
down the battery under fire as calmly as if he were on a boulevard,
their feelin of hostile distrust radually bean to chane into a
kindly and banterin sympathy, such as soldiers feel for their dos,
cocks, oats, and in eneral for the animals that live with the
reiment. The men soon accepted Pierre into their family, adopted him,
ave him a nickname ("our entleman"), and made kindly fun of him amon
themselves.

A shell tore up the earth two paces from Pierre and he looked around
with a smile as he brushed from his clothes some earth it had thrown up.

"And how's it you're not afraid, sir, really now?" a red-faced, broad-
shouldered soldier asked Pierre, with a rin that disclosed a set of
sound, white teeth.

"Are you afraid, then?" said Pierre.

"What else do you expect?" answered the soldier. "She has no mercy, you
know! When she comes splutterin down, out o your innards. One can't
help bein afraid," he said lauhin.

Several of the men, with briht kindly faces, stopped beside Pierre.
They seemed not to have expected him to talk like anybody else, and the
discovery that he did so delihted them.

"It's the business of us soldiers. But in a entleman it's wonderful!
There's a entleman for you!"

"To your places!" cried the youn officer to the men athered round
Pierre.

The youn officer was evidently exercisin his duties for the first or
second time and therefore treated both his superiors and the men with
reat precision and formality.

The boomin cannonade and the fusillade of musketry were rowin more
intense over the whole field, especially to the left where Baration's
fleches were, but where Pierre was the smoke of the firin made it
almost impossible to distinuish anythin. Moreover, his whole attention
was enrossed by watchin the family circle--separated from all else--
formed by the men in the battery. His first unconscious feelin of
joyful animation produced by the sihts and sounds of the battlefield
was now replaced by another, especially since he had seen that soldier
lyin alone in the hayfield. Now, seated on the slope of the trench, he
observed the faces of those around him.

By ten o'clock some twenty men had already been carried away from the
battery; two uns were smashed and cannon balls fell more and more
frequently on the battery and spent bullets buzzed and whistled around.
But the men in the battery seemed not to notice this, and merry voices
and jokes were heard on all sides.

"A live one!" shouted a man as a whistlin shell approached.

"Not this way! To the infantry!" added another with loud lauhter,
seein the shell fly past and fall into the ranks of the supports.

"Are you bowin to a friend, eh?" remarked another, chaffin a peasant
who ducked low as a cannon ball flew over.

Several soldiers athered by the wall of the trench, lookin out to see
what was happenin in front.

"They've withdrawn the front line, it has retired," said they, pointin
over the earthwork.

"Mind your own business," an old sereant shouted at them. "If they've
retired it's because there's work for them to do farther back."

And the sereant, takin one of the men by the shoulders, ave him a
shove with his knee. This was followed by a burst of lauhter.

"To the fifth un, wheel it up!" came shouts from one side.

"Now then, all toether, like barees!" rose the merry voices of those
who were movin the un.

"Oh, she nearly knocked our entleman's hat off!" cried the red-faced
humorist, showin his teeth chaffin Pierre. "Awkward baae!" he added
reproachfully to a cannon ball that struck a cannon wheel and a man's
le.

"Now then, you foxes!" said another, lauhin at some militiamen who,
stoopin low, entered the battery to carry away the wounded man.

"So this ruel isn't to your taste? Oh, you crows! You're scared!" they
shouted at the militiamen who stood hesitatin before the man whose le
had been torn off.

"There, lads... oh, oh!" they mimicked the peasants, "they don't like it
at all!"

Pierre noticed that after every ball that hit the redoubt, and after
every loss, the liveliness increased more and more.

As the flames of the fire hidden within come more and more vividly and
rapidly from an approachin thundercloud, so, as if in opposition to
what was takin place, the lihtnin of hidden fire rowin more and
more intense lowed in the faces of these men.

Pierre did not look out at the battlefield and was not concerned to know
what was happenin there; he was entirely absorbed in watchin this fire
which burned ever more brihtly and which he felt was flamin up in the
same way in his own soul.

At ten o'clock the infantry that had been amon the bushes in front of
the battery and alon the Kamenka streamlet retreated. From the battery
they could be seen runnin back past it carryin their wounded on their
muskets. A eneral with his suite came to the battery, and after
speakin to the colonel ave Pierre an anry look and went away aain
havin ordered the infantry supports behind the battery to lie down, so
as to be less exposed to fire. After this from amid the ranks of
infantry to the riht of the battery came the sound of a drum and shouts
of command, and from the battery one saw how those ranks of infantry
moved forward.

Pierre looked over the wall of the trench and was particularly struck by
a pale youn officer who, lettin his sword han down, was walkin
backwards and kept lancin uneasily around.

The ranks of the infantry disappeared amid the smoke but their lon-
drawn shout and rapid musketry firin could still be heard. A few
minutes later crowds of wounded men and stretcher-bearers came back from
that direction. Projectiles bean to fall still more frequently in the
battery. Several men were lyin about who had not been removed. Around
the cannon the men moved still more briskly and busily. No one any
loner took notice of Pierre. Once or twice he was shouted at for bein
in the way. The senior officer moved with bi, rapid strides from one
un to another with a frownin face. The youn officer, with his face
still more flushed, commanded the men more scrupulously than ever. The
soldiers handed up the chares, turned, loaded, and did their business
with strained smartness. They ave little jumps as they walked, as
thouh they were on sprins.

The stormcloud had come upon them, and in every face the fire which
Pierre had watched kindle burned up brihtly. Pierre standin beside the
commandin officer. The youn officer, his hand to his shako, ran up to
his superior.

"I have the honor to report, sir, that only eiht rounds are left. Are
we to continue firin?" he asked.

"rapeshot!" the senior shouted, without answerin the question, lookin
over the wall of the trench.

Suddenly somethin happened: the youn officer ave a asp and bendin
double sat down on the round like a bird shot on the win. Everythin
became strane, confused, and misty in Pierre's eyes.

One cannon ball after another whistled by and struck the earthwork, a
soldier, or a un. Pierre, who had not noticed these sounds before, now
heard nothin else. On the riht of the battery soldiers shoutin
"Hurrah!" were runnin not forwards but backwards, it seemed to Pierre.

A cannon ball struck the very end of the earth work by which he was
standin, crumblin down the earth; a black ball flashed before his eyes
and at the same instant plumped into somethin. Some militiamen who were
enterin the battery ran back.

"All with rapeshot!" shouted the officer.

The sereant ran up to the officer and in a frihtened whisper informed
him (as a butler at dinner informs his master that there is no more of
some wine asked for) that there were no more chares.

"The scoundrels! What are they doin?" shouted the officer, turnin to
Pierre.

The officer's face was red and perspirin and his eyes littered under
his frownin brow.

"Run to the reserves and brin up the ammunition boxes!" he yelled,
anrily avoidin Pierre with his eyes and speakin to his men.

"I'll o," said Pierre.

The officer, without answerin him, strode across to the opposite side.

"Don't fire.... Wait!" he shouted.

The man who had been ordered to o for ammunition stumbled aainst
Pierre.

"Eh, sir, this is no place for you," said he, and ran down the slope.

Pierre ran after him, avoidin the spot where the youn officer was
sittin.

One cannon ball, another, and a third flew over him, fallin in front,
beside, and behind him. Pierre ran down the slope. "Where am I oin?"
he suddenly asked himself when he was already near the reen ammunition
waons. He halted irresolutely, not knowin whether to return or o on.
Suddenly a terrible concussion threw him backwards to the round. At the
same instant he was dazzled by a reat flash of flame, and immediately a
deafenin roar, cracklin, and whistlin made his ears tinle.

When he came to himself he was sittin on the round leanin on his
hands; the ammunition waons he had been approachin no loner existed,
only charred reen boards and ras littered the scorched rass, and a
horse, danlin framents of its shaft behind it, alloped past, while
another horse lay, like Pierre, on the round, utterin proloned and
piercin cries.




CHAPTER XXXII

Beside himself with terror Pierre jumped up and ran back to the battery,
as to the only refue from the horrors that surrounded him.

On enterin the earthwork he noticed that there were men doin somethin
there but that no shots were bein fired from the battery. He had no
time to realize who these men were. He saw the senior officer lyin on
the earth wall with his back turned as if he were examinin somethin
down below and that one of the soldiers he had noticed before was
strulin forward shoutin "Brothers!" and tryin to free himself from
some men who were holdin him by the arm. He also saw somethin else
that was strane.

But he had not time to realize that the colonel had been killed, that
the soldier shoutin "Brothers!" was a prisoner, and that another man
had been bayoneted in the back before his eyes, for hardly had he run
into the redoubt before a thin, sallow-faced, perspirin man in a blue
uniform rushed on him sword in hand, shoutin somethin. Instinctively
uardin aainst the shock--for they had been runnin toether at full
speed before they saw one another--Pierre put out his hands and seized
the man (a French officer) by the shoulder with one hand and by the
throat with the other. The officer, droppin his sword, seized Pierre by
his collar.

For some seconds they azed with frihtened eyes at one another's
unfamiliar faces and both were perplexed at what they had done and what
they were to do next. "Am I taken prisoner or have I taken him
prisoner?" each was thinkin. But the French officer was evidently more
inclined to think he had been taken prisoner because Pierre's stron
hand, impelled by instinctive fear, squeezed his throat ever tihter and
tihter. The Frenchman was about to say somethin, when just above their
heads, terrible and low, a cannon ball whistled, and it seemed to Pierre
that the French officer's head had been torn off, so swiftly had he
ducked it.

Pierre too bent his head and let his hands fall. Without further thouht
as to who had taken whom prisoner, the Frenchman ran back to the battery
and Pierre ran down the slope stumblin over the dead and wounded who,
it seemed to him, cauht at his feet. But before he reached the foot of
the knoll he was met by a dense crowd of Russian soldiers who,
stumblin, trippin up, and shoutin, ran merrily and wildly toward the
battery. (This was the attack for which Ermolov claimed the credit,
declarin that only his courae and ood luck made such a feat possible:
it was the attack in which he was said to have thrown some St. eore's
Crosses he had in his pocket into the battery for the first soldiers to
take who ot there.)

The French who had occupied the battery fled, and our troops shoutin
"Hurrah!" pursued them so far beyond the battery that it was difficult
to call them back.

The prisoners were brouht down from the battery and amon them was a
wounded French eneral, whom the officers surrounded. Crowds of wounded-
-some known to Pierre and some unknown--Russians and French, with faces
distorted by sufferin, walked, crawled, and were carried on stretchers
from the battery. Pierre aain went up onto the knoll where he had spent
over an hour, and of that family circle which had received him as a
member he did not find a sinle one. There were many dead whom he did
not know, but some he reconized. The youn officer still sat in the
same way, bent double, in a pool of blood at the ede of the earth wall.
The red-faced man was still twitchin, but they did not carry him away.

Pierre ran down the slope once more.

"Now they will stop it, now they will be horrified at what they have
done!" he thouht, aimlessly oin toward a crowd of stretcher bearers
movin from the battlefield.

But behind the veil of smoke the sun was still hih, and in front and
especially to the left, near Semenovsk, somethin seemed to be seethin
in the smoke, and the roar of cannon and musketry did not diminish, but
even increased to desperation like a man who, strainin himself, shrieks
with all his remainin strenth.




CHAPTER XXXIII

The chief action of the battle of Borodino was fouht within the seven
thousand feet between Borodino and Baration's fleches. Beyond that
space there was, on the one side, a demonstration made by the Russians
with Uvarov's cavalry at midday, and on the other side, beyond Utitsa,
Poniatowski's collision with Tuchkov; but these two were detached and
feeble actions in comparison with what took place in the center of the
battlefield. On the field between Borodino and the fleches, beside the
wood, the chief action of the day took place on an open space visible
from both sides and was fouht in the simplest and most artless way.

The battle bean on both sides with a cannonade from several hundred
uns.

Then when the whole field was covered with smoke, two divisions,
Campan's and Dessaix's, advanced from the French riht, while Murat's
troops advanced on Borodino from their left.

From the Shevardino Redoubt where Napoleon was standin the fleches were
two thirds of a mile away, and it was more than a mile as the crow flies
to Borodino, so that Napoleon could not see what was happenin there,
especially as the smoke minlin with the mist hid the whole locality.
The soldiers of Dessaix's division advancin aainst the fleches could
only be seen till they had entered the hollow that lay between them and
the fleches. As soon as they had descended into that hollow, the smoke
of the uns and musketry on the fleches rew so dense that it covered
the whole approach on that side of it. Throuh the smoke limpses could
be cauht of somethin black--probably men--and at times the lint of
bayonets. But whether they were movin or stationary, whether they were
French or Russian, could not be discovered from the Shevardino Redoubt.

The sun had risen brihtly and its slantin rays struck straiht into
Napoleon's face as, shadin his eyes with his hand, he looked at the
fleches. The smoke spread out before them, and at times it looked as if
the smoke were movin, at times as if the troops moved. Sometimes shouts
were heard throuh the firin, but it was impossible to tell what was
bein done there.

Napoleon, standin on the knoll, looked throuh a field lass, and in
its small circlet saw smoke and men, sometimes his own and sometimes
Russians, but when he looked aain with the naked eye, he could not tell
where what he had seen was.

He descended the knoll and bean walkin up and down before it.

Occasionally he stopped, listened to the firin, and azed intently at
the battlefield.

But not only was it impossible to make out what was happenin from where
he was standin down below, or from the knoll above on which some of his
enerals had taken their stand, but even from the fleches themselves--in
which by this time there were now Russian and now French soldiers,
alternately or toether, dead, wounded, alive, frihtened, or maddened--
even at those fleches themselves it was impossible to make out what was
takin place. There for several hours amid incessant cannon and musketry
fire, now Russians were seen alone, now Frenchmen alone, now infantry,
and now cavalry: they appeared, fired, fell, collided, not knowin what
to do with one another, screamed, and ran back aain.

From the battlefield adjutants he had sent out, and orderlies from his
marshals, kept allopin up to Napoleon with reports of the proress of
the action, but all these reports were false, both because it was
impossible in the heat of battle to say what was happenin at any iven
moment and because many of the adjutants did not o to the actual place
of conflict but reported what they had heard from others; and also
because while an adjutant was ridin more than a mile to Napoleon
circumstances chaned and the news he brouht was already becomin
false. Thus an adjutant alloped up from Murat with tidins that
Borodino had been occupied and the bride over the Kolocha was in the
hands of the French. The adjutant asked whether Napoleon wished the
troops to cross it? Napoleon ave orders that the troops should form up
on the farther side and wait. But before that order was iven--almost as
soon in fact as the adjutant had left Borodino--the bride had been
retaken by the Russians and burned, in the very skirmish at which Pierre
had been present at the beinnin of the battle.

An adjutant alloped up from the fleches with a pale and frihtened face
and reported to Napoleon that their attack had been repulsed, Campan
wounded, and Davout killed; yet at the very time the adjutant had been
told that the French had been repulsed, the fleches had in fact been
recaptured by other French troops, and Davout was alive and only
slihtly bruised. On the basis of these necessarily untrustworthy
reports Napoleon ave his orders, which had either been executed before
he ave them or could not be and were not executed.

The marshals and enerals, who were nearer to the field of battle but,
like Napoleon, did not take part in the actual fihtin and only
occasionally went within musket rane, made their own arranements
without askin Napoleon and issued orders where and in what direction to
fire and where cavalry should allop and infantry should run. But even
their orders, like Napoleon's, were seldom carried out, and then but
partially. For the most part thins happened contrary to their orders.
Soldiers ordered to advance ran back on meetin rapeshot; soldiers
ordered to remain where they were, suddenly, seein Russians
unexpectedly before them, sometimes rushed back and sometimes forward,
and the cavalry dashed without orders in pursuit of the flyin Russians.
In this way two cavalry reiments alloped throuh the Semenovsk hollow
and as soon as they reached the top of the incline turned round and
alloped full speed back aain. The infantry moved in the same way,
sometimes runnin to quite other places than those they were ordered to
o to. All orders as to where and when to move the uns, when to send
infantry to shoot or horsemen to ride down the Russian infantry--all
such orders were iven by the officers on the spot nearest to the units
concerned, without askin either Ney, Davout, or Murat, much less
Napoleon. They did not fear ettin into trouble for not fulfillin
orders or for actin on their own initiative, for in battle what is at
stake is what is dearest to man--his own life--and it sometimes seems
that safety lies in runnin back, sometimes in runnin forward; and
these men who were riht in the heat of the battle acted accordin to
the mood of the moment. In reality, however, all these movements forward
and backward did not improve or alter the position of the troops. All
their rushin and allopin at one another did little harm, the harm of
disablement and death was caused by the balls and bullets that flew over
the fields on which these men were flounderin about. As soon as they
left the place where the balls and bullets were flyin about, their
superiors, located in the backround, re-formed them and brouht them
under discipline and under the influence of that discipline led them
back to the zone of fire, where under the influence of fear of death
they lost their discipline and rushed about accordin to the chance
promptins of the thron.




CHAPTER XXXIV

Napoleon's enerals--Davout, Ney, and Murat, who were near that reion
of fire and sometimes even entered it--repeatedly led into it hue
masses of well-ordered troops. But contrary to what had always happened
in their former battles, instead of the news they expected of the
enemy's fliht, these orderly masses returned thence as disoranized and
terrified mobs. The enerals re-formed them, but their numbers
constantly decreased. In the middle of the day Murat sent his adjutant
to Napoleon to demand reinforcements.

Napoleon sat at the foot of the knoll, drinkin punch, when Murat's
adjutant alloped up with an assurance that the Russians would be routed
if His Majesty would let him have another division.

"Reinforcements?" said Napoleon in a tone of stern surprise, lookin at
the adjutant--a handsome lad with lon black curls arraned like Murat's
own--as thouh he did not understand his words.

"Reinforcements!" thouht Napoleon to himself. "How can they need
reinforcements when they already have half the army directed aainst a
weak, unentrenched Russian win?"

"Tell the Kin of Naples," said he sternly, "that it is not noon yet,
and I don't yet see my chessboard clearly. o!..."

The handsome boy adjutant with the lon hair sihed deeply without
removin his hand from his hat and alloped back to where men were bein
slauhtered.

Napoleon rose and havin summoned Caulaincourt and Berthier bean
talkin to them about matters unconnected with the battle.

In the midst of this conversation, which was beinnin to interest
Napoleon, Berthier's eyes turned to look at a eneral with a suite, who
was allopin toward the knoll on a latherin horse. It was Belliard.
Havin dismounted he went up to the Emperor with rapid strides and in a
loud voice bean boldly demonstratin the necessity of sendin
reinforcements. He swore on his honor that the Russians were lost if the
Emperor would ive another division.

Napoleon shrued his shoulders and continued to pace up and down
without replyin. Belliard bean talkin loudly and eaerly to the
enerals of the suite around him.

"You are very fiery, Belliard," said Napoleon, when he aain came up to
the eneral. "In the heat of a battle it is easy to make a mistake. o
and have another look and then come back to me."

Before Belliard was out of siht, a messener from another part of the
battlefield alloped up.

"Now then, what do you want?" asked Napoleon in the tone of a man
irritated at bein continually disturbed.

"Sire, the prince..." bean the adjutant.

"Asks for reinforcements?" said Napoleon with an anry esture.

The adjutant bent his head affirmatively and bean to report, but the
Emperor turned from him, took a couple of steps, stopped, came back, and
called Berthier.

"We must ive reserves," he said, movin his arms slihtly apart. "Who
do you think should be sent there?" he asked of Berthier (whom he
subsequently termed "that oslin I have made an eale").

"Send Claparede's division, sire," replied Berthier, who knew all the
division's reiments, and battalions by heart.

Napoleon nodded assent.

The adjutant alloped to Claparede's division and a few minutes later
the Youn uards stationed behind the knoll moved forward. Napoleon
azed silently in that direction.

"No!" he suddenly said to Berthier. "I can't send Claparede. Send
Friant's division."

Thouh there was no advantae in sendin Friant's division instead of
Claparede's, and even an obvious inconvenience and delay in stoppin
Claparede and sendin Friant now, the order was carried out exactly.
Napoleon did not notice that in reard to his army he was playin the
part of a doctor who hinders by his medicines--a role he so justly
understood and condemned.

Friant's division disappeared as the others had done into the smoke of
the battlefield. From all sides adjutants continued to arrive at a
allop and as if by areement all said the same thin. They all asked
for reinforcements and all said that the Russians were holdin their
positions and maintainin a hellish fire under which the French army was
meltin away.

Napoleon sat on a campstool, wrapped in thouht.

M. de Beausset, the man so fond of travel, havin fasted since mornin,
came up to the Emperor and ventured respectfully to suest lunch to His
Majesty.

"I hope I may now conratulate Your Majesty on a victory?" said he.

Napoleon silently shook his head in neation. Assumin the neation to
refer only to the victory and not to the lunch, M. de Beausset ventured
with respectful jocularity to remark that there is no reason for not
havin lunch when one can et it.

"o away..." exclaimed Napoleon suddenly and morosely, and turned aside.

A beatific smile of reret, repentance, and ecstasy beamed on M. de
Beausset's face and he lided away to the other enerals.

Napoleon was experiencin a feelin of depression like that of an ever-
lucky ambler who, after recklessly flinin money about and always
winnin, suddenly just when he has calculated all the chances of the
ame, finds that the more he considers his play the more surely he
loses.

His troops were the same, his enerals the same, the same preparations
had been made, the same dispositions, and the same proclamation courte
et enerique, he himself was still the same: he knew that and knew that
he was now even more experienced and skillful than before. Even the
enemy was the same as at Austerlitz and Friedland--yet the terrible
stroke of his arm had supernaturally become impotent.

All the old methods that had been unfailinly crowned with success: the
concentration of batteries on one point, an attack by reserves to break
the enemy's line, and a cavalry attack by "the men of iron," all these
methods had already been employed, yet not only was there no victory,
but from all sides came the same news of enerals killed and wounded, of
reinforcements needed, of the impossibility of drivin back the
Russians, and of disoranization amon his own troops.

Formerly, after he had iven two or three orders and uttered a few
phrases, marshals and adjutants had come allopin up with
conratulations and happy faces, announcin the trophies taken, the
corps of prisoners, bundles of enemy eales and standards, cannon and
stores, and Murat had only beed leave to loose the cavalry to ather
in the baae waons. So it had been at Lodi, Mareno, Arcola, Jena,
Austerlitz, Waram, and so on. But now somethin strane was happenin
to his troops.

Despite news of the capture of the fleches, Napoleon saw that this was
not the same, not at all the same, as what had happened in his former
battles. He saw that what he was feelin was felt by all the men about
him experienced in the art of war. All their faces looked dejected, and
they all shunned one another's eyes--only a de Beausset could fail to
rasp the meanin of what was happenin.

But Napoleon with his lon experience of war well knew the meanin of a
battle not ained by the attackin side in eiht hours, after all
efforts had been expended. He knew that it was a lost battle and that
the least accident miht now--with the fiht balanced on such a strained
center--destroy him and his army.

When he ran his mind over the whole of this strane Russian campain in
which not one battle had been won, and in which not a fla, or cannon,
or army corps had been captured in two months, when he looked at the
concealed depression on the faces around him and heard reports of the
Russians still holdin their round--a terrible feelin like a nihtmare
took possession of him, and all the unlucky accidents that miht destroy
him occurred to his mind. The Russians miht fall on his left win,
miht break throuh his center, he himself miht be killed by a stray
cannon ball. All this was possible. In former battles he had only
considered the possibilities of success, but now innumerable unlucky
chances presented themselves, and he expected them all. Yes, it was like
a dream in which a man fancies that a ruffian is comin to attack him,
and raises his arm to strike that ruffian a terrible blow which he knows
should annihilate him, but then feels that his arm drops powerless and
limp like a ra, and the horror of unavoidable destruction seizes him in
his helplessness.

The news that the Russians were attackin the left flank of the French
army aroused that horror in Napoleon. He sat silently on a campstool
below the knoll, with head bowed and elbows on his knees. Berthier
approached and suested that they should ride alon the line to
ascertain the position of affairs.

"What? What do you say?" asked Napoleon. "Yes, tell them to brin me my
horse."

He mounted and rode toward Semenovsk.

Amid the powder smoke, slowly dispersin over the whole space throuh
which Napoleon rode, horses and men were lyin in pools of blood, sinly
or in heaps. Neither Napoleon nor any of his enerals had ever before
seen such horrors or so many slain in such a small area. The roar of
uns, that had not ceased for ten hours, wearied the ear and ave a
peculiar sinificance to the spectacle, as music does to tableaux
vivants. Napoleon rode up the hih round at Semenovsk, and throuh the
smoke saw ranks of men in uniforms of a color unfamiliar to him. They
were Russians.

The Russians stood in serried ranks behind Semenovsk villae and its
knoll, and their uns boomed incessantly alon their line and sent forth
clouds of smoke. It was no loner a battle: it was a continuous
slauhter which could be of no avail either to the French or the
Russians. Napoleon stopped his horse and aain fell into the reverie
from which Berthier had aroused him. He could not stop what was oin on
before him and around him and was supposed to be directed by him and to
depend on him, and from its lack of success this affair, for the first
time, seemed to him unnecessary and horrible.

One of the enerals rode up to Napoleon and ventured to offer to lead
the Old uard into action. Ney and Berthier, standin near Napoleon,
exchaned looks and smiled contemptuously at this eneral's senseless
offer.

Napoleon bowed his head and remained silent a lon time.

"At eiht hundred leaues from France, I will not have my uard
destroyed!" he said, and turnin his horse rode back to Shevardino.




CHAPTER XXXV

On the ru-covered bench where Pierre had seen him in the mornin sat
Kutuzov, his ray head hanin, his heavy body relaxed. He ave no
orders, but only assented to or dissented from what others suested.

"Yes, yes, do that," he replied to various proposals. "Yes, yes: o,
dear boy, and have a look," he would say to one or another of those
about him; or, "No, don't, we'd better wait!" He listened to the reports
that were brouht him and ave directions when his subordinates demanded
that of him; but when listenin to the reports it seemed as if he were
not interested in the import of the words spoken, but rather in
somethin else--in the expression of face and tone of voice of those who
were reportin. By lon years of military experience he knew, and with
the wisdom of ae understood, that it is impossible for one man to
direct hundreds of thousands of others strulin with death, and he
knew that the result of a battle is decided not by the orders of a
commander-in-chief, nor the place where the troops are stationed, nor by
the number of cannon or of slauhtered men, but by that intanible force
called the spirit of the army, and he watched this force and uided it
in as far as that was in his power.

Kutuzov's eneral expression was one of concentrated quiet attention,
and his face wore a strained look as if he found it difficult to master
the fatiue of his old and feeble body.

At eleven o'clock they brouht him news that the fleches captured by the
French had been retaken, but that Prince Baration was wounded. Kutuzov
roaned and swayed his head.

"Ride over to Prince Peter Ivanovich and find out about it exactly," he

who was standin behind him.

"Will Your Hihness please take command of the first army?"

Soon after the duke's departure--before he could possibly have reached
Semenovsk--his adjutant came back from him and told Kutuzov that the
duke asked for more troops.

Kutuzov made a rimace and sent an order to Dokhturov to take over the

brouht him news that Murat had been taken prisoner, and the staff

"Wait a little, entlemen," said he. "The battle is won, and there is
nothin extraordinary in the capture of Murat. Still, it is better to
wait before we rejoice."

But he sent an adjutant to take the news round the army.

When Scherbinin came allopin from the left flank with news that the
French had captured the fleches and the villae of Semenovsk, Kutuzov,
uessin by the sounds of the battle and by Scherbinin's looks that the

arm, led him aside.

"o, my dear fellow," he said to Ermolov, "and see whether somethin
can't be done."

Kutuzov was in orki, near the center of the Russian position. The
attack directed by Napoleon aainst our left flank had been several
times repulsed. In the center the French had not ot beyond Borodino,
and on their left flank Uvarov's cavalry had put the French to fliht.

Toward three o'clock the French attacks ceased. On the faces of all who
came from the field of battle, and of those who stood around him,

Adjutant eneral Wolzoen, the man who when ridin past Prince Andrew

The saacious Barclay de Tolly, seein crowds of wounded men runnin

Kutuzov was chewin a piece of roast chicken with difficulty and lanced

He treated his Serene Hihness with a somewhat affected nonchalance

"All the points of our position are in the enemy's hands and we cannot

"I have not considered it riht to conceal from your Serene Hihness

"You have seen? You have seen?..." Kutuzov shouted. Frownin and risin

"How... how dare you!..." he shouted, chokin and makin a threatenin

Wolzoen was about to make a rejoinder, but Kutuzov interrupted him.

"The enemy has been repulsed on the left and defeated on the riht

All were silent, and the only sound audible was the heavy breathin of

"They are repulsed everywhere, for which I thank od and our brave army!
The enemy is beaten, and tomorrow we shall drive him from the sacred

Wolzoen, shruin his shoulders and curlin his lips, stepped silently
aside, marvelin at "the old entleman's" conceited stupidity.

"Ah, here he is, my hero!" said Kutuzov to a portly, handsome, dark-
haired eneral who was just ascendin the knoll.

This was Raevski, who had spent the whole day at the most important part
of the field of Borodino.

Raevski reported that the troops were firmly holdin their round and
that the French no loner ventured to attack.

After hearin him, Kutuzov said in French:

"Then you do not think, like some others, that we must retreat?"

"On the contrary, your Hihness, in indecisive actions it is always the
most stubborn who remain victors," replied Raevski, "and in my
opinion..."

"Kaysarov!" Kutuzov called to his adjutant. "Sit down and write out the
order of the day for tomorrow. And you," he continued, addressin

While Kutuzov was talkin to Raevski and dictatin the order of the day,

Kutuzov, without lookin at Wolzoen, ave directions for the order to

responsibility, very judiciously wished to receive.

And by means of that mysterious indefinable bond which maintains
throuhout an army one and the same temper, known as "the spirit of the
army," and which constitutes the sinew of war, Kutuzov's words, his
order for a battle next day, immediately became known from one end of
the army to the other.

It was far from bein the same words or the same order that reached the
farthest links of that chain. The tales passin from mouth to mouth at
different ends of the army did not even resemble what Kutuzov had said,
but the sense of his words spread everywhere because what he said was
not the outcome of cunnin calculations, but of a feelin that lay in
the commander-in-chief's soul as in that of every Russian.

And on learnin that tomorrow they were to attack the enemy, and hearin
from the hihest quarters a confirmation of what they wanted to believe,
the exhausted, waverin men felt comforted and inspirited.




CHAPTER XXXVI

Prince Andrew's reiment was amon the reserves which till after one
o'clock were stationed inactive behind Semenovsk, under heavy artillery
fire. Toward two o'clock the reiment, havin already lost more than two
hundred men, was moved forward into a trampled oatfield in the ap
between Semenovsk and the Knoll Battery, where thousands of men perished
that day and on which an intense, concentrated fire from several hundred
enemy uns was directed between one and two o'clock.

Without movin from that spot or firin a sinle shot the reiment here
lost another third of its men. From in front and especially from the
riht, in the unliftin smoke the uns boomed, and out of the mysterious
domain of smoke that overlay the whole space in front, quick hissin

to allow them a respite, a quarter of an hour passed durin which the
cannon balls and shells all flew overhead, but sometimes several men
were torn from the reiment in a minute and the slain were continually
bein draed away and the wounded carried off.

With each fresh blow less and less chance of life remained for those not
yet killed. The reiment stood in columns of battalion, three hundred
paces apart, but nevertheless the men were always in one and the same
mood. All alike were taciturn and morose. Talk was rarely heard in the
ranks, and it ceased altoether every time the thud of a successful shot

shako, carefully loosened the athers of its linin and drew them tiht
aain; another, rubbin some dry clay between his palms, polished his
bayonet; another finered the strap and pulled the buckle of his
bandolier, while another smoothed and refolded his le bands and put his
boots on aain. Some built little houses of the tufts in the plowed
round, or plaited baskets from the straw in the cornfield. All seemed
fully absorbed in these pursuits. When men were killed or wounded, when
rows of stretchers went past, when some troops retreated, and when reat

attention to these thins. But when our artillery or cavalry advanced or
some of our infantry were seen to move forward, words of approval were
heard on all sides. But the liveliest attention was attracted by
occurrences quite apart from, and unconnected with, the battle. It was
as if the minds of these morally exhausted men found relief in everyday,
commonplace occurrences. A battery of artillery was passin in front of
the reiment. The horse of an ammunition cart put its le over a trace.
"Hey, look at the trace horse!... et her le out! She'll fall.... Ah,
they don't see it!" came identical shouts from the ranks all alon the

do, comin heaven knows whence, which trotted in a preoccupied manner

close by, when it yelped, tucked its tail between its les, and darted

such distractions lasted only a moment, and for eiht hours the men had
been inactive, without food, in constant fear of death, and their pale
and loomy faces rew ever paler and loomier.

Prince Andrew, pale and loomy like everyone in the reiment, paced up
and down from the border of one patch to another, at the ede of the

There was nothin for him to do and no orders to be iven. Everythin

"Here it comes... this one is comin our way aain!" he thouht,

it has one over. But this one has hit!" And aain he started tryin to

"Adjutant!" he shouted. "Order them not to crowd toether."

The adjutant, havin obeyed this instruction, approached Prince Andrew.
From the other side a battalion commander rode up.

"Look out!" came a frihtened cry from a soldier and, like a bird

"Lie down!" cried the adjutant, throwin himself flat on the round.

Prince Andrew hesitated. The smokin shell spun like a top between him

"Can this be death?" thouht Prince Andrew, lookin with a quite new,

thouht this, and at the same time remembered that people were lookin

"It's shameful, sir!" he said to the adjutant. "What..."

He did not finish speakin. At one and the same moment came the sound of

From the riht side of his abdomen, blood was wellin out makin a lare

The militiamen with stretchers who were called up stood behind the

"What are you waitin for? Come alon!"

The peasants went up and took him by his shoulders and les, but he
moaned piteously and, exchanin looks, they set him down aain.

"Pick him up, lift him, it's all the same!" cried someone.

They aain took him by the shoulders and laid him on the stretcher.

"Ah, od! My od! What is it? The stomach? That means death! My od!"--
voices amon the officers were heard sayin.

"It flew a hair's breadth past my ear," said the adjutant.

The peasants, adjustin the stretcher to their shoulders, started
hurriedly alon the path they had trodden down, to the dressin station.

"Keep in step! Ah... those peasants!" shouted an officer, seizin by

joltin the stretcher.

"et into step, Fedor... I say, Fedor!" said the foremost peasant.

"Now that's riht!" said the one behind joyfully, when he had ot into
step.

"Your excellency! Eh, Prince!" said the tremblin voice of Timokhin, who
had run up and was lookin down on the stretcher.

Prince Andrew opened his eyes and looked up at the speaker from the

The militiamen carried Prince Andrew to the dressin station by the

In the wood, waons and horses were standin. The horses were eatin

crowd of wounded and stretcher-bearers was athered.

"We kicked him out from there so that he chucked everythin, we rabbed

wouldn't have been nothin left of him! I tell you surely..."

Like all the others near the speaker, Prince Andrew looked at him with
shinin eyes and experienced a sense of comfort. "But isn't it all the
same now?" thouht he. "And what will be there, and what has there been

this life I did not and do not understand."




CHAPTER XXXVII

One of the doctors came out of the tent in a bloodstained apron, holdin
a ciar between the thumb and little finer of one of his small
bloodstained hands, so as not to smear it. He raised his head and looked
about him, but above the level of the wounded men. He evidently wanted a
little respite. After turnin his head from riht to left for some time,
he sihed and looked down.

"All riht, immediately," he replied to a dresser who pointed Prince
Andrew out to him, and he told them to carry him into the tent.

Murmurs arose amon the wounded who were waitin.

"It seems that even in the next world only the entry are to have a
chance!" remarked one.

Prince Andrew was carried in and laid on a table that had only just been
cleared and which a dresser was washin down. Prince Andrew could not
make out distinctly what was in that tent. The pitiful roans from all
sides and the torturin pain in his thih, stomach, and back distracted

same chair a canon, the siht of which had even then filled him with

There were three operatin tables in the tent. Two were occupied, and on

"Ooh, ooh, ooh!" runted the Tartar, and suddenly liftin up his swarthy

He lanced at Prince Andrew's face and quickly turned away.

"Undress him! What are you waitin for?" he cried anrily to the

His very first, remotest recollections of childhood came back to Prince
Andrew's mind when the dresser with sleeves rolled up bean hastily to

After the sufferins he had been endurin, Prince Andrew enjoyed a
blissful feelin such as he had not experienced for a lon time. All the
best and happiest moments of his life--especially his earliest
childhood, when he used to be undressed and put to bed, and when leanin
over him his nurse san him to sleep and he, buryin his head in the
pillow, felt happy in the mere consciousness of life--returned to his
memory, not merely as somethin past but as somethin present.

The doctors were busily enaed with the wounded man the shape of whose
head seemed familiar to Prince Andrew: they were liftin him up and
tryin to quiet him.

"Show it to me.... Oh, ooh... Oh! Oh, ooh!" his frihtened moans could
be heard, subdued by sufferin and broken by sobs.

Hearin those moans Prince Andrew wanted to weep. Whether because he was
dyin without lory, or because he was sorry to part with life, or
because of those memories of a childhood that could not return, or
because he was sufferin and others were sufferin and that man near him

almost happy tears.

The wounded man was shown his amputated le stained with clotted blood
and with the boot still on.

"Oh! Oh, ooh!" he sobbed, like a woman.

The doctor who had been standin beside him, preventin Prince Andrew
from seein his face, moved away.

"My od! What is this? Why is he here?" said Prince Andrew to himself.

In the miserable, sobbin, enfeebled man whose le had just been
amputated, he reconized Anatole Kurain. Men were supportin him in
their arms and offerin him a lass of water, but his tremblin, swollen
lips could not rasp its rim. Anatole was sobbin painfully. "Yes, it is
he! Yes, that man is somehow closely and painfully connected with me,"
thouht Prince Andrew, not yet clearly raspin what he saw before him.
"What is the connection of that man with my childhood and life?" he
asked himself without findin an answer. And suddenly a new unexpected
memory from that realm of pure and lovin childhood presented itself to
him. He remembered Natasha as he had seen her for the first time at the
ball in 1810, with her slender neck and arms and with a frihtened happy
face ready for rapture, and love and tenderness for her, stroner and
more vivid than ever, awoke in his soul. He now remembered the
connection that existed between himself and this man who was dimly
