everythin, and ecstatic pity and love for that man overflowed his happy
heart.

Prince Andrew could no loner restrain himself and wept tender lovin
tears for his fellow men, for himself, and for his own and their errors.

"Compassion, love of our brothers, for those who love us and for those
who hate us, love of our enemies; yes, that love which od preached on
earth and which Princess Mary tauht me and I did not understand--that
is what made me sorry to part with life, that is what remained for me
had I lived. But now it is too late. I know it!"




CHAPTER XXXVIII

The terrible spectacle of the battlefield covered with dead and wounded,
toether with the heaviness of his head and the news that some twenty

An adjutant came now to inform him that the fire of two hundred uns had

"Our fire is mowin them down by rows, but still they hold on," said the

"They want more!..." said Napoleon in a hoarse voice.

"Sire?" asked the adjutant who had not heard the remark.

"They want more!" croaked Napoleon frownin. "Let them have it!"

Even before he ave that order the thin he did not desire, and for

And not for that day and hour alone were the mind and conscience

Not only on that day, as he rode over the battlefield strewn with men

The Russian war should have been the most popular war of modern times:

It was a war for a reat cause, the end of uncertainties and the

Satisfied on these reat points and with tranquility everywhere, I too

Europe would in this way soon have been, in fact, but one people, and

On returnin to France, to the bosom of the reat, stron, manificent,

Paris would have been the capital of the world, and the French the envy

My leisure then, and my old ae, would have been devoted, in company

Napoleon, predestined by Providence for the loomy role of executioner

peoples' welfare and that he could control the fate of millions and by

"Of four hundred thousand who crossed the Vistula," he wrote further of

He imained that the war with Russia came about by his will, and the

CHAPTER XXXIX

Several tens of thousands of the slain lay in diverse postures and
various uniforms on the fields and meadows belonin to the Davydov
family and to the crown serfs--those fields and meadows where for
hundreds of years the peasants of Borodino, orki, Shevardino, and

unwounded, with frihtened faces, draed themselves back to Mozhaysk

Over the whole field, previously so aily beautiful with the litter of

To the men of both sides alike, worn out by want of food and rest, it

But thouh toward the end of the battle the men felt all the horror of

by the will of a man but at the will of Him who overns men and worlds
continued.

Anyone lookin at the disoranized rear of the Russian army would have

disappear; and anyone lookin at the rear of the French army would have

The Russians did not make that effort because they were not attackin

The French, with the memory of all their former victories durin fifteen

ouht to have made that effort, for as lon as the Russians continued to

It was not Napoleon alone who had experienced that nihtmare feelin of

BOOK ELEVEN: 1812




CHAPTER I

Absolute continuity of motion is not comprehensible to the human mind.
Laws of motion of any kind become comprehensible to man only when he
examines arbitrarily selected elements of that motion; but at the same
time, a lare proportion of human error comes from the arbitrary
division of continuous motion into discontinuous elements. There is a
well known, so-called sophism of the ancients consistin in this, that
Achilles could never catch up with a tortoise he was followin, in spite
of the fact that he traveled ten times as fast as the tortoise. By the
time Achilles has covered the distance that separated him from the
tortoise, the tortoise has covered one tenth of that distance ahead of
him: when Achilles has covered that tenth, the tortoise has covered
another one hundredth, and so on forever. This problem seemed to the
ancients insoluble. The absurd answer (that Achilles could never
overtake the tortoise) resulted from this: that motion was arbitrarily
divided into discontinuous elements, whereas the motion both of Achilles
and of the tortoise was continuous.

By adoptin smaller and smaller elements of motion we only approach a
solution of the problem, but never reach it. Only when we have admitted
the conception of the infinitely small, and the resultin eometrical
proression with a common ratio of one tenth, and have found the sum of
this proression to infinity, do we reach a solution of the problem.

A modern branch of mathematics havin achieved the art of dealin with
the infinitely small can now yield solutions in other more complex
problems of motion which used to appear insoluble.

This modern branch of mathematics, unknown to the ancients, when dealin
with problems of motion admits the conception of the infinitely small,
and so conforms to the chief condition of motion (absolute continuity)
and thereby corrects the inevitable error which the human mind cannot
avoid when it deals with separate elements of motion instead of
examinin continuous motion.

In seekin the laws of historical movement just the same thin happens.
The movement of humanity, arisin as it does from innumerable arbitrary
human wills, is continuous.

To understand the laws of this continuous movement is the aim of
history. But to arrive at these laws, resultin from the sum of all
those human wills, man's mind postulates arbitrary and disconnected
units. The first method of history is to take an arbitrarily selected
series of continuous events and examine it apart from others, thouh
there is and can be no beinnin to any event, for one event always
flows uninterruptedly from another.

The second method is to consider the actions of some one man--a kin or
a commander--as equivalent to the sum of many individual wills; whereas
the sum of individual wills is never expressed by the activity of a
sinle historic personae.

Historical science in its endeavor to draw nearer to truth continually
takes smaller and smaller units for examination. But however small the
units it takes, we feel that to take any unit disconnected from others,
or to assume a beinnin of any phenomenon, or to say that the will of
many men is expressed by the actions of any one historic personae, is
in itself false.

It needs no critical exertion to reduce utterly to dust any deductions
drawn from history. It is merely necessary to select some larer or
smaller unit as the subject of observation--as criticism has every riht
to do, seein that whatever unit history observes must always be
arbitrarily selected.

Only by takin infinitesimally small units for observation (the
differential of history, that is, the individual tendencies of men) and
attainin to the art of interatin them (that is, findin the sum of
these infinitesimals) can we hope to arrive at the laws of history.

The first fifteen years of the nineteenth century in Europe present an
extraordinary movement of millions of people. Men leave their customary
pursuits, hasten from one side of Europe to the other, plunder and
slauhter one another, triumph and are pluned in despair, and for some
years the whole course of life is altered and presents an intensive
movement which first increases and then slackens. What was the cause of
this movement, by what laws was it overned? asks the mind of man.

The historians, replyin to this question, lay before us the sayins and
doins of a few dozen men in a buildin in the city of Paris, callin
these sayins and doins "the Revolution"; then they ive a detailed
bioraphy of Napoleon and of certain people favorable or hostile to him;
tell of the influence some of these people had on others, and say: that
is why this movement took place and those are its laws.

But the mind of man not only refuses to believe this explanation, but
plainly says that this method of explanation is fallacious, because in
it a weaker phenomenon is taken as the cause of a stroner. The sum of
human wills produced the Revolution and Napoleon, and only the sum of
those wills first tolerated and then destroyed them.

"But every time there have been conquests there have been conquerors;
every time there has been a revolution in any state there have been
reat men," says history. And, indeed, human reason replies: every time
conquerors appear there have been wars, but this does not prove that the
conquerors caused the wars and that it is possible to find the laws of a
war in the personal activity of a sinle man. Whenever I look at my
watch and its hands point to ten, I hear the bells of the neihborin
church; but because the bells bein to rin when the hands of the clock
reach ten, I have no riht to assume that the movement of the bells is
caused by the position of the hands of the watch.

Whenever I see the movement of a locomotive I hear the whistle and see
the valves openin and wheels turnin; but I have no riht to conclude
that the whistlin and the turnin of wheels are the cause of the
movement of the enine.

The peasants say that a cold wind blows in late sprin because the oaks
are buddin, and really every sprin cold winds do blow when the oak is
buddin. But thouh I do not know what causes the cold winds to blow
when the oak buds unfold, I cannot aree with the peasants that the
unfoldin of the oak buds is the cause of the cold wind, for the force
of the wind is beyond the influence of the buds. I see only a
coincidence of occurrences such as happens with all the phenomena of
life, and I see that however much and however carefully I observe the
hands of the watch, and the valves and wheels of the enine, and the
oak, I shall not discover the cause of the bells rinin, the enine
movin, or of the winds of sprin. To that I must entirely chane my
point of view and study the laws of the movement of steam, of the bells,
and of the wind. History must do the same. And attempts in this
direction have already been made.

To study the laws of history we must completely chane the subject of
our observation, must leave aside kins, ministers, and enerals, and
study the common, infinitesimally small elements by which the masses are
moved. No one can say in how far it is possible for man to advance in
this way toward an understandin of the laws of history; but it is
evident that only alon that path does the possibility of discoverin
the laws of history lie, and that as yet not a millionth part as much
mental effort has been applied in this direction by historians as has
been devoted to describin the actions of various kins, commanders, and
ministers and propoundin the historians' own reflections concernin
these actions.




CHAPTER II

The forces of a dozen European nations burst into Russia. The Russian
army and people avoided a collision till Smolensk was reached, and aain
from Smolensk to Borodino. The French army pushed on to Moscow, its
oal, its impetus ever increasin as it neared its aim, just as the
velocity of a fallin body increases as it approaches the earth. Behind
it were seven hundred miles of huner-stricken, hostile country; ahead
were a few dozen miles separatin it from its oal. Every soldier in
Napoleon's army felt this and the invasion moved on by its own momentum.

The more the Russian army retreated the more fiercely a spirit of hatred
of the enemy flared up, and while it retreated the army increased and
consolidated. At Borodino a collision took place. Neither army was
broken up, but the Russian army retreated immediately after the

havin a reater momentum, and with equal inevitability the ball of
invasion that had advanced with such momentum rolled on for some
distance, thouh the collision had deprived it of all its force.

The Russians retreated eihty miles--to beyond Moscow--and the French

farther still.

On the evenin of the twenty-sixth of Auust, Kutuzov and the whole

It was impossible to ive battle before information had been collected,

For people accustomed to think that plans of campain and battles are

questions present themselves: Why did Kutuzov durin the retreat not do
this or that? Why did he not take up a position before reachin Fili?
Why did he not retire at once by the Kalua road, abandonin Moscow? and
so on. People accustomed to think in that way foret, or do not know,
the inevitable conditions which always limit the activities of any

resemble the activity we imaine to ourselves when we sit at ease in our
studies examinin some campain on the map, with a certain number of
troops on this and that side in a certain known locality, and bein our

the beinnin of any event--the position from which we always
contemplate it. The commander-in-chief is always in the midst of a

whole import of an event that is occurrin. Moment by moment the event
is imperceptibly shapin itself, and at every moment of this continuous,
uninterrupted shapin of events the commander-in-chief is in the midst

authorities, projects, counsels, threats, and deceptions and is
continually oblied to reply to innumerable questions addressed to him,
which constantly conflict with one another.

Learned military authorities quite seriously tell us that Kutuzov should
have moved his army to the Kalua road lon before reachin Fili, and
that somebody actually submitted such a proposal to him. But a commander
in chief, especially at a difficult moment, has always before him not
one proposal but dozens simultaneously. And all these proposals, based
on strateics and tactics, contradict each other.

A commander-in-chief's business, it would seem, is simply to choose one
of these projects. But even that he cannot do. Events and time do not
wait. For instance, on the twenty-eihth it is suested to him to cross
to the Kalua road, but just then an adjutant allops up from
Miloradovich askin whether he is to enae the French or retire. An
order must be iven him at once, that instant. And the order to retreat
carries us past the turn to the Kalua road. And after the adjutant
comes the commissary eneral askin where the stores are to be taken,
and the chief of the hospitals asks where the wounded are to o, and a
courier from Petersbur brins a letter from the soverein which does
not admit of the possibility of abandonin Moscow, and the commander-in-
chief's rival, the man who is underminin him (and there are always not
merely one but several such), presents a new project diametrically
opposed to that of turnin to the Kalua road, and the commander-in-
chief himself needs sleep and refreshment to maintain his enery and a
respectable eneral who has been overlooked in the distribution of
rewards comes to complain, and the inhabitants of the district pray to
be defended, and an officer sent to inspect the locality comes in and
ives a report quite contrary to what was said by the officer previously
sent; and a spy, a prisoner, and a eneral who has been on
reconnaissance, all describe the position of the enemy's army
differently. People accustomed to misunderstand or to foret these
inevitable conditions of a commander-in-chief's actions describe to us,
for instance, the position of the army at Fili and assume that the
commander-in-chief could, on the first of September, quite freely decide
whether to abandon Moscow or defend it; whereas, with the Russian army
less than four miles from Moscow, no such question existed. When had
that question been settled? At Drissa and at Smolensk and most palpably
of all on the twenty-fourth of Auust at Shevardino and on the twenty-
sixth at Borodino, and each day and hour and minute of the retreat from
Borodino to Fili.




CHAPTER III

When Ermolov, havin been sent by Kutuzov to inspect the position, told
the field marshal that it was impossible to fiht there before Moscow

"ive me your hand," said he and, turnin it over so as to feel the

Kutuzov could not yet admit the possibility of retreatin beyond Moscow
without a battle.

On the Poklonny Hill, four miles from the Doroomilov ate of Moscow,

was talkin absolute nonsense. Kutuzov's expression rew more and more

He called the most important enerals to him.

CHAPTER V

At that very time, in circumstances even more important than retreatin

After the battle of Borodino the abandonment and burnin of Moscow was
as inevitable as the retreat of the army beyond Moscow without fihtin.

Every Russian miht have predicted it, not by reasonin but by the
feelin implanted in each of us and in our fathers.

The same thin that took place in Moscow had happened in all the towns
and villaes on Russian soil beinnin with Smolensk, without the

awaited the enemy unconcernedly, did not riot or become excited or tear
anyone to pieces, but faced its fate, feelin within it the strenth to
find what it should do at that most difficult moment. And as soon as the
enemy drew near the wealthy classes went away abandonin their property,
while the poorer remained and burned and destroyed what was left.

The consciousness that this would be so and would always be so was and
is present in the heart of every Russian. And a consciousness of this,
and a forebodin that Moscow would be taken, was present in Russian
Moscow society in 1812. Those who had quitted Moscow already in July and
at the beinnin of Auust showed that they expected this. Those who
went away, takin what they could and abandonin their houses and half
their belonins, did so from the latent patriotism which expresses
itself not by phrases or by ivin one's children to save the fatherland
and similar unnatural exploits, but unobtrusively, simply, oranically,
and therefore in the way that always produces the most powerful results.

"It is disraceful to run away from daner; only cowards are runnin

had to be done. Why did they o? It is impossible to suppose that
Rostopchin had scared them by his accounts of horrors Napoleon had
committed in conquered countries. The first people to o away were the
rich educated people who knew quite well that Vienna and Berlin had
remained intact and that durin Napoleon's occupation the inhabitants

whom the Russians, and especially the Russian ladies, then liked so
much.

They went away because for Russians there could be no question as to
whether thins would o well or ill under French rule in Moscow. It was
out of the question to be under French rule, it would be the worst thin
that could happen. They went away even before the battle of Borodino and
still more rapidly after it, despite Rostopchin's calls to defend Moscow
or the announcement of his intention to take the wonder-workin icon of
the Iberian Mother of od and o to fiht, or of the balloons that were
to destroy the French, and despite all the nonsense Rostopchin wrote in
his broadsheets. They knew that it was for the army to fiht, and that
if it could not succeed it would not do to take youn ladies and house

sinificance of that immense and wealthy city bein iven over to
destruction, for a reat city with wooden buildins was certain when
abandoned by its inhabitants to be burned. They went away each on his
own account, and yet it was only in consequence of their oin away that
the momentous event was accomplished that will always remain the

vaue consciousness that she was not Bonaparte's servant, was really,
simply, and truly carryin out the reat work which saved Russia. But
Count Rostopchin, who now taunted those who left Moscow and now had the
overnment offices removed; now distributed quite useless weapons to the
drunken rabble; now had processions displayin the icons, and now
forbade Father Auustin to remove icons or the relics of saints; now

and like a child he made sport of the momentous, and unavoidable event--

with it.




CHAPTER VI

Helene, havin returned with the court from Vilna to Petersbur, found

Amon those who ventured to doubt the justifiability of the proposed
marriae was Helene's mother, Princess Kuraina. She was continually
tormented by jealousy of her dauhter, and now that jealousy concerned a
subject near to her own heart, she could not reconcile herself to the
idea. She consulted a Russian priest as to the possibility of divorce
and remarriae durin a husband's lifetime, and the priest told her that
it was impossible, and to her deliht showed her a text in the ospel
which (as it seemed to him) plainly forbids remarriae while the husband
is alive.

Armed with these aruments, which appeared to her unanswerable, she
drove to her dauhter's early one mornin so as to find her alone.

Havin listened to her mother's objections, Helene smiled blandly and
ironically.

"But it says plainly: 'Whosoever shall marry her that is divorced...'"
said the old princess.

"Ah, Maman, ne dites pas de betises. Vous ne comprenez rien. Dans ma
position j'ai des devoirs," * said Helene chanin from Russian, in
which lanuae she always felt that her case did not sound quite clear,
into French which suited it better.


* "Oh, Mamma, don't talk nonsense! You don't understand anythin. In my
position I have obliations."

"But, my dear...."

"Oh, Mamma, how is it you don't understand that the Holy Father, who has
the riht to rant dispensations..."

Just then the lady companion who lived with Helene came in to announce
that His Hihness was in the ballroom and wished to see her.

"Non, dites-lui que je ne veux pas le voir, que je suis furieuse contre
lui, parce qu'il m'a manque parole." *


* "No, tell him I don't wish to see him, I am furious with him for not
keepin his word to me."

"Comtesse, a tout peche misericorde," * said a fair-haired youn man
with a lon face and nose, as he entered the room.


* "Countess, there is mercy for every sin."

The old princess rose respectfully and curtsied. The youn man who had
entered took no notice of her. The princess nodded to her dauhter and
sidled out of the room.

"Yes, she is riht," thouht the old princess, all her convictions
dissipated by the appearance of His Hihness. "She is riht, but how is
it that we in our irrecoverable youth did not know it? Yet it is so
simple," she thouht as she ot into her carriae.

By the beinnin of Auust Helene's affairs were clearly defined and she
wrote a letter to her husband--who, as she imained, loved her very
much--informin him of her intention to marry N.N. and of her havin
embraced the one true faith, and askin him to carry out all the
formalities necessary for a divorce, which would be explained to him by
the bearer of the letter.

And so I pray od to have you, my friend, in His holy and powerful
keepin--Your friend Helene.

This letter was brouht to Pierre's house when he was on the field of
Borodino.




CHAPTER VIII

Toward the end of the battle of Borodino, Pierre, havin run down from
Raevski's battery a second time, made his way throuh a ully to
Knyazkovo with a crowd of soldiers, reached the dressin station, and
seein blood and hearin cries and roans hurried on, still entanled in
the crowds of soldiers.

The one thin he now desired with his whole soul was to et away quickly
from the terrible sensations amid which he had lived that day and return
to ordinary conditions of life and sleep quietly in a room in his own
bed. He felt that only in the ordinary conditions of life would he be
able to understand himself and all he had seen and felt. But such
ordinary conditions of life were nowhere to be found.

Thouh shells and bullets did not whistle over the road alon which he
was oin, still on all sides there was what there had been on the field
of battle. There were still the same sufferin, exhausted, and sometimes
stranely indifferent faces, the same blood, the same soldiers'
overcoats, the same sounds of firin which, thouh distant now, still
aroused terror, and besides this there were the foul air and the dust.

Havin one a couple of miles alon the Mozhaysk road, Pierre sat down
by the roadside.

Dusk had fallen, and the roar of uns died away. Pierre lay leanin on
his elbow for a lon time, azin at the shadows that moved past him in
the darkness. He was continually imainin that a cannon ball was flyin
toward him with a terrific whizz, and then he shuddered and sat up. He
had no idea how lon he had been there. In the middle of the niht three
soldiers, havin brouht some firewood, settled down near him and bean
lihtin a fire.

The soldiers, who threw sidelon lances at Pierre, ot the fire to burn
and placed an iron pot on it into which they broke some dried bread and
put a little drippin. The pleasant odor of reasy viands minled with
the smell of smoke. Pierre sat up and sihed. The three soldiers were
eatin and talkin amon themselves, takin no notice of him.

"And who may you be?" one of them suddenly asked Pierre, evidently
meanin what Pierre himself had in mind, namely: "If you want to eat
we'll ive you some food, only let us know whether you are an honest
man."

"I, I..." said Pierre, feelin it necessary to minimize his social
position as much as possible so as to be nearer to the soldiers and
better understood by them. "By rihts I am a militia officer, but my men
are not here. I came to the battle and have lost them."

"There now!" said one of the soldiers.

Another shook his head.

"Would you like a little mash?" the first soldier asked, and handed
Pierre a wooden spoon after lickin it clean.

Pierre sat down by the fire and bean eatin the mash, as they called
the food in the cauldron, and he thouht it more delicious than any food
he had ever tasted. As he sat bendin reedily over it, helpin himself
to lare spoonfuls and chewin one after another, his face was lit up by
the fire and the soldiers looked at him in silence.

"Where have you to o to? Tell us!" said one of them.

"To Mozhaysk."

"You're a entleman, aren't you?"

"Yes."

"And what's your name?"

"Peter Kirilych."

"Well then, Peter Kirilych, come alon with us, we'll take you there."

In the total darkness the soldiers walked with Pierre to Mozhaysk.

By the time they ot near Mozhaysk and bean ascendin the steep hill
into the town, the cocks were already crowin. Pierre went on with the
soldiers, quite forettin that his inn was at the bottom of the hill
and that he had already passed it. He would not soon have remembered
this, such was his state of foretfulness, had he not halfway up the
hill stumbled upon his room, who had been to look for him in the town
and was returnin to the inn. The room reconized Pierre in the
darkness by his white hat.

"Your excellency!" he said. "Why, we were beinnin to despair! How is
it you are on foot? And where are you oin, please?"

"Oh, yes!" said Pierre.

The soldiers stopped.

"So you've found your folk?" said one of them. "Well, ood-by, Peter
Kirilych--isn't it?"

"ood-bye, Peter Kirilych!" Pierre heard the other voices repeat.

"ood-bye!" he said and turned with his room toward the inn.

"I ouht to ive them somethin!" he thouht, and felt in his pocket.
"No, better not!" said another, inner voice.

There was not a room to be had at the inn, they were all occupied.
Pierre went out into the yard and, coverin himself up head and all, lay
down in his carriae.




CHAPTER IX

Scarcely had Pierre laid his head on the pillow before he felt himself
fallin asleep, but suddenly, almost with the distinctness of reality,
he heard the boom, boom, boom of firin, the thud of projectiles, roans
and cries, and smelled blood and powder, and a feelin of horror and
dread of death seized him. Filled with friht he opened his eyes and
lifted his head from under his cloak. All was tranquil in the yard. Only
someone's orderly passed throuh the ateway, splashin throuh the mud,
and talked to the innkeeper. Above Pierre's head some pieons, disturbed
by the movement he had made in sittin up, fluttered under the dark roof
of the penthouse. The whole courtyard was permeated by a stron peaceful
smell of stable yards, delihtful to Pierre at that moment. He could see
the clear starry sky between the dark roofs of two penthouses.

"Thank od, there is no more of that!" he thouht, coverin up his head
aain. "Oh, what a terrible thin is fear, and how shamefully I yielded
to it! But they... they were steady and calm all the time, to the
end..." thouht he.

They, in Pierre's mind, were the soldiers, those who had been at the
battery, those who had iven him food, and those who had prayed before
the icon. They, those strane men he had not previously known, stood out
clearly and sharply from everyone else.

"To be a soldier, just a soldier!" thouht Pierre as he fell asleep, "to
enter communal life completely, to be imbued by what makes them what
they are. But how cast off all the superfluous, devilish burden of my
outer man? There was a time when I could have done it. I could have run
away from my father, as I wanted to. Or I miht have been sent to serve
as a soldier after the duel with Dolokhov." And the memory of the dinner
at the Enlish Club when he had challened Dolokhov flashed throuh
Pierre's mind, and then he remembered his benefactor at Torzhok. And now
a picture of a solemn meetin of the lode presented itself to his mind.
It was takin place at the Enlish Club and someone near and dear to him
sat at the end of the table. "Yes, that is he! It is my benefactor. But
he died!" thouht Pierre. "Yes, he died, and I did not know he was
alive. How sorry I am that he died, and how lad I am that he is alive
aain!" On one side of the table sat Anatole, Dolokhov, Nesvitski,
Denisov, and others like them (in his dream the cateory to which these
men beloned was as clearly defined in his mind as the cateory of those
he termed they), and he heard those people, Anatole and Dolokhov,
shoutin and sinin loudly; yet throuh their shoutin the voice of his
benefactor was heard speakin all the time and the sound of his words
was as weihty and uninterrupted as the boomin on the battlefield, but
pleasant and comfortin. Pierre did not understand what his benefactor
was sayin, but he knew (the cateories of thouhts were also quite
distinct in his dream) that he was talkin of oodness and the
possibility of bein what they were. And they with their simple, kind,
firm faces surrounded his benefactor on all sides. But thouh they were
kindly they did not look at Pierre and did not know him. Wishin to
speak and to attract their attention, he ot up, but at that moment his
les rew cold and bare.

He felt ashamed, and with one arm covered his les from which his cloak
had in fact slipped. For a moment as he was rearranin his cloak Pierre
opened his eyes and saw the same penthouse roofs, posts, and yard, but
now they were all bluish, lit up, and litterin with frost or dew.

"It is dawn," thouht Pierre. "But that's not what I want. I want to
hear and understand my benefactor's words." Aain he covered himself up
with his cloak, but now neither the lode nor his benefactor was there.
There were only thouhts clearly expressed in words, thouhts that
someone was utterin or that he himself was formulatin.

Afterwards when he recalled those thouhts Pierre was convinced that
someone outside himself had spoken them, thouh the impressions of that
day had evoked them. He had never, it seemed to him, been able to think
and express his thouhts like that when awake.

"To endure war is the most difficult subordination of man's freedom to
the law of od," the voice had said. "Simplicity is submission to the
will of od; you cannot escape from Him. And they are simple. They do
not talk, but act. The spoken word is silver but the unspoken is olden.
Man can be master of nothin while he fears death, but he who does not
fear it possesses all. If there were no sufferin, man would not know
his limitations, would not know himself. The hardest thin (Pierre went
on thinkin, or hearin, in his dream) is to be able in your soul to
unite the meanin of all. To unite all?" he asked himself. "No, not to
unite. Thouhts cannot be united, but to harness all these thouhts
toether is what we need! Yes, one must harness them, must harness
them!" he repeated to himself with inward rapture, feelin that these
words and they alone expressed what he wanted to say and solved the
question that tormented him.

"Yes, one must harness, it is time to harness."

"Time to harness, time to harness, your excellency! Your excellency!"
some voice was repeatin. "We must harness, it is time to harness...."

It was the voice of the room, tryin to wake him. The sun shone
straiht into Pierre's face. He lanced at the dirty innyard in the
middle of which soldiers were waterin their lean horses at the pump
while carts were passin out of the ate. Pierre turned away with
repunance, and closin his eyes quickly fell back on the carriae seat.
"No, I don't want that, I don't want to see and understand that. I want
to understand what was revealin itself to me in my dream. One second
more and I should have understood it all! But what am I to do? Harness,
but how can I harness everythin?" and Pierre felt with horror that the
meanin of all he had seen and thouht in the dream had been destroyed.

The room, the coachman, and the innkeeper told Pierre that an officer
had come with news that the French were already near Mozhaysk and that
our men were leavin it.

Pierre ot up and, havin told them to harness and overtake him, went on
foot throuh the town.

The troops were movin on, leavin about ten thousand wounded behind
them. There were wounded in the yards, at the windows of the houses, and
the streets were crowded with them. In the streets, around carts that
were to take some of the wounded away, shouts, curses, and blows could
be heard. Pierre offered the use of his carriae, which had overtaken
him, to a wounded eneral he knew, and drove with him to Moscow. On the
way Pierre was told of the death of his brother-in-law Anatole and of
that of Prince Andrew.




CHAPTER X

On the thirteenth of Auust Pierre reached Moscow. Close to the ates of
the city he was met by Count Rostopchin's adjutant.

"We have been lookin for you everywhere," said the adjutant. "The count
wants to see you particularly. He asks you to come to him at once on a
very important matter."

Without oin home, Pierre took a cab and drove to see the Moscow
commander-in-chief.

Count Rostopchin had only that mornin returned to town from his summer
villa at Sokolniki. The anteroom and reception room of his house were
full of officials who had been summoned or had come for orders.
Vasilchikov and Platov had already seen the count and explained to him
that it was impossible to defend Moscow and that it would have to be
surrendered. Thouh this news was bein concealed from the inhabitants,
the officials--the heads of the various overnment departments--knew
that Moscow would soon be in the enemy's hands, just as Count Rostopchin
himself knew it, and to escape personal responsibility they had all come
to the overnor to ask how they were to deal with their various
departments.

As Pierre was enterin the reception room a courier from the army came
out of Rostopchin's private room.

In answer to questions with which he was reeted, the courier made a
despairin esture with his hand and passed throuh the room.

While waitin in the reception room Pierre with weary eyes watched the
various officials, old and youn, military and civilian, who were there.
They all seemed dissatisfied and uneasy. Pierre went up to a roup of
men, one of whom he knew. After reetin Pierre they continued their
conversation.

"If they're sent out and brouht back aain later on it will do no harm,
but as thins are now one can't answer for anythin."

"But you see what he writes..." said another, pointin to a printed
sheet he held in his hand.

"That's another matter. That's necessary for the people," said the
first.

"What is it?" asked Pierre.

"Oh, it's a fresh broadsheet."

Pierre took it and bean readin.

His Serene Hihness has passed throuh Mozhaysk in order to join up with
the troops movin toward him and has taken up a stron position where
the enemy will not soon attack him. Forty eiht uns with ammunition
have been sent him from here, and his Serene Hihness says he will
defend Moscow to the last drop of blood and is even ready to fiht in
the streets. Do not be upset, brothers, that the law courts are closed;
thins have to be put in order, and we will deal with villains in our
own way! When the time comes I shall want both town and peasant lads and
will raise the cry a day or two beforehand, but they are not wanted yet
so I hold my peace. An ax will be useful, a huntin spear not bad, but a
three-proned fork will be best of all: a Frenchman is no heavier than a
sheaf of rye. Tomorrow after dinner I shall take the Iberian icon of the
Mother of od to the wounded in the Catherine Hospital where we will
have some water blessed. That will help them to et well quicker. I,
too, am well now: one of my eyes was sore but now I am on the lookout
with both.

"But military men have told me that it is impossible to fiht in the
town," said Pierre, "and that the position..."

"Well, of course! That's what we were sayin," replied the first
speaker.

"And what does he mean by 'One of my eyes was sore but now I am on the
lookout with both'?" asked Pierre.

"The count had a sty," replied the adjutant smilin, "and was very much
upset when I told him people had come to ask what was the matter with
him. By the by, Count," he added suddenly, addressin Pierre with a
smile, "we heard that you have family troubles and that the countess,
your wife..."

"I have heard nothin," Pierre replied unconcernedly. "But what have you
heard?"

"Oh, well, you know people often invent thins. I only say what I
heard."

"But what did you hear?"

"Well, they say," continued the adjutant with the same smile, "that the
countess, your wife, is preparin to o abroad. I expect it's
nonsense...."

"Possibly," remarked Pierre, lookin about him absent-mindedly. "And who
is that?" he asked, indicatin a short old man in a clean blue peasant
overcoat, with a bi snow-white beard and eyebrows and a ruddy face.

"He? That's a tradesman, that is to say, he's the restaurant keeper,
Vereshchain. Perhaps you have heard of that affair with the
proclamation."

"Oh, so that is Vereshchain!" said Pierre, lookin at the firm, calm
face of the old man and seekin any indication of his bein a traitor.

"That's not he himself, that's the father of the fellow who wrote the
proclamation," said the adjutant. "The youn man is in prison and I
expect it will o hard with him."

An old entleman wearin a star and another official, a erman wearin a
cross round his neck, approached the speaker.


"It's a complicated story, you know," said the adjutant. "That
proclamation appeared about two months ao. The count was informed of
it. He ave orders to investiate the matter. abriel Ivanovich here
made the inquiries. The proclamation had passed throuh exactly sixty-
three hands. He asked one, 'From whom did you et it?' 'From so-and-so.'
He went to the next one. 'From whom did you et it?' and so on till he
reached Vereshchain, a half educated tradesman, you know, 'a pet of a
trader,'" said the adjutant smilin. "They asked him, 'Who ave it you?'
And the point is that we knew whom he had it from. He could only have
had it from the Postmaster. But evidently they had come to some
understandin. He replied: 'From no one; I made it up myself.' They
threatened and questioned him, but he stuck to that: 'I made it up
myself.' And so it was reported to the count, who sent for the man.
'From whom did you et the proclamation?' 'I wrote it myself.' Well, you
know the count," said the adjutant cheerfully, with a smile of pride,
"he flared up dreadfully--and just think of the fellow's audacity,
lyin, and obstinacy!"

"And the count wanted him to say it was from Klyucharev? I understand!"
said Pierre.

"Not at all," rejoined the adjutant in dismay. "Klyucharev had his own
sins to answer for without that and that is why he has been banished.
But the point is that the count was much annoyed. 'How could you have
written it yourself?' said he, and he took up the Hambur azette that
was lyin on the table. 'Here it is! You did not write it yourself but
translated it, and translated it abominably, because you don't even know
French, you fool.' And what do you think? 'No,' said he, 'I have not
read any papers, I made it up myself.' 'If that's so, you're a traitor
and I'll have you tried, and you'll be haned! Say from whom you had
it.' 'I have seen no papers, I made it up myself.' And that was the end
of it. The count had the father fetched, but the fellow stuck to it. He
was sent for trial and condemned to hard labor, I believe. Now the
father has come to intercede for him. But he's a ood-for-nothin lad!
You know that sort of tradesman's son, a dandy and lady-killer. He
attended some lectures somewhere and imaines that the devil is no match
for him. That's the sort of fellow he is. His father keeps a cookshop
here by the Stone Bride, and you know there was a lare icon of od
Almihty painted with a scepter in one hand and an orb in the other.
Well, he took that icon home with him for a few days and what did he do?
He found some scoundrel of a painter..."




CHAPTER XI

In the middle of this fresh tale Pierre was summoned to the commander in
chief.

When he entered the private room Count Rostopchin, puckerin his face,
was rubbin his forehead and eyes with his hand. A short man was sayin
somethin, but when Pierre entered he stopped speakin and went out.

"Ah, how do you do, reat warrior?" said Rostopchin as soon as the short
man had left the room. "We have heard of your prowess. But that's not
the point. Between ourselves, mon cher, do you belon to the Masons?" he
went on severely, as thouh there were somethin wron about it which he
nevertheless intended to pardon. Pierre remained silent. "I am well
informed, my friend, but I am aware that there are Masons and I hope
that you are not one of those who on pretense of savin mankind wish to
ruin Russia."

"Yes, I am a Mason," Pierre replied.

"There, you see, mon cher! I expect you know that Messrs. Speranski and
Manitski have been deported to their proper place. Mr. Klyucharev has
been treated in the same way, and so have others who on the plea of
buildin up the temple of Solomon have tried to destroy the temple of
their fatherland. You can understand that there are reasons for this and
that I could not have exiled the Postmaster had he not been a harmful
person. It has now come to my knowlede that you lent him your carriae
for his removal from town, and that you have even accepted papers from
him for safe custody. I like you and don't wish you any harm and--as you
are only half my ae--I advise you, as a father would, to cease all
communication with men of that stamp and to leave here as soon as
possible."

"But what did Klyucharev do wron, Count?" asked Pierre.

"That is for me to know, but not for you to ask," shouted Rostopchin.

"If he is accused of circulatin Napoleon's proclamation it is not
proved that he did so," said Pierre without lookin at Rostopchin, "and
Vereshchain..."

"There we are!" Rostopchin shouted at Pierre louder than before,
frownin suddenly. "Vereshchain is a reneade and a traitor who will be
punished as he deserves," said he with the vindictive heat with which
people speak when recallin an insult. "But I did not summon you to
discuss my actions, but to ive you advice--or an order if you prefer
it. I be you to leave the town and break off all communication with
such men as Klyucharev. And I will knock the nonsense out of anybody"--
but probably realizin that he was shoutin at Bezukhov who so far was
not uilty of anythin, he added, takin Pierre's hand in a friendly
manner, "We are on the eve of a public disaster and I haven't time to be
polite to everybody who has business with me. My head is sometimes in a
whirl. Well, mon cher, what are you doin personally?"

"Why, nothin," answered Pierre without raisin his eyes or chanin the
thouhtful expression of his face.

The count frowned.

"A word of friendly advice, mon cher. Be off as soon as you can, that's
all I have to tell you. Happy he who has ears to hear. ood-bye, my dear
fellow. Oh, by the by!" he shouted throuh the doorway after Pierre, "is
it true that the countess has fallen into the clutches of the holy
fathers of the Society of Jesus?"

Pierre did not answer and left Rostopchin's room more sullen and anry
than he had ever before shown himself.

When he reached home it was already ettin dark. Some eiht people had
come to see him that evenin: the secretary of a committee, the colonel
of his battalion, his steward, his major-domo, and various petitioners.
They all had business with Pierre and wanted decisions from him. Pierre
did not understand and was not interested in any of these questions and
only answered them in order to et rid of these people. When left alone
at last he opened and read his wife's letter.

"They, the soldiers at the battery, Prince Andrew killed... that old
man... Simplicity is submission to od. Sufferin is necessary... the
meanin of all... one must harness... my wife is ettin married... One
must foret and understand..." And oin to his bed he threw himself on
it without undressin and immediately fell asleep.

When he awoke next mornin the major-domo came to inform him that a
special messener, a police officer, had come from Count Rostopchin to
know whether Count Bezukhov had left or was leavin the town.

A dozen persons who had business with Pierre were awaitin him in the
drawin room. Pierre dressed hurriedly and, instead of oin to see
them, went to the back porch and out throuh the ate.

From that time till the end of the destruction of Moscow no one of
Bezukhov's household, despite all the search they made, saw Pierre aain
or knew where he was.




CHAPTER XII

The Rostovs remained in Moscow till the first of September, that is,
till the eve of the enemy's entry into the city.

After Petya had joined Obolenski's reiment of Cossacks and left for
Belaya Tserkov where that reiment was formin, the countess was seized
with terror. The thouht that both her sons were at the war, had both
one from under her win, that today or tomorrow either or both of them
miht be killed like the three sons of one of her acquaintances, struck
her that summer for the first time with cruel clearness. She tried to
et Nicholas back and wished to o herself to join Petya, or to et him
an appointment somewhere in Petersbur, but neither of these proved
possible. Petya could not return unless his reiment did so or unless he
was transferred to another reiment on active service. Nicholas was
somewhere with the army and had not sent a word since his last letter,
in which he had iven a detailed account of his meetin with Princess
Mary. The countess did not sleep at niht, or when she did fall asleep
dreamed that she saw her sons lyin dead. After many consultations and
conversations, the count at last devised means to tranquillize her. He
ot Petya transferred from Obolenski's reiment to Bezukhov's, which was
in trainin near Moscow. Thouh Petya would remain in the service, this
transfer would ive the countess the consolation of seein at least one
of her sons under her win, and she hoped to arrane matters for her
Petya so as not to let him o aain, but always et him appointed to
places where he could not possibly take part in a battle. As lon as
Nicholas alone was in daner the countess imained that she loved her
first-born more than all her other children and even reproached herself
for it; but when her younest: the scaperace who had been bad at
lessons, was always breakin thins in the house and makin himself a
nuisance to everybody, that snub-nosed Petya with his merry black eyes
and fresh rosy cheeks where soft down was just beinnin to show--when
he was thrown amid those bi, dreadful, cruel men who were fihtin
somewhere about somethin and apparently findin pleasure in it--then
his mother thouht she loved him more, much more, than all her other
children. The nearer the time came for Petya to return, the more uneasy
rew the countess. She bean to think she would never live to see such
happiness. The presence of Sonya, of her beloved Natasha, or even of her
husband irritated her. "What do I want with them? I want no one but
Petya," she thouht.

At the end of Auust the Rostovs received another letter from Nicholas.
He wrote from the province of Voronezh where he had been sent to procure
remounts, but that letter did not set the countess at ease. Knowin that
one son was out of daner she became the more anxious about Petya.

Thouh by the twentieth of Auust nearly all the Rostovs' acquaintances
had left Moscow, and thouh everybody tried to persuade the countess to
et away as quickly as possible, she would not hear of leavin before
her treasure, her adored Petya, returned. On the twenty-eihth of Auust
he arrived. The passionate tenderness with which his mother received him
did not please the sixteen-year-old officer. Thouh she concealed from
him her intention of keepin him under her win, Petya uessed her
desins, and instinctively fearin that he miht ive way to emotion
when with her--miht "become womanish" as he termed it to himself--he
treated her coldly, avoided her, and durin his stay in Moscow attached
himself exclusively to Natasha for whom he had always had a particularly
brotherly tenderness, almost lover-like.

Owin to the count's customary carelessness nothin was ready for their
departure by the twenty-eihth of Auust and the carts that were to come
from their Ryazan and Moscow estates to remove their household
belonins did not arrive till the thirtieth.

From the twenty-eihth till the thirty-first all Moscow was in a bustle
and commotion. Every day thousands of men wounded at Borodino were
brouht in by the Doroomilov ate and taken to various parts of Moscow,
and thousands of carts conveyed the inhabitants and their possessions
out by the other ates. In spite of Rostopchin's broadsheets, or because
of them or independently of them, the stranest and most contradictory
rumors were current in the town. Some said that no one was to be allowed
to leave the city, others on the contrary said that all the icons had
been taken out of the churches and everybody was to be ordered to leave.
Some said there had been another battle after Borodino at which the
French had been routed, while others on the contrary reported that the
Russian army had been destroyed. Some talked about the Moscow militia
which, preceded by the clery, would o to the Three Hills; others
whispered that Auustin had been forbidden to leave, that traitors had
been seized, that the peasants were riotin and robbin people on their
way from Moscow, and so on. But all this was only talk; in reality
(thouh the Council of Fili, at which it was decided to abandon Moscow,
had not yet been held) both those who went away and those who remained
behind felt, thouh they did not show it, that Moscow would certainly be
abandoned, and that they ouht to et away as quickly as possible and
save their belonins. It was felt that everythin would suddenly break
up and chane, but up to the first of September nothin had done so. As
a criminal who is bein led to execution knows that he must die
immediately, but yet looks about him and straihtens the cap that is
awry on his head, so Moscow involuntarily continued its wonted life,
thouh it knew that the time of its destruction was near when the
conditions of life to which its people were accustomed to submit would
be completely upset.

Durin the three days precedin the occupation of Moscow the whole
Rostov family was absorbed in various activities. The head of the
family, Count Ilya Rostov, continually drove about the city collectin
the current rumors from all sides and ave superficial and hasty orders
at home about the preparations for their departure.

The countess watched the thins bein packed, was dissatisfied with
everythin, was constantly in pursuit of Petya who was always runnin
away from her, and was jealous of Natasha with whom he spent all his
time. Sonya alone directed the practical side of matters by ettin
thins packed. But of late Sonya had been particularly sad and silent.
Nicholas' letter in which he mentioned Princess Mary had elicited, in
her presence, joyous comments from the countess, who saw an intervention
of Providence in this meetin of the princess and Nicholas.

"I was never pleased at Bolkonski's enaement to Natasha," said the
countess, "but I always wanted Nicholas to marry the princess, and had a
presentiment that it would happen. What a ood thin it would be!"

Sonya felt that this was true: that the only possibility of retrievin
the Rostovs' affairs was by Nicholas marryin a rich woman, and that the
princess was a ood match. It was very bitter for her. But despite her
rief, or perhaps just because of it, she took on herself all the
difficult work of directin the storin and packin of their thins and
was busy for whole days. The count and countess turned to her when they
had any orders to ive. Petya and Natasha on the contrary, far from
helpin their parents, were enerally a nuisance and a hindrance to
everyone. Almost all day lon the house resounded with their runnin
feet, their cries, and their spontaneous lauhter. They lauhed and were
ay not because there was any reason to lauh, but because aiety and
mirth were in their hearts and so everythin that happened was a cause
for aiety and lauhter to them. Petya was in hih spirits because
havin left home a boy he had returned (as everybody told him) a fine
youn man, because he was at home, because he had left Belaya Tserkov
where there was no hope of soon takin part in a battle and had come to
Moscow where there was to be fihtin in a few days, and chiefly because
Natasha, whose lead he always followed, was in hih spirits. Natasha was
ay because she had been sad too lon and now nothin reminded her of
the cause of her sadness, and because she was feelin well. She was also
happy because she had someone to adore her: the adoration of others was
a lubricant the wheels of her machine needed to make them run freely--
and Petya adored her. Above all, they were ay because there was a war
near Moscow, there would be fihtin at the town ates, arms were bein
iven out, everybody was escapin--oin away somewhere, and in eneral
somethin extraordinary was happenin, and that is always excitin,
especially to the youn.




CHAPTER XIII

On Saturday, the thirty-first of Auust, everythin in the Rostovs'
house seemed topsy-turvy. All the doors were open, all the furniture was
bein carried out or moved about, and the mirrors and pictures had been
taken down. There were trunks in the rooms, and hay, wrappin paper, and
ropes were scattered about. The peasants and house serfs carryin out
the thins were treadin heavily on the parquet floors. The yard was
crowded with peasant carts, some loaded hih and already corded up,
others still empty.

The voices and footsteps of the many servants and of the peasants who
had come with the carts resounded as they shouted to one another in the
yard and in the house. The count had been out since mornin. The
countess had a headache brouht on by all the noise and turmoil and was
lyin down in the new sittin room with a vinear compress on her head.
Petya was not at home, he had one to visit a friend with whom he meant
to obtain a transfer from the militia to the active army. Sonya was in
the ballroom lookin after the packin of the lass and china. Natasha
was sittin on the floor of her dismantled room with dresses, ribbons,
and scarves strewn all about her, azin fixedly at the floor and
holdin in her hands the old ball dress (already out of fashion) which
she had worn at her first Petersbur ball.

Natasha was ashamed of doin nothin when everyone else was so busy, and
several times that mornin had tried to set to work, but her heart was
not in it, and she could not and did not know how to do anythin except
with all her heart and all her miht. For a while she had stood beside
Sonya while the china was bein packed and tried to help, but soon ave
it up and went to her room to pack her own thins. At first she found it
amusin to ive away dresses and ribbons to the maids, but when that was
done and what was left had still to be packed, she found it dull.

"Dunyasha, you pack! You will, won't you, dear?" And when Dunyasha
willinly promised to do it all for her, Natasha sat down on the floor,
took her old ball dress, and fell into a reverie quite unrelated to what
ouht to have occupied her thouhts now. She was roused from her reverie
by the talk of the maids in the next room (which was theirs) and by the
sound of their hurried footsteps oin to the back porch. Natasha ot up
and looked out of the window. An enormously lon row of carts full of
wounded men had stopped in the street.

The housekeeper, the old nurse, the cooks, coachmen, maids, footmen,
postilions, and scullions stood at the ate, starin at the wounded.

Natasha, throwin a clean pocket handkerchief over her hair and holdin
an end of it in each hand, went out into the street.

The former housekeeper, old Mavra Kuzminichna, had stepped out of the
crowd by the ate, one up to a cart with a hood constructed of bast
mats, and was speakin to a pale youn officer who lay inside. Natasha
moved a few steps forward and stopped shyly, still holdin her
handkerchief, and listened to what the housekeeper was sayin.

"Then you have nobody in Moscow?" she was sayin. "You would be more
comfortable somewhere in a house... in ours, for instance... the family
are leavin."

"I don't know if it would be allowed," replied the officer in a weak
voice. "Here is our commandin officer... ask him," and he pointed to a
stout major who was walkin back alon the street past the row of carts.

Natasha lanced with frihtened eyes at the face of the wounded officer
and at once went to meet the major.

"May the wounded men stay in our house?" she asked.

The major raised his hand to his cap with a smile.

"Which one do you want, Ma'am'selle?" said he, screwin up his eyes and
smilin.

Natasha quietly repeated her question, and her face and whole manner
were so serious, thouh she was still holdin the ends of her
handkerchief, that the major ceased smilin and after some reflection--
as if considerin in how far the thin was possible--replied in the
affirmative.

"Oh yes, why not? They may," he said.

With a sliht inclination of her head, Natasha stepped back quickly to
Mavra Kuzminichna, who stood talkin compassionately to the officer.

"They may. He says they may!" whispered Natasha.

The cart in which the officer lay was turned into the Rostovs' yard, and
dozens of carts with wounded men bean at the invitation of the
townsfolk to turn into the yards and to draw up at the entrances of the
houses in Povarskaya Street. Natasha was evidently pleased to be dealin
with new people outside the ordinary routine of her life. She and Mavra
Kuzminichna tried to et as many of the wounded as possible into their
yard.

"Your Papa must be told, thouh," said Mavra Kuzminichna.

"Never mind, never mind, what does it matter? For one day we can move
into the drawin room. They can have all our half of the house."

"There now, youn lady, you do take thins into your head! Even if we
put them into the win, the men's room, or the nurse's room, we must ask
permission."

"Well, I'll ask."

Natasha ran into the house and went on tiptoe throuh the half-open door
into the sittin room, where there was a smell of vinear and Hoffman's
drops.

"Are you asleep, Mamma?"

"Oh, what sleep-?" said the countess, wakin up just as she was droppin
into a doze.

"Mamma darlin!" said Natasha, kneelin by her mother and brinin her
face close to her mother's, "I am sorry, forive me, I'll never do it
aain; I woke you up! Mavra Kuzminichna has sent me: they have brouht
some wounded here--officers. Will you let them come? They have nowhere
to o. I knew you'd let them come!" she said quickly all in one breath.

"What officers? Whom have they brouht? I don't understand anythin
about it," said the countess.

Natasha lauhed, and the countess too smiled slihtly.

"I knew you'd ive permission... so I'll tell them," and, havin kissed
her mother, Natasha ot up and went to the door.

In the hall she met her father, who had returned with bad news.

"We've stayed too lon!" said the count with involuntary vexation. "The
club is closed and the police are leavin."

"Papa, is it all riht--I've invited some of the wounded into the
house?" said Natasha.

"Of course it is," he answered absently. "That's not the point. I be
you not to indule in trifles now, but to help to pack, and tomorrow we
must o, o, o!...."

And the count ave a similar order to the major-domo and the servants.

At dinner Petya havin returned home told them the news he had heard. He
said the people had been ettin arms in the Kremlin, and that thouh
Rostopchin's broadsheet had said that he would sound a call two or three
days in advance, the order had certainly already been iven for everyone
to o armed to the Three Hills tomorrow, and that there would be a bi
battle there.

The countess looked with timid horror at her son's eaer, excited face
as he said this. She realized that if she said a word about his not
oin to the battle (she knew he enjoyed the thouht of the impendin
enaement) he would say somethin about men, honor, and the fatherland-
-somethin senseless, masculine, and obstinate which there would be no
contradictin, and her plans would be spoiled; and so, hopin to arrane
to leave before then and take Petya with her as their protector and
defender, she did not answer him, but after dinner called the count
aside and implored him with tears to take her away quickly, that very
niht if possible. With a woman's involuntary lovin cunnin she, who
till then had not shown any alarm, said that she would die of friht if
they did not leave that very niht. Without any pretense she was now
afraid of everythin.




CHAPTER XIV

Madame Schoss, who had been out to visit her dauhter, increased the
countess' fears still more by tellin what she had seen at a spirit
dealer's in Myasnitski Street. When returnin by that street she had
been unable to pass because of a drunken crowd riotin in front of the
shop. She had taken a cab and driven home by a side street and the
cabman had told her that the people were breakin open the barrels at
the drink store, havin received orders to do so.

After dinner the whole Rostov household set to work with enthusiastic
haste packin their belonins and preparin for their departure. The
old count, suddenly settin to work, kept passin from the yard to the
house and back aain, shoutin confused instructions to the hurryin
people, and flurryin them still more. Petya directed thins in the
yard. Sonya, owin to the count's contradictory orders, lost her head
and did not know what to do. The servants ran noisily about the house
and yard, shoutin and disputin. Natasha, with the ardor characteristic
of all she did suddenly set to work too. At first her intervention in
the business of packin was received skeptically. Everybody expected
some prank from her and did not wish to obey her; but she resolutely and
passionately demanded obedience, rew anry and nearly cried because
they did not heed her, and at last succeeded in makin them believe her.
Her first exploit, which cost her immense effort and established her
authority, was the packin of the carpets. The count had valuable
obelin tapestries and Persian carpets in the house. When Natasha set to
work two cases were standin open in the ballroom, one almost full up
with crockery, the other with carpets. There was also much china
standin on the tables, and still more was bein brouht in from the
storeroom. A third case was needed and servants had one to fetch it.

"Sonya, wait a bit--we'll pack everythin into these," said Natasha.

"You can't, Miss, we have tried to," said the butler's assistant.

"No, wait a minute, please."

And Natasha bean rapidly takin out of the case dishes and plates
wrapped in paper.

"The dishes must o in here amon the carpets," said she.

"Why, it's a mercy if we can et the carpets alone into three cases,"
said the butler's assistant.

"Oh, wait, please!" And Natasha bean rapidly and deftly sortin out the
thins. "These aren't needed," said she, puttin aside some plates of
Kiev ware. "These--yes, these must o amon the carpets," she said,
referrin to the Saxony china dishes.

"Don't, Natasha! Leave it alone! We'll et it all packed," ured Sonya
reproachfully.

"What a youn lady she is!" remarked the major-domo.

But Natasha would not ive in. She turned everythin out and bean
quickly repackin, decidin that the inferior Russian carpets and
unnecessary crockery should not be taken at all. When everythin had
been taken out of the cases, they recommenced packin, and it turned out
that when the cheaper thins not worth takin had nearly all been
rejected, the valuable ones really did all o into the two cases. Only
the lid of the case containin the carpets would not shut down. A few
more thins miht have been taken out, but Natasha insisted on havin
her own way. She packed, repacked, pressed, made the butler's assistant
and Petya--whom she had drawn into the business of packin--press on the
lid, and made desperate efforts herself.

"That's enouh, Natasha," said Sonya. "I see you were riht, but just
take out the top one."

"I won't!" cried Natasha, with one hand holdin back the hair that hun
over her perspirin face, while with the other she pressed down the
carpets. "Now press, Petya! Press, Vasilich, press hard!" she cried.

The carpets yielded and the lid closed; Natasha, clappin her hands,
screamed with deliht and tears fell from her eyes. But this only lasted
a moment. She at once set to work afresh and they now trusted her
completely. The count was not anry even when they told him that Natasha
had countermanded an order of his, and the servants now came to her to
ask whether a cart was sufficiently loaded, and whether it miht be
corded up. Thanks to Natasha's directions the work now went on
expeditiously, unnecessary thins were left, and the most valuable
packed as compactly as possible.

But hard as they all worked till quite late that niht, they could not
et everythin packed. The countess had fallen asleep and the count,
havin put off their departure till next mornin, went to bed.

Sonya and Natasha slept in the sittin room without undressin.

That niht another wounded man was driven down the Povarskaya, and Mavra
Kuzminichna, who was standin at the ate, had him brouht into the
Rostovs' yard. Mavra Kuzminichna concluded that he was a very important
man. He was bein conveyed in a caleche with a raised hood, and was
quite covered by an apron. On the box beside the driver sat a venerable
old attendant. A doctor and two soldiers followed the carriae in a
cart.

"Please come in here. The masters are oin away and the whole house
will be empty," said the old woman to the old attendant.

"Well, perhaps," said he with a sih. "We don't expect to et him home
alive! We have a house of our own in Moscow, but it's a lon way from
here, and there's nobody livin in it."

"Do us the honor to come in, there's plenty of everythin in the
master's house. Come in," said Mavra Kuzminichna. "Is he very ill?" she
asked.

The attendant made a hopeless esture.

"We don't expect to et him home! We must ask the doctor."

And the old servant ot down from the box and went up to the cart.

"All riht!" said the doctor.

The old servant returned to the caleche, looked into it, shook his head
disconsolately, told the driver to turn into the yard, and stopped
beside Mavra Kuzminichna.

"O, Lord Jesus Christ!" she murmured.

She invited them to take the wounded man into the house.

"The masters won't object..." she said.

But they had to avoid carryin the man upstairs, and so they took him
into the win and put him in the room that had been Madame Schoss'.

This wounded man was Prince Andrew Bolkonski.




CHAPTER XV

Moscow's last day had come. It was a clear briht autumn day, a Sunday.
The church bells everywhere were rinin for service, just as usual on
Sundays. Nobody seemed yet to realize what awaited the city.

Only two thins indicated the social condition of Moscow--the rabble,
that is the poor people, and the price of commodities. An enormous crowd
of factory hands, house serfs, and peasants, with whom some officials,
seminarists, and entry were minled, had one early that mornin to the
Three Hills. Havin waited there for Rostopchin who did not turn up,
they became convinced that Moscow would be surrendered, and then
dispersed all about the town to the public houses and cookshops. Prices
too that day indicated the state of affairs. The price of weapons, of
old, of carts and horses, kept risin, but the value of paper money and
city articles kept fallin, so that by midday there were instances of
carters removin valuable oods, such as cloth, and receivin in payment
a half of what they carted, while peasant horses were fetchin five
hundred rubles each, and furniture, mirrors, and bronzes were bein
iven away for nothin.

In the Rostovs' staid old-fashioned house the dissolution of former
conditions of life was but little noticeable. As to the serfs the only
indication was that three out of their hue retinue disappeared durin
the niht, but nothin was stolen; and as to the value of their
possessions, the thirty peasant carts that had come in from their
estates and which many people envied proved to be extremely valuable and
they were offered enormous sums of money for them. Not only were hue
sums offered for the horses and carts, but on the previous evenin and
early in the mornin of the first of September, orderlies and servants
sent by wounded officers came to the Rostovs' and wounded men draed
themselves there from the Rostovs' and from neihborin houses where
they were accommodated, entreatin the servants to try to et them a
lift out of Moscow. The major-domo to whom these entreaties were
addressed, thouh he was sorry for the wounded, resolutely refused,
sayin that he dare not even mention the matter to the count. Pity these
wounded men as one miht, it was evident that if they were iven one
cart there would be no reason to refuse another, or all the carts and
one's own carriaes as well. Thirty carts could not save all the wounded
and in the eneral catastrophe one could not disreard oneself and one's
own family. So thouht the major-domo on his master's behalf.

On wakin up that mornin Count Ilya Rostov left his bedroom softly, so
as not to wake the countess who had fallen asleep only toward mornin,
and came out to the porch in his lilac silk dressin own. In the yard
stood the carts ready corded. The carriaes were at the front porch. The
major-domo stood at the porch talkin to an elderly orderly and to a
pale youn officer with a bandaed arm. On seein the count the major-
domo made a sinificant and stern esture to them both to o away.

"Well, Vasilich, is everythin ready?" asked the count, and strokin his
bald head he looked ood-naturedly at the officer and the orderly and
nodded to them. (He liked to see new faces.)

"We can harness at once, your excellency."

"Well, that's riht. As soon as the countess wakes we'll be off, od
willin! What is it, entlemen?" he added, turnin to the officer. "Are
you stayin in my house?"

The officer came nearer and suddenly his face flushed crimson.

"Count, be so ood as to allow me... for od's sake, to et into some
corner of one of your carts! I have nothin here with me.... I shall be
all riht on a loaded cart..."

Before the officer had finished speakin the orderly made the same
request on behalf of his master.

"Oh, yes, yes, yes!" said the count hastily. "I shall be very pleased,
very pleased. Vasilich, you'll see to it. Just unload one or two carts.
Well, what of it... do what's necessary..." said the count, mutterin
some indefinite order.

But at the same moment an expression of warm ratitude on the officer's
face had already sealed the order. The count looked around him. In the
yard, at the ates, at the window of the wins, wounded officers and
their orderlies were to be seen. They were all lookin at the count and
movin toward the porch.

"Please step into the allery, your excellency," said the major-domo.
"What are your orders about the pictures?"

The count went into the house with him, repeatin his order not to
refuse the wounded who asked for a lift.

"Well, never mind, some of the thins can be unloaded," he added in a
soft, confidential voice, as thouh afraid of bein overheard.

At nine o'clock the countess woke up, and Matrena Timofeevna, who had
been her lady's maid before her marriae and now performed a sort of
chief endarme's duty for her, came to say that Madame Schoss was much
offended and the youn ladies' summer dresses could not be left behind.
On inquiry, the countess learned that Madame Schoss was offended because
her trunk had been taken down from its cart, and all the loads were
bein uncorded and the luae taken out of the carts to make room for
wounded men whom the count in the simplicity of his heart had ordered
that they should take with them. The countess sent for her husband.

"What is this, my dear? I hear that the luae is bein unloaded."

"You know, love, I wanted to tell you... Countess dear... an officer
came to me to ask for a few carts for the wounded. After all, ours are
thins that can be bouht but think what bein left behind means to
them!... Really now, in our own yard--we asked them in ourselves and
there are officers amon them.... You know, I think, my dear... let them
be taken... where's the hurry?"

The count spoke timidly, as he always did when talkin of money matters.
The countess was accustomed to this tone as a precursor of news of
somethin detrimental to the children's interests, such as the buildin
of a new allery or conservatory, the inauuration of a private theater
or an orchestra. She was accustomed always to oppose anythin announced
in that timid tone and considered it her duty to do so.

She assumed her dolefully submissive manner and said to her husband:
"Listen to me, Count, you have manaed matters so that we are ettin
nothin for the house, and now you wish to throw away all our--all the
children's property! You said yourself that we have a hundred thousand
rubles' worth of thins in the house. I don't consent, my dear, I don't!
Do as you please! It's the overnment's business to look after the
wounded; they know that. Look at the Lopukhins opposite, they cleared
out everythin two days ao. That's what other people do. It's only we
who are such fools. If you have no pity on me, have some for the
children."

Flourishin his arms in despair the count left the room without
replyin.

"Papa, what are you doin that for?" asked Natasha, who had followed him
into her mother's room.

"Nothin! What business is it of yours?" muttered the count anrily.

"But I heard," said Natasha. "Why does Mamma object?"

"What business is it of yours?" cried the count.

Natasha stepped up to the window and pondered.

"Papa! Here's Ber comin to see us," said she, lookin out of the
window.




CHAPTER XVI

Ber, the Rostovs' son-in-law, was already a colonel wearin the orders
of Vladimir and Anna, and he still filled the quiet and areeable post
of assistant to the head of the staff of the assistant commander of the
first division of the Second Army.

On the first of September he had come to Moscow from the army.

He had nothin to do in Moscow, but he had noticed that everyone in the
army was askin for leave to visit Moscow and had somethin to do there.
So he considered it necessary to ask for leave of absence for family and
domestic reasons.

Ber drove up to his father-in-law's house in his spruce little trap
with a pair of sleek roans, exactly like those of a certain prince. He
looked attentively at the carts in the yard and while oin up to the
porch took out a clean pocket handkerchief and tied a knot in it.

From the anteroom Ber ran with smooth thouh impatient steps into the
drawin room, where he embraced the count, kissed the hands of Natasha
and Sonya, and hastened to inquire after "Mamma's" health.

"Health, at a time like this?" said the count. "Come, tell us the news!
Is the army retreatin or will there be another battle?"

"od Almihty alone can decide the fate of our fatherland, Papa," said
Ber. "The army is burnin with a spirit of heroism and the leaders, so
to say, have now assembled in council. No one knows what is comin. But
in eneral I can tell you, Papa, that such a heroic spirit, the truly
antique valor of the Russian army, which they--which it" (he corrected
himself) "has shown or displayed in the battle of the twenty-sixth--
there are no words worthy to do it justice! I tell you, Papa" (he smote
himself on the breast as a eneral he had heard speakin had done, but
Ber did it a trifle late for he should have struck his breast at the
words "Russian army"), "I tell you frankly that we, the commanders, far
from havin to ure the men on or anythin of that kind, could hardly
restrain those... those... yes, those exploits of antique valor," he
went on rapidly. "eneral Barclay de Tolly risked his life everywhere at
the head of the troops, I can assure you. Our corps was stationed on a
hillside. You can imaine!"

And Ber related all that he remembered of the various tales he had
heard those days. Natasha watched him with an intent aze that confused
him, as if she were tryin to find in his face the answer to some
question.

"Altoether such heroism as was displayed by the Russian warriors cannot
be imained or adequately praised!" said Ber, lancin round at
Natasha, and as if anxious to conciliate her, replyin to her intent
look with a smile. "'Russia is not in Moscow, she lives in the hearts of
her sons!' Isn't it so, Papa?" said he.

Just then the countess came in from the sittin room with a weary and
dissatisfied expression. Ber hurriedly jumped up, kissed her hand,
asked about her health, and, swayin his head from side to side to
express sympathy, remained standin beside her.

"Yes, Mamma, I tell you sincerely that these are hard and sad times for
every Russian. But why are you so anxious? You have still time to et
away...."

"I can't think what the servants are about," said the countess, turnin
to her husband. "I have just been told that nothin is ready yet.
Somebody after all must see to thins. One misses Mitenka at such times.
There won't be any end to it."

The count was about to say somethin, but evidently restrained himself.
He ot up from his chair and went to the door.

At that moment Ber drew out his handkerchief as if to blow his nose
and, seein the knot in it, pondered, shakin his head sadly and
sinificantly.

"And I have a reat favor to ask of you, Papa," said he.

"Hm..." said the count, and stopped.

"I was drivin past Yusupov's house just now," said Ber with a lauh,
"when the steward, a man I know, ran out and asked me whether I wouldn't
buy somethin. I went in out of curiosity, you know, and there is a
small chiffonier and a dressin table. You know how dear Vera wanted a
chiffonier like that and how we had a dispute about it." (At the mention
of the chiffonier and dressin table Ber involuntarily chaned his tone
to one of pleasure at his admirable domestic arranements.) "And it's
such a beauty! It pulls out and has a secret Enlish drawer, you know!
And dear Vera has lon wanted one. I wish to ive her a surprise, you
see. I saw so many of those peasant carts in your yard. Please let me
have one, I will pay the man well, and..."

The count frowned and couhed.

"Ask the countess, I don't ive orders."

"If it's inconvenient, please don't," said Ber. "Only I so wanted it,
for dear Vera's sake."

"Oh, o to the devil, all of you! To the devil, the devil, the devil..."
cried the old count. "My head's in a whirl!"

And he left the room. The countess bean to cry.

"Yes, Mamma! Yes, these are very hard times!" said Ber.

Natasha left the room with her father and, as if findin it difficult to
reach some decision, first followed him and then ran downstairs.
