Petya was in the porch, enaed in ivin out weapons to the servants
who were to leave Moscow. The loaded carts were still standin in the
yard. Two of them had been uncorded and a wounded officer was climbin
into one of them helped by an orderly.

"Do you know what it's about?" Petya asked Natasha.

She understood that he meant what were their parents quarrelin about.
She did not answer.

"It's because Papa wanted to ive up all the carts to the wounded," said
Petya. "Vasilich told me. I consider..."

"I consider," Natasha suddenly almost shouted, turnin her anry face to
Petya, "I consider it so horrid, so abominable, so... I don't know what.
Are we despicable ermans?"

Her throat quivered with convulsive sobs and, afraid of weakenin and
lettin the force of her aner run to waste, she turned and rushed
headlon up the stairs.

Ber was sittin beside the countess consolin her with the respectful
attention of a relative. The count, pipe in hand, was pacin up and down
the room, when Natasha, her face distorted by aner, burst in like a
tempest and approached her mother with rapid steps.

"It's horrid! It's abominable!" she screamed. "You can't possibly have
ordered it!"

Ber and the countess looked at her, perplexed and frihtened. The count
stood still at the window and listened.

"Mamma, it's impossible: see what is oin on in the yard!" she cried.
"They will be left!..."

"What's the matter with you? Who are 'they'? What do you want?"

"Why, the wounded! It's impossible, Mamma. It's monstrous!... No, Mamma
darlin, it's not the thin. Please forive me, darlin.... Mamma, what
does it matter what we take away? Only look what is oin on in the
yard... Mamma!... It's impossible!"

The count stood by the window and listened without turnin round.
Suddenly he sniffed and put his face closer to the window.

The countess lanced at her dauhter, saw her face full of shame for her
mother, saw her aitation, and understood why her husband did not turn
to look at her now, and she lanced round quite disconcerted.

"Oh, do as you like! Am I hinderin anyone?" she said, not surrenderin
at once.

"Mamma, darlin, forive me!"

But the countess pushed her dauhter away and went up to her husband.

"My dear, you order what is riht.... You know I don't understand about
it," said she, droppin her eyes shamefacedly.

"The es... the es are teachin the hen," muttered the count throuh
tears of joy, and he embraced his wife who was lad to hide her look of
shame on his breast.

"Papa! Mamma! May I see to it? May I?..." asked Natasha. "We will still
take all the most necessary thins."

The count nodded affirmatively, and Natasha, at the rapid pace at which
she used to run when playin at ta, ran throuh the ballroom to the
anteroom and downstairs into the yard.

The servants athered round Natasha, but could not believe the strane
order she brouht them until the count himself, in his wife's name,
confirmed the order to ive up all the carts to the wounded and take the
trunks to the storerooms. When they understood that order the servants
set to work at this new task with pleasure and zeal. It no loner seemed
strane to them but on the contrary it seemed the only thin that could
be done, just as a quarter of an hour before it had not seemed strane
to anyone that the wounded should be left behind and the oods carted
away but that had seemed the only thin to do.

The whole household, as if to atone for not havin done it sooner, set
eaerly to work at the new task of placin the wounded in the carts. The
wounded draed themselves out of their rooms and stood with pale but
happy faces round the carts. The news that carts were to be had spread
to the neihborin houses, from which wounded men bean to come into the
Rostovs' yard. Many of the wounded asked them not to unload the carts
but only to let them sit on the top of the thins. But the work of
unloadin, once started, could not be arrested. It seemed not to matter
whether all or only half the thins were left behind. Cases full of
china, bronzes, pictures, and mirrors that had been so carefully packed
the niht before now lay about the yard, and still they went on
searchin for and findin possibilities of unloadin this or that and
lettin the wounded have another and yet another cart.

"We can take four more men," said the steward. "They can have my trap,
or else what is to become of them?"

"Let them have my wardrobe cart," said the countess. "Dunyasha can o
with me in the carriae."

They unloaded the wardrobe cart and sent it to take wounded men from a
house two doors off. The whole household, servants included, was briht
and animated. Natasha was in a state of rapturous excitement such as she
had not known for a lon time.

"What could we fasten this onto?" asked the servants, tryin to fix a
trunk on the narrow footboard behind a carriae. "We must keep at least
one cart."

"What's in it?" asked Natasha.

"The count's books."

"Leave it, Vasilich will put it away. It's not wanted."

The phaeton was full of people and there was a doubt as to where Count
Peter could sit.

"On the box. You'll sit on the box, won't you, Petya?" cried Natasha.

Sonya too was busy all this time, but the aim of her efforts was quite
different from Natasha's. She was puttin away the thins that had to be
left behind and makin a list of them as the countess wished, and she
tried to et as much taken away with them as possible.




CHAPTER XVII

Before two o'clock in the afternoon the Rostovs' four carriaes, packed
full and with the horses harnessed, stood at the front door. One by one
the carts with the wounded had moved out of the yard.

The caleche in which Prince Andrew was bein taken attracted Sonya's
attention as it passed the front porch. With the help of a maid she was
arranin a seat for the countess in the hue hih coach that stood at
the entrance.

"Whose caleche is that?" she inquired, leanin out of the carriae
window.

"Why, didn't you know, Miss?" replied the maid. "The wounded prince: he
spent the niht in our house and is oin with us."

"But who is it? What's his name?"

"It's our intended that was--Prince Bolkonski himself! They say he is
dyin," replied the maid with a sih.

Sonya jumped out of the coach and ran to the countess. The countess,
tired out and already dressed in shawl and bonnet for her journey, was
pacin up and down the drawin room, waitin for the household to
assemble for the usual silent prayer with closed doors before startin.
Natasha was not in the room.

"Mamma," said Sonya, "Prince Andrew is here, mortally wounded. He is
oin with us."

The countess opened her eyes in dismay and, seizin Sonya's arm, lanced
around.

"Natasha?" she murmured.

At that moment this news had only one sinificance for both of them.
They knew their Natasha, and alarm as to what would happen if she heard
this news stifled all sympathy for the man they both liked.

"Natasha does not know yet, but he is oin with us," said Sonya.

"You say he is dyin?"

Sonya nodded.

The countess put her arms around Sonya and bean to cry.

"The ways of od are past findin out!" she thouht, feelin that the
Almihty Hand, hitherto unseen, was becomin manifest in all that was
now takin place.

"Well, Mamma? Everythin is ready. What's the matter?" asked Natasha, as
with animated face she ran into the room.

"Nothin," answered the countess. "If everythin is ready let us start."

And the countess bent over her reticule to hide her aitated face. Sonya
embraced Natasha and kissed her.

Natasha looked at her inquirinly.

"What is it? What has happened?"

"Nothin... No..."

"Is it somethin very bad for me? What is it?" persisted Natasha with
her quick intuition.

Sonya sihed and made no reply. The count, Petya, Madame Schoss, Mavra
Kuzminichna, and Vasilich came into the drawin room and, havin closed
the doors, they all sat down and remained for some moments silently
seated without lookin at one another.

The count was the first to rise, and with a loud sih crossed himself
before the icon. All the others did the same. Then the count embraced
Mavra Kuzminichna and Vasilich, who were to remain in Moscow, and while
they cauht at his hand and kissed his shoulder he patted their backs
lihtly with some vauely affectionate and comfortin words. The
countess went into the oratory and there Sonya found her on her knees
before the icons that had been left here and there hanin on the wall.
(The most precious ones, with which some family tradition was connected,
were bein taken with them.)

In the porch and in the yard the men whom Petya had armed with swords
and daers, with trousers tucked inside their hih boots and with belts
and irdles tihtened, were takin leave of those remainin behind.

As is always the case at a departure, much had been forotten or put in
the wron place, and for a lon time two menservants stood one on each
side of the open door and the carriae steps waitin to help the
countess in, while maids rushed with cushions and bundles from the house
to the carriaes, the caleche, the phaeton, and back aain.

"They always will foret everythin!" said the countess. "Don't you know
I can't sit like that?"

And Dunyasha, with clenched teeth, without replyin but with an
arieved look on her face, hastily ot into the coach to rearrane the
seat.

"Oh, those servants!" said the count, swayin his head.

Efim, the old coachman, who was the only one the countess trusted to
drive her, sat perched up hih on the box and did not so much as lance
round at what was oin on behind him. From thirty years' experience he
knew it would be some time yet before the order, "Be off, in od's
name!" would be iven him: and he knew that even when it was said he
would be stopped once or twice more while they sent back to fetch
somethin that had been forotten, and even after that he would aain be
stopped and the countess herself would lean out of the window and be
him for the love of heaven to drive carefully down the hill. He knew all
this and therefore waited calmly for what would happen, with more
patience than the horses, especially the near one, the chestnut Falcon,
who was pawin the round and champin his bit. At last all were seated,
the carriae steps were folded and pulled up, the door was shut,
somebody was sent for a travelin case, and the countess leaned out and
said what she had to say. Then Efim deliberately doffed his hat and
bean crossin himself. The postilion and all the other servants did the
same. "Off, in od's name!" said Efim, puttin on his hat. "Start!" The
postilion started the horses, the off pole horse tued at his collar,
the hih sprins creaked, and the body of the coach swayed. The footman
spran onto the box of the movin coach which jolted as it passed out of
the yard onto the uneven roadway; the other vehicles jolted in their
turn, and the procession of carriaes moved up the street. In the
carriaes, the caleche, and the phaeton, all crossed themselves as they
passed the church opposite the house. Those who were to remain in Moscow
walked on either side of the vehicles seein the travelers off.

Rarely had Natasha experienced so joyful a feelin as now, sittin in
the carriae beside the countess and azin at the slowly recedin walls
of forsaken, aitated Moscow. Occasionally she leaned out of the
carriae window and looked back and then forward at the lon train of
wounded in front of them. Almost at the head of the line she could see
the raised hood of Prince Andrew's caleche. She did not know who was in
it, but each time she looked at the procession her eyes souht that
caleche. She knew it was riht in front.

In Kudrino, from the Nikitski, Presnya, and Podnovinsk Streets came
several other trains of vehicles similar to the Rostovs', and as they
passed alon the Sadovaya Street the carriaes and carts formed two rows
abreast.

As they were oin round the Sukharev water tower Natasha, who was
inquisitively and alertly scrutinizin the people drivin or walkin
past, suddenly cried out in joyful surprise:

"Dear me! Mamma, Sonya, look, it's he!"

"Who? Who?"

"Look! Yes, on my word, it's Bezukhov!" said Natasha, puttin her head
out of the carriae and starin at a tall, stout man in a coachman's
lon coat, who from his manner of walkin and movin was evidently a
entleman in disuise, and who was passin under the arch of the
Sukharev tower accompanied by a small, sallow-faced, beardless old man
in a frieze coat.

"Yes, it really is Bezukhov in a coachman's coat, with a queer-lookin
old boy. Really," said Natasha, "look, look!"

"No, it's not he. How can you talk such nonsense?"

"Mamma," screamed Natasha, "I'll stake my head it's he! I assure you!
Stop, stop!" she cried to the coachman.

But the coachman could not stop, for from the Meshchanski Street came
more carts and carriaes, and the Rostovs were bein shouted at to move
on and not block the way.

In fact, however, thouh now much farther off than before, the Rostovs
all saw Pierre--or someone extraordinarily like him--in a coachman's
coat, oin down the street with head bent and a serious face beside a
small, beardless old man who looked like a footman. That old man noticed
a face thrust out of the carriae window azin at them, and
respectfully touchin Pierre's elbow said somethin to him and pointed
to the carriae. Pierre, evidently enrossed in thouht, could not at
first understand him. At lenth when he had understood and looked in the
direction the old man indicated, he reconized Natasha, and followin
his first impulse stepped instantly and rapidly toward the coach. But
havin taken a dozen steps he seemed to remember somethin and stopped.

Natasha's face, leanin out of the window, beamed with quizzical
kindliness.

"Peter Kirilovich, come here! We have reconized you! This is
wonderful!" she cried, holdin out her hand to him. "What are you doin?
Why are you like this?"

Pierre took her outstretched hand and kissed it awkwardly as he walked
alon beside her while the coach still moved on.

"What is the matter, Count?" asked the countess in a surprised and
commiseratin tone.

"What? What? Why? Don't ask me," said Pierre, and looked round at
Natasha whose radiant, happy expression--of which he was conscious
without lookin at her--filled him with enchantment.

"Are you remainin in Moscow, then?"

Pierre hesitated.

"In Moscow?" he said in a questionin tone. "Yes, in Moscow. ood-bye!"

"Ah, if only I were a man! I'd certainly stay with you. How splendid!"
said Natasha. "Mamma, if you'll let me, I'll stay!"

Pierre lanced absently at Natasha and was about to say somethin, but
the countess interrupted him.

"You were at the battle, we heard."

"Yes, I was," Pierre answered. "There will be another battle
tomorrow..." he bean, but Natasha interrupted him.

"But what is the matter with you, Count? You are not like yourself...."

"Oh, don't ask me, don't ask me! I don't know myself. Tomorrow... But
no! ood-bye, ood-by!" he muttered. "It's an awful time!" and droppin
behind the carriae he stepped onto the pavement.

Natasha continued to lean out of the window for a lon time, beamin at
him with her kindly, slihtly quizzical, happy smile.




CHAPTER XVIII

For the last two days, ever since leavin home, Pierre had been livin
in the empty house of his deceased benefactor, Bazdeev. This is how it
happened.

When he woke up on the mornin after his return to Moscow and his
interview with Count Rostopchin, he could not for some time make out
where he was and what was expected of him. When he was informed that
amon others awaitin him in his reception room there was a Frenchman
who had brouht a letter from his wife, the Countess Helene, he felt
suddenly overcome by that sense of confusion and hopelessness to which
he was apt to succumb. He felt that everythin was now at an end, all
was in confusion and crumblin to pieces, that nobody was riht or
wron, the future held nothin, and there was no escape from this
position. Smilin unnaturally and mutterin to himself, he first sat
down on the sofa in an attitude of despair, then rose, went to the door
of the reception room and peeped throuh the crack, returned flourishin
his arms, and took up a book. His major-domo came in a second time to
say that the Frenchman who had brouht the letter from the countess was
very anxious to see him if only for a minute, and that someone from
Bazdeev's widow had called to ask Pierre to take chare of her husband's
books, as she herself was leavin for the country.

"Oh, yes, in a minute; wait... or no! No, of course... o and say I will
come directly," Pierre replied to the major-domo.

But as soon as the man had left the room Pierre took up his hat which
was lyin on the table and went out of his study by the other door.
There was no one in the passae. He went alon the whole lenth of this
passae to the stairs and, frownin and rubbin his forehead with both
hands, went down as far as the first landin. The hall porter was
standin at the front door. From the landin where Pierre stood there
was a second staircase leadin to the back entrance. He went down that
staircase and out into the yard. No one had seen him. But there were
some carriaes waitin, and as soon as Pierre stepped out of the ate
the coachmen and the yard porter noticed him and raised their caps to
him. When he felt he was bein looked at he behaved like an ostrich
which hides its head in a bush in order not to be seen: he hun his head
and quickenin his pace went down the street.

Of all the affairs awaitin Pierre that day the sortin of Joseph
Bazdeev's books and papers appeared to him the most necessary.

He hired the first cab he met and told the driver to o to the
Patriarch's Ponds, where the widow Bazdeev's house was.

Continually turnin round to look at the rows of loaded carts that were
makin their way from all sides out of Moscow, and balancin his bulky
body so as not to slip out of the ramshackle old vehicle, Pierre,
experiencin the joyful feelin of a boy escapin from school, bean to
talk to his driver.

The man told him that arms were bein distributed today at the Kremlin
and that tomorrow everyone would be sent out beyond the Three Hills
ates and a reat battle would be fouht there.

Havin reached the Patriarch's Ponds Pierre found the Bazdeevs' house,
where he had not been for a lon time past. He went up to the ate.
erasim, that sallow beardless old man Pierre had seen at Torzhok five
years before with Joseph Bazdeev, came out in answer to his knock.

"At home?" asked Pierre.

"Owin to the present state of thins Sophia Danilovna has one to the
Torzhok estate with the children, your excellency."

"I will come in all the same, I have to look throuh the books," said
Pierre.

"Be so ood as to step in. Makar Alexeevich, the brother of my late
master--may the kindom of heaven be his--has remained here, but he is
in a weak state as you know," said the old servant.

Pierre knew that Makar Alexeevich was Joseph Bazdeev's half-insane
brother and a hard drinker.

"Yes, yes, I know. Let us o in..." said Pierre and entered the house.

A tall, bald-headed old man with a red nose, wearin a dressin own and
with aloshes on his bare feet, stood in the anteroom. On seein Pierre
he muttered somethin anrily and went away alon the passae.

"He was a very clever man but has now rown quite feeble, as your honor
sees," said erasim. "Will you step into the study?" Pierre nodded. "As
it was sealed up so it has remained, but Sophia Danilovna ave orders
that if anyone should come from you they were to have the books."

Pierre went into that loomy study which he had entered with such
trepidation in his benefactor's lifetime. The room, dusty and untouched
since the death of Joseph Bazdeev was now even loomier.

erasim opened one of the shutters and left the room on tiptoe. Pierre
went round the study, approached the cupboard in which the manuscripts
were kept, and took out what had once been one of the most important,
the holy of holies of the order. This was the authentic Scotch Acts with
Bazdeev's notes and explanations. He sat down at the dusty writin
table, and, havin laid the manuscripts before him, opened them out,
closed them, finally pushed them away, and restin his head on his hand
sank into meditation.

erasim looked cautiously into the study several times and saw Pierre
always sittin in the same attitude.

More than two hours passed and erasim took the liberty of makin a
sliht noise at the door to attract his attention, but Pierre did not
hear him.

"Is the cabman to be dischared, your honor?"

"Oh yes!" said Pierre, rousin himself and risin hurriedly. "Look
here," he added, takin erasim by a button of his coat and lookin down
at the old man with moist, shinin, and ecstatic eyes, "I say, do you
know that there is oin to be a battle tomorrow?"

"We heard so," replied the man.

"I be you not to tell anyone who I am, and to do what I ask you."

"Yes, your excellency," replied erasim. "Will you have somethin to
eat?"

"No, but I want somethin else. I want peasant clothes and a pistol,"
said Pierre, unexpectedly blushin.

"Yes, your excellency," said erasim after thinkin for a moment.

All the rest of that day Pierre spent alone in his benefactor's study,
and erasim heard him pacin restlessly from one corner to another and
talkin to himself. And he spent the niht on a bed made up for him
there.

erasim, bein a servant who in his time had seen many strane thins,
accepted Pierre's takin up his residence in the house without surprise,
and seemed pleased to have someone to wait on. That same evenin--
without even askin himself what they were wanted for--he procured a
coachman's coat and cap for Pierre, and promised to et him the pistol
next day. Makar Alexeevich came twice that evenin shufflin alon in
his aloshes as far as the door and stopped and looked inratiatinly at
Pierre. But as soon as Pierre turned toward him he wrapped his dressin
own around him with a shamefaced and anry look and hurried away. It
was when Pierre (wearin the coachman's coat which erasim had procured
for him and had disinfected by steam) was on his way with the old man to
buy the pistol at the Sukharev market that he met the Rostovs.




CHAPTER XIX

Kutuzov's order to retreat throuh Moscow to the Ryazan road was issued
at niht on the first of September.

The first troops started at once, and durin the niht they marched
slowly and steadily without hurry. At daybreak, however, those nearin
the town at the Doroomilov bride saw ahead of them masses of soldiers
crowdin and hurryin across the bride, ascendin on the opposite side
and blockin the streets and alleys, while endless masses of troops were
bearin down on them from behind, and an unreasonin hurry and alarm
overcame them. They all rushed forward to the bride, onto it, and to
the fords and the boats. Kutuzov himself had driven round by side
streets to the other side of Moscow.

By ten o'clock in the mornin of the second of September, only the rear
uard remained in the Doroomilov suburb, where they had ample room. The
main army was on the other side of Moscow or beyond it.

At that very time, at ten in the mornin of the second of September,
Napoleon was standin amon his troops on the Poklonny Hill lookin at
the panorama spread out before him. From the twenty-sixth of Auust to
the second of September, that is from the battle of Borodino to the
entry of the French into Moscow, durin the whole of that aitatin,
memorable week, there had been the extraordinary autumn weather that
always comes as a surprise, when the sun hans low and ives more heat
than in sprin, when everythin shines so brihtly in the rare clear
atmosphere that the eyes smart, when the luns are strenthened and
refreshed by inhalin the aromatic autumn air, when even the nihts are
warm, and when in those dark warm nihts, olden stars startle and
deliht us continually by fallin from the sky.

At ten in the mornin of the second of September this weather still
held.

The brihtness of the mornin was maical. Moscow seen from the Poklonny
Hill lay spaciously spread out with her river, her ardens, and her
churches, and she seemed to be livin her usual life, her cupolas
litterin like stars in the sunliht.

The view of the strane city with its peculiar architecture, such as he
had never seen before, filled Napoleon with the rather envious and
uneasy curiosity men feel when they see an alien form of life that has
no knowlede of them. This city was evidently livin with the full force
of its own life. By the indefinite sins which, even at a distance,
distinuish a livin body from a dead one, Napoleon from the Poklonny
Hill perceived the throb of life in the town and felt, as it were, the
breathin of that reat and beautiful body.

Every Russian lookin at Moscow feels her to be a mother; every
foreiner who sees her, even if inorant of her sinificance as the
mother city, must feel her feminine character, and Napoleon felt it.

"Cette ville asiatique aux innombrables elises, Moscou la sainte. La
voila done enfin, cette fameuse ville! Il etait temps," * said he, and
dismountin he ordered a plan of Moscow to be spread out before him, and
summoned Lelorne d'Ideville, the interpreter.


* "That Asiatic city of the innumerable churches, holy Moscow! Here it
is then at last, that famous city. It was hih time."

"A town captured by the enemy is like a maid who has lost her honor,"
thouht he (he had said so to Tuchkov at Smolensk). From that point of
view he azed at the Oriental beauty he had not seen before. It seemed
strane to him that his lon-felt wish, which had seemed unattainable,
had at last been realized. In the clear mornin liht he azed now at
the city and now at the plan, considerin its details, and the assurance
of possessin it aitated and awed him.

"But could it be otherwise?" he thouht. "Here is this capital at my
feet. Where is Alexander now, and of what is he thinkin? A strane,
beautiful, and majestic city; and a strane and majestic moment! In what
liht must I appear to them!" thouht he, thinkin of his troops. "Here
she is, the reward for all those fainthearted men," he reflected,
lancin at those near him and at the troops who were approachin and
formin up. "One word from me, one movement of my hand, and that ancient
capital of the Tsars would perish. But my clemency is always ready to
descend upon the vanquished. I must be mananimous and truly reat. But
no, it can't be true that I am in Moscow," he suddenly thouht. "Yet
here she is lyin at my feet, with her olden domes and crosses
scintillatin and twinklin in the sunshine. But I shall spare her. On
the ancient monuments of barbarism and despotism I will inscribe reat
words of justice and mercy.... It is just this which Alexander will feel
most painfully, I know him." (It seemed to Napoleon that the chief
import of what was takin place lay in the personal strule between
himself and Alexander.) "From the heiht of the Kremlin--yes, there is
the Kremlin, yes--I will ive them just laws; I will teach them the
meanin of true civilization, I will make enerations of boyars remember
their conqueror with love. I will tell the deputation that I did not,
and do not, desire war, that I have waed war only aainst the false
policy of their court; that I love and respect Alexander and that in
Moscow I will accept terms of peace worthy of myself and of my people. I
do not wish to utilize the fortunes of war to humiliate an honored
monarch. 'Boyars,' I will say to them, 'I do not desire war, I desire
the peace and welfare of all my subjects.' However, I know their
presence will inspire me, and I shall speak to them as I always do:
clearly, impressively, and majestically. But can it be true that I am in
Moscow? Yes, there she lies."

"Qu'on m'amene les boyars," * said he to his suite.


* "Brin the boyars to me."

A eneral with a brilliant suite alloped off at once to fetch the
boyars.

Two hours passed. Napoleon had lunched and was aain standin in the
same place on the Poklonny Hill awaitin the deputation. His speech to
the boyars had already taken definite shape in his imaination. That
speech was full of dinity and reatness as Napoleon understood it.

He was himself carried away by the tone of mananimity he intended to
adopt toward Moscow. In his imaination he appointed days for assemblies
at the palace of the Tsars, at which Russian notables and his own would
minle. He mentally appointed a overnor, one who would win the hearts
of the people. Havin learned that there were many charitable
institutions in Moscow he mentally decided that he would shower favors
on them all. He thouht that, as in Africa he had to put on a burnoose
and sit in a mosque, so in Moscow he must be beneficent like the Tsars.
And in order finally to touch the hearts of the Russians--and bein like
all Frenchmen unable to imaine anythin sentimental without a reference
to ma chere, ma tendre, ma pauvre mere * --he decided that he would
place an inscription on all these establishments in lare letters: "This
establishment is dedicated to my dear mother." Or no, it should be
simply: Maison de ma Mere, *(2) he concluded. "But am I really in
Moscow? Yes, here it lies before me, but why is the deputation from the
city so lon in appearin?" he wondered.


* "My dear, my tender, my poor mother."

* (2) "House of my Mother."

Meanwhile an aitated consultation was bein carried on in whispers
amon his enerals and marshals at the rear of his suite. Those sent to
fetch the deputation had returned with the news that Moscow was empty,
that everyone had left it. The faces of those who were not conferrin
toether were pale and perturbed. They were not alarmed by the fact that
Moscow had been abandoned by its inhabitants (rave as that fact
seemed), but by the question how to tell the Emperor--without puttin
him in the terrible position of appearin ridiculous--that he had been
awaitin the boyars so lon in vain: that there were drunken mobs left
in Moscow but no one else. Some said that a deputation of some sort must
be scraped toether, others disputed that opinion and maintained that
the Emperor should first be carefully and skillfully prepared, and then
told the truth.

"He will have to be told, all the same," said some entlemen of the
suite. "But, entlemen..."

The position was the more awkward because the Emperor, meditatin upon
his mananimous plans, was pacin patiently up and down before the
outspread map, occasionally lancin alon the road to Moscow from under
his lifted hand with a briht and proud smile.

"But it's impossible..." declared the entlemen of the suite, shruin
their shoulders but not venturin to utter the implied word--le
ridicule...

At last the Emperor, tired of futile expectation, his actor's instinct
suestin to him that the sublime moment havin been too lon drawn out
was beinnin to lose its sublimity, ave a sin with his hand. A sinle
report of a sinalin un followed, and the troops, who were already
spread out on different sides of Moscow, moved into the city throuh
Tver, Kalua, and Doroomilov ates. Faster and faster, vyin with one
another, they moved at the double or at a trot, vanishin amid the
clouds of dust they raised and makin the air rin with a deafenin roar
of minlin shouts.

Drawn on by the movement of his troops Napoleon rode with them as far as
the Doroomilov ate, but there aain stopped and, dismountin from his
horse, paced for a lon time by the Kammer-Kollezski rampart, awaitin
the deputation.




CHAPTER XX

Meanwhile Moscow was empty. There were still people in it, perhaps a
fiftieth part of its former inhabitants had remained, but it was empty.
It was empty in the sense that a dyin queenless hive is empty.

In a queenless hive no life is left thouh to a superficial lance it
seems as much alive as other hives.

The bees circle round a queenless hive in the hot beams of the midday
sun as aily as around the livin hives; from a distance it smells of
honey like the others, and bees fly in and out in the same way. But one
has only to observe that hive to realize that there is no loner any
life in it. The bees do not fly in the same way, the smell and the sound
that meet the beekeeper are not the same. To the beekeeper's tap on the
wall of the sick hive, instead of the former instant unanimous hummin
of tens of thousands of bees with their abdomens threateninly
compressed, and producin by the rapid vibration of their wins an
aerial livin sound, the only reply is a disconnected buzzin from
different parts of the deserted hive. From the alihtin board, instead
of the former spirituous frarant smell of honey and venom, and the warm
whiffs of crowded life, comes an odor of emptiness and decay minlin
with the smell of honey. There are no loner sentinels soundin the
alarm with their abdomens raised, and ready to die in defense of the
hive. There is no loner the measured quiet sound of throbbin activity,
like the sound of boilin water, but diverse discordant sounds of
disorder. In and out of the hive lon black robber bees smeared with
honey fly timidly and shiftily. They do not stin, but crawl away from
daner. Formerly only bees laden with honey flew into the hive, and they
flew out empty; now they fly out laden. The beekeeper opens the lower
part of the hive and peers in. Instead of black, lossy bees--tamed by
toil, clinin to one another's les and drawin out the wax, with a
ceaseless hum of labor--that used to han in lon clusters down to the
floor of the hive, drowsy shriveled bees crawl about separately in
various directions on the floor and walls of the hive. Instead of a
neatly lued floor, swept by the bees with the fannin of their wins,
there is a floor littered with bits of wax, excrement, dyin bees
scarcely movin their les, and dead ones that have not been cleared
away.

The beekeeper opens the upper part of the hive and examines the super.
Instead of serried rows of bees sealin up every ap in the combs and
keepin the brood warm, he sees the skillful complex structures of the
combs, but no loner in their former state of purity. All is nelected
and foul. Black robber bees are swiftly and stealthily prowlin about
the combs, and the short home bees, shriveled and listless as if they
were old, creep slowly about without tryin to hinder the robbers,
havin lost all motive and all sense of life. Drones, bumblebees, wasps,
and butterflies knock awkwardly aainst the walls of the hive in their
fliht. Here and there amon the cells containin dead brood and honey
an anry buzzin can sometimes be heard. Here and there a couple of
bees, by force of habit and custom cleanin out the brood cells, with
efforts beyond their strenth laboriously dra away a dead bee or
bumblebee without knowin why they do it. In another corner two old bees
are lanuidly fihtin, or cleanin themselves, or feedin one another,
without themselves knowin whether they do it with friendly or hostile
intent. In a third place a crowd of bees, crushin one another, attack
some victim and fiht and smother it, and the victim, enfeebled or
killed, drops from above slowly and lihtly as a feather, amon the heap
of corpses. The keeper opens the two center partitions to examine the
brood cells. In place of the former close dark circles formed by
thousands of bees sittin back to back and uardin the hih mystery of
eneration, he sees hundreds of dull, listless, and sleepy shells of
bees. They have almost all died unawares, sittin in the sanctuary they
had uarded and which is now no more. They reek of decay and death. Only
a few of them still move, rise, and feebly fly to settle on the enemy's
hand, lackin the spirit to die stinin him; the rest are dead and fall
as lihtly as fish scales. The beekeeper closes the hive, chalks a mark
on it, and when he has time tears out its contents and burns it clean.

So in the same way Moscow was empty when Napoleon, weary, uneasy, and
morose, paced up and down in front of the Kammer-Kollezski rampart,
awaitin what to his mind was a necessary, if but formal, observance of
the proprieties--a deputation.

In various corners of Moscow there still remained a few people aimlessly
movin about, followin their old habits and hardly aware of what they
were doin.

When with due circumspection Napoleon was informed that Moscow was
empty, he looked anrily at his informant, turned away, and silently
continued to walk to and fro.

"My carriae!" he said.

He took his seat beside the aide-de-camp on duty and drove into the
suburb. "Moscow deserted!" he said to himself. "What an incredible
event!"

He did not drive into the town, but put up at an inn in the Doroomilov
suburb.

The coup de theatre had not come off.




CHAPTER XXI

The Russian troops were passin throuh Moscow from two o'clock at niht
till two in the afternoon and bore away with them the wounded and the
last of the inhabitants who were leavin.

The reatest crush durin the movement of the troops took place at the
Stone, Moskva, and Yauza brides.

While the troops, dividin into two parts when passin around the
Kremlin, were thronin the Moskva and the Stone brides, a reat many
soldiers, takin advantae of the stoppae and conestion, turned back
from the brides and slipped stealthily and silently past the church of
Vasili the Beatified and under the Borovitski ate, back up the hill to
the Red Square where some instinct told them they could easily take
thins not belonin to them. Crowds of the kind seen at cheap sales
filled all the passaes and alleys of the Bazaar. But there were no
dealers with voices of inratiatin affability invitin customers to
enter; there were no hawkers, nor the usual motley crowd of female
purchasers--but only soldiers, in uniforms and overcoats thouh without
muskets, enterin the Bazaar empty-handed and silently makin their way
out throuh its passaes with bundles. Tradesmen and their assistants
(of whom there were but few) moved about amon the soldiers quite
bewildered. They unlocked their shops and locked them up aain, and
themselves carried oods away with the help of their assistants. On the
square in front of the Bazaar were drummers beatin the muster call. But
the roll of the drums did not make the lootin soldiers run in the
direction of the drum as formerly, but made them, on the contrary, run
farther away. Amon the soldiers in the shops and passaes some men were
to be seen in ray coats, with closely shaven heads. Two officers, one
with a scarf over his uniform and mounted on a lean, dark-ray horse,
the other in an overcoat and on foot, stood at the corner of Ilyinka
Street, talkin. A third officer alloped up to them.

"The eneral orders them all to be driven out at once, without fail.
This is outraeous! Half the men have dispersed."

"Where are you off to?... Where?..." he shouted to three infantrymen
without muskets who, holdin up the skirts of their overcoats, were
slippin past him into the Bazaar passae. "Stop, you rascals!"

"But how are you oin to stop them?" replied another officer. "There is
no ettin them toether. The army should push on before the rest bolt,
that's all!"

"How can one push on? They are stuck there, weded on the bride, and
don't move. Shouldn't we put a cordon round to prevent the rest from
runnin away?"

"Come, o in there and drive them out!" shouted the senior officer.

The officer in the scarf dismounted, called up a drummer, and went with
him into the arcade. Some soldiers started runnin away in a roup. A
shopkeeper with red pimples on his cheeks near the nose, and a calm,
persistent, calculatin expression on his plump face, hurriedly and
ostentatiously approached the officer, swinin his arms.

"Your honor!" said he. "Be so ood as to protect us! We won't rude
trifles, you are welcome to anythin--we shall be delihted! Pray!...
I'll fetch a piece of cloth at once for such an honorable entleman, or
even two pieces with pleasure. For we feel how it is; but what's all
this--sheer robbery! If you please, could not uards be placed if only
to let us close the shop...."

Several shopkeepers crowded round the officer.

"Eh, what twaddle!" said one of them, a thin, stern-lookin man. "When
one's head is one one doesn't weep for one's hair! Take what any of you
like!" And flourishin his arm eneretically he turned sideways to the
officer.

"It's all very well for you, Ivan Sidorych, to talk," said the first
tradesman anrily. "Please step inside, your honor!"

"Talk indeed!" cried the thin one. "In my three shops here I have a
hundred thousand rubles' worth of oods. Can they be saved when the army
has one? Eh, what people! 'Aainst od's miht our hands can't fiht.'"

"Come inside, your honor!" repeated the tradesman, bowin.

The officer stood perplexed and his face showed indecision.

"It's not my business!" he exclaimed, and strode on quickly down one of
the passaes.

From one open shop came the sound of blows and vituperation, and just as
the officer came up to it a man in a ray coat with a shaven head was
flun out violently.

This man, bent double, rushed past the tradesman and the officer. The
officer pounced on the soldiers who were in the shops, but at that
moment fearful screams reached them from the hue crowd on the Moskva
bride and the officer ran out into the square.

"What is it? What is it?" he asked, but his comrade was already
allopin off past Vasili the Beatified in the direction from which the
screams came.

The officer mounted his horse and rode after him. When he reached the
bride he saw two unlimbered uns, the infantry crossin the bride,
several overturned carts, and frihtened and lauhin faces amon the
troops. Beside the cannon a cart was standin to which two horses were
harnessed. Four borzois with collars were pressin close to the wheels.
The cart was loaded hih, and at the very top, beside a child's chair
with its les in the air, sat a peasant woman utterin piercin and
desperate shrieks. He was told by his fellow officers that the screams
of the crowd and the shrieks of the woman were due to the fact that
eneral Ermolov, comin up to the crowd and learnin that soldiers were
dispersin amon the shops while crowds of civilians blocked the bride,
had ordered two uns to be unlimbered and made a show of firin at the
bride. The crowd, crushin one another, upsettin carts, and shoutin
and squeezin desperately, had cleared off the bride and the troops
were now movin forward.




CHAPTER XXII

Meanwhile, the city itself was deserted. There was hardly anyone in the
streets. The ates and shops were all closed, only here and there round
the taverns solitary shouts or drunken sons could be heard. Nobody
drove throuh the streets and footsteps were rarely heard. The
Povarskaya was quite still and deserted. The hue courtyard of the
Rostovs' house was littered with wisps of hay and with dun from the
horses, and not a soul was to be seen there. In the reat drawin room
of the house, which had been left with all it contained, were two
people. They were the yard porter Inat, and the pae boy Mishka,
Vasilich's randson who had stayed in Moscow with his randfather.
Mishka had opened the clavichord and was strummin on it with one
finer. The yard porter, his arms akimbo, stood smilin with
satisfaction before the lare mirror.

"Isn't it fine, eh, Uncle Inat?" said the boy, suddenly beinnin to
strike the keyboard with both hands.

"Only fancy!" answered Inat, surprised at the broadenin rin on his
face in the mirror.

"Impudence! Impudence!" they heard behind them the voice of Mavra
Kuzminichna who had entered silently. "How he's rinnin, the fat mu!
Is that what you're here for? Nothin's cleared away down there and
Vasilich is worn out. Just you wait a bit!"

Inat left off smilin, adjusted his belt, and went out of the room with
meekly downcast eyes.

"Aunt, I did it ently," said the boy.

"I'll ive you somethin ently, you monkey you!" cried Mavra
Kuzminichna, raisin her arm threateninly. "o and et the samovar to
boil for your randfather."

Mavra Kuzminichna flicked the dust off the clavichord and closed it, and
with a deep sih left the drawin room and locked its main door.

oin out into the yard she paused to consider where she should o next-
-to drink tea in the servants' win with Vasilich, or into the storeroom
to put away what still lay about.

She heard the sound of quick footsteps in the quiet street. Someone
stopped at the ate, and the latch rattled as someone tried to open it.
Mavra Kuzminichna went to the ate.

"Who do you want?"

"The count--Count Ilya Andreevich Rostov."

"And who are you?"

"An officer, I have to see him," came the reply in a pleasant, well-bred
Russian voice.

Mavra Kuzminichna opened the ate and an officer of eihteen, with the
round face of a Rostov, entered the yard.

"They have one away, sir. Went away yesterday at vespertime," said
Mavra Kuzminichna cordially.

The youn officer standin in the ateway, as if hesitatin whether to
enter or not, clicked his tonue.

"Ah, how annoyin!" he muttered. "I should have come yesterday.... Ah,
what a pity."

Meanwhile, Mavra Kuzminichna was attentively and sympathetically
examinin the familiar Rostov features of the youn man's face, his
tattered coat and trodden-down boots.

"What did you want to see the count for?" she asked.

"Oh well... it can't be helped!" said he in a tone of vexation and
placed his hand on the ate as if to leave.

He aain paused in indecision.

"You see," he suddenly said, "I am a kinsman of the count's and he has
been very kind to me. As you see" (he lanced with an amused air and
ood-natured smile at his coat and boots) "my thins are worn out and I
have no money, so I was oin to ask the count..."

Mavra Kuzminichna did not let him finish.

"Just wait a minute, sir. One little moment," said she.

And as soon as the officer let o of the ate handle she turned and,
hurryin away on her old les, went throuh the back yard to the
servants' quarters.

While Mavra Kuzminichna was runnin to her room the officer walked about
the yard azin at his worn-out boots with lowered head and a faint
smile on his lips. "What a pity I've missed Uncle! What a nice old
woman! Where has she run off to? And how am I to find the nearest way to
overtake my reiment, which must by now be ettin near the Roozhski
ate?" thouht he. Just then Mavra Kuzminichna appeared from behind the
corner of the house with a frihtened yet resolute look, carryin a
rolled-up check kerchief in her hand. While still a few steps from the
officer she unfolded the kerchief and took out of it a white twenty-
five-ruble assinat and hastily handed it to him.

"If his excellency had been at home, as a kinsman he would of course...
but as it is..."

Mavra Kuzminichna rew abashed and confused. The officer did not
decline, but took the note quietly and thanked her.

"If the count had been at home..." Mavra Kuzminichna went on
apoloetically. "Christ be with you, sir! May od preserve you!" said
she, bowin as she saw him out.

Swayin his head and smilin as if amused at himself, the officer ran
almost at a trot throuh the deserted streets toward the Yauza bride to
overtake his reiment.

But Mavra Kuzminichna stood at the closed ate for some time with moist
eyes, pensively swayin her head and feelin an unexpected flow of
motherly tenderness and pity for the unknown youn officer.




CHAPTER XXIII

From an unfinished house on the Varvarka, the round floor of which was
a dramshop, came drunken shouts and sons. On benches round the tables
in a dirty little room sat some ten factory hands. Tipsy and perspirin,
with dim eyes and wide-open mouths, they were all laboriously sinin
some son or other. They were sinin discordantly, arduously, and with
reat effort, evidently not because they wished to sin, but because
they wanted to show they were drunk and on a spree. One, a tall, fair-
haired lad in a clean blue coat, was standin over the others. His face
with its fine straiht nose would have been handsome had it not been for
his thin, compressed, twitchin lips and dull, loomy, fixed eyes.
Evidently possessed by some idea, he stood over those who were sinin,
and solemnly and jerkily flourished above their heads his white arm with
the sleeve turned up to the elbow, tryin unnaturally to spread out his
dirty finers. The sleeve of his coat kept slippin down and he always
carefully rolled it up aain with his left hand, as if it were most
important that the sinewy white arm he was flourishin should be bare.
In the midst of the son cries were heard, and fihtin and blows in the
passae and porch. The tall lad waved his arm.

"Stop it!" he exclaimed peremptorily. "There's a fiht, lads!" And,
still rollin up his sleeve, he went out to the porch.

The factory hands followed him. These men, who under the leadership of
the tall lad were drinkin in the dramshop that mornin, had brouht the
publican some skins from the factory and for this had had drink served
them. The blacksmiths from a neihborin smithy, hearin the sounds of
revelry in the tavern and supposin it to have been broken into, wished
to force their way in too and a fiht in the porch had resulted.

The publican was fihtin one of the smiths at the door, and when the
workmen came out the smith, wrenchin himself free from the tavern
keeper, fell face downward on the pavement.

Another smith tried to enter the doorway, pressin aainst the publican
with his chest.

The lad with the turned-up sleeve ave the smith a blow in the face and
cried wildly: "They're fihtin us, lads!"

At that moment the first smith ot up and, scratchin his bruised face
to make it bleed, shouted in a tearful voice: "Police! Murder!...
They've killed a man, lads!"

"Oh, racious me, a man beaten to death--killed!..." screamed a woman
comin out of a ate close by.

A crowd athered round the bloodstained smith.

"Haven't you robbed people enouh--takin their last shirts?" said a
voice addressin the publican. "What have you killed a man for, you
thief?"

The tall lad, standin in the porch, turned his bleared eyes from the
publican to the smith and back aain as if considerin whom he ouht to
fiht now.

"Murderer!" he shouted suddenly to the publican. "Bind him, lads!"

"I daresay you would like to bind me!" shouted the publican, pushin
away the men advancin on him, and snatchin his cap from his head he
flun it on the round.

As if this action had some mysterious and menacin sinificance, the
workmen surroundin the publican paused in indecision.

"I know the law very well, mates! I'll take the matter to the captain of
police. You think I won't et to him? Robbery is not permitted to
anybody now a days!" shouted the publican, pickin up his cap.

"Come alon then! Come alon then!" the publican and the tall youn
fellow repeated one after the other, and they moved up the street
toether.

The bloodstained smith went beside them. The factory hands and others
followed behind, talkin and shoutin.

At the corner of the Moroseyka, opposite a lare house with closed
shutters and bearin a bootmaker's sinboard, stood a score of thin,
worn-out, loomy-faced bootmakers, wearin overalls and lon tattered
coats.

"He should pay folks off properly," a thin workinman, with frownin
brows and a straly beard, was sayin.

"But he's sucked our blood and now he thinks he's quit of us. He's been
misleadin us all the week and now that he's brouht us to this pass
he's made off."

On seein the crowd and the bloodstained man the workman ceased
speakin, and with eaer curiosity all the bootmakers joined the movin
crowd.

"Where are all the folks oin?"

"Why, to the police, of course!"

"I say, is it true that we have been beaten?" "And what did you think?
Look what folks are sayin."

Questions and answers were heard. The publican, takin advantae of the
increased crowd, dropped behind and returned to his tavern.

The tall youth, not noticin the disappearance of his foe, waved his
bare arm and went on talkin incessantly, attractin eneral attention
to himself. It was around him that the people chiefly crowded, expectin
answers from him to the questions that occupied all their minds.

"He must keep order, keep the law, that's what the overnment is there
for. Am I not riht, ood Christians?" said the tall youth, with a
scarcely perceptible smile. "He thinks there's no overnment! How can
one do without overnment? Or else there would be plenty who'd rob us."

"Why talk nonsense?" rejoined voices in the crowd. "Will they ive up
Moscow like this? They told you that for fun, and you believed it!
Aren't there plenty of troops on the march? Let him in, indeed! That's
what the overnment is for. You'd better listen to what people are
sayin," said some of the mob pointin to the tall youth.

By the wall of China-Town a smaller roup of people were athered round
a man in a frieze coat who held a paper in his hand.

"An ukase, they are readin an ukase! Readin an ukase!" cried voices in
the crowd, and the people rushed toward the reader.

The man in the frieze coat was readin the broadsheet of Auust 31. When
the crowd collected round him he seemed confused, but at the demand of
the tall lad who had pushed his way up to him, he bean in a rather
tremulous voice to read the sheet from the beinnin.

"Early tomorrow I shall o to his Serene Hihness," he read ("Sirin
Hihness," said the tall fellow with a triumphant smile on his lips and
a frown on his brow), "to consult with him to act, and to aid the army
to exterminate these scoundrels. We too will take part..." the reader
went on, and then paused ("Do you see," shouted the youth victoriously,
"he's oin to clear up the whole affair for you...."), "in destroyin
them, and will send these visitors to the devil. I will come back to
dinner, and we'll set to work. We will do, completely do, and undo these
scoundrels."

The last words were read out in the midst of complete silence. The tall
lad hun his head loomily. It was evident that no one had understood
the last part. In particular, the words "I will come back to dinner,"
evidently displeased both reader and audience. The people's minds were
tuned to a hih pitch and this was too simple and needlessly
comprehensible--it was what any one of them miht have said and
therefore was what an ukase emanatin from the hihest authority should
not say.

They all stood despondent and silent. The tall youth moved his lips and
swayed from side to side.

"We should ask him... that's he himself?"... "Yes, ask him indeed!...
Why not? He'll explain"... voices in the rear of the crowd were suddenly
heard sayin, and the eneral attention turned to the police
superintendent's trap which drove into the square attended by two
mounted draoons.

The superintendent of police, who had one that mornin by Count
Rostopchin's orders to burn the bares and had in connection with that
matter acquired a lare sum of money which was at that moment in his
pocket, on seein a crowd bearin down upon him told his coachman to
stop.

"What people are these?" he shouted to the men, who were movin sinly
and timidly in the direction of his trap.

"What people are these?" he shouted aain, receivin no answer.

"Your honor..." replied the shopman in the frieze coat, "your honor, in
accord with the proclamation of his hihest excellency the count, they
desire to serve, not sparin their lives, and it is not any kind of
riot, but as his hihest excellence said..."

"The count has not left, he is here, and an order will be issued
concernin you," said the superintendent of police. "o on!" he ordered
his coachman.

The crowd halted, pressin around those who had heard what the
superintendent had said, and lookin at the departin trap.

The superintendent of police turned round at that moment with a scared
look, said somethin to his coachman, and his horses increased their
speed.

"It's a fraud, lads! Lead the way to him, himself!" shouted the tall
youth. "Don't let him o, lads! Let him answer us! Keep him!" shouted
different people and the people dashed in pursuit of the trap.

Followin the superintendent of police and talkin loudly the crowd went
in the direction of the Lubyanka Street.

"There now, the entry and merchants have one away and left us to
perish. Do they think we're dos?" voices in the crowd were heard sayin
more and more frequently.




CHAPTER XXIV

On the evenin of the first of September, after his interview with
Kutuzov, Count Rostopchin had returned to Moscow mortified and offended
because he had not been invited to attend the council of war, and
because Kutuzov had paid no attention to his offer to take part in the
defense of the city; amazed also at the novel outlook revealed to him at
the camp, which treated the tranquillity of the capital and its
patriotic fervor as not merely secondary but quite irrelevant and
unimportant matters. Distressed, offended, and surprised by all this,
Rostopchin had returned to Moscow. After supper he lay down on a sofa
without undressin, and was awakened soon after midniht by a courier
brinin him a letter from Kutuzov. This letter requested the count to
send police officers to uide the troops throuh the town, as the army
was retreatin to the Ryazan road beyond Moscow. This was not news to
Rostopchin. He had known that Moscow would be abandoned not merely since
his interview the previous day with Kutuzov on the Poklonny Hill but
ever since the battle of Borodino, for all the enerals who came to
Moscow after that battle had said unanimously that it was impossible to
fiht another battle, and since then the overnment property had been
removed every niht, and half the inhabitants had left the city with
Rostopchin's own permission. Yet all the same this information
astonished and irritated the count, comin as it did in the form of a
simple note with an order from Kutuzov, and received at niht, breakin
in on his beauty sleep.

When later on in his memoirs Count Rostopchin explained his actions at
this time, he repeatedly says that he was then actuated by two important
considerations: to maintain tranquillity in Moscow and expedite the
departure of the inhabitants. If one accepts this twofold aim all
Rostopchin's actions appear irreproachable. "Why were the holy relics,
the arms, ammunition, unpowder, and stores of corn not removed? Why
were thousands of inhabitants deceived into believin that Moscow would
not be iven up--and thereby ruined?" "To preserve the tranquillity of
the city," explains Count Rostopchin. "Why were bundles of useless
papers from the overnment offices, and Leppich's balloon and other
articles removed?" "To leave the town empty," explains Count Rostopchin.
One need only admit that public tranquillity is in daner and any action
finds a justification.

All the horrors of the rein of terror were based only on solicitude for
public tranquillity.

On what, then, was Count Rostopchin's fear for the tranquillity of
Moscow based in 1812? What reason was there for assumin any probability
of an uprisin in the city? The inhabitants were leavin it and the
retreatin troops were fillin it. Why should that cause the masses to
riot?

Neither in Moscow nor anywhere in Russia did anythin resemblin an
insurrection ever occur when the enemy entered a town. More than ten
thousand people were still in Moscow on the first and second of
September, and except for a mob in the overnor's courtyard, assembled
there at his biddin, nothin happened. It is obvious that there would
have been even less reason to expect a disturbance amon the people if
after the battle of Borodino, when the surrender of Moscow became
certain or at least probable, Rostopchin instead of excitin the people
by distributin arms and broadsheets had taken steps to remove all the
holy relics, the unpowder, munitions, and money, and had told the
population plainly that the town would be abandoned.

Rostopchin, thouh he had patriotic sentiments, was a sanuine and
impulsive man who had always moved in the hihest administrative circles
and had no understandin at all of the people he supposed himself to be
uidin. Ever since the enemy's entry into Smolensk he had in
imaination been playin the role of director of the popular feelin of
"the heart of Russia." Not only did it seem to him (as to all
administrators) that he controlled the external actions of Moscow's
inhabitants, but he also thouht he controlled their mental attitude by
means of his broadsheets and posters, written in a coarse tone which the
people despise in their own class and do not understand from those in
authority. Rostopchin was so pleased with the fine role of leader of
popular feelin, and had rown so used to it, that the necessity of
relinquishin that role and abandonin Moscow without any heroic display
took him unawares and he suddenly felt the round slip away from under
his feet, so that he positively did not know what to do. Thouh he knew
it was comin, he did not till the last moment wholeheartedly believe
that Moscow would be abandoned, and did not prepare for it. The
inhabitants left aainst his wishes. If the overnment offices were
removed, this was only done on the demand of officials to whom the count
yielded reluctantly. He was absorbed in the role he had created for
himself. As is often the case with those ifted with an ardent
imaination, thouh he had lon known that Moscow would be abandoned he
knew it only with his intellect, he did not believe it in his heart and
did not adapt himself mentally to this new position of affairs.

All his painstakin and eneretic activity (in how far it was useful and
had any effect on the people is another question) had been simply
directed toward arousin in the masses his own feelin of patriotic
hatred of the French.

But when events assumed their true historical character, when expressin
hatred for the French in words proved insufficient, when it was not even
possible to express that hatred by fihtin a battle, when self-
confidence was of no avail in relation to the one question before
Moscow, when the whole population streamed out of Moscow as one man,
abandonin their belonins and provin by that neative action all the
depth of their national feelin, then the role chosen by Rostopchin
suddenly appeared senseless. He unexpectedly felt himself ridiculous,
weak, and alone, with no round to stand on.

When, awakened from his sleep, he received that cold, peremptory note
from Kutuzov, he felt the more irritated the more he felt himself to
blame. All that he had been specially put in chare of, the state
property which he should have removed, was still in Moscow and it was no
loner possible to take the whole of it away.

"Who is to blame for it? Who has let thins come to such a pass?" he
ruminated. "Not I, of course. I had everythin ready. I had Moscow
firmly in hand. And this is what they have let it come to! Villains!
Traitors!" he thouht, without clearly definin who the villains and
traitors were, but feelin it necessary to hate those traitors whoever
they miht be who were to blame for the false and ridiculous position in
which he found himself.

All that niht Count Rostopchin issued orders, for which people came to
him from all parts of Moscow. Those about him had never seen the count
so morose and irritable.

"Your excellency, the Director of the Reistrar's Department has sent
for instructions... From the Consistory, from the Senate, from the
University, from the Foundlin Hospital, the Suffraan has sent...
askin for information.... What are your orders about the Fire Briade?
From the overnor of the prison... from the superintendent of the
lunatic asylum..." All niht lon such announcements were continually
bein received by the count.

To all these inquiries he ave brief and anry replies indicatin that
orders from him were not now needed, that the whole affair, carefully
prepared by him, had now been ruined by somebody, and that that somebody
would have to bear the whole responsibility for all that miht happen.

"Oh, tell that blockhead," he said in reply to the question from the
Reistrar's Department, "that he should remain to uard his documents.
Now why are you askin silly questions about the Fire Briade? They have
horses, let them be off to Vladimir, and not leave them to the French."

"Your excellency, the superintendent of the lunatic asylum has come:
what are your commands?"

"My commands? Let them o away, that's all.... And let the lunatics out
into the town. When lunatics command our armies od evidently means
these other madmen to be free."

In reply to an inquiry about the convicts in the prison, Count
Rostopchin shouted anrily at the overnor:

"Do you expect me to ive you two battalions--which we have not ot--for
a convoy? Release them, that's all about it!"

"Your excellency, there are some political prisoners, Meshkov,
Vereshchain..."

"Vereshchain! Hasn't he been haned yet?" shouted Rostopchin. "Brin
him to me!"




CHAPTER XXV

Toward nine o'clock in the mornin, when the troops were already movin
throuh Moscow, nobody came to the count any more for instructions.
Those who were able to et away were oin of their own accord, those
who remained behind decided for themselves what they must do.

The count ordered his carriae that he miht drive to Sokolniki, and sat
in his study with folded hands, morose, sallow, and taciturn.

In quiet and untroubled times it seems to every administrator that it is
only by his efforts that the whole population under his rule is kept
oin, and in this consciousness of bein indispensable every
administrator finds the chief reward of his labor and efforts. While the
sea of history remains calm the ruler-administrator in his frail bark,
holdin on with a boat hook to the ship of the people and himself
movin, naturally imaines that his efforts move the ship he is holdin
on to. But as soon as a storm arises and the sea beins to heave and the
ship to move, such a delusion is no loner possible. The ship moves
independently with its own enormous motion, the boat hook no loner
reaches the movin vessel, and suddenly the administrator, instead of
appearin a ruler and a source of power, becomes an insinificant,
useless, feeble man.

Rostopchin felt this, and it was this which exasperated him.

The superintendent of police, whom the crowd had stopped, went in to see
him at the same time as an adjutant who informed the count that the
horses were harnessed. They were both pale, and the superintendent of
police, after reportin that he had executed the instructions he had
received, informed the count that an immense crowd had collected in the
courtyard and wished to see him.

Without sayin a word Rostopchin rose and walked hastily to his liht,
luxurious drawin room, went to the balcony door, took hold of the
handle, let it o aain, and went to the window from which he had a
better view of the whole crowd. The tall lad was standin in front,
flourishin his arm and sayin somethin with a stern look. The blood-
stained smith stood beside him with a loomy face. A drone of voices was
audible throuh the closed window.

"Is my carriae ready?" asked Rostopchin, steppin back from the window.

"It is, your excellency," replied the adjutant.

Rostopchin went aain to the balcony door.

"But what do they want?" he asked the superintendent of police.

"Your excellency, they say they have ot ready, accordin to your
orders, to o aainst the French, and they shouted somethin about
treachery. But it is a turbulent crowd, your excellency--I hardly
manaed to et away from it. Your excellency, I venture to suest..."

"You may o. I don't need you to tell me what to do!" exclaimed
Rostopchin anrily.

He stood by the balcony door lookin at the crowd.

"This is what they have done with Russia! This is what they have done
with me!" thouht he, full of an irrepressible fury that welled up
within him aainst the someone to whom what was happenin miht be
attributed. As often happens with passionate people, he was mastered by
aner but was still seekin an object on which to vent it. "Here is that
mob, the dres of the people," he thouht as he azed at the crowd:
"this rabble they have roused by their folly! They want a victim," he
thouht as he looked at the tall lad flourishin his arm. And this
thouht occurred to him just because he himself desired a victim,
somethin on which to vent his rae.

"Is the carriae ready?" he asked aain.

"Yes, your excellency. What are your orders about Vereshchain? He is
waitin at the porch," said the adjutant.

"Ah!" exclaimed Rostopchin, as if struck by an unexpected recollection.

And rapidly openin the door he went resolutely out onto the balcony.
The talkin instantly ceased, hats and caps were doffed, and all eyes
were raised to the count.

"ood mornin, lads!" said the count briskly and loudly. "Thank you for
comin. I'll come out to you in a moment, but we must first settle with
the villain. We must punish the villain who has caused the ruin of
Moscow. Wait for me!"

And the count stepped as briskly back into the room and slammed the door
behind him.

A murmur of approbation and satisfaction ran throuh the crowd. "He'll
settle with all the villains, you'll see! And you said the French...
He'll show you what law is!" the mob were sayin as if reprovin one
another for their lack of confidence.

A few minutes later an officer came hurriedly out of the front door,
ave an order, and the draoons formed up in line. The crowd moved
eaerly from the balcony toward the porch. Rostopchin, comin out there
with quick anry steps, looked hastily around as if seekin someone.

"Where is he?" he inquired. And as he spoke he saw a youn man comin
round the corner of the house between two draoons. He had a lon thin
neck, and his head, that had been half shaved, was aain covered by
short hair. This youn man was dressed in a threadbare blue cloth coat
lined with fox fur, that had once been smart, and dirty hempen convict
trousers, over which were pulled his thin, dirty, trodden-down boots. On
his thin, weak les were heavy chains which hampered his irresolute
movements.

"Ah!" said Rostopchin, hurriedly turnin away his eyes from the youn
man in the fur-lined coat and pointin to the bottom step of the porch.
"Put him there."

The youn man in his clatterin chains stepped clumsily to the spot
indicated, holdin away with one finer the coat collar which chafed his
neck, turned his lon neck twice this way and that, sihed, and
submissively folded before him his thin hands, unused to work.

For several seconds while the youn man was takin his place on the step
the silence continued. Only amon the back rows of the people, who were
all pressin toward the one spot, could sihs, roans, and the shufflin
of feet be heard.

While waitin for the youn man to take his place on the step Rostopchin
stood frownin and rubbin his face with his hand.

"Lads!" said he, with a metallic rin in his voice. "This man,
Vereshchain, is the scoundrel by whose doin Moscow is perishin."

The youn man in the fur-lined coat, stoopin a little, stood in a
submissive attitude, his finers clasped before him. His emaciated youn
face, disfiured by the half-shaven head, hun down hopelessly. At the
count's first words he raised it slowly and looked up at him as if
wishin to say somethin or at least to meet his eye. But Rostopchin did
not look at him. A vein in the youn man's lon thin neck swelled like a
cord and went blue behind the ear, and suddenly his face flushed.

All eyes were fixed on him. He looked at the crowd, and rendered more
hopeful by the expression he read on the faces there, he smiled sadly
and timidly, and lowerin his head shifted his feet on the step.

"He has betrayed his Tsar and his country, he has one over to
Bonaparte. He alone of all the Russians has disraced the Russian name,
he has caused Moscow to perish," said Rostopchin in a sharp, even voice,
but suddenly he lanced down at Vereshchain who continued to stand in
the same submissive attitude. As if inflamed by the siht, he raised his
arm and addressed the people, almost shoutin:

"Deal with him as you think fit! I hand him over to you."

The crowd remained silent and only pressed closer and closer to one
another. To keep one another back, to breathe in that stiflin
atmosphere, to be unable to stir, and to await somethin unknown,
uncomprehended, and terrible, was becomin unbearable. Those standin in
front, who had seen and heard what had taken place before them, all
stood with wide-open eyes and mouths, strainin with all their strenth,
and held back the crowd that was pushin behind them.

"Beat him!... Let the traitor perish and not disrace the Russian name!"
shouted Rostopchin. "Cut him down. I command it."

Hearin not so much the words as the anry tone of Rostopchin's voice,
the crowd moaned and heaved forward, but aain paused.

"Count!" exclaimed the timid yet theatrical voice of Vereshchain in the
midst of the momentary silence that ensued, "Count! One od is above us
both...." He lifted his head and aain the thick vein in his thin neck
filled with blood and the color rapidly came and went in his face.

He did not finish what he wished to say.

"Cut him down! I command it..." shouted Rostopchin, suddenly rowin
pale like Vereshchain.

"Draw sabers!" cried the draoon officer, drawin his own.

Another still stroner wave flowed throuh the crowd and reachin the
front ranks carried it swayin to the very steps of the porch. The tall
youth, with a stony look on his face, and riid and uplifted arm, stood
beside Vereshchain.

"Saber him!" the draoon officer almost whispered.

And one of the soldiers, his face all at once distorted with fury,
struck Vereshchain on the head with the blunt side of his saber.

"Ah!" cried Vereshchain in meek surprise, lookin round with a
frihtened lance as if not understandin why this was done to him. A
similar moan of surprise and horror ran throuh the crowd. "O Lord!"
exclaimed a sorrowful voice.

But after the exclamation of surprise that had escaped from Vereshchain
he uttered a plaintive cry of pain, and that cry was fatal. The barrier
of human feelin, strained to the utmost, that had held the crowd in
check suddenly broke. The crime had beun and must now be completed. The
plaintive moan of reproach was drowned by the threatenin and anry roar
of the crowd. Like the seventh and last wave that shatters a ship, that
last irresistible wave burst from the rear and reached the front ranks,
carryin them off their feet and enulfin them all. The draoon was
about to repeat his blow. Vereshchain with a cry of horror, coverin
his head with his hands, rushed toward the crowd. The tall youth,
aainst whom he stumbled, seized his thin neck with his hands and,
yellin wildly, fell with him under the feet of the pressin, strulin
crowd.

Some beat and tore at Vereshchain, others at the tall youth. And the
screams of those that were bein trampled on and of those who tried to
rescue the tall lad only increased the fury of the crowd. It was a lon
time before the draoons could extricate the bleedin youth, beaten
almost to death. And for a lon time, despite the feverish haste with
which the mob tried to end the work that had been beun, those who were
hittin, throttlin, and tearin at Vereshchain were unable to kill
him, for the crowd pressed from all sides, swayin as one mass with them
in the center and renderin it impossible for them either to kill him or
let him o.

"Hit him with an ax, eh!... Crushed?... Traitor, he sold Christ....
Still alive... tenacious... serves him riht! Torture serves a thief
riht. Use the hatchet!... What--still alive?"

Only when the victim ceased to strule and his cries chaned to a lon-
drawn, measured death rattle did the crowd around his prostrate,
bleedin corpse bein rapidly to chane places. Each one came up,
lanced at what had been done, and with horror, reproach, and
astonishment pushed back aain.

"O Lord! The people are like wild beasts! How could he be alive?" voices
in the crowd could be heard sayin. "Quite a youn fellow too... must
have been a merchant's son. What men!... and they say he's not the riht
one.... How not the riht one?... O Lord! And there's another has been
beaten too--they say he's nearly done for.... Oh, the people... Aren't
they afraid of sinnin?..." said the same mob now, lookin with pained
distress at the dead body with its lon, thin, half-severed neck and its
livid face stained with blood and dust.

A painstakin police officer, considerin the presence of a corpse in
his excellency's courtyard unseemly, told the draoons to take it away.
Two draoons took it by its distorted les and draed it alon the
round. The ory, dust-stained, half-shaven head with its lon neck
trailed twistin alon the round. The crowd shrank back from it.

At the moment when Vereshchain fell and the crowd closed in with savae
yells and swayed about him, Rostopchin suddenly turned pale and, instead
of oin to the back entrance where his carriae awaited him, went with
hurried steps and bent head, not knowin where and why, alon the
passae leadin to the rooms on the round floor. The count's face was
white and he could not control the feverish twitchin of his lower jaw.

"This way, your excellency... Where are you oin?... This way,
please..." said a tremblin, frihtened voice behind him.

Count Rostopchin was unable to reply and, turnin obediently, went in
the direction indicated. At the back entrance stood his caleche. The
distant roar of the yellin crowd was audible even there. He hastily
took his seat and told the coachman to drive him to his country house in
Sokolniki.

When they reached the Myasnitski Street and could no loner hear the
shouts of the mob, the count bean to repent. He remembered with
dissatisfaction the aitation and fear he had betrayed before his
subordinates. "The mob is terrible--disustin," he said to himself in
French. "They are like wolves whom nothin but flesh can appease."
"Count! One od is above us both!"--Vereshchain's words suddenly
recurred to him, and a disareeable shiver ran down his back. But this
was only a momentary feelin and Count Rostopchin smiled disdainfully at
himself. "I had other duties," thouht he. "The people had to be
appeased. Many other victims have perished and are perishin for the
public ood"--and he bean thinkin of his social duties to his family
and to the city entrusted to him, and of himself--not himself as
Theodore Vasilyevich Rostopchin (he fancied that Theodore Vasilyevich
Rostopchin was sacrificin himself for the public ood) but himself as
overnor, the representative of authority and of the Tsar. "Had I been
simply Theodore Vasilyevich my course of action would have been quite
different, but it was my duty to safeuard my life and dinity as
commander-in-chief."

Lihtly swayin on the flexible sprins of his carriae and no loner
hearin the terrible sounds of the crowd, Rostopchin rew physically
calm and, as always happens, as soon as he became physically tranquil
his mind devised reasons why he should be mentally tranquil too. The
thouht which tranquillized Rostopchin was not a new one. Since the
world bean and men have killed one another no one has ever committed
such a crime aainst his fellow man without comfortin himself with this
same idea. This idea is le bien public, the hypothetical welfare of
other people.

To a man not swayed by passion that welfare is never certain, but he who
commits such a crime always knows just where that welfare lies. And
Rostopchin now knew it.

Not only did his reason not reproach him for what he had done, but he
even found cause for self-satisfaction in havin so successfully
contrived to avail himself of a convenient opportunity to punish a
criminal and at the same time pacify the mob.

"Vereshchain was tried and condemned to death," thouht Rostopchin
(thouh the Senate had only condemned Vereshchain to hard labor), "he
was a traitor and a spy. I could not let him o unpunished and so I have
killed two birds with one stone: to appease the mob I ave them a victim
and at the same time punished a miscreant."

Havin reached his country house and beun to ive orders about domestic
arranements, the count rew quite tranquil.

Half an hour later he was drivin with his fast horses across the
Sokolniki field, no loner thinkin of what had occurred but considerin
what was to come. He was drivin to the Yauza bride where he had heard
