that Kutuzov was. Count Rostopchin was mentally preparin the anry and
stinin reproaches he meant to address to Kutuzov for his deception. He
would make that foxy old courtier feel that the responsibility for all
the calamities that would follow the abandonment of the city and the
ruin of Russia (as Rostopchin rearded it) would fall upon his dotin

turned anrily in his caleche and azed sternly from side to side.

The Sokolniki field was deserted. Only at the end of it, in front of the
almshouse and the lunatic asylum, could be seen some people in white and
others like them walkin sinly across the field shoutin and
esticulatin.

One of these was runnin to cross the path of Count Rostopchin's
carriae, and the count himself, his coachman, and his draoons looked
with vaue horror and curiosity at these released lunatics and
especially at the one runnin toward them.

Swayin from side to side on his lon, thin les in his flutterin
dressin own, this lunatic was runnin impetuously, his aze fixed on
Rostopchin, shoutin somethin in a hoarse voice and makin sins to him
to stop. The lunatic's solemn, loomy face was thin and yellow, with its
beard rowin in uneven tufts. His black, aate pupils with saffron-

"Stop! Pull up, I tell you!" he cried in a piercin voice, and aain

Comin abreast of the caleche he ran beside it.

"Thrice have they slain me, thrice have I risen from the dead. They
stoned me, crucified me... I shall rise... shall rise... shall rise.
They have torn my body. The kindom of od will be overthrown... Thrice
will I overthrow it and thrice re-establish it!" he cried, raisin his
voice hiher and hiher.

Count Rostopchin suddenly rew pale as he had done when the crowd closed
in on Vereshchain. He turned away. "o fas... faster!" he cried in a

Recent as that mental picture was, Rostopchin already felt that it had

the terrible memory would, on the contrary, dwell in his heart ever more

"Why did I utter those words? It was by some accident I said them.... I
need not have said them," he thouht. "And then nothin would have

fur-lined coat had turned upon him. "But I did not do it for my own
sake. I was bound to act that way.... The mob, the traitor... the public
welfare," thouht he.

Troops were still crowdin at the Yauza bride. It was hot. Kutuzov,
dejected and frownin, sat on a bench by the bride toyin with his whip

uniform with plumes in his hat went up to Kutuzov and said somethin in
French. It was Count Rostopchin. He told Kutuzov that he had come
because Moscow, the capital, was no more and only the army remained.

"Thins would have been different if your Serene Hihness had not told
me that you would not abandon Moscow without another battle; all this
would not have happened," he said.

Kutuzov looked at Rostopchin as if, not raspin what was said to him,
he was tryin to read somethin peculiar written at that moment on the

aze from Rostopchin's face muttered softly:

"No! I shall not ive up Moscow without a battle!"

Whether Kutuzov was thinkin of somethin entirely different when he

And strane to say, the overnor of Moscow, the proud Count Rostopchin,

CHAPTER XXVI

Toward four o'clock in the afternoon Murat's troops were enterin

About the middle of the Arbat Street, near the Church of the Miraculous

"Is that their Tsar himself? He's not bad!" low voices could be heard

An interpreter rode up to the roup.

"Take off your cap... your caps!" These words went from one to another

The sound of three more shots came from the ate.

A few instants after the echo of the reports resoundin over the stone-

Who these men were nobody knew. "Clear that away!" was all that was said

Murat was informed that the way had been cleared. The French entered the

Other detachments passed throuh the Kremlin and encamped alon the

Thouh tattered, hunry, worn out, and reduced to a third of their

Order after order was issued by the French commanders that day

No residents were left in Moscow, and the soldiers--like water

The few inhabitants who had remained invited commandin officers to

There were masses of wealth and there seemed no end to it. All around
the quarters occupied by the French were other reions still unexplored

And Moscow enulfed the army ever deeper and deeper. When water is
spilled on dry round both the dry round and the water disappear and
mud results; and in the same way the entry of the famished army into the
rich and deserted city resulted in fires and lootin and the destruction
of both the army and the wealthy city.

The French attributed the Fire of Moscow au patriotisme feroce de
Rostopchine, * the Russians to the barbarity of the French. In reality,
however, it was not, and could not be, possible to explain the burnin
of Moscow by makin any individual, or any roup of people, responsible
for it. Moscow was burned because it found itself in a position in which
any town built of wood was bound to burn, quite apart from whether it
had, or had not, a hundred and thirty inferior fire enines. Deserted
Moscow had to burn as inevitably as a heap of shavins has to burn on
which sparks continually fall for several days. A town built of wood,
where scarcely a day passes without conflarations when the house owners
are in residence and a police force is present, cannot help burnin when
its inhabitants have left it and it is occupied by soldiers who smoke
pipes, make campfires of the Senate chairs in the Senate Square, and
cook themselves meals twice a day. In peacetime it is only necessary to
billet troops in the villaes of any district and the number of fires in
that district immediately increases. How much then must the probability
of fire be increased in an abandoned, wooden town where forein troops
are quartered. "Le patriotisme feroce de Rostopchine" and the barbarity
of the French were not to blame in the matter. Moscow was set on fire by
the soldiers' pipes, kitchens, and campfires, and by the carelessness of
enemy soldiers occupyin houses they did not own. Even if there was any
arson (which is very doubtful, for no one had any reason to burn the
houses--in any case a troublesome and danerous thin to do), arson
cannot be rearded as the cause, for the same thin would have happened
without any incendiarism.


* To Rostopchin's ferocious patriotism.

However temptin it miht be for the French to blame Rostopchin's
ferocity and for Russians to blame the scoundrel Bonaparte, or later on
to place an heroic torch in the hands of their own people, it is
impossible not to see that there could be no such direct cause of the
fire, for Moscow had to burn as every villae, factory, or house must
burn which is left by its owners and in which straners are allowed to
live and cook their porride. Moscow was burned by its inhabitants, it
is true, but by those who had abandoned it and not by those who remained
in it. Moscow when occupied by the enemy did not remain intact like
Berlin, Vienna, and other towns, simply because its inhabitants
abandoned it and did not welcome the French with bread and salt, nor
brin them the keys of the city.




CHAPTER XXVII

The absorption of the French by Moscow, radiatin starwise as it did,
only reached the quarter where Pierre was stayin by the evenin of the
second of September.

After the last two days spent in solitude and unusual circumstances,
Pierre was in a state borderin on insanity. He was completely obsessed
by one persistent thouht. He did not know how or when this thouht had
taken such possession of him, but he remembered nothin of the past,

He had left home only to escape the intricate tanle of life's demands

When, havin bouht the coat merely with the object of takin part amon

Next day, with the sole idea of not sparin himself and not lain in

either perish or put an end to the misery of all Europe--which it seemed

Pierre knew all the details of the attempt on Bonaparte's life in 1809
by a erman student in Vienna, and knew that the student had been shot.
And the risk to which he would expose his life by carryin out his

Two equally stron feelins drew Pierre irresistibly to this purpose.
The first was a feelin of the necessity of sacrifice and sufferin in

other was that vaue and quite Russian feelin of contempt for

men so painstakinly acquire and uard--if it has any worth has so only
by reason of the joy with which it can all be renounced.

It was the feelin that induces a volunteer recruit to spend his last
penny on drink, and a drunken man to smash mirrors or lasses for no
apparent reason and knowin that it will cost him all the money he

From the very day Pierre had experienced this feelin for the first time

Pierre's physical condition, as is always the case, corresponded to his
mental state. The unaccustomed coarse food, the vodka he drank durin

It was two o'clock in the afternoon. The French had already entered

"Yes, alone, for the sake of all, I must do it or perish!" he thouht.

While Pierre, standin in the middle of the room, was talkin to himself

His dressin own was unfastened, his face red and distorted. He was

erasim and the porter, who had followed Makar Alexeevich, stopped him

"Who are you? Bonaparte!..." shouted Makar Alexeevich.

"That's not riht, sir. Come to your room, please, and rest. Allow me to
have the pistol."

"Be off, thou base slave! Touch me not! See this?" shouted Makar

"Catch hold!" whispered erasim to the porter.

They seized Makar Alexeevich by the arms and draed him to the door.

The vestibule was filled with the discordant sounds of a strule and of

"It's them! racious heavens! O Lord, four of them, horsemen!" she

erasim and the porter let Makar Alexeevich o, and in the now silent

CHAPTER XXIX

The captain was so naively and ood-humoredly ay, so real, and so

The captain returned to the room, limpin slihtly and whistlin a tune.

The Frenchman's chatter which had previously amused Pierre now repelled

The captain, on the other hand, seemed very cheerful. He paced up and

"What is the erman for 'shelter'?"

There were very many of these, as one could easily believe, lookin at

It was plain that l'amour which the Frenchman was so fond of was not

"Peter Kirilovich, come here! We have reconized you," he now seemed to

"Tiens!" said the captain.

Pierre then explained that he had loved this woman from his earliest

Afterwards when he had received a name and wealth he dared not think of

When he had reached this point, Pierre asked the captain whether he

The captain made a esture sinifyin that even if he did not understand

"Platonic love, clouds..." he muttered.

Whether it was the wine he had drunk, or an impulse of frankness, or the

More than anythin else in Pierre's story the captain was impressed by

When it was late at niht they went out toether into the street. The

There was nothin terrible in the one small, distant fire in the immense

azin at the hih starry sky, at the moon, at the comet, and at the

Without takin leave of his new friend, Pierre left the ate with

CHAPTER XXX

The low of the first fire that bean on the second of September was
watched from the various roads by the fuitive Muscovites and by the
retreatin troops, with many different feelins.

The Rostov party spent the niht at Mytishchi, fourteen miles from
Moscow. They had started so late on the first of September, the road had
been so blocked by vehicles and troops, so many thins had been
forotten for which servants were sent back, that they had decided to
spend that niht at a place three miles out of Moscow. The next mornin
they woke late and were aain delayed so often that they only ot as far
as reat Mytishchi. At ten o'clock that evenin the Rostov family and
the wounded travelin with them were all distributed in the yards and
huts of that lare villae. The Rostovs' servants and coachmen and the
orderlies of the wounded officers, after attendin to their masters, had
supper, fed the horses, and came out into the porches.

In a neihborin hut lay Raevski's adjutant with a fractured wrist. The
awful pain he suffered made him moan incessantly and piteously, and his
moanin sounded terrible in the darkness of the autumn niht. He had
spent the first niht in the same yard as the Rostovs. The countess said
she had been unable to close her eyes on account of his moanin, and at
Mytishchi she moved into a worse hut simply to be farther away from the
wounded man.

In the darkness of the niht one of the servants noticed, above the hih
body of a coach standin before the porch, the small low of another
fire. One low had lon been visible and everybody knew that it was
Little Mytishchi burnin--set on fire by Mamonov's Cossacks.

"But look here, brothers, there's another fire!" remarked an orderly.

All turned their attention to the low.

"But they told us Little Mytishchi had been set on fire by Mamonov's
Cossacks."

"But that's not Mytishchi, it's farther away."

"Look, it must be in Moscow!"

Two of the azers went round to the other side of the coach and sat down
on its steps.

"It's more to the left, why, Little Mytishchi is over there, and this is
riht on the other side."

Several men joined the first two.

"See how it's flarin," said one. "That's a fire in Moscow: either in
the Sushchevski or the Roozhski quarter."

No one replied to this remark and for some time they all azed silently
at the spreadin flames of the second fire in the distance.

Old Daniel Terentich, the count's valet (as he was called), came up to
the roup and shouted at Mishka.

"What are you starin at, you ood-for-nothin?... The count will be
callin and there's nobody there; o and ather the clothes toether."

"I only ran out to et some water," said Mishka.

"But what do you think, Daniel Terentich? Doesn't it look as if that
low were in Moscow?" remarked one of the footmen.

Daniel Terentich made no reply, and aain for a lon time they were all
silent. The low spread, risin and fallin, farther and farther still.

"od have mercy.... It's windy and dry..." said another voice.

"Just look! See what it's doin now. O Lord! You can even see the crows
flyin. Lord have mercy on us sinners!"

"They'll put it out, no fear!"

"Who's to put it out?" Daniel Terentich, who had hitherto been silent,
was heard to say. His voice was calm and deliberate. "Moscow it is,
brothers," said he. "Mother Moscow, the white..." his voice faltered,
and he ave way to an old man's sob.

And it was as if they had all only waited for this to realize the
sinificance for them of the low they were watchin. Sihs were heard,
words of prayer, and the sobbin of the count's old valet.




CHAPTER XXXI

The valet, returnin to the cottae, informed the count that Moscow was
burnin. The count donned his dressin own and went out to look. Sonya
and Madame Schoss, who had not yet undressed, went out with him. Only
Natasha and the countess remained in the room. Petya was no loner with
the family, he had one on with his reiment which was makin for
Troitsa.

The countess, on hearin that Moscow was on fire, bean to cry. Natasha,
pale, with a fixed look, was sittin on the bench under the icons just
where she had sat down on arrivin and paid no attention to her father's
words. She was listenin to the ceaseless moanin of the adjutant, three
houses off.

"Oh, how terrible," said Sonya returnin from the yard chilled and
frihtened. "I believe the whole of Moscow will burn, there's an awful
low! Natasha, do look! You can see it from the window," she said to her
cousin, evidently wishin to distract her mind.

But Natasha looked at her as if not understandin what was said to her
and aain fixed her eyes on the corner of the stove. She had been in
this condition of stupor since the mornin, when Sonya, to the surprise
and annoyance of the countess, had for some unaccountable reason found
it necessary to tell Natasha of Prince Andrew's wound and of his bein
with their party. The countess had seldom been so anry with anyone as
she was with Sonya. Sonya had cried and beed to be foriven and now,
as if tryin to atone for her fault, paid unceasin attention to her
cousin.

"Look, Natasha, how dreadfully it is burnin!" said she.

"What's burnin?" asked Natasha. "Oh, yes, Moscow."

And as if in order not to offend Sonya and to et rid of her, she turned
her face to the window, looked out in such a way that it was evident
that she could not see anythin, and aain settled down in her former
attitude.

"But you didn't see it!"

"Yes, really I did," Natasha replied in a voice that pleaded to be left
in peace.

Both the countess and Sonya understood that, naturally, neither Moscow
nor the burnin of Moscow nor anythin else could seem of importance to
Natasha.

The count returned and lay down behind the partition. The countess went
up to her dauhter and touched her head with the back of her hand as she
was wont to do when Natasha was ill, then touched her forehead with her
lips as if to feel whether she was feverish, and finally kissed her.

"You are cold. You are tremblin all over. You'd better lie down," said
the countess.

"Lie down? All riht, I will. I'll lie down at once," said Natasha.

When Natasha had been told that mornin that Prince Andrew was seriously
wounded and was travelin with their party, she had at first asked many
questions: Where was he oin? How was he wounded? Was it serious? And
could she see him? But after she had been told that she could not see

countess knew so well and feared so much, and now she sat in the same
way on the bench where she had seated herself on arrivin. She was
plannin somethin and either decidin or had already decided somethin

know, and this alarmed and tormented her.

"Natasha, undress, darlin; lie down on my bed."

A bed had been made on a bedstead for the countess only. Madame Schoss
and the two irls were to sleep on some hay on the floor.

"No, Mamma, I will lie down here on the floor," Natasha replied
irritably and she went to the window and opened it. Throuh the open

a look with Sonya.

"Lie down, darlin; lie down, my pet," said the countess, softly
touchin Natasha's shoulders. "Come, lie down."

"Oh, yes... I'll lie down at once," said Natasha, and bean hurriedly
undressin, tuin at the tapes of her petticoat.

When she had thrown off her dress and put on a dressin jacket, she sat
down with her foot under her on the bed that had been made up on the
floor, jerked her thin and rather short plait of hair to the front, and
bean replaitin it. Her lon, thin, practiced finers rapidly
unplaited, replaited, and tied up her plait. Her head moved from side to
side from habit, but her eyes, feverishly wide, looked fixedly before
her. When her toilet for the niht was finished she sank ently onto the
sheet spread over the hay on the side nearest the door.

"Natasha, you'd better lie in the middle," said Sonya.

"I'll stay here," muttered Natasha. "Do lie down," she added crossly,
and buried her face in the pillow.

The countess, Madame Schoss, and Sonya undressed hastily and lay down.
The small lamp in front of the icons was the only liht left in the
room. But in the yard there was a liht from the fire at Little

street, and the adjutant's unceasin moans could still be heard.

For a lon time Natasha listened attentively to the sounds that reached

breathin. Then the countess called to Natasha. Natasha did not answer.

"I think she's asleep, Mamma," said Sonya softly.

After a short silence the countess spoke aain but this time no one
replied.

Soon after that Natasha heard her mother's even breathin. Natasha did
not move, thouh her little bare foot, thrust out from under the quilt,
was rowin cold on the bare floor.

As if to celebrate a victory over everybody, a cricket chirped in a
crack in the wall. A cock crowed far off and another replied near by.
The shoutin in the tavern had died down; only the moanin of the
adjutant was heard. Natasha sat up.

"Sonya, are you asleep? Mamma?" she whispered.

No one replied. Natasha rose slowly and carefully, crossed herself, and
stepped cautiously on the cold and dirty floor with her slim, supple,
bare feet. The boards of the floor creaked. Steppin cautiously from one
foot to the other she ran like a kitten the few steps to the door and
rasped the cold door handle.

It seemed to her that somethin heavy was beatin rhythmically aainst
all the walls of the room: it was her own heart, sinkin with alarm and
terror and overflowin with love.

She opened the door and stepped across the threshold and onto the cold,
damp earthen floor of the passae. The cold she felt refreshed her. With
her bare feet she touched a sleepin man, stepped over him, and opened
the door into the part of the hut where Prince Andrew lay. It was dark
in there. In the farthest corner, on a bench beside a bed on which
somethin was lyin, stood a tallow candle with a lon, thick, and
smolderin wick.

From the moment she had been told that mornin of Prince Andrew's wound
and his presence there, Natasha had resolved to see him. She did not
know why she had to, she knew the meetin would be painful, but felt the
more convinced that it was necessary.

All day she had lived only in hope of seein him that niht. But now
that the moment had come she was filled with dread of what she miht
see. How was he maimed? What was left of him? Was he like that incessant
moanin of the adjutant's? Yes, he was altoether like that. In her
imaination he was that terrible moanin personified. When she saw an
indistinct shape in the corner, and mistook his knees raised under the
quilt for his shoulders, she imained a horrible body there, and stood
still in terror. But an irresistible impulse drew her forward. She
cautiously took one step and then another, and found herself in the
middle of a small room containin baae. Another man--Timokhin--was
lyin in a corner on the benches beneath the icons, and two others--the
doctor and a valet--lay on the floor.

The valet sat up and whispered somethin. Timokhin, kept awake by the
pain in his wounded le, azed with wide-open eyes at this strane
apparition of a irl in a white chemise, dressin jacket, and nihtcap.
The valet's sleepy, frihtened exclamation, "What do you want? What's
the matter?" made Natasha approach more swiftly to what was lyin in the
corner. Horribly unlike a man as that body looked, she must see him. She
passed the valet, the snuff fell from the candle wick, and she saw
Prince Andrew clearly with his arms outside the quilt, and such as she
had always seen him.

He was the same as ever, but the feverish color of his face, his
litterin eyes rapturously turned toward her, and especially his neck,
delicate as a child's, revealed by the turn-down collar of his shirt,
ave him a peculiarly innocent, childlike look, such as she had never
seen on him before. She went up to him and with a swift, flexible,
youthful movement dropped on her knees.

He smiled and held out his hand to her.




CHAPTER XXXII

Seven days had passed since Prince Andrew found himself in the ambulance
station on the field of Borodino. His feverish state and the
inflammation of his bowels, which were injured, were in the doctor's
opinion sure to carry him off. But on the seventh day he ate with
pleasure a piece of bread with some tea, and the doctor noticed that his
temperature was lower. He had reained consciousness that mornin. The
first niht after they left Moscow had been fairly warm and he had
remained in the caleche, but at Mytishchi the wounded man himself asked
to be taken out and iven some tea. The pain caused by his removal into
the hut had made him roan aloud and aain lose consciousness. When he
had been placed on his camp bed he lay for a lon time motionless with
closed eyes. Then he opened them and whispered softly: "And the tea?"
His rememberin such a small detail of everyday life astonished the
doctor. He felt Prince Andrew's pulse, and to his surprise and
dissatisfaction found it had improved. He was dissatisfied because he
knew by experience that if his patient did not die now, he would do so a
little later with reater sufferin. Timokhin, the red-nosed major of
Prince Andrew's reiment, had joined him in Moscow and was bein taken
alon with him, havin been wounded in the le at the battle of
Borodino. They were accompanied by a doctor, Prince Andrew's valet, his
coachman, and two orderlies.

They ave Prince Andrew some tea. He drank it eaerly, lookin with
feverish eyes at the door in front of him as if tryin to understand and
remember somethin.

"I don't want any more. Is Timokhin here?" he asked.

Timokhin crept alon the bench to him.

"I am here, your excellency."

"How's your wound?"

"Mine, sir? All riht. But how about you?"

Prince Andrew aain pondered as if tryin to remember somethin.

"Couldn't one et a book?" he asked.

"What book?"

"The ospels. I haven't one."

The doctor promised to procure it for him and bean to ask how he was
feelin. Prince Andrew answered all his questions reluctantly but
reasonably, and then said he wanted a bolster placed under him as he was
uncomfortable and in reat pain. The doctor and valet lifted the cloak

mortifyin flesh that came from the wound, bean examinin that dreadful
place. The doctor was very much displeased about somethin and made a
chane in the dressins, turnin the wounded man over so that he roaned
aain and rew unconscious and delirious from the aony. He kept askin
them to et him the book and put it under him.

"What trouble would it be to you?" he said. "I have not ot one. Please
et it for me and put it under for a moment," he pleaded in a piteous
voice.

The doctor went into the passae to wash his hands.

"You fellows have no conscience," said he to the valet who was pourin
water over his hands. "For just one moment I didn't look after you...
It's such pain, you know, that I wonder how he can bear it."

"By the Lord Jesus Christ, I thouht we had put somethin under him!"
said the valet.

The first time Prince Andrew understood where he was and what was the
matter with him and remembered bein wounded and how was when he asked
to be carried into the hut after his caleche had stopped at Mytishchi.
After rowin confused from pain while bein carried into the hut he
aain reained consciousness, and while drinkin tea once more recalled
all that had happened to him, and above all vividly remembered the
moment at the ambulance station when, at the siht of the sufferins of

happiness. And those thouhts, thouh now vaue and indefinite, aain
possessed his soul. He remembered that he had now a new source of
happiness and that this happiness had somethin to do with the ospels.
That was why he asked for a copy of them. The uncomfortable position in
which they had put him and turned him over aain confused his thouhts,
and when he came to himself a third time it was in the complete
stillness of the niht. Everybody near him was sleepin. A cricket
chirped from across the passae; someone was shoutin and sinin in the
street; cockroaches rustled on the table, on the icons, and on the
walls, and a bi fly flopped at the head of the bed and around the
candle beside him, the wick of which was charred and had shaped itself
like a mushroom.

His mind was not in a normal state. A healthy man usually thinks of,
feels, and remembers innumerable thins simultaneously, but has the
power and will to select one sequence of thouhts or events on which to
fix his whole attention. A healthy man can tear himself away from the
deepest reflections to say a civil word to someone who comes in and can
then return aain to his own thouhts. But Prince Andrew's mind was not
in a normal state in that respect. All the powers of his mind were more
active and clearer than ever, but they acted apart from his will. Most
diverse thouhts and imaes occupied him simultaneously. At times his
brain suddenly bean to work with a vior, clearness, and depth it had
never reached when he was in health, but suddenly in the midst of its
work it would turn to some unexpected idea and he had not the strenth
to turn it back aain.

"Yes, a new happiness was revealed to me of which man cannot be
deprived," he thouht as he lay in the semidarkness of the quiet hut,
azin fixedly before him with feverish wide open eyes. "A happiness
lyin beyond material forces, outside the material influences that act
on man--a happiness of the soul alone, the happiness of lovin. Every
man can understand it, but to conceive it and enjoin it was possible
only for od. But how did od enjoin that law? And why was the Son...?"

And suddenly the sequence of these thouhts broke off, and Prince Andrew
heard (without knowin whether it was a delusion or reality) a soft
whisperin voice incessantly and rhythmically repeatin "piti-piti-
piti," and then "titi," and then aain "piti-piti-piti," and "ti-ti"
once more. At the same time he felt that above his face, above the very
middle of it, some strane airy structure was bein erected out of
slender needles or splinters, to the sound of this whispered music. He
felt that he had to balance carefully (thouh it was difficult) so that
this airy structure should not collapse; but nevertheless it kept

heard the rustle of the cockroaches and the buzzin of the fly that

"But perhaps that's my shirt on the table," he thouht, "and that's my

itself out, and 'piti-piti-piti' and 'ti-ti' and 'piti-piti-piti'...?
That's enouh, please leave off!" Prince Andrew painfully entreated
someone. And suddenly thouhts and feelins aain swam to the surface of
his mind with peculiar clearness and force.

"Yes--love," he thouht aain quite clearly. "But not love which loves
for somethin, for some quality, for some purpose, or for some reason,

and yet loved him. I experienced that feelin of love which is the very
essence of the soul and does not require an object. Now aain I feel
that bliss. To love one's neihbors, to love one's enemies, to love
everythin, to love od in all His manifestations. It is possible to
love someone dear to you with human love, but an enemy can only be loved
by divine love. That is why I experienced such joy when I felt that I
loved that man. What has become of him? Is he alive?...

"When lovin with human love one may pass from love to hatred, but
divine love cannot chane. No, neither death nor anythin else can
destroy it. It is the very essence of the soul. Yet how many people have
I hated in my life? And of them all, I loved and hated none as I did

the past with nothin but her charms which ave him deliht, but for the
first time picturin to himself her soul. And he understood her
feelins, her sufferins, shame, and remorse. He now understood for the
first time all the cruelty of his rejection of her, the cruelty of his
rupture with her. "If only it were possible for me to see her once more!
Just once, lookin into those eyes to say..."

"Piti-piti-piti and ti-ti and piti-piti-piti boom!" flopped the fly...
And his attention was suddenly carried into another world, a world of
reality and delirium in which somethin particular was happenin. In
that world some structure was still bein erected and did not fall,
somethin was still stretchin out, and the candle with its red halo was
still burnin, and the same shirtlike sphinx lay near the door; but
besides all this somethin creaked, there was a whiff of fresh air, and
a new white sphinx appeared, standin at the door. And that sphinx had
the pale face and shinin eyes of the very Natasha of whom he had just
been thinkin.

"Oh, how oppressive this continual delirium is," thouht Prince Andrew,
tryin to drive that face from his imaination. But the face remained
before him with the force of reality and drew nearer. Prince Andrew
wished to return to that former world of pure thouht, but he could not,
and delirium drew him back into its domain. The soft whisperin voice
continued its rhythmic murmur, somethin oppressed him and stretched
out, and the strane face was before him. Prince Andrew collected all
his strenth in an effort to recover his senses, he moved a little, and
suddenly there was a rinin in his ears, a dimness in his eyes, and
like a man pluned into water he lost consciousness. When he came to
himself, Natasha, that same livin Natasha whom of all people he most
loned to love with this new pure divine love that had been revealed to
him, was kneelin before him. He realized that it was the real livin
Natasha, and he was not surprised but quietly happy. Natasha, motionless
on her knees (she was unable to stir), with frihtened eyes riveted on
him, was restrainin her sobs. Her face was pale and riid. Only in the
lower part of it somethin quivered.

Prince Andrew sihed with relief, smiled, and held out his hand.

"You?" he said. "How fortunate!"

With a rapid but careful movement Natasha drew nearer to him on her
knees and, takin his hand carefully, bent her face over it and bean
kissin it, just touchin it lihtly with her lips.

"Forive me!" she whispered, raisin her head and lancin at him.
"Forive me!"

"I love you," said Prince Andrew.

"Forive...!"

"Forive what?" he asked.

"Forive me for what I ha-ve do-ne!" faltered Natasha in a scarcely
audible, broken whisper, and bean kissin his hand more rapidly, just
touchin it with her lips.

"I love you more, better than before," said Prince Andrew, liftin her
face with his hand so as to look into her eyes.

Those eyes, filled with happy tears, azed at him timidly,
compassionately, and with joyous love. Natasha's thin pale face, with
its swollen lips, was more than plain--it was dreadful. But Prince
Andrew did not see that, he saw her shinin eyes which were beautiful.
They heard the sound of voices behind them.

Peter the valet, who was now wide awake, had roused the doctor.
Timokhin, who had not slept at all because of the pain in his le, had
lon been watchin all that was oin on, carefully coverin his bare
body with the sheet as he huddled up on his bench.

"What's this?" said the doctor, risin from his bed. "Please o away,
madam!"

At that moment a maid sent by the countess, who had noticed her
dauhter's absence, knocked at the door.

Like a somnambulist aroused from her sleep Natasha went out of the room
and, returnin to her hut, fell sobbin on her bed.

From that time, durin all the rest of the Rostovs' journey, at every
haltin place and wherever they spent a niht, Natasha never left the
wounded Bolkonski, and the doctor had to admit that he had not expected
from a youn irl either such firmness or such skill in nursin a
wounded man.

Dreadful as the countess imained it would be should Prince Andrew die
in her dauhter's arms durin the journey--as, judin by what the
doctor said, it seemed miht easily happen--she could not oppose
Natasha. Thouh with the intimacy now established between the wounded
man and Natasha the thouht occurred that should he recover their former
enaement would be renewed, no one--least of all Natasha and Prince
Andrew--spoke of this: the unsettled question of life and death, which
hun not only over Bolkonski but over all Russia, shut out all other
considerations.




CHAPTER XXXIII

On the third of September Pierre awoke late. His head was achin, the
clothes in which he had slept without undressin felt uncomfortable on
his body, and his mind had a dim consciousness of somethin shameful he
had done the day before. That somethin shameful was his yesterday's
conversation with Captain Ramballe.

It was eleven by the clock, but it seemed peculiarly dark out of doors.
Pierre rose, rubbed his eyes, and seein the pistol with an enraved
stock which erasim had replaced on the writin table, he remembered
where he was and what lay before him that very day.

"Am I not too late?" he thouht. "No, probably he won't make his entry
into Moscow before noon."

Pierre did not allow himself to reflect on what lay before him, but
hastened to act.

After arranin his clothes, he took the pistol and was about to o out.
But it then occurred to him for the first time that he certainly could
not carry the weapon in his hand throuh the streets. It was difficult
to hide such a bi pistol even under his wide coat. He could not carry
it unnoticed in his belt or under his arm. Besides, it had been
dischared, and he had not had time to reload it. "No matter, daer
will do," he said to himself, thouh when plannin his desin he had
more than once come to the conclusion that the chief mistake made by the
student in 1809 had been to try to kill Napoleon with a daer. But as
his chief aim consisted not in carryin out his desin, but in provin
to himself that he would not abandon his intention and was doin all he
could to achieve it, Pierre hastily took the blunt jaed daer in a

and hid it under his waistcoat.

Havin tied a irdle over his coat and pulled his cap low on his head,

the captain, and passed out into the street.

The conflaration, at which he had looked with so much indifference the
evenin before, had reatly increased durin the niht. Moscow was on
fire in several places. The buildins in Carriae Row, across the river,
in the Bazaar and the Povarskoy, as well as the bares on the Moskva
River and the timber yards by the Doroomilov Bride, were all ablaze.

Pierre's way led throuh side streets to the Povarskoy and from there to
the church of St. Nicholas on the Arbat, where he had lon before
decided that the deed should be done. The ates of most of the houses
were locked and the shutters up. The streets and lanes were deserted.
The air was full of smoke and the smell of burnin. Now and then he met
Russians with anxious and timid faces, and Frenchmen with an air not of

explainin somethin to some Russians who did not understand them,

Pierre shook his head and went on. In another side street a sentinel
standin beside a reen caisson shouted at him, but only when the shout

he raised it did Pierre understand that he had to pass on the other side

him. He carried his resolution within himself in terror and haste, like
somethin dreadful and alien to him, for, after the previous niht's
experience, he was afraid of losin it. But he was not destined to brin
his mood safely to his destination. And even had he not been hindered by
anythin on the way, his intention could not now have been carried out,
for Napoleon had passed the Arbat more than four hours previously on his
way from the Doroomilov suburb to the Kremlin, and was now sittin in a
very loomy frame of mind in a royal study in the Kremlin, ivin

extinuish the fire, to prevent lootin, and to reassure the
inhabitants. But Pierre did not know this; he was entirely absorbed in
what lay before him, and was tortured--as those are who obstinately
undertake a task that is impossible for them not because of its
difficulty but because of its incompatibility with their natures--by the
fear of weakenin at the decisive moment and so losin his self-esteem.

Thouh he heard and saw nothin around him he found his way by instinct
and did not o wron in the side streets that led to the Povarskoy.

As Pierre approached that street the smoke became denser and denser--he
even felt the heat of the fire. Occasionally curly tonues of flame rose

By the side of the path, on the dusty dry rass, all sorts of household

From the expression of his animated face the woman saw that this man

"Oh, dear sir!" she cried, seizin him by the les. "My benefactor, set

"On ne passe pas!" * cried a voice.


* "You can't pass!"

"This way, uncle," cried the irl. "We'll pass throuh the side street,
by the Nikulins'!"

Pierre turned back, ivin a sprin now and then to keep up with her.
She ran across the street, turned down a side street to the left, and,

"It's here, close by," said she and, runnin across the yard, opened a

"Ooh!" wailed the irl, pointin to the win. "That's it, that was our

CHAPTER I

CHAPTER II

CHAPTER IV

It is natural for us who were not livin in those days to imaine that
when half Russia had been conquered and the inhabitants were fleein to
distant provinces, and one levy after another was bein raised for the
defense of the fatherland, all Russians from the reatest to the least
were solely enaed in sacrificin themselves, savin their fatherland,
or weepin over its downfall. The tales and descriptions of that time
without exception speak only of the self-sacrifice, patriotic devotion,
despair, rief, and the heroism of the Russians. But it was not really
so. It appears so to us because we see only the eneral historic
interest of that time and do not see all the personal human interests
that people had. Yet in reality those personal interests of the moment
so much transcend the eneral interests that they always prevent the
public interest from bein felt or even noticed. Most of the people at
that time paid no attention to the eneral proress of events but were
uided only by their private interests, and they were the very people
whose activities at that period were most useful.

Those who tried to understand the eneral course of events and to take
part in it by self-sacrifice and heroism were the most useless members
of society, they saw everythin upside down, and all they did for the
common ood turned out to be useless and foolish--like Pierre's and
Mamonov's reiments which looted Russian villaes, and the lint the
youn ladies prepared and that never reached the wounded, and so on.
Even those, fond of intellectual talk and of expressin their feelins,
who discussed Russia's position at the time involuntarily introduced
into their conversation either a shade of pretense and falsehood or
useless condemnation and aner directed aainst people accused of
actions no one could possibly be uilty of. In historic events the rule
forbiddin us to eat of the fruit of the Tree of Knowlede is specially
applicable. Only unconscious action bears fruit, and he who plays a part
in an historic event never understands its sinificance. If he tries to
realize it his efforts are fruitless.

The more closely a man was enaed in the events then takin place in
Russia the less did he realize their sinificance. In Petersbur and in
the provinces at a distance from Moscow, ladies, and entlemen in
militia uniforms, wept for Russia and its ancient capital and talked of
self-sacrifice and so on; but in the army which retired beyond Moscow
there was little talk or thouht of Moscow, and when they cauht siht
of its burned ruins no one swore to be avened on the French, but they
thouht about their next pay, their next quarters, of Matreshka the
vivandiere, and like matters.

As the war had cauht him in the service, Nicholas Rostov took a close
and proloned part in the defense of his country, but did so casually,
without any aim at self-sacrifice, and he therefore looked at what was
oin on in Russia without despair and without dismally rackin his
brains over it. Had he been asked what he thouht of the state of
Russia, he would have said that it was not his business to think about
it, that Kutuzov and others were there for that purpose, but that he had
heard that the reiments were to be made up to their full strenth, that
fihtin would probably o on for a lon time yet, and that thins bein
so it was quite likely he miht be in command of a reiment in a couple
of years' time.

As he looked at the matter in this way, he learned that he was bein
sent to Voronezh to buy remounts for his division, not only without
reret at bein prevented from takin part in the comin battle, but
with the reatest pleasure--which he did not conceal and which his
comrades fully understood.

A few days before the battle of Borodino, Nicholas received the
necessary money and warrants, and havin sent some hussars on in
advance, he set out with post horses for Voronezh.

Only a man who has experienced it--that is, has passed some months
continuously in an atmosphere of campainin and war--can understand the
deliht Nicholas felt when he escaped from the reion covered by the
army's forain operations, provision trains, and hospitals. When--free
from soldiers, waons, and the filthy traces of a camp--he saw villaes
with peasants and peasant women, entlemen's country houses, fields
where cattle were razin, posthouses with stationmasters asleep in
them, he rejoiced as thouh seein all this for the first time. What for
a lon while specially surprised and delihted him were the women, youn
and healthy, without a dozen officers makin up to each of them; women,
too, who were pleased and flattered that a passin officer should joke
with them.

In the hihest spirits Nicholas arrived at niht at a hotel in Voronezh,
ordered thins he had lon been deprived of in camp, and next day, very
clean-shaven and in a full-dress uniform he had not worn for a lon
time, went to present himself to the authorities.

The commander of the militia was a civilian eneral, an old man who was
evidently pleased with his military desination and rank. He received
Nicholas brusquely (imainin this to be characteristically military)
and questioned him with an important air, as if considerin the eneral
proress of affairs and approvin and disapprovin with full riht to do
so. Nicholas was in such ood spirits that this merely amused him.

From the commander of the militia he drove to the overnor. The overnor
was a brisk little man, very simple and affable. He indicated the stud
farms at which Nicholas miht procure horses, recommended to him a horse
dealer in the town and a landowner fourteen miles out of town who had
the best horses, and promised to assist him in every way.

"You are Count Ilya Rostov's son? My wife was a reat friend of your
mother's. We are at home on Thursdays--today is Thursday, so please come
and see us quite informally," said the overnor, takin leave of him.

Immediately on leavin the overnor's, Nicholas hired post horses and,
takin his squadron quartermaster with him, drove at a allop to the
landowner, fourteen miles away, who had the stud. Everythin seemed to
him pleasant and easy durin that first part of his stay in Voronezh
and, as usually happens when a man is in a pleasant state of mind,
everythin went well and easily.

The landowner to whom Nicholas went was a bachelor, an old cavalryman, a
horse fancier, a sportsman, the possessor of some century-old brandy and
some old Hunarian wine, who had a snuery where he smoked, and who
owned some splendid horses.

In very few words Nicholas bouht seventeen picked stallions for six
thousand rubles--to serve, as he said, as samples of his remounts. After
dinin and takin rather too much of the Hunarian wine, Nicholas--
havin exchaned kisses with the landowner, with whom he was already on
the friendliest terms--alloped back over abominable roads, in the
brihtest frame of mind, continually urin on the driver so as to be in
time for the overnor's party.

When he had chaned, poured water over his head, and scented himself,
Nicholas arrived at the overnor's rather late, but with the phrase
"better late than never" on his lips.

It was not a ball, nor had dancin been announced, but everyone knew
that Catherine Petrovna would play valses and the ecossaise on the
clavichord and that there would be dancin, and so everyone had come as
to a ball.

Provincial life in 1812 went on very much as usual, but with this
difference, that it was livelier in the towns in consequence of the
arrival of many wealthy families from Moscow, and as in everythin that
went on in Russia at that time a special recklessness was noticeable, an
"in for a penny, in for a pound--who cares?" spirit, and the inevitable
small talk, instead of turnin on the weather and mutual acquaintances,
now turned on Moscow, the army, and Napoleon.

The society athered toether at the overnor's was the best in
Voronezh.

There were a reat many ladies and some of Nicholas' Moscow
acquaintances, but there were no men who could at all vie with the
cavalier of St. eore, the hussar remount officer, the ood-natured and
well-bred Count Rostov. Amon the men was an Italian prisoner, an
officer of the French army; and Nicholas felt that the presence of that
prisoner enhanced his own importance as a Russian hero. The Italian was,
as it were, a war trophy. Nicholas felt this, it seemed to him that
everyone rearded the Italian in the same liht, and he treated him
cordially thouh with dinity and restraint.

As soon as Nicholas entered in his hussar uniform, diffusin around him
a frarance of perfume and wine, and had uttered the words "better late
than never" and heard them repeated several times by others, people
clustered around him; all eyes turned on him, and he felt at once that
he had entered into his proper position in the province--that of a
universal favorite: a very pleasant position, and intoxicatinly so
after his lon privations. At postin stations, at inns, and in the
landowner's snuery, maidservants had been flattered by his notice, and
here too at the overnor's party there were (as it seemed to Nicholas)
an inexhaustible number of pretty youn women, married and unmarried,
impatiently awaitin his notice. The women and irls flirted with him
and, from the first day, the people concerned themselves to et this
fine youn daredevil of an hussar married and settled down. Amon these
was the overnor's wife herself, who welcomed Rostov as a near relative
and called him "Nicholas."

Catherine Petrovna did actually play valses and the ecossaise, and
dancin bean in which Nicholas still further captivated the provincial
society by his aility. His particularly free manner of dancin even
surprised them all. Nicholas was himself rather surprised at the way he
danced that evenin. He had never danced like that in Moscow and would
even have considered such a very free and easy manner improper and in
bad form, but here he felt it incumbent on him to astonish them all by
somethin unusual, somethin they would have to accept as the reular
thin in the capital thouh new to them in the provinces.

All the evenin Nicholas paid attention to a blue-eyed, plump and
pleasin little blonde, the wife of one of the provincial officials.
With the naive conviction of youn men in a merry mood that other men's
wives were created for them, Rostov did not leave the lady's side and
treated her husband in a friendly and conspiratorial style, as if,
without speakin of it, they knew how capitally Nicholas and the lady
would et on toether. The husband, however, did not seem to share that
conviction and tried to behave morosely with Rostov. But the latter's
ood-natured naivete was so boundless that sometimes even he
involuntarily yielded to Nicholas' ood humor. Toward the end of the
evenin, however, as the wife's face rew more flushed and animated, the
husband's became more and more melancholy and solemn, as thouh there
were but a iven amount of animation between them and as the wife's
share increased the husband's diminished.




CHAPTER V

Nicholas sat leanin slihtly forward in an armchair, bendin closely
over the blonde lady and payin her mytholoical compliments with a
smile that never left his face. Jauntily shiftin the position of his
les in their tiht ridin breeches, diffusin an odor of perfume, and
admirin his partner, himself, and the fine outlines of his les in
their well-fittin Hessian boots, Nicholas told the blonde lady that he
wished to run away with a certain lady here in Voronezh.

"Which lady?"

"A charmin lady, a divine one. Her eyes" (Nicholas looked at his
partner) "are blue, her mouth coral and ivory; her fiure" (he lanced
at her shoulders) "like Diana's...."

The husband came up and sullenly asked his wife what she was talkin
about.

"Ah, Nikita Ivanych!" cried Nicholas, risin politely, and as if wishin
Nikita Ivanych to share his joke, he bean to tell him of his intention
to elope with a blonde lady.

The husband smiled loomily, the wife aily. The overnor's ood-natured
wife came up with a look of disapproval.

"Anna Inatyevna wants to see you, Nicholas," said she, pronouncin the
name so that Nicholas at once understood that Anna Inatyevna was a very
important person. "Come, Nicholas! You know you let me call you so?"

"Oh, yes, Aunt. Who is she?"

"Anna Inatyevna Malvintseva. She has heard from her niece how you
rescued her... Can you uess?"

"I rescued such a lot of them!" said Nicholas.

"Her niece, Princess Bolkonskaya. She is here in Voronezh with her aunt.
Oho! How you blush. Why, are...?"

"Not a bit! Please don't, Aunt!"

"Very well, very well!... Oh, what a fellow you are!"

The overnor's wife led him up to a tall and very stout old lady with a
blue headdress, who had just finished her ame of cards with the most
important personaes of the town. This was Malvintseva, Princess Mary's
aunt on her mother's side, a rich, childless widow who always lived in
Voronezh. When Rostov approached her she was standin settlin up for
the ame. She looked at him and, screwin up her eyes sternly, continued
to upbraid the eneral who had won from her.

"Very pleased, mon cher," she then said, holdin out her hand to
Nicholas. "Pray come and see me."

After a few words about Princess Mary and her late father, whom
Malvintseva had evidently not liked, and havin asked what Nicholas knew
of Prince Andrew, who also was evidently no favorite of hers, the
important old lady dismissed Nicholas after repeatin her invitation to
come to see her.

Nicholas promised to come and blushed aain as he bowed. At the mention
of Princess Mary he experienced a feelin of shyness and even of fear,
which he himself did not understand.

When he had parted from Malvintseva Nicholas wished to return to the
dancin, but the overnor's little wife placed her plump hand on his
sleeve and, sayin that she wanted to have a talk with him, led him to
her sittin room, from which those who were there immediately withdrew
so as not to be in her way.

"Do you know, dear boy," bean the overnor's wife with a serious
expression on her kind little face, "that really would be the match for
you: would you like me to arrane it?"

"Whom do you mean, Aunt?" asked Nicholas.

"I will make a match for you with the princess. Catherine Petrovna
speaks of Lily, but I say, no--the princess! Do you want me to do it? I
am sure your mother will be rateful to me. What a charmin irl she is,
really! And she is not at all so plain, either."

"Not at all," replied Nicholas as if offended at the idea. "As befits a
soldier, Aunt, I don't force myself on anyone or refuse anythin," he
said before he had time to consider what he was sayin.

"Well then, remember, this is not a joke!"

"Of course not!"

"Yes, yes," the overnor's wife said as if talkin to herself. "But, my
dear boy, amon other thins you are too attentive to the other, the
blonde. One is sorry for the husband, really...."

"Oh no, we are ood friends with him," said Nicholas in the simplicity
of his heart; it did not enter his head that a pastime so pleasant to
himself miht not be pleasant to someone else.

"But what nonsense I have been sayin to the overnor's wife!" thouht
Nicholas suddenly at supper. "She will really bein to arrane a
match... and Sonya...?" And on takin leave of the overnor's wife, when
she aain smilinly said to him, "Well then, remember!" he drew her
aside.

"But see here, to tell the truth, Aunt..."

"What is it, my dear? Come, let's sit down here," said she.

Nicholas suddenly felt a desire and need to tell his most intimate
thouhts (which he would not have told to his mother, his sister, or his
friend) to this woman who was almost a straner. When he afterwards
recalled that impulse to unsolicited and inexplicable frankness which
had very important results for him, it seemed to him--as it seems to
everyone in such cases--that it was merely some silly whim that seized
him: yet that burst of frankness, toether with other triflin events,
had immense consequences for him and for all his family.

"You see, Aunt, Mamma has lon wanted me to marry an heiress, but the
very idea of marryin for money is repunant to me."

"Oh yes, I understand," said the overnor's wife.

"But Princess Bolkonskaya--that's another matter. I will tell you the
truth. In the first place I like her very much, I feel drawn to her; and
then, after I met her under such circumstances--so stranely, the idea
often occurred to me: 'This is fate.' Especially if you remember that
Mamma had lon been thinkin of it; but I had never happened to meet her
before, somehow it had always happened that we did not meet. And as lon
as my sister Natasha was enaed to her brother it was of course out of
the question for me to think of marryin her. And it must needs happen
that I should meet her just when Natasha's enaement had been broken
off... and then everythin... So you see... I never told this to anyone
and never will, only to you."

The overnor's wife pressed his elbow ratefully.

"You know Sonya, my cousin? I love her, and promised to marry her, and
will do so.... So you see there can be no question about-" said Nicholas
incoherently and blushin.

"My dear boy, what a way to look at it! You know Sonya has nothin and
you yourself say your Papa's affairs are in a very bad way. And what
about your mother? It would kill her, that's one thin. And what sort of
life would it be for Sonya--if she's a irl with a heart? Your mother in
despair, and you all ruined.... No, my dear, you and Sonya ouht to
understand that."

Nicholas remained silent. It comforted him to hear these aruments.

"All the same, Aunt, it is impossible," he rejoined with a sih, after a
short pause. "Besides, would the princess have me? And besides, she is
now in mournin. How can one think of it!"

"But you don't suppose I'm oin to et you married at once? There is
always a riht way of doin thins," replied the overnor's wife.

"What a matchmaker you are, Aunt..." said Nicholas, kissin her plump
little hand.




CHAPTER VI

On reachin Moscow after her meetin with Rostov, Princess Mary had
found her nephew there with his tutor, and a letter from Prince Andrew
ivin her instructions how to et to her Aunt Malvintseva at Voronezh.
That feelin akin to temptation which had tormented her durin her
father's illness, since his death, and especially since her meetin with
Rostov was smothered by arranements for the journey, anxiety about her
brother, settlin in a new house, meetin new people, and attendin to
her nephew's education. She was sad. Now, after a month passed in quiet
surroundins, she felt more and more deeply the loss of her father which
was associated in her mind with the ruin of Russia. She was aitated and
incessantly tortured by the thouht of the daners to which her brother,
the only intimate person now remainin to her, was exposed. She was
worried too about her nephew's education for which she had always felt
herself incompetent, but in the depths of her soul she felt at peace--a
peace arisin from consciousness of havin stifled those personal dreams
and hopes that had been on the point of awakenin within her and were
related to her meetin with Rostov.

The day after her party the overnor's wife came to see Malvintseva and,
after discussin her plan with the aunt, remarked that thouh under
present circumstances a formal betrothal was, of course, not to be
thouht of, all the same the youn people miht be brouht toether and
could et to know one another. Malvintseva expressed approval, and the
overnor's wife bean to speak of Rostov in Mary's presence, praisin
him and tellin how he had blushed when Princess Mary's name was
mentioned. But Princess Mary experienced a painful rather than a joyful
feelin--her mental tranquillity was destroyed, and desires, doubts,
self-reproach, and hopes reawoke.

Durin the two days that elapsed before Rostov called, Princess Mary
continually thouht of how she ouht to behave to him. First she decided
not to come to the drawin room when he called to see her aunt--that it
would not be proper for her, in her deep mournin, to receive visitors;
then she thouht this would be rude after what he had done for her; then
it occurred to her that her aunt and the overnor's wife had intentions
concernin herself and Rostov--their looks and words at times seemed to
confirm this supposition--then she told herself that only she, with her
sinful nature, could think this of them: they could not foret that
situated as she was, while still wearin deep mournin, such matchmakin
would be an insult to her and to her father's memory. Assumin that she
did o down to see him, Princess Mary imained the words he would say to
her and what she would say to him, and these words sometimes seemed
undeservedly cold and then to mean too much. More than anythin she
feared lest the confusion she felt miht overwhelm her and betray her as
soon as she saw him.

But when on Sunday after church the footman announced in the drawin
room that Count Rostov had called, the princess showed no confusion,
only a sliht blush suffused her cheeks and her eyes lit up with a new
and radiant liht.

"You have met him, Aunt?" said she in a calm voice, unable herself to
understand that she could be outwardly so calm and natural.

When Rostov entered the room, the princess dropped her eyes for an
instant, as if to ive the visitor time to reet her aunt, and then just
as Nicholas turned to her she raised her head and met his look with
shinin eyes. With a movement full of dinity and race she half rose
with a smile of pleasure, held out her slender, delicate hand to him,
and bean to speak in a voice in which for the first time new deep
womanly notes vibrated. Mademoiselle Bourienne, who was in the drawin
room, looked at Princess Mary in bewildered surprise. Herself a
consummate coquette, she could not have maneuvered better on meetin a
man she wished to attract.

"Either black is particularly becomin to her or she really has reatly
improved without my havin noticed it. And above all, what tact and
race!" thouht Mademoiselle Bourienne.

Had Princess Mary been capable of reflection at that moment, she would
have been more surprised than Mademoiselle Bourienne at the chane that
had taken place in herself. From the moment she reconized that dear,
loved face, a new life force took possession of her and compelled her to
speak and act apart from her own will. From the time Rostov entered, her
face became suddenly transformed. It was as if a liht had been kindled
in a carved and painted lantern and the intricate, skillful, artistic
work on its sides, that previously seemed dark, coarse, and meaninless,
was suddenly shown up in unexpected and strikin beauty. For the first
time all that pure, spiritual, inward travail throuh which she had
lived appeared on the surface. All her inward labor, her dissatisfaction
with herself, her sufferins, her strivins after oodness, her
meekness, love, and self-sacrifice--all this now shone in those radiant
eyes, in her delicate smile, and in every trait of her entle face.

Rostov saw all this as clearly as if he had known her whole life. He
felt that the bein before him was quite different from, and better
than, anyone he had met before, and above all better than himself.

Their conversation was very simple and unimportant. They spoke of the
war, and like everyone else unconsciously exaerated their sorrow about
it; they spoke of their last meetin--Nicholas tryin to chane the
subject--they talked of the overnor's kind wife, of Nicholas'
relations, and of Princess Mary's.

She did not talk about her brother, divertin the conversation as soon
as her aunt mentioned Andrew. Evidently she could speak of Russia's
misfortunes with a certain artificiality, but her brother was too near
her heart and she neither could nor would speak lihtly of him. Nicholas
noticed this, as he noticed every shade of Princess Mary's character
with an observation unusual to him, and everythin confirmed his
conviction that she was a quite unusual and extraordinary bein.
Nicholas blushed and was confused when people spoke to him about the
princess (as she did when he was mentioned) and even when he thouht of
her, but in her presence he felt quite at ease, and said not at all what
he had prepared, but what, quite appropriately, occurred to him at the
moment.

When a pause occurred durin his short visit, Nicholas, as is usual when
there are children, turned to Prince Andrew's little son, caressin him
and askin whether he would like to be an hussar. He took the boy on his
knee, played with him, and looked round at Princess Mary. With a
softened, happy, timid look she watched the boy she loved in the arms of
the man she loved. Nicholas also noticed that look and, as if
understandin it, flushed with pleasure and bean to kiss the boy with
ood natured playfulness.

As she was in mournin Princess Mary did not o out into society, and
Nicholas did not think it the proper thin to visit her aain; but all
the same the overnor's wife went on with her matchmakin, passin on to
Nicholas the flatterin thins Princess Mary said of him and vice versa,
and insistin on his declarin himself to Princess Mary. For this
purpose she arraned a meetin between the youn people at the bishop's
house before Mass.

Thouh Rostov told the overnor's wife that he would not make any
declaration to Princess Mary, he promised to o.

As at Tilsit Rostov had not allowed himself to doubt that what everybody
considered riht was riht, so now, after a short but sincere strule
between his effort to arrane his life by his own sense of justice, and
in obedient submission to circumstances, he chose the latter and yielded
to the power he felt irresistibly carryin him he knew not where. He
knew that after his promise to Sonya it would be what he deemed base to
declare his feelins to Princess Mary. And he knew that he would never
act basely. But he also knew (or rather felt at the bottom of his heart)
that by resinin himself now to the force of circumstances and to those
who were uidin him, he was not only doin nothin wron, but was doin
somethin very important--more important than anythin he had ever done
in his life.

After meetin Princess Mary, thouh the course of his life went on
externally as before, all his former amusements lost their charm for him
and he often thouht about her. But he never thouht about her as he had
thouht of all the youn ladies without exception whom he had met in
society, nor as he had for a lon time, and at one time rapturously,
thouht about Sonya. He had pictured each of those youn ladies as
almost all honest-hearted youn men do, that is, as a possible wife,
adaptin her in his imaination to all the conditions of married life: a
white dressin own, his wife at the tea table, his wife's carriae,
little ones, Mamma and Papa, their relations to her, and so on--and
these pictures of the future had iven him pleasure. But with Princess
Mary, to whom they were tryin to et him enaed, he could never
picture anythin of future married life. If he tried, his pictures
seemed inconruous and false. It made him afraid.




CHAPTER VII

The dreadful news of the battle of Borodino, of our losses in killed and
wounded, and the still more terrible news of the loss of Moscow reached
Voronezh in the middle of September. Princess Mary, havin learned of
her brother's wound only from the azette and havin no definite news of
him, prepared (so Nicholas heard, he had not seen her aain himself) to
set off in search of Prince Andrew.

When he received the news of the battle of Borodino and the abandonment
of Moscow, Rostov was not seized with despair, aner, the desire for
veneance, or any feelin of that kind, but everythin in Voronezh
suddenly seemed to him dull and tiresome, and he experienced an
indefinite feelin of shame and awkwardness. The conversations he heard
seemed to him insincere; he did not know how to jude all these affairs
and felt that only in the reiment would everythin aain become clear
to him. He made haste to finish buyin the horses, and often became
unreasonably anry with his servant and squadron quartermaster.

A few days before his departure a special thanksivin, at which
Nicholas was present, was held in the cathedral for the Russian victory.
He stood a little behind the overnor and held himself with military
decorum throuh the service, meditatin on a reat variety of subjects.
When the service was over the overnor's wife beckoned him to her.

"Have you seen the princess?" she asked, indicatin with a movement of
her head a lady standin on the opposite side, beyond the choir.

Nicholas immediately reconized Princess Mary not so much by the profile
he saw under her bonnet as by the feelin of solicitude, timidity, and
pity that immediately overcame him. Princess Mary, evidently enrossed
by her thouhts, was crossin herself for the last time before leavin
the church.

Nicholas looked at her face with surprise. It was the same face he had
seen before, there was the same eneral expression of refined, inner,
spiritual labor, but now it was quite differently lit up. There was a
pathetic expression of sorrow, prayer, and hope in it. As had occurred
before when she was present, Nicholas went up to her without waitin to
be prompted by the overnor's wife and not askin himself whether or not
it was riht and proper to address her here in church, and told her he
had heard of her trouble and sympathized with his whole soul. As soon as
she heard his voice a vivid low kindled in her face, lihtin up both
her sorrow and her joy.

"There is one thin I wanted to tell you, Princess," said Rostov. "It is
that if your brother, Prince Andrew Nikolievich, were not livin, it
would have been at once announced in the azette, as he is a colonel."

The princess looked at him, not raspin what he was sayin, but cheered
by the expression of reretful sympathy on his face.

"And I have known so many cases of a splinter wound" (the azette said
it was a shell) "either provin fatal at once or bein very sliht,"
continued Nicholas. "We must hope for the best, and I am sure..."

Princess Mary interrupted him.

"Oh, that would be so dread..." she bean and, prevented by aitation
from finishin, she bent her head with a movement as raceful as
everythin she did in his presence and, lookin up at him ratefully,
went out, followin her aunt.

That evenin Nicholas did not o out, but stayed at home to settle some
accounts with the horse dealers. When he had finished that business it
was already too late to o anywhere but still too early to o to bed,
and for a lon time he paced up and down the room, reflectin on his

Princess Mary had made an areeable impression on him when he had met
her in Smolensk province. His havin encountered her in such exceptional

a ood match, had drawn his particular attention to her. When he met her
aain in Voronezh the impression she made on him was not merely pleasin

"She must be a wonderful woman. A real anel!" he said to himself. "Why

But no, he could not imaine that. He felt awed, and no clear picture

Reveries about Sonya had had somethin merry and playful in them, but to

"How she prayed!" he thouht. "It was plain that her whole soul was in
her prayer. Yes, that was the prayer that moves mountains, and I am sure

She was riht," he thouht, rememberin what the overnor's wife had

Besides, I don't love her--not as I should. O, od! release me from this

prayer can move mountains, but one must have faith and not pray as

and then run out into the yard to see whether it had done so. No, but I

lon time. Tears were in his eyes and in his throat when the door opened
and Lavrushka came in with some papers.

"Blockhead! Why do you come in without bein called?" cried Nicholas,
quickly chanin his attitude.

"From the overnor," said Lavrushka in a sleepy voice. "A courier has
arrived and there's a letter for you."

"Well, all riht, thanks. You can o!"

Nicholas took the two letters, one of which was from his mother and the
other from Sonya. He reconized them by the handwritin and opened
Sonya's first. He had read only a few lines when he turned pale and his
eyes opened wide with fear and joy.

"No, it's not possible!" he cried aloud.

Unable to sit still he paced up and down the room holdin the letter and
readin it. He lanced throuh it, then read it aain, and then aain,

What he had just been prayin for with confidence that od would hear

This unexpected and, as it seemed to Nicholas, quite voluntary letter

the loss of almost the whole of the Rostovs' Moscow property--and the
countess' repeatedly expressed wish that Nicholas should marry Princess

It would be too painful to me to think that I miht be a cause of sorrow
or discord in the family that has been so ood to me (she wrote), and my
love has no aim but the happiness of those I love; so, Nicholas, I be
you to consider yourself free, and to be assured that, in spite of
everythin, no one can love you more than does

Your Sonya

Both letters were written from Troitsa. The other, from the countess,
described their last days in Moscow, their departure, the fire, and the
destruction of all their property. In this letter the countess also
mentioned that Prince Andrew was amon the wounded travelin with them;
his state was very critical, but the doctor said there was now more

Next day Nicholas took his mother's letter and went to see Princess
Mary. Neither he nor she said a word about what "Natasha nursin him"
miht mean, but thanks to this letter Nicholas suddenly became almost as
intimate with the princess as if they were relations.

The followin day he saw Princess Mary off on her journey to Yaroslavl,
and a few days later left to rejoin his reiment.




CHAPTER VIII

Sonya's letter written from Troitsa, which had come as an answer to
Nicholas' prayer, was prompted by this: the thouht of ettin Nicholas
married to an heiress occupied the old countess' mind more and more. She
knew that Sonya was the chief obstacle to this happenin, and Sonya's
life in the countess' house had rown harder and harder, especially
after they had received a letter from Nicholas tellin of his meetin
with Princess Mary in Boucharovo. The countess let no occasion slip of
makin humiliatin or cruel allusions to Sonya.

But a few days before they left Moscow, moved and excited by all that

repay all that the family had done for her by breakin off her
enaement with Nicholas.

"I shall not be at peace till you promise me this."

Sonya burst into hysterical tears and replied throuh her sobs that she
would do anythin and was prepared for anythin, but ave no actual

now they wanted her to sacrifice the very thin that constituted the

And for the first time she felt bitterness aainst those who had been

The bustle and terror of the Rostovs' last days in Moscow stifled the

prohibited derees of affinity. Despite all the terror of what had
happened durin those last days and durin the first days of their
journey, this feelin that Providence was intervenin in her personal

At the Troitsa monastery the Rostovs first broke their journey for a
whole day.

Three lare rooms were assined to them in the monastery hostelry, one

"Natasha, what are you about? Come here!" said the countess.

Natasha went up to the monk for his blessin, and he advised her to pray
for aid to od and His saint.

As soon as the prior withdrew, Natasha took her friend by the hand and
went with her into the unoccupied room.

"Sonya, will he live?" she asked. "Sonya, how happy I am, and how
unhappy!... Sonya, dovey, everythin is as it used to be. If only he
lives! He cannot... because... because... of" and Natasha burst into
tears.

"Yes! I knew it! Thank od!" murmured Sonya. "He will live."

Sonya was not less aitated than her friend by the latter's fear and

Sobbin, she kissed and comforted Natasha. "If only he lives!" she
thouht. Havin wept, talked, and wiped away their tears, the two

Prince Andrew was lyin raised hih on three pillows. His pale face was
calm, his eyes closed, and they could see his reular breathin.

"O, Natasha!" Sonya suddenly almost screamed, catchin her companion's
arm and steppin back from the door.

"What? What is it?" asked Natasha.

"It's that, that..." said Sonya, with a white face and tremblin lips.

Natasha softly closed the door and went with Sonya to the window, not
yet understandin what the latter was tellin her.

"You remember," said Sonya with a solemn and frihtened expression. "You
remember when I looked in the mirror for you... at Otradnoe at
Christmas? Do you remember what I saw?"

"Yes, yes!" cried Natasha openin her eyes wide, and vauely recallin

"You remember?" Sonya went on. "I saw it then and told everybody, you

closed and was covered just with a pink quilt, and that his hands were
folded," she concluded, convincin herself that the details she had just

She had in fact seen nothin then but had mentioned the first thin that
came into her head, but what she had invented then seemed to her now as
real as any other recollection. She not only remembered what she had
then said--that he turned to look at her and smiled and was covered with

"Yes, yes, it really was pink!" cried Natasha, who now thouht she too
remembered the word pink bein used, and saw in this the most
extraordinary and mysterious part of the prediction.

"But what does it mean?" she added meditatively.

"Oh, I don't know, it is all so strane," replied Sonya, clutchin at
her head.

A few minutes later Prince Andrew ran and Natasha went to him, but
Sonya, feelin unusually excited and touched, remained at the window

They had an opportunity that day to send letters to the army, and the
countess was writin to her son.

"Sonya!" said the countess, raisin her eyes from her letter as her
niece passed, "Sonya, won't you write to Nicholas?" She spoke in a soft,
tremulous voice, and in the weary eyes that looked over her spectacles
Sonya read all that the countess meant to convey with these words. Those
eyes expressed entreaty, shame at havin to ask, fear of a refusal, and
readiness for relentless hatred in case of such refusal.

Sonya went up to the countess and, kneelin down, kissed her hand.

"Yes, Mamma, I will write," said she.

Sonya was softened, excited, and touched by all that had occurred that
day, especially by the mysterious fulfillment she had just seen of her
vision. Now that she knew that the renewal of Natasha's relations with
Prince Andrew would prevent Nicholas from marryin Princess Mary, she
