consciousness of performin a mananimous deed--interrupted several
times by the tears that dimmed her velvety black eyes--she wrote that
touchin letter the arrival of which had so amazed Nicholas.




CHAPTER IX

The officer and soldiers who had arrested Pierre treated him with
hostility but yet with respect, in the uardhouse to which he was taken.
In their attitude toward him could still be felt both uncertainty as to
who he miht be--perhaps a very important person--and hostility as a
result of their recent personal conflict with him.

But when the uard was relieved next mornin, Pierre felt that for the
new uard--both officers and men--he was not as interestin as he had
been to his captors; and in fact the uard of the second day did not
reconize in this bi, stout man in a peasant coat the viorous person
who had fouht so desperately with the marauder and the convoy and had
uttered those solemn words about savin a child; they saw in him only
No. 17 of the captured Russians, arrested and detained for some reason
by order of the Hiher Command. If they noticed anythin remarkable
about Pierre, it was only his unabashed, meditative concentration and
thouhtfulness, and the way he spoke French, which struck them as
surprisinly ood. In spite of this he was placed that day with the
other arrested suspects, as the separate room he had occupied was
required by an officer.

All the Russians confined with Pierre were men of the lowest class and,
reconizin him as a entleman, they all avoided him, more especially as
he spoke French. Pierre felt sad at hearin them makin fun of him.

That evenin he learned that all these prisoners (he, probably, amon
them) were to be tried for incendiarism. On the third day he was taken
with the others to a house where a French eneral with a white mustache
sat with two colonels and other Frenchmen with scarves on their arms.
With the precision and definiteness customary in addressin prisoners,
and which is supposed to preclude human frailty, Pierre like the others
was questioned as to who he was, where he had been, with what object,
and so on.

These questions, like questions put at trials enerally, left the
essence of the matter aside, shut out the possibility of that essence's
bein revealed, and were desined only to form a channel throuh which
the judes wished the answers of the accused to flow so as to lead to
the desired result, namely a conviction. As soon as Pierre bean to say
anythin that did not fit in with that aim, the channel was removed and
the water could flow to waste. Pierre felt, moreover, what the accused
always feel at their trial, perplexity as to why these questions were
put to him. He had a feelin that it was only out of condescension or a
kind of civility that this device of placin a channel was employed. He
knew he was in these men's power, that only by force had they brouht
him there, that force alone ave them the riht to demand answers to
their questions, and that the sole object of that assembly was to
inculpate him. And so, as they had the power and wish to inculpate him,
this expedient of an inquiry and trial seemed unnecessary. It was
evident that any answer would lead to conviction. When asked what he was
doin when he was arrested, Pierre replied in a rather traic manner
that he was restorin to its parents a child he had saved from the
flames. Why had he fouht the marauder? Pierre answered that he "was
protectin a woman," and that "to protect a woman who was bein insulted
was the duty of every man; that..." They interrupted him, for this was
not to the point. Why was he in the yard of a burnin house where
witnesses had seen him? He replied that he had one out to see what was
happenin in Moscow. Aain they interrupted him: they had not asked
where he was oin, but why he was found near the fire? Who was he? they
asked, repeatin their first question, which he had declined to answer.
Aain he replied that he could not answer it.

"Put that down, that's bad... very bad," sternly remarked the eneral
with the white mustache and red flushed face.

On the fourth day fires broke out on the Zubovski rampart.

Pierre and thirteen others were moved to the coach house of a merchant's
house near the Crimean bride. On his way throuh the streets Pierre
felt stifled by the smoke which seemed to han over the whole city.
Fires were visible on all sides. He did not then realize the
sinificance of the burnin of Moscow, and looked at the fires with
horror.

He passed four days in the coach house near the Crimean bride and
durin that time learned, from the talk of the French soldiers, that all
those confined there were awaitin a decision which miht come any day
from the marshal. What marshal this was, Pierre could not learn from the
soldiers. Evidently for them "the marshal" represented a very hih and
rather mysterious power.

These first days, before the eihth of September when the prisoners were
had up for a second examination, were the hardest of all for Pierre.




CHAPTER X

On the eihth of September an officer--a very important one judin by
the respect the uards showed him--entered the coach house where the
prisoners were. This officer, probably someone on the staff, was holdin
a paper in his hand, and called over all the Russians there, namin
Pierre as "the man who does not ive his name." lancin indolently and
indifferently at all the prisoners, he ordered the officer in chare to
have them decently dressed and tidied up before takin them to the
marshal. An hour later a squad of soldiers arrived and Pierre with
thirteen others was led to the Virin's Field. It was a fine day, sunny
after rain, and the air was unusually pure. The smoke did not han low
as on the day when Pierre had been taken from the uardhouse on the
Zubovski rampart, but rose throuh the pure air in columns. No flames
were seen, but columns of smoke rose on all sides, and all Moscow as far
as Pierre could see was one vast charred ruin. On all sides there were
waste spaces with only stoves and chimney stacks still standin, and
here and there the blackened walls of some brick houses. Pierre azed at
the ruins and did not reconize districts he had known well. Here and
there he could see churches that had not been burned. The Kremlin, which
was not destroyed, leamed white in the distance with its towers and the
belfry of Ivan the reat. The domes of the New Convent of the Virin
littered brihtly and its bells were rinin particularly clearly.
These bells reminded Pierre that it was Sunday and the feast of the
Nativity of the Virin. But there seemed to be no one to celebrate this
holiday: everywhere were blackened ruins, and the few Russians to be
seen were tattered and frihtened people who tried to hide when they saw
the French.

It was plain that the Russian nest was ruined and destroyed, but in
place of the Russian order of life that had been destroyed, Pierre
unconsciously felt that a quite different, firm, French order had been
established over this ruined nest. He felt this in the looks of the
soldiers who, marchin in reular ranks briskly and aily, were
escortin him and the other criminals; he felt it in the looks of an
important French official in a carriae and pair driven by a soldier,
whom they met on the way. He felt it in the merry sounds of reimental
music he heard from the left side of the field, and felt and realized it
especially from the list of prisoners the French officer had read out
when he came that mornin. Pierre had been taken by one set of soldiers
and led first to one and then to another place with dozens of other men,
and it seemed that they miht have forotten him, or confused him with
the others. But no: the answers he had iven when questioned had come
back to him in his desination as "the man who does not ive his name,"
and under that appellation, which to Pierre seemed terrible, they were
now leadin him somewhere with unhesitatin assurance on their faces
that he and all the other prisoners were exactly the ones they wanted
and that they were bein taken to the proper place. Pierre felt himself
to be an insinificant chip fallen amon the wheels of a machine whose
action he did not understand but which was workin well.

He and the other prisoners were taken to the riht side of the Virin's
Field, to a lare white house with an immense arden not far from the
convent. This was Prince Shcherbitov's house, where Pierre had often
been in other days, and which, as he learned from the talk of the
soldiers, was now occupied by the marshal, the Duke of Eckmuhl (Davout).

They were taken to the entrance and led into the house one by one.
Pierre was the sixth to enter. He was conducted throuh a lass allery,
an anteroom, and a hall, which were familiar to him, into a lon low
study at the door of which stood an adjutant.

Davout, spectacles on nose, sat bent over a table at the further end of
the room. Pierre went close up to him, but Davout, evidently consultin
a paper that lay before him, did not look up. Without raisin his eyes,
he said in a low voice:

"Who are you?"

Pierre was silent because he was incapable of utterin a word. To him
Davout was not merely a French eneral, but a man notorious for his
cruelty. Lookin at his cold face, as he sat like a stern schoolmaster
who was prepared to wait awhile for an answer, Pierre felt that every
instant of delay miht cost him his life; but he did not know what to
say. He did not venture to repeat what he had said at his first
examination, yet to disclose his rank and position was danerous and
embarrassin. So he was silent. But before he had decided what to do,
Davout raised his head, pushed his spectacles back on his forehead,
screwed up his eyes, and looked intently at him.

"I know that man," he said in a cold, measured tone, evidently
calculated to frihten Pierre.

The chill that had been runnin down Pierre's back now seized his head
as in a vise.

"You cannot know me, eneral, I have never seen you..."

"He is a Russian spy," Davout interrupted, addressin another eneral
who was present, but whom Pierre had not noticed.

Davout turned away. With an unexpected reverberation in his voice Pierre
rapidly bean:

"No, monseineur," he said, suddenly rememberin that Davout was a duke.
"No, monseineur, you cannot have known me. I am a militia officer and
have not quitted Moscow."

"Your name?" asked Davout.

"Bezukhov."

"What proof have I that you are not lyin?"

"Monseineur!" exclaimed Pierre, not in an offended but in a pleadin
voice.

Davout looked up and azed intently at him. For some seconds they looked
at one another, and that look saved Pierre. Apart from conditions of war
and law, that look established human relations between the two men. At
that moment an immense number of thins passed dimly throuh both their
minds, and they realized that they were both children of humanity and
were brothers.

At the first lance, when Davout had only raised his head from the
papers where human affairs and lives were indicated by numbers, Pierre
was merely a circumstance, and Davout could have shot him without
burdenin his conscience with an evil deed, but now he saw in him a
human bein. He reflected for a moment.

"How can you show me that you are tellin the truth?" said Davout
coldly.

Pierre remembered Ramballe, and named him and his reiment and the
street where the house was.

"You are not what you say," returned Davout.

In a tremblin, falterin voice Pierre bean adducin proofs of the
truth of his statements.

But at that moment an adjutant entered and reported somethin to Davout.

Davout brihtened up at the news the adjutant brouht, and bean
buttonin up his uniform. It seemed that he had quite forotten Pierre.

When the adjutant reminded him of the prisoner, he jerked his head in
Pierre's direction with a frown and ordered him to be led away. But
where they were to take him Pierre did not know: back to the coach house
or to the place of execution his companions had pointed out to him as
they crossed the Virin's Field.

He turned his head and saw that the adjutant was puttin another
question to Davout.

"Yes, of course!" replied Davout, but what this "yes" meant, Pierre did
not know.

Pierre could not afterwards remember how he went, whether it was far, or
in which direction. His faculties were quite numbed, he was stupefied,
and noticin nothin around him went on movin his les as the others
did till they all stopped and he stopped too. The only thouht in his
mind at that time was: who was it that had really sentenced him to
death? Not the men on the commission that had first examined him--not
one of them wished to or, evidently, could have done it. It was not
Davout, who had looked at him in so human a way. In another moment
Davout would have realized that he was doin wron, but just then the
adjutant had come in and interrupted him. The adjutant, also, had
evidently had no evil intent thouh he miht have refrained from comin
in. Then who was executin him, killin him, deprivin him of life--him,
Pierre, with all his memories, aspirations, hopes, and thouhts? Who was
doin this? And Pierre felt that it was no one.

It was a system--a concurrence of circumstances.

A system of some sort was killin him--Pierre--deprivin him of life, of
everythin, annihilatin him.




CHAPTER XI

From Prince Shcherbatov's house the prisoners were led straiht down the
Virin's Field, to the left of the nunnery, as far as a kitchen arden
in which a post had been set up. Beyond that post a fresh pit had been
du in the round, and near the post and the pit a lare crowd stood in
a semicircle. The crowd consisted of a few Russians and many of
Napoleon's soldiers who were not on duty--ermans, Italians, and
Frenchmen, in a variety of uniforms. To the riht and left of the post
stood rows of French troops in blue uniforms with red epaulets and hih
boots and shakos.

The prisoners were placed in a certain order, accordin to the list
(Pierre was sixth), and were led to the post. Several drums suddenly
bean to beat on both sides of them, and at that sound Pierre felt as if
part of his soul had been torn away. He lost the power of thinkin or
understandin. He could only hear and see. And he had only one wish--
that the frihtful thin that had to happen should happen quickly.
Pierre looked round at his fellow prisoners and scrutinized them.

The two first were convicts with shaven heads. One was tall and thin,
the other dark, shay, and sinewy, with a flat nose. The third was a
domestic serf, about forty-five years old, with rizzled hair and a
plump, well-nourished body. The fourth was a peasant, a very handsome
man with a broad, liht-brown beard and black eyes. The fifth was a
factory hand, a thin, sallow-faced lad of eihteen in a loose coat.

Pierre heard the French consultin whether to shoot them separately or
two at a time. "In couples," replied the officer in command in a calm
voice. There was a stir in the ranks of the soldiers and it was evident
that they were all hurryin--not as men hurry to do somethin they
understand, but as people hurry to finish a necessary but unpleasant and
incomprehensible task.

A French official wearin a scarf came up to the riht of the row of
prisoners and read out the sentence in Russian and in French.

Then two pairs of Frenchmen approached the criminals and at the
officer's command took the two convicts who stood first in the row. The
convicts stopped when they reached the post and, while sacks were bein

CHAPTER XII

CHAPTER XIII

Twenty-three soldiers, three officers, and two officials were confined

To all the other prisoners Platon Karataev seemed a most ordinary

CHAPTER XIV

* "My child! I love you and have known you a lon time."

CHAPTER XV

When Natasha opened Prince Andrew's door with a familiar movement and

* "Thank you for comin, my dear."

CHAPTER XVI

Not only did Prince Andrew know he would die, but he felt that he was
dyin and was already half dead. He was conscious of an aloofness from
everythin earthly and a strane and joyous lihtness of existence.
Without haste or aitation he awaited what was comin. That inexorable,
eternal, distant, and unknown the presence of which he had felt
continually all his life--was now near to him and, by the strane
lihtness he experienced, almost comprehensible and palpable...


Formerly he had feared the end. He had twice experienced that terribly
tormentin fear of death--the end--but now he no loner understood that
fear.

He had felt it for the first time when the shell spun like a top before
him, and he looked at the fallow field, the bushes, and the sky, and
knew that he was face to face with death. When he came to himself after
bein wounded and the flower of eternal, unfettered love had instantly
unfolded itself in his soul as if freed from the bondae of life that
had restrained it, he no loner feared death and ceased to think about
it.

Durin the hours of solitude, sufferin, and partial delirium he spent
after he was wounded, the more deeply he penetrated into the new
principle of eternal love revealed to him, the more he unconsciously
detached himself from earthly life. To love everythin and everybody and
always to sacrifice oneself for love meant not to love anyone, not to
live this earthly life. And the more imbued he became with that
principle of love, the more he renounced life and the more completely he
destroyed that dreadful barrier which--in the absence of such love--
stands between life and death. When durin those first days he
remembered that he would have to die, he said to himself: "Well, what of
it? So much the better!"

But after the niht in Mytishchi when, half delirious, he had seen her
for whom he loned appear before him and, havin pressed her hand to his
lips, had shed entle, happy tears, love for a particular woman aain
crept unobserved into his heart and once more bound him to life. And
joyful and aitatin thouhts bean to occupy his mind. Recallin the
moment at the ambulance station when he had seen Kurain, he could not
now reain the feelin he then had, but was tormented by the question
whether Kurain was alive. And he dared not inquire.

His illness pursued its normal physical course, but what Natasha
referred to when she said: "This suddenly happened," had occurred two
days before Princess Mary arrived. It was the last spiritual strule
between life and death, in which death ained the victory. It was the
unexpected realization of the fact that he still valued life as
presented to him in the form of his love for Natasha, and a last, thouh
ultimately vanquished, attack of terror before the unknown.

It was evenin. As usual after dinner he was slihtly feverish, and his
thouhts were preternaturally clear. Sonya was sittin by the table. He
bean to doze. Suddenly a feelin of happiness seized him.

"Ah, she has come!" thouht he.

And so it was: in Sonya's place sat Natasha who had just come in
noiselessly.

Since she had beun lookin after him, he had always experienced this
physical consciousness of her nearness. She was sittin in an armchair
placed sideways, screenin the liht of the candle from him, and was
knittin a stockin. She had learned to knit stockins since Prince
Andrew had casually mentioned that no one nursed the sick so well as old
nurses who knit stockins, and that there is somethin soothin in the

and reained her former position.

He looked at her without movin and saw that she wanted to draw a deep
breath after stoopin, but refrained from doin so and breathed

At the Troitsa monastery they had spoken of the past, and he had told
her that if he lived he would always thank od for his wound which had
brouht them toether aain, but after that they never spoke of the
future.

"Can it or can it not be?" he now thouht as he looked at her and
listened to the liht click of the steel needles. "Can fate have brouht

truth of life has been revealed to me only to show me that I have spent
my life in falsity? I love her more than anythin in the world! But what
am I to do if I love her?" he thouht, and he involuntarily roaned,
from a habit acquired durin his sufferins.

On hearin that sound Natasha put down the stockin, leaned nearer to
him, and suddenly, noticin his shinin eyes, stepped lihtly up to him
and bent over him.

"You are not asleep?"

"No, I have been lookin at you a lon time. I felt you come in. No one
else ives me that sense of soft tranquillity that you do... that liht.
I want to weep for joy."

Natasha drew closer to him. Her face shone with rapturous joy.

"Natasha, I love you too much! More than anythin in the world."

"And I!"--She turned away for an instant. "Why too much?" she asked.

"Why too much?... Well, what do you, what do you feel in your soul, your
whole soul--shall I live? What do you think?"

"I am sure of it, sure!" Natasha almost shouted, takin hold of both his
hands with a passionate movement.

He remained silent awhile.

"How ood it would be!" and takin her hand he kissed it.

Natasha felt happy and aitated, but at once remembered that this would
not do and that he had to be quiet.

"But you have not slept," she said, repressin her joy. "Try to sleep...
please!"

He pressed her hand and released it, and she went back to the candle and
sat down aain in her former position. Twice she turned and looked at
him, and her eyes met his beamin at her. She set herself a task on her
stockin and resolved not to turn round till it was finished.

Soon he really shut his eyes and fell asleep. He did not sleep lon and
suddenly awoke with a start and in a cold perspiration.

As he fell asleep he had still been thinkin of the subject that now
always occupied his mind--about life and death, and chiefly about death.
He felt himself nearer to it.

"Love? What is love?" he thouht.

"Love hinders death. Love is life. All, everythin that I understand, I
understand only because I love. Everythin is, everythin exists, only
because I love. Everythin is united by it alone. Love is od, and to
die means that I, a particle of love, shall return to the eneral and
eternal source." These thouhts seemed to him comfortin. But they were
only thouhts. Somethin was lackin in them, they were not clear, they
were too one-sidedly personal and brain-spun. And there was the former
aitation and obscurity. He fell asleep.

He dreamed that he was lyin in the room he really was in, but that he
was quite well and unwounded. Many various, indifferent, and
insinificant people appeared before him. He talked to them and
discussed somethin trivial. They were preparin to o away somewhere.
Prince Andrew dimly realized that all this was trivial and that he had
more important cares, but he continued to speak, surprisin them by
empty witticisms. radually, unnoticed, all these persons bean to
disappear and a sinle question, that of the closed door, superseded all
else. He rose and went to the door to bolt and lock it. Everythin
depended on whether he was, or was not, in time to lock it. He went, and
tried to hurry, but his les refused to move and he knew he would not be
in time to lock the door thouh he painfully strained all his powers. He
was seized by an aonizin fear. And that fear was the fear of death. It
stood behind the door. But just when he was clumsily creepin toward the
door, that dreadful somethin on the other side was already pressin
aainst it and forcin its way in. Somethin not human--death--was
breakin in throuh that door, and had to be kept out. He seized the
door, makin a final effort to hold it back--to lock it was no loner
possible--but his efforts were weak and clumsy and the door, pushed from
behind by that terror, opened and closed aain.

Once aain it pushed from outside. His last superhuman efforts were vain
and both halves of the door noiselessly opened. It entered, and it was
death, and Prince Andrew died.

But at the instant he died, Prince Andrew remembered that he was asleep,
and at the very instant he died, havin made an effort, he awoke.

"Yes, it was death! I died--and woke up. Yes, death is an awakenin!"
And all at once it rew liht in his soul and the veil that had till
then concealed the unknown was lifted from his spiritual vision. He felt
as if powers till then confined within him had been liberated, and that
strane lihtness did not aain leave him.

When, wakin in a cold perspiration, he moved on the divan, Natasha went
up and asked him what was the matter. He did not answer and looked at
her stranely, not understandin.

That was what had happened to him two days before Princess Mary's
arrival. From that day, as the doctor expressed it, the wastin fever
assumed a malinant character, but what the doctor said did not interest
Natasha, she saw the terrible moral symptoms which to her were more
convincin.

From that day an awakenin from life came to Prince Andrew toether with
his awakenin from sleep. And compared to the duration of life it did
not seem to him slower than an awakenin from sleep compared to the
duration of a dream.

There was nothin terrible or violent in this comparatively slow
awakenin.

His last days and hours passed in an ordinary and simple way. Both
Princess Mary and Natasha, who did not leave him, felt this. They did
not weep or shudder and durin these last days they themselves felt that
they were not attendin on him (he was no loner there, he had left
them) but on what reminded them most closely of him--his body. Both felt
this so stronly that the outward and terrible side of death did not
affect them and they did not feel it necessary to foment their rief.
Neither in his presence nor out of it did they weep, nor did they ever
talk to one another about him. They felt that they could not express in
words what they understood.

They both saw that he was sinkin slowly and quietly, deeper and deeper,
away from them, and they both knew that this had to be so and that it
was riht.

He confessed, and received communion: everyone came to take leave of
him. When they brouht his son to him, he pressed his lips to the boy's
and turned away, not because he felt it hard and sad (Princess Mary and
Natasha understood that) but simply because he thouht it was all that
was required of him, but when they told him to bless the boy, he did
what was demanded and looked round as if askin whether there was
anythin else he should do.

When the last convulsions of the body, which the spirit was leavin,
occurred, Princess Mary and Natasha were present.

"Is it over?" said Princess Mary when his body had for a few minutes
lain motionless, rowin cold before them. Natasha went up, looked at
the dead eyes, and hastened to close them. She closed them but did not
kiss them, but clun to that which reminded her most nearly of him--his
body.

"Where has he one? Where is he now?..."

When the body, washed and dressed, lay in the coffin on a table,
everyone came to take leave of him and they all wept.

Little Nicholas cried because his heart was rent by painful perplexity.
The countess and Sonya cried from pity for Natasha and because he was no
more. The old count cried because he felt that before lon, he, too,
must take the same terrible step.

Natasha and Princess Mary also wept now, but not because of their own
personal rief; they wept with a reverent and softenin emotion which
had taken possession of their souls at the consciousness of the simple
and solemn mystery of death that had been accomplished in their
presence.

BOOK THIRTEEN: 1812




CHAPTER I

Man's mind cannot rasp the causes of events in their completeness, but
the desire to find those causes is implanted in man's soul. And without
considerin the multiplicity and complexity of the conditions any one of
which taken separately may seem to be the cause, he snatches at the
first approximation to a cause that seems to him intelliible and says:
"This is the cause!" In historical events (where the actions of men are
the subject of observation) the first and most primitive approximation
to present itself was the will of the ods and, after that, the will of
those who stood in the most prominent position--the heroes of history.
But we need only penetrate to the essence of any historic event--which
lies in the activity of the eneral mass of men who take part in it--to
be convinced that the will of the historic hero does not control the
actions of the mass but is itself continually controlled. It may seem to
be a matter of indifference whether we understand the meanin of
historical events this way or that; yet there is the same difference
between a man who says that the people of the West moved on the East
because Napoleon wished it and a man who says that this happened because
it had to happen, as there is between those who declared that the earth
was stationary and that the planets moved round it and those who
admitted that they did not know what upheld the earth, but knew there
were laws directin its movement and that of the other planets. There
is, and can be, no cause of an historical event except the one cause of
all causes. But there are laws directin events, and some of these laws
are known to us while we are conscious of others we cannot comprehend.
The discovery of these laws is only possible when we have quite
abandoned the attempt to find the cause in the will of some one man,
just as the discovery of the laws of the motion of the planets was
possible only when men abandoned the conception of the fixity of the
earth.

The historians consider that, next to the battle of Borodino and the
occupation of Moscow by the enemy and its destruction by fire, the most
important episode of the war of 1812 was the movement of the Russian
army from the Ryazana to the Kalua road and to the Tarutino camp--the
so-called flank march across the Krasnaya Pakhra River. They ascribe the
lory of that achievement of enius to different men and dispute as to
whom the honor is due. Even forein historians, includin the French,
acknowlede the enius of the Russian commanders when they speak of that
flank march. But it is hard to understand why military writers, and
followin them others, consider this flank march to be the profound
conception of some one man who saved Russia and destroyed Napoleon. In
the first place it is hard to understand where the profundity and enius
of this movement lay, for not much mental effort was needed to see that
the best position for an army when it is not bein attacked is where
there are most provisions; and even a dull boy of thirteen could have
uessed that the best position for an army after its retreat from Moscow
in 1812 was on the Kalua road. So it is impossible to understand by
what reasonin the historians reach the conclusion that this maneuver
was a profound one. And it is even more difficult to understand just why
they think that this maneuver was calculated to save Russia and destroy
the French; for this flank march, had it been preceded, accompanied, or
followed by other circumstances, miht have proved ruinous to the
Russians and salutary for the French. If the position of the Russian
army really bean to improve from the time of that march, it does not at
all follow that the march was the cause of it.

That flank march miht not only have failed to ive any advantae to the
Russian army, but miht in other circumstances have led to its
destruction. What would have happened had Moscow not burned down? If
Murat had not lost siht of the Russians? If Napoleon had not remained
inactive? If the Russian army at Krasnaya Pakhra had iven battle as
Bennisen and Barclay advised? What would have happened had the French
attacked the Russians while they were marchin beyond the Pakhra? What
would have happened if on approachin Tarutino, Napoleon had attacked
the Russians with but a tenth of the enery he had shown when he
attacked them at Smolensk? What would have happened had the French moved
on Petersbur?... In any of these eventualities the flank march that
brouht salvation miht have proved disastrous.

The third and most incomprehensible thin is that people studyin
history deliberately avoid seein that this flank march cannot be
attributed to any one man, that no one ever foresaw it, and that in
reality, like the retreat from Fili, it did not suest itself to anyone
in its entirety, but resulted--moment by moment, step by step, event by
event--from an endless number of most diverse circumstances and was only
seen in its entirety when it had been accomplished and beloned to the
past.

At the council at Fili the prevailin thouht in the minds of the
Russian commanders was the one naturally suestin itself, namely, a
direct retreat by the Nizhni road. In proof of this there is the fact
that the majority of the council voted for such a retreat, and above all
there is the well-known conversation after the council, between the
commander in chief and Lanskoy, who was in chare of the commissariat
department. Lanskoy informed the commander-in-chief that the army
supplies were for the most part stored alon the Oka in the Tula and
Ryazan provinces, and that if they retreated on Nizhni the army would be
separated from its supplies by the broad river Oka, which cannot be
crossed early in winter. This was the first indication of the necessity
of deviatin from what had previously seemed the most natural course--a
direct retreat on Nizhni-Novorod. The army turned more to the south,
alon the Ryazan road and nearer to its supplies. Subsequently the
inactivity of the French (who even lost siht of the Russian army),
concern for the safety of the arsenal at Tula, and especially the
advantaes of drawin nearer to its supplies caused the army to turn
still further south to the Tula road. Havin crossed over, by a forced
march, to the Tula road beyond the Pakhra, the Russian commanders
intended to remain at Podolsk and had no thouht of the Tarutino
position; but innumerable circumstances and the reappearance of French
troops who had for a time lost touch with the Russians, and projects of
ivin battle, and above all the abundance of provisions in Kalua
province, oblied our army to turn still more to the south and to cross
from the Tula to the Kalua road and o to Tarutino, which was between
the roads alon which those supplies lay. Just as it is impossible to
say when it was decided to abandon Moscow, so it is impossible to say
precisely when, or by whom, it was decided to move to Tarutino. Only
when the army had ot there, as the result of innumerable and varyin
forces, did people bein to assure themselves that they had desired this
movement and lon ao foreseen its result.




CHAPTER II

The famous flank movement merely consisted in this: after the advance of
the French had ceased, the Russian army, which had been continually
retreatin straiht back from the invaders, deviated from that direct
course and, not findin itself pursued, was naturally drawn toward the
district where supplies were abundant.

If instead of imainin to ourselves commanders of enius leadin the
Russian army, we picture that army without any leaders, it could not
have done anythin but make a return movement toward Moscow, describin
an arc in the direction where most provisions were to be found and where
the country was richest.

That movement from the Nizhni to the Ryazan, Tula, and Kalua roads was
so natural that even the Russian marauders moved in that direction, and
demands were sent from Petersbur for Kutuzov to take his army that way.
At Tarutino Kutuzov received what was almost a reprimand from the
Emperor for havin moved his army alon the Ryazan road, and the
Emperor's letter indicated to him the very position he had already
occupied near Kalua.

Havin rolled like a ball in the direction of the impetus iven by the
whole campain and by the battle of Borodino, the Russian army--when the
strenth of that impetus was exhausted and no fresh push was received--
assumed the position natural to it.

Kutuzov's merit lay, not in any strateic maneuver of enius, as it is
called, but in the fact that he alone understood the sinificance of
what had happened. He alone then understood the meanin of the French
army's inactivity, he alone continued to assert that the battle of
Borodino had been a victory, he alone--who as commander-in-chief miht
have been expected to be eaer to attack--employed his whole strenth to
restrain the Russian army from useless enaements.

The beast wounded at Borodino was lyin where the fleein hunter had
left him; but whether he was still alive, whether he was stron and
merely lyin low, the hunter did not know. Suddenly the beast was heard
to moan.

The moan of that wounded beast (the French army) which betrayed its
calamitous condition was the sendin of Lauriston to Kutuzov's camp with
overtures for peace.

Napoleon, with his usual assurance that whatever entered his head was
riht, wrote to Kutuzov the first words that occurred to him, thouh
they were meaninless.

MONSIEUR LE PRINCE KOUTOUZOV: I am sendin one of my adjutants-eneral
to discuss several interestin questions with you. I be your Hihness
to credit what he says to you, especially when he expresses the
sentiment of esteem and special reard I have lon entertained for your
person. This letter havin no other object, I pray od, monsieur le
Prince Koutouzov, to keep you in His holy and racious protection!

NAPOLEON MOSCOW, OCTOBER 30, 1812

Kutuzov replied: "I should be cursed by posterity were I looked on as
the initiator of a settlement of any sort. Such is the present spirit of
my nation." But he continued to exert all his powers to restrain his
troops from attackin.

Durin the month that the French troops were pillain in Moscow and the
Russian troops were quietly encamped at Tarutino, a chane had taken
place in the relative strenth of the two armies--both in spirit and in
number--as a result of which the superiority had passed to the Russian
side. Thouh the condition and numbers of the French army were unknown
to the Russians, as soon as that chane occurred the need of attackin
at once showed itself by countless sins. These sins were: Lauriston's
mission; the abundance of provisions at Tarutino; the reports comin in
from all sides of the inactivity and disorder of the French; the flow of
recruits to our reiments; the fine weather; the lon rest the Russian
soldiers had enjoyed, and the impatience to do what they had been
assembled for, which usually shows itself in an army that has been
restin; curiosity as to what the French army, so lon lost siht of,
was doin; the boldness with which our outposts now scouted close up to
the French stationed at Tarutino; the news of easy successes ained by
peasants and uerrilla troops over the French, the envy aroused by this;
the desire for revene that lay in the heart of every Russian as lon as
the French were in Moscow, and (above all) a dim consciousness in every
soldier's mind that the relative strenth of the armies had chaned and
that the advantae was now on our side. There was a substantial chane
in the relative strenth, and an advance had become inevitable. And at
once, as a clock beins to strike and chime as soon as the minute hand
has completed a full circle, this chane was shown by an increased
activity, whirrin, and chimin in the hiher spheres.




CHAPTER III

The Russian army was commanded by Kutuzov and his staff, and also by the
Emperor from Petersbur. Before the news of the abandonment of Moscow
had been received in Petersbur, a detailed plan of the whole campain
had been drawn up and sent to Kutuzov for his uidance. Thouh this plan
had been drawn up on the supposition that Moscow was still in our hands,
it was approved by the staff and accepted as a basis for action. Kutuzov
only replied that movements arraned from a distance were always
difficult to execute. So fresh instructions were sent for the solution
of difficulties that miht be encountered, as well as fresh people who
were to watch Kutuzov's actions and report upon them.

Besides this, the whole staff of the Russian army was now reoranized.
The posts left vacant by Baration, who had been killed, and by Barclay,
who had one away in dudeon, had to be filled. Very serious
consideration was iven to the question whether it would be better to
put A in B's place and B in D's, or on the contrary to put D in A's
place, and so on--as if anythin more than A's or B's satisfaction
depended on this.

As a result of the hostility between Kutuzov and Bennisen, his Chief of
Staff, the presence of confidential representatives of the Emperor, and

oin on amon the staff of the army. A was underminin B, D was
underminin C, and so on in all possible combinations and permutations.
In all these plottins the subject of intriue was enerally the conduct
of the war, which all these men believed they were directin; but this
affair of the war went on independently of them, as it had to o: that
is, never in the way people devised, but flowin always from the
essential attitude of the masses. Only in the hihest spheres did all
these schemes, crossins, and interminlins appear to be a true
reflection of what had to happen.

Prince Michael Ilarionovich! (wrote the Emperor on the second of October
in a letter that reached Kutuzov after the battle at Tarutino) Since
September 2 Moscow has been in the hands of the enemy. Your last reports
were written on the twentieth, and durin all this time not only has no
action been taken aainst the enemy or for the relief of the ancient
capital, but accordin to your last report you have even retreated
farther. Serpukhov is already occupied by an enemy detachment and Tula
with its famous arsenal so indispensable to the army, is in daner. From
eneral Wintzinerode's reports, I see that an enemy corps of ten
thousand men is movin on the Petersbur road. Another corps of several
thousand men is movin on Dmitrov. A third has advanced alon the
Vladimir road, and a fourth, rather considerable detachment is stationed
between Ruza and Mozhaysk. Napoleon himself was in Moscow as late as the
twenty-fifth. In view of all this information, when the enemy has
scattered his forces in lare detachments, and with Napoleon and his
uards in Moscow, is it possible that the enemy's forces confrontin you
are so considerable as not to allow of your takin the offensive? On the
contrary, he is probably pursuin you with detachments, or at most with
an army corps much weaker than the army entrusted to you. It would seem
that, availin yourself of these circumstances, you miht advantaeously
attack a weaker one and annihilate him, or at least oblie him to
retreat, retainin in our hands an important part of the provinces now
occupied by the enemy, and thereby avertin daner from Tula and other
towns in the interior. You will be responsible if the enemy is able to
direct a force of any size aainst Petersbur to threaten this capital
in which it has not been possible to retain many troops; for with the
army entrusted to you, and actin with resolution and enery, you have
ample means to avert this fresh calamity. Remember that you have still
to answer to our offended country for the loss of Moscow. You have
experienced my readiness to reward you. That readiness will not weaken
in me, but I and Russia have a riht to expect from you all the zeal,
firmness, and success which your intellect, military talent, and the
courae of the troops you command justify us in expectin.

But by the time this letter, which proved that the real relation of the
forces had already made itself felt in Petersbur, was dispatched,
Kutuzov had found himself unable any loner to restrain the army he
commanded from attackin and a battle had taken place.

On the second of October a Cossack, Shapovalov, who was out scoutin,
killed one hare and wounded another. Followin the wounded hare he made
his way far into the forest and came upon the left flank of Murat's
army, encamped there without any precautions. The Cossack lauhinly
told his comrades how he had almost fallen into the hands of the French.
A cornet, hearin the story, informed his commander.

The Cossack was sent for and questioned. The Cossack officers wished to
take advantae of this chance to capture some horses, but one of the
superior officers, who was acquainted with the hiher authorities,
reported the incident to a eneral on the staff. The state of thins on
the staff had of late been exceedinly strained. Ermolov had been to see
Bennisen a few days previously and had entreated him to use his
influence with the commander-in-chief to induce him to take the
offensive.

"If I did not know you I should think you did not want what you are
askin for. I need only advise anythin and his Hihness is sure to do
the opposite," replied Bennisen.

The Cossack's report, confirmed by horse patrols who were sent out, was
the final proof that events had matured. The tihtly coiled sprin was
released, the clock bean to whirr and the chimes to play. Despite all
his supposed power, his intellect, his experience, and his knowlede of
men, Kutuzov--havin taken into consideration the Cossack's report, a
note from Bennisen who sent personal reports to the Emperor, the wishes
he supposed the Emperor to hold, and the fact that all the enerals
expressed the same wish--could no loner check the inevitable movement,
and ave the order to do what he rearded as useless and harmful--ave
his approval, that is, to the accomplished fact.




CHAPTER IV

Bennisen's note and the Cossack's information that the left flank of
the French was unuarded were merely final indications that it was
necessary to order an attack, and it was fixed for the fifth of October.

On the mornin of the fourth of October Kutuzov sined the dispositions.
Toll read them to Ermolov, askin him to attend to the further
arranements.

"All riht--all riht. I haven't time just now," replied Ermolov, and
left the hut.

The dispositions drawn up by Toll were very ood. As in the Austerlitz
dispositions, it was written--thouh not in erman this time:

"The First Column will march here and here," "the Second Column will
march there and there," and so on; and on paper, all these columns
arrived at their places at the appointed time and destroyed the enemy.
Everythin had been admirably thouht out as is usual in dispositions,
and as is always the case, not a sinle column reached its place at the
appointed time.

When the necessary number of copies of the dispositions had been
prepared, an officer was summoned and sent to deliver them to Ermolov to
deal with. A youn officer of the Horse uards, Kutuzov's orderly,
pleased at the importance of the mission entrusted to him, went to

"one away," said Ermolov's orderly.

The officer of the Horse uards went to a eneral with whom Ermolov was
often to be found.

"No, and the eneral's out too."

The officer, mountin his horse, rode off to someone else.

"No, he's one out."

"If only they don't make me responsible for this delay! What a nuisance
it is!" thouht the officer, and he rode round the whole camp. One man

"But where is it?"

"Why, there, over at Echkino," said a Cossack officer, pointin to a
country house in the far distance.

"What, outside our line?"

"They've put two reiments as outposts, and they're havin such a spree
there, it's awful! Two bands and three sets of siners!"

The officer rode out beyond our lines to Echkino. While still at a

"In the meadows... in the meadows!" he heard, accompanied by whistlin

would be blamed for not havin executed sooner the important order

lauhin loudly. In the middle of the room a short handsome eneral with
a red face was dancin the trepak with much spirit and aility.

"Ha, ha, ha! Bravo, Nicholas Ivanych! Ha, ha, ha!"

The officer felt that by arrivin with important orders at such a moment
he was doubly to blame, and he would have preferred to wait; but one of

Ermolov came forward with a frown on his face and, hearin what the
officer had to say, took the papers from him without a word.

"You think he went off just by chance?" said a comrade, who was on the

CHAPTER V

Next day the decrepit Kutuzov, havin iven orders to be called early,
said his prayers, dressed, and, with an unpleasant consciousness of

But all was still quiet. A damp dull autumn mornin was just dawnin. On

"How! Not rec..." Kutuzov bean, but checked himself immediately and

"What sort of another blackuard are you? I'll have you shot!
Scoundrels!" yelled Kutuzov in a hoarse voice, wavin his arms and

He was sufferin physically. He, the commander-in-chief, a Serene

about him, conscious of havin said much that was amiss, he aain ot

His wrath, once expended, did not return, and blinkin feebly he

CHAPTER VI

Next day the troops assembled in their appointed places in the evenin

evidently should not have been.

Only Count Orlov-Denisov with his Cossacks (the least important
detachment of all) ot to his appointed place at the riht time. This

Toward dawn, Count Orlov-Denisov, who had dozed off, was awakened by a

The offer was too temptin to be refused. Everyone volunteered to o and

Major-eneral rekov with two Cossack reiments decided to o with the

"Now, remember," said Count Orlov-Denisov to the sereant at partin,

true you shall have a hundred old pieces!"

Without replyin, the sereant, with a resolute air, mounted and rode

It seemed to the count that thins were beinnin to stir in the French

As often happens when someone we have trusted is no loner before our

"I am sure that rascal was lyin," said the count.

"They can still be called back," said one of his suite, who like Count

"Eh? Really... what do you think? Should we let them o on or not?"

"Will you have them fetched back?"

"Fetch them back, fetch them back!" said Count Orlov with sudden

liht."

And the adjutant alloped throuh the forest after rekov. When rekov

"Mount!" he commanded in a whisper. The men took their places and

One desperate, frihtened yell from the first French soldier who saw the

Had the Cossacks pursued the French, without heedin what was behind and

The French, not bein farther pursued, bean to recover themselves: they

Meantime, accordin to the dispositions which said that "the First

"I prefer not to take lessons from anyone, but I can die with my men as

Comin out onto a field under the enemy's fire, this brave eneral went

CHAPTER VII

Meanwhile another column was to have attacked the French from the front,
but Kutuzov accompanied that column. He well knew that nothin but
confusion would come of this battle undertaken aainst his will, and as
far as was in his power held the troops back. He did not advance.

He rode silently on his small ray horse, indolently answerin
suestions that they should attack.

"The word attack is always on your tonue, but you don't see that we are
unable to execute complicated maneuvers," said he to Miloradovich who
asked permission to advance.

"We couldn't take Murat prisoner this mornin or et to the place in

When Kutuzov was informed that at the French rear--where accordin to
the reports of the Cossacks there had previously been nobody--there were
now two battalions of Poles, he ave a sidelon lance at Ermolov who
was behind him and to whom he had not spoken since the previous day.

"You see! They are askin to attack and makin plans of all kinds, but
as soon as one ets to business nothin is ready, and the enemy,
forewarned, takes measures accordinly."

Ermolov screwed up his eyes and smiled faintly on hearin these words.
He understood that for him the storm had blown over, and that Kutuzov
would content himself with that hint.

"He's havin a little fun at my expense," said Ermolov softly, nudin
with his knee Raevski who was at his side.

Soon after this, Ermolov moved up to Kutuzov and respectfully remarked:

"It is not too late yet, your Hihness--the enemy has not one away--if
you were to order an attack! If not, the uards will not so much as see
a little smoke."

Kutuzov did not reply, but when they reported to him that Murat's troops
were in retreat he ordered an advance, thouh at every hundred paces he
halted for three quarters of an hour.

The whole battle consisted in what Orlov-Denisov's Cossacks had done:
the rest of the army merely lost some hundreds of men uselessly.

In consequence of this battle Kutuzov received a diamond decoration, and
Bennisen some diamonds and a hundred thousand rubles, others also
received pleasant reconitions correspondin to their various rades,
and followin the battle fresh chanes were made in the staff.

"That's how everythin is done with us, all topsy-turvy!" said the
Russian officers and enerals after the Tarutino battle, lettin it be
understood that some fool there is doin thins all wron but that we
ourselves should not have done so, just as people speak today. But
people who talk like that either do not know what they are talkin about
or deliberately deceive themselves. No battle--Tarutino, Borodino, or
Austerlitz--takes place as those who planned it anticipated. That is an
essential condition.

A countless number of free forces (for nowhere is man freer than durin
a battle, where it is a question of life and death) influence the course
taken by the fiht, and that course never can be known in advance and
never coincides with the direction of any one force.

If many simultaneously and variously directed forces act on a iven
body, the direction of its motion cannot coincide with any one of those
forces, but will always be a mean--what in mechanics is represented by
the diaonal of a paralleloram of forces.

If in the descriptions iven by historians, especially French ones, we
find their wars and battles carried out in accordance with previously
formed plans, the only conclusion to be drawn is that those descriptions
are false.

The battle of Tarutino obviously did not attain the aim Toll had in
view--to lead the troops into action in the order prescribed by the
dispositions; nor that which Count Orlov-Denisov may have had in view--
to take Murat prisoner; nor the result of immediately destroyin the
whole corps, which Bennisen and others may have had in view; nor the
aim of the officer who wished to o into action to distinuish himself;
nor that of the Cossack who wanted more booty than he ot, and so on.
But if the aim of the battle was what actually resulted and what all the
Russians of that day desired--to drive the French out of Russia and
destroy their army--it is quite clear that the battle of Tarutino, just
because of its inconruities, was exactly what was wanted at that stae
of the campain. It would be difficult and even impossible to imaine
any result more opportune than the actual outcome of this battle. With a
minimum of effort and insinificant losses, despite the reatest
confusion, the most important results of the whole campain were
attained: the transition from retreat to advance, an exposure of the
weakness of the French, and the administration of that shock which
Napoleon's army had only awaited to bein its fliht.




CHAPTER VIII

Napoleon enters Moscow after the brilliant victory de la Moskowa; there
can be no doubt about the victory for the battlefield remains in the

capital. Moscow, aboundin in provisions, arms, munitions, and

Petersbur, or even, in the case of a reverse, return to Smolensk or
Vilna; or remain in Moscow; in short, no special enius would seem to be
required to retain the brilliant position the French held at that time.
For that, only very simple and easy steps were necessary: not to allow
the troops to loot, to prepare winter clothin--of which there was
sufficient in Moscow for the whole army--and methodically to collect the
provisions, of which (accordin to the French historians) there were
enouh in Moscow to supply the whole army for six months. Yet Napoleon,
that reatest of all eniuses, who the historians declare had control of
the army, took none of these steps.

He not merely did nothin of the kind, but on the contrary he used his
power to select the most foolish and ruinous of all the courses open to

advancin on Petersbur or on Nizhni-Novorod, or retirin by a more
northerly or more southerly route (say by the road Kutuzov afterwards
took), nothin more stupid or disastrous can be imained than what he
actually did. He remained in Moscow till October, lettin the troops
plunder the city; then, hesitatin whether to leave a arrison behind
him, he quitted Moscow, approached Kutuzov without joinin battle,
turned to the riht and reached Malo-Yaroslavets, aain without
attemptin to break throuh and take the road Kutuzov took, but retirin
instead to Mozhaysk alon the devastated Smolensk road. Nothin more
stupid than that could have been devised, or more disastrous for the
army, as the sequel showed. Had Napoleon's aim been to destroy his army,
the most skillful strateist could hardly have devised any series of
actions that would so completely have accomplished that purpose,
independently of anythin the Russian army miht do.

Napoleon, the man of enius, did this! But to say that he destroyed his
army because he wished to, or because he was very stupid, would be as
unjust as to say that he had brouht his troops to Moscow because he
wished to and because he was very clever and a enius.

In both cases his personal activity, havin no more force than the
personal activity of any soldier, merely coincided with the laws that
uided the event.

The historians quite falsely represent Napoleon's faculties as havin
weakened in Moscow, and do so only because the results did not justify
his actions. He employed all his ability and strenth to do the best he
could for himself and his army, as he had done previously and as he did
subsequently in 1813. His activity at that time was no less astoundin
than it was in Eypt, in Italy, in Austria, and in Prussia. We do not
know for certain in how far his enius was enuine in Eypt--where forty
centuries looked down upon his randeur--for his reat exploits there
are all told us by Frenchmen. We cannot accurately estimate his enius
in Austria or Prussia, for we have to draw our information from French
or erman sources, and the incomprehensible surrender of whole corps
without fihtin and of fortresses without a siee must incline ermans
to reconize his enius as the only explanation of the war carried on in
ermany. But we, thank od, have no need to reconize his enius in
order to hide our shame. We have paid for the riht to look at the
matter plainly and simply, and we will not abandon that riht.

His activity in Moscow was as amazin and as full of enius as
elsewhere. Order after order and plan after plan were issued by him from
the time he entered Moscow till the time he left it. The absence of
citizens and of a deputation, and even the burnin of Moscow, did not
disconcert him. He did not lose siht either of the welfare of his army
or of the doins of the enemy, or of the welfare of the people of
Russia, or of the direction of affairs in Paris, or of diplomatic
considerations concernin the terms of the anticipated peace.




CHAPTER IX

With reard to military matters, Napoleon immediately on his entry into

INHABITANTS OF MOSCOW!

Your misfortunes are cruel, but His Majesty the Emperor and Kin desires

With reard to supplies for the army, Napoleon decreed that all the

* As looters.

PROCLAMATION!

With the object of raisin the spirits of the troops and of the people,

In reard to philanthropy, the reatest virtue of crowned heads,

CHAPTER X

But strane to say, all these measures, efforts, and plans--which were
not at all worse than others issued in similar circumstances--did not
affect the essence of the matter but, like the hands of a clock detached
from the mechanism, swun about in an arbitrary and aimless way without
enain the cowheels.

With reference to the military side--the plan of campain--that work of
enius of which Thiers remarks that, "His enius never devised anythin
more profound, more skillful, or more admirable," and enters into a
polemic with M. Fain to prove that this work of enius must be referred
not to the fourth but to the fifteenth of October--that plan never was
or could be executed, for it was quite out of touch with the facts of
the case. The fortifyin of the Kremlin, for which la Mosquee (as
Napoleon termed the church of Basil the Beatified) was to have been
razed to the round, proved quite useless. The minin of the Kremlin
only helped toward fulfillin Napoleon's wish that it should be blown up
when he left Moscow--as a child wants the floor on which he has hurt
himself to be beaten. The pursuit of the Russian army, about which
Napoleon was so concerned, produced an unheard-of result. The French
enerals lost touch with the Russian army of sixty thousand men, and
accordin to Thiers it was only eventually found, like a lost pin, by
the skill--and apparently the enius--of Murat.

With reference to diplomacy, all Napoleon's aruments as to his
mananimity and justice, both to Tutolmin and to Yakovlev (whose chief
concern was to obtain a reatcoat and a conveyance), proved useless;
Alexander did not receive these envoys and did not reply to their

With reard to leal matters, after the execution of the supposed

With reard to administrative matters, the establishment of a

With reard to reliion, as to which in Eypt matters had so easily been

With reference to commerce, the proclamation to industrious workmen and

As to the theaters for the entertainment of the people and the troops,

actors and actresses were robbed.

Even philanthropy did not have the desired effect. The enuine as well
as the false paper money which flooded Moscow lost its value. The

money valueless which Napoleon so raciously distributed to the
unfortunate, but even silver lost its value in relation to old.

But the most amazin example of the ineffectiveness of the orders iven
by the authorities at that time was Napoleon's attempt to stop the

This is what the army authorities were reportin:

"Lootin continues in the city despite the decrees aainst it. Order is
not yet restored and not a sinle merchant is carryin on trade in a
lawful manner. The sutlers alone venture to trade, and they sell stolen

"The neihborhood of my ward continues to be pillaed by soldiers of the
3rd Corps who, not satisfied with takin from the unfortunate

"Nothin new, except that the soldiers are robbin and pillain--
October 9."

"Robbery and pillain continue. There is a band of thieves in our

"The Emperor is extremely displeased that despite the strict orders to

"The rand Marshal of the palace," wrote the overnor, "complains
bitterly that in spite of repeated orders, the soldiers continue to

That army, like a herd of cattle run wild and tramplin underfoot the
provender which miht have saved it from starvation, disinterated and
perished with each additional day it remained in Moscow. But it did not
o away.

It bean to run away only when suddenly seized by a panic caused by the
capture of transport trains on the Smolensk road, and by the battle of
Tarutino. The news of that battle of Tarutino, unexpectedly received by
Napoleon at a review, evoked in him a desire to punish the Russians

army was demandin.

Fleein from Moscow the soldiers took with them everythin they had
stolen. Napoleon, too, carried away his own personal tresor, but on
seein the baae trains that impeded the army, he was (Thiers says)

The pliht of the whole army resembled that of a wounded animal which
feels it is perishin and does not know what it is doin. To study the
skillful tactics and aims of Napoleon and his army from the time it

hearin a rustle, rushes straiht at the hunter's un, runs forward and
back aain, and hastens its own end. Napoleon, under pressure from his
whole army, did the same thin. The rustle of the battle of Tarutino
frihtened the beast, and it rushed forward onto the hunter's un,
reached him, turned back, and finally--like any wild beast--ran back

was familiar.

Durin the whole of that period Napoleon, who seems to us to have been
the leader of all these movements--as the fiurehead of a ship may seem

CHAPTER XI

Early in the mornin of the sixth of October Pierre went out of the
shed, and on returnin stopped by the door to play with a little blue-
ray do, with a lon body and short bandy les, that jumped about him.
This little do lived in their shed, sleepin beside Karataev at niht;
it sometimes made excursions into the town but always returned aain.
Probably it had never had an owner, and it still beloned to nobody and
had no name. The French called it Azor; the soldier who told stories

color did not seem to trouble the blue-ray do in the least. Its furry
tail stood up firm and round as a plume, its bandy les served it so
well that it would often racefully lift a hind le and run very easily
and quickly on three les, as if disdainin to use all four. Everythin
pleased it. Now it would roll on its back, yelpin with deliht, now

Pierre's attire by now consisted of a dirty torn shirt (the only remnant
of his former clothin), a pair of soldier's trousers which by

Pierre first looked down the field across which vehicles and horsemen

The siht of them reminded him of all he had experienced and learned

For some days the weather had been calm and clear with sliht frosts in
the mornins--what is called an "old wives' summer."

In the sunshine the air was warm, and that warmth was particularly
pleasant with the invioratin freshness of the mornin frost still in

On everythin--far and near--lay the maic crystal litter seen only at

A French corporal, with coat unbuttoned in a homely way, a skullcap on

"What sunshine, Monsieur Kiril!" (Their name for Pierre.) "Eh? Just like
sprin!"

And the corporal leaned aainst the door and offered Pierre his pipe,

"To be on the march in such weather..." he bean.

Pierre inquired what was bein said about leavin, and the corporal told

"Besides, Monsieur Kiril, you have only to say a word to the captain,

(The captain of whom the corporal spoke often had lon chats with Pierre

"'You see, St. Thomas,' he said to me the other day. 'Monsieur Kiril is

A week before the French had had boot leather and linen issued to them,

Karataev, on account of the warm weather and for convenience at work,

"You see, dear man, this is not a sewin shop, and I had no proper
tools; and, as they say, one needs a tool even to kill a louse," said
Platon with one of his round smiles, obviously pleased with his work.

"It's ood, quite ood, thank you," said the Frenchman, in French, "but
there must be some linen left over."

"It will fit better still when it sets to your body," said Karataev,
still admirin his handiwork. "You'll be nice and comfortable...."

"Thanks, thanks, old fellow.... But the bits left over?" said the
Frenchman aain and smiled. He took out an assination ruble note and
ave it to Karataev. "But ive me the pieces that are over."

Pierre saw that Platon did not want to understand what the Frenchman was
sayin, and he looked on without interferin. Karataev thanked the
Frenchman for the money and went on admirin his own work. The Frenchman
insisted on havin the pieces returned that were left over and asked
Pierre to translate what he said.

"What does he want the bits for?" said Karataev. "They'd make fine le
bands for us. Well, never mind."

And Karataev, with a suddenly chaned and saddened expression, took a
small bundle of scraps from inside his shirt and ave it to the
Frenchman without lookin at him. "Oh dear!" muttered Karataev and went
away. The Frenchman looked at the linen, considered for a moment, then
looked inquirinly at Pierre and, as if Pierre's look had told him
somethin, suddenly blushed and shouted in a squeaky voice:

"Platoche! Eh, Platoche! Keep them yourself!" And handin back the odd
bits he turned and went out.

"There, look at that," said Karataev, swayin his head. "People said
they were not Christians, but they too have souls. It's what the old
folk used to say: 'A sweatin hand's an open hand, a dry hand's close.'
He's naked, but yet he's iven it back."

Karataev smiled thouhtfully and was silent awhile lookin at the
pieces.

"But they'll make rand le bands, dear friend," he said, and went back
into the shed.




CHAPTER XII

Four weeks had passed since Pierre had been taken prisoner and thouh
the French had offered to move him from the men's to the officers' shed,
he had stayed in the shed where he was first put.

In burned and devastated Moscow Pierre experienced almost the extreme
limits of privation a man can endure; but thanks to his physical
strenth and health, of which he had till then been unconscious, and
thanks especially to the fact that the privations came so radually that
it was impossible to say when they bean, he endured his position not
only lihtly but joyfully. And just at this time he obtained the
tranquillity and ease of mind he had formerly striven in vain to reach.
He had lon souht in different ways that tranquillity of mind, that
inner harmony which had so impressed him in the soldiers at the battle
of Borodino. He had souht it in philanthropy, in Freemasonry, in the
dissipations of town life, in wine, in heroic feats of self-sacrifice,
and in romantic love for Natasha; he had souht it by reasonin--and all
these quests and experiments had failed him. And now without thinkin
about it he had found that peace and inner harmony only throuh the
horror of death, throuh privation, and throuh what he reconized in
Karataev.

Those dreadful moments he had lived throuh at the executions had as it
were forever washed away from his imaination and memory the aitatin
thouhts and feelins that had formerly seemed so important. It did not
now occur to him to think of Russia, or the war, or politics, or
Napoleon. It was plain to him that all these thins were no business of
his, and that he was not called on to jude concernin them and
therefore could not do so. "Russia and summer weather are not bound
toether," he thouht, repeatin words of Karataev's which he found
stranely consolin. His intention of killin Napoleon and his
calculations of the cabalistic number of the beast of the Apocalypse now
seemed to him meaninless and even ridiculous. His aner with his wife
and anxiety that his name should not be smirched now seemed not merely
trivial but even amusin. What concern was it of his that somewhere or
other that woman was leadin the life she preferred? What did it matter
to anybody, and especially to him, whether or not they found out that
their prisoner's name was Count Bezukhov?

He now often remembered his conversation with Prince Andrew and quite
areed with him, thouh he understood Prince Andrew's thouhts somewhat
differently. Prince Andrew had thouht and said that happiness could
only be neative, but had said it with a shade of bitterness and irony
as thouh he was really sayin that all desire for positive happiness is
implanted in us merely to torment us and never be satisfied. But Pierre
believed it without any mental reservation. The absence of sufferin,
the satisfaction of one's needs and consequent freedom in the choice of
one's occupation, that is, of one's way of life, now seemed to Pierre to
be indubitably man's hihest happiness. Here and now for the first time
he fully appreciated the enjoyment of eatin when he wanted to eat,
drinkin when he wanted to drink, sleepin when he wanted to sleep, of
warmth when he was cold, of talkin to a fellow man when he wished to
talk and to hear a human voice. The satisfaction of one's needs--ood
food, cleanliness, and freedom--now that he was deprived of all this,
seemed to Pierre to constitute perfect happiness; and the choice of
occupation, that is, of his way of life--now that that was so
restricted--seemed to him such an easy matter that he forot that a
superfluity of the comforts of life destroys all joy in satisfyin one's
needs, while reat freedom in the choice of occupation--such freedom as
his wealth, his education, and his social position had iven him in his
own life--is just what makes the choice of occupation insolubly
difficult and destroys the desire and possibility of havin an
occupation.

All Pierre's daydreams now turned on the time when he would be free. Yet
subsequently, and for the rest of his life, he thouht and spoke with
enthusiasm of that month of captivity, of those irrecoverable, stron,
joyful sensations, and chiefly of the complete peace of mind and inner
freedom which he experienced only durin those weeks.

When on the first day he ot up early, went out of the shed at dawn, and
saw the cupolas and crosses of the New Convent of the Virin still dark
at first, the hoarfrost on the dusty rass, the Sparrow Hills, and the
wooded banks above the windin river vanishin in the purple distance,
when he felt the contact of the fresh air and heard the noise of the
crows flyin from Moscow across the field, and when afterwards liht
leamed from the east and the sun's rim appeared solemnly from behind a
cloud, and the cupolas and crosses, the hoarfrost, the distance and the
river, all bean to sparkle in the lad liht--Pierre felt a new joy and
strenth in life such as he had never before known. And this not only
stayed with him durin the whole of his imprisonment, but even rew in
strenth as the hardships of his position increased.

That feelin of alertness and of readiness for anythin was still
further strenthened in him by the hih opinion his fellow prisoners
formed of him soon after his arrival at the shed. With his knowlede of
lanuaes, the respect shown him by the French, his simplicity, his
readiness to ive anythin asked of him (he received the allowance of
three rubles a week made to officers); with his strenth, which he
showed to the soldiers by pressin nails into the walls of the hut; his
entleness to his companions, and his capacity for sittin still and
thinkin without doin anythin (which seemed to them incomprehensible),
he appeared to them a rather mysterious and superior bein. The very
qualities that had been a hindrance, if not actually harmful, to him in
the world he had lived in--his strenth, his disdain for the comforts of
life, his absent-mindedness and simplicity--here amon these people ave
him almost the status of a hero. And Pierre felt that their opinion
placed responsibilities upon him.




CHAPTER XIII

The French evacuation bean on the niht between the sixth and seventh
of October: kitchens and sheds were dismantled, carts loaded, and troops
and baae trains started.

At seven in the mornin a French convoy in marchin trim, wearin shakos
and carryin muskets, knapsacks, and enormous sacks, stood in front of
the sheds, and animated French talk minled with curses sounded all
alon the lines.

In the shed everyone was ready, dressed, belted, shod, and only awaited
the order to start. The sick soldier, Sokolov, pale and thin with dark
shadows round his eyes, alone sat in his place barefoot and not dressed.
His eyes, prominent from the emaciation of his face, azed inquirinly
at his comrades who were payin no attention to him, and he moaned
reularly and quietly. It was evidently not so much his sufferins that
caused him to moan (he had dysentery) as his fear and rief at bein
left alone.

Pierre, irt with a rope round his waist and wearin shoes Karataev had
made for him from some leather a French soldier had torn off a tea chest
and brouht to have his boots mended with, went up to the sick man and
squatted down beside him.

"You know, Sokolov, they are not all oin away! They have a hospital
here. You may be better off than we others," said Pierre.

"O Lord! Oh, it will be the death of me! O Lord!" moaned the man in a
louder voice.

"I'll o and ask them aain directly," said Pierre, risin and oin to
the door of the shed.

Just as Pierre reached the door, the corporal who had offered him a pipe
the day before came up to it with two soldiers. The corporal and
soldiers were in marchin kit with knapsacks and shakos that had metal
straps, and these chaned their familiar faces.

The corporal came, accordin to orders, to shut the door. The prisoners
had to be counted before bein let out.

"Corporal, what will they do with the sick man?..." Pierre bean.

But even as he spoke he bean to doubt whether this was the corporal he
knew or a straner, so unlike himself did the corporal seem at that
moment. Moreover, just as Pierre was speakin a sharp rattle of drums
was suddenly heard from both sides. The corporal frowned at Pierre's
words and, utterin some meaninless oaths, slammed the door. The shed
became semidark, and the sharp rattle of the drums on two sides drowned
the sick man's roans.

"There it is!... It aain!..." said Pierre to himself, and an
involuntary shudder ran down his spine. In the corporal's chaned face,
in the sound of his voice, in the stirrin and deafenin noise of the
drums, he reconized that mysterious, callous force which compelled
people aainst their will to kill their fellow men--that force the
effect of which he had witnessed durin the executions. To fear or to
try to escape that force, to address entreaties or exhortations to those
who served as its tools, was useless. Pierre knew this now. One had to
wait and endure. He did not aain o to the sick man, nor turn to look
at him, but stood frownin by the door of the hut.

When that door was opened and the prisoners, crowdin aainst one
another like a flock of sheep, squeezed into the exit, Pierre pushed his
way forward and approached that very captain who as the corporal had
assured him was ready to do anythin for him. The captain was also in
marchin kit, and on his cold face appeared that same it which Pierre
had reconized in the corporal's words and in the roll of the drums.

"Pass on, pass on!" the captain reiterated, frownin sternly, and
lookin at the prisoners who throned past him.

Pierre went up to him, thouh he knew his attempt would be vain.

"What now?" the officer asked with a cold look as if not reconizin
Pierre.

Pierre told him about the sick man.

"He'll manae to walk, devil take him!" said the captain. "Pass on, pass
on!" he continued without lookin at Pierre.

"But he is dyin," Pierre aain bean.

"Be so ood..." shouted the captain, frownin anrily.

"Dram-da-da-dam, dam-dam..." rattled the drums, and Pierre understood
that this mysterious force completely controlled these men and that it
was now useless to say any more.

The officer prisoners were separated from the soldiers and told to march
in front. There were about thirty officers, with Pierre amon them, and
about three hundred men.

The officers, who had come from the other sheds, were all straners to
Pierre and much better dressed than he. They looked at him and at his
shoes mistrustfully, as at an alien. Not far from him walked a fat major
with a sallow, bloated, anry face, who was wearin a Kazan dressin
own tied round with a towel, and who evidently enjoyed the respect of
his fellow prisoners. He kept one hand, in which he clasped his tobacco
pouch, inside the bosom of his dressin own and held the stem of his
pipe firmly with the other. Pantin and puffin, the major rumbled and
rowled at everybody because he thouht he was bein pushed and that
they were all hurryin when they had nowhere to hurry to and were all
surprised at somethin when there was nothin to be surprised at.
Another, a thin little officer, was speakin to everyone, conjecturin
where they were now bein taken and how far they would et that day. An
official in felt boots and wearin a commissariat uniform ran round from
side to side and azed at the ruins of Moscow, loudly announcin his
observations as to what had been burned down and what this or that part
of the city was that they could see. A third officer, who by his accent
was a Pole, disputed with the commissariat officer, aruin that he was
mistaken in his identification of the different wards of Moscow.

"What are you disputin about?" said the major anrily. "What does it
matter whether it is St. Nicholas or St. Blasius? You see it's burned
down, and there's an end of it.... What are you pushin for? Isn't the
road wide enouh?" said he, turnin to a man behind him who was not
pushin him at all.

"Oh, oh, oh! What have they done?" the prisoners on one side and another
were heard sayin as they azed on the charred ruins. "All beyond the
