river, and Zubova, and in the Kremlin.... Just look! There's not half of
it left. Yes, I told you--the whole quarter beyond the river, and so it
is."

"Well, you know it's burned, so what's the use of talkin?" said the
major.

As they passed near a church in the Khamovniki (one of the few unburned
quarters of Moscow) the whole mass of prisoners suddenly started to one
side and exclamations of horror and disust were heard.

"Ah, the villains! What heathens! Yes; dead, dead, so he is... And
smeared with somethin!"

Pierre too drew near the church where the thin was that evoked these
exclamations, and dimly made out somethin leanin aainst the palins
surroundin the church. From the words of his comrades who saw better
than he did, he found that this was the body of a man, set upriht
aainst the palins with its face smeared with soot.

"o on! What the devil... o on! Thirty thousand devils!..." the convoy
uards bean cursin and the French soldiers, with fresh virulence,
drove away with their swords the crowd of prisoners who were azin at
the dead man.




CHAPTER XIV

Throuh the cross streets of the Khamovniki quarter the prisoners
marched, followed only by their escort and the vehicles and waons
belonin to that escort, but when they reached the supply stores they
came amon a hue and closely packed train of artillery minled with
private vehicles.

At the bride they all halted, waitin for those in front to et across.
From the bride they had a view of endless lines of movin baae
trains before and behind them. To the riht, where the Kalua road turns
near Neskuchny, endless rows of troops and carts stretched away into the
distance. These were troops of Beauharnais' corps which had started
before any of the others. Behind, alon the riverside and across the
Stone Bride, were Ney's troops and transport.

Davout's troops, in whose chare were the prisoners, were crossin the
Crimean bride and some were already debouchin into the Kalua road.
But the baae trains stretched out so that the last of Beauharnais'
train had not yet ot out of Moscow and reached the Kalua road when the
vanuard of Ney's army was already emerin from the reat Ordynka
Street.

When they had crossed the Crimean bride the prisoners moved a few steps
forward, halted, and aain moved on, and from all sides vehicles and men
crowded closer and closer toether. They advanced the few hundred paces
that separated the bride from the Kalua road, takin more than an hour
to do so, and came out upon the square where the streets of the
Transmoskva ward and the Kalua road convere, and the prisoners jammed
close toether had to stand for some hours at that crossway. From all
sides, like the roar of the sea, were heard the rattle of wheels, the
tramp of feet, and incessant shouts of aner and abuse. Pierre stood
pressed aainst the wall of a charred house, listenin to that noise
which minled in his imaination with the roll of the drums.

To et a better view, several officer prisoners climbed onto the wall of
the half-burned house aainst which Pierre was leanin.

"What crowds! Just look at the crowds!... They've loaded oods even on
the cannon! Look there, those are furs!" they exclaimed. "Just see what
the blackuards have looted.... There! See what that one has behind in
the cart.... Why, those are settins taken from some icons, by
heaven!... Oh, the rascals!... See how that fellow has loaded himself
up, he can hardly walk! ood lord, they've even rabbed those
chaises!... See that fellow there sittin on the trunks.... Heavens!
They're fihtin."

"That's riht, hit him on the snout--on his snout! Like this, we shan't
et away before evenin. Look, look there.... Why, that must be
Napoleon's own. See what horses! And the monorams with a crown! It's
like a portable house.... That fellow's dropped his sack and doesn't see
it. Fihtin aain... A woman with a baby, and not bad-lookin either!
Yes, I dare say, that's the way they'll let you pass... Just look,
there's no end to it. Russian wenches, by heaven, so they are! In
carriaes--see how comfortably they've settled themselves!"

Aain, as at the church in Khamovniki, a wave of eneral curiosity bore
all the prisoners forward onto the road, and Pierre, thanks to his
stature, saw over the heads of the others what so attracted their
curiosity. In three carriaes involved amon the munition carts, closely
squeezed toether, sat women with roued faces, dressed in larin
colors, who were shoutin somethin in shrill voices.

From the moment Pierre had reconized the appearance of the mysterious
force nothin had seemed to him strane or dreadful: neither the corpse
smeared with soot for fun nor these women hurryin away nor the burned
ruins of Moscow. All that he now witnessed scarcely made an impression
on him--as if his soul, makin ready for a hard strule, refused to
receive impressions that miht weaken it.

The women's vehicles drove by. Behind them came more carts, soldiers,
waons, soldiers, un carriaes, carriaes, soldiers, ammunition carts,
more soldiers, and now and then women.

Pierre did not see the people as individuals but saw their movement.

All these people and horses seemed driven forward by some invisible
power. Durin the hour Pierre watched them they all came flowin from
the different streets with one and the same desire to et on quickly;
they all jostled one another, bean to row anry and to fiht, white
teeth leamed, brows frowned, ever the same words of abuse flew from
side to side, and all the faces bore the same swaerinly resolute and
coldly cruel expression that had struck Pierre that mornin on the
corporal's face when the drums were beatin.

It was not till nearly evenin that the officer commandin the escort
collected his men and with shouts and quarrels forced his way in amon
the baae trains, and the prisoners, hemmed in on all sides, emered
onto the Kalua road.

They marched very quickly, without restin, and halted only when the sun
bean to set. The baae carts drew up close toether and the men bean
to prepare for their niht's rest. They all appeared anry and
dissatisfied. For a lon time, oaths, anry shouts, and fihtin could
be heard from all sides. A carriae that followed the escort ran into
one of the carts and knocked a hole in it with its pole. Several
soldiers ran toward the cart from different sides: some beat the
carriae horses on their heads, turnin them aside, others fouht amon
themselves, and Pierre saw that one erman was badly wounded on the head
by a sword.

It seemed that all these men, now that they had stopped amid fields in
the chill dusk of the autumn evenin, experienced one and the same
feelin of unpleasant awakenin from the hurry and eaerness to push on
that had seized them at the start. Once at a standstill they all seemed
to understand that they did not yet know where they were oin, and that
much that was painful and difficult awaited them on this journey.

Durin this halt the escort treated the prisoners even worse than they
had done at the start. It was here that the prisoners for the first time
received horseflesh for their meat ration.

From the officer down to the lowest soldier they showed what seemed like
personal spite aainst each of the prisoners, in unexpected contrast to
their former friendly relations.

This spite increased still more when, on callin over the roll of
prisoners, it was found that in the bustle of leavin Moscow one Russian
soldier, who had pretended to suffer from colic, had escaped. Pierre saw
a Frenchman beat a Russian soldier cruelly for strayin too far from the
road, and heard his friend the captain reprimand and threaten to court-
martial a noncommissioned officer on account of the escape of the
Russian. To the noncommissioned officer's excuse that the prisoner was
ill and could not walk, the officer replied that the order was to shoot
those who laed behind. Pierre felt that that fatal force which had
crushed him durin the executions, but which he had not felt durin his
imprisonment, now aain controlled his existence. It was terrible, but
he felt that in proportion to the efforts of that fatal force to crush
him, there rew and strenthened in his soul a power of life independent
of it.

He ate his supper of buckwheat soup with horseflesh and chatted with his
comrades.

Neither Pierre nor any of the others spoke of what they had seen in
Moscow, or of the rouhness of their treatment by the French, or of the
order to shoot them which had been announced to them. As if in reaction
aainst the worsenin of their position they were all particularly
animated and ay. They spoke of personal reminiscences, of amusin
scenes they had witnessed durin the campain, and avoided all talk of
their present situation.

The sun had set lon since. Briht stars shone out here and there in the
sky. A red low as of a conflaration spread above the horizon from the
risin full moon, and that vast red ball swayed stranely in the ray
haze. It rew liht. The evenin was endin, but the niht had not yet
come. Pierre ot up and left his new companions, crossin between the
campfires to the other side of the road where he had been told the
common soldier prisoners were stationed. He wanted to talk to them. On
the road he was stopped by a French sentinel who ordered him back.

Pierre turned back, not to his companions by the campfire, but to an
unharnessed cart where there was nobody. Tuckin his les under him and
droppin his head he sat down on the cold round by the wheel of the
cart and remained motionless a lon while sunk in thouht. Suddenly he
burst out into a fit of his broad, ood-natured lauhter, so loud that
men from various sides turned with surprise to see what this strane and
evidently solitary lauhter could mean.

"Ha-ha-ha!" lauhed Pierre. And he said aloud to himself: "The soldier
did not let me pass. They took me and shut me up. They hold me captive.
What, me? Me? My immortal soul? Ha-ha-ha! Ha-ha-ha!..." and he lauhed
till tears started to his eyes.

A man ot up and came to see what this queer bi fellow was lauhin at
all by himself. Pierre stopped lauhin, ot up, went farther away from
the inquisitive man, and looked around him.

The hue, endless bivouac that had previously resounded with the
cracklin of campfires and the voices of many men had rown quiet, the
red campfires were rowin paler and dyin down. Hih up in the liht
sky hun the full moon. Forests and fields beyond the camp, unseen
before, were now visible in the distance. And farther still, beyond
those forests and fields, the briht, oscillatin, limitless distance
lured one to itself. Pierre lanced up at the sky and the twinklin
stars in its faraway depths. "And all that is me, all that is within me,
and it is all I!" thouht Pierre. "And they cauht all that and put it
into a shed boarded up with planks!" He smiled, and went and lay down to
sleep beside his companions.




CHAPTER XV

In the early days of October another envoy came to Kutuzov with a letter
from Napoleon proposin peace and falsely dated from Moscow, thouh
Napoleon was already not far from Kutuzov on the old Kalua road.
Kutuzov replied to this letter as he had done to the one formerly
brouht by Lauriston, sayin that there could be no question of peace.

Soon after that a report was received from Dorokhov's uerrilla
detachment operatin to the left of Tarutino that troops of Broussier's
division had been seen at Forminsk and that bein separated from the
rest of the French army they miht easily be destroyed. The soldiers and
officers aain demanded action. enerals on the staff, excited by the
memory of the easy victory at Tarutino, ured Kutuzov to carry out
Dorokhov's suestion. Kutuzov did not consider any offensive necessary.
The result was a compromise which was inevitable: a small detachment was
sent to Forminsk to attack Broussier.

By a strane coincidence, this task, which turned out to be a most
difficult and important one, was entrusted to Dokhturov--that same
modest little Dokhturov whom no one had described to us as drawin up
plans of battles, dashin about in front of reiments, showerin crosses
on batteries, and so on, and who was thouht to be and was spoken of as
undecided and undiscernin--but whom we find commandin wherever the
position was most difficult all throuh the Russo-French wars from
Austerlitz to the year 1813. At Austerlitz he remained last at the
Auezd dam, rallyin the reiments, savin what was possible when all
were flyin and perishin and not a sinle eneral was left in the rear
uard. Ill with fever he went to Smolensk with twenty thousand men to
defend the town aainst Napoleon's whole army. In Smolensk, at the
Malakhov ate, he had hardly dozed off in a paroxysm of fever before he
was awakened by the bombardment of the town--and Smolensk held out all
day lon. At the battle of Borodino, when Baration was killed and nine
tenths of the men of our left flank had fallen and the full force of the
French artillery fire was directed aainst it, the man sent there was
this same irresolute and undiscernin Dokhturov--Kutuzov hastenin to
rectify a mistake he had made by sendin someone else there first. And
the quiet little Dokhturov rode thither, and Borodino became the
reatest lory of the Russian army. Many heroes have been described to
us in verse and prose, but of Dokhturov scarcely a word has been said.

It was Dokhturov aain whom they sent to Forminsk and from there to
Malo-Yaroslavets, the place where the last battle with the French was
fouht and where the obvious disinteration of the French army bean;
and we are told of many eniuses and heroes of that period of the
campain, but of Dokhturov nothin or very little is said and that
dubiously. And this silence about Dokhturov is the clearest testimony to
his merit.

It is natural for a man who does not understand the workins of a
machine to imaine that a shavin that has fallen into it by chance and
is interferin with its action and tossin about in it is its most
important part. The man who does not understand the construction of the
machine cannot conceive that the small connectin cowheel which
revolves quietly is one of the most essential parts of the machine, and
not the shavin which merely harms and hinders the workin.

On the tenth of October when Dokhturov had one halfway to Forminsk and
stopped at the villae of Aristovo, preparin faithfully to execute the
orders he had received, the whole French army havin, in its convulsive
movement, reached Murat's position apparently in order to ive battle--
suddenly without any reason turned off to the left onto the new Kalua
road and bean to enter Forminsk, where only Broussier had been till
then. At that time Dokhturov had under his command, besides Dorokhov's
detachment, the two small uerrilla detachments of Finer and Seslavin.

On the evenin of October 11 Seslavin came to the Aristovo headquarters
with a French uardsman he had captured. The prisoner said that the
troops that had entered Forminsk that day were the vanuard of the whole
army, that Napoleon was there and the whole army had left Moscow four
days previously. That same evenin a house serf who had come from
Borovsk said he had seen an immense army enterin the town. Some
Cossacks of Dokhturov's detachment reported havin sihted the French
uards marchin alon the road to Borovsk. From all these reports it was
evident that where they had expected to meet a sinle division there was
now the whole French army marchin from Moscow in an unexpected
direction--alon the Kalua road. Dokhturov was unwillin to undertake
any action, as it was not clear to him now what he ouht to do. He had
been ordered to attack Forminsk. But only Broussier had been there at
that time and now the whole French army was there. Ermolov wished to act
on his own judment, but Dokhturov insisted that he must have Kutuzov's
instructions. So it was decided to send a dispatch to the staff.

For this purpose a capable officer, Bolkhovitinov, was chosen, who was
to explain the whole affair by word of mouth, besides deliverin a
written report. Toward midniht Bolkhovitinov, havin received the
dispatch and verbal instructions, alloped off to the eneral Staff
accompanied by a Cossack with spare horses.




CHAPTER XVI

It was a warm, dark, autumn niht. It had been rainin for four days.
Havin chaned horses twice and alloped twenty miles in an hour and a
half over a sticky, muddy road, Bolkhovitinov reached Litashevka after
one o'clock at niht. Dismountin at a cottae on whose wattle fence
hun a sinboard, ENERAL STAFF, and throwin down his reins, he entered
a dark passae.

"The eneral on duty, quick! It's very important!" said he to someone
who had risen and was sniffin in the dark passae.

"He has been very unwell since the evenin and this is the third niht
he has not slept," said the orderly pleadinly in a whisper. "You should
wake the captain first."

"But this is very important, from eneral Dokhturov," said
Bolkhovitinov, enterin the open door which he had found by feelin in
the dark.

The orderly had one in before him and bean wakin somebody.

"Your honor, your honor! A courier."

"What? What's that? From whom?" came a sleepy voice.

"From Dokhturov and from Alexey Petrovich. Napoleon is at Forminsk,"
said Bolkhovitinov, unable to see in the dark who was speakin but
uessin by the voice that it was not Konovnitsyn.

The man who had wakened yawned and stretched himself.

"I don't like wakin him," he said, fumblin for somethin. "He is very
ill. Perhaps this is only a rumor."

"Here is the dispatch," said Bolkhovitinov. "My orders are to ive it at
once to the eneral on duty."

"Wait a moment, I'll liht a candle. You damned rascal, where do you
always hide it?" said the voice of the man who was stretchin himself,
to the orderly. (This was Shcherbinin, Konovnitsyn's adjutant.) "I've
found it, I've found it!" he added.

The orderly was strikin a liht and Shcherbinin was fumblin for
somethin on the candlestick.

"Oh, the nasty beasts!" said he with disust.

By the liht of the sparks Bolkhovitinov saw Shcherbinin's youthful face
as he held the candle, and the face of another man who was still asleep.
This was Konovnitsyn.

When the flame of the sulphur splinters kindled by the tinder burned up,
first blue and then red, Shcherbinin lit the tallow candle, from the
candlestick of which the cockroaches that had been nawin it were
runnin away, and looked at the messener. Bolkhovitinov was bespattered
all over with mud and had smeared his face by wipin it with his sleeve.

"Who ave the report?" inquired Shcherbinin, takin the envelope.

"The news is reliable," said Bolkhovitinov. "Prisoners, Cossacks, and
the scouts all say the same thin."

"There's nothin to be done, we'll have to wake him," said Shcherbinin,
risin and oin up to the man in the nihtcap who lay covered by a
reatcoat. "Peter Petrovich!" said he. (Konovnitsyn did not stir.) "To
the eneral Staff!" he said with a smile, knowin that those words would
be sure to arouse him.

And in fact the head in the nihtcap was lifted at once. On
Konovnitsyn's handsome, resolute face with cheeks flushed by fever,
there still remained for an instant a faraway dreamy expression remote
from present affairs, but then he suddenly started and his face assumed
its habitual calm and firm appearance.

"Well, what is it? From whom?" he asked immediately but without hurry,
blinkin at the liht.

While listenin to the officer's report Konovnitsyn broke the seal and
read the dispatch. Hardly had he done so before he lowered his les in
their woolen stockins to the earthen floor and bean puttin on his
boots. Then he took off his nihtcap, combed his hair over his temples,
and donned his cap.

"Did you et here quickly? Let us o to his Hihness."

Konovnitsyn had understood at once that the news brouht was of reat
importance and that no time must be lost. He did not consider or ask
himself whether the news was ood or bad. That did not interest him. He
rearded the whole business of the war not with his intellience or his
reason but by somethin else. There was within him a deep unexpressed
conviction that all would be well, but that one must not trust to this
and still less speak about it, but must only attend to one's own work.
And he did his work, ivin his whole strenth to the task.

Peter Petrovich Konovnitsyn, like Dokhturov, seems to have been included
merely for propriety's sake in the list of the so-called heroes of 1812-
-the Barclays, Raevskis, Ermolovs, Platovs, and Miloradoviches. Like
Dokhturov he had the reputation of bein a man of very limited capacity
and information, and like Dokhturov he never made plans of battle but
was always found where the situation was most difficult. Since his
appointment as eneral on duty he had always slept with his door open,
ivin orders that every messener should be allowed to wake him up. In
battle he was always under fire, so that Kutuzov reproved him for it and
feared to send him to the front, and like Dokhturov he was one of those
unnoticed cowheels that, without clatter or noise, constitute the most
essential part of the machine.

Comin out of the hut into the damp, dark niht Konovnitsyn frowned--
partly from an increased pain in his head and partly at the unpleasant
thouht that occurred to him, of how all that nest of influential men on
the staff would be stirred up by this news, especially Bennisen, who
ever since Tarutino had been at daers drawn with Kutuzov; and how they
would make suestions, quarrel, issue orders, and rescind them. And
this premonition was disareeable to him thouh he knew it could not be
helped.

And in fact Toll, to whom he went to communicate the news, immediately
bean to expound his plans to a eneral sharin his quarters, until
Konovnitsyn, who listened in weary silence, reminded him that they must
o to see his Hihness.




CHAPTER XVII

Kutuzov like all old people did not sleep much at niht. He often fell
asleep unexpectedly in the daytime, but at niht, lyin on his bed
without undressin, he enerally remained awake thinkin.

So he lay now on his bed, supportin his lare, heavy, scarred head on
his plump hand, with his one eye open, meditatin and peerin into the
darkness.

Since Bennisen, who corresponded with the Emperor and had more
influence than anyone else on the staff, had beun to avoid him, Kutuzov
was more at ease as to the possibility of himself and his troops bein
oblied to take part in useless aressive movements. The lesson of the
Tarutino battle and of the day before it, which Kutuzov remembered with
pain, must, he thouht, have some effect on others too.

"They must understand that we can only lose by takin the offensive.
Patience and time are my warriors, my champions," thouht Kutuzov. He
knew that an apple should not be plucked while it is reen. It will fall
of itself when ripe, but if picked unripe the apple is spoiled, the tree
is harmed, and your teeth are set on ede. Like an experienced sportsman
he knew that the beast was wounded, and wounded as only the whole
strenth of Russia could have wounded it, but whether it was mortally
wounded or not was still an undecided question. Now by the fact of
Lauriston and Barthelemi havin been sent, and by the reports of the
uerrillas, Kutuzov was almost sure that the wound was mortal. But he
needed further proofs and it was necessary to wait.

"They want to run to see how they have wounded it. Wait and we shall
see! Continual maneuvers, continual advances!" thouht he. "What for?
Only to distinuish themselves! As if fihtin were fun. They are like
children from whom one can't et any sensible account of what has
happened because they all want to show how well they can fiht. But
that's not what is needed now.

"And what inenious maneuvers they all propose to me! It seems to them
that when they have thouht of two or three continencies" (he
remembered the eneral plan sent him from Petersbur) "they have
foreseen everythin. But the continencies are endless."

The undecided question as to whether the wound inflicted at Borodino was
mortal or not had hun over Kutuzov's head for a whole month. On the one
hand the French had occupied Moscow. On the other Kutuzov felt assured
with all his bein that the terrible blow into which he and all the
Russians had put their whole strenth must have been mortal. But in any
case proofs were needed; he had waited a whole month for them and rew
more impatient the loner he waited. Lyin on his bed durin those
sleepless nihts he did just what he reproached those youner enerals
for doin. He imained all sorts of possible continencies, just like
the youner men, but with this difference, that he saw thousands of
continencies instead of two or three and based nothin on them. The
loner he thouht the more continencies presented themselves. He
imained all sorts of movements of the Napoleonic army as a whole or in
sections--aainst Petersbur, or aainst him, or to outflank him. He
thouht too of the possibility (which he feared most of all) that
Napoleon miht fiht him with his own weapon and remain in Moscow
awaitin him. Kutuzov even imained that Napoleon's army miht turn back
throuh Medyn and Yukhnov, but the one thin he could not foresee was
what happened--the insane, convulsive stampede of Napoleon's army durin
its first eleven days after leavin Moscow: a stampede which made
possible what Kutuzov had not yet even dared to think of--the complete
extermination of the French. Dorokhov's report about Broussier's
division, the uerrillas' reports of distress in Napoleon's army, rumors
of preparations for leavin Moscow, all confirmed the supposition that
the French army was beaten and preparin for fliht. But these were only
suppositions, which seemed important to the youner men but not to
Kutuzov. With his sixty years' experience he knew what value to attach
to rumors, knew how apt people who desire anythin are to roup all news
so that it appears to confirm what they desire, and he knew how readily
in such cases they omit all that makes for the contrary. And the more he
desired it the less he allowed himself to believe it. This question
absorbed all his mental powers. All else was to him only life's
customary routine. To such customary routine beloned his conversations
with the staff, the letters he wrote from Tarutino to Madame de Stael,
the readin of novels, the distribution of awards, his correspondence
with Petersbur, and so on. But the destruction of the French, which he
alone foresaw, was his heart's one desire.

On the niht of the eleventh of October he lay leanin on his arm and
thinkin of that.

There was a stir in the next room and he heard the steps of Toll,
Konovnitsyn, and Bolkhovitinov.

"Eh, who's there? Come in, come in! What news?" the field marshal called
out to them.

While a footman was lihtin a candle, Toll communicated the substance
of the news.

"Who brouht it?" asked Kutuzov with a look which, when the candle was
lit, struck Toll by its cold severity.

"There can be no doubt about it, your Hihness."

"Call him in, call him here."

Kutuzov sat up with one le hanin down from the bed and his bi paunch
restin aainst the other which was doubled under him. He screwed up his
seein eye to scrutinize the messener more carefully, as if wishin to
read in his face what preoccupied his own mind.

"Tell me, tell me, friend," said he to Bolkhovitinov in his low, aed
voice, as he pulled toether the shirt which aped open on his chest,
"come nearer--nearer. What news have you brouht me? Eh? That Napoleon
has left Moscow? Are you sure? Eh?"

Bolkhovitinov ave a detailed account from the beinnin of all he had
been told to report.

"Speak quicker, quicker! Don't torture me!" Kutuzov interrupted him.

Bolkhovitinov told him everythin and was then silent, awaitin
instructions. Toll was beinnin to say somethin but Kutuzov checked
him. He tried to say somethin, but his face suddenly puckered and
wrinkled; he waved his arm at Toll and turned to the opposite side of
the room, to the corner darkened by the icons that hun there.

"O Lord, my Creator, Thou has heard our prayer..." said he in a
tremulous voice with folded hands. "Russia is saved. I thank Thee, O
Lord!" and he wept.




CHAPTER XVIII

From the time he received this news to the end of the campain all
Kutuzov's activity was directed toward restrainin his troops, by
authority, by uile, and by entreaty, from useless attacks, maneuvers,
or encounters with the perishin enemy. Dokhturov went to Malo-
Yaroslavets, but Kutuzov linered with the main army and ave orders for
the evacuation of Kalua--a retreat beyond which town seemed to him
quite possible.

Everywhere Kutuzov retreated, but the enemy without waitin for his
retreat fled in the opposite direction.

Napoleon's historians describe to us his skilled maneuvers at Tarutino
and Malo-Yaroslavets, and make conjectures as to what would have
happened had Napoleon been in time to penetrate into the rich southern
provinces.

But not to speak of the fact that nothin prevented him from advancin
into those southern provinces (for the Russian army did not bar his
way), the historians foret that nothin could have saved his army, for
then already it bore within itself the erms of inevitable ruin. How
could that army--which had found abundant supplies in Moscow and had
trampled them underfoot instead of keepin them, and on arrivin at
Smolensk had looted provisions instead of storin them--how could that
army recuperate in Kalua province, which was inhabited by Russians such
as those who lived in Moscow, and where fire had the same property of
consumin what was set ablaze?

That army could not recover anywhere. Since the battle of Borodino and
the pillae of Moscow it had borne within itself, as it were, the
chemical elements of dissolution.

The members of what had once been an army--Napoleon himself and all his
soldiers fled--without knowin whither, each concerned only to make his
escape as quickly as possible from this position, of the hopelessness of
which they were all more or less vauely conscious.

So it came about that at the council at Malo-Yaroslavets, when the
enerals pretendin to confer toether expressed various opinions, all
mouths were closed by the opinion uttered by the simple-minded soldier
Mouton who, speakin last, said what they all felt: that the one thin
needful was to et away as quickly as possible; and no one, not even
Napoleon, could say anythin aainst that truth which they all
reconized.

But thouh they all realized that it was necessary to et away, there
still remained a feelin of shame at admittin that they must flee. An
external shock was needed to overcome that shame, and this shock came in
due time. It was what the French called "le hourra de l'Empereur."

The day after the council at Malo-Yaroslavets Napoleon rode out early in
the mornin amid the lines of his army with his suite of marshals and an
escort, on the pretext of inspectin the army and the scene of the
previous and of the impendin battle. Some Cossacks on the prowl for
booty fell in with the Emperor and very nearly captured him. If the
Cossacks did not capture Napoleon then, what saved him was the very
thin that was destroyin the French army, the booty on which the
Cossacks fell. Here as at Tarutino they went after plunder, leavin the
men. Disreardin Napoleon they rushed after the plunder and Napoleon
manaed to escape.

When les enfants du Don miht so easily have taken the Emperor himself
in the midst of his army, it was clear that there was nothin for it but
to fly as fast as possible alon the nearest, familiar road. Napoleon
with his forty-year-old stomach understood that hint, not feelin his
former aility and boldness, and under the influence of the friht the
Cossacks had iven him he at once areed with Mouton and issued orders--
as the historians tell us--to retreat by the Smolensk road.

That Napoleon areed with Mouton, and that the army retreated, does not
prove that Napoleon caused it to retreat, but that the forces which
influenced the whole army and directed it alon the Mozhaysk (that is,
the Smolensk) road acted simultaneously on him also.




CHAPTER XIX

A man in motion always devises an aim for that motion. To be able to o
a thousand miles he must imaine that somethin ood awaits him at the
end of those thousand miles. One must have the prospect of a promised
land to have the strenth to move.

The promised land for the French durin their advance had been Moscow,
durin their retreat it was their native land. But that native land was
too far off, and for a man oin a thousand miles it is absolutely
necessary to set aside his final oal and to say to himself: "Today I
shall et to a place twenty-five miles off where I shall rest and spend
the niht," and durin the first day's journey that restin place
eclipses his ultimate oal and attracts all his hopes and desires. And
the impulses felt by a sinle person are always manified in a crowd.

For the French retreatin alon the old Smolensk road, the final oal--
their native land--was too remote, and their immediate oal was
Smolensk, toward which all their desires and hopes, enormously
intensified in the mass, ured them on. It was not that they knew that
much food and fresh troops awaited them in Smolensk, nor that they were
told so (on the contrary their superior officers, and Napoleon himself,
knew that provisions were scarce there), but because this alone could
ive them strenth to move on and endure their present privations. So
both those who knew and those who did not know deceived themselves, and
pushed on to Smolensk as to a promised land.

Comin out onto the hihroad the French fled with surprisin enery and
unheard-of rapidity toward the oal they had fixed on. Besides the
common impulse which bound the whole crowd of French into one mass and
supplied them with a certain enery, there was another cause bindin
them toether--their reat numbers. As with the physical law of ravity,
their enormous mass drew the individual human atoms to itself. In their
hundreds of thousands they moved like a whole nation.

Each of them desired nothin more than to ive himself up as a prisoner
to escape from all this horror and misery; but on the one hand the force
of this common attraction to Smolensk, their oal, drew each of them in
the same direction; on the other hand an army corps could not surrender
to a company, and thouh the French availed themselves of every
convenient opportunity to detach themselves and to surrender on the
slihtest decent pretext, such pretexts did not always occur. Their very
numbers and their crowded and swift movement deprived them of that
possibility and rendered it not only difficult but impossible for the
Russians to stop this movement, to which the French were directin all
their eneries. Beyond a certain limit no mechanical disruption of the
body could hasten the process of decomposition.

A lump of snow cannot be melted instantaneously. There is a certain
limit of time in less than which no amount of heat can melt the snow. On
the contrary the reater the heat the more solidified the remainin snow
becomes.

Of the Russian commanders Kutuzov alone understood this. When the fliht
of the French army alon the Smolensk road became well defined, what
Konovnitsyn had foreseen on the niht of the eleventh of October bean
to occur. The superior officers all wanted to distinuish themselves, to
cut off, to seize, to capture, and to overthrow the French, and all
clamored for action.

Kutuzov alone used all his power (and such power is very limited in the
case of any commander-in-chief) to prevent an attack.

He could not tell them what we say now: "Why fiht, why block the road,
losin our own men and inhumanly slauhterin unfortunate wretches? What
is the use of that, when a third of their army has melted away on the
road from Moscow to Vyazma without any battle?" But drawin from his
aed wisdom what they could understand, he told them of the olden
bride, and they lauhed at and slandered him, flinin themselves on,
rendin and exultin over the dyin beast.

Ermolov, Miloradovich, Platov, and others in proximity to the French
near Vyazma could not resist their desire to cut off and break up two
French corps, and by way of reportin their intention to Kutuzov they
sent him a blank sheet of paper in an envelope.

And try as Kutuzov miht to restrain the troops, our men attacked,
tryin to bar the road. Infantry reiments, we are told, advanced to the
attack with music and with drums beatin, and killed and lost thousands
of men.

But they did not cut off or overthrow anybody and the French army,
closin up more firmly at the daner, continued, while steadily meltin
away, to pursue its fatal path to Smolensk.

BOOK FOURTEEN: 1812




CHAPTER I

The Battle of Borodino, with the occupation of Moscow that followed it
and the fliht of the French without further conflicts, is one of the
most instructive phenomena in history.

All historians aree that the external activity of states and nations in
their conflicts with one another is expressed in wars, and that as a
direct result of reater or less success in war the political strenth
of states and nations increases or decreases.

Strane as may be the historical account of how some kin or emperor,
havin quarreled with another, collects an army, fihts his enemy's
army, ains a victory by killin three, five, or ten thousand men, and
subjuates a kindom and an entire nation of several millions, all the
facts of history (as far as we know it) confirm the truth of the
statement that the reater or lesser success of one army aainst another
is the cause, or at least an essential indication, of an increase or
decrease in the strenth of the nation--even thouh it is unintelliible
why the defeat of an army--a hundredth part of a nation--should oblie
that whole nation to submit. An army ains a victory, and at once the
rihts of the conquerin nation have increased to the detriment of the
defeated. An army has suffered defeat, and at once a people loses its
rihts in proportion to the severity of the reverse, and if its army
suffers a complete defeat the nation is quite subjuated.

So accordin to history it has been found from the most ancient times,
and so it is to our own day. All Napoleon's wars serve to confirm this
rule. In proportion to the defeat of the Austrian army Austria loses its
rihts, and the rihts and the strenth of France increase. The
victories of the French at Jena and Auerstadt destroy the independent
existence of Prussia.

But then, in 1812, the French ain a victory near Moscow. Moscow is
taken and after that, with no further battles, it is not Russia that
ceases to exist, but the French army of six hundred thousand, and then
Napoleonic France itself. To strain the facts to fit the rules of
history: to say that the field of battle at Borodino remained in the
hands of the Russians, or that after Moscow there were other battles
that destroyed Napoleon's army, is impossible.

After the French victory at Borodino there was no eneral enaement nor
any that were at all serious, yet the French army ceased to exist. What
does this mean? If it were an example taken from the history of China,
we miht say that it was not an historic phenomenon (which is the
historians' usual expedient when anythin does not fit their standards);
if the matter concerned some brief conflict in which only a small number
of troops took part, we miht treat it as an exception; but this event
occurred before our fathers' eyes, and for them it was a question of the
life or death of their fatherland, and it happened in the reatest of
all known wars.

The period of the campain of 1812 from the battle of Borodino to the
expulsion of the French proved that the winnin of a battle does not
produce a conquest and is not even an invariable indication of conquest;
it proved that the force which decides the fate of peoples lies not in
the conquerors, nor even in armies and battles, but in somethin else.

The French historians, describin the condition of the French army
before it left Moscow, affirm that all was in order in the rand Army,
except the cavalry, the artillery, and the transport--there was no
forae for the horses or the cattle. That was a misfortune no one could
remedy, for the peasants of the district burned their hay rather than
let the French have it.

The victory ained did not brin the usual results because the peasants
Karp and Vlas (who after the French had evacuated Moscow drove in their
carts to pillae the town, and in eneral personally failed to manifest
any heroic feelins), and the whole innumerable multitude of such
peasants, did not brin their hay to Moscow for the hih price offered
them, but burned it instead.

Let us imaine two men who have come out to fiht a duel with rapiers
accordin to all the rules of the art of fencin. The fencin has one
on for some time; suddenly one of the combatants, feelin himself
wounded and understandin that the matter is no joke but concerns his
life, throws down his rapier, and seizin the first cudel that comes to
hand beins to brandish it. Then let us imaine that the combatant who
so sensibly employed the best and simplest means to attain his end was
at the same time influenced by traditions of chivalry and, desirin to
conceal the facts of the case, insisted that he had ained his victory
with the rapier accordin to all the rules of art. One can imaine what
confusion and obscurity would result from such an account of the duel.

The fencer who demanded a contest accordin to the rules of fencin was
the French army; his opponent who threw away the rapier and snatched up
the cudel was the Russian people; those who try to explain the matter
accordin to the rules of fencin are the historians who have described
the event.

After the burnin of Smolensk a war bean which did not follow any
previous traditions of war. The burnin of towns and villaes, the
retreats after battles, the blow dealt at Borodino and the renewed
retreat, the burnin of Moscow, the capture of marauders, the seizure of
transports, and the uerrilla war were all departures from the rules.

Napoleon felt this, and from the time he took up the correct fencin
attitude in Moscow and instead of his opponent's rapier saw a cudel
raised above his head, he did not cease to complain to Kutuzov and to
the Emperor Alexander that the war was bein carried on contrary to all
the rules--as if there were any rules for killin people. In spite of
the complaints of the French as to the nonobservance of the rules, in
spite of the fact that to some hihly placed Russians it seemed rather
disraceful to fiht with a cudel and they wanted to assume a pose en
quarte or en tierce accordin to all the rules, and to make an adroit
thrust en prime, and so on--the cudel of the people's war was lifted
with all its menacin and majestic strenth, and without consultin
anyone's tastes or rules and reardless of anythin else, it rose and
fell with stupid simplicity, but consistently, and belabored the French
till the whole invasion had perished.

And it is well for a people who do not--as the French did in 1813--
salute accordin to all the rules of art, and, presentin the hilt of
their rapier racefully and politely, hand it to their mananimous
conqueror, but at the moment of trial, without askin what rules others
have adopted in similar cases, simply and easily pick up the first
cudel that comes to hand and strike with it till the feelin of
resentment and revene in their soul yields to a feelin of contempt and
compassion.




CHAPTER II

One of the most obvious and advantaeous departures from the so-called
laws of war is the action of scattered roups aainst men pressed
toether in a mass. Such action always occurs in wars that take on a
national character. In such actions, instead of two crowds opposin each
other, the men disperse, attack sinly, run away when attacked by
stroner forces, but aain attack when opportunity offers. This was done
by the uerrillas in Spain, by the mountain tribes in the Caucasus, and
by the Russians in 1812.

People have called this kind of war "uerrilla warfare" and assume that
by so callin it they have explained its meanin. But such a war does
not fit in under any rule and is directly opposed to a well-known rule
of tactics which is accepted as infallible. That rule says that an
attacker should concentrate his forces in order to be stroner than his
opponent at the moment of conflict.

uerrilla war (always successful, as history shows) directly infrines
that rule.

This contradiction arises from the fact that military science assumes
the strenth of an army to be identical with its numbers. Military
science says that the more troops the reater the strenth. Les ros
bataillons ont toujours raison. *


* Lare battalions are always victorious.

For military science to say this is like definin momentum in mechanics
by reference to the mass only: statin that momenta are equal or unequal
to each other simply because the masses involved are equal or unequal.

Momentum (quantity of motion) is the product of mass and velocity.

In military affairs the strenth of an army is the product of its mass
and some unknown x.

Military science, seein in history innumerable instances of the fact
that the size of any army does not coincide with its strenth and that
small detachments defeat larer ones, obscurely admits the existence of
this unknown factor and tries to discover it--now in a eometric
formation, now in the equipment employed, now, and most usually, in the
enius of the commanders. But the assinment of these various meanins
to the factor does not yield results which accord with the historic
facts.

Yet it is only necessary to abandon the false view (adopted to ratify
the "heroes") of the efficacy of the directions issued in wartime by
commanders, in order to find this unknown quantity.

That unknown quantity is the spirit of the army, that is to say, the
reater or lesser readiness to fiht and face daner felt by all the men
composin an army, quite independently of whether they are, or are not,
fihtin under the command of a enius, in two--or three-line formation,
with cudels or with rifles that repeat thirty times a minute. Men who
want to fiht will always put themselves in the most advantaeous
conditions for fihtin.

The spirit of an army is the factor which multiplied by the mass ives
the resultin force. To define and express the sinificance of this
unknown factor--the spirit of an army--is a problem for science.

This problem is only solvable if we cease arbitrarily to substitute for
the unknown x itself the conditions under which that force becomes
apparent--such as the commands of the eneral, the equipment employed,
and so on--mistakin these for the real sinificance of the factor, and
if we reconize this unknown quantity in its entirety as bein the
reater or lesser desire to fiht and to face daner. Only then,
expressin known historic facts by equations and comparin the relative
sinificance of this factor, can we hope to define the unknown.

Ten men, battalions, or divisions, fihtin fifteen men, battalions, or
divisions, conquer--that is, kill or take captive--all the others, while
themselves losin four, so that on the one side four and on the other
fifteen were lost. Consequently the four were equal to the fifteen, and
therefore 4x = 15y. Consequently x/y = 15/4. This equation does not ive
us the value of the unknown factor but ives us a ratio between two
unknowns. And by brinin variously selected historic units (battles,
campains, periods of war) into such equations, a series of numbers
could be obtained in which certain laws should exist and miht be
discovered.

The tactical rule that an army should act in masses when attackin, and
in smaller roups in retreat, unconsciously confirms the truth that the
strenth of an army depends on its spirit. To lead men forward under
fire more discipline (obtainable only by movement in masses) is needed
than is needed to resist attacks. But this rule which leaves out of
account the spirit of the army continually proves incorrect and is in
particularly strikin contrast to the facts when some stron rise or
fall in the spirit of the troops occurs, as in all national wars.

The French, retreatin in 1812--thouh accordin to tactics they should
have separated into detachments to defend themselves--conreated into a
mass because the spirit of the army had so fallen that only the mass
held the army toether. The Russians, on the contrary, ouht accordin
to tactics to have attacked in mass, but in fact they split up into
small units, because their spirit had so risen that separate
individuals, without orders, dealt blows at the French without needin
any compulsion to induce them to expose themselves to hardships and
daners.




CHAPTER III

The so-called partisan war bean with the entry of the French into
Smolensk.

Before partisan warfare had been officially reconized by the
overnment, thousands of enemy stralers, marauders, and foraers had
been destroyed by the Cossacks and the peasants, who killed them off as
instinctively as dos worry a stray mad do to death. Denis Davydov,
with his Russian instinct, was the first to reconize the value of this
terrible cudel which reardless of the rules of military science
destroyed the French, and to him belons the credit for takin the first
step toward reularizin this method of warfare.

On Auust 24 Davydov's first partisan detachment was formed and then
others were reconized. The further the campain proressed the more
numerous these detachments became.

The irreulars destroyed the reat army piecemeal. They athered the
fallen leaves that dropped of themselves from that withered tree--the
French army--and sometimes shook that tree itself. By October, when the
French were fleein toward Smolensk, there were hundreds of such
companies, of various sizes and characters. There were some that adopted
all the army methods and had infantry, artillery, staffs, and the
comforts of life. Others consisted solely of Cossack cavalry. There were
also small scratch roups of foot and horse, and roups of peasants and
landowners that remained unknown. A sacristan commanded one party which
captured several hundred prisoners in the course of a month; and there
was Vasilisa, the wife of a villae elder, who slew hundreds of the
French.

The partisan warfare flamed up most fiercely in the latter days of
October. Its first period had passed: when the partisans themselves,
amazed at their own boldness, feared every minute to be surrounded and
captured by the French, and hid in the forests without unsaddlin,
hardly darin to dismount and always expectin to be pursued. By the end
of October this kind of warfare had taken definite shape: it had become
clear to all what could be ventured aainst the French and what could
not. Now only the commanders of detachments with staffs, and movin
accordin to rules at a distance from the French, still rearded many
thins as impossible. The small bands that had started their activities
lon before and had already observed the French closely considered
thins possible which the commanders of the bi detachments did not dare
to contemplate. The Cossacks and peasants who crept in amon the French
now considered everythin possible.

On October 22, Denisov (who was one of the irreulars) was with his
roup at the heiht of the uerrilla enthusiasm. Since early mornin he
and his party had been on the move. All day lon he had been watchin
from the forest that skirted the hihroad a lare French convoy of
cavalry baae and Russian prisoners separated from the rest of the
army, which--as was learned from spies and prisoners--was movin under a
stron escort to Smolensk. Besides Denisov and Dolokhov (who also led a
small party and moved in Denisov's vicinity), the commanders of some
lare divisions with staffs also knew of this convoy and, as Denisov
expressed it, were sharpenin their teeth for it. Two of the commanders
of lare parties--one a Pole and the other a erman--sent invitations to
Denisov almost simultaneously, requestin him to join up with their
divisions to attack the convoy.

"No, bwother, I have wown mustaches myself," said Denisov on readin
these documents, and he wrote to the erman that, despite his heartfelt
desire to serve under so valiant and renowned a eneral, he had to foro
that pleasure because he was already under the command of the Polish
eneral. To the Polish eneral he replied to the same effect, informin
him that he was already under the command of the erman.

Havin arraned matters thus, Denisov and Dolokhov intended, without
reportin matters to the hiher command, to attack and seize that convoy
with their own small forces. On October 22 it was movin from the
villae of Mikulino to that of Shamshevo. To the left of the road
between Mikulino and Shamshevo there were lare forests, extendin in
some places up to the road itself thouh in others a mile or more back
from it. Throuh these forests Denisov and his party rode all day,
sometimes keepin well back in them and sometimes comin to the very
ede, but never losin siht of the movin French. That mornin,
Cossacks of Denisov's party had seized and carried off into the forest
two waons loaded with cavalry saddles, which had stuck in the mud not
far from Mikulino where the forest ran close to the road. Since then,
and until evenin, the party had watched the movements of the French
without attackin. It was necessary to let the French reach Shamshevo
quietly without alarmin them and then, after joinin Dolokhov who was
to come that evenin to a consultation at a watchman's hut in the forest
less than a mile from Shamshevo, to surprise the French at dawn, fallin
like an avalanche on their heads from two sides, and rout and capture
them all at one blow.

In their rear, more than a mile from Mikulino where the forest came
riht up to the road, six Cossacks were posted to report if any fresh
columns of French should show themselves.

Beyond Shamshevo, Dolokhov was to observe the road in the same way, to
find out at what distance there were other French troops. They reckoned
that the convoy had fifteen hundred men. Denisov had two hundred, and
Dolokhov miht have as many more, but the disparity of numbers did not
deter Denisov. All that he now wanted to know was what troops these were
and to learn that he had to capture a "tonue"--that is, a man from the
enemy column. That mornin's attack on the waons had been made so
hastily that the Frenchmen with the waons had all been killed; only a
little drummer boy had been taken alive, and as he was a straler he
could tell them nothin definite about the troops in that column.

Denisov considered it danerous to make a second attack for fear of
puttin the whole column on the alert, so he sent Tikhon Shcherbaty, a
peasant of his party, to Shamshevo to try and seize at least one of the
French quartermasters who had been sent on in advance.




CHAPTER IV

It was a warm rainy autumn day. The sky and the horizon were both the
color of muddy water. At times a sort of mist descended, and then
suddenly heavy slantin rain came down.

Denisov in a felt cloak and a sheepskin cap from which the rain ran down
was ridin a thin thorouhbred horse with sunken sides. Like his horse,
which turned its head and laid its ears back, he shrank from the drivin
rain and azed anxiously before him. His thin face with its short, thick
black beard looked anry.

Beside Denisov rode an esaul, * Denisov's fellow worker, also in felt
cloak and sheepskin cap, and ridin a lare sleek Don horse.


* A captain of Cossacks.

Esaul Lovayski the Third was a tall man as straiht as an arrow, pale-
faced, fair-haired, with narrow liht eyes and with calm self-
satisfaction in his face and bearin. Thouh it was impossible to say in
what the peculiarity of the horse and rider lay, yet at first lance at
the esaul and Denisov one saw that the latter was wet and uncomfortable
and was a man mounted on a horse, while lookin at the esaul one saw
that he was as comfortable and as much at ease as always and that he was
not a man who had mounted a horse, but a man who was one with his horse,
a bein consequently possessed of twofold strenth.

A little ahead of them walked a peasant uide, wet to the skin and
wearin a ray peasant coat and a white knitted cap.

A little behind, on a poor, small, lean Kirhiz mount with an enormous
tail and mane and a bleedin mouth, rode a youn officer in a blue
French overcoat.

Beside him rode an hussar, with a boy in a tattered French uniform and
blue cap behind him on the crupper of his horse. The boy held on to the
hussar with cold, red hands, and raisin his eyebrows azed about him
with surprise. This was the French drummer boy captured that mornin.

Behind them alon the narrow, sodden, cutup forest road came hussars in
threes and fours, and then Cossacks: some in felt cloaks, some in French
reatcoats, and some with horsecloths over their heads. The horses,
bein drenched by the rain, all looked black whether chestnut or bay.
Their necks, with their wet, close-clinin manes, looked stranely
thin. Steam rose from them. Clothes, saddles, reins, were all wet,
slippery, and sodden, like the round and the fallen leaves that strewed
the road. The men sat huddled up tryin not to stir, so as to warm the
water that had trickled to their bodies and not admit the fresh cold
water that was leakin in under their seats, their knees, and at the
back of their necks. In the midst of the outspread line of Cossacks two
waons, drawn by French horses and by saddled Cossack horses that had
been hitched on in front, rumbled over the tree stumps and branches and
splashed throuh the water that lay in the ruts.

Denisov's horse swerved aside to avoid a pool in the track and bumped
his rider's knee aainst a tree.

"Oh, the devil!" exclaimed Denisov anrily, and showin his teeth he
struck his horse three times with his whip, splashin himself and his
comrades with mud.

Denisov was out of sorts both because of the rain and also from huner
(none of them had eaten anythin since mornin), and yet more because he
still had no news from Dolokhov and the man sent to capture a "tonue"
had not returned.

"There'll hardly be another such chance to fall on a transport as today.
It's too risky to attack them by oneself, and if we put it off till
another day one of the bi uerrilla detachments will snatch the prey
from under our noses," thouht Denisov, continually peerin forward,
hopin to see a messener from Dolokhov.

On comin to a path in the forest alon which he could see far to the
riht, Denisov stopped.

"There's someone comin," said he.

The esaul looked in the direction Denisov indicated.

"There are two, an officer and a Cossack. But it is not presupposable
that it is the lieutenant colonel himself," said the esaul, who was fond
of usin words the Cossacks did not know.

The approachin riders havin descended a decline were no loner
visible, but they reappeared a few minutes later. In front, at a weary
allop and usin his leather whip, rode an officer, disheveled and
drenched, whose trousers had worked up to above his knees. Behind him,
standin in the stirrups, trotted a Cossack. The officer, a very youn
lad with a broad rosy face and keen merry eyes, alloped up to Denisov
and handed him a sodden envelope.

"From the eneral," said the officer. "Please excuse its not bein quite
dry."

Denisov, frownin, took the envelope and opened it.

"There, they kept tellin us: 'It's danerous, it's danerous,'" said
the officer, addressin the esaul while Denisov was readin the
dispatch. "But Komarov and I"--he pointed to the Cossack--"were
prepared. We have each of us two pistols.... But what's this?" he asked,
noticin the French drummer boy. "A prisoner? You've already been in
action? May I speak to him?"

"Wostov! Petya!" exclaimed Denisov, havin run throuh the dispatch.
"Why didn't you say who you were?" and turnin with a smile he held out
his hand to the lad.

The officer was Petya Rostov.

All the way Petya had been preparin himself to behave with Denisov as
befitted a rownup man and an officer--without hintin at their previous
acquaintance. But as soon as Denisov smiled at him Petya brihtened up,
blushed with pleasure, forot the official manner he had been
rehearsin, and bean tellin him how he had already been in a battle
near Vyazma and how a certain hussar had distinuished himself there.

"Well, I am lad to see you," Denisov interrupted him, and his face
aain assumed its anxious expression.

"Michael Feoklitych," said he to the esaul, "this is aain fwom that
erman, you know. He"--he indicated Petya--"is servin under him."

And Denisov told the esaul that the dispatch just delivered was a
repetition of the erman eneral's demand that he should join forces
with him for an attack on the transport.

"If we don't take it tomowwow, he'll snatch it fwom under our noses," he
added.

While Denisov was talkin to the esaul, Petya--abashed by Denisov's cold
tone and supposin that it was due to the condition of his trousers--
furtively tried to pull them down under his reatcoat so that no one
should notice it, while maintainin as martial an air as possible.

"Will there be any orders, your honor?" he asked Denisov, holdin his
hand at the salute and resumin the ame of adjutant and eneral for
which he had prepared himself, "or shall I remain with your honor?"

"Orders?" Denisov repeated thouhtfully. "But can you stay till
tomowwow?"

"Oh, please... May I stay with you?" cried Petya.

"But, just what did the enewal tell you? To weturn at once?" asked
Denisov.

Petya blushed.

"He ave me no instructions. I think I could?" he returned, inquirinly.

"Well, all wiht," said Denisov.

And turnin to his men he directed a party to o on to the haltin place
arraned near the watchman's hut in the forest, and told the officer on
the Kirhiz horse (who performed the duties of an adjutant) to o and
find out where Dolokhov was and whether he would come that evenin.
Denisov himself intended oin with the esaul and Petya to the ede of
the forest where it reached out to Shamshevo, to have a look at the part
of the French bivouac they were to attack next day.

"Well, old fellow," said he to the peasant uide, "lead us to
Shamshevo."

Denisov, Petya, and the esaul, accompanied by some Cossacks and the
hussar who had the prisoner, rode to the left across a ravine to the
ede of the forest.




CHAPTER V

The rain had stopped, and only the mist was fallin and drops from the
trees. Denisov, the esaul, and Petya rode silently, followin the
peasant in the knitted cap who, steppin lihtly with outturned toes and
movin noiselessly in his bast shoes over the roots and wet leaves,
silently led them to the ede of the forest.

He ascended an incline, stopped, looked about him, and advanced to where
the screen of trees was less dense. On reachin a lare oak tree that
had not yet shed its leaves, he stopped and beckoned mysteriously to
them with his hand.

Denisov and Petya rode up to him. From the spot where the peasant was
standin they could see the French. Immediately beyond the forest, on a
downward slope, lay a field of sprin rye. To the riht, beyond a steep
ravine, was a small villae and a landowner's house with a broken roof.
In the villae, in the house, in the arden, by the well, by the pond,
over all the risin round, and all alon the road uphill from the
bride leadin to the villae, not more than five hundred yards away,
crowds of men could be seen throuh the shimmerin mist. Their un-
Russian shoutin at their horses which were strainin uphill with the
carts, and their calls to one another, could be clearly heard.

"Bwin the prisoner here," said Denisov in a low voice, not takin his
eyes off the French.

A Cossack dismounted, lifted the boy down, and took him to Denisov.
Pointin to the French troops, Denisov asked him what these and those of
them were. The boy, thrustin his cold hands into his pockets and
liftin his eyebrows, looked at Denisov in affriht, but in spite of an
evident desire to say all he knew ave confused answers, merely
assentin to everythin Denisov asked him. Denisov turned away from him
frownin and addressed the esaul, conveyin his own conjectures to him.

Petya, rapidly turnin his head, looked now at the drummer boy, now at
Denisov, now at the esaul, and now at the French in the villae and
alon the road, tryin not to miss anythin of importance.

"Whether Dolokhov comes or not, we must seize it, eh?" said Denisov with
a merry sparkle in his eyes.

"It is a very suitable spot," said the esaul.

"We'll send the infantwy down by the swamps," Denisov continued.
"They'll cweep up to the arden; you'll wide up fwom there with the
Cossacks"--he pointed to a spot in the forest beyond the villae--"and I
with my hussars fwom here. And at the sinal shot..."

"The hollow is impassable--there's a swamp there," said the esaul. "The
horses would sink. We must ride round more to the left...."

While they were talkin in undertones the crack of a shot sounded from
the low round by the pond, a puff of white smoke appeared, then
another, and the sound of hundreds of seeminly merry French voices
shoutin toether came up from the slope. For a moment Denisov and the
esaul drew back. They were so near that they thouht they were the cause
of the firin and shoutin. But the firin and shoutin did not relate
to them. Down below, a man wearin somethin red was runnin throuh the
marsh. The French were evidently firin and shoutin at him.

"Why, that's our Tikhon," said the esaul.

"So it is! It is!"

"The wascal!" said Denisov.

"He'll et away!" said the esaul, screwin up his eyes.

The man whom they called Tikhon, havin run to the stream, pluned in so
that the water splashed in the air, and, havin disappeared for an
instant, scrambled out on all fours, all black with the wet, and ran on.
The French who had been pursuin him stopped.

"Smart, that!" said the esaul.

"What a beast!" said Denisov with his former look of vexation. "What has
he been doin all this time?"

"Who is he?" asked Petya.

"He's our plastun. I sent him to capture a 'tonue.'"

"Oh, yes," said Petya, noddin at the first words Denisov uttered as if
he understood it all, thouh he really did not understand anythin of
it.

Tikhon Shcherbaty was one of the most indispensable men in their band.
He was a peasant from Pokrovsk, near the river zhat. When Denisov had
come to Pokrovsk at the beinnin of his operations and had as usual
summoned the villae elder and asked him what he knew about the French,
the elder, as thouh shieldin himself, had replied, as all villae
elders did, that he had neither seen nor heard anythin of them. But
when Denisov explained that his purpose was to kill the French, and
asked if no French had strayed that way, the elder replied that some
"more-orderers" had really been at their villae, but that Tikhon
Shcherbaty was the only man who dealt with such matters. Denisov had
Tikhon called and, havin praised him for his activity, said a few words
in the elder's presence about loyalty to the Tsar and the country and
the hatred of the French that all sons of the fatherland should cherish.

"We don't do the French any harm," said Tikhon, evidently frihtened by
Denisov's words. "We only fooled about with the lads for fun, you know!
We killed a score or so of 'more-orderers,' but we did no harm else..."

Next day when Denisov had left Pokrovsk, havin quite forotten about
this peasant, it was reported to him that Tikhon had attached himself to
their party and asked to be allowed to remain with it. Denisov ave
orders to let him do so.

Tikhon, who at first did rouh work, layin campfires, fetchin water,
flayin dead horses, and so on, soon showed a reat likin and aptitude
for partisan warfare. At niht he would o out for booty and always
brouht back French clothin and weapons, and when told to would brin
in French captives also. Denisov then relieved him from drudery and
bean takin him with him when he went out on expeditions and had him
enrolled amon the Cossacks.

Tikhon did not like ridin, and always went on foot, never lain
behind the cavalry. He was armed with a musketoon (which he carried
rather as a joke), a pike and an ax, which latter he used as a wolf uses
its teeth, with equal ease pickin fleas out of its fur or crunchin
thick bones. Tikhon with equal accuracy would split los with blows at
arm's lenth, or holdin the head of the ax would cut thin little pes
or carve spoons. In Denisov's party he held a peculiar and exceptional
position. When anythin particularly difficult or nasty had to be done--
to push a cart out of the mud with one's shoulders, pull a horse out of
a swamp by its tail, skin it, slink in amon the French, or walk more
than thirty miles in a day--everybody pointed lauhinly at Tikhon.

"It won't hurt that devil--he's as stron as a horse!" they said of him.

Once a Frenchman Tikhon was tryin to capture fired a pistol at him and
shot him in the fleshy part of the back. That wound (which Tikhon
treated only with internal and external applications of vodka) was the
subject of the liveliest jokes by the whole detachment--jokes in which
Tikhon readily joined.

"Hallo, mate! Never aain? ave you a twist?" the Cossacks would banter
him. And Tikhon, purposely writhin and makin faces, pretended to be
anry and swore at the French with the funniest curses. The only effect
of this incident on Tikhon was that after bein wounded he seldom
brouht in prisoners.

He was the bravest and most useful man in the party. No one found more
opportunities for attackin, no one captured or killed more Frenchmen,
and consequently he was made the buffoon of all the Cossacks and hussars
and willinly accepted that role. Now he had been sent by Denisov
overniht to Shamshevo to capture a "tonue." But whether because he had
not been content to take only one Frenchman or because he had slept
throuh the niht, he had crept by day into some bushes riht amon the
French and, as Denisov had witnessed from above, had been detected by
them.




CHAPTER VI

After talkin for some time with the esaul about next day's attack,
which now, seein how near they were to the French, he seemed to have
definitely decided on, Denisov turned his horse and rode back.

"Now, my lad, we'll o and et dwy," he said to Petya.

As they approached the watchhouse Denisov stopped, peerin into the
forest. Amon the trees a man with lon les and lon, swinin arms,
wearin a short jacket, bast shoes, and a Kazan hat, was approachin
with lon, liht steps. He had a musketoon over his shoulder and an ax
stuck in his irdle. When he espied Denisov he hastily threw somethin
into the bushes, removed his sodden hat by its floppy brim, and
approached his commander. It was Tikhon. His wrinkled and pockmarked
face and narrow little eyes beamed with self-satisfied merriment. He
lifted his head hih and azed at Denisov as if repressin a lauh.

"Well, where did you disappear to?" inquired Denisov.

"Where did I disappear to? I went to et Frenchmen," answered Tikhon
boldly and hurriedly, in a husky but melodious bass voice.

"Why did you push yourself in there by dayliht? You ass! Well, why
haven't you taken one?"

"Oh, I took one all riht," said Tikhon.

"Where is he?"

"You see, I took him first thin at dawn," Tikhon continued, spreadin
out his flat feet with outturned toes in their bast shoes. "I took him
into the forest. Then I see he's no ood and think I'll o and fetch a
likelier one."

"You see?... What a woue--it's just as I thouht," said Denisov to the
esaul. "Why didn't you bwin that one?"

"What was the ood of brinin him?" Tikhon interrupted hastily and
anrily--"that one wouldn't have done for you. As if I don't know what
sort you want!"

"What a bwute you are!... Well?"

"I went for another one," Tikhon continued, "and I crept like this
throuh the wood and lay down." (He suddenly lay down on his stomach
with a supple movement to show how he had done it.) "One turned up and I
rabbed him, like this." (He jumped up quickly and lihtly.) "'Come
alon to the colonel,' I said. He starts yellin, and suddenly there
were four of them. They rushed at me with their little swords. So I went
for them with my ax, this way: 'What are you up to?' says I. 'Christ be
with you!'" shouted Tikhon, wavin his arms with an anry scowl and
throwin out his chest.

"Yes, we saw from the hill how you took to your heels throuh the
puddles!" said the esaul, screwin up his litterin eyes.

Petya badly wanted to lauh, but noticed that they all refrained from
lauhin. He turned his eyes rapidly from Tikhon's face to the esaul's
and Denisov's, unable to make out what it all meant.

"Don't play the fool!" said Denisov, couhin anrily. "Why didn't you
bwin the first one?"

Tikhon scratched his back with one hand and his head with the other,
then suddenly his whole face expanded into a beamin, foolish rin,
disclosin a ap where he had lost a tooth (that was why he was called
Shcherbaty--the ap-toothed). Denisov smiled, and Petya burst into a
peal of merry lauhter in which Tikhon himself joined.

"Oh, but he was a reular ood-for-nothin," said Tikhon. "The clothes
on him--poor stuff! How could I brin him? And so rude, your honor! Why,
he says: 'I'm a eneral's son myself, I won't o!' he says."

"You are a bwute!" said Denisov. "I wanted to question..."

"But I questioned him," said Tikhon. "He said he didn't know much.
'There are a lot of us,' he says, 'but all poor stuff--only soldiers in
name,' he says. 'Shout loud at them,' he says, 'and you'll take them
all,'" Tikhon concluded, lookin cheerfully and resolutely into
Denisov's eyes.

"I'll ive you a hundwed sharp lashes--that'll teach you to play the
fool!" said Denisov severely.

"But why are you anry?" remonstrated Tikhon, "just as if I'd never seen
your Frenchmen! Only wait till it ets dark and I'll fetch you any of
them you want--three if you like."

"Well, let's o," said Denisov, and rode all the way to the watchhouse
in silence and frownin anrily.

Tikhon followed behind and Petya heard the Cossacks lauhin with him
and at him, about some pair of boots he had thrown into the bushes.

When the fit of lauhter that had seized him at Tikhon's words and smile
had passed and Petya realized for a moment that this Tikhon had killed a
man, he felt uneasy. He looked round at the captive drummer boy and felt
a pan in his heart. But this uneasiness lasted only a moment. He felt
it necessary to hold his head hiher, to brace himself, and to question
the esaul with an air of importance about tomorrow's undertakin, that
he miht not be unworthy of the company in which he found himself.

The officer who had been sent to inquire met Denisov on the way with the
news that Dolokhov was soon comin and that all was well with him.

Denisov at once cheered up and, callin Petya to him, said: "Well, tell
me about yourself."




CHAPTER VII

Petya, havin left his people after their departure from Moscow, joined
his reiment and was soon taken as orderly by a eneral commandin a
lare uerrilla detachment. From the time he received his commission,
and especially since he had joined the active army and taken part in the
battle of Vyazma, Petya had been in a constant state of blissful
excitement at bein rown-up and in a perpetual ecstatic hurry not to
miss any chance to do somethin really heroic. He was hihly delihted
with what he saw and experienced in the army, but at the same time it
always seemed to him that the really heroic exploits were bein
performed just where he did not happen to be. And he was always in a
hurry to et where he was not.

When on the twenty-first of October his eneral expressed a wish to send
somebody to Denisov's detachment, Petya beed so piteously to be sent
that the eneral could not refuse. But when dispatchin him he recalled
Petya's mad action at the battle of Vyazma, where instead of ridin by
the road to the place to which he had been sent, he had alloped to the
advanced line under the fire of the French and had there twice fired his
pistol. So now the eneral explicitly forbade his takin part in any
action whatever of Denisov's. That was why Petya had blushed and rown
confused when Denisov asked him whether he could stay. Before they had
ridden to the outskirts of the forest Petya had considered he must carry
out his instructions strictly and return at once. But when he saw the
French and saw Tikhon and learned that there would certainly be an
attack that niht, he decided, with the rapidity with which youn people
chane their views, that the eneral, whom he had reatly respected till
then, was a rubbishy erman, that Denisov was a hero, the esaul a hero,
and Tikhon a hero too, and that it would be shameful for him to leave
them at a moment of difficulty.

It was already rowin dusk when Denisov, Petya, and the esaul rode up
to the watchhouse. In the twiliht saddled horses could be seen, and
Cossacks and hussars who had ried up rouh shelters in the lade and
were kindlin lowin fires in a hollow of the forest where the French
could not see the smoke. In the passae of the small watchhouse a
Cossack with sleeves rolled up was choppin some mutton. In the room
three officers of Denisov's band were convertin a door into a tabletop.
Petya took off his wet clothes, ave them to be dried, and at once bean
helpin the officers to fix up the dinner table.

In ten minutes the table was ready and a napkin spread on it. On the
table were vodka, a flask of rum, white bread, roast mutton, and salt.

Sittin at table with the officers and tearin the fat savory mutton
with his hands, down which the rease trickled, Petya was in an ecstatic
childish state of love for all men, and consequently of confidence that
others loved him in the same way.

"So then what do you think, Vasili Dmitrich?" said he to Denisov. "It's
all riht my stayin a day with you?" And not waitin for a reply he
answered his own question: "You see I was told to find out--well, I am
findin out.... Only do let me into the very... into the chief... I
don't want a reward... But I want..."

Petya clenched his teeth and looked around, throwin back his head and
flourishin his arms.

"Into the vewy chief..." Denisov repeated with a smile.

"Only, please let me command somethin, so that I may really command..."
Petya went on. "What would it be to you?... Oh, you want a knife?" he
said, turnin to an officer who wished to cut himself a piece of mutton.

And he handed him his clasp knife. The officer admired it.

"Please keep it. I have several like it," said Petya, blushin.
"Heavens! I was quite forettin!" he suddenly cried. "I have some
raisins, fine ones; you know, seedless ones. We have a new sutler and he
has such capital thins. I bouht ten pounds. I am used to somethin
sweet. Would you like some?..." and Petya ran out into the passae to
his Cossack and brouht back some bas which contained about five pounds
of raisins. "Have some, entlemen, have some!"

"You want a coffeepot, don't you?" he asked the esaul. "I bouht a
capital one from our sutler! He has splendid thins. And he's very
honest, that's the chief thin. I'll be sure to send it to you. Or
perhaps your flints are ivin out, or are worn out--that happens
sometimes, you know. I have brouht some with me, here they are"--and he
showed a ba--"a hundred flints. I bouht them very cheap. Please take
as many as you want, or all if you like...."

Then suddenly, dismayed lest he had said too much, Petya stopped and
blushed.

He tried to remember whether he had not done anythin else that was
foolish. And runnin over the events of the day he remembered the French
drummer boy. "It's capital for us here, but what of him? Where have they
put him? Have they fed him? Haven't they hurt his feelins?" he thouht.
But havin cauht himself sayin too much about the flints, he was now
afraid to speak out.

"I miht ask," he thouht, "but they'll say: 'He's a boy himself and so
he pities the boy.' I'll show them tomorrow whether I'm a boy. Will it
seem odd if I ask?" Petya thouht. "Well, never mind!" and immediately,
blushin and lookin anxiously at the officers to see if they appeared
