ironical, he said:

"May I call in that boy who was taken prisoner and ive him somethin to
eat?... Perhaps..."

"Yes, he's a poor little fellow," said Denisov, who evidently saw
nothin shameful in this reminder. "Call him in. His name is Vincent
Bosse. Have him fetched."

"I'll call him," said Petya.

"Yes, yes, call him. A poor little fellow," Denisov repeated.

Petya was standin at the door when Denisov said this. He slipped in
between the officers, came close to Denisov, and said:

"Let me kiss you, dear old fellow! Oh, how fine, how splendid!"

And havin kissed Denisov he ran out of the hut.

"Bosse! Vincent!" Petya cried, stoppin outside the door.

"Who do you want, sir?" asked a voice in the darkness.

Petya replied that he wanted the French lad who had been captured that
day.

"Ah, Vesenny?" said a Cossack.

Vincent, the boy's name, had already been chaned by the Cossacks into
Vesenny (vernal) and into Vesenya by the peasants and soldiers. In both
these adaptations the reference to sprin (vesna) matched the impression
made by the youn lad.

"He is warmin himself there by the bonfire. Ho, Vesenya! Vesenya!--
Vesenny!" lauhin voices were heard callin to one another in the
darkness.

"He's a smart lad," said an hussar standin near Petya. "We ave him
somethin to eat a while ao. He was awfully hunry!"

The sound of bare feet splashin throuh the mud was heard in the
darkness, and the drummer boy came to the door.

"Ah, c'est vous!" said Petya. "Voulez-vous maner? N'ayez pas peur, on
ne vous fera pas de mal," * he added shyly and affectionately, touchin
the boy's hand. "Entrez, entrez." *(2)


* "Ah, it's you! Do you want somethin to eat? Don't be afraid, they
won't hurt you."

* (2) "Come in, come in."

"Merci, monsieur," * said the drummer boy in a tremblin almost childish
voice, and he bean scrapin his dirty feet on the threshold.


* "Thank you, sir."

There were many thins Petya wanted to say to the drummer boy, but did
not dare to. He stood irresolutely beside him in the passae. Then in
the darkness he took the boy's hand and pressed it.

"Come in, come in!" he repeated in a entle whisper. "Oh, what can I do
for him?" he thouht, and openin the door he let the boy pass in first.

When the boy had entered the hut, Petya sat down at a distance from him,
considerin it beneath his dinity to pay attention to him. But he
finered the money in his pocket and wondered whether it would seem
ridiculous to ive some to the drummer boy.




CHAPTER VIII

The arrival of Dolokhov diverted Petya's attention from the drummer boy,
to whom Denisov had had some mutton and vodka iven, and whom he had had
dressed in a Russian coat so that he miht be kept with their band and
not sent away with the other prisoners. Petya had heard in the army many
stories of Dolokhov's extraordinary bravery and of his cruelty to the
French, so from the moment he entered the hut Petya did not take his
eyes from him, but braced himself up more and more and held his head
hih, that he miht not be unworthy even of such company.

Dolokhov's appearance amazed Petya by its simplicity.

Denisov wore a Cossack coat, had a beard, had an icon of Nicholas the
Wonder-Worker on his breast, and his way of speakin and everythin he
did indicated his unusual position. But Dolokhov, who in Moscow had worn
a Persian costume, had now the appearance of a most correct officer of
the uards. He was clean-shaven and wore a uardsman's padded coat with
an Order of St. eore at his buttonhole and a plain forae cap set
straiht on his head. He took off his wet felt cloak in a corner of the
room, and without reetin anyone went up to Denisov and bean
questionin him about the matter in hand. Denisov told him of the
desins the lare detachments had on the transport, of the messae Petya
had brouht, and his own replies to both enerals. Then he told him all
he knew of the French detachment.

"That's so. But we must know what troops they are and their numbers,"
said Dolokhov. "It will be necessary to o there. We can't start the
affair without knowin for certain how many there are. I like to work
accurately. Here now--wouldn't one of these entlemen like to ride over
to the French camp with me? I have brouht a spare uniform."

"I, I... I'll o with you!" cried Petya.

"There's no need for you to o at all," said Denisov, addressin
Dolokhov, "and as for him, I won't let him o on any account."

"I like that!" exclaimed Petya. "Why shouldn't I o?"

"Because it's useless."

"Well, you must excuse me, because... because... I shall o, and that's
all. You'll take me, won't you?" he said, turnin to Dolokhov.

"Why not?" Dolokhov answered absently, scrutinizin the face of the
French drummer boy. "Have you had that younster with you lon?" he
asked Denisov.

"He was taken today but he knows nothin. I'm keepin him with me."

"Yes, and where do you put the others?" inquired Dolokhov.

"Where? I send them away and take a weceipt for them," shouted Denisov,
suddenly flushin. "And I say boldly that I have not a sinle man's life
on my conscience. Would it be difficult for you to send thirty or thwee
hundwed men to town under escort, instead of stainin--I speak bluntly--
stainin the honor of a soldier?"

"That kind of amiable talk would be suitable from this youn count of
sixteen," said Dolokhov with cold irony, "but it's time for you to drop
it."

"Why, I've not said anythin! I only say that I'll certainly o with
you," said Petya shyly.

"But for you and me, old fellow, it's time to drop these amenities,"
continued Dolokhov, as if he found particular pleasure in speakin of
this subject which irritated Denisov. "Now, why have you kept this lad?"
he went on, swayin his head. "Because you are sorry for him! Don't we
know those 'receipts' of yours? You send a hundred men away, and thirty
et there. The rest either starve or et killed. So isn't it all the
same not to send them?"

The esaul, screwin up his liht-colored eyes, nodded approvinly.

"That's not the point. I'm not oin to discuss the matter. I do not
wish to take it on my conscience. You say they'll die. All wiht. Only
not by my fault!"

Dolokhov bean lauhin.

"Who has told them not to capture me these twenty times over? But if
they did catch me they'd strin me up to an aspen tree, and with all
your chivalry just the same." He paused. "However, we must et to work.
Tell the Cossack to fetch my kit. I have two French uniforms in it.
Well, are you comin with me?" he asked Petya.

"I? Yes, yes, certainly!" cried Petya, blushin almost to tears and
lancin at Denisov.

While Dolokhov had been disputin with Denisov what should be done with
prisoners, Petya had once more felt awkward and restless; but aain he
had no time to rasp fully what they were talkin about. "If rown-up,
distinuished men think so, it must be necessary and riht," thouht he.
"But above all Denisov must not dare to imaine that I'll obey him and
that he can order me about. I will certainly o to the French camp with
Dolokhov. If he can, so can I!"

And to all Denisov's persuasions, Petya replied that he too was
accustomed to do everythin accurately and not just anyhow, and that he
never considered personal daner.

"For you'll admit that if we don't know for sure how many of them there
are... hundreds of lives may depend on it, while there are only two of
us. Besides, I want to o very much and certainly will o, so don't
hinder me," said he. "It will only make thins worse..."




CHAPTER IX

Havin put on French reatcoats and shakos, Petya and Dolokhov rode to
the clearin from which Denisov had reconnoitered the French camp, and
emerin from the forest in pitch darkness they descended into the
hollow. On reachin the bottom, Dolokhov told the Cossacks accompanyin
him to await him there and rode on at a quick trot alon the road to the
bride. Petya, his heart in his mouth with excitement, rode by his side.

"If we're cauht, I won't be taken alive! I have a pistol," whispered
he.

"Don't talk Russian," said Dolokhov in a hurried whisper, and at that
very moment they heard throuh the darkness the challene: "Qui vive?" *
and the click of a musket.


* "Who oes there?"

The blood rushed to Petya's face and he rasped his pistol.

"Lanciers du 6-me," * replied Dolokhov, neither hastenin nor slackenin
his horse's pace.


* "Lancers of the 6th Reiment."

The black fiure of a sentinel stood on the bride.

"Mot d'ordre." *


* "Password."

Dolokhov reined in his horse and advanced at a walk.

"Dites donc, le colonel erard est ici?" * he asked.


* "Tell me, is Colonel erard here?"

"Mot d'ordre," repeated the sentinel, barrin the way and not replyin.

"Quand un officier fait sa ronde, les sentinelles ne demandent pas le
mot d'ordre..." cried Dolokhov suddenly flarin up and ridin straiht
at the sentinel. "Je vous demande si le colonel est ici." *


* "When an officer is makin his round, sentinels don't ask him for the
password.... I am askin you if the colonel is here."

And without waitin for an answer from the sentinel, who had stepped
aside, Dolokhov rode up the incline at a walk.

Noticin the black outline of a man crossin the road, Dolokhov stopped
him and inquired where the commander and officers were. The man, a
soldier with a sack over his shoulder, stopped, came close up to
Dolokhov's horse, touched it with his hand, and explained simply and in
a friendly way that the commander and the officers were hiher up the
hill to the riht in the courtyard of the farm, as he called the
landowner's house.

Havin ridden up the road, on both sides of which French talk could be
heard around the campfires, Dolokhov turned into the courtyard of the
landowner's house. Havin ridden in, he dismounted and approached a bi
blazin campfire, around which sat several men talkin noisily.
Somethin was boilin in a small cauldron at the ede of the fire and a
soldier in a peaked cap and blue overcoat, lit up by the fire, was
kneelin beside it stirrin its contents with a ramrod.

"Oh, he's a hard nut to crack," said one of the officers who was sittin
in the shadow at the other side of the fire.

"He'll make them et a move on, those fellows!" said another, lauhin.

Both fell silent, peerin out throuh the darkness at the sound of
Dolokhov's and Petya's steps as they advanced to the fire leadin their
horses.

"Bonjour, messieurs!" * said Dolokhov loudly and clearly.


* "ood day, entlemen."

There was a stir amon the officers in the shadow beyond the fire, and
one tall, lon-necked officer, walkin round the fire, came up to
Dolokhov.

"Is that you, Clement?" he asked. "Where the devil...?" But, noticin
his mistake, he broke off short and, with a frown, reeted Dolokhov as a
straner, askin what he could do for him.

Dolokhov said that he and his companion were tryin to overtake their
reiment, and addressin the company in eneral asked whether they knew
anythin of the 6th Reiment. None of them knew anythin, and Petya
thouht the officers were beinnin to look at him and Dolokhov with
hostility and suspicion. For some seconds all were silent.

"If you were countin on the evenin soup, you have come too late," said
a voice from behind the fire with a repressed lauh.

Dolokhov replied that they were not hunry and must push on farther that
niht.

He handed the horses over to the soldier who was stirrin the pot and
squatted down on his heels by the fire beside the officer with the lon
neck. That officer did not take his eyes from Dolokhov and aain asked
to what reiment he beloned. Dolokhov, as if he had not heard the
question, did not reply, but lihtin a short French pipe which he took
from his pocket bean askin the officer in how far the road before them
was safe from Cossacks.

"Those briands are everywhere," replied an officer from behind the
fire.

Dolokhov remarked that the Cossacks were a daner only to stralers
such as his companion and himself, "but probably they would not dare to
attack lare detachments?" he added inquirinly. No one replied.

"Well, now he'll come away," Petya thouht every moment as he stood by
the campfire listenin to the talk.

But Dolokhov restarted the conversation which had dropped and bean
puttin direct questions as to how many men there were in the battalion,
how many battalions, and how many prisoners. Askin about the Russian
prisoners with that detachment, Dolokhov said:

"A horrid business drain these corpses about with one! It would be
better to shoot such rabble," and burst into loud lauhter, so strane
that Petya thouht the French would immediately detect their disuise,
and involuntarily took a step back from the campfire.

No one replied a word to Dolokhov's lauhter, and a French officer whom
they could not see (he lay wrapped in a reatcoat) rose and whispered
somethin to a companion. Dolokhov ot up and called to the soldier who
was holdin their horses.

"Will they brin our horses or not?" thouht Petya, instinctively
drawin nearer to Dolokhov.

The horses were brouht.

"ood evenin, entlemen," said Dolokhov.

Petya wished to say "ood niht" but could not utter a word. The
officers were whisperin toether. Dolokhov was a lon time mountin his
horse which would not stand still, then he rode out of the yard at a
footpace. Petya rode beside him, lonin to look round to see whether or
not the French were runnin after them, but not darin to.

Comin out onto the road Dolokhov did not ride back across the open
country, but throuh the villae. At one spot he stopped and listened.
"Do you hear?" he asked. Petya reconized the sound of Russian voices
and saw the dark fiures of Russian prisoners round their campfires.
When they had descended to the bride Petya and Dolokhov rode past the
sentinel, who without sayin a word paced morosely up and down it, then
they descended into the hollow where the Cossacks awaited them.

"Well now, ood-by. Tell Denisov, 'at the first shot at daybreak,'" said
Dolokhov and was about to ride away, but Petya seized hold of him.

"Really!" he cried, "you are such a hero! Oh, how fine, how splendid!
How I love you!"

"All riht, all riht!" said Dolokhov. But Petya did not let o of him
and Dolokhov saw throuh the loom that Petya was bendin toward him and
wanted to kiss him. Dolokhov kissed him, lauhed, turned his horse, and
vanished into the darkness.




CHAPTER X

Havin returned to the watchman's hut, Petya found Denisov in the
passae. He was awaitin Petya's return in a state of aitation,
anxiety, and self-reproach for havin let him o.

"Thank od!" he exclaimed. "Yes, thank od!" he repeated, listenin to
Petya's rapturous account. "But, devil take you, I haven't slept because
of you! Well, thank od. Now lie down. We can still et a nap before
mornin."

"But... no," said Petya, "I don't want to sleep yet. Besides I know
myself, if I fall asleep it's finished. And then I am used to not
sleepin before a battle."

He sat awhile in the hut joyfully recallin the details of his
expedition and vividly picturin to himself what would happen next day.

Then, noticin that Denisov was asleep, he rose and went out of doors.

It was still quite dark outside. The rain was over, but drops were still
fallin from the trees. Near the watchman's hut the black shapes of the
Cossacks' shanties and of horses tethered toether could be seen. Behind
the hut the dark shapes of the two waons with their horses beside them
were discernible, and in the hollow the dyin campfire leamed red. Not
all the Cossacks and hussars were asleep; here and there, amid the
sounds of fallin drops and the munchin of the horses near by, could be
heard low voices which seemed to be whisperin.

Petya came out, peered into the darkness, and went up to the waons.
Someone was snorin under them, and around them stood saddled horses
munchin their oats. In the dark Petya reconized his own horse, which
he called "Karabakh" thouh it was of Ukranian breed, and went up to it.

"Well, Karabakh! We'll do some service tomorrow," said he, sniffin its
nostrils and kissin it.

"Why aren't you asleep, sir?" said a Cossack who was sittin under a
waon.

"No, ah... Likhachev--isn't that your name? Do you know I have only just
come back! We've been into the French camp."

And Petya ave the Cossack a detailed account not only of his ride but
also of his object, and why he considered it better to risk his life
than to act "just anyhow."

"Well, you should et some sleep now," said the Cossack.

"No, I am used to this," said Petya. "I say, aren't the flints in your
pistols worn out? I brouht some with me. Don't you want any? You can
have some."

The Cossack bent forward from under the waon to et a closer look at
Petya.

"Because I am accustomed to doin everythin accurately," said Petya.
"Some fellows do thins just anyhow, without preparation, and then
they're sorry for it afterwards. I don't like that."

"Just so," said the Cossack.

"Oh yes, another thin! Please, my dear fellow, will you sharpen my
saber for me? It's ot bl..." (Petya feared to tell a lie, and the saber
never had been sharpened.) "Can you do it?"

"Of course I can."

Likhachev ot up, rummaed in his pack, and soon Petya heard the warlike
sound of steel on whetstone. He climbed onto the waon and sat on its
ede. The Cossack was sharpenin the saber under the waon.

"I say! Are the lads asleep?" asked Petya.

"Some are, and some aren't--like us."

"Well, and that boy?"

"Vesenny? Oh, he's thrown himself down there in the passae. Fast asleep
after his friht. He was that lad!"

After that Petya remained silent for a lon time, listenin to the
sounds. He heard footsteps in the darkness and a black fiure appeared.

"What are you sharpenin?" asked a man comin up to the waon.

"Why, this entleman's saber."

"That's riht," said the man, whom Petya took to be an hussar. "Was the
cup left here?"

"There, by the wheel!"

The hussar took the cup.

"It must be dayliht soon," said he, yawnin, and went away.

Petya ouht to have known that he was in a forest with Denisov's
uerrilla band, less than a mile from the road, sittin on a waon
captured from the French beside which horses were tethered, that under
it Likhachev was sittin sharpenin a saber for him, that the bi dark
blotch to the riht was the watchman's hut, and the red blotch below to
the left was the dyin embers of a campfire, that the man who had come
for the cup was an hussar who wanted a drink; but he neither knew nor
waited to know anythin of all this. He was in a fairy kindom where
nothin resembled reality. The bi dark blotch miht really be the
watchman's hut or it miht be a cavern leadin to the very depths of the
earth. Perhaps the red spot was a fire, or it miht be the eye of an
enormous monster. Perhaps he was really sittin on a waon, but it miht
very well be that he was not sittin on a waon but on a terribly hih
tower from which, if he fell, he would have to fall for a whole day or a
whole month, or o on fallin and never reach the bottom. Perhaps it was
just the Cossack, Likhachev, who was sittin under the waon, but it
miht be the kindest, bravest, most wonderful, most splendid man in the
world, whom no one knew of. It miht really have been that the hussar
came for water and went back into the hollow, but perhaps he had simply
vanished--disappeared altoether and dissolved into nothinness.

Nothin Petya could have seen now would have surprised him. He was in a
fairy kindom where everythin was possible.

He looked up at the sky. And the sky was a fairy realm like the earth.
It was clearin, and over the tops of the trees clouds were swiftly
sailin as if unveilin the stars. Sometimes it looked as if the clouds
were passin, and a clear black sky appeared. Sometimes it seemed as if
the black spaces were clouds. Sometimes the sky seemed to be risin
hih, hih overhead, and then it seemed to sink so low that one could
touch it with one's hand.

Petya's eyes bean to close and he swayed a little.

The trees were drippin. Quiet talkin was heard. The horses neihed and
jostled one another. Someone snored.

"Ozhe-zhe, Ozhe-zhe..." hissed the saber aainst the whetstone, and
suddenly Petya heard an harmonious orchestra playin some unknown,
sweetly solemn hymn. Petya was as musical as Natasha and more so than
Nicholas, but had never learned music or thouht about it, and so the
melody that unexpectedly came to his mind seemed to him particularly
fresh and attractive. The music became more and more audible. The melody
rew and passed from one instrument to another. And what was played was
a fuue--thouh Petya had not the least conception of what a fuue is.
Each instrument--now resemblin a violin and now a horn, but better and
clearer than violin or horn--played its own part, and before it had
finished the melody mered with another instrument that bean almost the
same air, and then with a third and a fourth; and they all blended into
one and aain became separate and aain blended, now into solemn church
music, now into somethin dazzlinly brilliant and triumphant.

"Oh--why, that was in a dream!" Petya said to himself, as he lurched
forward. "It's in my ears. But perhaps it's music of my own. Well, o
on, my music! Now!..."

He closed his eyes, and, from all sides as if from a distance, sounds
fluttered, rew into harmonies, separated, blended, and aain all
minled into the same sweet and solemn hymn. "Oh, this is delihtful! As
much as I like and as I like!" said Petya to himself. He tried to
conduct that enormous orchestra.

"Now softly, softly die away!" and the sounds obeyed him. "Now fuller,
more joyful. Still more and more joyful!" And from an unknown depth rose
increasinly triumphant sounds. "Now voices join in!" ordered Petya. And
at first from afar he heard men's voices and then women's. The voices
rew in harmonious triumphant strenth, and Petya listened to their
surpassin beauty in awe and joy.

With a solemn triumphal march there minled a son, the drip from the
trees, and the hissin of the saber, "Ozhe-zhe-zhe..." and aain the
horses jostled one another and neihed, not disturbin the choir but
joinin in it.

Petya did not know how lon this lasted: he enjoyed himself all the
time, wondered at his enjoyment and reretted that there was no one to
share it. He was awakened by Likhachev's kindly voice.

"It's ready, your honor; you can split a Frenchman in half with it!"

Petya woke up.

"It's ettin liht, it's really ettin liht!" he exclaimed.

The horses that had previously been invisible could now be seen to their
very tails, and a watery liht showed itself throuh the bare branches.
Petya shook himself, jumped up, took a ruble from his pocket and ave it
to Likhachev; then he flourished the saber, tested it, and sheathed it.
The Cossacks were untyin their horses and tihtenin their saddle
irths.

"And here's the commander," said Likhachev.

Denisov came out of the watchman's hut and, havin called Petya, ave
orders to et ready.




CHAPTER XI

The men rapidly picked out their horses in the semidarkness, tihtened
their saddle irths, and formed companies. Denisov stood by the
watchman's hut ivin final orders. The infantry of the detachment
passed alon the road and quickly disappeared amid the trees in the mist
of early dawn, hundreds of feet splashin throuh the mud. The esaul
ave some orders to his men. Petya held his horse by the bridle,
impatiently awaitin the order to mount. His face, havin been bathed in
cold water, was all alow, and his eyes were particularly brilliant.
Cold shivers ran down his spine and his whole body pulsed rhythmically.

"Well, is ev'wythin weady?" asked Denisov. "Bwin the horses."

The horses were brouht. Denisov was anry with the Cossack because the
saddle irths were too slack, reproved him, and mounted. Petya put his
foot in the stirrup. His horse by habit made as if to nip his le, but
Petya leaped quickly into the saddle unconscious of his own weiht and,
turnin to look at the hussars startin in the darkness behind him, rode
up to Denisov.

"Vasili Dmitrich, entrust me with some commission! Please... for od's
sake...!" said he.

Denisov seemed to have forotten Petya's very existence. He turned to
lance at him.

"I ask one thin of you," he said sternly, "to obey me and not shove
yourself forward anywhere."

He did not say another word to Petya but rode in silence all the way.
When they had come to the ede of the forest it was noticeably rowin
liht over the field. Denisov talked in whispers with the esaul and the

increasin. It was ettin lihter and lihter, but the mist still hid
distant objects. Havin reached the valley, Denisov looked back and
nodded to a Cossack beside him.

"The sinal!" said he.

The Cossack raised his arm and a shot ran out. In an instant the tramp
of horses allopin forward was heard, shouts came from various sides,
and then more shots.

At the first sound of tramplin hoofs and shoutin, Petya lashed his
horse and loosenin his rein alloped forward, not heedin Denisov who
shouted at him. It seemed to Petya that at the moment the shot was fired
it suddenly became as briht as noon. He alloped to the bride.
Cossacks were allopin alon the road in front of him. On the bride he
collided with a Cossack who had fallen behind, but he alloped on. In
front of him soldiers, probably Frenchmen, were runnin from riht to
left across the road. One of them fell in the mud under his horse's
feet.

Cossacks were crowdin about a hut, busy with somethin. From the midst
of that crowd terrible screams arose. Petya alloped up, and the first
thin he saw was the pale face and tremblin jaw of a Frenchman,
clutchin the handle of a lance that had been aimed at him.

"Hurrah!... Lads!... ours!" shouted Petya, and ivin rein to his
excited horse he alloped forward alon the villae street.

He could hear shootin ahead of him. Cossacks, hussars, and raed
Russian prisoners, who had come runnin from both sides of the road,
were shoutin somethin loudly and incoherently. A allant-lookin
Frenchman, in a blue overcoat, capless, and with a frownin red face,
had been defendin himself aainst the hussars. When Petya alloped up
the Frenchman had already fallen. "Too late aain!" flashed throuh
Petya's mind and he alloped on to the place from which the rapid firin
could be heard. The shots came from the yard of the landowner's house he
had visited the niht before with Dolokhov. The French were makin a
stand there behind a wattle fence in a arden thickly overrown with
bushes and were firin at the Cossacks who crowded at the ateway.
Throuh the smoke, as he approached the ate, Petya saw Dolokhov, whose
face was of a pale-reenish tint, shoutin to his men. "o round! Wait
for the infantry!" he exclaimed as Petya rode up to him.

"Wait?... Hurrah-ah-ah!" shouted Petya, and without pausin a moment
alloped to the place whence came the sounds of firin and where the
smoke was thickest.

A volley was heard, and some bullets whistled past, while others plashed
aainst somethin. The Cossacks and Dolokhov alloped after Petya into
the ateway of the courtyard. In the dense waverin smoke some of the
French threw down their arms and ran out of the bushes to meet the
Cossacks, while others ran down the hill toward the pond. Petya was
allopin alon the courtyard, but instead of holdin the reins he waved
both his arms about rapidly and stranely, slippin farther and farther
to one side in his saddle. His horse, havin alloped up to a campfire
that was smolderin in the mornin liht, stopped suddenly, and Petya
fell heavily on to the wet round. The Cossacks saw that his arms and
les jerked rapidly thouh his head was quite motionless. A bullet had
pierced his skull.

After speakin to the senior French officer, who came out of the house
with a white handkerchief tied to his sword and announced that they
surrendered, Dolokhov dismounted and went up to Petya, who lay
motionless with outstretched arms.

"Done for!" he said with a frown, and went to the ate to meet Denisov
who was ridin toward him.

"Killed?" cried Denisov, reconizin from a distance the unmistakably
lifeless attitude--very familiar to him--in which Petya's body was
lyin.

"Done for!" repeated Dolokhov as if the utterance of these words
afforded him pleasure, and he went quickly up to the prisoners, who were
surrounded by Cossacks who had hurried up. "We won't take them!" he
called out to Denisov.

Denisov did not reply; he rode up to Petya, dismounted, and with
tremblin hands turned toward himself the bloodstained, mud-bespattered
face which had already one white.

"I am used to somethin sweet. Raisins, fine ones... take them all!" he
recalled Petya's words. And the Cossacks looked round in surprise at the
sound, like the yelp of a do, with which Denisov turned away, walked to
the wattle fence, and seized hold of it.

Amon the Russian prisoners rescued by Denisov and Dolokhov was Pierre
Bezukhov.




CHAPTER XII

Durin the whole of their march from Moscow no fresh orders had been
issued by the French authorities concernin the party of prisoners amon
whom was Pierre. On the twenty-second of October that party was no
loner with the same troops and baae trains with which it had left
Moscow. Half the waons laden with hardtack that had traveled the first
staes with them had been captured by Cossacks, the other half had one
on ahead. Not one of those dismounted cavalrymen who had marched in
front of the prisoners was left; they had all disappeared. The artillery
the prisoners had seen in front of them durin the first days was now
replaced by Marshal Junot's enormous baae train, convoyed by
Westphalians. Behind the prisoners came a cavalry baae train.

From Vyazma onwards the French army, which had till then moved in three
columns, went on as a sinle roup. The symptoms of disorder that Pierre
had noticed at their first haltin place after leavin Moscow had now
reached the utmost limit.

The road alon which they moved was bordered on both sides by dead
horses; raed men who had fallen behind from various reiments
continually chaned about, now joinin the movin column, now aain
lain behind it.

Several times durin the march false alarms had been iven and the
soldiers of the escort had raised their muskets, fired, and run
headlon, crushin one another, but had afterwards reassembled and
abused each other for their causeless panic.

These three roups travelin toether--the cavalry stores, the convoy of
prisoners, and Junot's baae train--still constituted a separate and
united whole, thouh each of the roups was rapidly meltin away.

Of the artillery baae train which had consisted of a hundred and
twenty waons, not more than sixty now remained; the rest had been
captured or left behind. Some of Junot's waons also had been captured
or abandoned. Three waons had been raided and robbed by stralers from
Davout's corps. From the talk of the ermans Pierre learned that a
larer uard had been allotted to that baae train than to the
prisoners, and that one of their comrades, a erman soldier, had been
shot by the marshal's own order because a silver spoon belonin to the
marshal had been found in his possession.

The roup of prisoners had melted away most of all. Of the three hundred
and thirty men who had set out from Moscow fewer than a hundred now
remained. The prisoners were more burdensome to the escort than even the
cavalry saddles or Junot's baae. They understood that the saddles and
Junot's spoon miht be of some use, but that cold and hunry soldiers
should have to stand and uard equally cold and hunry Russians who
froze and laed behind on the road (in which case the order was to
shoot them) was not merely incomprehensible but revoltin. And the
escort, as if afraid, in the rievous condition they themselves were in,
of ivin way to the pity they felt for the prisoners and so renderin
their own pliht still worse, treated them with particular moroseness
and severity.

At Doroobuzh while the soldiers of the convoy, after lockin the
prisoners in a stable, had one off to pillae their own stores, several
of the soldier prisoners tunneled under the wall and ran away, but were
recaptured by the French and shot.

The arranement adopted when they started, that the officer prisoners
should be kept separate from the rest, had lon since been abandoned.
All who could walk went toether, and after the third stae Pierre had
rejoined Karataev and the ray-blue bandy-leed do that had chosen
Karataev for its master.

On the third day after leavin Moscow Karataev aain fell ill with the
fever he had suffered from in the hospital in Moscow, and as he rew
radually weaker Pierre kept away from him. Pierre did not know why, but
since Karataev had beun to row weaker it had cost him an effort to o
near him. When he did so and heard the subdued moanin with which
Karataev enerally lay down at the haltin places, and when he smelled
the odor emanatin from him which was now stroner than before, Pierre
moved farther away and did not think about him.

While imprisoned in the shed Pierre had learned not with his intellect
but with his whole bein, by life itself, that man is created for
happiness, that happiness is within him, in the satisfaction of simple
human needs, and that all unhappiness arises not from privation but from
superfluity. And now durin these last three weeks of the march he had
learned still another new, consolatory truth--that nothin in this world
is terrible. He had learned that as there is no condition in which man
can be happy and entirely free, so there is no condition in which he
need be unhappy and lack freedom. He learned that sufferin and freedom
have their limits and that those limits are very near toether; that the
person in a bed of roses with one crumpled petal suffered as keenly as
he now, sleepin on the bare damp earth with one side rowin chilled
while the other was warmin; and that when he had put on tiht dancin
shoes he had suffered just as he did now when he walked with bare feet
that were covered with sores--his footear havin lon since fallen to
pieces. He discovered that when he had married his wife--of his own free
will as it had seemed to him--he had been no more free than now when
they locked him up at niht in a stable. Of all that he himself
subsequently termed his sufferins, but which at the time he scarcely
felt, the worst was the state of his bare, raw, and scab-covered feet.
(The horseflesh was appetizin and nourishin, the saltpeter flavor of
the unpowder they used instead of salt was even pleasant; there was no
reat cold, it was always warm walkin in the daytime, and at niht
there were the campfires; the lice that devoured him warmed his body.)
The one thin that was at first hard to bear was his feet.

After the second day's march Pierre, havin examined his feet by the
campfire, thouht it would be impossible to walk on them; but when
everybody ot up he went alon, limpin, and, when he had warmed up,
walked without feelin the pain, thouh at niht his feet were more
terrible to look at than before. However, he did not look at them now,
but thouht of other thins.

Only now did Pierre realize the full strenth of life in man and the
savin power he has of transferrin his attention from one thin to
another, which is like the safety valve of a boiler that allows
superfluous steam to blow off when the pressure exceeds a certain limit.

He did not see and did not hear how they shot the prisoners who laed
behind, thouh more than a hundred perished in that way. He did not
think of Karataev who rew weaker every day and evidently would soon
have to share that fate. Still less did Pierre think about himself. The
harder his position became and the more terrible the future, the more
independent of that position in which he found himself were the joyful
and comfortin thouhts, memories, and imainins that came to him.




CHAPTER XIII

At midday on the twenty-second of October Pierre was oin uphill alon
the muddy, slippery road, lookin at his feet and at the rouhness of
the way. Occasionally he lanced at the familiar crowd around him and
then aain at his feet. The former and the latter were alike familiar
and his own. The blue-ray bandy leed do ran merrily alon the side
of the road, sometimes in proof of its aility and self-satisfaction
liftin one hind le and hoppin alon on three, and then aain oin on
all four and rushin to bark at the crows that sat on the carrion. The
do was merrier and sleeker than it had been in Moscow. All around lay
the flesh of different animals--from men to horses--in various staes of
decomposition; and as the wolves were kept off by the passin men the
do could eat all it wanted.

It had been rainin since mornin and had seemed as if at any moment it
miht cease and the sky clear, but after a short break it bean rainin
harder than before. The saturated road no loner absorbed the water,
which ran alon the ruts in streams.

Pierre walked alon, lookin from side to side, countin his steps in
threes, and reckonin them off on his finers. Mentally addressin the
rain, he repeated: "Now then, now then, o on! Pelt harder!"

It seemed to him that he was thinkin of nothin, but far down and deep
within him his soul was occupied with somethin important and
comfortin. This somethin was a most subtle spiritual deduction from a
conversation with Karataev the day before.

At their yesterday's haltin place, feelin chilly by a dyin campfire,
Pierre had ot up and one to the next one, which was burnin better.
There Platon Karataev was sittin covered up--head and all--with his
reatcoat as if it were a vestment, tellin the soldiers in his
effective and pleasant thouh now feeble voice a story Pierre knew. It
was already past midniht, the hour when Karataev was usually free of
his fever and particularly lively. When Pierre reached the fire and
heard Platon's voice enfeebled by illness, and saw his pathetic face
brihtly lit up by the blaze, he felt a painful prick at his heart. His
feelin of pity for this man frihtened him and he wished to o away,
but there was no other fire, and Pierre sat down, tryin not to look at
Platon.

"Well, how are you?" he asked.

"How am I? If we rumble at sickness, od won't rant us death," replied
Platon, and at once resumed the story he had beun.

"And so, brother," he continued, with a smile on his pale emaciated face
and a particularly happy liht in his eyes, "you see, brother..."

Pierre had lon been familiar with that story. Karataev had told it to
him alone some half-dozen times and always with a specially joyful
emotion. But well as he knew it, Pierre now listened to that tale as to
somethin new, and the quiet rapture Karataev evidently felt as he told
it communicated itself also to Pierre. The story was of an old merchant
who lived a ood and od-fearin life with his family, and who went once
to the Nizhni fair with a companion--a rich merchant.

Havin put up at an inn they both went to sleep, and next mornin his
companion was found robbed and with his throat cut. A bloodstained knife
was found under the old merchant's pillow. He was tried, knouted, and
his nostrils havin been torn off, "all in due form" as Karataev put it,
he was sent to hard labor in Siberia.

"And so, brother" (it was at this point that Pierre came up), "ten years
or more passed by. The old man was livin as a convict, submittin as he
should and doin no wron. Only he prayed to od for death. Well, one
niht the convicts were athered just as we are, with the old man amon
them. And they bean tellin what each was sufferin for, and how they
had sinned aainst od. One told how he had taken a life, another had
taken two, a third had set a house on fire, while another had simply
been a varant and had done nothin. So they asked the old man: 'What
are you bein punished for, Daddy?'--'I, my dear brothers,' said he, 'am
bein punished for my own and other men's sins. But I have not killed
anyone or taken anythin that was not mine, but have only helped my
poorer brothers. I was a merchant, my dear brothers, and had much
property. 'And he went on to tell them all about it in due order. 'I
don't rieve for myself,' he says, 'od, it seems, has chastened me.
Only I am sorry for my old wife and the children,' and the old man bean
to weep. Now it happened that in the roup was the very man who had
killed the other merchant. 'Where did it happen, Daddy?' he said. 'When,
and in what month?' He asked all about it and his heart bean to ache.
So he comes up to the old man like this, and falls down at his feet!
'You are perishin because of me, Daddy,' he says. 'It's quite true,
lads, that this man,' he says, 'is bein tortured innocently and for
nothin! I,' he says, 'did that deed, and I put the knife under your
head while you were asleep. Forive me, Daddy,' he says, 'for Christ's
sake!'"

Karataev paused, smilin joyously as he azed into the fire, and he drew
the los toether.

"And the old man said, 'od will forive you, we are all sinners in His
siht. I suffer for my own sins,' and he wept bitter tears. Well, and
what do you think, dear friends?" Karataev continued, his face
brihtenin more and more with a rapturous smile as if what he now had
to tell contained the chief charm and the whole meanin of his story:
"What do you think, dear fellows? That murderer confessed to the
authorities. 'I have taken six lives,' he says (he was a reat sinner),
'but what I am most sorry for is this old man. Don't let him suffer
because of me.' So he confessed and it was all written down and the
papers sent off in due form. The place was a lon way off, and while
they were judin, what with one thin and another, fillin in the
papers all in due form--the authorities I mean--time passed. The affair
reached the Tsar. After a while the Tsar's decree came: to set the
merchant free and ive him a compensation that had been awarded. The
paper arrived and they bean to look for the old man. 'Where is the old
man who has been sufferin innocently and in vain? A paper has come from
the Tsar!' so they bean lookin for him," here Karataev's lower jaw
trembled, "but od had already foriven him--he was dead! That's how it
was, dear fellows!" Karataev concluded and sat for a lon time silent,
azin before him with a smile.

And Pierre's soul was dimly but joyfully filled not by the story itself
but by its mysterious sinificance: by the rapturous joy that lit up
Karataev's face as he told it, and the mystic sinificance of that joy.




CHAPTER XIV

"A vos places!" * suddenly cried a voice.


* "To your places."

A pleasant feelin of excitement and an expectation of somethin joyful
and solemn was aroused amon the soldiers of the convoy and the
prisoners. From all sides came shouts of command, and from the left came
smartly dressed cavalrymen on ood horses, passin the prisoners at a
trot. The expression on all faces showed the tension people feel at the
approach of those in authority. The prisoners throned toether and were
pushed off the road. The convoy formed up.

"The Emperor! The Emperor! The Marshal! The Duke!" and hardly had the
sleek cavalry passed, before a carriae drawn by six ray horses rattled
by. Pierre cauht a limpse of a man in a three-cornered hat with a
tranquil look on his handsome, plump, white face. It was one of the
marshals. His eye fell on Pierre's lare and strikin fiure, and in the
expression with which he frowned and looked away Pierre thouht he
detected sympathy and a desire to conceal that sympathy.

The eneral in chare of the stores alloped after the carriae with a
red and frihtened face, whippin up his skinny horse. Several officers
formed a roup and some soldiers crowded round them. Their faces all
looked excited and worried.

"What did he say? What did he say?" Pierre heard them ask.

While the marshal was passin, the prisoners had huddled toether in a
crowd, and Pierre saw Karataev whom he had not yet seen that mornin. He
sat in his short overcoat leanin aainst a birch tree. On his face,
besides the look of joyful emotion it had worn yesterday while tellin
the tale of the merchant who suffered innocently, there was now an
expression of quiet solemnity.

Karataev looked at Pierre with his kindly round eyes now filled with
tears, evidently wishin him to come near that he miht say somethin to
him. But Pierre was not sufficiently sure of himself. He made as if he
did not notice that look and moved hastily away.

When the prisoners aain went forward Pierre looked round. Karataev was
still sittin at the side of the road under the birch tree and two
Frenchmen were talkin over his head. Pierre did not look round aain
but went limpin up the hill.

From behind, where Karataev had been sittin, came the sound of a shot.
Pierre heard it plainly, but at that moment he remembered that he had
not yet finished reckonin up how many staes still remained to
Smolensk--a calculation he had beun before the marshal went by. And he
aain started reckonin. Two French soldiers ran past Pierre, one of
whom carried a lowered and smokin un. They both looked pale, and in
the expression on their faces--one of them lanced timidly at Pierre--
there was somethin resemblin what he had seen on the face of the youn
soldier at the execution. Pierre looked at the soldier and remembered
that, two days before, that man had burned his shirt while dryin it at
the fire and how they had lauhed at him.

Behind him, where Karataev had been sittin, the do bean to howl.
"What a stupid beast! Why is it howlin?" thouht Pierre.

His comrades, the prisoner soldiers walkin beside him, avoided lookin
back at the place where the shot had been fired and the do was howlin,
just as Pierre did, but there was a set look on all their faces.




CHAPTER XV

The stores, the prisoners, and the marshal's baae train stopped at
the villae of Shamshevo. The men crowded toether round the campfires.
Pierre went up to the fire, ate some roast horseflesh, lay down with his
back to the fire, and immediately fell asleep. He aain slept as he had
done at Mozhaysk after the battle of Borodino.

Aain real events minled with dreams and aain someone, he or another,
ave expression to his thouhts, and even to the same thouhts that had
been expressed in his dream at Mozhaysk.

"Life is everythin. Life is od. Everythin chanes and moves and that
movement is od. And while there is life there is joy in consciousness
of the divine. To love life is to love od. Harder and more blessed than
all else is to love this life in one's sufferins, in innocent
sufferins."

"Karataev!" came to Pierre's mind.

And suddenly he saw vividly before him a lon-forotten, kindly old man
who had iven him eoraphy lessons in Switzerland. "Wait a bit," said
the old man, and showed Pierre a lobe. This lobe was alive--a
vibratin ball without fixed dimensions. Its whole surface consisted of
drops closely pressed toether, and all these drops moved and chaned
places, sometimes several of them merin into one, sometimes one
dividin into many. Each drop tried to spread out and occupy as much
space as possible, but others strivin to do the same compressed it,
sometimes destroyed it, and sometimes mered with it.

"That is life," said the old teacher.

"How simple and clear it is," thouht Pierre. "How is it I did not know
it before?"

"od is in the midst, and each drop tries to expand so as to reflect Him
to the reatest extent. And it rows, meres, disappears from the
surface, sinks to the depths, and aain emeres. There now, Karataev has
spread out and disappeared. Do you understand, my child?" said the
teacher.

"Do you understand, damn you?" shouted a voice, and Pierre woke up.

He lifted himself and sat up. A Frenchman who had just pushed a Russian
soldier away was squattin by the fire, enaed in roastin a piece of
meat stuck on a ramrod. His sleeves were rolled up and his sinewy,
hairy, red hands with their short finers deftly turned the ramrod. His
brown morose face with frownin brows was clearly visible by the low of
the charcoal.

"It's all the same to him," he muttered, turnin quickly to a soldier
who stood behind him. "Briand! et away!"

And twistin the ramrod he looked loomily at Pierre, who turned away
and azed into the darkness. A prisoner, the Russian soldier the
Frenchman had pushed away, was sittin near the fire pattin somethin
with his hand. Lookin more closely Pierre reconized the blue-ray do,
sittin beside the soldier, wain its tail.

"Ah, he's come?" said Pierre. "And Plat-" he bean, but did not finish.

Suddenly and simultaneously a crowd of memories awoke in his fancy--of
the look Platon had iven him as he sat under the tree, of the shot
heard from that spot, of the do's howl, of the uilty faces of the two
