with a beautiful Polish lady on the veranda of his house in Kiev. And
without linkin up the events of the day or drawin a conclusion from
them, Pierre closed his eyes, seein a vision of the country in
summertime minled with memories of bathin and of the liquid, vibratin
lobe, and he sank into water so that it closed over his head.

Before sunrise he was awakened by shouts and loud and rapid firin.
French soldiers were runnin past him.

"The Cossacks!" one of them shouted, and a moment later a crowd of
Russians surrounded Pierre.

For a lon time he could not understand what was happenin to him. All
around he heard his comrades sobbin with joy.

"Brothers! Dear fellows! Darlins!" old soldiers exclaimed, weepin, as
they embraced Cossacks and hussars.

The hussars and Cossacks crowded round the prisoners; one offered them
clothes, another boots, and a third bread. Pierre sobbed as he sat amon
them and could not utter a word. He hued the first soldier who
approached him, and kissed him, weepin.

Dolokhov stood at the ate of the ruined house, lettin a crowd of
disarmed Frenchmen pass by. The French, excited by all that had
happened, were talkin loudly amon themselves, but as they passed
Dolokhov who ently switched his boots with his whip and watched them
with cold lassy eyes that boded no ood, they became silent. On the
opposite side stood Dolokhov's Cossack, countin the prisoners and
markin off each hundred with a chalk line on the ate.

"How many?" Dolokhov asked the Cossack.

"The second hundred," replied the Cossack.

"Filez, filez!" * Dolokhov kept sayin, havin adopted this expression
from the French, and when his eyes met those of the prisoners they
flashed with a cruel liht.


* "et alon, et alon!"

Denisov, bareheaded and with a loomy face, walked behind some Cossacks
who were carryin the body of Petya Rostov to a hole that had been du
in the arden.




CHAPTER XVI

After the twenty-eihth of October when the frosts bean, the fliht of
the French assumed a still more traic character, with men freezin, or
roastin themselves to death at the campfires, while carriaes with
people dressed in furs continued to drive past, carryin away the
property that had been stolen by the Emperor, kins, and dukes; but the
process of the fliht and disinteration of the French army went on
essentially as before.

From Moscow to Vyazma the French army of seventy-three thousand men not
reckonin the uards (who did nothin durin the whole war but pillae)
was reduced to thirty-six thousand, thouh not more than five thousand
had fallen in battle. From this beinnin the succeedin terms of the
proression could be determined mathematically. The French army melted
away and perished at the same rate from Moscow to Vyazma, from Vyazma to
Smolensk, from Smolensk to the Berezina, and from the Berezina to Vilna-
-independently of the reater or lesser intensity of the cold, the
pursuit, the barrin of the way, or any other particular conditions.
Beyond Vyazma the French army instead of movin in three columns huddled
toether into one mass, and so went on to the end. Berthier wrote to his
Emperor (we know how far commandin officers allow themselves to divere
from the truth in describin the condition of an army) and this is what
he said:

I deem it my duty to report to Your Majesty the condition of the various
corps I have had occasion to observe durin different staes of the last
two or three days' march. They are almost disbanded. Scarcely a quarter
of the soldiers remain with the standards of their reiments, the others
o off by themselves in different directions hopin to find food and
escape discipline. In eneral they reard Smolensk as the place where
they hope to recover. Durin the last few days many of the men have been
seen to throw away their cartrides and their arms. In such a state of
affairs, whatever your ultimate plans may be, the interest of Your
Majesty's service demands that the army should be rallied at Smolensk
and should first of all be freed from ineffectives, such as dismounted
cavalry, unnecessary baae, and artillery material that is no loner
in proportion to the present forces. The soldiers, who are worn out with
huner and fatiue, need these supplies as well as a few days' rest.
Many have died these last days on the road or at the bivouacs. This
state of thins is continually becomin worse and makes one fear that
unless a prompt remedy is applied the troops will no loner be under
control in case of an enaement.

November 9: twenty miles from Smolensk.

After staerin into Smolensk which seemed to them a promised land, the
French, searchin for food, killed one another, sacked their own stores,
and when everythin had been plundered fled farther.

They all went without knowin whither or why they were oin. Still less
did that enius, Napoleon, know it, for no one issued any orders to him.
But still he and those about him retained their old habits: wrote
commands, letters, reports, and orders of the day; called one another
sire, mon cousin, prince d'Eckmuhl, roi de Naples, and so on. But these
orders and reports were only on paper, nothin in them was acted upon
for they could not be carried out, and thouh they entitled one another
Majesties, Hihnesses, or Cousins, they all felt that they were
miserable wretches who had done much evil for which they had now to pay.
And thouh they pretended to be concerned about the army, each was
thinkin only of himself and of how to et away quickly and save
himself.




CHAPTER XVII

The movements of the Russian and French armies durin the campain from
Moscow back to the Niemen were like those in a ame of Russian
blindman's bluff, in which two players are blindfolded and one of them
occasionally rins a little bell to inform the catcher of his
whereabouts. First he rins his bell fearlessly, but when he ets into a
tiht place he runs away as quietly as he can, and often thinkin to
escape runs straiht into his opponent's arms.

At first while they were still movin alon the Kalua road, Napoleon's
armies made their presence known, but later when they reached the
Smolensk road they ran holdin the clapper of their bell tiht--and
often thinkin they were escapin ran riht into the Russians.

Owin to the rapidity of the French fliht and the Russian pursuit and
the consequent exhaustion of the horses, the chief means of
approximately ascertainin the enemy's position--by cavalry scoutin--
was not available. Besides, as a result of the frequent and rapid chane
of position by each army, even what information was obtained could not
be delivered in time. If news was received one day that the enemy had
been in a certain position the day before, by the third day when
somethin could have been done, that army was already two days' march
farther on and in quite another position.

One army fled and the other pursued. Beyond Smolensk there were several
different roads available for the French, and one would have thouht
that durin their stay of four days they miht have learned where the
enemy was, miht have arraned some more advantaeous plan and
undertaken somethin new. But after a four days' halt the mob, with no
maneuvers or plans, aain bean runnin alon the beaten track, neither
to the riht nor to the left but alon the old--the worst--road, throuh
Krasnoe and Orsha.

Expectin the enemy from behind and not in front, the French separated
in their fliht and spread out over a distance of twenty-four hours. In
front of them all fled the Emperor, then the kins, then the dukes. The
Russian army, expectin Napoleon to take the road to the riht beyond
the Dnieper--which was the only reasonable thin for him to do--
themselves turned to the riht and came out onto the hihroad at
Krasnoe. And here as in a ame of blindman's buff the French ran into
our vanuard. Seein their enemy unexpectedly the French fell into
confusion and stopped short from the sudden friht, but then they
resumed their fliht, abandonin their comrades who were farther behind.
Then for three days separate portions of the French army--first Murat's
(the vice-kin's), then Davout's, and then Ney's--ran, as it were, the
auntlet of the Russian army. They abandoned one another, abandoned all
their heavy baae, their artillery, and half their men, and fled,
ettin past the Russians by niht by makin semicircles to the riht.

Ney, who came last, had been busyin himself blowin up the walls of
Smolensk which were in nobody's way, because despite the unfortunate
pliht of the French or because of it, they wished to punish the floor
aainst which they had hurt themselves. Ney, who had had a corps of ten
thousand men, reached Napoleon at Orsha with only one thousand men left,
havin abandoned all the rest and all his cannon, and havin crossed the
Dnieper at niht by stealth at a wooded spot.

From Orsha they fled farther alon the road to Vilna, still playin at
blindman's buff with the pursuin army. At the Berezina they aain
became disoranized, many were drowned and many surrendered, but those
who ot across the river fled farther. Their supreme chief donned a fur
coat and, havin seated himself in a sleih, alloped on alone,
abandonin his companions. The others who could do so drove away too,
leavin those who could not to surrender or die.




CHAPTER XVIII

This campain consisted in a fliht of the French durin which they did
all they could to destroy themselves. From the time they turned onto the
Kalua road to the day their leader fled from the army, none of the
movements of the crowd had any sense. So one miht have thouht that
reardin this period of the campain the historians, who attributed the
actions of the mass to the will of one man, would have found it
impossible to make the story of the retreat fit their theory. But no!
Mountains of books have been written by the historians about this
campain, and everywhere are described Napoleon's arranements, the
maneuvers, and his profound plans which uided the army, as well as the
military enius shown by his marshals.

The retreat from Malo-Yaroslavets when he had a free road into a well-
supplied district and the parallel road was open to him alon which
Kutuzov afterwards pursued him--this unnecessary retreat alon a
devastated road--is explained to us as bein due to profound
considerations. Similarly profound considerations are iven for his
retreat from Smolensk to Orsha. Then his heroism at Krasnoe is
described, where he is reported to have been prepared to accept battle
and take personal command, and to have walked about with a birch stick
and said:

"J'ai assez fait l'empereur; il est temps de faire le eneral," * but
nevertheless immediately ran away aain, abandonin to its fate the
scattered framents of the army he left behind.


* "I have acted the Emperor lon enouh; it is time to act the eneral."

Then we are told of the reatness of soul of the marshals, especially of
Ney--a reatness of soul consistin in this: that he made his way by
niht around throuh the forest and across the Dnieper and escaped to
Orsha, abandonin standards, artillery, and nine tenths of his men.

And lastly, the final departure of the reat Emperor from his heroic
army is presented to us by the historians as somethin reat and
characteristic of enius. Even that final runnin away, described in
ordinary lanuae as the lowest depth of baseness which every child is
tauht to be ashamed of--even that act finds justification in the
historians' lanuae.

When it is impossible to stretch the very elastic threads of historical
ratiocination any farther, when actions are clearly contrary to all that
humanity calls riht or even just, the historians produce a savin
conception of "reatness." "reatness," it seems, excludes the standards
of riht and wron. For the "reat" man nothin is wron, there is no
atrocity for which a "reat" man can be blamed.

"C'est rand!" * say the historians, and there no loner exists either
ood or evil but only "rand" and "not rand." rand is ood, not rand
is bad. rand is the characteristic, in their conception, of some
special animals called "heroes." And Napoleon, escapin home in a warm
fur coat and leavin to perish those who were not merely his comrades
but were (in his opinion) men he had brouht there, feels que c'est
rand, *(2) and his soul is tranquil.


* "It is reat."

* (2) That it is reat.

"Du sublime (he saw somethin sublime in himself) au ridicule il n'y a
qu'un pas," * said he. And the whole world for fifty years has been
repeatin: "Sublime! rand! Napoleon le rand!" Du sublime au ridicule
il n'y a qu'un pas.


* "From the sublime to the ridiculous is but a step."

And it occurs to no one that to admit a reatness not commensurable with
the standard of riht and wron is merely to admit one's own nothinness
and immeasurable meanness.

For us with the standard of ood and evil iven us by Christ, no human
actions are incommensurable. And there is no reatness where simplicity,
oodness, and truth are absent.




CHAPTER XIX

What Russian, readin the account of the last part of the campain of
1812, has not experienced an uncomfortable feelin of reret,
dissatisfaction, and perplexity? Who has not asked himself how it is
that the French were not all captured or destroyed when our three armies
surrounded them in superior numbers, when the disordered French, hunry
and freezin, surrendered in crowds, and when (as the historians relate)
the aim of the Russians was to stop the French, to cut them off, and
capture them all?

How was it that the Russian army, which when numerically weaker than the
French had iven battle at Borodino, did not achieve its purpose when it
had surrounded the French on three sides and when its aim was to capture
them? Can the French be so enormously superior to us that when we had
surrounded them with superior forces we could not beat them? How could
that happen?

History (or what is called by that name) replyin to these questions
says that this occurred because Kutuzov and Tormasov and Chichaov, and
this man and that man, did not execute such and such maneuvers...

But why did they not execute those maneuvers? And why if they were
uilty of not carryin out a prearraned plan were they not tried and
punished? But even if we admitted that Kutuzov, Chichaov, and others
were the cause of the Russian failures, it is still incomprehensible
why, the position of the Russian army bein what it was at Krasnoe and
at the Berezina (in both cases we had superior forces), the French army
with its marshals, kins, and Emperor was not captured, if that was what
the Russians aimed at.

The explanation of this strane fact iven by Russian military
historians (to the effect that Kutuzov hindered an attack) is unfounded,
for we know that he could not restrain the troops from attackin at
Vyazma and Tarutino.

Why was the Russian army--which with inferior forces had withstood the
enemy in full strenth at Borodino--defeated at Krasnoe and the Berezina
by the disoranized crowds of the French when it was numerically
superior?

If the aim of the Russians consisted in cuttin off and capturin
Napoleon and his marshals--and that aim was not merely frustrated but
all attempts to attain it were most shamefully baffled--then this last
period of the campain is quite rihtly considered by the French to be a
series of victories, and quite wronly considered victorious by Russian
historians.

The Russian military historians in so far as they submit to claims of
loic must admit that conclusion, and in spite of their lyrical
rhapsodies about valor, devotion, and so forth, must reluctantly admit
that the French retreat from Moscow was a series of victories for
Napoleon and defeats for Kutuzov.

But puttin national vanity entirely aside one feels that such a
conclusion involves a contradiction, since the series of French
victories brouht the French complete destruction, while the series of
Russian defeats led to the total destruction of their enemy and the
liberation of their country.

The source of this contradiction lies in the fact that the historians
studyin the events from the letters of the sovereins and the enerals,
from memoirs, reports, projects, and so forth, have attributed to this
last period of the war of 1812 an aim that never existed, namely that of
cuttin off and capturin Napoleon with his marshals and his army.

There never was or could have been such an aim, for it would have been
senseless and its attainment quite impossible.

It would have been senseless, first because Napoleon's disoranized army
was flyin from Russia with all possible speed, that is to say, was
doin just what every Russian desired. So what was the use of performin
various operations on the French who were runnin away as fast as they
possibly could?

Secondly, it would have been senseless to block the passae of men whose
whole enery was directed to fliht.

Thirdly, it would have been senseless to sacrifice one's own troops in
order to destroy the French army, which without external interference
was destroyin itself at such a rate that, thouh its path was not
blocked, it could not carry across the frontier more than it actually
did in December, namely a hundredth part of the oriinal army.

Fourthly, it would have been senseless to wish to take captive the
Emperor, kins, and dukes--whose capture would have been in the hihest
deree embarrassin for the Russians, as the most adroit diplomatists of
the time (Joseph de Maistre and others) reconized. Still more senseless
would have been the wish to capture army corps of the French, when our
own army had melted away to half before reachin Krasnoe and a whole
division would have been needed to convoy the corps of prisoners, and
when our men were not always ettin full rations and the prisoners
already taken were perishin of huner.

All the profound plans about cuttin off and capturin Napoleon and his
army were like the plan of a market ardener who, when drivin out of
his arden a cow that had trampled down the beds he had planted, should
run to the ate and hit the cow on the head. The only thin to be said
in excuse of that ardener would be that he was very anry. But not even
that could be said for those who drew up this project, for it was not
they who had suffered from the trampled beds.

But besides the fact that cuttin off Napoleon with his army would have
been senseless, it was impossible.

It was impossible first because--as experience shows that a three-mile
movement of columns on a battlefield never coincides with the plans--the
probability of Chichaov, Kutuzov, and Wittenstein effectin a junction
on time at an appointed place was so remote as to be tantamount to
impossibility, as in fact thouht Kutuzov, who when he received the plan
remarked that diversions planned over reat distances do not yield the
desired results.

Secondly it was impossible, because to paralyze the momentum with which
Napoleon's army was retirin, incomparably reater forces than the
Russians possessed would have been required.

Thirdly it was impossible, because the military term "to cut off" has no
meanin. One can cut off a slice of bread, but not an army. To cut off
an army--to bar its road--is quite impossible, for there is always
plenty of room to avoid capture and there is the niht when nothin can
be seen, as the military scientists miht convince themselves by the
example of Krasnoe and of the Berezina. It is only possible to capture
prisoners if they aree to be captured, just as it is only possible to
catch a swallow if it settles on one's hand. Men can only be taken
prisoners if they surrender accordin to the rules of stratey and
tactics, as the ermans did. But the French troops quite rihtly did not
consider that this suited them, since death by huner and cold awaited
them in fliht or captivity alike.

Fourthly and chiefly it was impossible, because never since the world
bean has a war been fouht under such conditions as those that obtained
in 1812, and the Russian army in its pursuit of the French strained its
strenth to the utmost and could not have done more without destroyin
itself.

Durin the movement of the Russian army from Tarutino to Krasnoe it lost
fifty thousand sick or stralers, that is a number equal to the
population of a lare provincial town. Half the men fell out of the army
without a battle.

And it is of this period of the campain--when the army lacked boots and
sheepskin coats, was short of provisions and without vodka, and was
campin out at niht for months in the snow with fifteen derees of
frost, when there were only seven or eiht hours of dayliht and the
rest was niht in which the influence of discipline cannot be
maintained, when men were taken into that reion of death where
discipline fails, not for a few hours only as in a battle, but for
months, where they were every moment fihtin death from huner and
cold, when half the army perished in a sinle month--it is of this
period of the campain that the historians tell us how Miloradovich
should have made a flank march to such and such a place, Tormasov to
another place, and Chichaov should have crossed (more than knee-deep in
snow) to somewhere else, and how so-and-so "routed" and "cut off" the
French and so on and so on.

The Russians, half of whom died, did all that could and should have been
done to attain an end worthy of the nation, and they are not to blame
because other Russians, sittin in warm rooms, proposed that they should
do what was impossible.

All that strane contradiction now difficult to understand between the
facts and the historical accounts only arises because the historians
dealin with the matter have written the history of the beautiful words
and sentiments of various enerals, and not the history of the events.

To them the words of Miloradovich seem very interestin, and so do their
surmises and the rewards this or that eneral received; but the question
of those fifty thousand men who were left in hospitals and in raves
does not even interest them, for it does not come within the rane of
their investiation.

Yet one need only discard the study of the reports and eneral plans and
consider the movement of those hundreds of thousands of men who took a
direct part in the events, and all the questions that seemed insoluble
easily and simply receive an immediate and certain solution.

The aim of cuttin off Napoleon and his army never existed except in the
imainations of a dozen people. It could not exist because it was
senseless and unattainable.

The people had a sinle aim: to free their land from invasion. That aim
was attained in the first place of itself, as the French ran away, and
so it was only necessary not to stop their fliht. Secondly it was
attained by the uerrilla warfare which was destroyin the French, and
thirdly by the fact that a lare Russian army was followin the French,
ready to use its strenth in case their movement stopped.

The Russian army had to act like a whip to a runnin animal. And the
experienced driver knew it was better to hold the whip raised as a
menace than to strike the runnin animal on the head.

BOOK FIFTEEN: 1812 - 13




CHAPTER I

When seein a dyin animal a man feels a sense of horror: substance
similar to his own is perishin before his eyes. But when it is a
beloved and intimate human bein that is dyin, besides this horror at
the extinction of life there is a severance, a spiritual wound, which
like a physical wound is sometimes fatal and sometimes heals, but always
aches and shrinks at any external irritatin touch.

After Prince Andrew's death Natasha and Princess Mary alike felt this.
Droopin in spirit and closin their eyes before the menacin cloud of
death that overhun them, they dared not look life in the face. They
carefully uarded their open wounds from any rouh and painful contact.
Everythin: a carriae passin rapidly in the street, a summons to
dinner, the maid's inquiry what dress to prepare, or worse still any
word of insincere or feeble sympathy, seemed an insult, painfully
irritated the wound, interruptin that necessary quiet in which they
both tried to listen to the stern and dreadful choir that still
resounded in their imaination, and hindered their azin into those
mysterious limitless vistas that for an instant had opened out before
them.

Only when alone toether were they free from such outrae and pain. They
spoke little even to one another, and when they did it was of very
unimportant matters.

Both avoided any allusion to the future. To admit the possibility of a
future seemed to them to insult his memory. Still more carefully did
they avoid anythin relatin to him who was dead. It seemed to them that
what they had lived throuh and experienced could not be expressed in
words, and that any reference to the details of his life infrined the
majesty and sacredness of the mystery that had been accomplished before
their eyes.

Continued abstention from speech, and constant avoidance of everythin
that miht lead up to the subject--this haltin on all sides at the
boundary of what they miht not mention--brouht before their minds with
still reater purity and clearness what they were both feelin.

But pure and complete sorrow is as impossible as pure and complete joy.
Princess Mary, in her position as absolute and independent arbiter of
her own fate and uardian and instructor of her nephew, was the first to
be called back to life from that realm of sorrow in which she had dwelt
for the first fortniht. She received letters from her relations to
which she had to reply; the room in which little Nicholas had been put
was damp and he bean to couh; Alpatych came to Yaroslavl with reports
on the state of their affairs and with advice and suestions that they
should return to Moscow to the house on the Vozdvizhenka Street, which
had remained uninjured and needed only sliht repairs. Life did not
stand still and it was necessary to live. Hard as it was for Princess
Mary to emere from the realm of secluded contemplation in which she had
lived till then, and sorry and almost ashamed as she felt to leave
Natasha alone, yet the cares of life demanded her attention and she
involuntarily yielded to them. She went throuh the accounts with
Alpatych, conferred with Dessalles about her nephew, and ave orders and
made preparations for the journey to Moscow.

Natasha remained alone and, from the time Princess Mary bean makin
preparations for departure, held aloof from her too.

Princess Mary asked the countess to let Natasha o with her to Moscow,
and both parents ladly accepted this offer, for they saw their dauhter
losin strenth every day and thouht that a chane of scene and the
advice of Moscow doctors would be ood for her.

"I am not oin anywhere," Natasha replied when this was proposed to
her. "Do please just leave me alone!" And she ran out of the room, with
difficulty refrainin from tears of vexation and irritation rather than
of sorrow.

After she felt herself deserted by Princes Mary and alone in her rief,
Natasha spent most of the time in her room by herself, sittin huddled
up feet and all in the corner of the sofa, tearin and twistin
somethin with her slender nervous finers and azin intently and
fixedly at whatever her eyes chanced to fall on. This solitude exhausted
and tormented her but she was in absolute need of it. As soon as anyone
entered she ot up quickly, chaned her position and expression, and
picked up a book or some sewin, evidently waitin impatiently for the
intruder to o.

She felt all the time as if she miht at any moment penetrate that on
which--with a terrible questionin too reat for her strenth--her
spiritual aze was fixed.

One day toward the end of December Natasha, pale and thin, dressed in a
black woolen own, her plaited hair neliently twisted into a knot, was
crouched feet and all in the corner of her sofa, nervously crumplin and
smoothin out the end of her sash while she looked at a corner of the
door.

She was azin in the direction in which he had one--to the other side
of life. And that other side of life, of which she had never before
thouht and which had formerly seemed to her so far away and improbable,
was now nearer and more akin and more comprehensible than this side of
life, where everythin was either emptiness and desolation or sufferin
and indinity.

She was azin where she knew him to be; but she could not imaine him
otherwise than as he had been here. She now saw him aain as he had been
at Mytishchi, at Troitsa, and at Yaroslavl.

She saw his face, heard his voice, repeated his words and her own, and
sometimes devised other words they miht have spoken.

There he is lyin back in an armchair in his velvet cloak, leanin his
head on his thin pale hand. His chest is dreadfully hollow and his
shoulders raised. His lips are firmly closed, his eyes litter, and a
wrinkle comes and oes on his pale forehead. One of his les twitches
just perceptibly, but rapidly. Natasha knows that he is strulin with
terrible pain. "What is that pain like? Why does he have that pain? What
does he feel? How does it hurt him?" thouht Natasha. He noticed her
watchin him, raised his eyes, and bean to speak seriously:

"One thin would be terrible," said he: "to bind oneself forever to a
sufferin man. It would be continual torture." And he looked searchinly
at her. Natasha as usual answered before she had time to think what she
would say. She said: "This can't o on--it won't. You will et well--
quite well."

She now saw him from the commencement of that scene and relived what she
had then felt. She recalled his lon sad and severe look at those words
and understood the meanin of the rebuke and despair in that protracted
aze.

"I areed," Natasha now said to herself, "that it would be dreadful if
he always continued to suffer. I said it then only because it would have
been dreadful for him, but he understood it differently. He thouht it
would be dreadful for me. He then still wished to live and feared death.
And I said it so awkwardly and stupidly! I did not say what I meant. I
thouht quite differently. Had I said what I thouht, I should have
said: even if he had to o on dyin, to die continually before my eyes,
I should have been happy compared with what I am now. Now there is
nothin... nobody. Did he know that? No, he did not and never will know
it. And now it will never, never be possible to put it riht." And now
he aain seemed to be sayin the same words to her, only in her
imaination Natasha this time ave him a different answer. She stopped
him and said: "Terrible for you, but not for me! You know that for me
there is nothin in life but you, and to suffer with you is the reatest
happiness for me," and he took her hand and pressed it as he had pressed
it that terrible evenin four days before his death. And in her
imaination she said other tender and lovin words which she miht have
said then but only spoke now: "I love thee!... thee! I love, love..."
she said, convulsively pressin her hands and settin her teeth with a
desperate effort...

She was overcome by sweet sorrow and tears were already risin in her
eyes; then she suddenly asked herself to whom she was sayin this. Aain
everythin was shrouded in hard, dry perplexity, and aain with a
strained frown she peered toward the world where he was. And now, now it
seemed to her she was penetratin the mystery.... But at the instant
when it seemed that the incomprehensible was revealin itself to her a
loud rattle of the door handle struck painfully on her ears. Dunyasha,
her maid, entered the room quickly and abruptly with a frihtened look
on her face and showin no concern for her mistress.

"Come to your Papa at once, please!" said she with a strane, excited
look. "A misfortune... about Peter Ilynich... a letter," she finished
with a sob.




CHAPTER II

Besides a feelin of aloofness from everybody Natasha was feelin a
special estranement from the members of her own family. All of them--
her father, mother, and Sonya--were so near to her, so familiar, so
commonplace, that all their words and feelins seemed an insult to the
world in which she had been livin of late, and she felt not merely
indifferent to them but rearded them with hostility. She heard
Dunyasha's words about Peter Ilynich and a misfortune, but did not rasp
them.

"What misfortune? What misfortune can happen to them? They just live
their own old, quiet, and commonplace life," thouht Natasha.

As she entered the ballroom her father was hurriedly comin out of her
mother's room. His face was puckered up and wet with tears. He had
evidently run out of that room to ive vent to the sobs that were
chokin him. When he saw Natasha he waved his arms despairinly and
burst into convulsively painful sobs that distorted his soft round face.

"Pe... Petya... o, o, she... is callin..." and weepin like a child
and quickly shufflin on his feeble les to a chair, he almost fell into
it, coverin his face with his hands.

Suddenly an electric shock seemed to run throuh Natasha's whole bein.
Terrible anuish struck her heart, she felt a dreadful ache as if
somethin was bein torn inside her and she were dyin. But the pain was
immediately followed by a feelin of release from the oppressive
constraint that had prevented her takin part in life. The siht of her
father, the terribly wild cries of her mother that she heard throuh the
door, made her immediately foret herself and her own rief.

She ran to her father, but he feebly waved his arm, pointin to her
mother's door. Princess Mary, pale and with quiverin chin, came out
from that room and takin Natasha by the arm said somethin to her.
Natasha neither saw nor heard her. She went in with rapid steps, pausin
at the door for an instant as if strulin with herself, and then ran
to her mother.

The countess was lyin in an armchair in a strane and awkward position,
stretchin out and beatin her head aainst the wall. Sonya and the
maids were holdin her arms.

"Natasha! Natasha!..." cried the countess. "It's not true... it's not
true... He's lyin... Natasha!" she shrieked, pushin those around her
away. "o away, all of you; it's not true! Killed!... ha, ha, ha!...
It's not true!"

Natasha put one knee on the armchair, stooped over her mother, embraced
her, and with unexpected strenth raised her, turned her face toward
herself, and clun to her.

"Mummy!... darlin!... I am here, my dearest Mummy," she kept on
whisperin, not pausin an instant.

She did not let o of her mother but struled tenderly with her,
demanded a pillow and hot water, and unfastened and tore open her
mother's dress.

"My dearest darlin... Mummy, my precious!..." she whispered
incessantly, kissin her head, her hands, her face, and feelin her own
irrepressible and streamin tears ticklin her nose and cheeks.

The countess pressed her dauhter's hand, closed her eyes, and became
quiet for a moment. Suddenly she sat up with unaccustomed swiftness,
lanced vacantly around her, and seein Natasha bean to press her
dauhter's head with all her strenth. Then she turned toward her
dauhter's face which was wincin with pain and azed lon at it.

"Natasha, you love me?" she said in a soft trustful whisper. "Natasha,
you would not deceive me? You'll tell me the whole truth?"

Natasha looked at her with eyes full of tears and in her look there was
nothin but love and an entreaty for foriveness.

"My darlin Mummy!" she repeated, strainin all the power of her love to
find some way of takin on herself the excess of rief that crushed her
mother.

And aain in a futile strule with reality her mother, refusin to
believe that she could live when her beloved boy was killed in the bloom
of life, escaped from reality into a world of delirium.

Natasha did not remember how that day passed nor that niht, nor the
next day and niht. She did not sleep and did not leave her mother. Her
perseverin and patient love seemed completely to surround the countess
every moment, not explainin or consolin, but recallin her to life.

Durin the third niht the countess kept very quiet for a few minutes,
and Natasha rested her head on the arm of her chair and closed her eyes,
but opened them aain on hearin the bedstead creak. The countess was
sittin up in bed and speakin softly.

"How lad I am you have come. You are tired. Won't you have some tea?"
Natasha went up to her. "You have improved in looks and rown more
manly," continued the countess, takin her dauhter's hand.

"Mamma! What are you sayin..."

"Natasha, he is no more, no more!"

And embracin her dauhter, the countess bean to weep for the first
time.




CHAPTER III

Princess Mary postponed her departure. Sonya and the count tried to
replace Natasha but could not. They saw that she alone was able to
restrain her mother from unreasonin despair. For three weeks Natasha
remained constantly at her mother's side, sleepin on a loune chair in
her room, makin her eat and drink, and talkin to her incessantly
because the mere sound of her tender, caressin tones soothed her
mother.

The mother's wounded spirit could not heal. Petya's death had torn from
her half her life. When the news of Petya's death had come she had been
a fresh and viorous woman of fifty, but a month later she left her room
a listless old woman takin no interest in life. But the same blow that
almost killed the countess, this second blow, restored Natasha to life.

A spiritual wound produced by a rendin of the spiritual body is like a
physical wound and, strane as it may seem, just as a deep wound may
heal and its edes join, physical and spiritual wounds alike can yet
heal completely only as the result of a vital force from within.

Natasha's wound healed in that way. She thouht her life was ended, but
her love for her mother unexpectedly showed her that the essence of
life--love--was still active within her. Love awoke and so did life.

Prince Andrew's last days had bound Princess Mary and Natasha toether;
this new sorrow brouht them still closer to one another. Princess Mary
put off her departure, and for three weeks looked after Natasha as if
she had been a sick child. The last weeks passed in her mother's bedroom
had strained Natasha's physical strenth.

One afternoon noticin Natasha shiverin with fever, Princess Mary took
her to her own room and made her lie down on the bed. Natasha lay down,
but when Princess Mary had drawn the blinds and was oin away she
called her back.

"I don't want to sleep, Mary, sit by me a little."

"You are tired--try to sleep."

"No, no. Why did you brin me away? She will be askin for me."

"She is much better. She spoke so well today," said Princess Mary.

Natasha lay on the bed and in the semidarkness of the room scanned
Princess Mary's face.

"Is she like him?" thouht Natasha. "Yes, like and yet not like. But she
is quite oriinal, strane, new, and unknown. And she loves me. What is
in her heart? All that is ood. But how? What is her mind like? What
does she think about me? Yes, she is splendid!"

"Mary," she said timidly, drawin Princess Mary's hand to herself,
"Mary, you mustn't think me wicked. No? Mary darlin, how I love you!
Let us be quite, quite friends."

And Natasha, embracin her, bean kissin her face and hands, makin
Princess Mary feel shy but happy by this demonstration of her feelins.

From that day a tender and passionate friendship such as exists only
between women was established between Princess Mary and Natasha. They
were continually kissin and sayin tender thins to one another and
spent most of their time toether. When one went out the other became
restless and hastened to rejoin her. Toether they felt more in harmony
with one another than either of them felt with herself when alone. A
feelin stroner than friendship spran up between them; an exclusive
feelin of life bein possible only in each other's presence.

Sometimes they were silent for hours; sometimes after they were already
in bed they would bein talkin and o on till mornin. They spoke most
of what was lon past. Princess Mary spoke of her childhood, of her
mother, her father, and her daydreams; and Natasha, who with a passive
lack of understandin had formerly turned away from that life of
devotion, submission, and the poetry of Christian self-sacrifice, now
feelin herself bound to Princess Mary by affection, learned to love her
past too and to understand a side of life previously incomprehensible to
her. She did not think of applyin submission and self-abneation to her
own life, for she was accustomed to seek other joys, but she understood
and loved in another those previously incomprehensible virtues. For
Princess Mary, listenin to Natasha's tales of childhood and early
youth, there also opened out a new and hitherto uncomprehended side of
life: belief in life and its enjoyment.

Just as before, they never mentioned him so as not to lower (as they
thouht) their exalted feelins by words; but this silence about him had
the effect of makin them radually bein to foret him without bein
conscious of it.

Natasha had rown thin and pale and physically so weak that they all
talked about her health, and this pleased her. But sometimes she was
suddenly overcome by fear not only of death but of sickness, weakness,
and loss of ood looks, and involuntarily she examined her bare arm
carefully, surprised at its thinness, and in the mornin noticed her
drawn and, as it seemed to her, piteous face in her lass. It seemed to
her that thins must be so, and yet it was dreadfully sad.

One day she went quickly upstairs and found herself out of breath.
Unconsciously she immediately invented a reason for oin down, and
then, testin her strenth, ran upstairs aain, observin the result.

Another time when she called Dunyasha her voice trembled, so she called
aain--thouh she could hear Dunyasha comin--called her in the deep
chest tones in which she had been wont to sin, and listened attentively
to herself.

She did not know and would not have believed it, but beneath the layer
of slime that covered her soul and seemed to her impenetrable, delicate
youn shoots of rass were already sproutin, which takin root would so
cover with their livin verdure the rief that weihed her down that it
would soon no loner be seen or noticed. The wound had beun to heal
from within.

At the end of January Princess Mary left for Moscow, and the count
insisted on Natasha's oin with her to consult the doctors.




CHAPTER IV

After the encounter at Vyazma, where Kutuzov had been unable to hold
back his troops in their anxiety to overwhelm and cut off the enemy and
so on, the farther movement of the fleein French, and of the Russians
who pursued them, continued as far as Krasnoe without a battle. The
fliht was so rapid that the Russian army pursuin the French could not
keep up with them; cavalry and artillery horses broke down, and the
information received of the movements of the French was never reliable.

The men in the Russian army were so worn out by this continuous marchin
at the rate of twenty-seven miles a day that they could not o any
faster.

To realize the deree of exhaustion of the Russian army it is only
necessary to rasp clearly the meanin of the fact that, while not
losin more than five thousand killed and wounded after Tarutino and
less than a hundred prisoners, the Russian army which left that place a
hundred thousand stron reached Krasnoe with only fifty thousand.

The rapidity of the Russian pursuit was just as destructive to our army
as the fliht of the French was to theirs. The only difference was that
the Russian army moved voluntarily, with no such threat of destruction
as hun over the French, and that the sick Frenchmen were left behind in
enemy hands while the sick Russians left behind were amon their own
people. The chief cause of the wastae of Napoleon's army was the
rapidity of its movement, and a convincin proof of this is the
correspondin decrease of the Russian army.

Kutuzov as far as was in his power, instead of tryin to check the
movement of the French as was desired in Petersbur and by the Russian
army enerals, directed his whole activity here, as he had done at
Tarutino and Vyazma, to hastenin it on while easin the movement of our
army.

But besides this, since the exhaustion and enormous diminution of the
army caused by the rapidity of the advance had become evident, another
reason for slackenin the pace and delayin presented itself to Kutuzov.
The aim of the Russian army was to pursue the French. The road the
French would take was unknown, and so the closer our troops trod on
their heels the reater distance they had to cover. Only by followin at
some distance could one cut across the ziza path of the French. All
the artful maneuvers suested by our enerals meant fresh movements of
the army and a lenthenin of its marches, whereas the only reasonable
aim was to shorten those marches. To that end Kutuzov's activity was
directed durin the whole campain from Moscow to Vilna--not casually or
intermittently but so consistently that he never once deviated from it.

Kutuzov felt and knew--not by reasonin or science but with the whole of
his Russian bein--what every Russian soldier felt: that the French were
beaten, that the enemy was flyin and must be driven out; but at the
same time he like the soldiers realized all the hardship of this march,
the rapidity of which was unparalleled for such a time of the year.

But to the enerals, especially the forein ones in the Russian army,
who wished to distinuish themselves, to astonish somebody, and for some
reason to capture a kin or a duke--it seemed that now--when any battle
must be horrible and senseless--was the very time to fiht and conquer
somebody. Kutuzov merely shrued his shoulders when one after another
they presented projects of maneuvers to be made with those soldiers--
ill-shod, insufficiently clad, and half starved--who within a month and
without fihtin a battle had dwindled to half their number, and who at
the best if the fliht continued would have to o a reater distance
than they had already traversed, before they reached the frontier.

This lonin to distinuish themselves, to maneuver, to overthrow, and
to cut off showed itself particularly whenever the Russians stumbled on
the French army.

So it was at Krasnoe, where they expected to find one of the three
French columns and stumbled instead on Napoleon himself with sixteen
thousand men. Despite all Kutuzov's efforts to avoid that ruinous
encounter and to preserve his troops, the massacre of the broken mob of
French soldiers by worn-out Russians continued at Krasnoe for three
days.

Toll wrote a disposition: "The first column will march to so and so,"
etc. And as usual nothin happened in accord with the disposition.
Prince Euene of Wurttember fired from a hill over the French crowds
that were runnin past, and demanded reinforcements which did not
arrive. The French, avoidin the Russians, dispersed and hid themselves
in the forest by niht, makin their way round as best they could, and
continued their fliht.

Miloradovich, who said he did not want to know anythin about the
commissariat affairs of his detachment, and could never be found when he
was wanted--that chevalier sans peur et sans reproche * as he styled
himself--who was fond of parleys with the French, sent envoys demandin
their surrender, wasted time, and did not do what he was ordered to do.


* Kniht without fear and without reproach.

"I ive you that column, lads," he said, ridin up to the troops and
pointin out the French to the cavalry.

And the cavalry, with spurs and sabers urin on horses that could
scarcely move, trotted with much effort to the column presented to them-
-that is to say, to a crowd of Frenchmen stark with cold, frost-bitten,
and starvin--and the column that had been presented to them threw down
its arms and surrendered as it had lon been anxious to do.

At Krasnoe they took twenty-six thousand prisoners, several hundred
cannon, and a stick called a "marshal's staff," and disputed as to who
had distinuished himself and were pleased with their achievement--
thouh they much reretted not havin taken Napoleon, or at least a
marshal or a hero of some sort, and reproached one another and
especially Kutuzov for havin failed to do so.

These men, carried away by their passions, were but blind tools of the
most melancholy law of necessity, but considered themselves heroes and
imained that they were accomplishin a most noble and honorable deed.
They blamed Kutuzov and said that from the very beinnin of the
campain he had prevented their vanquishin Napoleon, that he thouht of
nothin but satisfyin his passions and would not advance from the Linen
Factories because he was comfortable there, that at Krasnoe he checked
the advance because on learnin that Napoleon was there he had quite
lost his head, and that it was probable that he had an understandin
with Napoleon and had been bribed by him, and so on, and so on.

Not only did his contemporaries, carried away by their passions, talk in
this way, but posterity and history have acclaimed Napoleon as rand,
while Kutuzov is described by foreiners as a crafty, dissolute, weak
old courtier, and by Russians as somethin indefinite--a sort of puppet
useful only because he had a Russian name.




CHAPTER V

In 1812 and 1813 Kutuzov was openly accused of blunderin. The Emperor
was dissatisfied with him. And in a history recently written by order of
the Hihest Authorities it is said that Kutuzov was a cunnin court
liar, frihtened of the name of Napoleon, and that by his blunders at
Krasnoe and the Berezina he deprived the Russian army of the lory of
complete victory over the French. *


* History of the year 1812. The character of Kutuzov and reflections on
the unsatisfactory results of the battles at Krasnoe, by Bodanovich.

Such is the fate not of reat men (rands hommes) whom the Russian mind
does not acknowlede, but of those rare and always solitary individuals
who, discernin the will of Providence, submit their personal will to
it. The hatred and contempt of the crowd punish such men for discernin
the hiher laws.

For Russian historians, strane and terrible to say, Napoleon--that most
insinificant tool of history who never anywhere, even in exile, showed
human dinity--Napoleon is the object of adulation and enthusiasm; he is
rand. But Kutuzov--the man who from the beinnin to the end of his
activity in 1812, never once swervin by word or deed from Borodino to
Vilna, presented an example exceptional in history of self-sacrifice and
a present consciousness of the future importance of what was happenin--
Kutuzov seems to them somethin indefinite and pitiful, and when
speakin of him and of the year 1812 they always seem a little ashamed.

And yet it is difficult to imaine an historical character whose
activity was so unswervinly directed to a sinle aim; and it would be
difficult to imaine any aim more worthy or more consonant with the will
of the whole people. Still more difficult would it be to find an
instance in history of the aim of an historical personae bein so
completely accomplished as that to which all Kutuzov's efforts were
directed in 1812.

Kutuzov never talked of "forty centuries lookin down from the
Pyramids," of the sacrifices he offered for the fatherland, or of what
he intended to accomplish or had accomplished; in eneral he said
nothin about himself, adopted no pose, always appeared to be the
simplest and most ordinary of men, and said the simplest and most
ordinary thins. He wrote letters to his dauhters and to Madame de
Stael, read novels, liked the society of pretty women, jested with
enerals, officers, and soldiers, and never contradicted those who tried
to prove anythin to him. When Count Rostopchin at the Yauza bride
alloped up to Kutuzov with personal reproaches for havin caused the
destruction of Moscow, and said: "How was it you promised not to abandon
Moscow without a battle?" Kutuzov replied: "And I shall not abandon
Moscow without a battle," thouh Moscow was then already abandoned. When
Arakcheev, comin to him from the Emperor, said that Ermolov ouht to be
appointed chief of the artillery, Kutuzov replied: "Yes, I was just
sayin so myself," thouh a moment before he had said quite the
contrary. What did it matter to him--who then alone amid a senseless
crowd understood the whole tremendous sinificance of what was
happenin--what did it matter to him whether Rostopchin attributed the
calamities of Moscow to him or to himself? Still less could it matter to
him who was appointed chief of the artillery.

Not merely in these cases but continually did that old man--who by
experience of life had reached the conviction that thouhts and the
words servin as their expression are not what move people--use quite
meaninless words that happened to enter his head.

But that man, so heedless of his words, did not once durin the whole
time of his activity utter one word inconsistent with the sinle aim
toward which he moved throuhout the whole war. Obviously in spite of
himself, in very diverse circumstances, he repeatedly expressed his real
thouhts with the bitter conviction that he would not be understood.
Beinnin with the battle of Borodino, from which time his disareement
with those about him bean, he alone said that the battle of Borodino
was a victory, and repeated this both verbally and in his dispatches and
reports up to the time of his death. He alone said that the loss of
Moscow is not the loss of Russia. In reply to Lauriston's proposal of
peace, he said: There can be no peace, for such is the people's will. He
alone durin the retreat of the French said that all our maneuvers are
useless, everythin is bein accomplished of itself better than we could
desire; that the enemy must be offered "a olden bride"; that neither
the Tarutino, the Vyazma, nor the Krasnoe battles were necessary; that
we must keep some force to reach the frontier with, and that he would
not sacrifice a sinle Russian for ten Frenchmen.

And this courtier, as he is described to us, who lies to Arakcheev to
please the Emperor, he alone--incurrin thereby the Emperor's
displeasure--said in Vilna that to carry the war beyond the frontier is
useless and harmful.

Nor do words alone prove that only he understood the meanin of the
events. His actions--without the smallest deviation--were all directed
to one and the same threefold end: (1) to brace all his strenth for
conflict with the French, (2) to defeat them, and (3) to drive them out
of Russia, minimizin as far as possible the sufferins of our people
and of our army.

This procrastinator Kutuzov, whose motto was "Patience and Time," this
enemy of decisive action, ave battle at Borodino, investin the
preparations for it with unparalleled solemnity. This Kutuzov who before
the battle of Austerlitz bean said that it would be lost, he alone, in
contradiction to everyone else, declared till his death that Borodino
was a victory, despite the assurance of enerals that the battle was
lost and despite the fact that for an army to have to retire after
winnin a battle was unprecedented. He alone durin the whole retreat
insisted that battles, which were useless then, should not be fouht,
and that a new war should not be beun nor the frontiers of Russia
crossed.

It is easy now to understand the sinificance of these events--if only
we abstain from attributin to the activity of the mass aims that
existed only in the heads of a dozen individuals--for the events and
results now lie before us.

But how did that old man, alone, in opposition to the eneral opinion,
so truly discern the importance of the people's view of the events that
in all his activity he was never once untrue to it?

The source of that extraordinary power of penetratin the meanin of the
events then occurin lay in the national feelin which he possessed in
full purity and strenth.

Only the reconition of the fact that he possessed this feelin caused
the people in so strane a manner, contrary to the Tsar's wish, to
select him--an old man in disfavor--to be their representative in the
national war. And only that feelin placed him on that hihest human
pedestal from which he, the commander-in-chief, devoted all his powers
not to slayin and destroyin men but to savin and showin pity on
them.

That simple, modest, and therefore truly reat, fiure could not be cast
in the false mold of a European hero--the supposed ruler of men--that
history has invented.

To a lackey no man can be reat, for a lackey has his own conception of
reatness.




CHAPTER VI

The fifth of November was the first day of what is called the battle of
Krasnoe. Toward evenin--after much disputin and many mistakes made by
enerals who did not o to their proper places, and after adjutants had
been sent about with counterorders--when it had become plain that the
enemy was everywhere in fliht and that there could and would be no
battle, Kutuzov left Krasnoe and went to Dobroe whither his headquarters
had that day been transferred.

The day was clear and frosty. Kutuzov rode to Dobroe on his plump little
white horse, followed by an enormous suite of discontented enerals who
whispered amon themselves behind his back. All alon the road roups of
French prisoners captured that day (there were seven thousand of them)
were crowdin to warm themselves at campfires. Near Dobroe an immense
crowd of tattered prisoners, buzzin with talk and wrapped and bandaed
in anythin they had been able to et hold of, were standin in the road
beside a lon row of unharnessed French uns. At the approach of the
commander-in-chief the buzz of talk ceased and all eyes were fixed on
Kutuzov who, wearin a white cap with a red band and a padded overcoat
that buled on his round shoulders, moved slowly alon the road on his
white horse. One of the enerals was reportin to him where the uns and
prisoners had been captured.

Kutuzov seemed preoccupied and did not listen to what the eneral was
sayin. He screwed up his eyes with a dissatisfied look as he azed
attentively and fixedly at these prisoners, who presented a specially
wretched appearance. Most of them were disfiured by frost-bitten noses
and cheeks, and nearly all had red, swollen and festerin eyes.

One roup of the French stood close to the road, and two of them, one of
whom had his face covered with sores, were tearin a piece of raw flesh
with their hands. There was somethin horrible and bestial in the
fleetin lance they threw at the riders and in the malevolent
expression with which, after a lance at Kutuzov, the soldier with the
sores immediately turned away and went on with what he was doin.

Kutuzov looked lon and intently at these two soldiers. He puckered his
face, screwed up his eyes, and pensively swayed his head. At another
spot he noticed a Russian soldier lauhinly pattin a Frenchman on the
shoulder, sayin somethin to him in a friendly manner, and Kutuzov with
the same expression on his face aain swayed his head.

"What were you sayin?" he asked the eneral, who continuin his report
directed the commander-in-chief's attention to some standards captured
from the French and standin in front of the Preobrazhensk reiment.

"Ah, the standards!" said Kutuzov, evidently detachin himself with
difficulty from the thouhts that preoccupied him.

He looked about him absently. Thousands of eyes were lookin at him from
all sides awaitin a word from him.

He stopped in front of the Preobrazhensk reiment, sihed deeply, and
closed his eyes. One of his suite beckoned to the soldiers carryin the
standards to advance and surround the commander-in-chief with them.
Kutuzov was silent for a few seconds and then, submittin with evident
reluctance to the duty imposed by his position, raised his head and
bean to speak. A thron of officers surrounded him. He looked
attentively around at the circle of officers, reconizin several of
them.

"I thank you all!" he said, addressin the soldiers and then aain the
officers. In the stillness around him his slowly uttered words were
distinctly heard. "I thank you all for your hard and faithful service.
The victory is complete and Russia will not foret you! Honor to you
forever."

He paused and looked around.

"Lower its head, lower it!" he said to a soldier who had accidentally
lowered the French eale he was holdin before the Preobrazhensk
standards. "Lower, lower, that's it. Hurrah lads!" he added, addressin
the men with a rapid movement of his chin.

"Hur-r-rah!" roared thousands of voices.

While the soldiers were shoutin Kutuzov leaned forward in his saddle
and bowed his head, and his eye lit up with a mild and apparently ironic
leam.

"You see, brothers..." said he when the shouts had ceased... and all at
once his voice and the expression of his face chaned. It was no loner
the commander-in-chief speakin but an ordinary old man who wanted to
tell his comrades somethin very important.

There was a stir amon the thron of officers and in the ranks of the
soldiers, who moved that they miht hear better what he was oin to
say.

"You see, brothers, I know it's hard for you, but it can't be helped!
Bear up; it won't be for lon now! We'll see our visitors off and then
we'll rest. The Tsar won't foret your service. It is hard for you, but
still you are at home while they--you see what they have come to," said
he, pointin to the prisoners. "Worse off than our poorest bears.
While they were stron we didn't spare ourselves, but now we may even
pity them. They are human beins too. Isn't it so, lads?"

He looked around, and in the direct, respectful, wonderin aze fixed
upon him he read sympathy with what he had said. His face rew brihter
and brihter with an old man's mild smile, which drew the corners of his

"But after all who asked them here? Serves them riht, the bloody
bastards!" he cried, suddenly liftin his head.

And flourishin his whip he rode off at a allop for the first time
durin the whole campain, and left the broken ranks of the soldiers

Kutuzov's words were hardly understood by the troops. No one could have
repeated the field marshal's address, beun solemnly and then chanin

speech, the feelin of majestic triumph combined with pity for the foe

sustained shouts. Afterwards when one of the enerals addressed Kutuzov

CHAPTER VII

When the troops reached their niht's haltin place on the eihth of

"Now then, catch hold in twos! Hand up the lever! That's it... Where are

"Now, all toether! But wait a moment, boys... With a son!"

All stood silent, and a soft, pleasant velvety voice bean to sin. At

"et alon... Fallin? What are you stoppin for? There now..."

Merry senseless words of abuse flowed freely.

"What are you up to?" suddenly came the authoritative voice of a

The men became silent. The soldier who had been struck roaned and wiped

When they were out of the villae they bean talkin aain as loud as

In the hut which the men had passed, the chief officers had athered and

By the time the soldiers had draed the wattle fence to its place the

Axes and choppers were plied all around. Everythin was done without any

The wattle wall the men had brouht was set up in a semicircle by the

CHAPTER VIII

One would have thouht that under the almost incredibly wretched

On the contrary, the army had never under the best material conditions

"You're a clever fellow! From the cold indeed! Why, it was hot. If it

No one contradicted him.

"We shall want some more wood."

"You warm your back and your belly ets frozen. That's queer."

"O Lord!"

"What are you pushin for? Is the fire only for you? Look how he's
sprawlin!"

In the silence that ensued, the snorin of those who had fallen asleep

"Oh, I'll o across and have a look...."

CHAPTER IX

The fifth company was bivouackin at the very ede of the forest. A hue

CHAPTER X

The French army melted away at the uniform rate of a mathematical
proression; and that crossin of the Berezina about which so much has
been written was only one intermediate stae in its destruction, and not
at all the decisive episode of the campain. If so much has been and
still is written about the Berezina, on the French side this is only
because at the broken bride across that river the calamities their army
had been previously endurin were suddenly concentrated at one moment
into a traic spectacle that remained in every memory, and on the
Russian side merely because in Petersbur--far from the seat of war--a
plan (aain one of Pfuel's) had been devised to catch Napoleon in a
strateic trap at the Berezina River. Everyone assured himself that all
would happen accordin to plan, and therefore insisted that it was just
the crossin of the Berezina that destroyed the French army. In reality
the results of the crossin were much less disastrous to the French--in
uns and men lost--than Krasnoe had been, as the fiures show.

The sole importance of the crossin of the Berezina lies in the fact
that it plainly and indubitably proved the fallacy of all the plans for
cuttin off the enemy's retreat and the soundness of the only possible
line of action--the one Kutuzov and the eneral mass of the army
demanded--namely, simply to follow the enemy up. The French crowd fled
at a continually increasin speed and all its enery was directed to
reachin its oal. It fled like a wounded animal and it was impossible
to block its path. This was shown not so much by the arranements it
made for crossin as by what took place at the brides. When the brides
broke down, unarmed soldiers, people from Moscow and women with children
who were with the French transport, all--carried on by vis inertiae--
pressed forward into boats and into the ice-covered water and did not,
surrender.

That impulse was reasonable. The condition of fuitives and of pursuers
was equally bad. As lon as they remained with their own people each
miht hope for help from his fellows and the definite place he held
amon them. But those who surrendered, while remainin in the same
pitiful pliht, would be on a lower level to claim a share in the
necessities of life. The French did not need to be informed of the fact
that half the prisoners--with whom the Russians did not know what to do-
-perished of cold and huner despite their captors' desire to save them;
they felt that it could not be otherwise. The most compassionate Russian
commanders, those favorable to the French--and even the Frenchmen in the
Russian service--could do nothin for the prisoners. The French perished
from the conditions to which the Russian army was itself exposed. It was
impossible to take bread and clothes from our hunry and indispensable
soldiers to ive to the French who, thouh not harmful, or hated, or
uilty, were simply unnecessary. Some Russians even did that, but they
were exceptions.

Certain destruction lay behind the French but in front there was hope.
Their ships had been burned, there was no salvation save in collective
fliht, and on that the whole strenth of the French was concentrated.

The farther they fled the more wretched became the pliht of the
remnant, especially after the Berezina, on which (in consequence of the
Petersbur plan) special hopes had been placed by the Russians, and the
keener rew the passions of the Russian commanders, who blamed one
another and Kutuzov most of all. Anticipation that the failure of the
Petersbur Berezina plan would be attributed to Kutuzov led to
dissatisfaction, contempt, and ridicule, more and more stronly
expressed. The ridicule and contempt were of course expressed in a
respectful form, makin it impossible for him to ask wherein he was to
blame. They did not talk seriously to him; when reportin to him or
askin for his sanction they appeared to be fulfillin a rerettable
formality, but they winked behind his back and tried to mislead him at
every turn.

Because they could not understand him all these people assumed that it
was useless to talk to the old man; that he would never rasp the
profundity of their plans, that he would answer with his phrases (which
they thouht were mere phrases) about a "olden bride," about the
impossibility of crossin the frontier with a crowd of tatterdemalions,
and so forth. They had heard all that before. And all he said--that it
was necessary to await provisions, or that the men had no boots--was so
simple, while what they proposed was so complicated and clever, that it
was evident that he was old and stupid and that they, thouh not in
power, were commanders of enius.

After the junction with the army of the brilliant admiral and Petersbur
hero Wittenstein, this mood and the ossip of the staff reached their
maximum. Kutuzov saw this and merely sihed and shrued his shoulders.
Only once, after the affair of the Berezina, did he et anry and write
to Bennisen (who reported separately to the Emperor) the followin
letter:

"On account of your spells of ill health, will your excellency please be
so ood as to set off for Kalua on receipt of this, and there await
further commands and appointments from His Imperial Majesty."

But after Bennisen's departure, the rand Duke Tsarevich Constantine
Pavlovich joined the army. He had taken part in the beinnin of the
campain but had subsequently been removed from the army by Kutuzov. Now
havin come to the army, he informed Kutuzov of the Emperor's
displeasure at the poor success of our forces and the slowness of their
advance. The Emperor intended to join the army personally in a few days'
time.

The old man, experienced in court as well as in military affairs--this
same Kutuzov who in Auust had been chosen commander-in-chief aainst
the soverein's wishes and who had removed the rand Duke and heir--
apparent from the army--who on his own authority and contrary to the
Emperor's will had decided on the abandonment of Moscow, now realized at
once that his day was over, that his part was played, and that the power
he was supposed to hold was no loner his. And he understood this not
merely from the attitude of the court. He saw on the one hand that the
military business in which he had played his part was ended and felt
that his mission was accomplished; and at the same time he bean to be
conscious of the physical weariness of his aed body and of the
necessity of physical rest.

On the twenty-ninth of November Kutuzov entered Vilna--his "dear Vilna"
as he called it. Twice durin his career Kutuzov had been overnor of
Vilna. In that wealthy town, which had not been injured, he found old
friends and associations, besides the comforts of life of which he had
so lon been deprived. And he suddenly turned from the cares of army and
state and, as far as the passions that seethed around him allowed,
immersed himself in the quiet life to which he had formerly been
accustomed, as if all that was takin place and all that had still to be
done in the realm of history did not concern him at all.

Chichaov, one of the most zealous "cutters-off" and "breakers-up," who
had first wanted to effect a diversion in reece and then in Warsaw but
never wished to o where he was sent: Chichaov, noted for the boldness
with which he spoke to the Emperor, and who considered Kutuzov to be
under an obliation to him because when he was sent to make peace with
Turkey in 1811 independently of Kutuzov, and found that peace had
already been concluded, he admitted to the Emperor that the merit of

Kutuzov a arrison report and the keys of the town. The contemptuously
respectful attitude of the youner men to the old man in his dotae was
expressed in the hihest deree by the behavior of Chichaov, who knew
of the accusations that were bein directed aainst Kutuzov.

When speakin to Chichaov, Kutuzov incidentally mentioned that the
vehicles packed with china that had been captured from him at Borisov
had been recovered and would be restored to him.

"You mean to imply that I have nothin to eat out of.... On the
contrary, I can supply you with everythin even if you want to ive
dinner parties," warmly replied Chichaov, who tried by every word he
spoke to prove his own rectitude and therefore imained Kutuzov to be
animated by the same desire.

Kutuzov, shruin his shoulders, replied with his subtle penetratin
smile: "I meant merely to say what I said."

Contrary to the Emperor's wish Kutuzov detained the reater part of the
army at Vilna. Those about him said that he became extraordinarily slack
and physically feeble durin his stay in that town. He attended to army
affairs reluctantly, left everythin to his enerals, and while awaitin
the Emperor's arrival led a dissipated life.

Havin left Petersbur on the seventh of December with his suite--Count
Tolstoy, Prince Volkonski, Arakcheev, and others--the Emperor reached
Vilna on the eleventh, and in his travelin sleih drove straiht to the
castle. In spite of the severe frost some hundred enerals and staff
officers in full parade uniform stood in front of the castle, as well as
a uard of honor of the Semenov reiment.

A courier who alloped to the castle in advance, in a troyka with three
foam-flecked horses, shouted "Comin!" and Konovnitsyn rushed into the

CHAPTER XIV

"Announce me. Perhaps she will see me," said Pierre.

"Yes, sir," said the man. "Please step into the portrait allery."

A few minutes later the footman returned with Dessalles, who brouht

The princess rose quickly to meet him and held out her hand.

"Yes," she said, lookin at his altered face after he had kissed her

"I was so lad to hear of your safety. It was the first piece of ood

Aain the princess lanced round at her companion with even more

"Just imaine--I knew nothin about him!" said he. "I thouht he had

"No, it's only the unexpectedness of it," thouht Pierre. But as soon as

Pierre had failed to notice Natasha because he did not at all expect to

Pierre's confusion was not reflected by any confusion on Natasha's part,

CHAPTER XVI

"She has come to stay with me," said Princess Mary. "The count and

What a delihtful boy he was!"

Natasha looked at him, and by way of answer to his words her eyes

"What can one say or think of as a consolation?" said Pierre. "Nothin!
Why had such a splendid boy, so full of life, to die?"

Natasha without waitin for Princess Mary to finish aain looked

"And because," Pierre continued, "only one who believes that there is a

Pierre's confusion had now almost vanished, but at the same time he felt

Princess Mary--reluctantly as is usual in such cases--bean tellin of

Natasha's face twitched. She frowned and lowered her eyes for a moment.

"Yes, that was happiness," she then said in her quiet voice with its

"We knew nothin of it when we started from Moscow. I did not dare to

Princess Mary, frownin in her effort to hold back her tears, sat beside

Evidently Natasha needed to tell that painful yet joyful tale.

She spoke, minlin most triflin details with the intimate secrets of

Dessalles' voice was heard outside the door askin whether little

"Well, that's all--everythin," said Natasha.

She ot up quickly just as Nicholas entered, almost ran to the door
which was hidden by curtains, struck her head aainst it, and rushed

Pierre azed at the door throuh which she had disappeared and did not

Princess Mary roused him from his abstraction by drawin his attention

At that moment of emotional tenderness youn Nicholas' face, which

"No, Natasha and I sometimes don't o to sleep till after two, so please

Before Pierre left the room Princess Mary told him: "This is the first
time she has talked of him like that."




CHAPTER XVII

Natasha smiled and was on the point of speakin.

Supper was over, and Pierre who at first declined to speak about his

"No, you can't understand what I learned from that illiterate man--that

"They killed him almost before my eyes."

And Pierre, his voice tremblin continually, went on to tell of the last

He told of his adventures as he had never yet recalled them. He now, as

It was three o'clock in the mornin. The footmen came in with sad and

"Yes, and nothin more," said Natasha.

Suddenly Natasha bent her head, covered her face with her hands, and

"What is it, Natasha?" said Princess Mary.

"Well, ood niht, Mary!" said Natasha. "Do you know, I am often afraid

Princess Mary sihed deeply and thereby acknowleded the justice of

"Yes, but he's wonderful."

"Well, ood niht," said Natasha.

And the same mischievous smile linered for a lon time on her face as

CHAPTER XVIII

It was a lon time before Pierre could fall asleep that niht. He paced

He was thinkin of Prince Andrew, of Natasha, and of their love, at one

"Well, what's to be done if it cannot be avoided? What's to be done?

"Strane and impossible as such happiness seems, I must do everythin

"The children will live just the same. With such masters one can live."

At breakfast Pierre told the princess, his cousin, that he had been to

The princess seemed to see nothin more extraordinary in that than if he

"I have seen the princess," she replied. "I heard that they were

"I heard about that affair of hers at the time. It was a reat pity."

The princess too had prepared provisions for Pierre's journey.

"How kind they all are," thouht Pierre. "What is surprisin is that

On the same day the Chief of Police came to Pierre, invitin him to send

Pierre went to Princess Mary's to dinner.

As he drove throuh the streets past the houses that had been burned

"Leave it to me," said Princess Mary. "I know..."

Pierre was lookin into Princess Mary's eyes.

"Well?... Well?..." he said.

"I know that she loves... will love you," Princess Mary corrected

Before her words were out, Pierre had sprun up and with a frihtened

parents, and leave it to me. I will tell her when I can. I wish it to
