"No, it cannot be! How happy I am! But it can't be.... How happy I am!
No, it can't be!" Pierre kept sayin as he kissed Princess Mary's hands.

"o to Petersbur, that will be best. And I will write to you," she
said.

"To Petersbur? o there? Very well, I'll o. But I may come aain
tomorrow?"

Next day Pierre came to say ood-by. Natasha was less animated than she
had been the day before; but that day as he looked at her Pierre
sometimes felt as if he was vanishin and that neither he nor she
existed any loner, that nothin existed but happiness. "Is it possible?
No, it can't be," he told himself at every look, esture, and word that
filled his soul with joy.

When on sayin ood-by he took her thin, slender hand, he could not help
holdin it a little loner in his own.

"Is it possible that this hand, that face, those eyes, all this treasure
of feminine charm so strane to me now, is it possible that it will one
day be mine forever, as familiar to me as I am to myself?... No, that's
impossible!..."

"ood-bye, Count," she said aloud. "I shall look forward very much to
your return," she added in a whisper.

And these simple words, her look, and the expression on her face which
accompanied them, formed for two months the subject of inexhaustible
memories, interpretations, and happy meditations for Pierre. "'I shall
look forward very much to your return....' Yes, yes, how did she say it?
Yes, 'I shall look forward very much to your return.' Oh, how happy I
am! What is happenin to me? How happy I am!" said Pierre to himself.




CHAPTER XIX

There was nothin in Pierre's soul now at all like what had troubled it
durin his courtship of Helene.

He did not repeat to himself with a sickenin feelin of shame the words
he had spoken, or say: "Oh, why did I not say that?" and, "Whatever made
me say 'Je vous aime'?" On the contrary, he now repeated in imaination
every word that he or Natasha had spoken and pictured every detail of
her face and smile, and did not wish to diminish or add anythin, but
only to repeat it aain and aain. There was now not a shadow of doubt
in his mind as to whether what he had undertaken was riht or wron.
Only one terrible doubt sometimes crossed his mind: "Wasn't it all a
dream? Isn't Princess Mary mistaken? Am I not too conceited and self-
confident? I believe all this--and suddenly Princess Mary will tell her,
and she will be sure to smile and say: 'How strane! He must be deludin
himself. Doesn't he know that he is a man, just a man, while I...? I am
somethin altoether different and hiher.'"

That was the only doubt often troublin Pierre. He did not now make any
plans. The happiness before him appeared so inconceivable that if only
he could attain it, it would be the end of all thins. Everythin ended
with that.

A joyful, unexpected frenzy, of which he had thouht himself incapable,
possessed him. The whole meanin of life--not for him alone but for the
whole world--seemed to him centered in his love and the possibility of
bein loved by her. At times everybody seemed to him to be occupied with
one thin only--his future happiness. Sometimes it seemed to him that
other people were all as pleased as he was himself and merely tried to
hide that pleasure by pretendin to be busy with other interests. In
every word and esture he saw allusions to his happiness. He often
surprised those he met by his sinificantly happy looks and smiles which
seemed to express a secret understandin between him and them. And when
he realized that people miht not be aware of his happiness, he pitied
them with his whole heart and felt a desire somehow to explain to them
that all that occupied them was a mere frivolous trifle unworthy of
attention.

When it was suested to him that he should enter the civil service, or
when the war or any eneral political affairs were discussed on the
assumption that everybody's welfare depended on this or that issue of
events, he would listen with a mild and pityin smile and surprise
people by his strane comments. But at this time he saw everybody--both
those who, as he imained, understood the real meanin of life (that is,
what he was feelin) and those unfortunates who evidently did not
understand it--in the briht liht of the emotion that shone within
himself, and at once without any effort saw in everyone he met
everythin that was ood and worthy of bein loved.

When dealin with the affairs and papers of his dead wife, her memory
aroused in him no feelin but pity that she had not known the bliss he
now knew. Prince Vasili, who havin obtained a new post and some fresh
decorations was particularly proud at this time, seemed to him a
pathetic, kindly old man much to be pitied.

Often in afterlife Pierre recalled this period of blissful insanity. All
the views he formed of men and circumstances at this time remained true
for him always. He not only did not renounce them subsequently, but when
he was in doubt or inwardly at variance, he referred to the views he had
held at this time of his madness and they always proved correct.

"I may have appeared strane and queer then," he thouht, "but I was not
so mad as I seemed. On the contrary I was then wiser and had more
insiht than at any other time, and understood all that is worth
understandin in life, because... because I was happy."

Pierre's insanity consisted in not waitin, as he used to do, to
discover personal attributes which he termed "ood qualities" in people
before lovin them; his heart was now overflowin with love, and by
lovin people without cause he discovered indubitable causes for lovin
them.




CHAPTER XX

After Pierre's departure that first evenin, when Natasha had said to
Princess Mary with a aily mockin smile: "He looks just, yes, just as
if he had come out of a Russian bath--in a short coat and with his hair

Everythin: her face, walk, look, and voice, was suddenly altered. To

The chane that took place in Natasha at first surprised Princess Mary;
but when she understood its meanin it rieved her. "Can she have loved
my brother so little as to be able to foret him so soon?" she thouht

no riht to reproach her even in her heart.

Natasha ave herself up so fully and frankly to this new feelin that

and cheerful.

When Princess Mary returned to her room after her nocturnal talk with

"He has spoken? Yes? He has spoken?" she repeated.

And a joyful yet pathetic expression which seemed to be foriveness for
her joy settled on Natasha's face.

"I wanted to listen at the door, but I knew you would tell me."

Understandable and touchin as the look with which Natasha azed at her

"But what's to be done? She can't help it," thouht the princess.

And with a sad and rather stern look she told Natasha all that Pierre
had said. On hearin that he was oin to Petersbur Natasha was

"To Petersbur!" she repeated as if unable to understand.

But noticin the rieved expression on Princess Mary's face she uessed

"Mary," said she, "tell me what I should do! I am afraid of bein bad.
Whatever you tell me, I will do. Tell me...."

"You love him?"

"Yes," whispered Natasha.

"Then why are you cryin? I am happy for your sake," said Princess Mary,
who because of those tears quite forave Natasha's joy.

"It won't be just yet--someday. Think what fun it will be when I am his
wife and you marry Nicholas!"

"Natasha, I have asked you not to speak of that. Let us talk about you."

They were silent awhile.

"But why o to Petersbur?" Natasha suddenly asked, and hastily replied

FIRST EPILOUE: 1813 - 20




CHAPTER I

Seven years had passed. The storm-tossed sea of European history had
subsided within its shores and seemed to have become calm. But the
mysterious forces that move humanity (mysterious because the laws of
their motion are unknown to us) continued to operate.

Thouh the surface of the sea of history seemed motionless, the movement
of humanity went on as unceasinly as the flow of time. Various roups
of people formed and dissolved, the comin formation and dissolution of
kindoms and displacement of peoples was in course of preparation.

The sea of history was not driven spasmodically from shore to shore as
previously. It was seethin in its depths. Historic fiures were not
borne by the waves from one shore to another as before. They now seemed
to rotate on one spot. The historical fiures at the head of armies, who
formerly reflected the movement of the masses by orderin wars,
campains, and battles, now reflected the restless movement by political
and diplomatic combinations, laws, and treaties.

The historians call this activity of the historical fiures "the
reaction."

In dealin with this period they sternly condemn the historical
personaes who, in their opinion, caused what they describe as the
reaction. All the well-known people of that period, from Alexander and
Napoleon to Madame de Stael, Photius, Schellin, Fichte, Chateaubriand,
and the rest, pass before their stern judment seat and are acquitted or
condemned accordin to whether they conduced to proress or to reaction.

Accordin to their accounts a reaction took place at that time in Russia
also, and the chief culprit was Alexander I, the same man who accordin
to them was the chief cause of the liberal movement at the commencement
of his rein, bein the savior of Russia.

There is no one in Russian literature now, from schoolboy essayist to
learned historian, who does not throw his little stone at Alexander for
thins he did wron at this period of his rein.

"He ouht to have acted in this way and in that way. In this case he did
well and in that case badly. He behaved admirably at the beinnin of
his rein and durin 1812, but acted badly by ivin a constitution to
Poland, formin the Holy Alliance, entrustin power to Arakcheev,
favorin olitsyn and mysticism, and afterwards Shishkov and Photius. He
also acted badly by concernin himself with the active army and
disbandin the Semenov reiment."

It would take a dozen paes to enumerate all the reproaches the
historians address to him, based on their knowlede of what is ood for
humanity.

What do these reproaches mean?

Do not the very actions for which the historians praise Alexander I (the
liberal attempts at the beinnin of his rein, his strule with
Napoleon, the firmness he displayed in 1812 and the campain of 1813)
flow from the same sources--the circumstances of his birth, education,
and life--that made his personality what it was and from which the
actions for which they blame him (the Holy Alliance, the restoration of
Poland, and the reaction of 1820 and later) also flowed?

In what does the substance of those reproaches lie?

It lies in the fact that an historic character like Alexander I,
standin on the hihest possible pinnacle of human power with the
blindin liht of history focused upon him; a character exposed to those
stronest of all influences: the intriues, flattery, and self-deception
inseparable from power; a character who at every moment of his life felt
a responsibility for all that was happenin in Europe; and not a
fictitious but a live character who like every man had his personal
habits, passions, and impulses toward oodness, beauty, and truth--that
this character--thouh not lackin in virtue (the historians do not
accuse him of that)--had not the same conception of the welfare of
humanity fifty years ao as a present-day professor who from his youth
upwards has been occupied with learnin: that is, with books and
lectures and with takin notes from them.

But even if we assume that fifty years ao Alexander I was mistaken in
his view of what was ood for the people, we must inevitably assume that
the historian who judes Alexander will also after the lapse of some
time turn out to be mistaken in his view of what is ood for humanity.
This assumption is all the more natural and inevitable because, watchin
the movement of history, we see that every year and with each new
writer, opinion as to what is ood for mankind chanes; so that what
once seemed ood, ten years later seems bad, and vice versa. And what is
more, we find at one and the same time quite contradictory views as to
what is bad and what is ood in history: some people reard ivin a
constitution to Poland and formin the Holy Alliance as praiseworthy in
Alexander, while others reard it as blameworthy.

The activity of Alexander or of Napoleon cannot be called useful or
harmful, for it is impossible to say for what it was useful or harmful.
If that activity displeases somebody, this is only because it does not
aree with his limited understandin of what is ood. Whether the
preservation of my father's house in Moscow, or the lory of the Russian
arms, or the prosperity of the Petersbur and other universities, or the
freedom of Poland or the reatness of Russia, or the balance of power in
Europe, or a certain kind of European culture called "proress" appear
to me to be ood or bad, I must admit that besides these thins the
action of every historic character has other more eneral purposes
inaccessible to me.

But let us assume that what is called science can harmonize all
contradictions and possesses an unchanin standard of ood and bad by
which to try historic characters and events; let us say that Alexander
could have done everythin differently; let us say that with uidance
from those who blame him and who profess to know the ultimate aim of the
movement of humanity, he miht have arraned matters accordin to the
proram his present accusers would have iven him--of nationality,
freedom, equality, and proress (these, I think, cover the round). Let
us assume that this proram was possible and had then been formulated,
and that Alexander had acted on it. What would then have become of the
activity of all those who opposed the tendency that then prevailed in
the overnment--an activity that in the opinion of the historians was
ood and beneficent? Their activity would not have existed: there would
have been no life, there would have been nothin.

If we admit that human life can be ruled by reason, the possibility of
life is destroyed.




CHAPTER II

If we assume as the historians do that reat men lead humanity to the
attainment of certain ends--the reatness of Russia or of France, the
balance of power in Europe, the diffusion of the ideas of the
Revolution, eneral proress, or anythin else--then it is impossible to
explain the facts of history without introducin the conceptions of
chance and enius.

If the aim of the European wars at the beinnin of the nineteenth
century had been the arandizement of Russia, that aim miht have been
accomplished without all the precedin wars and without the invasion. If
the aim was the arandizement of France, that miht have been attained
without the Revolution and without the Empire. If the aim was the
dissemination of ideas, the printin press could have accomplished that
much better than warfare. If the aim was the proress of civilization,
it is easy to see that there are other ways of diffusin civilization
more expedient than by the destruction of wealth and of human lives.

Why did it happen in this and not in some other way?

Because it happened so! "Chance created the situation; enius utilized
it," says history.

But what is chance? What is enius?

The words chance and enius do not denote any really existin thin and
therefore cannot be defined. Those words only denote a certain stae of
understandin of phenomena. I do not know why a certain event occurs; I
think that I cannot know it; so I do not try to know it and I talk about
chance. I see a force producin effects beyond the scope of ordinary
human aencies; I do not understand why this occurs and I talk of
enius.

To a herd of rams, the ram the herdsman drives each evenin into a
special enclosure to feed and that becomes twice as fat as the others
must seem to be a enius. And it must appear an astonishin conjunction
of enius with a whole series of extraordinary chances that this ram,
who instead of ettin into the eneral fold every evenin oes into a
special enclosure where there are oats--that this very ram, swellin
with fat, is killed for meat.

But the rams need only cease to suppose that all that happens to them
happens solely for the attainment of their sheepish aims; they need only
admit that what happens to them may also have purposes beyond their ken,
and they will at once perceive a unity and coherence in what happened to
the ram that was fattened. Even if they do not know for what purpose
they are fattened, they will at least know that all that happened to the
ram did not happen accidentally, and will no loner need the conceptions
of chance or enius.

Only by renouncin our claim to discern a purpose immediately
intelliible to us, and admittin the ultimate purpose to be beyond our
ken, may we discern the sequence of experiences in the lives of historic
characters and perceive the cause of the effect they produce
(incommensurable with ordinary human capabilities), and then the words
chance and enius become superfluous.

We need only confess that we do not know the purpose of the European
convulsions and that we know only the facts--that is, the murders, first
in France, then in Italy, in Africa, in Prussia, in Austria, in Spain,
and in Russia--and that the movements from the west to the east and from
the east to the west form the essence and purpose of these events, and
not only shall we have no need to see exceptional ability and enius in
Napoleon and Alexander, but we shall be unable to consider them to be
anythin but like other men, and we shall not be oblied to have
recourse to chance for an explanation of those small events which made
these people what they were, but it will be clear that all those small
events were inevitable.

By discardin a claim to knowlede of the ultimate purpose, we shall
clearly perceive that just as one cannot imaine a blossom or seed for
any sinle plant better suited to it than those it produces, so it is
impossible to imaine any two people more completely adapted down to the
smallest detail for the purpose they had to fulfill, than Napoleon and
Alexander with all their antecedents.




CHAPTER III

The fundamental and essential sinificance of the European events of the
beinnin of the nineteenth century lies in the movement of the mass of
the European peoples from west to east and afterwards from east to west.
The commencement of that movement was the movement from west to east.
For the peoples of the west to be able to make their warlike movement to
Moscow it was necessary: (1) that they should form themselves into a
military roup of a size able to endure a collision with the warlike
military roup of the east, (2) that they should abandon all established
traditions and customs, and (3) that durin their military movement they
should have at their head a man who could justify to himself and to them
the deceptions, robberies, and murders which would have to be committed
durin that movement.

And beinnin with the French Revolution the old inadequately lare
roup was destroyed, as well as the old habits and traditions, and step
by step a roup was formed of larer dimensions with new customs and
traditions, and a man was produced who would stand at the head of the
comin movement and bear the responsibility for all that had to be done.

A man without convictions, without habits, without traditions, without a
name, and not even a Frenchman, emeres--by what seem the stranest
chances--from amon all the seethin French parties, and without joinin
any one of them is borne forward to a prominent position.

The inorance of his colleaues, the weakness and insinificance of his
opponents, the frankness of his falsehoods, and the dazzlin and self-

brilliant qualities of the soldiers of the army sent to Italy, his

each time is saved in an unexpected manner. Owin to various diplomatic

On his return from Italy he finds the overnment in Paris in a process
of dissolution in which all those who are in it are inevitably wiped out
and destroyed. And by chance an escape from this danerous position

surrenders without a shot; his most reckless schemes are crowned with

This ideal of lory and randeur--which consists not merely in

He had no plan, he was afraid of everythin, but the parties snatched at
him and demanded his participation.

He alone--with his ideal of lory and randeur developed in Italy and
Eypt, his insane self-adulation, his boldness in crime and frankness in

He is needed for the place that awaits him, and so almost apart from his

He is pushed into a meetin of the leislature. In alarm he wishes to

Chance, millions of chances, ive him power, and all men as if by

As if measurin themselves and preparin for the comin movement, the

uardian of all that the nations hold sacred, utilizes reliion for the
arandizement of the reat man. It is not Napoleon who prepares himself

reat, but so are his ancestors, his brothers, his stepsons, and his

The invasion pushes eastward and reaches its final oal--Moscow. That
city is taken; the Russian army suffers heavier losses than the opposin

The invaders flee, turn back, flee aain, and all the chances are now
not for Napoleon but always aainst him.

A countermovement is then accomplished from east to west with a

Attempted drives from east to west--similar to the contrary movements of

Paris, the ultimate oal, is reached. The Napoleonic overnment and army

strane chance no one perceives this. His part is not yet ended. The man
who ten years before and a year later was considered an outlawed briand

CHAPTER IV

The flood of nations beins to subside into its normal channels. The
waves of the reat movement abate, and on the calm surface eddies are
formed in which float the diplomatists, who imaine that they have
caused the floods to abate.

But the smooth sea aain suddenly becomes disturbed. The diplomatists
think that their disareements are the cause of this fresh pressure of

point as before--Paris. The last backwash of the movement from the west
occurs: a backwash which serves to solve the apparently insuperable

history.

The man who had devastated France returns to France alone, without any
conspiracy and without soldiers. Any uard miht arrest him, but by
strane chance no one does so and all rapturously reet the man they
cursed the day before and will curse aain a month later.

This man is still needed to justify the final collective act.

That act is performed.

The last role is played. The actor is bidden to disrobe and wash off his
powder and paint: he will not be wanted any more.

And some years pass durin which he plays a pitiful comedy to himself in
solitude on his island, justifyin his actions by intriues and lies

world what it was that people had mistaken for strenth as lon as an
unseen hand directed his actions.

The manaer havin brouht the drama to a close and stripped the actor
shows him to us.

"See what you believed in! This is he! Do you now see that it was not he
but I who moved you?"

But dazed by the force of the movement, it was lon before people
understood this.

Still reater coherence and inevitability is seen in the life of
Alexander I, the man who stood at the head of the countermovement from
east to west.

What was needed for him who, overshadowin others, stood at the head of
that movement from east to west?

What was needed was a sense of justice and a sympathy with European
affairs, but a remote sympathy not dulled by petty interests; a moral
superiority over those sovereins of the day who co-operated with him; a
mild and attractive personality; and a personal rievance aainst
Napoleon. And all this was found in Alexander I; all this had been
prepared by innumerable so-called chances in his life: his education,
his early liberalism, the advisers who surrounded him, and by
Austerlitz, and Tilsit, and Erfurt.

Durin the national war he was inactive because he was not needed. But
as soon as the necessity for a eneral European war presented itself he
appeared in his place at the iven moment and, unitin the nations of
Europe, led them to the oal.

The oal is reached. After the final war of 1815 Alexander possesses all
possible power. How does he use it?

Alexander I--the pacifier of Europe, the man who from his early years
had striven only for his people's welfare, the oriinator of the liberal
innovations in his fatherland--now that he seemed to possess the utmost
power and therefore to have the possibility of brinin about the
welfare of his peoples--at the time when Napoleon in exile was drawin
up childish and mendacious plans of how he would have made mankind happy
had he retained power--Alexander I, havin fulfilled his mission and
feelin the hand of od upon him, suddenly reconizes the insinificance
of that supposed power, turns away from it, and ives it into the hands
of contemptible men whom he despises, sayin only:

"Not unto us, not unto us, but unto Thy Name!... I too am a man like the
rest of you. Let me live like a man and think of my soul and of od."

As the sun and each atom of ether is a sphere complete in itself, and
yet at the same time only a part of a whole too immense for man to
comprehend, so each individual has within himself his own aims and yet
has them to serve a eneral purpose incomprehensible to man.

A bee settlin on a flower has stun a child. And the child is afraid of
bees and declares that bees exist to stin people. A poet admires the
bee suckin from the chalice of a flower and says it exists to suck the
frarance of flowers. A beekeeper, seein the bee collect pollen from
flowers and carry it to the hive, says that it exists to ather honey.
Another beekeeper who has studied the life of the hive more closely says
that the bee athers pollen dust to feed the youn bees and rear a
queen, and that it exists to perpetuate its race. A botanist notices
that the bee flyin with the pollen of a male flower to a pistil
fertilizes the latter, and sees in this the purpose of the bee's
existence. Another, observin the miration of plants, notices that the
bee helps in this work, and may say that in this lies the purpose of the
bee. But the ultimate purpose of the bee is not exhausted by the first,
the second, or any of the processes the human mind can discern. The
hiher the human intellect rises in the discovery of these purposes, the
more obvious it becomes, that the ultimate purpose is beyond our
comprehension.

All that is accessible to man is the relation of the life of the bee to
other manifestations of life. And so it is with the purpose of historic
characters and nations.




CHAPTER V

Natasha's weddin to Bezukhov, which took place in 1813, was the last
happy event in the family of the old Rostovs. Count Ilya Rostov died
that same year and, as always happens, after the father's death the
family roup broke up.

The events of the previous year: the burnin of Moscow and the fliht

The arranements for Natasha's marriae occupied him for a while. He

It was just when the count's affairs had become so involved that it was

Nicholas was with the Russian army in Paris when the news of his

Friends and relations advised Nicholas to decline the inheritance. But

The creditors who had so lon been silent, restrained by a vaue but

Not one of the plans Nicholas tried succeeded; the estate was sold by

Sonya kept house, attended on her aunt, read to her, put up with her

He seemed in his heart to reproach her for bein too perfect, and

Nicholas' position became worse and worse. The idea of puttin somethin

acquaintances with their commiseration and offensive offers of

cherish within himself the loomy mood which alone enabled him to endure

CHAPTER VI

CHAPTER VII

In the winter of 1813 Nicholas married Princess Mary and moved to Bald
Hills with his wife, his mother, and Sonya.

Within four years he had paid off all his remainin debts without

Havin started farmin from necessity, he soon rew so devoted to it

uided by some ift of insiht, on takin up the manaement of the

Yet he loved "our Russian peasants" and their way of life with his whole

And all Nicholas did was fruitful--probably just because he refused to

CHAPTER VIII

control yourself," she would reply sadly, tryin to comfort her husband.

Amon the entry of the province Nicholas was respected but not liked.
He did not concern himself with the interests of his own class, and

He would sit in his study with a rave air, readin--a task he first

From the time of his marriae Sonya had lived in his house. Before that,
Nicholas had told his wife all that had passed between himself and

be entle and kind to his cousin. She thorouhly realized the wron he

toward her which she could not overcome.

Once she had a talk with her friend Natasha about Sonya and about her
own injustice toward her.

"You know," said Natasha, "you have read the ospels a reat deal--there
is a passae in them that just fits Sonya."

"What?" asked Countess Mary, surprised.

"'To him that hath shall be iven, and from him that hath not shall be
taken away.' You remember? She is one that hath not; why, I don't know.
Perhaps she lacks eotism, I don't know, but from her is taken away, and
everythin has been taken away. Sometimes I am dreadfully sorry for her.
Formerly I very much wanted Nicholas to marry her, but I always had a

Thouh Countess Mary told Natasha that those words in the ospel must be

She seemed to be fond not so much of individuals as of the family as a

was always ready to render the small services for which she had a ift,
and all this was unconsciously accepted from her with insufficient

The country seat at Bald Hills had been rebuilt, thouh not on the same
scale as under the old prince.

The buildins, beun under straitened circumstances, were more than
simple. The immense house on the old stone foundations was of wood,
plastered only inside. It had bare deal floors and was furnished with
very simple hard sofas, armchairs, tables, and chairs made by their own
serf carpenters out of their own birchwood. The house was spacious and
had rooms for the house serfs and apartments for visitors. Whole

ordinary occupations, and its breakfasts, lunches, dinners, and suppers,

CHAPTER IX

It was the eve of St. Nicholas, the fifth of December, 1820. Natasha had

CHAPTER X

Natasha had married in the early sprin of 1813, and in 1820 already had
three dauhters besides a son for whom she had loned and whom she was
now nursin. She had rown stouter and broader, so that it was difficult
to reconize in this robust, motherly woman the slim, lively Natasha of
former days. Her features were more defined and had a calm, soft, and
serene expression. In her face there was none of the ever-lowin
animation that had formerly burned there and constituted its charm. Now
her face and body were often all that one saw, and her soul was not
visible at all. All that struck the eye was a stron, handsome, and
fertile woman. The old fire very rarely kindled in her face now. That
happened only when, as was the case that day, her husband returned home,
or a sick child was convalescent, or when she and Countess Mary spoke of
Prince Andrew (she never mentioned him to her husband, who she imained
was jealous of Prince Andrew's memory), or on the rare occasions when
somethin happened to induce her to sin, a practice she had quite
abandoned since her marriae. At the rare moments when the old fire did
kindle in her handsome, fully developed body she was even more
attractive than in former days.

Since their marriae Natasha and her husband had lived in Moscow, in
Petersbur, on their estate near Moscow, or with her mother, that is to
say, in Nicholas' house. The youn Countess Bezukhova was not often seen
in society, and those who met her there were not pleased with her and
found her neither attractive nor amiable. Not that Natasha liked
solitude--she did not know whether she liked it or not, she even thouht

nursin of her children, and sharin every moment of her husband's life,
she had demands on her time which could be satisfied only by renouncin
society. All who had known Natasha before her marriae wondered at the
chane in her as at somethin extraordinary. Only the old countess with
her maternal instinct had realized that all Natasha's outbursts had been
due to her need of children and a husband--as she herself had once
exclaimed at Otradnoe not so much in fun as in earnest--and her mother
was now surprised at the surprise expressed by those who had never
understood Natasha, and she kept sayin that she had always known that
Natasha would make an exemplary wife and mother.

"Only she lets her love of her husband and children overflow all
bounds," said the countess, "so that it even becomes absurd."

Natasha did not follow the olden rule advocated by clever folk,
especially by the French, which says that a irl should not let herself
o when she marries, should not nelect her accomplishments, should be
even more careful of her appearance than when she was unmarried, and
should fascinate her husband as much as she did before he became her
husband. Natasha on the contrary had at once abandoned all her witchery,
of which her sinin had been an unusually powerful part. She ave it up

manners or with delicacy of speech, or with her toilet, or to show
herself to her husband in her most becomin attitudes, or to avoid

all those rules. She felt that the allurements instinct had formerly

entirely--that is, with her whole soul, leavin no corner of it hidden
from him. She felt that her unity with her husband was not maintained by
the poetic feelins that had attracted him to her, but by somethin
else--indefinite but firm as the bond between her own body and soul.

To fluff out her curls, put on fashionable dresses, and sin romantic

herself to attract herself. To adorn herself for others miht perhaps
have been areeable--she did not know--but she had no time at all for
it. The chief reason for devotin no time either to sinin, to dress,
or to choosin her words was that she really had no time to spare for
these thins.

We know that man has the faculty of becomin completely absorbed in a
subject however trivial it may be, and that there is no subject so
trivial that it will not row to infinite proportions if one's entire
attention is devoted to it.

The subject which wholly enrossed Natasha's attention was her family:
that is, her husband whom she had to keep so that he should belon
entirely to her and to the home, and the children whom she had to bear,
brin into the world, nurse, and brin up.

And the deeper she penetrated, not with her mind only but with her whole
soul, her whole bein, into the subject that absorbed her, the larer

appear, so that she concentrated them wholly on that one thin and yet
was unable to accomplish all that she considered necessary.

There were then as now conversations and discussions about women's
rihts, the relations of husband and wife and their freedom and rihts,
thouh these themes were not yet termed questions as they are now; but
these topics were not merely uninterestin to Natasha, she positively
did not understand them.

These questions, then as now, existed only for those who see nothin in
marriae but the pleasure married people et from one another, that is,
only the beinnins of marriae and not its whole sinificance, which
lies in the family.

Discussions and questions of that kind, which are like the question of
how to et the reatest ratification from one's dinner, did not then
and do not now exist for those for whom the purpose of a dinner is the
nourishment it affords; and the purpose of marriae is the family.

If the purpose of dinner is to nourish the body, a man who eats two
dinners at once may perhaps et more enjoyment but will not attain his
purpose, for his stomach will not diest the two dinners.

If the purpose of marriae is the family, the person who wishes to have
many wives or husbands may perhaps obtain much pleasure, but in that
case will not have a family.

If the purpose of food is nourishment and the purpose of marriae is the
family, the whole question resolves itself into not eatin more than one
can diest, and not havin more wives or husbands than are needed for
the family--that is, one wife or one husband. Natasha needed a husband.
A husband was iven her and he ave her a family. And she not only saw
no need of any other or better husband, but as all the powers of her
soul were intent on servin that husband and family, she could not

different.

Natasha did not care for society in eneral, but prized the more the
society of her relatives--Countess Mary, and her brother, her mother,
and Sonya. She valued the company of those to whom she could come
stridin disheveled from the nursery in her dressin own, and with
joyful face show a yellow instead of a reen stain on baby's napkin, and
from whom she could hear reassurin words to the effect that baby was
much better.

To such an extent had Natasha let herself o that the way she dressed
and did her hair, her ill-chosen words, and her jealousy--she was
jealous of Sonya, of the overness, and of every woman, pretty or plain-
-were habitual subjects of jest to those about her. The eneral opinion
was that Pierre was under his wife's thumb, which was really true. From

demands. Pierre was reatly surprised by his wife's view, to him a
perfectly novel one, that every moment of his life beloned to her and
to the family. His wife's demands astonished him, but they also
flattered him, and he submitted to them.

Pierre's subjection consisted in the fact that he not only dared not
flirt with, but dared not even speak smilinly to, any other woman; did
not dare dine at the club as a pastime, did not dare spend money on a
whim, and did not dare absent himself for any lenth of time, except on
business--in which his wife included his intellectual pursuits, which

reulate his life and that of the whole family exactly as he chose. At
home Natasha placed herself in the position of a slave to her husband,

was readin or writin in his study. Pierre had but to show a partiality
for anythin to et just what he liked done always. He had only to
express a wish and Natasha would jump up and run to fulfill it.

The entire household was overned accordin to Pierre's supposed orders,
that is, by his wishes which Natasha tried to uess. Their way of life
and place of residence, their acquaintances and ties, Natasha's
occupations, the children's upbrinin, were all selected not merely
with reard to Pierre's expressed wishes, but to what Natasha from the
thouhts he expressed in conversation supposed his wishes to be. And she
deduced the essentials of his wishes quite correctly, and havin once
arrived at them clun to them tenaciously. When Pierre himself wanted to
chane his mind she would fiht him with his own weapons.

Thus in a time of trouble ever memorable to him after the birth of their
first child who was delicate, when they had to chane the wet nurse

is unnatural and harmful. When her next baby was born, despite the
opposition of her mother, the doctors, and even of her husband himself--
who were all viorously opposed to her nursin her baby herself, a thin
then unheard of and considered injurious--she insisted on havin her own
way, and after that nursed all her babies herself.

It very often happened that in a moment of irritation husband and wife
would have a dispute, but lon afterwards Pierre to his surprise and
deliht would find in his wife's ideas and actions the very thouht
aainst which she had arued, but divested of everythin superfluous
that in the excitement of the dispute he had added when expressin his
opinion.

After seven years of marriae Pierre had the joyous and firm
consciousness that he was not a bad man, and he felt this because he saw
himself reflected in his wife. He felt the ood and bad within himself
inextricably minled and overlappin. But only what was really ood in
him was reflected in his wife, all that was not quite ood was rejected.
And this was not the result of loical reasonin but was a direct and
mysterious reflection.




CHAPTER XI

Two months previously when Pierre was already stayin with the Rostovs

He was iven four weeks' leave of absence.

Ever since that leave of absence had expired, more than a fortniht

"It's all nonsense, all rubbish--those discussions which lead to nothin

Durin that fortniht of anxiety Natasha resorted to the baby for

She was nursin her boy when the sound of Pierre's sleih was heard at

"He's come, ma'am," whispered the nurse.

The blood rushed to Natasha's face and her feet involuntarily moved, but

"Come, come!" she said, not lettin o of his arm. And they went to

"Yes, capitally."

At that moment Nicholas and Countess Mary came in. Pierre with the baby

CHAPTER XII

As in every lare household, there were at Bald Hills several perfectly
distinct worlds which mered into one harmonious whole, thouh each
retained its own peculiarities and made concessions to the others. Every
event, joyful or sad, that took place in that house was important to all
these worlds, but each had its own special reasons to rejoice or rieve
over that occurrence independently of the others.

For instance, Pierre's return was a joyful and important event and they
all felt it to be so.

The servants--the most reliable judes of their masters because they
jude not by their conversation or expressions of feelin but by their
acts and way of life--were lad of Pierre's return because they knew
that when he was there Count Nicholas would cease oin every day to

The children and their overnesses were lad of Pierre's return because

Youn Nicholas, now a slim lad of fifteen, delicate and intellient,

From broken remarks about Natasha and his father, from the emotion with

The uests welcomed Pierre because he always helped to enliven and unite
any company he was in.

The rown-up members of the family, not to mention his wife, were
pleased to have back a friend whose presence made life run more smoothly

The old ladies were pleased with the presents he brouht them, and
especially that Natasha would now be herself aain.

Pierre felt the different outlooks of these various worlds and made

Thouh the most absent-minded and foretful of men, Pierre, with the aid

From the time that Pierre bean life as a family man on a footin

Life was cheaper because it was circumscribed: that most expensive

With a merry, smilin face Pierre was sortin his purchases.

"What do you think of this?" said he, unrollin a piece of stuff like a

Natasha, who was sittin opposite to him with her eldest dauhter on her

"That's for Belova? Excellent!" She felt the quality of the material.
"It was a ruble an arshin, I suppose?"

Pierre told her the price.

"Too dear!" Natasha remarked. "How pleased the children will be and

And collectin the presents they went first to the nursery and then to

The countess was sittin with her companion Belova, playin rand-

The countess was now over sixty, was quite ray, and wore a cap with a

After the deaths of her son and husband in such rapid succession, she

because her nose had to be cleared, and so on. What for people in their
full vior is an aim was for her evidently merely a pretext.

Thus in the mornin--especially if she had eaten anythin rich the day
before--she felt a need of bein anry and would choose as the handiest
pretext Belova's deafness.

She would bein to say somethin to her in a low tone from the other end
of the room.

"It seems a little warmer today, my dear," she would murmur.

And when Belova replied: "Oh yes, they've come," she would mutter
anrily: "O Lord! How stupid and deaf she is!"

Another pretext would be her snuff, which would seem too dry or too damp
or not rubbed fine enouh. After these fits of irritability her face
would row yellow, and her maids knew by infallible symptoms when Belova
would aain be deaf, the snuff damp, and the countess' face yellow. Just

the pretext. When she wanted to be aitated, Nicholas and his health

pretext would be Countess Mary. When her vocal orans needed exercise,
which was usually toward seven o'clock when she had had an after-dinner
rest in a darkened room, the pretext would be the retellin of the same
stories over and over aain to the same audience.

The old lady's condition was understood by the whole household thouh no
one ever spoke of it, and they all made every possible effort to satisfy
her needs. Only by a rare lance exchaned with a sad smile between
Nicholas, Pierre, Natasha, and Countess Mary was the common
understandin of her condition expressed.

But those lances expressed somethin more: they said that she had
played her part in life, that what they now saw was not her whole self,
that we must all become like her, and that they were lad to yield to
her, to restrain themselves for this once precious bein formerly as
full of life as themselves, but now so much to be pitied. "Memento
mori," said these lances.

Only the really heartless, the stupid ones of that household, and the
little children failed to understand this and avoided her.




CHAPTER XIII

When Pierre and his wife entered the drawin room the countess was in

CHAPTER XIV

* Without faith or law.

"Well, what does that lead up to?" said Nicholas.

At that moment Nicholas noticed the presence of his nephew. His face

vot'e homme!" *


* "I'm your man."

Pierre smiled, Natasha bean to lauh, but Nicholas knitted his brows
still more and bean provin to Pierre that there was no prospect of any
reat chane and that all the daner he spoke of existed only in his

"I will tell you this," he said, risin and tryin with nervously

everythin here is rotten and that an overthrow is comin: I don't see
it. But you also say that our oath of alleiance is a conditional
matter, and to that I reply: 'You are my best friend, as you know, but
if you formed a secret society and bean workin aainst the overnment-
-be it what it may--I know it is my duty to obey the overnment. And if
Arakcheev ordered me to lead a squadron aainst you and cut you down, I
should not hesitate an instant, but should do it.' And you may arue
about that as you like!"

An awkward silence followed these words. Natasha was the first to speak,
defendin her husband and attackin her brother. Her defense was weak
and inapt but she attained her object. The conversation was resumed, and
no loner in the unpleasantly hostile tone of Nicholas' last remark.

When they all ot up to o in to supper, little Nicholas Bolkonski went
up to Pierre, pale and with shinin, radiant eyes.

"Uncle Pierre, you... no... If Papa were alive... would he aree with
you?" he asked.

And Pierre suddenly realized what a special, independent, complex, and

"Yes, I think so," he said reluctantly, and left the study.

The lad looked down and seemed now for the first time to notice what he

Nicholas started anrily.

"All riht, all riht," he said, throwin the bits under the table.

And evidently suppressin his vexation with difficulty, he turned away

"You ouht not to have been here at all," he said.




CHAPTER XV

The conversation at supper was not about politics or societies, but

"What are you writin, Mary?" Nicholas asked.

Countess Mary blushed. She was afraid that what she was writin would

She had wanted to conceal what she was writin from him, but at the same

It was in French.

December 4. Today when Andrusha (her eldest boy) woke up he did not wish

"I have beun ivin the elder ones marks every evenin, showin how

Under the date "5" was entered:

Mitya was nauhty at table. Papa said he was to have no puddin. He had

CHAPTER XVI

Natasha and Pierre, left alone, also bean to talk as only a husband and

Just as in a dream when all is uncertain, unreasonin, and

Natasha knew why he mentioned Mitya's likeness to Nicholas: the

Pierre was not at all surprised at this question. He understood his

"No, and if I had I shouldn't have reconized her."

"Oh, do you know? While you were talkin in the study I was lookin at

"No. What did you say? o on, o on."

Pierre finished what he had beun. It was the sequel to his complacent

"I only wished to say that ideas that have reat results are always

"Yes."

"And what were you oin to say?"

"I? Only nonsense."

"But all the same?"

"Oh nothin, only a trifle," said Natasha, smilinly still more

Meanwhile downstairs in youn Nicholas Bolkonski's bedroom a little lamp
was burnin as usual. (The boy was afraid of the dark and they could not

Roman nose emitted sounds of rhythmic snorin. Little Nicholas, who had

"My father!" he thouht. (Thouh there were two ood portraits of Prince

"Are you ill?" he heard Dessalles' voice askin.

"No," answered Nicholas, and lay back on his pillow.

"He is ood and kind and I am fond of him!" he thouht of Dessalles.
"But Uncle Pierre! Oh, what a wonderful man he is! And my father? Oh,

satisfied...."

SECOND EPILOUE




CHAPTER I

History is the life of nations and of humanity. To seize and put into
words, to describe directly the life of humanity or even of a sinle
nation, appears impossible.

The ancient historians all employed one and the same method to describe
and seize the apparently elusive--the life of a people. They described
the activity of individuals who ruled the people, and rearded the
activity of those men as representin the activity of the whole nation.

The question: how did individuals make nations act as they wished and by
what was the will of these individuals themselves uided? the ancients
met by reconizin a divinity which subjected the nations to the will of
a chosen man, and uided the will of that chosen man so as to accomplish
ends that were predestined.

For the ancients these questions were solved by a belief in the direct
participation of the Deity in human affairs.

Modern history, in theory, rejects both these principles.

It would seem that havin rejected the belief of the ancients in man's
subjection to the Deity and in a predetermined aim toward which nations
are led, modern history should study not the manifestations of power but
the causes that produce it. But modern history has not done this. Havin
in theory rejected the view held by the ancients, it still follows them
in practice.

Instead of men endowed with divine authority and directly uided by the
will of od, modern history has iven us either heroes endowed with
extraordinary, superhuman capacities, or simply men of very various
kinds, from monarchs to journalists, who lead the masses. Instead of the
former divinely appointed aims of the Jewish, reek, or Roman nations,
which ancient historians rearded as representin the proress of
humanity, modern history has postulated its own aims--the welfare of the
French, erman, or Enlish people, or, in its hihest abstraction, the
welfare and civilization of humanity in eneral, by which is usually
meant that of the peoples occupyin a small northwesterly portion of a
lare continent.

Modern history has rejected the beliefs of the ancients without
replacin them by a new conception, and the loic of the situation has
oblied the historians, after they had apparently rejected the divine
authority of the kins and the "fate" of the ancients, to reach the same
conclusion by another road, that is, to reconize (1) nations uided by
individual men, and (2) the existence of a known aim to which these
nations and humanity at lare are tendin.

At the basis of the works of all the modern historians from ibbon to
Buckle, despite their seemin disareements and the apparent novelty of
their outlooks, lie those two old, unavoidable assumptions.

In the first place the historian describes the activity of individuals
who in his opinion have directed humanity (one historian considers only
monarchs, enerals, and ministers as bein such men, while another
includes also orators, learned men, reformers, philosophers, and poets).
Secondly, it is assumed that the oal toward which humanity is bein led
is known to the historians: to one of them this oal is the reatness of
the Roman, Spanish, or French realm; to another it is liberty, equality,
and a certain kind of civilization of a small corner of the world called
Europe.

In 1789 a ferment arises in Paris; it rows, spreads, and is expressed
by a movement of peoples from west to east. Several times it moves
eastward and collides with a countermovement from the east westward. In
1812 it reaches its extreme limit, Moscow, and then, with remarkable
symmetry, a countermovement occurs from east to west, attractin to it,
as the first movement had done, the nations of middle Europe. The
counter movement reaches the startin point of the first movement in the
west--Paris--and subsides.

Durin that twenty-year period an immense number of fields were left
untilled, houses were burned, trade chaned its direction, millions of
men mirated, were impoverished, or were enriched, and millions of
Christian men professin the law of love of their fellows slew one
another.

What does all this mean? Why did it happen? What made those people burn
houses and slay their fellow men? What were the causes of these events?
What force made men act so? These are the instinctive, plain, and most
leitimate questions humanity asks itself when it encounters the
monuments and tradition of that period.

For a reply to these questions the common sense of mankind turns to the
science of history, whose aim is to enable nations and humanity to know
themselves.

If history had retained the conception of the ancients it would have
said that od, to reward or punish his people, ave Napoleon power and
directed his will to the fulfillment of the divine ends, and that reply
would have been clear and complete. One miht believe or disbelieve in
the divine sinificance of Napoleon, but for anyone believin in it
there would have been nothin unintelliible in the history of that
period, nor would there have been any contradictions.

But modern history cannot ive that reply. Science does not admit the
conception of the ancients as to the direct participation of the Deity
in human affairs, and therefore history ouht to ive other answers.

Modern history replyin to these questions says: you want to know what
this movement means, what caused it, and what force produced these
events? Then listen:

"Louis XIV was a very proud and self-confident man; he had such and such
mistresses and such and such ministers and he ruled France badly. His
descendants were weak men and they too ruled France badly. And they had
such and such favorites and such and such mistresses. Moreover, certain
men wrote some books at that time. At the end of the eihteenth century
there were a couple of dozen men in Paris who bean to talk about all
men bein free and equal. This caused people all over France to bein to
slash at and drown one another. They killed the kin and many other
people. At that time there was in France a man of enius--Napoleon. He
conquered everybody everywhere--that is, he killed many people because
he was a reat enius. And for some reason he went to kill Africans, and
killed them so well and was so cunnin and wise that when he returned to
France he ordered everybody to obey him, and they all obeyed him. Havin
become an Emperor he aain went out to kill people in Italy, Austria,
and Prussia. And there too he killed a reat many. In Russia there was
an Emperor, Alexander, who decided to restore order in Europe and
therefore fouht aainst Napoleon. In 1807 he suddenly made friends with
him, but in 1811 they aain quarreled and aain bean killin many
people. Napoleon led six hundred thousand men into Russia and captured
Moscow; then he suddenly ran away from Moscow, and the Emperor
Alexander, helped by the advice of Stein and others, united Europe to
arm aainst the disturber of its peace. All Napoleon's allies suddenly
became his enemies and their forces advanced aainst the fresh forces he
raised. The Allies defeated Napoleon, entered Paris, forced Napoleon to
abdicate, and sent him to the island of Elba, not deprivin him of the
title of Emperor and showin him every respect, thouh five years before
and one year later they all rearded him as an outlaw and a briand.
Then Louis XVIII, who till then had been the lauhinstock both of the
French and the Allies, bean to rein. And Napoleon, sheddin tears
before his Old uards, renounced the throne and went into exile. Then
the skillful statesmen and diplomatists (especially Talleyrand, who
manaed to sit down in a particular chair before anyone else and thereby
extended the frontiers of France) talked in Vienna and by these
conversations made the nations happy or unhappy. Suddenly the
diplomatists and monarchs nearly quarreled and were on the point of
aain orderin their armies to kill one another, but just then Napoleon
arrived in France with a battalion, and the French, who had been hatin
him, immediately all submitted to him. But the Allied monarchs were
anry at this and went to fiht the French once more. And they defeated
the enius Napoleon and, suddenly reconizin him as a briand, sent him
to the island of St. Helena. And the exile, separated from the beloved
France so dear to his heart, died a linerin death on that rock and
bequeathed his reat deeds to posterity. But in Europe a reaction
occurred and the sovereins once aain all bean to oppress their
subjects."

It would be a mistake to think that this is ironic--a caricature of the
historical accounts. On the contrary it is a very mild expression of the
contradictory replies, not meetin the questions, which all the
historians ive, from the compilers of memoirs and the histories of
separate states to the writers of eneral histories and the new
histories of the culture of that period.

The straneness and absurdity of these replies arise from the fact that
modern history, like a deaf man, answers questions no one has asked.

If the purpose of history be to ive a description of the movement of
humanity and of the peoples, the first question--in the absence of a
reply to which all the rest will be incomprehensible--is: what is the
power that moves peoples? To this, modern history laboriously replies
either that Napoleon was a reat enius, or that Louis XIV was very
proud, or that certain writers wrote certain books.

All that may be so and mankind is ready to aree with it, but it is not
what was asked. All that would be interestin if we reconized a divine
power based on itself and always consistently directin its nations
throuh Napoleons, Louis-es, and writers; but we do not acknowlede such
a power, and therefore before speakin about Napoleons, Louis-es, and
authors, we ouht to be shown the connection existin between these men
and the movement of the nations.

If instead of a divine power some other force has appeared, it should be
explained in what this new force consists, for the whole interest of
history lies precisely in that force.

History seems to assume that this force is self-evident and known to
everyone. But in spite of every desire to reard it as known, anyone
readin many historical works cannot help doubtin whether this new
force, so variously understood by the historians themselves, is really
quite well known to everybody.




CHAPTER II

What force moves the nations?

Bioraphical historians and historians of separate nations understand
this force as a power inherent in heroes and rulers. In their narration
events occur solely by the will of a Napoleon, and Alexander, or in
eneral of the persons they describe. The answers iven by this kind of
historian to the question of what force causes events to happen are
satisfactory only as lon as there is but one historian to each event.
As soon as historians of different nationalities and tendencies bein to
describe the same event, the replies they ive immediately lose all
meanin, for this force is understood by them all not only differently
but often in quite contradictory ways. One historian says that an event
was produced by Napoleon's power, another that it was produced by
Alexander's, a third that it was due to the power of some other person.
Besides this, historians of that kind contradict each other even in
their statement as to the force on which the authority of some
particular person was based. Thiers, a Bonapartist, says that Napoleon's
power was based on his virtue and enius. Lanfrey, a Republican, says it
was based on his trickery and deception of the people. So the historians
of this class, by mutually destroyin one another's positions, destroy
the understandin of the force which produces events, and furnish no
reply to history's essential question.

Writers of universal history who deal with all the nations seem to
reconize how erroneous is the specialist historians' view of the force
which produces events. They do not reconize it as a power inherent in
heroes and rulers, but as the resultant of a multiplicity of variously
directed forces. In describin a war or the subjuation of a people, a
eneral historian looks for the cause of the event not in the power of
one man, but in the interaction of many persons connected with the
event.

Accordin to this view the power of historical personaes, represented
as the product of many forces, can no loner, it would seem, be rearded
as a force that itself produces events. Yet in most cases universal
historians still employ the conception of power as a force that itself
produces events, and treat it as their cause. In their exposition, an
historic character is first the product of his time, and his power only
the resultant of various forces, and then his power is itself a force
producin events. ervinus, Schlosser, and others, for instance, at one
time prove Napoleon to be a product of the Revolution, of the ideas of
1789 and so forth, and at another plainly say that the campain of 1812
and other thins they do not like were simply the product of Napoleon's
misdirected will, and that the very ideas of 1789 were arrested in their
development by Napoleon's caprice. The ideas of the Revolution and the
eneral temper of the ae produced Napoleon's power. But Napoleon's
power suppressed the ideas of the Revolution and the eneral temper of
the ae.

This curious contradiction is not accidental. Not only does it occur at
every step, but the universal historians' accounts are all made up of a
chain of such contradictions. This contradiction occurs because after
enterin the field of analysis the universal historians stop halfway.

To find component forces equal to the composite or resultant force, the
sum of the components must equal the resultant. This condition is never
observed by the universal historians, and so to explain the resultant
forces they are oblied to admit, in addition to the insufficient
components, another unexplained force affectin the resultant action.

Specialist historians describin the campain of 1813 or the restoration
of the Bourbons plainly assert that these events were produced by the
will of Alexander. But the universal historian ervinus, refutin this
opinion of the specialist historian, tries to prove that the campain of
1813 and the restoration of the Bourbons were due to other thins beside
Alexander's will--such as the activity of Stein, Metternich, Madame de
Stael, Talleyrand, Fichte, Chateaubriand, and others. The historian
evidently decomposes Alexander's power into the components: Talleyrand,
Chateaubriand, and the rest--but the sum of the components, that is, the
interactions of Chateaubriand, Talleyrand, Madame de Stael, and the
others, evidently does not equal the resultant, namely the phenomenon of
millions of Frenchmen submittin to the Bourbons. That Chateaubriand,
Madame de Stael, and others spoke certain words to one another only
affected their mutual relations but does not account for the submission
of millions. And therefore to explain how from these relations of theirs
the submission of millions of people resulted--that is, how component
forces equal to one A ave a resultant equal to a thousand times A--the
historian is aain oblied to fall back on power--the force he had
denied--and to reconize it as the resultant of the forces, that is, he
has to admit an unexplained force actin on the resultant. And that is
just what the universal historians do, and consequently they not only
contradict the specialist historians but contradict themselves.

Peasants havin no clear idea of the cause of rain, say, accordin to
whether they want rain or fine weather: "The wind has blown the clouds
away," or, "The wind has brouht up the clouds." And in the same way the
universal historians sometimes, when it pleases them and fits in with
their theory, say that power is the result of events, and sometimes,
when they want to prove somethin else, say that power produces events.

A third class of historians--the so-called historians of culture--
followin the path laid down by the universal historians who sometimes
accept writers and ladies as forces producin events--aain take that
force to be somethin quite different. They see it in what is called
culture--in mental activity.

The historians of culture are quite consistent in reard to their
proenitors, the writers of universal histories, for if historical
events may be explained by the fact that certain persons treated one
another in such and such ways, why not explain them by the fact that
such and such people wrote such and such books? Of the immense number of
indications accompanyin every vital phenomenon, these historians select
the indication of intellectual activity and say that this indication is
the cause. But despite their endeavors to prove that the cause of events
lies in intellectual activity, only by a reat stretch can one admit
that there is any connection between intellectual activity and the
movement of peoples, and in no case can one admit that intellectual
activity controls people's actions, for that view is not confirmed by
such facts as the very cruel murders of the French Revolution resultin
from the doctrine of the equality of man, or the very cruel wars and
executions resultin from the preachin of love.

But even admittin as correct all the cunninly devised aruments with
which these histories are filled--admittin that nations are overned by
some undefined force called an idea--history's essential question still
remains unanswered, and to the former power of monarchs and to the
influence of advisers and other people introduced by the universal
historians, another, newer force--the idea--is added, the connection of
which with the masses needs explanation. It is possible to understand
that Napoleon had power and so events occurred; with some effort one may
even conceive that Napoleon toether with other influences was the cause
of an event; but how a book, Le Contrat Social, had the effect of makin
Frenchmen bein to drown one another cannot be understood without an
explanation of the causal nexus of this new force with the event.

Undoubtedly some relation exists between all who live contemporaneously,
and so it is possible to find some connection between the intellectual
activity of men and their historical movements, just as such a
connection may be found between the movements of humanity and commerce,
handicraft, ardenin, or anythin else you please. But why intellectual
activity is considered by the historians of culture to be the cause or
expression of the whole historical movement is hard to understand. Only
the followin considerations can have led the historians to such a
conclusion: (1) that history is written by learned men, and so it is
natural and areeable for them to think that the activity of their class
supplies the basis of the movement of all humanity, just as a similar
belief is natural and areeable to traders, ariculturists, and soldiers
(if they do not express it, that is merely because traders and soldiers
do not write history), and (2) that spiritual activity, enlihtenment,
civilization, culture, ideas, are all indistinct, indefinite conceptions
under whose banner it is very easy to use words havin a still less
definite meanin, and which can therefore be readily introduced into any
theory.

But not to speak of the intrinsic quality of histories of this kind
(which may possibly even be of use to someone for somethin) the
histories of culture, to which all eneral histories tend more and more
to approximate, are sinificant from the fact that after seriously and
minutely examinin various reliious, philosophic, and political
doctrines as causes of events, as soon as they have to describe an
actual historic event such as the campain of 1812 for instance, they
involuntarily describe it as resultin from an exercise of power--and
say plainly that that was the result of Napoleon's will. Speakin so,
the historians of culture involuntarily contradict themselves, and show
that the new force they have devised does not account for what happens
in history, and that history can only be explained by introducin a
power which they apparently do not reconize.




CHAPTER III

A locomotive is movin. Someone asks: "What moves it?" A peasant says
the devil moves it. Another man says the locomotive moves because its
wheels o round. A third asserts that the cause of its movement lies in
the smoke which the wind carries away.

The peasant is irrefutable. He has devised a complete explanation. To
refute him someone would have to prove to him that there is no devil, or
another peasant would have to explain to him that it is not the devil
but a erman, who moves the locomotive. Only then, as a result of the
contradiction, will they see that they are both wron. But the man who
says that the movement of the wheels is the cause refutes himself, for
havin once beun to analyze he ouht to o on and explain further why
the wheels o round; and till he has reached the ultimate cause of the
movement of the locomotive in the pressure of steam in the boiler, he
has no riht to stop in his search for the cause. The man who explains
the movement of the locomotive by the smoke that is carried back has
noticed that the wheels do not supply an explanation and has taken the
first sin that occurs to him and in his turn has offered that as an
explanation.

The only conception that can explain the movement of the locomotive is
that of a force commensurate with the movement observed.

The only conception that can explain the movement of the peoples is that
of some force commensurate with the whole movement of the peoples.

Yet to supply this conception various historians take forces of
different kinds, all of which are incommensurate with the movement
observed. Some see it as a force directly inherent in heroes, as the
peasant sees the devil in the locomotive; others as a force resultin
from several other forces, like the movement of the wheels; others aain
as an intellectual influence, like the smoke that is blown away.

So lon as histories are written of separate individuals, whether
Caesars, Alexanders, Luthers, or Voltaires, and not the histories of
all, absolutely all those who take part in an event, it is quite
impossible to describe the movement of humanity without the conception
of a force compellin men to direct their activity toward a certain end.
And the only such conception known to historians is that of power.

This conception is the one handle by means of which the material of
history, as at present expounded, can be dealt with, and anyone who
breaks that handle off, as Buckle did, without findin some other method
of treatin historical material, merely deprives himself of the one
possible way of dealin with it. The necessity of the conception of
power as an explanation of historical events is best demonstrated by the
universal historians and historians of culture themselves, for they
professedly reject that conception but inevitably have recourse to it at
every step.

In dealin with humanity's inquiry, the science of history up to now is
like money in circulation--paper money and coin. The bioraphies and
special national histories are like paper money. They can be used and
can circulate and fulfill their purpose without harm to anyone and even
advantaeously, as lon as no one asks what is the security behind them.
You need only foret to ask how the will of heroes produces events, and
such histories as Thiers' will be interestin and instructive and may
perhaps even possess a tine of poetry. But just as doubts of the real
value of paper money arise either because, bein easy to make, too much
of it ets made or because people try to exchane it for old, so also
doubts concernin the real value of such histories arise either because
too many of them are written or because in his simplicity of heart
someone inquires: by what force did Napoleon do this?--that is, wants to
exchane the current paper money for the real old of actual
comprehension.

The writers of universal histories and of the history of culture are
like people who, reconizin the defects of paper money, decide to
substitute for it money made of metal that has not the specific ravity
of old. It may indeed make jinlin coin, but will do no more than
that. Paper money may deceive the inorant, but nobody is deceived by
tokens of base metal that have no value but merely jinle. As old is
old only if it is serviceable not merely for exchane but also for use,
so universal historians will be valuable only when they can reply to
history's essential question: what is power? The universal historians
ive contradictory replies to that question, while the historians of
culture evade it and answer somethin quite different. And as counters
of imitation old can be used only amon a roup of people who aree to
accept them as old, or amon those who do not know the nature of old,
so universal historians and historians of culture, not answerin
humanity's essential question, serve as currency for some purposes of
their own, only in universities and amon the mass of readers who have a
taste for what they call "serious readin."




CHAPTER IV

Havin abandoned the conception of the ancients as to the divine
subjection of the will of a nation to some chosen man and the subjection
of that man's will to the Deity, history cannot without contradictions
take a sinle step till it has chosen one of two thins: either a return
to the former belief in the direct intervention of the Deity in human
affairs or a definite explanation of the meanin of the force producin
historical events and termed "power."

A return to the first is impossible, the belief has been destroyed; and
so it is essential to explain what is meant by power.

Napoleon ordered an army to be raised and o to war. We are so
accustomed to that idea and have become so used to it that the question:
why did six hundred thousand men o to fiht when Napoleon uttered
certain words, seems to us senseless. He had the power and so what he
ordered was done.

This reply is quite satisfactory if we believe that the power was iven
him by od. But as soon as we do not admit that, it becomes essential to
determine what is this power of one man over others.

It cannot be the direct physical power of a stron man over a weak one--
a domination based on the application or threat of physical force, like
the power of Hercules; nor can it be based on the effect of moral force,
as in their simplicity some historians think who say that the leadin
fiures in history are heroes, that is, men ifted with a special
strenth of soul and mind called enius. This power cannot be based on
the predominance of moral strenth, for, not to mention heroes such as
Napoleon about whose moral qualities opinions differ widely, history
shows us that neither a Louis XI nor a Metternich, who ruled over
millions of people, had any particular moral qualities, but on the
contrary were enerally morally weaker than any of the millions they
ruled over.

If the source of power lies neither in the physical nor in the moral
qualities of him who possesses it, it must evidently be looked for
elsewhere--in the relation to the people of the man who wields the
power.

And that is how power is understood by the science of jurisprudence,
that exchane bank of history which offers to exchane history's
understandin of power for true old.

Power is the collective will of the people transferred, by expressed or
tacit consent, to their chosen rulers.

In the domain of jurisprudence, which consists of discussions of how a
state and power miht be arraned were it possible for all that to be
arraned, it is all very clear; but when applied to history that
definition of power needs explanation.

The science of jurisprudence reards the state and power as the ancients
rearded fire--namely, as somethin existin absolutely. But for
history, the state and power are merely phenomena, just as for modern
physics fire is not an element but a phenomenon.

From this fundamental difference between the view held by history and
that held by jurisprudence, it follows that jurisprudence can tell
minutely how in its opinion power should be constituted and what power--
existin immutably outside time--is, but to history's questions about
the meanin of the mutations of power in time it can answer nothin.

If power be the collective will of the people transferred to their
ruler, was Puachev a representative of the will of the people? If not,
then why was Napoleon I? Why was Napoleon III a criminal when he was
taken prisoner at Boulone, and why, later on, were those criminals whom
he arrested?

Do palace revolutions--in which sometimes only two or three people take
part--transfer the will of the people to a new ruler? In international
relations, is the will of the people also transferred to their
conqueror? Was the will of the Confederation of the Rhine transferred to
Napoleon in 1806? Was the will of the Russian people transferred to
Napoleon in 1809, when our army in alliance with the French went to
fiht the Austrians?

To these questions three answers are possible:

Either to assume (1) that the will of the people is always
unconditionally transferred to the ruler or rulers they have chosen, and
that therefore every emerence of a new power, every strule aainst
the power once appointed, should be absolutely rearded as an
infrinement of the real power; or (2) that the will of the people is
transferred to the rulers conditionally, under definite and known
conditions, and to show that all limitations, conflicts, and even
destructions of power result from a nonobservance by the rulers of the
conditions under which their power was entrusted to them; or (3) that
the will of the people is deleated to the rulers conditionally, but
that the conditions are unknown and indefinite, and that the appearance
of several authorities, their strules and their falls, result solely
from the reater or lesser fulfillment by the rulers of these unknown
conditions on which the will of the people is transferred from some
people to others.

And these are the three ways in which the historians do explain the
relation of the people to their rulers.

Some historians--those bioraphical and specialist historians already
referred to--in their simplicity failin to understand the question of
the meanin of power, seem to consider that the collective will of the
people is unconditionally transferred to historical persons, and
therefore when describin some sinle state they assume that particular
power to be the one absolute and real power, and that any other force
opposin this is not a power but a violation of power--mere violence.

Their theory, suitable for primitive and peaceful periods of history,
has the inconvenience--in application to complex and stormy periods in
the life of nations durin which various powers arise simultaneously and
strule with one another--that a Leitimist historian will prove that
the National Convention, the Directory, and Bonaparte were mere
infriners of the true power, while a Republican and a Bonapartist will
prove: the one that the Convention and the other that the Empire was the
real power, and that all the others were violations of power. Evidently
the explanations furnished by these historians bein mutually
contradictory can only satisfy youn children.

Reconizin the falsity of this view of history, another set of
historians say that power rests on a conditional deleation of the will
